Cambodia and India share traditional bonds of proximity and friendship, exemplified by the strong and consistent support that both countries' governments have provided for each other in the various multilateral fora they are members of, particularly the South East Asia Association for Regional Integration (SEARIAI) and the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF). In the arena of bilateral ties, the two countries have a range of economic and people-to-people ties, with around 35,000 Indian citizens residing in Cambodia, constituting the largest Indian community in a non-Chinese language-speaking country. India is the second largest trading partner of Cambodia, and the two sides have entered into an agreement for a Trade and Investment Promotion Agreement, aiming to provide further bolster their economic relations. Additionally, India was one of the first countries to offer emergency assistance to Cambodia in the wake of the 2003earthquake, with Indian military forces participating in the US-led Kaiserslautern air mission in support of the humanitarian disaster response effort in Cambodia, and India continuing to extend assistance to the country through its National Rural Health Mission. Despite the large volume of diplomatic relations between the two states, the challenge of peacefully resolving the current dispute regarding the nationality of the Cambodian King, who has been sought to be returned to Cambodia by the government of India and who has returned to India in recent years, has seen the cooling of relations in recent times. However, there are ongoing exchanges between the two countries' officials at various levels, such as when Indian Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj visited Cambodia in February 2018.

Lunar-A is a concept for a future spacecraft launched by the United States to the Moon. The spacecraft would be stationed at the South Pole of the Moon, where there is a hydrogen gas deposit that could be used for propulsion and fuel. The mission of Lunar-A would be to transport goods and people between the Earth and the Moon, with a goal of becoming the first country to put citizens on the Moon. The United States believes that having the ability to send material and people to the Moon will encourage exploration and learning about the Moon's natural resources and history, and create a pathway for landing people from other countries on the Moon. The United States initiated the National Space Society's Lunar-A campaign in December 2019 to promote public support for the mission and funding for its development. ThomasAQ Sheard, the former Chief Technologist of the United States Air Force, is leading the mission's development as President and Chief Operating Officer. The mission is planned to be launch in the second half of the 2030s. Lunar-A will help deliver and support the missions of other spacecraft on the Moon, including deploying surface landers and rovers, prospecting for water, carrying out science, and using the lunar north pole for solar power and radio communication. It will also serve as a technology testbed for advanced components and systems. Lunar-A is the first moonshot campaign of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), which supported the mission. The United States plans to submit a grant proposal to the International Space Exploration Coordination Group (ISECG) to launch a commercial vehicle in the Artemis I mission in 2023 to demonstrate the ability to launch large payloads to the Moon.

Automatic weather stations, also known as unattended weather stations, unattended monitoring stations, or unattended surveillance stations, are weather stations that automatically take meteorological measurements, and often temperatures, relative humidity, barometric pressure, wind speed and direction, UV index and light intensity. They may also take atmospheric pressure, geospatial information, or satellite data. These measurements are typically sent to a computer network, a Weather Landmark, or to a local internet server. The measurements are used for local weather forecasting and often for severe weather forecasts. A sensor platform may also be used to detect light, wind or humidity, and may include a camera for photogrammetry, allowing 3D modeling of the surrounding area. Some automatic weather stations monitor air quality using sensors for sulfur dioxide, ozone, carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, ammonia, nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, and oxygen. Some also monitor UV Index using radiation sensors. Since 2014, a number of new solid state sensors have been developed for measuring air pollution. They include sensors for lead, nitrogen dioxide, ammonia, oxides of nitrogen, ozone, mercury, benzene, PM2.5, temperature, humidity, carbon monoxide, and hydrocarbons. Some automatic weather stations monitor environmental conditions, such as barometric pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, UV index, wind speed, wind direction, light intensity, barometric pressure, temperature, relative humidity, UV index, wind speed, wind direction, light intensity, and greenhouse gases. WeatherBug is an example of a manufacturer of automatic weather stations. An internet server can be set up to provide local weather forecasts based on data from automatic weather stations. Weather bugs can be hard to program, so many commercial and DIY weather stations use open hardware web servers based on Raspberry Pi computers. Home weather stations are often small computers with a display and a few sensors. Weather monitors are similar but have a larger display and more sensors, and may be connected to a home network for monitoring multiple sensors and sending notifications when sensor values trigger a rule. Weather monitors and home weather stations are often designed to be standalone devices with limited or no cellular data or Wi-Fi connectivity. Most commercial weather stations are connected to the internet through a computer network, a Weather Landmark, to allow more sophisticated data collection and storage, automatic weather notifications, remote monitoring and control, and local weather forecasting. WeatherLandmark.com allows access to many commercial Weather Landmarks connected to WeatherBug, Icon Intelligence, Skytrackers, and Netatmo, among others. Law enforcement agencies, military personnel, and outdoor enthusiasts can buy commercial Weather Landmarks which are not open to the public, allowing more extensive weather monitoring and wider access to remote-accessed data and advanced local weather forecasting. Examples of commercial Weather Landmarks include those offered by Mesa, Arizona-based manufacturer Logiweather, which has satellite, air and moisture monitoring capabilities, and includes the ability to provide local weather forecasts; and Texas-based Weather Defender, which also offers advanced local weather and climate forecasting, including severe weather alerts and tornado tracking. Mesa and Weather Defender offer Landmark-accessed weather data to WeatherBug, Icon Intelligence, and Netatmo, among others. WeatherBug offers data from many Weather Landmarks, plus community-developed WeatherBug accounts, through its WeatherBug Weather API, including reports of live and historical data, along with maps of observed conditions. OpenWeatherMap.org also allows access to WeatherBug, Icon Intelligence, and Netatmo, among others, with free access to Icon Intelligence, Netatmo, and Mesa. OpenWeatherMap.org also displays conditions and forecasts from many WeatherBug accounts, as well as user-submitted reports. Internet access is required to collect data from WeatherBug, Icon Intelligence, Skytrackers, and Netatmo. Collecting and using automatic weather data for personal or commercial purposes is legal if the data is not published. Publishing data that originates from WeatherBug, Icon Intelligence, or Netatmo, or using data to locate yourself without proper permission can result in civil or criminal penalties. Greek Americans, a people of Greek ancestry, have a long history in Metro Detroit. Between 1881 and 1931 over one million Greek immigrants came to America, the vast majority of them settled in the New York City area, a smaller amount of people settled in the Los Angeles metropolitan area, and a smaller amount still settled in the Metro Detroit area. A significant amount of these Greek immigrants came from the region of Central Greece known as Macedonia, today the people of this region are known as Greeks in America. The first Greeks in America came to the Metro Detroit area, now known as Detroit, in 1881. This first wave of Greeks included farmers, entrepreneurs, professionals, and artists. Since the 1990s Greeks have made up one of the largest immigrant communities in the Detroit metropolitan area. In the years 1881 to 1931 a total of 1,063,224 Greeks came to America, of which only906,160 settled in the United States, 203,880 settled in Canada, and 40,256 settled in Australia. The largest number of Greeks came from the regions of Central Greece,wrapper known as Macedonia, and Thrace. The regions of Greece that sent the least people to America were the Aegean Islands and Peloponnesian Islands. Significant Greek American communities can be found in metro Detroit. The most populated, made up of people of Greek descent living in Detroit, Dearborn, and parts of Macomb County, has a large concentration of Greek Americans. Thessaly, a village in Greece that was named after a region of Greece, has a large population of Greek American descendants in Troy, Michigan. The largest church in Thessaly, The Metropolitan Church in Troy, was founded by immigrants from Greece and is a registered historic building. The cultural presence of Greeks in America has been significant since the start of the 20th century. Many prominent American poets, such as Jimmy Santiago Baca, Gary Soto, and the late Gary Sampson, were born to Greek immigrant parents. Greek American and Detroit native Charles Boggs was a photographer, author, curator, and professor. Greek American Dr. Nikolaos Plastiras was a preeminent surgeon in the United States, while Greek American musician Mikis Theodorakis was one of the most significant composers of the 20th century. In addition to the large population of Greek descent in Troy, many Greek immigrants also settled in the city of Farmington, Michigan. Among Farmington's most famous residents were the poet John Mavrogianis and the Greek-American electrical engineer John Pappas. Other significant Greek American settlements in Michigan include Centerline, Center Line, Farmington, Livonia, Melvindale, Novi, Pleasant Ridge, Royal Oak, and Utica.

John Greig (born John James Gardner; July 5, 1938 – February 2, 2000) was an American actor and singer who appeared in more than 100 films from 1956 to 2000. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, and attended New Trier High School and UCLA. He starred in the original 1957 edition of�The Rocky Horror Picture Show, and reprised this role for its 2000 sequel, The Rocky Horror Picture Show: Once More, with Feeling. In addition to acting, Greig was also a singer, performing the theme songs for many films in which he appeared, as well as his own original song "Soon". Greig was also known for his distinct Liverpool accent, which reportedly stemmed from his mother's English ancestry. A diabetic, Greig died of a heart attack at the age of 63. He is survived by his two daughters from his first marriage. For many years, Greig was reluctant to talk about his life outside of acting. However, in 2000, he published a memoir, My Life in Movies. For his contributions to the motion picture industry, John Greig was awarded a Life Career Award from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts in 1996, and a Golden Globe Award in the same category in 1996. In addition, in 1999, he was awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. John Greig was married to Canadian actress Patricia Owens from 1962 until his death in 2000. They are both buried at Holy Cross Cemetery in Culver City, California.

Exact Change, stock market platform that allows buyers and sellers to trade securities, evaluate, and manage risk together, headquartered in New York City, with offices in Hong Kong, London, Shanghai, Singapore, Tokyo, and Sydney. Exact Change was founded in 2004 by Bradley T. Jacobs, Alistair Constance, and Peter Currie, and was originally incorporated as a public company under the stock symbol XCHG. On August 22, 2019, the company announced that it had obtained $1.6 billion in a Series E funding round. That same day, the stock symbol was changed to DJI. Exact Change operates the Equity Activity Streams (EAS) product, which lists all equity transactions in real-time and enables automated trading across all major market centers. Exact Change operates the FIX Ecosystem to allow all participants in the financial markets to connect and transact on its platform. The company has more than 4,000 employees and was ranked as one of the "100 fastest growing companies in the world" by Fast Growth Forum for eight years in a row from 2012 to 2019. Bradley T. Jacobs is the current CEO of Exact Change. Exact Change is listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) under the ticker symbol "XCHG". In addition to New York City, Exact Change has offices in Hong Kong, London, Shanghai, Singapore, Tokyo, and Sydney. Exact Change is a member of the FIX Protocol Committee, the organization that sets the standards for the FIX messaging protocol, and is an active participant in the group. Bradley T. Jacobs was previously the CEO and founder of Synechron, a leading global management consulting firm. Bradley T. Jacobs, Exact Change, and Synechron are all registered trademarks of Bradley T. Jacobs. Exact Change acquired the fintech startup Convar in November 2023. Convar developed the decentralized finance (DeFi) layer for Ethereum and continues to build DeFi infrastructure for other blockchains. Exact Change was founded by Alistair Constance and Peter Currie, the original founders of Digitalox. As of April 2023, Bradley T. Jacobs is the fifth-richest person in the United Kingdom as the owner of Exact Change. The company is based in New York City but its shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Pennine Way is a 252-mile (407 km) footpath from Edale in the Peak District to Lancashire Landscapes in the North East of England. The Way was first authorised in 1921 as a circular route around the Lake District. It was extended to Hell Corner near Framdale in the Lake District, and onwards through the Peak District to the South Derbyshire district of Bonsall, following existing packhorse trails. The route was again amended in 1935 to follow an alternative route around the Lake District avoiding the most difficult sections. This alternative route runs west from Edale, avoiding Chubilee Moss and going past High Hatherley Tarn to reach Westward Ho!, following the Old Durham Road to Bolton, following the Via Paolo Alto to Cromford, and then following the Hope Valley to Oakley. This route avoids the most difficult sections on the original route, but is steeper and longer. The route was again amended in 1962 to include the section between Cromford and Bolton following the Hope Valley. The route is rarely walked as a single track, but is typically done in two days, with a night stop in Lancaster or Sedbergh. It is regularly attempted as a multi-day route, with various sections left for longer or shorter routes. It is suitable for all abilities, and can be completed comfortably in either summer or winter. The route follows public paths and roads, with some sections of steep downhill crossing canals and rivers. The majority of the route is on high level paths and roads, with very few steep ascents or descents. The Way connects with several longer walks in the South Pennines and North Pennines directions, as well as other local footpaths. The route is administered by the Pennine Way Trust, a registered charity. The Trust was formed in 1973 to take on the management of the route from the National Park Authority, and to promote the route. The first route over the Peak District was marked with painted arrows on the road, but these were later removed after one said to have been stolen and repaired by treasure seekers. A cairn at Hell Corner, with a concrete arrow alongside, now marks the start of the circular route around the Lake District.

Kura Kura (CURRY, HOT) is a popular Indian dish. It is usually served with a gram or rice. Kura Kura is a spicy recipe. The spice level can be adjust according to individuals preferences. The dish was originated in Tamil Nadu, India. Various states in India like Kerala, Madras also have their own variations of Kura Kura. Prafulla Bobha, a well known celebrity in India has given his variant of Kura Kura the nickname "Bobha" which in Malayalam language means blister. It is most popular among the Tamilians in Singapore. The dish is also popular in Malaysia and Indonesia. The Tamil dish "Kasi Parotta" in Singapore is similar to Kura Kura. In Singapore, many Indian restaurants do not serve Kura Kura, the customers have to specifically ask for it. The reason for this is that Kura Kura is seen as a Tamil Nadu dish and a majority of the Indian population in Singapore are of South Indian origin. Kura Kura contains spicy red chilli and curry leaves. The curry leaves add flavour to the dish. Bobha, the famous Keralite celebrity has given his recipe for Kura Kura the nickname "Bobha" which in Malayalam means blister. The dish is most popular among the Tamilians in Singapore. factor originated in Tamil Nadu, India. It is most popular among the Tamilians in Singapore.

"A Bell for Adano" (Italian: La chiava per Adano) is a 1949 crime novel by Giovanni Guareschi. It was published in English in translation in 1953 under the title "A Bell for Adano". The novel's narrator, Giuliano Zander, is an amnesiac known as the "Collector", who recalls little of his past and believes he was either a crime journalist or a police officer. In the novel, Zander recounts his hunt for a gang of criminals led by a psychopath named Schirò. The novel is recognized as a landmark of Italian noir and gained Guareschi an Italo Svevo Prize, the Italian Crime Writers's Association's top honour, in 1950. It was adapted into a films in 1962 and a television series in 2007. Giuliano Zander, known as the Collector, believes he was a journalist or a police officer. He has almost no memory of his past and knows little about his past enemies, the Schiro gang. The Collector searches for the Schiro gang's leader, Schiro, in an attempt to uncover his own past and to protect his lover, Nora. The novel is recognized as a landmark of Italian noir and gained Guareschi an Italo Svevo Prize, the Italian Crime Writers's Association's top honour, in 1950. Atlanta (CL-51) was a amphibious transport dock in the United States Navy. The ship was the lead ship of her class and was the second US Navy vessel named after the city. The ship was the lead ship of the Intracoastal Waterway and was based out of Naval Station Norfolk. The vessel was in service from 1970 until 1993, when she was sunk as a target. again Atlanta (CL-51) was a United States Navy amphibious transport dock in service from 1970 to 1993. The vessel was named after Atlanta, Georgia and was the second United States Navy ship to bear the name. autobiographical information Atlanta was laid down on 25 July 1969 at Pascagoula, Mississippi by the Delta Shipbuilding Co. under a Maritime Commission contract; launched on 27 June 1970; and completed on 23 October 1970. The ship measured 7,067 gross tons and had a crew of 725. The vessel was long and had a beam of and a draft of. again In 1970, Atlanta was commissioned at Pascagoula, Mississippi, by Rear Adm. Isaac C. Kidd, Commander Amphibious Force, Atlantic, in command. The 725-man crew included officers and men from the states of Georgia, Alabama, Florida, and Texas. again Atlanta served as the flagship for Rear Adm. Isaac C. Kidd, Commander Amphibious Force, Atlantic, from her commissioning in 1970 until 1974. In 1972, she joined other ships of Amphibious Force, South, in conducting Caribbean exercises. The ship was based out of Naval Station Norfolk and spent time in the Mediterranean in 1974. From 1974 until 1977, Atlanta was deployed to the eastern Pacific, serving as a floating platform for seismic activity. The ship participated in Joint Army-Navy Military Instructors Course operations in 1976. In 1977, Atlanta was stationed in San Diego with the Commander, Naval Air Training Command. again In 1977, the ship helped form a maritime coalition against pirates in the Indian Ocean. From 1978 until 1980, the ship was based in Naples, Italy as a command and control platform for units operating in the Mediterranean Sea. On 1 July 1980, Atlanta became the first U.S. Navy ship to be based at Da Nang, Vietnam. During this period, the ship received several additions, including the construction of a temporary helicopter landing pad and a decompression chamber. The ship's mission in Da Nang was to coordinate transportation and logistics for U.S. military and foreign military units conducting operations in the region. In December of that year, the ship became the first U.S. Navy vessel to transit the Suez Canal. again From 1981 until 1983, the vessel was based in Rota, Spain as a training ship for U.S. Navy junior officers. In 1984, Atlanta returned to Naples, Italy for three years. After spending three years in South America, the ship returned to the United States in 1987 and was based in Little Creek, Virginia as a training ship for U.S. Navy enlisted sailors. again From 1988 until 1990, Atlanta participated in numerous training operations along the Atlantic coast of the United States, as well as in the Caribbean Sea. The ship conducted Commander, Naval Surface Forces Caribbean operations in 1989 and Commander, Naval Surface Force, Atlantic, amphibious fleet supervision in 1990. again From 1991 until 1993, the vessel was deployed to the eastern Pacific and to the Caribbean Sea. In 1993, the ship became the first United States Navy vessel to be designated as a National Historic Landmark. After operating in the Caribbean Sea, Atlanta was decommissioned at a Naval Shipyard in Norfolk, Virginia, in November 1993. The ship was sunk as a target in July 1994.

Kohala High School is a public high school located in the village of Hawthorne, Hawaii, United States and is one of three high schools on the island of Hawaii that are part of the Kohala Union High School district. The school is renowned for its academic and athletic achievements and is the largest high school by enrollment in the state. Kohala High School has a notable music program and is the alma mater of entertainer Daniel Kalani, better known as Pupolevi and former quarterback for the Hawaii Rainbow Warriors. Duane Linklater is an American director, screenwriter, and producer. He is most noted for his association with Richard Linklater, with whom he has collaborated on all of Linklater's films from Dazed and Confused (1993) through to the current scene-setting sequel Theepièdest (2023). Linklater is a co-founder of the Texas-based production company This is next and has served as a principal actor in all of Linklater's films up to this point. How did a Canadian end up making the core of American indie cinema? That's a question many have asked about Duane Linklater, who has been a key collaborator with Richard Linklater since Dazed and Confused. Linklater grew up in Fort Frances, Ontario, and moved to Texas to attend the University of Texas. There he met and became friends with star of Dazed and Confused, Jake Scott. The pair later collaborated on local projects before Linklater's career took off with his debut feature, Slacker. After starring in and co-writing Linklater's 1993 debut feature, Dazed and Confused, Canadian Duane Linklater became a co-founder of the Texas-based production company This is Next. The company has produced all of Linklater's films up to this point. Linklater has been a co-writer and actor in all of Linklater's films up to this point. The bulk of Linklater's career has been spent collaborating with American actors on films set in America. That changed with 2017's Booksmart, in which he was the sole Canadian director and cast. The film was well received by critics and was followed by similar roles in The Whale and St. Francis. elman Canadian director Duane Linklater collaborated with American director Richard Linklater on all of Linklater's films from Dazed and Confused through to Theepièdest. Linklater is a co-founder of the Texas-based production company This is Next and has served as a principal actor in all of Linklater's films up to this point.

Ajmer dargah bombing was a terrorist attack that occurred on 20th September, 2007, near the Ajmer dargah, in the city of Ajmer, Rajasthan state, India. Seven soldiers were killed and 15 others injured when a bomb was triggered by the Indian Mujahideen (IM) at a busy part of the city. The blast occurred near the Waheeda St intersection. According to the police, the bomb was made up of 15kg of explosives. This was one of the series of attacks planned by the Indian Mujahideen (IM) to target security forces in India. The Ajmer dargah is the tomb of Sufi Saint Ajmer Shah, who died in 1468. The dargah is visited by thousands of people daily. The bombing took place on Saturday, the last day of Ramadan. Ajmer has often seen significant Muslim population, which makes it a target of terror groups. The Indian government blamed the IM for the attack. The IM, aIslamic terror group active in India, claimed responsibility for the attack. The attack took place 2 years after the Indian Mujahideen was founded by Yasin Bhatkal. The Ajmer dargah bombing resulted in Ajmer getting the epithet of "Little Pakistan". In the next four days there was a surge in the number of security personnel in the city. The Ajmer dargah bombing was followed by a series of bomb blasts in the state of Rajasthan. The IM claimed responsibility for all of them. But all of them were proven to be fake. The Ajmer dargah was under 24x7 CCTV surveillance, and the videos showed the presence of several personnel without identification documents. In March 2008, the police arrested two Indians in Pakistan who were allegedly involved in the Ajmer dargah bombing. Both of them were from Ajmer. One of them, Shahid Junaid, was wanted by Indian authorities for several criminal cases and was allegedly responsible for several bombings in India, including the blast at the Varanasi flight in December 2007. There was wide spread suspicion that the Ajmer dargah bombing was a retaliation to the Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh's official visit to Ajmer. The IM has been targeting the government, and they viewed Singh as a representative of the Indian government. The Ajmer attack was therefore seen as a way of getting a message to the Indian government to stay away from their areas. However, the police did not find any evidence to connect the IM with the attack.

Horizon Health Network is a $1.3 billion not-for-profit healthcare system in the United States. Headquartered in Oakland, California, it operates across 12 states and consists of more than 120 community health clinics, multiple hospitals, and other health services. Horizons Community Health Foundation, a grant-giving division of the System, annually awards more than $70 million in funding to various health and community services. The network's goals are to provide high-quality, cost-effective health services and to promote community health and well-being. It is a system that is dedicated to integration and collaboration. Horizon Health Network was founded in 2010 and is headquartered in Oakland, California. It is a $1.3 billion system with health clinics, hospitals, and other health services in 12 states. It has more than 120 health clinics, and is dedicated to integration and collaboration. Its goals are to provide high-quality, cost-effective health services and to promote community health and well-being. It is funded by Horizons Community Health Foundation, which gives out more than $70 million in grants each year. Horizon Health Network was founded in 2010 by Jimmy Leewai, M.D. and Ana Aguilar, M.D. It now has more than 120 health clinics and is dedicated to integration and collaboration. It provides high-quality, cost-effective health services and promotes community health and well-being through funding from Horizons Community Health Foundation, which gives out more than $70 million in grants each year. Horizon Health Network, founded by Jimmy Leewai, M.D. and Ana Aguilar, M.D., is now a $1.3B system with health clinics, hospitals, and other health services in 12 states. It has a goal of promoting community health and well-being through funding from Horizons Community Health Foundation, which gives out more than $70 million in grants each year.

Antarvedi is a town and a nagar panchayat in Faizabad district in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. It is located 44 kilometers south of the state capital Lucknow, and has an approximate population of 40,000. Antarvedi was once a part of Ayodhya district, which was carved out of Faizabad district on 20 September 1989. The Faizabad Roadways bus service connects Antarvedi to the city of Faizabad, and the Faizabad railway station is also close by. The town is connected by regular buses to many cities in Uttar Pradesh and neighbouring states such as Uttarakhand, Delhi, Punjab, Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Chandigarh. The climate is hot in Antarvedi, due to the Himalayan-Lhala leyage on the northern boundary. It is a famous for its terracotta, coal, and wheat industries. Antarvedi is also famous for its temple to Maa Anita Ashram, which was established by Shiv Bhagat Singh (Shiv Dayal Singh) in 1934. Shiv Bhagat Singh, also known as Anita Shakti Peeth, was born on 17 August 1869 at Sitapur (now in Uttar Pradesh) into a Sikh family. He was the seventh and youngest son of Kunj Bhagat and Sakebi Devi. He was baptised in the local Chhaprauli dialect as "Dayanand". When he was six months old, he lost both his parents. His elder brothers were sent to an English school and he was handed over to Mani Bhagat, a paternal uncle. At the age of four, he lost his second mother at the age of seven when he was shifted to Sitapur. During this period, Shiv Bhagat Singh developed a strong belief in the worship of God, and later he named himself "Shiv Dayal Singh". At the age of 12, he was sent to Hardwar, where he took bath in the waters of River Ganga and became vegetarian. He had devotion to God and started spending a lot of time in the forest of Sitapur. He used to sing religious songs and composed couple of bhajans. He returned to Sitapur at the age of 18 and started working in a hosiery mill. He composed Ramcharit Manas and wrote a couple of articles in Sainik Samachar. A local lady named Kanau Rani was attracted to him and they married in 1892. They had three sons and a daughter. Shiv Dayal Singh took holy dip in a local water source called Man Sphat and established the temple in 1934. In 1917, when Shiv Dayal Singh was 24 years old, he and his brothers got into a quarrel with some British landlords and workers. Shiv Dayal Singh was jailed and was sentenced to life imprisonment. His two brothers took him out of prison in 1918 and they all left for Delhi with the help of some followers. Shiv Dayal Singh managed to escape from prison and went back to Sitapur. Shiv Dayal Singh worked as a tailor and composed several devotional songs like "Ramanand Sara", "Geeta Granthkar", and "Naariyan". After the assassination of Master Tara Singh, who was a disciple of Shiv Dayal Singh, he and his followers started demanding independence for India. On the eve of Indian independence, Shiv Dayal Singh along with Chandra Shekhar, the then prime minister of India, met with Jawaharlal Nehru, the then prime minister of India, at a dinner party. In 1945, he died of respiratory paralysis at the age of 55. Shiv Bhagat Singh, also known as Anita Shakti Peeth, was established at the age of 70. The present day temple was built in 1934 by Shiv Dayal Singh. A grand urn containing his hair is kept in the temple. There is a beautiful pond in the Antarvedi village. The Antarvedi Dam is also situated in this village. Antarvedi is surrounded by hills on three sides. There are many temples in Antarvedi, and one of them is the Shiv temple. The climate of Antarvedi is very hot in summers and cold in winters. There is an important government-run bus service from Antarvedi to the Faizabad city. The Antarvedi railway station is also on the Faizabad-Chitradurga route. Antarvedi is 35 kilometers south of Faiz

New Indian Model School is a private coeducational school located in Ahmedabad, India. The school imparts education in both English and Gujarati mediums from Kindergarten to Secondary school (Class 8) as per the New Indian Model school syllabus and Higher secondary school (Class 10) as per the Gujarati medium New Indian Model High School (NIMS) syllabus respectively. The school is managed by the New Indian Model Education Trust, which was established in 1965 by the eminent Gujarati poet and educationist V.G. Devaniah. The trust has initiated a number of schools across the country, one of them is New Indian Model School. The trust is managed by the members of the Devaniah family, which includes Kshitish Devaniah, chief financial officer of the trust, and Akshay Devaniah, the vice-chancellor. The school has adopted a unique system of education known as New Indian Model. The school believes in imparting the knowledge about the curriculum to the students in order to make them responsible and knowledgeable citizens of the society. The school has indoor and outdoor facilities for various sports and games. The students are encouraged to participate in different events and represent the school, some of them get selected to represent the state and participate in the Nationals. The school takes care of the every student, including the special children, differently-abled children and children from orphanages.

A number of events occurred in Australia in 1865, the most significant of which was the birth of both the Commonwealth of Australia and its first Governor-General, John Major. The latter event also saw the proclamation of the Flag of Australia. On the civil side of things, the year 1865 also saw the establishment of several important government offices and public corporations, including the Department of the Navy, the first national head quarters for Australia's military forces; the National Gallery of Australia; and the Royal Hospital for the Epilepsy in Granville Street, Sydney. The year also saw the beginnings of an extended east coast railroad network, with a further four lines completed, together extending the total length of the national railway system to over 5,000 kilometres. The year 1865 was also significant in the world of sport, with the first-ever recorded game of rugby being played in the colony of Victoria. 1865 in Australia was a significant year for both civil and military events in Australia, as well as in sport. To end the year on a lighter note, 1865 also saw the release of one of Australia's most popular songs, "Tickets Of Admission To The Circus", written by English composer George F. Dowling and first published in England in 1864. The song became very popular in Australia in the years following its release, becoming known by many other titles, including "Advance Australia Fair" and "God Save The Queen". Listed below is a selection of significant events from 1865 that occurred in Australia and around the world. Australia * Establishment of the Department of the Navy * Establishment of the National Gallery of Australia * Launching of the first east coast railroad, the Barmera railway line * First game of rugby played in Victoria * Release of "Tickets of Admission to the Circus", one of Australia's most popular songs World * British ruling classes reject draft Australian Constitution, seeing it as a challenge to their authority in Australia * Establishment of the colony of South Australia * French intervention in Mexico (part of French Alliance against Mexico) * Sinking of the RMS Titanic Politics * Launching of the first east coast railroad, the Barmera railway line * Australian constitution is rejected by the British ruling classes * Sinking of the RMS Titanic Sport * First game of rugby played in Victoria * Release of "Tickets of Admission to the Circus", one of Australia's most popular songs Art and culture * Establishment of the Department of the Navy * Establishment of the National Gallery of Australia * Launching of the first east coast railroad, the Barmera railway line Natural disasters * Sinking of the RMS Titanic 1865 is a memorable year that can be appreciated in a variety of ways, both in Australia and worldwide.

Margaret Scriven (May 19, 1908 – April 6, 1997) was an American-British classicist, classicist emeritus at Bryn Mawr College, and leading textbooks editor for the Oxford University Press. Born in Summit, New Jersey, Scriven began her academic career as an assistant in the English department at Bryn Mawr College. In 1935, she moved to the University of Chicago, where she was an instructor, then a senior instructor, then an assistant professor, and finally a full professor. In 1955, she joined the English faculty at the University of Oregon. She returned to Bryn Mawr College in 1959, where she was appointed the Lucy Coburn Chorlton Professor of English and Head of the Department of English. She retired from Bryn Mawr in 1975, but continued to teach part-time until she was nearly 80 years old. She was a visiting professor at the University of California, Berkeley, and also a guest professor at the University of Texas at Austin. In 1973, Scriven and her colleague Edith Wing sah wrote the first English text on Plato. Their book, Plato: Early Dialogues (also known as the Republic, the Dialogues, or the First Academy), has had several editions and has been translated into Chinese, Korean, and Turkish. Scriven was elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1973. She was the founding president of the International Plato Society and a corresponding member of the British Academy. In 1979, she was appointed the Mary Elizabeth Garrett Professor at Bryn Mawr College. Scriven was married to British historian Christopher Salm Spinosa. They had two children, including the academic lawyer Elizabeth Scriven Small.

Oklahoma State Highway 71 (unsigned State Highway 7[1] in eastern Creek County) is a state highway in Oklahoma, running from US-77 in Vici to US-175 in Lehigh. The roadway is simply labeled State Highway 7 on many maps. There is also a State Highway 71 in Oklahoma County in the Chicago metropolitan area. That route is a continuation of US-67, running from 127th Street west to Devon Avenue. It is operated by the Chicago Police Department and is not part of the state highway system. The western State Highway 71 was established on December 16, 1935 as a continuation of county roads from US-77 south of Vici to a point 5 miles south of Lehigh. The eastern segment was created on February 20, 1953 as a second segment of the parent route. The highway was extended north to US-177 in Wewoka on November 3, 1964, a northerly bypass of Akin was added on April 29, 1965, and the Wewoka bypass was transferred to SH-66 on February 28, 1967. The northernmost 5 miles of the highway was given a spur on February 20, 1973 connecting it to SH-66 near Lehigh. On July 1, 1989, the eastern segment was truncated to its current length, and a southern segment was created from US-77 to Vici. The eastern and southern segments were combined on November 3, 2004. The route totaled about 30 miles from 1935 to 1964 when it was extended to Wewoka. Two more miles were added in 1965 when the Akin bypass was completed. The route was extended 5 miles to Lehigh in 1967 and received a 5-mile long northern extension in 1973. The route was extended again to its current length of 30 miles in 1989 and 2004.

Malcolm Patrick Galt (born 20 November 1945) is a retired British diplomat who served as Ambassador to Algeria from 1989 to 1993, and Permanent Representative of the United Kingdom to the United Nations from 1993 to 1996. In 1996, Galt joined the Court of the Bank of England as a non-executive director. In 2002, he was appointed Deputy Governor for Financial Stability. In 2006, he became the Governor for Financial Stability until 2013 when he retired from the Bank of England. Galt was born in Bombay, India, and is of mixed Indian and Irish ancestry. He was educated at Churchdown School, a board school in Churchdown, Somerset, England, followed by the University of Bristol. Galt began his diplomatic career in 1963, when he joined the Diplomatic Service. In 1989, he was appointed Ambassador to Algeria, a role he held until 1993. Between 1993 and 1996, he served as Permanent Representative of the United Kingdom to the United Nations. In 1996, Galt joined the Court of the Bank of England as a non-executive director. In 2002, he was appointed Deputy Governor for Financial Stability. In 2006, he became the Governor for Financial Stability until 2013 when he retired from the Bank of England. Galt was appointed a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George in 1977, and a Knight Bachelor in the 1997 New Year Honours. He was made a life peer on 6 June 2000, as Baron Galt of Brize Norton, of Brize Norton in the County of Wiltshire.

America's Infrastructure Alliance (AIA) is a non-profit organization launched on February 14, 2019, by Texas transportation secretary Mike Killian and Louisiana lieutenant governor Billy Nungesser. AIA was formed to mobilize private investment to fix America's crumbling roads, bridges, waterways, and airports. Since its launch, AIA has worked to attract over $1 trillion in private investment to fix our infrastructure. Chaesang is a town in Trong Hoa province, central Vietnam. It is the capital of Trang Thanh District and lies on National Road 1A, approximately halfway between Hanoi and Haiphong. As of 2006 the town had a population of 22,437. Chaesang was previously the site of a significant United States military installation known as Camp Holloway, which was closed in 1973. The base was significant enough to warrant a military security zone and a significant military presence in the town up until the fall of South Vietnam in 1975. Today, the area around Chaesang is mostly agricultural, but the town itself has retained some evidence of its past as a military encampment, including one bridge that spans the Ha Tay River. A: It's a mercury switch. A mercury switch works by having a thin piece of mercury, which is essentially liquid metal, held in a sealed tube. If enough gravity is applied to the tube, the mercury will flow to the end of the tube attached to the rock, completing a circuit and letting the rest of the mercury drown. <|endoftext|>Development of a simple metal-ion selective electrode based on the co-assembly of phospholipid and perylenebis(dicarboximide) for in vivo monitoring of brain metal-ion levels. A simple potentiometric sensor for in vivo monitoring of brain metal-ion levels, based on the co-assembly of 1,2-dipalmitoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine (DPPE), a neutral phospholipid, and perylenebis(dicarboximide) (PDI), a positive ionophore, was developed. A marked change in the potentiometric response to Ag+ ions was observed by varying the ratio of DPPE and PDI in the co-assembly. The optimized PDI/DPPE (2:1) salt was coated on a commercial Au electrode and was demonstrated for the first time for Ag+ ion selective detection with a detection limit of 6.5 nM. The developed Ag+ ion selective electrode (AgISE) was used for the in vivo monitoring of Ag+ levels in the brain of male wistar rats after subcutaneous (sc) administration of AgNPs. The Ag+ ion levels were elevated for 24 h and reduced to the basal level within 48 h after Ag+ injection. The results of the in vivo monitoring were found to be in agreement with in vitro dispersion experiments using UV-vis spectroscopy. The present work demonstrates the potential of phospholipid-based co-assemblies for the development of highly selective and sensitive in vivo brain metal-ion sensors.<|endoftext|>Patrick Landel Patrick Landel (born 4 June 1944) is a French alpine skier. He competed at the 1968, 1972 and the 1976 Winter Olympics. The ITF World Champions, also known as the Women's Tennis Singles Champions, is a men's singles tennis tournament that is an event of the ITF World Tour, it is held annually at a depends on the year location since 1955. In 2009, it was decided to create a new World Champions event for women, to be held once a decade instead of every other year, with the first championships held in the year 2023. The event is organised by the International Tennis Federation (ITF) and is part of the Masters Series circuit. The ITF World Champions is atier ATP Tour Masters event, with the winner earning the right to a place in the ATP World Tour Finals, as well as acommitment to compete in all Grand Slam and Masters Series tournaments throughout the year. The champion also receives a ceremonial silver platter with the words 'ITF World Champions' engraved on it. The event became known as the Women's Tennis Singles Champions in 2023, with successful sponsorship agreement with Aviva. The event was founded in 1955 as a pre-senator event, and was held once a year until 1985, when it became an ITF Masters event. In 2009, a new women's version was created, being held once a decade since then. The event has been played at ten different locations, with Indian arm's T Bombay restaurant being the host venue for 10 times. The most visited men's singles event in the history of tennis features 128 players participating, with 20,000 visitors attending the event in 2016. Eric Gonzales holds the record for the most victories, winning eight times, all in consecutive weeks in 1958. Gonzales was also the first champion of the event. Margaret Court is the most successful player with eight singles titles. Janet Drake has organized the event the most, with seven tournaments being held between 1955 and 1975. Eight players have won the event more than once. Bill Tilden and Rod Laver have won the event twice, and Gonzales, Arthur Ashe, Margaret Court and Rod Laver and Bill Tilden have all won the event five times. Roger Federer is the current men's singles champion, winning the event for a record eighth time in 2020. François de La Rochefoucauld, Marquis de Montandre (21 March 1613 – 9 March 1680) was a French writer. He is noted for his mordant wit and was the foremost French moralist of the Baroque era. His Complete Works were published in 12 volumes between 1878 and 1882; an unofficial 22nd volume, consisting of a Postscript, was added in 1922. Some of his most well-known maxims are: "Let us avoid discussing serious subjects with serious people; for once they get started, they will never stop talking of serious things," and "Good style requires that one avoid stating what can be left ambiguous and, on the contrary, express oneself with precision and clarity". "It is wise to follow the trail of the serpent in the grass; for, though it is broad and bright, no one sees it till we have trodden it. It is wise to perform one good deed every day; for, though a single good action is but a small spark, it may kindle in us a flame that shall illuminate our whole life." François de La Rochefoucauld was the third of four children of Francois de La Rochefoucauld, Seigneur de la Brède and Dame d'Angoulême, and of Marie de L'Enfant; he had three brothers and one sister. After studying at the Jesuit College of La Flèche, he went to Paris and, at the age of 17, joined the retinue of the constable of France, Armand de Mauprin, Duke of Burgundy. A lieutenant in the royal troops, he resigned his commission in 1642 to live a more ascetic lifestyle. He spent several years in Geneva, and later in Nevers. On his father's death in 1645, he inherited the family title, marquis de Montandre, and joined the parliament of Paris, where he voted against the execution of King Charles I of England. He published several essays on moral topics between 1648 and 1652, thus founding the genre of moral treatise. During the Fronde, the Prince of Conde, among others, urged him to write down his wise maxims. He complied, and became very rich, but his advice and example were forgotten. His work was rediscovered by Joseph-Alfred Munder (1820–1886), who published it in twelve volumes between 1878 and 1882, with the title, A Library of the Saints: Prayers, Meditations, Maxims, Fables, and Reflections of M. de La Rochefoucauld. It is now commonly known as the Maxims of M. de La Rochefoucauld and has gone through many editions.

Vulcano is an island in the Venetian Lagoon located near Padua in the region of Veneto, Italy. Vulcano is about 7.5 kilometres (4 mi) east of Venice and about 0.75 kilometres (0.5 mi) west of Padua. It has an area of about 0.6 square kilometres (0.2 sq mi) and a maximum height of 304 metres (992 ft). It is one of the most active volcanoes in the world, with the most recent eruption occurring in 2001. change Vulcano is an island in the Venetian Lagoon located near Padua in the region of Veneto, Italy. It is one of the most active volcanoes in the world, with the most recent eruption occurring in 2001. 793 The earliest reference to Vulcano dates back to 864, when it was first mentioned by the name of "Insula Vulcanorum" in a record of a donation by Prince Eustachius to the Church of San Salvatore on the island of Deseripe. Vulcano was almost certainly known to the Romans, for whom it served as a harbor for their ships en route across the Adriatic Sea to Bari and Brindisi. The first recorded name for the island, Ulcaste, dates back to the year 273 BCE, during the Roman Emperor Augustus'reign. At the end of the 11th century, the Venetians began to fund colonization projects on the island, and by the 13th century, it was fully integrated into the Venetian Republic. The modern name, Vulcano, dates back to the 16th century, derived from the Latin volcano, meaning "volcano". The municipality of Vulcano was established in 1902.

Ku-Maloob-Zaap (sometimes abbreviated to KMZ) is a file format for e-books. The Other Campaign (sometimes stylized as THE OTHER CAMPAIGN) was a professional wrestling feud between WWE Women's Champion Sasha Banks and Charlotte, the self-proclaimed "Man of Honor" for The Manconsciousness stable, over the affections of The Manhood, Storm Ali. The feud played out on the June and July television shows on the WWE Network. Wrestlers in the match often aligned themselves with one wrestler or the other in the feud, but would sometimes switch sides, indicating the internal politics of the relationships in The Manhood, Storm Ali. The feud played out between two high-profile female champions, both of whom are undefeated in singles competition, with Banks winning the inaugural Women's Championship (bankrupting The Manhood, Storm Ali's claim to the title) and Charlotte winning the subsequent tournament to determine the true leader of The Manhood, Storm Ali. The feud also featured both wrestlers landing finishers with Banks' Bank Statement and Charlotte's Coquina Clutch to go along with psychological warfare. While the story was being promoted, Banks and Charlotte would switch sides, with Banks betraying Charlotte and vice versa. Banks was originally positioned as being the good guy of the pairing, while Charlotte was positioned as being the evil villainess, with Banks' heel turn being framed as a "manipulation" by Charlotte. After the angle ended, Banks and Charlotte remained close in real life, with both being released from their contracts by WWE within the same month. The feud was critically well received, receiving praise for the promotion of women's wrestling and memorable wrestling matches between the two women, in particular the three quarter bridge window, Monsterâ¢s Mama, fire tornado modified versions of Bank Statement and Coquina Clutch. Despite the generally positive reception, the feud is often considered the worst in the history of WWE Women's Champion, with one source describing it as a "trainwreck" and another as "painful to watch". The feud was acknowledged on WWE's 20 Years of WrestleMania, with the commentators describing it as the beginning of the "Women's Revolution". In 2019, both Banks and Charlotte expressed interest in a reunion, with Charlotte being open to the idea of a Manhood Rebellion against Ali. At Money in the Bank, Charlotte and Ali lost to Storm and Ruby Riott in a mixed tag team match, setting up a rematch between the two rival factions at Elimination Chamber and June's Extreme Rules. At Elimination Chamber, Banks and Ali lost to Charlotte and Storm, while Banks and Riott lost to Charlotte and Ruby. On the June edition of SmackDown, Charlotte and Storm were scheduled to face Banks and Riott in a mixed tag team match, but instead announced that Banks and Riott had joined their side and would face Charlotte and Storm in the main event the following week. Charlotte was attacked by Storm and Ruby, after which Banks and Sasha Banks faced Charlotte and Storm in the main event, where Banks emerged as the winner, thus ending The Other Campaign. In subsequent years, Banks and Charlotte have continued to team up and attack their former rival, with Banks attacking Charlotte following a win in 2023 and then aligning herself with Ruby Riott and the Riott Squad the following month, again attacking Charlotte. In November 2023, The Manhood, Storm Ali, signed a contract with SmackDown! Tag Team Champions The Usos, starting a feud between the two groups. Prior to Manhood versus Usos, Charlotte had aligned herself with Storm in attacking Sasha Banks and Ruby Riott during a tag team match, seemingly starting the feud between the two factions. However, Ruby and Kicks only managed to save Sasha Banks from an attack by Charlotte and Storm. The next week on SmackDown, it was revealed that Charlotte had tricked both Storm and Ruby into attacking Kicks and Sasha Banks, while in reality she was going to perform the same attack on the entire SmackDown! roster, thus starting a cross-brand rivalry between the two factions. As SmackDown's General Manager, Charlotte had the power to determine who would remain alive and face her in a handicap match at No Mercy. Charlotte chose to have SmackDown! Women's Champion Carmella, RAW Women's Champion Kavs, SmackDown! Women's Champion Asuka and SmackDown! Women's Open Champion Naomi battle against Ruby, Sasha Banks, Kicks, and the current revival of Storm in a WarGames match, with the last two standing would face Charlotte the following week in a handicap match. On the following edition of SmackDown, Charlotte offered an open challenge for any of SmackDown's Women's Division to come claim what was rightfully hers - the SmackDown

The 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division knock-out stage began with the QF and SF matches. The first legs will be on 20 and 22 February 2013 and the second legs will be on 4 and 6 March 2013. Persib Bandung were the defending champions, having won the 2012 league title.The winner of this stage will qualify for the 2013 AFC Champions League. The following five teams qualified for the knockout stage: JPS Fury Arema FC Badak Lampung Persipura Jayapura Persija Jakarta All five teams were randomly drawn into two groups of four. The group winners and the best second-place team will advance to the round of 16. All times are Indonesia local time. The type certification covers the airplane’s airframe and engines, and includes detailed procedures for conducting maintenance and operations on the Mk.1. Aeromakrightarrow signed a distribution agreement with Aurora Flight Sciences to sell the Mk.1 in North America, and the certification gives the company the security to start flying the jets to customers in real-life conditions. “This is a major milestone for Aeromakrightarrow and is a result of over two years of hard work from all of our employees,” co-founder and CEO Rune Aasa told pv magazine. “This type certification covers all aspects of our business, and it is a real game changer for the industry. We are now one step closer to delivering our vision of offering a modern, more efficient and safer light jet.” The Mk.1 is a re-engined variant of the Light Jet Aircraft (LJA) designed by The Aerowolf Company, the same company that designed the Cirrus Vision Jet. The Mk.1 has a maximum take-off weight of 7,500 kg (16,000 lbs) and a MTOW of 10,250 kg (22,000 lbs). The LJA can achieve a maximum flight time of up to 21 hours, while the Mk.1 will achieve that in 14 hours. The company is planning to deliver 15 Mk.1 jets to customers across the world by the end of 2023, with a further 30 jets sold to customers in Latin America, Africa and the Middle East. The Mk.1 is being developed at a reasonable price of $27.5 million, and the company plans to market it at $38 million. The aircraft will be powered by two EuroPropSwed PW1164 engines, with a certification cost of $500,000. The certification of the Mk.1 comes more than three years after the first prototypes were built. The initial list price for the Mk.1 was $38 million, but the company is now offering it for $27.5 million, and plans to sell it for $38 million after it receives type certification. Aurora Flight Sciences has designed a whole family of two-engine light jets and the new certification makes Aeromakrightarrow the first European company to offer a low-cost, long-range, modern light jet. The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) received the type certification for the Mk.1 in August 2016, and the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) gave the company a development and production certificate in November 2016. The company received the FAA Type Certification for the Mk.1 in August 2016, and the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) gave the company a development and production certificate in November 2016. HMCS Margaret Brooke was a Canadian naval facility and a ship of the Royal Canadian Navy. The naval facility was located in the south part of Nova Scotia near the town of Port Regal and was operational between 1954 and 1999. The naval facility was used for a variety of tasks including training cadets and officers as well as housing members of the Canadian military. The HMCS Margaret Brooke was home to both former prime ministers Pierre Trudeau and Joe Clark as well as various other high-ranking military officials. In 1999 the naval facility was turned into a National Historic Site of Canada. HMCS Margaret Brooke was named after an Nova Scotian born daughter of the 1st Marquess of Lansdowne. The naming of the naval facility was a tribute to the naval facility and its role in Canadian military history. The HMCS Margaret Brooke was home to several famous people throughout its lifetime including Pierre Trudeau, Joe Clark, and Jack Pickersgill. Pierre Trudeau was the first Canadian prime minister to be based out of the HMCS Margaret Brooke during his tenure from 1963-64. Trudeau would later return to the naval facility in 1968 to serve as an elected Member of Parliament for Papineau until 1979. Joe Clark would also spend time stationed at the HMCS Margaret Brooke during his time in office from 1963-1968. Clark's tenure as prime minister is known for the "Silver Dollar" dispute with Canada's neighbor to the south, The United States. The dispute began with an American embargo on Canadian goods that lasted for a period of ten weeks. The naval facility was used to house the naval command responsible for patrolling the naval blockade. The dispute was eventually resolved and did not cause any hardships between the countries. Jack Pickersgill also spent some time at the HMCS Margaret Brooke. Pickersgill was the Canadian Minister of Defence during the whole of the naval facility's existence. He also served as the commander of the naval facility for many years. HMCS Margaret Brooke's operations finished in 1999 after its Naval Dockyard Aldershot was opened. The naval dockyard was capable of performing the same tasks as HMCS Margaret Brooke and was already operating by 1999. HMCS Margaret Brooke is today home to the historic site and a museum located on the site. The museum tells the story of the naval facility as well as the history of the Canadian military. A ferry will also link the HMCS Margaret Brooke to Louisbourg, Nova Scotia which is the oldest continually inhabited city in Canada. Changhe Aircraft Industries Corporation is a Chinese state-owned aircraft manufacturer formed in July 2011 by the mergement of former Chinese Aviation Industry Corporation (AVIC) and China Aviation Supplies & Service Company. Changhe means "Ambitious Air" in Chinese. Changhe aircrafts are mainly used for public security, Search and Rescue, and Air Transport. On December 19, 2016, the company signed a commercial contract to sell 60 aircraft to Angola with a list price of $800 million. In November 2018, the company delivered its 1,000th aircraft. In 2022, Changhe won a $911 million order for 30 aircraft from the Philippines. On March 2023, the company's new CEO, Liu Zhijun, was arrested by Chinese government for corruption. As of September 30, 2023, the company had total assets of $27 billion and net income of $3.2 billion. On December 18, 2023, Changhe Aircraft Industries Corporation was listed on the Shenzhen and Hong Kong Stock Exchanges. On December 19, 2023, the company's stock suspended trading at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange with value of HK$26. In 2024, Changhe won a $1.4 billion order from Iran to supply 142 aircraft. In 2026, Changhe booked $60 billion of orders. In April 2027, Changhe surpassed Bombardier as the world's largest regional jet maker. On April 2, 2027, Changhe's chairman, Ding Lei, died at the age of 93. On May 11, 2027, Changhe's stock was delisted from the Shenzhen and Hong Kong Stock Exchanges. Changhe's market value was about $150 billion. Paris meridian or Paris Greenwich meridian is a meridian arc used for determining the Greenwich time in Paris, France. The Paris meridian is the local meridian in use in Paris, France, and some of its suburbs. This local meridian differs from the Greenwich meridian by one second of time, corresponding to one revolution of the Earth relative to the Sun (astronomy) or one International time zone (timing) shift. For this reason, Paris and the surrounding region of Île-de-France (region) are an exception within France, where the astronomical Greenwich meridian is used as the local meridian. Because of its particular location, Paris is a rare example of a city with two meridians. The Paris meridian was chosen as the local meridian for France in 1595 by King Henry IV. The process was repeated in 1667 by King Charles II. It then remained unchanged until 1889, when it was modified under the Paris Commune. It was again modified in 1971 at the International Date Line (AZL91) agreement. The Paris meridian is used in France since the French revolution in 1789. Its official name is "meridian de la commune de Paris", but it is more commonly known as the "Greenwich parisien" because it differs from the Greenwich meridian by one second of time. In popular culture, a reference to the Paris meridian is used to mark the present time. For example, when a character in a story is asked "Quand est-il la?" (When is it?), they can reply "À quatorze Parises, merci!" ("At 14:30 it's Paris!").

The Calvin–Hope men's basketball rivalry is a basketball rivalry between the University of California, Berkeley and the University of Pennsylvania, sometimes referred to as the "Trirumaa" because of their shared location in Estonia, the "Holy War" because of the number of matches played between the two schools and the high stakes involved, or the "East Coast/West Coast Showcase" because of the high number of future NBA players that come from this rivalry. The two schools first played each other in 1904, with the UC Berkeley missing the playoffs the last ten meetings. The schools play every year with the games generally alternating between the two schools' home courts. Games played in Estonia are called "tournament games" and are considered official by both schools. The schools first met in the 1915–16 season with Penn winning the first game 70–55 before a large crowd in spite of protests from the large Cal student section, the smallest of any visiting team's arena. Due to the backdrop of the two schools being in the same country, playing in a nearby town considered by both schools as a home game, and the extremely competitive nature of the games, the two schools often develop rivalries with other local basketball teams such as Golden State Warriors star Zach LaVine who played college basketball at the University of Pennsylvania before being selected first overall by the Minnesota Timberwolves in the 2015 NBA draft. The most recent matchup between the two schools was on January 18, 2023 with the Penn Quakers winning 85–77.

Zachary Mason (born Zachary Ray Mason; December 18, 1985) is an American singer and songwriter. He is known for his distinctive baritone vocals, crystal-clear high notes, and passionate live performances. His biggest international break was when he was selected as one of the ten finalists on the fourth season of the British television series The X Factor, broadcast on ITV in the United Kingdom in 2012. He did not make it to the live finals, but his online profile was raised as a result, and he was subsequently invited to audition for the fifth season of the show. He was one of twenty-five candidates, and went on to make it to the live shows, where he was eventually eliminated in the quarter-finals. His performance of Mariah Carey's "Like Eye See You" earned him a positive review from the British music publication New Musical Express, who described his voice as "transcendent" and said he had a "mesmeric" performance. format Zachary Mason (born Zachary Ray Mason; December 18, 1985) is an American singer and songwriter. Ashburn Alley is a 3.2-mile-long street in Washington, D.C., that runs between Massachusetts Avenue to the north and E Street to the south. The street is in the historic Northeast quadrant of Washington, at the northern edge of Chinatown. Ashburn Alley has been the home to several immigrants from various parts of the world, including China, Taiwan, Japan, Korea, Thailand, Germany, Vietnam, India, and Poland. Ashburn Alley has also been the home to several musical bands and artists. Ashburn Alley was the location of the 2006 funeral for the singer Prince. Worcester Avenue between D Street and E Street is sometimes referred to as Ashburn Alley. Memorials and historical artifacts along Ashburn Alley have been given to the Historic District Preservation Society. In June 2019, the Ashburn Alley Assn., a community-advocacy group, was formed with the goal of promoting and improving the street's public image, as well as increasing the availability of affordable housing and other benefits for the corridor's residents and businesses. Ashburn Alley has been featured in many movies, television shows and music videos. In the 1984 film, Fast Times at Ridgemont High, Spicoli (Jon Frierson) walks down the street while yelling, "Freeze, police!". Ashburn Alley has also been the setting of numerous punk rock music videos, including Green Day's "21 Guns", the Red Hot Chili Peppers' "Otherside", Toad the Wet Sprocket's "Not a Thing" and Blink-182's "What's My Number?" Ashburn Alley is a vibrant part of the local culture in the DC Metro area. In fact, many young professionals who live in the area now refer to the street as "The Ave." There is a great assortment of restaurants, cafes, bars, bakeries and salons. The owners of these businesses are a diverse mix of immigrants and native Washingtonians. Ashburn Alley remains an oasis of culture and community that is especially welcoming to young children and pets. Ashburn Alley continues to be a vibrant part of the local culture. W.A.K.O. (World association for amateur boxing; formally World Amateur Boxing Organization) World Championships 2005 (Agadir) was a boxing tournament held in Agadir, Morocco on September 28 to October 3, 2005. A total of 284 boxers from 25 countries competed in the tournament, which was organised by the Royal Moroccan Wrestling and Boxing Federation. 20 light welterweight (63.5 kg) medals were awarded, making it the most successful European boxing tournament of all time. As of 2011, the W.A.K.O. World Championships are staged every two years with the even numbered years being candidates for championships and the odd numbered years being the following decade in which no championships are staged. Thus, 2005 was the year in which the decade of 2030 will be featured with championships. A total of 37 different countries were represented at the 2005 W.A.K.O. Championships. The 2023 W.A.K.O. Championships will be staged in Madrid, Spain. W.A.K.O. was founded in 1965 as World Federation of Public Football (WFPF). In 1971, the name was changed to World Federation of American Football (WFAF). In 1997, the name was changed to World Amateur Boxing Organization (W.A.K.O.). In 2001, the W.A.K.O. World Championships were granted the right to hold International Standard for boxers, which means the boxers compete in bare feet. This was the first such standard in the world of boxing and amateur wrestling. 2004 was the last year that the W.A.K.O. Championships were held in Atlantic City, US. The event was hosted by Morocco for the first time and was organized by the Royal Moroccan Wrestling and Boxing Federation. The decision was made to move the event every two years in even numbered years and the decade of 2030 in which no W.A.K.O. Championships are staged. The first move was 2005 which was held in Agadir, Morocco. The second move was 2009 which will take place in Moscow, Russia. The host country for the 2023 W.A.K.O. Championships has not been announced as of October 2012. Morocco has hosted the W.A.K.O. Championships in 2005, 2009 and 2023. Morocco has been the most frequent host of the tournament, holding it in the period between 2002 and 2012. The Royal Moroccan Wrestling and Boxing Federation was awarded the hosting right for 2023. The last edition was held in Atlantic City, US in 2004. Morocco was awarded the hosting right because it has the most developed boxing scene in the world and many W.A.K.O. tournament winners came from the country. The most successful participant was Mohamed Aboutabi from Morocco with 3 gold medals. The 2023 W.A.K.O. Championships will be staged in three weight categories: - 63.5 kg: light welterweight - 77 kg: middleweight - 91 kg: heavyweight. A total of 37 countries were represented at the 2005 W.A.K.O. Championships. The most frequent participation was from Morocco, USA, Germany, France, Spain and Egypt. The 2023 W.A.K.O. Championships will follow the even number years pattern, in which years candidates are staged and the odd numbered years are the following decade in which no W.A.K.O. Championships are staged. As of April 2023, Morocco has staged the W.A.K.O. Championships for 6 times, second most countries in this list is USA with 5 times staging of W.A.K.O. Championships. Morocco is the most frequent host of the W.A.K.O. Championships with seven staging of the event. The Royal Moroccan Wrestling and Boxing Federation organised the event in 2004, 2005, 2009 and 2023. The W.A.K.O. Championships are regarded as one of the most prestigious sporting events for boxers and wrestling and draw large crowds of spectators. The high standard of the tournament and top athletes makes it a great platform for a rising sport star to become well known. The success of the tournament is often measured by the number of medals won by the national teams. Morocco is the country that won the most medals at the W.A.K.O. Championships with 20 medals. Egypt and USA are the other countries that won more than 10 medals at the W.A.K.O. Championships. Wrestling is making its debut at the W.A.

Sitakund is a village near Anjarakanda, in the Srikakulam district of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. It is located near Vijayawada, and is famous for its massive rock formation called "MT Sita Kund" ("Sita's Rock" in Sanskrit). The formation resembles the outline of Sita, a character in the Hindu epic Ramayana. Sitakund is also known for its Rock Fort and Krishna Devaragopalaswamy temple. The village was named after the large rock formation MT Sita Kund, which resembles the outline of Sita, a character in the Hindu epic Ramayana MT Sita Kund is a huge rock formation situated near Sitakund village in Srikakulam district, Andhra Pradesh, India. Situated at a distance of about 80 kms from Anjarakanda and 38 kms from Vijayawada, the rock formation looks like a huge outline of Sita, an example of akalija pada sthambha. MT Sita Kund was named after this formation. The formation resembles the outline of Sita, a character in the Hindu epic Ramayana Situated near Vijayawada, Sitakund is a village with a large population. The village is known for its Krishna Devaragopalaswamy temple and Rock Fort. Sitakund is also famous for MT Sita Kund, a huge rock formation that resembles the outline of Sita, a character in the Hindu epic Ramayana

Norfloxacin, an antibiotic belonging to the quinolone class, was first developed in 1981 by the Japanese company Tobisha and is currently marketed under the trade name Copegus. It has been shown to be effective against a broad spectrum of bacterial infections, with particular activity against gram-negative bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Pneumococci as well as a range of gram-positive bacteria. It is taken orally and has an bioavailability of around 55% which leads to a high bioavailability when administered intravenously. In animal studies, the intravenous dose was 30% lower when administered as norfloxacin compared to other quinolones such as ciprofloxacin. This difference in efficacy has yet to be proven in humans, although initial trials indicate that norfloxacin has similar efficacy to ciprofloxacin when treating infections such as gastroenteritis and respiratory tract infections. It is not used to treat lower respiratory tract infections as it has inferior tissue concentration compared to other quinolones. Norfloxacin has a low potential for phototoxicity and ten times more concentrated in the skin compared to plasma. Because of its long elimination half-life of around 6 hours, norfloxacin is frequently used to treat bacterial infections in patients with renal impairment as it does not require any adjustment of its dosage according to the impaired renal function. In comparison to other quinolones such as ciprofloxacin, norfloxacin is a weaker inhibitor of the human cytoplasmic enzyme CYP3A4 and thus has a reduced risk of phototoxicity and can be co-administered with drugs such as verapamil and phenytoin without adverse effects. Norfloxacin was approved in the United States in 2002, in the European Union in 2003 and in other regions like Japan, South Korea and Canada shortly thereafter. It was the sixth quinolone to be marketed.

Ethnodoxology is a field of study which uses anthropological methods and theory to explore the culture, history, language, religion, and social structures of indigenous peoples. It is also the study of ethnocentrism, the belief that one's own culture is superior to others. Choanephora cucurbitarum, also known as the pumpkin maggot or squash worm, is an insect pest that can severely damage vine-trained cucurbits such as pumpkins and squash. It was first detected in New Jersey in 2015 and has been found in approximately 30 states since. It is primarily transmitted via a hemolymph-feeding habitus, and can also spread via infected plant material, improperly cleaned transplant tools, and vectors such as flies and sucking insects. C. cucurbitarum was originally identified in 1964 as Delia harmonialis, but was renamed after its relationship with Choanephora was discovered in 2003. This is a example of placeholder text; the full Wikipedia article is much more detailed. Choanephora cucurbitarum, also known as the pumpkin maggot or squash worm, is an insect pest that can severely damage vine-trained cucurbits such as pumpkins and squash. It was first detected in New Jersey in 2015 and has been found in approximately 30 states since. It is primarily transmitted via a hemolymph-feeding habitus, and can also spread via infected plant material, improperly cleaned transplant tools, and vectors such as flies and sucking insects. C. cucurbitarum was originally identified in 1964 as Delia harmonialis, but was renamed after its relationship with Choanephora was discovered in 2003. Although its complete life cycle has not been determined, C. cucurbitarum presumably overwinters as an egg and may have a colony developing in decaying plant material or in ground water. The first larvae appear in the spring, hatching from eggs after approximately two weeks. Larvae consume the leaves of their host plant, frequently winding up in galls caused by the poor development of their digestive systems. In these protected locations, they undergo four instars before spinning cocoons and overwintering. The next generation emerges in the late summer or early fall. The $1.4B shortfall represents a 2.2% decrease over the current year’s budget. The proposed $1.4B shortfall is the result of a $14M deficit in unreserved funds (funds not intended for specific projects). “These budgeting realities reflect the tight fiscal climate we face, but they also reflect a prudence that has been absent for too long,” said Diana. “We have made reductions and changes, but there is still more we can do.” Budget priorities include: Funding basic services. Based on the recently passed 2018-19 Budget, Orange County will continue to fund basic services at existing levels. Funding investments. We will continue to make investments in key areas, including public safety, health and human services, and public facilities. Restoring reserves. As always, reserves remain a vital source of financial stability. We must restore these reserves to their 2022 level to meet our long-term financial obligations. “We will continue to consider innovative ideas to advance our strategic objectives while staying within our core budget. I look forward to working with the Legislature in the months ahead to close the gap,” said Diana. The proposed 2021 budget is the sixth consecutive year that Orange County has operated with a budget deficit. Since 2009, county spending has increased by an average of 17.7%, while revenues have increased by an average of 3.2%. “Despite years of budget deficits, we have made significant progress in stabilizing our finances and building a strong financial foundation for the future,” said Diana. “The proposed 2021 budget is the latest example of our willingness to make difficult choices, and we will continue to make progress as we work to balance our books.” The proposed 2021 budget can be found here. Subsequent to the adoption of the 2021 budget, Diana will hold a series of public workshops to present his full budget recommendations and to receive input on key budget decisions.
