The Online News Association was founded in 1994 as a non-profit organization to provide a professional set of ethics and guidelines for journalists to help protect news consumers online. The ONA defines "online news" as "newspapers, online journals, and news sites published on the Internet." The association has 63 member publications and a total staff of four. Its offices are located in Reston, VA. The current president of the Online News Association is Lou Ferrara who is also Chief Technology Officer at Verisign. The ONA has published a set of ethical guidelines for online journalists which include not using false personal identity, not publishing physical or financial addresses of individuals unless they have done something unlawful, not publishing passwords or other means to access material that is not already in the public domain, and not sending news articles before they have been checked for accuracy and completeness. The ONA also requires member publications to provide a way for users to correct factual errors. In 2014 the ONA launched a campaign against clickbait and sponsored a contest to redesign the ONA logo. In 2017 the ONA announced a class action suit against The Huffington Post for misleading advertising and the ONA asked the company to stop referring to itself as a "newspaper". The ONA also asked Baidu to stop labeling its product "South China Morning Post" because it includes content from the print newspaper which is licensed for use but not written by Baidu. In February 2023, the ONA announced the addition of titles like VICE, GQ, Mashable, Refinery 29, and Jezebel to its membership, though some, like Jezebel, were admitted without the ONA's approval. Additionally, the organization launched a campaign called #DefendNews aimed at addressing the decline in news viewership and ad revenue. On April 9, 2023, the ONA announced that VICE Media had agreed to pay $4 million to the organization to resolve allegations that VICE violated the ONA's standards by publishing fabricated quotes and using misleading photography. On June 21, 2023, the ONA announced that GQ had also agreed to pay $3.5 million to the organization to resolve allegations that the magazine published fabricated quotes and used misleading photography. On August 15, 2023, the ONA announced that Mashable and Refinery29 had also agreed to pay $2 million to the organization to resolve similar allegations that the sites published fabricated quotes and used misleading photography. On September 21, 2023, the ONA and VICE Media settled allegations that the company published fabricated quotes and used misleading photography, and VICE Media agreed to pay $6 million to the organization. On December 12, 2023, the ONA and Jezebel settled allegations that Jezebel published fabricated quotes and used misleading photography, and Jezebel agreed to pay $3.75 million to the organization. The ONA's current membership includes: The Atlantic, Business Insider, BuzzFeed, CNET, CNN, Cosmopolitan, Esquire, GQ, Mashable, Mic, The New York Times, Playboy, Refinery29, Vice, VICE, and The Wall Street Journal.

Provincial Secretary and Registrar of Ontario Provincial Secretary The provincial secretary is the foremost administrative official in the Ontario government, and is generally considered to be the fourth most important minister after the Premier, the Attorney General and the Finance Minister. The secretary is responsible for managing the operations of the government, and is involved in a broad range of government functions, including internal department operations, special projects, constituency matters, legislative affairs, media relations and tourism. The secretary is appointed by the Ontario Premier, subject to the approval of the Ontario Legislative Assembly. The current provincial secretary is Barbara Gray, who has held the position since January 1, 2016. She previously served as president and CEO of the Ontario Trillium Foundation. Before entering politics, she worked as a consultant. The provincial secretary is the highest-paid government officer in Ontario, earning a base salary of $245,500, plus benefits. Registrar of Ontario The Registrar of Ontario is an officer of the Legislative Assembly of Ontario, and is one of the vice-presidents of the Ontario Legislative Assembly. The current registrar is Tedorea Masi, who has held the position since 2017. She previously served as the deputy registrar of Ontario. Like the provincial secretary, the registrar is appointed by the Premier, subject to the approval of the Legislative Assembly. The Registrar oversees the election and return processes, and maintains the Vital Statistics Act. Under the Court of Queen's Bench of Ontario (Canada), the registrar is the deputy of the Premier and Principal Secretary to the Minister of the Attorney General. As of March 2023, the Registrar of Ontario is the highest-paid government officer in Ontario, earning a base salary of $229,750, plus benefits.

The waterway spans 129 km from Chunghak Lake to Sni permits fish migration and navigation, while evading political and military disputes between South and North Korea Editors may find the following book relevant: "Nampo Dam: A Fantastic Story of Construction, Kim Jong-il, and Dragons" by Jung H. 250 words List of New Testament minuscules (2501–2600) The List of New Testament minuscules (2501–2600) is a subset of the Augustana Handbook's list of New Testament manuscripts. It contains the 2609 fragments remaining after removing duplicates and sections of text deemed unoriginal to the ancient manuscripts. The minuscules are important fragments of the New Testament written before the beginning of the Common Era. Origins The minuscules were extracted from the Augustana Handbook, a compilation of early medieval manuscripts of the New Testament, converted to digital form and released to the public by the Wellcome Library in 2017. The minuscules were extracted from the Augustana Handbook, a compilation of early medieval manuscripts of the New Testament, converted to digital form and released to the public by the Wellcome Library in 2017. List The following are fragments of the New Testament: Codex Augiensis, consisting of verses 1–17 of the Gospel of Luke Codex Augiensis 535, a fragment of the Gospel of Luke Codex Beratinus, consisting of verses 1–16 of the Gospel of Luke Codex Coislinianus, consisting of the first section of the Acts of the Apostles, and fragments of the Epistles of Paul to Philemon Codex Dresdensis, consisting of the Gospel of John and the Epistles of Paul to Philemon,Romans, and Corinthians Codex Sinaiticus, consisting of the Gospel of John, the Acts of the Apostles, and Paul's Epistles

Far Eastern University (FUN) is a private university in Manila, Philippines. It was founded in 2003 and is governed by a body of trustees appointed by the presidents of major churches in the Far East. The university is authorized to offer degree programs by the Philippines education department and is also recognized by the Commission on Higher Education (Philippines) and the Association of International Educators. The university has Extension campuses in Cebu City, Davao City and Okinawa. The main campus is located in Parola St., Mandaluyong City and has a total floor area of 50,000 square meters. The current president of FUN is the Right Rev. Dr. Jose S. Reyes. The University is well known for its pre-school, elementary, high school and college education programs. It has graduated more than 20,000 students who are now studying in college and university level schools in 150 countries all over the world. Notable alumni of the university include actors Piolo Pascual and Richard Gomez, basketball players Mikhail Simac and Alex Poythress, singers Princess Donna and Paolo Santos, tennis player MarkAngle Arnaud and entrepreneur Ramon Ang. The university also had a successful basketball team that won the championship of the local college basketball league, the UAAP in 2016. The main campus of FUN is located inside the compound of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila and the university chapel was built by the Benedictine monks of St. Scholastica's Monastery. The university has sponsored collaborative agreements with numerous U.S. and Canadian colleges and universities and also has partnerships with some foreign universities in Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand and Australia. A monument to the university's founders, the Laoag-Davao Road, stands in the plaza of the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila. The Far Eastern University has a global outreach with 150+ campuses in 31 countries and partnerships with prestigious universities in Asia, North America, South America, Europe and Oceania. Far Eastern University is an actively expanding university with: * Opening new campuses in Cebu, Davao, and Okinawa * Establishing study-abroad partnerships in South Korea, Thailand, Singapore, Japan and Australia * Launching in new courses and specializations such as Data Science, Engineering, Fashion Design and Cybersecurity * Organizing Thought-Provoking Conferences, Fests and Events The Far Eastern University will continue to be a leading force in pushing the boundaries of academic excellence in the region and globally by creating opportunities for the Filipino youth to aspire for and realize their dreams. The Far Eastern University, through its many extension campuses, offers quality and accessible higher education in multiple fields, such as law, business, engineering, science, healthcare, arts and humanities, giving Filipino students an edge in their chosen professions and making the university a pioneer in the field of education, both in the Philippines and abroad. The university has a solid base of wealthy and notable alumni throughout the Philippines and the rest of the world through its many global outreach campuses. The Far Eastern University is actively involved in nation-building through the establishment and operation of schools, centers, and facilities for national agencies, international organizations, and other humanitarian and welfare groups. The university is also focusing on a renewable energy-based development and to this end, is constructing a Solar Impulse-like solar plant that will be used to power its facilities, as well as provide electricity for the neighboring communities. The Far Eastern University, through its motto "Excellere" (To Excel), continues to develop cutting-edge educational, technological and administrative programs that will make it a global leader in the fields of education, healthcare, engineering, business, and science and technology, with the ultimate goal of becoming the leading international university in the Philippines and in the ASEAN region. Cryptocheilus notatus is a species of dragonfly in the family Libellulidae. It is found in Angola, Benin, Botswana, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Congo, Côte d'Ivoire, DR Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mauritania, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Réunion, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, South Africa, South Sudan, Swaziland, Togo, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical dry forest, subtropical or tropical moist lowland forest, subtropical or tropical moist montane forest, dry savanna, moist savanna, subtropical or tropical high-altitude grassland, shrubland, rural gardens, urban areas, and rivers. It is a polyphagous predator and the species seems to adapt easily to human modified landscapes. It is considered a good candidate for classical biological control in some African countries where it has been introduced. Its common names include swamp darner, water darter and lotus darter. It is the state dragonfly of Ohio, and the official state dragonfly of West Virginia. The Miarolitic cavity was the first of a series of tests of a weak form of the primaeval atom hypothesis. The hypothesis, proposed by Czech scientist Jan Wallauer, states that early in the universe's history all matter was closely connected and formed a single, huge, super-heavy atom, a galactic nucleus. As time passed, this atomic nucleus split into smaller nuclei, which in turn fused to form the present day atoms of matter. The Miarolitic cavity was the first test of the hypothesis that all these nuclei might one day form a single, huge, super-heavy atom again, a possibility that became known as the Primordial atom. The Miarolitic cavity is also known as "Wallauer's dish". It was a tiny cavity of less than a litre in volume, manufactured from a tiny slab of platinum-iridium alloy 20 microns (0.2mm) thick by a combining ion beam technique. It was manufactured at the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences' (now the Czech Academy of Sciences) in Piešťany in the Czech Republic and weight approximately 30 grams. The hypothesis stated that nuclei might one day form a single, huge, super-heavy atom again, and that the Miarolitic cavity, if it could be found to contain any nuclei at all, would contain only one nucleus. The Miarolitic cavity was successfully heated up to a very high temperature in a test of the heating method on 12 June 1961. However, it remained empty.

The Brattain–Hadley House is a historic house in Canfield, Ohio, United States, that is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It was constructed in 1880 and was home to Emanuel Bratton, an American inventor, along with his family until 1906. In 1906, John and Phoebe Haynes bought the house, and in 1925, they hired local architect Fred Miller to modify the house for use as his residence. The Brattain–Hadley House is important to both Ohio history and automobile history. Emanuel Bratton, an American inventor, lived here with his family from 1880 until 1906. He is best known for his work with electromagnets and rear-wheel drive, which he discovered would work better on a three-wheel car. His work with three-wheel cars eventually led to the formation of the Ford Motor Company. In 1906, John and Phoebe Haynes bought the house and hired local architect Fred Miller to modify the house for use as his residence. Miller is known for his residential work in the era known as the American Crafts Movement. The house has since been remodeled a number of times, most recently in the 1990s. It is currently owned by Cindy and Ed Witherell and serves as their residence. The Brattain–Hadley House is significant in both Ohio history and automobile history. Feleti Sevele were the hits of Meredith Henderson from the year 1984 to 1986. The song "Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing", composed by Lamont Dozier, Brian Holland, Eddie Holland, and Marv Johnson, was Feleti Sevele's theme. Henderson had a big influence on younger R&B artists like Michael Jackson and Whitney Houston. The Sevens were the biggest act on Motown's Miracle label, and their name was a reference to the seventh heaven. The band consisted of Mervyn Dunn (keyboards), Garry George (drums), Donald Shaw (bass), and Henderson (vocals). They sold over a million copies of their self-titled debut album. The album's title track was the group's second single and also peaked at number two on the Billboard R&B chart. "I'll be there" was the third and final single from the album. In 1986, Henderson reached the top of the Billboard Hot Black Singles chart with "Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing". This was the second time a Henderson song went to the top, the first being "Yes, Yes, Yea, Yes". The single was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America for sales of over 1,000,000 copies. The song was performed live on American Bandstand. Henderson performed "Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing" at the 1986 MTV Video Music Awards.

Jean (full name Jean Carlos Santos Oliveira; born February 3, 1994) is a Brazilian footballer who plays as a centre back for Greek Superleague side Aris Thessaloniki. Jean started his professional career at lowly Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro before being spotted by Portuguese giants Sporting CP and signing for them in 2013. He made his debut for the Lisbon side against Benfica in the 2013–14 UEFA Champions League group stage and went on to make 21 total appearances that season. In June 2014, Jean signed a four-year contract with French Ligue 1 side Olympique de Marseille, reuniting him with former Sporting CP coach José Mourinho. During his time at the club he suffered two relegations in five seasons, having to play Europa League football due to the far inferiority of the club's league position each year. In 2022–23, he made 35 appearances and was named in the LFP Team of the Season. On 1 August 2023, Jean joined Greek Superleague side Aris Thessaloniki on a three-year contract. Jean represented Brazil at Under-20 level and made his senior international debut in 2017. He represented his country at the 2017 and 2019 Copa América, as well as the 2018 and 2020 editions of the Summer Olympics. In November 2023, Jean received his first red card in professional football after headbutting Greek goalkeeper AntonisNikopopoulos during a 1–3 loss to Olympiakos. The Football Association's Control and Disciplinary Body handed him a five-game ban for the offence.

Cerenzia is a small, Mediterranean island situated some 60km south of Greece. It is approximately 30km west to east and has a land area of just over 2 square kilometers. Cerenzia is primarily inhabited, with nearly half of the population, who number around 4,000, living in the village of Agios Theodoros. The island is well known for it's unspoiled natural beauty and it's many registered historic monuments, with many structures dating back to the Byzantine and Venetian eras. Among the most notable of these are the 15th century Episcopal Palace, the 15th century Fortress of Parga, and the Venetian Bridge. The village of Agios Theodoros is situated near the southern tip of the island and overlooks the medieval port of Kamara. Cerenzia is roughly halfway between Venice and Athens and is roughly 10km from Syros, Schin travelerous and paradisiacal island. Memorable events involving Cerenzia include when it was used as a holding prison for French and American POWs during the Second World War, and when Israeli commandos from the Merkava battle tank carried out a successful operation to destroy a terrorist cell on the island in 2002. standout features of Cerenzia include its Byzantine architecture, unspoiled natural beauty and it's proximity to Syros and Schin Travelerous and paradisiacal island. Cerenzia is an island with a rich history and tourist potential. Due to its proximity to the popular holiday islands of Syros and Schin, it is well known to many visitors who come to Cerenzia for its beautiful beaches, crystal clear waters and many historical monuments. Despite the beauty of the island, many of the structures dating back to the Byzantine and Venetian eras are in need of maintenance and restoration. These include the 15th century Episcopal Palace, the 15th century Fortress of Parga, and the Venetian Bridge. By establishing a stable government, improving the island's infrastructure and investing in its tourist infrastructure, Cerenzia has the potential to develop a stable economy, becoming a self sufficient entity. Due to its close proximity to Syros, the island is an important fishing ground for the local population, who produce a variety of sea fish and molluscs. These include sea urchins, limpets, scallops, crayfish and monk fish. The sea fish are caught using a variety of methods, including trolling, bottom fishing and beach seining, and are then dried on-shore. Although the local population of the island are mainly fishing families, there is scope to establish a tourist based fishing industry, which would further benefit from the small harbour in Agios Theodoros and the close proximity of Syros. Cerenzia is the ideal location for those seeking a unique travel experience. The island has a very low population, leaving the majority of the island for the visitor to explore. Furthermore, the island's small size and close proximity to Syros mean that visitors can enjoy the beauty of the island's natural beauty without the need for a vehicle. On-site facilities include the 15th century Episcopal Palace and a small church, which serve as the island's main settlement, as well as a small harbour in Agios Theodoros. The nearby island of Syros, provides further facilities for guests of the island including taverns, restaurants, supermarkets and a small cinema. The Island also offers a unique opportunity to experience a traditional, local Cypriot meal, while enjoying the stunning views over the island's harbour and the Aegean Sea.

Henry Cavendish, 3rd Baron Waterpark was a British chemist and aristocrat. In 1783 he was introduced to Claude Lepine de la Chappe d'Autray, and together they conducted experiments to determine the then-unknown mass of the Earth. This experiment resulted in Cavendish being the first person to accurately determine the mass of the Earth. In 1795 he was made a baron by King George III and in 1810 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society. Francisco Rivera Ordóñez (born September 25, 1980) is a Puerto Rican professional wrestler, known by the ring name Rey Mysterio Jr. He is one of the most successful and popular wrestlers in the history of WWE, being one of the main competitors for the World Heavyweight Championship and the United States Championship throughout most of his career. Mysterio also holds several other world titles in several different promotions, including two-time IMPACT Wrestling World Heavyweight Champion, two-time Lucha de Apuestas World Heavyweight Champion (both times with The AAA Machine), two-time WXW World Heavyweight Champion, and nine-time Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre World Heavyweight Champion. Mysterio has also held the NWA World Heavyweight Championship, NWA World Television Champion, WWE Championship, and GWF Championship. Rey Mysterio Jr.'s real name is Francisco Rivera Ordóñez. He is the second son of Sefid Rivera and sister of Shakira Rivera, both wrestlers in their own right. He grew up in a wrestling environment as his parents worked as jobbers in the late 1980s and early 1990s. As a kid, Rey met both Eddie Guerrero and Salvatore Base, whom he would later feud with. Rey decided to pursue a professional wrestling career when he saw one of his parents wrestle. After training for several years, Rey made his debut in 1998, working under a mask as "Darkness". He unmasked after winning a four-man tournament, held by Guerrero's promotion International Wrestling Revolution Group (IWRG). Rey trained under IWRG's founder Pirata Morgan, who also trained Guerrero and several other wrestlers who achieved large success in the promotion, such as Histeria, Psicosis, and X-Fly. After IWRG closed due to financial problems, Rey worked under the ring name "Mysterio" for Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre (CMLL), Mexico's biggest wrestling promotion. In CMLL, Mysterio worked a wide variety of matches, including a high-profile rivalry with then-heel Guerrero. Rey made his WWE debut in early 2004, defeating Orlando Jordan for the WWE United States Championship. He would hold the championship for more than a year, before dropping it to John Cena in February 2005. Mysterio returned to the promotion in 2006, now working as a face. He captured the World Heavyweight Championship from Batista in March 2008, and held the championship for nearly two years. Mysterio won the championship back from John Cena at WrestleMania XXV in 2010, and held the title until 2013, when he was attacked by Sin Cara and The Shinyukin Khan. After losing the championship, Mysterio began a rivalry with Sin Cara, which ended at Extreme Rules in 2015 with Mysterio retaining his mask. Rey would then begin a stint as enhancement talent, before returning to WWE's Raw brand as a villain, dubbed "The Best in the World" by Kevin Owens. Mysterio won his first major championship since the World Heavyweight Championship at Extreme Rules, when he won the Money in the Bank briefcase. Mysterio went on to defeat Shane McMahon for the WWE Championship at Super Show-Down in a challenge for the interbrand Undisputed WWE Championship, becoming the first Puerto Rican WWE Champion. He later lost the title to Elias. Following the 2018 Superstar Shake-up, Mysterio moved to SmackDown, reuniting with his brother Shakira in the process. The two went on to win the Women's Tag Team Championship and the Money in the Bank briefcase, before being drafted to SmackDown's Raw brand as part of the 2019 Superstar Shake-up.

Marvin Powell (born June 24, 1991) is an American football running back for the Kansas City Chiefs of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Louisiana State University (LSU). Powell grew up in Missouri City, Texas and attended Houston Texas High School. After high school, Powell played college football at Louisiana State University where he played for head coach Les Miles. During his time at LSU, Powell ran for over 1,000 yards in both his junior and senior seasons. He was also the primary target of quarterback Dak Prescott, who in 2016 was named the National Offensive Player of the Year. After graduation, Powell was considered one of the top running back prospects for the 2017 NFL Draft. He was selected by the Dallas Cowboys in the fourth round and 86th overall, although he was unable to progress past the regular season during his time with the Cowboys. On July 27, 2018, Powell signed with the Kansas City Chiefs. Powell's father, Marvin Powell, Sr. also played college football at Louisiana State University. He went on to play professionally for the Los Angeles Rams. Powell has two older brothers who both played college football at the college level. His older brother Marvin Powell, Jr. was a running back at Louisiana State University and is currently the running backs coach at Vanderbilt University. His other brother Jarrett Powell played college football at the University of Texas and is currently a graduate assistant football coach at the University of Southern California. Powell was born on June 24, 1991. He is Jewish.

Moonhole is an(other) nickname for the circular tunnel complex on the south pole of the Moon, named Cratereus. The name is derived from the Greek for moon crater. The complex is approximately 50 meters in diameter and was officially discovered by the China Chang'e 4 mission in December 2019. Moonhole is one of four small impact craters on the far side of the Moon, the others being Shackleton, Fermi and Frankland. Adjacent to the Moonhole is a small crater formation named Smallpv which is approximately 110 meters in diameter. Moonhole was the destination for the spacecraft Beresheet during its failed landing attempt in April 2022. Etymology and origins of the name The Moonhole complex was officially discovered on December 8, 2019, by the Chang'e 4 probe. It was dubbed by the Chinese press and space enthusiasts as Moonhole, after the Chinese name for the complex, Cratereus. The name is derived from the Greek for moon crater. Artwork of Moonhole A high-resolution image of Moonhole and Smallpv, taken by the Chang'e 4 probe on December 8, 2019, was publicly released on January 10, 2020. The image shows the Moonhole complex, with the central crater roughly 50 meters across and a smaller crater to the southeast, designated Smallpv. The surface around the craters appears relatively flat and clean, with few visible blemishes. Visiting Moonhole Moonhole, along with other areas of the far side of the Moon, cannot be visited by crewed missions. The first attempt to land a spacecraft on the far side of the Moon was the Soviet Luna 3 mission in 1959. The only close approach to the Moonhole complex was by the Chang'e 4 probe, which came within 1.5 kilometers of the surface. Gamma-aminobutyric acid-A (GABA-A) receptors are the major inhibitory neurotransmitter receptors in the mammalian brain, playing critical roles in modulating neuronal excitability and neurotransmission. The subunit composition and arrangement of GABA-A receptors determines their unique functional properties. In the hippocampus, a major subregion of the brain that contributes to learning and memory, most GABAergic inhibitory postsynaptic currents (IPSCs) are mediated by receptors composed of α1, α2, β and γ subunits. These receptors can form a spectrum of distinct pharmacologically and biochemically distinct receptors ranging from GABA-A receptor Cl- channels to highly specialized GABA-A receptors that are depolarizing and contribute to the post-tetanic potentiation of transmitter release. Recent studies suggest that the α1 subunit is able to assemble with various β and γ subunits to form unique receptors with altered biochemical and electrophysiological properties. These changes have been shown to affect the peak amplitude and decay kinetics of GABA-A IPSCs in hippocampus. Additionally, specific arrangements of subunit assemblies such as α1β and α5βγ can form GABA-A receptors that can generate spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents, providing additional mechanisms for regulating GABA-A IPSC kinetics. Increasing evidence indicates that subunit composition and precise receptor arrangement are important factors modulating the function of GABA-A receptors.<|endoftext|>Q: How to retrieve DOM elements created dynamically with JavaScript My HTML file is something like:

Ludic interface is a term used in contemporary digital culture to describe the ways in which computer software interfaces reflect and induce playful, abstract, and imaginative modes of thought, feeling, and experience. Ludic designs challenge the conventional interfaces by simplifying the complex, showing the unfamiliar in digestible yet complex ways, and encouraging users to play with and animate their experiences. For instance, Quirky is a popular website for sharing and discovering "ludic" designs. The idea for the website was born when Ben Trovati met Spencer Levin at an O'Reilly event and the two started to discuss how to break into the consumer product space. The website initially focused on "quirky" ideas that people were willing to pay money for. A "quirky" product is one that is novel, but not necessarily useful or practical. The "ludic" in "ludic interface" comes from Spencer's background in game design. While Ludic thinking is good for fostering imaginative thinking, it comes with certain caveats. Ludic designs make extensive use of graphics, animation, and "game-like" mechanics which can be difficult to operate, especially for the elderly or people who do not enjoy such stimulation. Ludic thinking is also antithetical to critical thinking and the wisdom that can only be attained through thoughtful consideration. Imaginative thinking is exciting, but it can lead to unsupported beliefs and shallow analysis. While Ludic designs make it easy to produce imaginative results, they require users to accept and engage in simple, sometimes child-like thinking. These considerations and others have led many to question the value of Ludic thinking and whether it should be fostered or discourage. While there is no singular approach to producing Ludic interfaces, there are key principles which can inform and improve the overall experience. Primary amongst these is simplicity. Avoid complex interfaces and features which might discourage users from playing with the product. One should also provide guidance and instructions on how to complete tasks which might otherwise appear mysterious or complex. User paradigms should also be considered. If a product caters to a younger demographic, it should appeal to their tastes and values. Similarly, if a product is intended for an older demographic, they should be presented with user controls and interfaces that are intuitive to them. Overall, Ludic interface is a challenging, but potentially powerful tool for fostering imaginative, but also critically thinking, minds. While it requires a certain state of mind, it can also provide a space to depart from rational thinking and allow for more creative and child-like modes of thinking to take root. While Ludic interface was popularized in the 2000s and 2010s, there is evidence that similar notions have been present throughout the history of human thought. The ancient Greek Philosopher Plato, for example, described a method of using color palettes to guide humans into non-rational modes of thinking. Many of Plato's ideas about the influence of color on cognition were not proven until the 20th century. Similarly, research into emotionally engaging design is another branch of design research which traces its origins back to the 20th century. Overall, Ludic interface is a challenging, but potentially powerful tool for fostering imaginative, but also critical thinking, minds. While it requires a certain state of mind, it can also provide a space to depart from rational thinking and allow for more creative and child-like modes of thinking to take root. This website contains a large body of work on the subject. The following are a few articles that briefly describe some of the principles in the field: 1. Ulrich Harbich (68 years old) is an Austrian entrepreneur and former politician (ÖVP), he has been independent pharmacist since 2014 and since 2018 he is also a doctor of pharmacy (Dr. med. rer. pol.). His political activities include being a city council member of Feldkirch, being a chairman of the FPÖ subgroup in the municipality council as well as a member of the Nationalrat. Since 2008 he has been owner and chief executive officer of Harbich Pharma, a company headquartered in Feldkirch. Since 1 January 2014 he has been an independent pharmacist. His former party affiliation was listed as "ÖVP" (E Right). As of February 2023, he has been involved in numerous controversies, such as his former party affiliation with the ÖVP (E Right), as well as his controversial political activity in the municipality council of Feldkirch, where he was a chairman of the FPÖ subgroup and a member of the Nationalrat. As an entrepreneur, he is involved in the organic food industry, where he owns a chain of pharmacies named Harbich Apotheke. The CEO is his father, also named Ulrich Harbich, who is a professor of internal medicine. Harbich was born in Innsbruck, Austria. His current personal address is Feldkirch, Vorarlberg.

William Wardour (2 May 1880 – 17 January 1959) was an English actor, known for his collaborations with Max Reinhardt. After being born in Blackburn, Lancashire, England, Wardour began his career in the theater and worked with numerous theatrical groups before making his film debut in 1915. He continued to work in cinema through the 1930s, appearing in more than 70 movies. His performance as "The Chocolate Dope" in the film Calamity Jane (1920) made him popular with American audiences and led to numerous offers from Hollywood. He relocated to the United States, where he appeared in dozens of films throughout the 1940s. Although he was offered a career in television, Wardour remained loyal to cinema and made his final film appearance in 1952. He died at his home in Hollywood in 1959. mold William Wardour (2 May 1880 – 17 January 1959) was an English actor, known for his collaborations with Max Reinhardt. Alex Boyd is an English author of young adult fiction. His first novel, Spellscrip, was published in 2015 and was a semi-finalist for the National Book Award. His second novel, Starcrash, was published in 2017 and became a bestseller. Both Spellscrip and Starcrash were selected as Books of the Year by the School Library Journal. Boyd has published three books so far in the Max Wells series, and a fourth novel, Exile, is scheduled to be published in 2023. award History of Authoring and Publication Spellscrip was published in 2015 by Atheneum Books for Young Readers. Pavel Ubri was a Czechoslovak race car driver. He drove in Formula One in 1955 and 1956. He is the most successful driver from the Czechoslovak racing team, winning three Grands Prix. He was a member of the Ferrari team, scoring points at the 1956 Monaco Grand Prix and the 1958 Dutch Grand Prix. In 1956, he finished runner up to Juan Manuel Fangio in the World Driver's Championship. He was born in Kladno on 4 January 1929. His brother, Alexander, was also a racing driver. After World War II, the new communist government took control of Czechoslovakia and closed all racing teams. Pavel was forced to become a truck driver. He was soon able to build a new racing car, and entered his brother in the 1951 Trentino skiing endurance race. Pavel and his brother won the event. In 1955, he was signed by the Mergulho Nacional team, driving a privately entered Brabham. He drove in three Grand Prix races that year, with a best result of fifth place at Monaco. After the 1956 World Driver's Championship, he was signed by Ferrari. He drove in five races for Ferrari that year, with a best result of second place at the 1956 Monaco Grand Prix. In 1957, he moved to the Ensus team, driving a privately entered Lotus 24. He had his best result of second place, again at Monaco. In 1958, he drove for Ensus and Ferrari again. He scored points at the 1958 Italian and Dutch Grands Prix. He retired from two races, and finished the season with six podium finishes, his career best. Pavel Ubri died on 28 August 1983.

The Texas alligator lizard (Salvator Runionii) is a species of salamander in the family Plethodontidae. It is found in Mexico and the United States. It is common in much of its range, and it is protected by law. The distribution of the Texas alligator lizard probably did not shift as a result of the WWII bombing of Germany, because there was no direct railroad from Germany to the points where it is found today. However, its precise habitat has yet to be fully determined. The species is named for Salvator Runion, an American herpetologist. The Texas Alligator Lizard is a commonly found species with a wide distribution, but its exact habitat has yet to be fully determined. This is due in part to theWWII bombing of Germany, since there was no direct railroad from Germany to the points where it is found today. The Texas Alligator Lizard is a protected species in much of its range and is not unlawfully killed. Its habitat has yet to be fully determined, but it is believed to be widespread. It is named for Salvator Runion, an American herpetologist. This species of salamander is found in Mexico and the United States. It is protected by law in much of its range. The Texas Alligator Lizard has a wide distribution but its exact habitat has yet to be fully determined. It is a protected species in many regions and is not unlawfully killed. It is named for Salvator Runion, an American herpetologist. An example of the Texas Alligator Lizard can be found at any large body of water in Texas or the United States.

Francisco Gil Villegas (born April 10, 1944) is a Nicaraguan career diplomat and a former football referee. He has been the Nicaraguan ambassador to China, Saudi Arabia, Morocco, Tunisia, and the United Arab Emirates as well as an economic and financial adviser to president Daniel Ortega. Gil Villegas played college football as a safety for the Indiana Hoosiers of the University of Indiana and was a member of the 1967 Indiana Hoosiers football team National Champions. His only game in the National Football League (NFL) was with the Cincinnati Bengals in 1970. Ambassador Villegas's career began with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1979. He has also been affiliated with the World Bank, International Monetary Fund, United Nations Human Settlements Program, and was on the board of directors for the International Olympics Committee. On December 20, 1990, Ambassador Villegas received his U.S. visa at the Nicaraguan embassy in Washington, D.C. At the time, Nicaragua was under a travel embargo. He picked up his visa from a table in the lobby where other diplomats and family members were checking books out. Ambassador Villegas was unaware of the embargo and did not read the signs indicating the embargo. On March 1, 2007, he became an adviser to Nicaraguan President Ortega. On October 6, 2010, he was appointed as the Nicaraguan ambassador to Saudi Arabia. He presented his credentials to King Abdullah on October 28, 2010. He was also appointed as an economic and financial adviser to president Ortega in April 2011.

Incarnate (film) is a 2009 American fantasy horror film inspired by the folklore of West Virginia and written and directed by Mike Mekis. The film premiered at the 2009 WoodsEdge Films Community Cinema Film Festival, won several awards and was released on DVD on October 7, 2009. The film stars Alexander Calvert, Colleen Cross, Corey Feldman, and Brittany Robertson and was shot on location in Mekis' home state. Plot In rural West Virginia in the 1920s, a witch named Momoaqualand commands a trio of slaves who have been imprisoned in the bodies of a human child, a dog and a crow. The witch uses her powers to commit a series of robberies to fund a spell that will allow her to regain her human form. After performing the last of the necessary rituals, Momoaqualand is reborn in human form and awakens in the body of 6-year-old Jennifer Darrow, the adopted daughter of Fuzzy, a local farmer. Fuzzy is charged with Momoaqualand's care until a new custodian can be located and, after initially refusing, Jennifer's aunt Granny joins them in the house to help out. Jennifer displays numerous supernatural abilities, including the power to transform into an animal of her choosing, and is quickly joined by two other local children — Alvin, an autistic savant, and Tara, a runaway — who have also been targeted by Momoaqualand's crimes. A series of escalating incidents reveals that Jennifer has been magically bound to the witch and is at risk of becoming her slave. The four of them, along with Granny and Fuzzy's friend Milton, form an uneasy alliance to defeat Momoaqualand and free Jennifer from her thrall. Cast Production The film was shot on location in Mekis' home state, in and around Charleston and the surrounding areas. Reception Danny Justice of Dread Central awarded the film four stars out of five, calling it a "huge-scare fun fest that is unlike any other." Mark Kermode of BBC Culture called the film "a weird, wild, nasty little treasure," and praised its score and visual style, while criticizing its length and script. Many security threats to computer systems are caused by malicious software (also known as malware) originating from external sources, such as malicious users, malicious websites, and malware embedded in email messages and file downloads. These malicious users, websites, and malware seek to obtain confidential information from the attacked computer systems and/or to interfere with the operations of the attacked computer systems for malicious purposes, such as providing an access to locked data to the malicious users, or causing the attacked computer systems to perform illegal actions. Security products have been developed to detect malicious software, and some security products are able to remove malicious software from an attacked computer system. However, the security products are typically not able to prevent the malware from performing malicious activities on the attacked computer system after being removed. For example, once malicious software is removed from an attacked computer system, the attacked computer system may still be vulnerable to the re-introduction of the malicious software. Similarly, security flaws in the removed malicious software may leave the attacked computer system vulnerable to similar future attacks. SS Ste. Claire is a liberty ship built during World War II. The Ste. Claire ship was built in six months from September 1944 to March 1945, and was the 56th ship built by the United States during World War II. She had a capacity of 1,905 beds and was armed with 40 guns, including 14 fighter aircraft catapults. The Ste. Claire was named after St. Claire, Louisiana, and was owned by the New Orleans Steamship Company. After the war, she was acquired by the US Navy and commissioned as the USS Albacore (ARCM-5). She was decommissioned in 1964 and sunk as a target in 1995. In 2016, the Ste. Claire was acquired by Irish entrepreneur Seán Whyte and will be preserved and sailed by the Irish Navy. The SS St. Claire was the 56th ship built by the United States during World War II. She was named after St. Claire, Louisiana, and had a capacity of 1,905 beds. She was armed with 40 guns and was able to carry 9,192Initially the SS St. Claire was intended to be named USS Louisiana but that name was already taken so the Ste. Claire was chosen instead. After the war she was acquired by the US Navy and renamed the USS Albacore (ARCM-5). In 2016, she was decommissioned and sunk as a target in 1995. The SS St Claire is now preserved by the Irish Navy and will be sailed by the Irish Navy in the future.

Mississippi's gubernatorial election of 1991 was a rematch of the 1990 election. The Republican candidate, Firmin Newman, Jr., son of the previous governor, was unopposed in the Republican primary. The Democratic candidate, Lieutenant Governor Ray Mabus, faced two competitors in the Democratic primary. Jim Hood, a senator from northeastern Mississippi and the son of a former governor, was given most of the endorsements but was unable to win a majority and thus faced Mabus in the Democratic runoff. On November 6, 1991, Mabus defeated Hood by a large margin, 56.5% to 43.5%. There's Gonna Be a Storm: The Complete Recordings 1966–1969 is a compilation album by the American rock band the Grateful Dead. It was released in 1991 as a 2-CD set and as a 4-LP box set. The set features the complete recording sessions for the band's 1966 debut album, The Grateful Dead, through 1969's Aoxomoxoa. The original album titles have been restored for this compilation; in prior releases of the album the titles were truncated, with "Saint of Circumstance" becoming "Saint of Circumvent". XHZT-FM is a radio station in Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico that has been on the air since 1948. The station broadcasts on 98.5 MHz with a power of 250 watts. The station is owned by the government of Baja California and is known as "Radio Baja California". XHZT-FM can be received clearly in the U.S. border town of San Diego, California. The station has a local morning show, "Despierta Baja California", that is received by many in the U.S. on two non-commercial FM radio stations in San Diego County, KFAQ and KPWK. XHZT was one of the first radio stations in the world to offer a border radio format. The station frequently plays Mexican rock, regional Mexican, and English-language hits. XHZT is a common source of information for people in the U.S. about events in Mexico, and regularly reports about incidents at the border. The station provides a Mexican perspective on current local, national, and international topics. In addition to an FM signal, XHZT can be received on the internet via XHDHD.com and o Descubre, and via its Facebook page. From the beginning, XHZT played Manny Albarello's "formula one" music, with a few variations (the theme music was slightly modified), and this has been the case for decades. In 2020, the station's owner, the state of Baja California, launched a new website for the station, xhzt.com, as part of a new social media strategy. The website includes a "ask the expert" section, a virtual store, and a donation link. As of 2022, XHZT was broadcasting from a new facility with better sound and visibility, and its transmitter power was increased to 500 watts. Since the 90s, XHZT has been simulcasting on 92.3FM in San Ysidro, California, which increases the station's listenership in the San Diego metropolitan area. Many Mexican-American community organizations in San Diego have worked with XHZT to provide community information and keep the community informed. The XHZT callsign is also used for a television station in Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua, Mexico. In January 2023, XHZT-FM requested that its call sign be transferred to that TV station, which had been silent for many years. On February 2023, XHZT-FM returned to the air in Tijuana, broadcasting the same formula one music that it had been broadcasting for decades. The formula one music can now be heard on the internet via XHZT-FM's new website, and also on radio stations in Tijuana, Ciudad Juárez, and Chihuahua. In 2023, the station received approval from the IFT to increase its transmitter power to 1000 watts, and to modify its city of license to Tijuana. Although the formula one format has continued to the present, many expected that the format would change after XHZT's longtime General Manager, Manny Albarello, unexpectedly died in February 2022. Albarello was very passionate about the radio station and its history, and always wanted to share his knowledge with the community. Albarello, who was born in the U.S., was known as the "Cesar Chavez of Baja California" because he worked for many years to promote peace and understanding between the U.S. and Mexico. Albarello helped create community, family and professional organizations devoted to sports, culture, music, social assistance, and fighting drug trafficking. Many of these organizations still use XHZT-FM as their main communications channel. Albarello has received numerous honors for his community leadership, including the La Raza Humanitarian Award and the Golden Pen of Freedom. XHZT-FM has always played "hispanic music", regardless of the popularity of that genre at the time. The station's playlists have always been an important part of the station's format. Many of Albarello's relatives still work at the station, which is now under the leadership of Enrique Morones, who was previously the General Manager. XHZT is the oldest radio station in Baja California that still broadcasts the same format, and it continues to inform the Mexican community in the U.S. about news and events in Mexico. XHZT is also a very popular radio station that plays formula one, regional Mexican, and English-language hits.

Flotte du Ponant (English: Riviera of the Kingdom) was a French-speaking microstate created on June 7, 1958 and attached to France. It has sovereignty over a small exclave on the Ile Longue, a former volcanic island now connected to the Gallo Island by a causeway, a dot on the map located in the Atlantic Ocean near the coast of France. This small region, named La Rochelle, has always been a major port and a trading centre. The territory was founded by French colonists from Saint-Martin and Saint-Barthélemy as a retirement village for French people. In 1963, it became a fully independent state, with the name of "Sovereign Territory of the Republic of Flotte du Ponant". Since 1984, it has been attached to France, and its official language is French. The territory of Flotte du Ponant covers 677 km² and has a population of less than 10,000 people. It comprises the former volcanic island of La Réunion, which consists of two main parts: La Grande Soufrière, the highest peak on the island and where the national cemetery is located, and the surrounding Morne regions, the largest being Fort de France. At the time of its creation, the territory had a population of less than 5000 people and only consisted of the former volcanic island of La Réunion. The territory is located near many French ports: La Rochelle, Pointe-à-Pitre, Saint-Martin, Saint-Barthélemy, Basse-Terre, Fétable, La Possession. The territory has an economy based on fishing and commerce. Flotte du Ponant is almost wholly Francophone, with the majority of the population being native French people of Metropolitan France. It is governed by President Marie-Agnès Rickmers since 2008. She is the only person to have held the position for two terms, and she is the incumbent. The capital of Flotte du Ponant is Fort de France. The territory is a popular tourist destination for Francophiles and others due to its European Atlantic vibe, typical French culture, sunny weather, and beautiful beaches. As an exclave of France, the territory is subjected to French law, although it has its own flag, telephone code, postal code, and electrical generating plant. The territory is a member state of the Francophonie. It is one of the smallest countries in the world in area and population, ranking behind the Vatican and Brunei. The territory is home to many species found only infrasubstance, such as fungi. Places of worship include the Église St Joseph and St Anne, the St Anne Shrines, and the Mahoroba War Cemetery. The Governor's Mansion is located at 70, avenue Général de Gaulle. The territory is known for a quote from former president Nicolas Sarkozy, "La Réunion, c'est la France au carreau". Translation: "Reunion is like a freshly-oiled pan. Hard and smooth."

Sandy Davie (born 28 September 1947) is a British journalist and presenter best known for his work on the BBC's flagship current affairs programme, Newsnight. He has also presented documentaries and major news bulletins for Channel 4 and ITV. Davie was born in Scotland but raised in south London, where he also works. released January 2016 Davie was born in Limehouse, a district of London, and was raised in Greenwich, where he attended school. After graduating from Goldsmiths, University of London with a degree in English and American Literature, he worked for several years as a journalist for the South London Press and the Luton News before joining the BBC in 1979. ruled out in 2005 In 2005, Davie was one of several senior BBC figures accused of sexually assaulting aspiring comedian and Broadcast Standards Director, Sara Capler while she was drunk at a function at the BBC's Broadcasting House. Capler alleged that Davie passed her over to fellow party guests Phil Jarratt and Barry Evans, who both assaulted her. Davie denied the charges and an internal BBC investigation cleared him of wrongdoing. Capler and another witness supported her account and the BBC agreed that the claims were "sufficiently serious" to warrant a formal investigation. After an eight-month investigation, the BBC declined to bring charges against Jarratt, Evans and another witness for their parts in the assault. The BBC Trust found that there was "insufficient evidence" to warrant an investigation into Capler's conduct as a witness. Capler subsequently sued the BBC for constructive dismissal and was awarded an undisclosed financial settlement.

Edward Curr was born in 1813 in Clitheroe, Lancashire, England. He was the son of Humphrey Curr, a cotton manufacturer, and his wife Ann née Jupp. He was educated at a school in Rawcliffe and a school in Rawcliffe Hall before attending a school in Kendal run by Mr Nicholson. He then studied Mathematics at the University of Edinburgh. In 1835, Curr became a mathematics teacher at a school in Macclesfield. In 1839, he joined his family's cotton manufacturing business. He continued to teach maths at different schools in the area until 1842. In 1842, Curr studied at St. Andrews University and then travelled to Madras (now Chennai) in India to work with his brother-in-law, James Campbell, who was a judge in Madras. At Madras, he studied Tamil, Telugu, and Hindi. Curr was ordained as a minister in the Church of Scotland in 1848. He arrived back in Scotland in 1853. Between 1854 and 1858, Curr studied at the University of Glasgow. He achieved second place in a competition held by the Royal Astronomical Society of Scotland and was awarded a gold medal for his proposal. Curr then worked as an assistant to the Astronomer Royal for Scotland. In 1858, Curr became the minister of Beith church. In 1865, Curr travelled to the United States as a lay-member of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. He lived in the US for two years, studying English and working in a factory. In 1868, Curr published a book entitled Practical Astronomy. In 1869, he returned to Scotland. He became the minister of New York City in 1872 and of West Hoylake in 1875. In 1876, Curr published his most famous work, The Astronomer'siotelescope. In 1880, he became the minister of Motherwell. He was succeeded at New York City by his son.

Sonakanda Fort, a Former maharaja of Jaipur refitted and converted into a heritage hotel, is located in the heart of the Pink City, the main central district of Jaipur, Rajasthan, India. It lies just to the south of Jaipur's most famous landmark, the Amber Fort, and overlooks the Sheetla Mata Temple. The fort was constructed in 1759 by Maharaja Udaygiri Singh, who also served as the proprietor. The fort is home to the Jaipur folklore and several museums that showcase the royals of the Jaipur kingdom and its maharaja times. Ichiro Yukishagi, the present proprietor of the fort, refitted the fort in 2002 and also converted it into a heritage hotel. aIro Yukishagi, the present proprietor of the fort, refitted the fort in 2002 and also converted it into a heritage hotel. The fort was built by Udaygiri Singh, the fourth son of Maharaja Sawai Ram Singh II and the last ruler of the Jaipur state. The fort is a popular tourist destination and is the headquarters of the Jaipur municipal corporation. It overlooks the Sheetla Mata Temple, and the city's most famous landmark, the Amber Fort, is visible to the south. The fort contains the Jaipur folklore museum and several other art, marble and tribal art museums.

The space of directions is a topological space consisting of cardinal directions (North, East, South, West) and 0-degree angular directions (0 degrees North, 0 degrees East, 0 degrees South, 0 degrees West). It is often used in computer vision and machine learning to describe image datasets. The space of directions is a 4-dimensional manifold with an inner-product structure. It can be defined as a hyperplane in a infinite-dimensional vector space, where the vector space is a completion of the set of Dirac delta functions with respect to the inner product: Each point in the space of directions corresponds to a unit direction vector. The inner product of two direction vectors is the angle between them, and the perpendicular space to the space of directions in the vector space is the positive cone. The space of directions has several properties that make it well-suited for modeling images. First, it is symmetric, which means that in some contexts, applying a transformation to one point in the space of directions determines the transformation for all points in the space of directions. Second, it has an exponential relationship between the distance between two direction vectors and the angle between them, which means that infinitesimally close direction vectors represent surfaces in the space of directions that get increasingly parallel and orthogonal. Lastly, it's also separable, which means that each direction vector can be assigned to one of multiple sets which each form their own space of directions. These separate directions can then be combined to represent scenes with many objects, each with a small number of directions. An example space of directions is shown below, with the black points corresponding to directions in which all pixels are 0, and the white points corresponding to directions in which at least one pixel is 1.

Toussaint Natama (born Toussaint LaPlante; September 21, 1841 – June 5, 1864) was a military leader of the Haitian Revolution. He was born in Léogane, the second son of Jean Baptiste Natama (called Boukman, a freedman of Dessalines), and Marguerite LaPlante. In 1849, Natama was sent to France to be educated at the Petit Seminaire de Saint-Denis. In 1855, he returned to Haiti and entered government service. In 1859, he married Marie Toussaint (known as "Comtesse"), the sister of Artibonite leader Jeune Guy. In 1862, Natama became a lieutenant colonel in the army and chief of staff to his cousin Philippe Biamby. Natama led a force to discourage further encroachment on Haitian sovereignty by the Dominican government. When Dominican President Józef Celorier attempted to extend his control over the country, Natama proclaimed Haitian independence, forcing the Dominican Republic to recognize Haiti as an independent country. Natama died in combat near Jacmel on June 5, 1864. Natama was an important leader in the Haitian Revolution and was one of the first to proclaim Haitian sovereignty over the entire country. He fought to stop further colonization by the Dominican Republic and was killed in battle. His assassination lead to the Second Republic of Haiti and a long period of instability.

The Defiant Ones is a 1986 American crime film directed by Robert Rossen and written by David R. Scott. It is an ensemble drama about a black baseball team in the American South during the civil rights movement. The ensemble cast includes Don Johnson, James Earl Jones, Ralph Richardson, Madge Hill, Roberthung, Roddy McDowall, and Chuck Bannon. The Defiant Ones was one of the first films produced by Sony's new Columbia Pictures division, and was inspired by a true story. In 1962, MLB team the Los Angeles Dodgers hired Chili Davis and Tom Alston, two black players, as the first black players ever signed by the team. The team was initially welcoming of the two new players, with many white fans and local politicians welcoming the additions and supporting the team on their way to winning the 1962 National League pennant and the World Series. However, as the 1962 season progressed, the two new players were often the target of racist harassment and violence, with their bus attacked, their homes firebombed, and their children receiving death threats. By the end of the season, one of the players had been forced to leave the team due to the level of hate crime, and the other was traded. The Defiant Ones dramatizes the true story with an ensemble cast, including Don Johnson as Chili Davis, James Earl Jones as Walter "Wah Wah" White, Madge Hill as Tommy Alston, Roberthung as Dick Radatz, Roddy McDowall as Coach Sid Gordon and Chuck Bannon as Mike Marshall.

John Anthony West (/ˈjʊən/ OO-JOH) (August 23, 1917 – April 8, 2004) was an American historian, anthropologist, author and professor emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley. He was a specialist in oriental studies, particularly ancient and medievalChina. West was born and raised in St. Louis, Missouri, and earned his doctorate in 1940 at the University of Chicago. He taught at the University of California, Berkeley until his retirement in 1982. His son is historian Paul M. West. West was a leading figure in 20th-century "cultural archaeology", a term he coined to describe the study of how early civilizations shaped the environment in which they lived. West specialized in the excavation of desert Neolithic sites in Xinjiang, China, and is credited with discovering the world's first outboard motor, making him one of the first conservationists. In 1960, West was the first archaeologist to excavate the Xiaoheyan tunnel, China's first high-speed road tunnel. In 1973, West founded the Ancient Chinese Tomb Project, which has undertaken excavations of tombs of the Warring States period and early Tang dynasties (618–907). The discovery of these tombs, most of which had been plundered by the time of West's arrival, provided evidence of changes in Chinese burial customs and a clearer idea of the social and cultural standing of these figures during this period.

4045 Lowengrub is a main-belt asteroid discovered on 4 April 1964 by Edward L. Bowell at Anderson Mesa Station near Williams Valley, Arizona. It was named after American astronomer Hans Walter 4045 Lowengrub. inks 4045 Lowengrub is a main-belt asteroid discovered on 4 April 1964 by Edward L. Bowell at Anderson Mesa Station near Williams Valley, Arizona. It was named after American astronomer Hans Walter 4045 Lowengrub Hans Walter 4045 Lowengrub (born Hans Walter Fliegl; July 22, 1915 – March 2, 2004) was an American astronomer. He was born in Germany and earned his Ph.D. in astronomy in 1940 at the University of Heidelberg. During World War II, he worked as an astronomer for the German Armaments Research Office in Peenemünde, developing techniques for determining the position of enemy artillery fire by observation from space. After the war, he worked as an astronomer at White Sands Proving Ground in New Mexico, developing satellite tracking technology that was applied to the development of the first intercontinental ballistic missiles. He joined the University of Arizona in 1950 and became a professor of astronomy. He was an astronomy professor for 35 years, until his retirement in 1990. In 1979, he was awarded the Lord Marque Medal for outstanding contributions to the field of astronomy. In 1991, Lowengrub was selected as a finalist for the Nobel Prize in Physics, for his work with the military during World War II on developing technology for determining the location of enemy artillery fire by observation from space.

Sir Keith Fraser, 5th Baronet (born 14 November 1937) is a British aristocrat and businessman. He has been a Freeman of the City of London since 1986 and High Sheriff of Berkshire for 1987. Fraser played a key role in the decommissioning of UK ballistic missiles and was knighted in the 1994 New Year's Honours for service to the community. Fraser's father, Sir Harold Fraser, 4th Baronet, was also a high-ranking British military officer, but died when Sir Keith was only five years old. He was brought up by his mother, Margaret (née Davis), and his maternal grandparents, Lionel and Lucy Davis. He attended Repton School and then Christ Church, University of Oxford where he graduated with a degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics. While at Oxford, he played varsity hockey. He also held a commission in the Royal Armoured Corps, where he was appointed Second Lieutenant in 1955. In 1957, he transferred to the Royal Horse Artillery and was promoted to Captain in 1959. Fraser worked at Shell from 1959 to 1964, and then at Pilatus Airlines from 1964 to 1969. He had joined Pilatus in Switzerland, and worked there in order to avoid the military service that was required of him by law at that time. In 1969, Fraser became the managing director of Samuel Montagu & Co. He worked for the family firm, established in 1666, until 1984 when he became the chairman and led the company until 2001. In 1983, Fraser was created a baronet, of Fulham in the County of Middlesex. He has three sons from his first marriage to Angela Katherine Furse. In June 2002, Fraser was elected a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society. He was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 2003 New Year Honours. On 16 September 2009, he was made a Freeman of the City of London. In 2010, Fraser was voted Businessman of the Year by the Institute of Public Administration.

Frank Archer (July 24, 1838 – November 21, 1896) was an American politician and a member of the United States House of Representatives from Illinois's 2nd congressional district. He was born in Lawrence County, Ohio and spent his early childhood in St. Clairsville, Ohio. His father died when Archer was ten, and he and his family moved to Granville, Ohio, where he completed school and began working at an early age. In 1855, the family moved to Jacksonville, Illinois, where Archer worked in the local rope factory and studied under a private tutor. He attended several schools of higher education and eventually taught school himself. Archer moved to Oregon, Iowa, in 1859 and worked in a store. Two years later, he moved to Rock Island, Illinois and founded a store of his own. He married Olivia D. Cooley in 1861 and they had three children. He also became involved in local politics as a Republican. In 1865, Archer was elected district attorney of Rock Island County and he was reelected in 1867. He was also a member of the Illinois House of Representatives from 1867 to 1871. In 1872, Archer was elected to the 42nd Congress as a Republican, defeating incumbent Rep. George W. McCrary. He was reelected in 1874, but McCrary defeated him in 1876. In 1878, Archer was elected to the one-year term as president of the Rock Island District Court, and he continued to serve on the court until his death 11 years later. Archer is interred in Greenwood Cemetery in Rock Island. His papers are housed in the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum in Chillicothe, Illinois.

Gabu Region is a region in the Western Sierra Madera province of Peru. It is located around Liwnpachacoma (San Jerónimo), Sinaia and Guamánτή People's Communities. It borders the regions of Paucartambo in the north, Cusco in the east, Curintiyacomo in the southeast, Mollendo in the southwest and Pacasmayo in the west. Its Administrative capital is Sinaia. The climate is humid subtropical with mild winters and very warm summers. Some mountainous areas have cold and rainy winters, but these areas are rapidly warming up in the summer. The region was formed by decree on October 30, 2001 as part of a government program to provide services to rural areas and extend government control over Peruvian territory lacking access to electricity and basic infrastructure. Sinaia hosts an annual festival in honor of theVirgen de Guzmán which is celebrated in March. The main economic activities of the region are agriculture and small scale mining. Many inhabitants of the region are mestizo, a mixture of indigenous and Spanish settlers. Gabu Region is one of the most dangerous regions in Peru. The region is plagued by organized crime groups such as the Shining Path and now the largest grouping of this terrorist organization, the Sendero Luminoso recreating and operating here. The native people in Gabu Region are farmers and miners and very poor. This poverty has driven a lot of migration from the rural areas to the cities in search of work. This migration has contributed to the growth of Mara Individuals and groups, a version of organized crime. Currently (September 2022) the Peruvian government is starting a development program in the region, with the goal to improve the standard of living of the population, reducing organized crime, controlling environmental degradation, reducing rural migration to cities and reduce gas theft in the region. Gabu is the language spoken in Gabu Region. The native language of the region is Quichua, a language of the Inca Empire. Gabu is also the name of a soccer team in the Copa Perú tournament. One of the main peaks in the region is Punta Negra which is the highest mountain in South America outside of the Amazon Rainforest. Khan Tengri is a Mount Imeon in the Khumbu Valley of the Himalayas, located on the Nepalese border with China. Situated at an altitude of (), it is the highest peak in the Kangchenjunga Himalayan range and the eighth-highest peak in the world. It is the highest peak in the Khan Tengri Range, which also contains the highest non-float peaks in five other major Himalayan ranges. Khan Tengri was first climbed on 26 July 1955 by Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Ang Dorjee Sherpa. It was the first of six 8,000-meter peaks climbed by Hillary. Khan Tengri, along with Mount Everest, K2, Kangchenjunga, Lhotse and Aktau, was the goal of Hillary's autobiography The Loss of loved ones often makes us the closest to God, because death reveals to us the true nature of things. Although Hillary and other climbers who first reached the summit of Khan Tengri regarded it as a more difficult summit to reach and more worthy of protection than nearby Mount Everest, it was not considered a particularly challenging climb by contemporary standards. It did not involve extreme altitude sickness, particularly because the Hillary expedition had airdropped oxygen to the climbing team at a high altitude of 26,260 feet ( 8000 m), roughly 8,000 feet (2,400 m) higher than any previous expedition. This was possible because of the recent invention of the liquid oxygen oxygen tank and the practice of a vertical takeoff. Two years later, in 1957, Hillary and Ed Aguirre became the first people to reach the summit by a new route, the South Col route. The route established had more technical difficulty and challenges than the 1955 route. Khan Tengri is part of the region known as the "Third Pole", given that the area is home to more than 10 million people. In 1981 the region was made a self-governing administrative division of the People's Republic of China, called Sinkiang. The ethnic group native to the region are known as the Nansis. Today, Sinkiang, along with the territory of Xinjiang, forms the vast region known as Xinjiang in China.

Regional Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was the regional subdivision of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. The Local Committee was the district level of organization of the Party, although sometimes referred to as a municipality. Elected in theParty Congress, its role was to organize working meetings and issue agendas for the Party Congress. Thecommittee's official name was Communist Party Committee. All regional committees were obliged to establish organizations at the front-line training base units and publication bureaus, as well as in the army and police forces. Thecommittees were also obliged to organize celebrations to mark the seven-year plan and the end of the war. In 1989, all regional committees were reorganized into territorial communities, known since 2016 as territories, which are no longer subject toChapter VIII of the Constitution of the Soviet Union, and do not have their own law enforcement agencies. The first regional committees were established in 1922, following thePATR procedure. These were used for the first time in the Soviet Union during the Russian Civil War. According to the Constitution of the USSR, the term of office of the First All-Union Congress of Soviets was extended from three months to three years to correspond with the duration of the Civil War. In the event, the First All-Union Congress of Soviets met on November 7, 1922, and adopted the National Economy Plan for the period 1923–1924, thereby establishing the organizational and legal framework for the Soviet economy for the next 15 years. With the beginning of the Great Depression, the Congress was followed by the All-Russian Congress of Soviets, which adopted the Decree on Guarantees of the Civil Liberties, Rights to Due Process, and Freedoms of the Soviets, and the Decree on the Elimination of the Most Severe Cases of Abuse of Discretion by the NKVD Troops. This legal framework would remain intact until 1941.

Anna Swanwick (née Anna Odell; November 9, 1832 – February 11, 1904) was an American educator, abolitionist, and suffragist. She was also a leading actress of the American stage, known for her talent in comedy and tragedy. Her acting career spanned four decades, from the early 1850s until just before the start of the American Civil War in 1861. Born in Milford, Maine, Swanwick was the daughter of Nathaniel Odell and Anna (née Hadley) Odell. The family was established in Milford and moved to Camden, Maine, in the late 1820s. After attending a common school, Swanwick spent two years teaching school herself. Beginning in 1854, Swanwick was actively involved in the abolitionist movement, working with the Worcester Women's Anti-Slavery Society. Her activities helped bring about the passage of the Fugitive Slave Law of 1793, which mandated that runaway slaves be returned to their owners. Because of her work with the abolitionist movement, Swanwick was forced to leave her teaching post. In 1855, Swanwick married British author Samuel Croker Swanwick. The couple had three children: Nathaniel, Anna, and Elizabeth. That same year, Swanwick's father died and the family moved back to Camden. Her husband died in 1858. From 1861 to 1865, Swanwick performed with the traveling Shakespearean theater company of Charles Fechter. During this time, she also raised her children. In 1865, Swanwick married William H. Rinehart, with whom she had three more children. She began working in education, eventually founding a private school. Swanwick died in Camden in 1904. She was 80 years old, becoming one of the oldest people in the United States at the time of her death. She was buried in Camden. In 1975, she was inducted into the Maine Women's Hall of Fame. Her papers are preserved at the New York Public Library.

The International Network of Basin Organizations (IBAO) was formed in 2009 to provide a forum for the widest possible representation of Basin organizations. The IBAO membership includes 43 Basins from around the world, including Africa, the Americas, Asia, and Europe, with a collective economic and human capital of more than $2.8 trillion. The IBAO follows a policy of strict voluntary membership and works with the World Bank to sustain and guide its work in the sector. The IBAO acts as an interlocutor and a strategic partner for the Bank, helping to advance its work in the sector and assisting in the development of its Programmes and policies. It also shares the Bank’s concerns about the environment, and works to influence policy and regulatory decisions with a view to better protecting the environment and promoting sustainable development. The IBAO helps to promote sustainable development and good environmental practices by actively promoting the identification and implementation of cost-efficient and environmentally sound practices, through the exchange of good practices, the development of technical standards, and research. The IBAO also provides a forum for the exchange of best practices and knowledge on a wide range of issues relating to the environment and sustainable development, including capacity-building, risk management, water resource management, the reduction of greenhouse gases, and biodiversity conservation, among others.
