Hinagdanan Cave is a show cave located in the Carcar City ng Baguaoblanco, Nueva Ecija, Philippines. The cave is long, with a main branch and two minor branches. It has two floors and a past filled with artifacts. The cave was declared a National Shrine by the National Museum of the Philippines in 2008. Hinagdanan Cave is a show cave located in the Carcar City ng Baguaoblanco, Nueva Ecija, Philippines. The cave is long, with a main branch and two minor branches. It has two floors and a past filled with artifacts. The cave was declared a National Shrine by the National Museum of the Philippines in 2008. Hinagdanan Cave was discovered on December 28, 1965 by Renato Canlas, an employee of the Provincial Government. The cave is named after a local Boholano heroine, Hinagdanan, who resisted the Japanese occupation during World War II. The main branch of the cave was filled with artifacts after Preservationist Director Jesús D. Villa declared it a National Shrine in 2008. The first branch, Hinagdanan II, was discovered on November 5, 1966 by Santiago Ramón, another employee of the Provincial Government. In 2012, a rescue team explored the unexplored middle branch of the cave but could not go all the way through due to tight spaces. It was declared sealed by the provincial government.

Akeem Ward (born Akeem Carlos Starks; January 1, 1973 – December 4, 2019) was an American professional basketball player. He played college basketball at San Diego and attended Everett Golson College. He played in the National Basketball Association for five seasons. After going undrafted in 1995, Ward played for several NBA teams including the Los Angeles Clippers, Cleveland Cavaliers, and Golden State Warriors. He averaged 4.6 points per game in his NBA career. In 2016, he played for the Delaware 87ers of the NBA G League, where he averaged 16.7 points per game. Ward was involved in a car accident in January 2019 that left him with traumatic brain injuries. He died from his injuries two months later, on April 1, 2019. Ward's son Akeem Jr. was born a month after his father died. Ward was raised by his grandmother; his parents had both died by the time of his car accident. Ward's former high school coach, Ed Salmon, described Ward as "the best practice player that I have ever had." Ward's brother, Al, played in the NBA. Ward was engaged to Letitia Wallace. The couple had a son and were in the process of planning a wedding. Ward spoke on his father's death and his own accident in an interview with Jalen Rose that was published in July 2019. He said, "My dad was my hero. My dad took care of me when I was younger. I was thinking about wanting to be like my dad when I grew up. He was thinking about retiring and he had just bought a new house and all that kind of stuff, so I was like, 'Oh, I want to be just like my dad.' Then all of a sudden, that was taken away from me. I had an accident where I was hurt, but I still think my dad was there for me, he was helping me, he was giving me positive vibes. I wasn't saying this to put blame on anybody or anything like that, but I was just really hurt, because I felt like I let my dad down." Ward also spoke about his son, Akeem Jr., in the same interview. Ward said, "My son is going to be really special. My wife Letitia is going to have a lot to do with him just growing up as a man. She's going to spoil him, because she didn't have a father herself when she was growing up. My son is going to have two women in his life, so I'm really happy right now." Ward played professionally until he was 28 years old. He is the only basketball player to die by traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) in 2019. Ward's death was covered by several news outlets, including The New York Times, The Washington Post, ESPN, and The Los Angeles Times. His former teams, and several coaches, remembered Ward on social media. Ward's car accident and subsequent death received a considerable amount of press due to his success in basketball and his tragic accident. The circumstances of his death, and the way it was reported on by news outlets, brought public attention to traumatic brain injuries and their links to car accidents. William Kingsmill (died 1618) was an English politician. He was a Member of Parliament (MP) for Marlborough in 1614. Kingsmill was the son of Robert Kingsmill and Joan Houghton. He was educated at Blundell's School and travelled to Europe with his uncle Thomasine West. He was educated at the University of Leuven and Padua. He was admitted as an Advocate at Lincoln's Inn in 1596. He was a Justice of the Peace for Wiltshire and Marlborough and was appointed High Sheriff of Wiltshire and Marlborough for 1605. He was elected a Member of Parliament for Marlborough in 1614. Kingsmill was a strong Royalist during the English Civil War and was appointed Governor of Sherborne Castle in Dorset. He was taken prisoner after the castle was taken by parliamentary forces in December 1646. He was released from prison in 1658. He died in 1618. At the time of his death, Kingsmill was the ancestor of the influential Edgecumbe family. His son John Kingsmill was also an MP. He was the great-great-grandfather of Sir Richard Edgecumbe, 1st Baronet, of Kingston-upon-Hull. The Robert Kingsmill referred to in this biography was his uncle. He was also an MP and served as High Sheriff of Wiltshire and Marlborough. The Edgecumbe family remain closely connected with Sherborne Castle and its surroundings. The family held the office of Bailiff of the castle from 1756 until the abolition of the post in 1834. As of 1920, the current lord of the manor of Sherborne is Sir Richard's descendant John Westacott Edgecumbe, 6th Baronet. Kingsmill is the great-great-great-great-great-grandfather of John Westacott Edgecumbe, 6th Baronet. The House of Commons Standing Orders of 1614 referred to Kingsmill as "Mr. William Kingsmill of Marldborough". The incorrect surname "Marldborough" was later corrected by the creation of a new constituency named Marlborough in 1754. Kingsmill is the ancestor of the Edgecumbe family, who remained influential in the locality of Sherborne Castle and are the current lord of the manor. His life is described in some detail as he was a strong Royalist during the English Civil War. He was a Justice of the Peace and High Sheriff for Wiltshire and Marlborough. He was elected to the House of Commons for Marlborough in 1614. Kingsmill was subsequently taken prisoner after the fall of Sherborne Castle in 1646. He was released from prison in 1658. He died in 1618.

Kheyrabad, also known as Chayrabad or Chehrabad, is a city in Semnan Province, Iran. The city is located 90 kilometres southeast of Semnan city and has a population of over 200,000 people. The city was founded in 1866 by a general in the Qajar dynasty, Hossein Khan Rechavi. It was named after the Persian poet Hafez. Famous people who were born in Kheyrabad include author Aşèr Hosaini and Shahab Vahabi founder of Persian Department of Moscow State University. The city is home to Al-Masqala football club which is famous in Iranian football. In 2017, a few weeks after the Iranian Revolution, the city was hit by a magnitude 6.3 earthquake. The city was mostly destroyed but was rebuilt within a few years. Kheyrabad's most notable football rival is Semnan. The two teams contest the Battle of Semnan yearly, in which Kheyrabad usually wins. The most famous battle of this series was in 2022 when Semnan beat Kheyrabad 2-0, causing Kheyrabad to be eliminated from the 2022 Persian Cup in the first round. In 2023, Kheyrabad reached the final of the Iranian League Cup but lost to Persepolis 2-1 after a penalty shootout. Kheyrabad is located at 36°47'52" N, 52°16'W and has a cool climate, with average temperature ranging from 16 °C to 22 °C. It is one of the most educated cities in Semnan Province and is known for having one of the biggest Deen education centers in Iran. Several renowned journalists, scientists and businessmen such as Kamran Hajimiri, Mohammad Taghi Paysabak, Mohammad Reza Farrokh and Mohammad Javad Azimi are from Kheyrabad. The most famous personality from Kheyrabad is composer, poet and journalist Ahmad Shamlu who is well-known for writing a famous book "Life is a Tear" about his experience during the Iranian Revolution. He was born in 1902 and died in 1985. Kheyrabad is considered as a city with harmonious ethnic mix. People from over 30 different nationalities live in Kheyrabad, including Assyrians, Arabs, Azerbaijanis, Baluchis, Armenians, Georgians, Hindis, Russians, Uzbeks and many other smaller minorities. The city is famous for having the largest market in Iran named "Grand Bazar" which hosts lots of traditional Persian pottery and carpet shops. Kheyrabad is also home to one of the biggest cooperative groups in Iran named "Behdad Company". The city is renowned for hosting the annual jazz and rock concerts known as "Jazz-e-Kherad". A lot of Iranian and international musicians such as Nicholas Payden, Esfir Shub, Alireza Parsian, Houman Rahmani and Alireza Parhsodani have performed in Kheyrabad. Kheyrabad is one of the safest cities in Iran and has hosted several peace ceremonies such as Persian New Year, International Yoga Day and Arbaeen. Shahin Najafi, the first Iranian supermodel and a former contestant on "The Model" is from Kheyrabad. Sia Aylund, the famous Norwegian singer is also from Kheyrabad. Kheyrabad has one of the oldest vineyards in Iran and is known as "the city of vineyards". It is also famous for producing one of the best Persian cheese in the world called "Bamiyan". Kheyrabad is also famous for producing some of the best cars in Iran such as Iran Khodro, Saipa and Iraku. The city is famous for its ancient architecture and is one of the most important historical cities in eastern Iran. Kheyrabad is a popular city for tourists, especially for those who love history and want to witness Iranian traditional life. The city was proclaimed as one of the most beautiful cities in Iran and was selected as the cultural city of Semnan in 2018. The city is famous for holding the annual "Iran oil Festival" that showcases oil industry in Iran and usually hosts Iranian president and some ministers. Kheyrabad is also home to famous warriors such as Abdulali, Shirzai, Fazli, Nader Shah and Alqasem among others. Nodular fasciitis is a reactive process that has been reported to mimic a soft-tissue neoplasm, most often a low-grade sarcoma. It is most frequently observed in young females. The tumor is most common on the extremities and rarely involves the trunk. This paper presents 5 cases of nodular fasciitis in the extremities of women aged 23-38 years, occurring on the hand, forearm, thigh and calf. The clinical and histologic features of nodular fasciitis are discussed and the literature is reviewed.<|endoftext|>Prodromou Prodromou is a surname. Turkish Cypriots are an ethnic group and part of the larger Cyprus population. They live mainly on the island of Cyprus, as well as in Turkey. Their number is approximately 1.4 million. fallout Cyprus was split into two states following the 1963 Cyprus crisis. While both ethnic groups live on the island, today's Republic of Cyprus includes the majority of the population, while the Turkish Cypriot community is supported by Turkey. Wilkinson County School District is a public school district in Wilkinson County, Alabama, United States. It is headquartered in Monticello, which is also the county seat. The district has one elementary school, one middle school, and one high school. As of the 2014-15 school year, the Wilkinson County School District has a total enrollment of 1,024 students and 101 employees. Wilkinson County School District covers an area of 9.23 square miles (or 23 km2). Of this, school property covers 5.61 square miles (or 14 km2). The average population density of the school property is 44 people per square mile The Wilkinson County School District has one elementary school with 105 students and eight teachers, one middle school with 122 students and eight teachers, and one high school with 160 students and 23 teachers. The district has one superintendent, Dr. Scott Walls, two business administrators, and four principals. The Wilkinson County School District has four schools with grades kindergarten through eight. One of the schools, Monticello Primary School, is on the same property as the Monticello Middle School and the Monticello High School. The Wilkinson County School District has two schools for boys and two schools for girls. All of the schools are on different property from each other. The Wilkinson County School District has a total of 101 employees, including 68 teachers. The student–teacher ratio is 13:1. The Wilkinson County School District funds 19% of its budget from local taxes, 30% from state funds, and 51% from federal funds. Of the total enrollment, 42% are Hispanic, 25% are Black, 14% are White, and 11% are two or more races. Wilkinson County School District students range from early childhood education through 12th grade. The Wilkinson County School District has an enrollment of 1,024 students and 101 employees. Helga Stephenson (born Helga Patricia Stephenson; 22 May 1917 – 11 March 2001) was a British screenwriter. She was nominated for two BAFTA Awards and three British Academy Film Awards. She was born in Norwich and died in London. Her parents were Walter Stephenson, a gravestone cutter, and his wife Elizabeth (née Harrison). She had an older brother and a younger sister. Stephenson was raised in Norwich and became a tearopper at 14. She married amateur dramatics promoter John Spence, with whom she had two children; they later divorced. In 1937, aged 18, she joined the Theatre Workshop, where she worked until 1939. During World War II, Stephenson worked as a WRNS officer interpreter. After the war, she worked as a freelance writer, writing radio plays and contributing to several British film magazines. She married director Michael Powell in 1948; they had one child. Her first big screenplay was for Powell's groundbreaking film noir 49 Steps (1935). She was an assistant to Powell and Robert Woodruff on tear-jerker Clara's Esimes (1946) and the film noir Up at the Villa (1953). She also worked as a script editor, first on Powell's adaptation of Jane Austen's Emma (1952) and then for his costume drama Black Narcissus (1954). She was nominated for two BAFTA Awards and three British Academy Film Awards and won the BAFTA Award for Best British Screenplay for Powell's debut film, Key Card (1954). She worked with Powell again on another BAFTA Award winning film, The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1965). Her other works include the British comedy Calendar, based on the stage farce of the same name, starring Harry Fowler and Flora Robson; and the biblical epic Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, for which she was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Story and shared in the award for Best Adapted Screenplay with Michael Comiskey. She was also the last compiler of the Oxford English Dictionary. She was made an OBE in 1965. Stephenson's work includes the screenplays for 49 Steps (1935), Clara's Esimes (1946), Up at the Villa (1953), Black Narcissus (1954), The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1965), Calendar (1968) and Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat (1970), for which she was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Story and shared in the award for Best Adapted Screenplay with Michael Comiskey. Stephenson was made an OBE in 1965. She was nominated for two BAFTA Awards and three British Academy Film Awards. She died in March 2001, aged 86, in London.

Pseudothurmannia is a controversial genus of the fungi family Schizophyllaceae, with sexual morph Nigrospora and anamorphic (asexual) morph Pseudothurmanniella. It was described by Petr Brundgt in 1987 with the type species Pseudothurmannia hypericinium. The generic name honors mycologist Walther Johannes Crotzides, who created the family Pseudothurmanniaceae in 1958 to contain the type species of Pseudothurmannia, P. kanzleri. Pseudothurmannia has been characterised as a genus of uncertain placement, with its species formerly classified in genera such as Chaetomella, Chaetomidium and Chaetothyriophora. An increasing number of molecular studies place Pseudothurmannia in a distinct family Pseudothurmanniaceae, along with the genera Nigrospora and Nigrosporum. The genera Chaetomella, Chaetomidium and Chaetothyriophora are classified in the family Chaetomiaceae. The type species, Pseudothurmannia hypericinium, grows on decomposing wood, and has more pigments than most species of Nigrospora or Nigrosporum. The conidiophores are composed of metula, metulae and phialides, and the phialides have collarettes. Nigrospora and Nigrosporum have metula and metulae, and Chaetomiaceae has metula only. There is genetic and morphological evidence supporting the placement of Pseudothurmannia in a separate family. Chaetomiaceae has 17 to 19-celled conidia with cicatrices, while Nigrospora and Nigrosporum have 14 to 15-celled conidia without cicatrices. The two alternatives to placing Pseudothurmannia in a new family are to either synonymize it with Chaetomella, Chaetomidium and Chaetothyriophora or create a new family for it. The generic name Pseudothurmannia has been conserved over the other choices. Illinois Route 133 (IL 133) is a state route in southern Illinois, United States, that parallels a stretch of Interstate 55. The southern terminus of the route is at Illinois Route 40 near Charleston; the northern terminus is at the Indiana state line near Machens. The roadway that is now IL 133 was originally established as a county road in Randolph County in 1908; the current configuration of the route was established in 1937. The route has had only minor realignments since then. The road is located in rural areas with an agriculture-related theme. Through 2020, Illinois had considered changing the route's number to honor President Ronald Reagan. The route had originally been designated as U.S. Route 66 in 1925; Reagan was known for his support of preserving the Route 66 landmarks. The Illinois Department of Transportation announced in 2013 that it would preserve the history of the highway but replace the number with a slogan. "There it is—the Main Street of Route 66" was chosen as the central theme for the new highway designation, and reflective median dividers were painted into the road. History The roadway that became IL 133 was established in 1908 as a county road in Randolph County. The current configuration of the route was established in 1937. The route has had only minor realignments since then. In the 1920s, the road that became IL 133 was designated as U.S. Route 66, which connected St. Louis, Missouri, to the West Coast. The road passed through several communities with named streets such as Alley, Arcade, and Mound. The Illinois Department of Transportation announced in 2013 that it would preserve the history of the highway but replace the number with a slogan. "There it is—the Main Street of Route 66" was chosen as the central theme for the new highway designation. Reflective median dividers were painted into the road.

Johnny Hopp (February 6, 1911 – November 22, 1998) was an American baseball right-handed pitcher who played in Major League Baseball from 1935 through 1954 for the Philadelphia Phillies, Chicago Cubs, Cincinnati Reds, and Brooklyn Dodgers. Hopp was born in Kansas City, Missouri and attended the University of Missouri before he was signed by the Phillies. In 1935 Hopp had one of the most remarkable rookie seasons in baseball history. Playing in 28 games, Hopp went 15-7 with a 2.34 earned run average. His 15 wins were a Phillies team record that stood until 1959, and his overall ERA was second best in the National League (N L) only to 1938 New York Giants pitchers Christy Mathewson and Carl Hubbell. In 1936 Hopp started 27 games, finishing with a 12-8 record and a 2.55 ERA. His 12 victories were a team high and second best in the N L. Hopp was almost completely blocked by white All-Stars Willie Mays, Hank Aaron and Roberto Clemente in the 1940s. But in 1945 Hopp led the N L in complete games (38) and innings pitched (247.0) and finished third in the league in wins (16) and strike out (184). The 1945 Phillies won the National League Pennant but lost the World Series to the cross-town rivals, the Cincinnati Reds. Hopp played his final game at the age of 46 in 1953. His record was 184-130.

The Holiday Report is an annual subscription-based report produced by the American television network NBC News. It debuted during the 2015 calendar year and is presented in a video format. It covers notable events that occurred during the last calendar year, 2020, and the first few months of 2021. As its name suggests, the report is meant to serve as a "holiday" for the audience, providing a quick glimpse of notable events and deaths that occurred during the last year and a few words about each. The format of the report borrows from that of news retrospectives, such as those published by NBC in the late 1980s and 1990s during the decade-long Cold War with the Soviet Union. The first Holiday Report, covering the year 2020, featured events such as the breakout of the Covid-19 pandemic and the United States Presidential election. The format was altered the following year, covering the year 2021, to present both positive and negative events in a bid to provide a more upbeat report in the wake of the devastation caused by the novel coronavirus and subsequent recession. As of 2023, a total of nine Holiday Reports have been published, the most of any year. The 2020 edition was the most-watched of the series to date, with more than four million viewers across three different platforms (NBC News online, NBC Nightly News, and the NBC News app). The Holiday Report has occasionally inspired parodies on the internet, especially on Twitter, where #Holiday hashtag has been widely used to poke fun at various trends that surfaced in the report.

Ohms is an alias for Jon Cohen, a American singer-songwriter and record producer. Cohen began his career in the early 1990s as a member of rock band Blue Sky Black Death. After going by the name Ohms and producing several instrumental hip hop albums under the moniker Asciic返ASCII, Cohen decided to change his musical style and started utilizing vocals. In 2001, he released his debut album under the name Ohms. The album was a critical and commercial success, and became a staple in the downtempo scene. Ohms' second album, Out of the Past, was released in 2003. It featured collaborations with notable artists such as David Burden, Tino Corpus, and Alistair Marsh. The album was again well received by the critics, although the music industry saw little success for it, leading Cohen to pursue a career in film scoring. In 2014, Cohen returned to his hip hop roots and released the Ohms 2 album. The album featured rappers such as Kool AD, Crooked Law, and Chala. Despite critical acclaim, the album did not receive the same commercial success as the first two albums. Ohms went through several lineup changes through the years. After briefly collaborating with Elucid in 2017, Cohen returned in 2019 with the release of Mycelium. The album featured collaborations with Elucid as well as American rapper k.one and electronic artist Tim Green. Ohms' discography consists of four studio albums, several compilation albums and many music videos.

The Captain Benjamin Williams House located at 1313 East 10th Street in Little Rock, Arkansas is a historic house that was built in 1912. The house was designed in the Colonial Revival style by architect Robert Swain Smith. It was home of Governor and Mrs. Earle C. Clements from 1912 to 1917. It was purchased by the Arkansas Children's Hospital in 1939 and was used as a pediatrics ward. It was purchased by the state of Arkansas in 1971 and was used as the Governor's Mansion until 2004 when it was restored to its current use. The Mother/Child Papers was a game invented by Gary Grigsby, Mike Kennedy, and Jason DeRose, which involved secretly observing one's parents interact, with the intent to disclose the information to one's children in later years. It was originally conceptualized while the developers were students at Rochester Institute of Technology. The game was the subject of an episode of Podtoid Convictions, a podcast by comedy writer Jacob Grumetti. The game includes four components: a secret box, observation slips, a codebook, and a decoder ring. The secret box contains a book describing the history of the game, observation slips written by the player's parents during their play, a codebook with clues for decoding the slips, and a decoder ring used to reveal details of the game to the player. The game was typically played at Christmas or on special occasions during a child's life. The player was typically an adult by the time the game was played, and typically had two children. The rules of the game often changed throughout the life of the player, with new layers of complexity being added as the player grew older. The observation slips were written in code, with words or phrases written in brackets hinting to the parent to leave more explicit clues in the text. Parents were instructed to only decode the slip once they had informed their children of its meaning. For example, the phrase "Build a snowman" might be written in the codebook with the instruction "Insert the following sentences when your child asks why you are writing in a secret code: [Because I'm writing a book about The Mother/Child Papers]". The game was always recommended to be played with children that were older than seven years old, and the parent was encouraged to only tell a small amount of lies to the child. The game was often described as providing a "safe" way for parents to discuss taboo subjects with their children, in an environment where the child could not ask questions and the parent could not tell the whole truth. However, several adults confessed to the game stated that they did not feel comfortable with the game's recommended age limit, and proceeded to secretly record their parents while they were not aware of it. Grigsby, Kennedy, and DeRose became aware of public interest in the game after their Podtoid Convictions episode received over a million views on YouTube and 500,000 views on the AltWeb.org video platform. They decided to release the game publicly after a suggestion from Patty McCord, who went on to work for CNN, with the goal to raise awareness of the game's importance as a tool for child observation and discussion. The game has been met with praise for its simulation of the taboo topics that real-life parents try to avoid, the realism of the observed actions, and the creativity of the story telling techniques that had to be used in order to explain the slips. Many journalists and parent advocates alike believe that the game should become a standard part of parent playbook materials, to be used with any child at any age.

Signal Hill - Quidi Vidi is a town in the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador, on the Avalon Peninsula on the island of Newfoundland. The town is located approximately 30 km east of St. John's. The population of the town is less than 1,000. The area was first settled in 1807 by immigrants from Scotland and Ireland. It was officially incorporated as a town in 1955. It takes its name from its close proximity to Signal Hill, a steep-sided headland overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. In 2017, Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi was briefly thrust into world news headlines due to Newfoundland's new provincial government, who introduced a bill to rename the town's airport, "Joe Hogan Field", in honour of the late Newfoundland and Labrador Liberal MP and former Deputy Premier. The bill passed the Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly but was struck down by the Newfoundland and Labrador Senate. Avenue u-turns are banned in the town. Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi is well known as a popular summer destination for residents of St. John's, the capital of Newfoundland, and around the Avalon Peninsula, due to its relatively central location and temperate climate. The area has several small lakes ideal for swimming, fishing and general recreation. The community centre is located on Victoria Avenue, close to the centre of the town. The Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi Tourist Association maintains a website with detailed information on activities and attractions in the area, as well as a listing of local accommodation providers. The community of Quidi Vidi, located across the Trout River to the south, is home to Signal Hill Farmer's Market, a popular weekly event held on Saturday mornings throughout the summer. In addition to tourism, the local economy also benefits from the presence of the federal government's Mad Cat zinc mine, located approximately 20 km to the southwest, and linked to the town by an annual event, Signal Hill Festival, which includes a parade and a community bonfire.

55 Cancri is a star system approximately 62 light years from the Earth in the southern constellation of Cancer. It has a mean solar analog is around 65 light years from the Earth. The name 55 Cancri comes from the Arabic phrase "al-Burhān al-Sharīf" meaning the chief lady in the breast. The planet 55 Cancri b is the only known planet to date in the system. The planet is 2.4 times the size of Earth and has an equilibrium temperature of 1450 K, which is hotter than both Venus and Mars. The planet is so hot because it is scorched by its parent star, 55 Cancri A, which has 4.2 times the mass of the Sun and has lived a longer lifespan of 12.3 billion years. The star is named 55 Cancri A. 55 Cancri A is relatively quiet, but its planet 55 Cancri b is being bombarded by rocks from its host star. Due to its proximity to the Earth, 55 Cancri system was one of the first star systems where an Earth-like planet was confirmed to be capable of supporting life. 55 Cancri system is also notable as the first system where the masses of the components were measured in a process known as astrometry. The planet 55 Cancri b is the only known planet to date in the system. The planet is 2.4 times the size of Earth and has an equilibrium temperature of 1450 K, which is hotter than both Venus and Mars. The planet is so hot because it is scorched by its parent star, 55 Cancri A, which has 4.2 times the mass of the Sun and has lived a longer lifespan of 12.3 billion years. The star is named 55 Cancri A. 55 Cancri A is relatively quiet, but its planet 55 Cancri b is being bombarded by rocks from its host star. Due to its proximity to the Earth, 55 Cancri system was one of the first star systems where an Earth-like planet was confirmed to be capable of supporting life. The planet 55 Cancri b is one of the best candidates for "terrestrial exoplanets" because it is in the "habitable zone" of its star, 55 Cancri A, and it is not being heated to a molten state.

Dear Myself You have been sitting on this bench for hours now, scrolling through Facebook, trying to ignore the pain in your legs from all the sitting. The wind is gently blowing through your brown hair, matching the slightly darker brown of the bench you are sitting on. You have realized that you have been in a very deep comparison loop for the last 5 hours, something has been constantly distracting you, and you can't seem to get it out of your head. You start thinking about how you dress, how you compare to how other people dress, how that must be so much easier, how everyone else's life seems to be so much more together than yours. You think about how you haven't spoken to your parents in a year now, because they didn't understand your frustration and were too busy worrying about the fact that you have started to smoke. You think about how you haven't written a letter to yourself in so long, because you weren't sure if you would ever read this letter, and now you feel like you can't read it because you are afraid of what will happen if you don't accomplish everything you set out to do. You start to cry. And then you hear something that snaps you out of it. Someone is playing a guitar not too far away, and the sound of the guitar is amazing. So amazing that it makes you feel like you are 10 years old again, and everything makes sense. You didn't realize how lost you had gotten in your own mind until you heard that guitar and it felt like someone reached into your heart and gave you a kick in the stomach, clearing away all the confusion and angst. You look up and see who is playing and smile. They are really good, you haven't seen a guitarist play in a long time, you have to check them out. The guitarist is sitting on a rug, around a fire, and you have to walk up a small hill to get to them. As you get closer, you see that the guitarist is not alone, there are several other people around the fire with them, and you realize that it is a jam session. Everyone is welcome to play, you can sit, you can dance, you can play. And you play too. You pick up the guitar, you haven't played in a long time, and you start playing along with the others. You are no longer lost, you are home. The song ends, and there is a moment of silence, and then another song starts. It is a slow song, and you put down your guitar and you start dancing. You haven't danced in so long, it feels strange, awkward, but somehow it just comes back to you. The guitar comes back, and you are again lost in your own mind, only this time you are lost in the moment. You close your eyes, and you start moving with the music. The song ends, and there is another moment of silence, and then you see a familiar face. A face that you haven't seen in a long time, a face that you haven't seen at all for the last year. But here it is, and it is beaming at you. You see that it is a song, and the song is called "Dear Myself". You smile, and you start singing along. The song ends, and it is time for another song. And another. And another. And after a few hours the jam session finally comes to an end. Everyone starts to filter out, you haven't seen most of the people who were playing with you, but you are happy to see that you still know most of the others by name. Your legs are a little bit sore from all the dancing, but you know that it will actually be more relaxing to just sit around the fire and talk for a while. The guitar comes back, and you pick it up, and this time you start playing a song for yourself. A song that you have been wanting to play for a long time, a song that you have been thinking about for a long time, a song that you haven't played in a long time, but now feels right in this moment. It takes some time for the song to finish, but when it does you feel satisfied. You walk over to the guitar, and you see something on it. There is a small note that says "Dear Myself, I love you, whatever you do, just love yourself first. Your friend, A" with a heart next to it. You look around and you see other people leaving notes for themselves. One says "Dear Myself, I love you, you can stop eating pasta for once and try something new. Your friend, Giovanni". Another says "Dear Myself, I love you, you have been waiting for this opportunity for so long, go for it!", and there are several other people leaving notes

South Wonston is a small village in the county of Norfolk,England, located about south of London and close to the North Sea coast. It is situated within the district of Waveney, within the county of Norfolk. The village is located close to the A12 and A140 roads and has a common station with buses to Lowestoft, Norwich and North Walsham. South Wonston was in the media spotlight in 2018 when its Church of England parish church was extensively repaired and renewed, including a new pulpit, pews, medieval coffin lid font, Royal Naval flags, lighting and ceiling roses. The village has a public house, the Chequers, which was built in the 17th century. It is now operated as a private house. South Wonston lies just outside the proposed sites for the new High Speed 2 railway and it is expected that development of the railway will be the key future industry for the village. The Cartmel Masterplan is a modernist office village in the Peak District National Park in England. The village was designed in the early 1950s by town planner Patrick Abercrombie in collaboration with architect Robert Matthew Burns. Abercrombie intended the village to be an "ideal community" in which people would live close to where they worked. The village was constructed between 1954 and 1964 in an Erskine type scheme, with three curved terraced streets radiating from a central junction formed by the junction of the principal A6144 road with Chapel Street, the eastern entry to the village. The village is exemplified as a utopian post-war design, with extensive amenities provided within the village. The public houses are considered excellent, and there are large green space areas and a children's play area at the junction of Chapel Street and Ebbw Vale Road. The housing is in a range of heights and styles, with a landscaped garden designed for each house. Residents own their own houses and the village is run as a private community by a homeowners' association. The village is administered from a parish council office in Chapel Street. The village has provided very few lettings over the years, despite its popularity with British people living in the Peak District as a rural idyll, as the maintenance costs are very high. In contrast, the village has always been much less popular with British people living outside of the Peak District, as it is very remote from any main settlements and has a relatively low population.

The Neil Gehrels Archive for Moonwatching, an astronomy blog he started in 2005, was the most widely-read astronomy blog in the world from 2014 until 2019 when it was surpassed by StarTalk Radio. Golyam Rezen is a city in Komi Republic, Russia, located on the Kuloy River, south-east of Kirov and south-west of Cherkessk. It is the administrative center of Golyam Rezen district, and its population was estimated in 2014 to be 19,400. Rezen was first founded in 1597 as a fort against the Tatars and was granted city status in 1782. The city has an agricultural economy, producing potatoes and cattle. From 1739 to 1918, Rezen was the capital of Rezen Governorate. During World War II, from July 1941 to July 1942, Rezen was occupied by Nazi Germany. In 1943, it was the site of a major battle between German and Soviet forces, after which the town was burnt to the ground. In 1958, the city was given the name Golyam Rezen, after the medieval prince RezEpaur. Golyam Rezen is one of the oldest cities in Russia and was one of the capitals of the Komi Republic between 1739 and 1818. During World War II it was occupied by Nazi Germany from July 1941 to July 1942. The town was burnt to the ground by German forces in 1943 but was rebuilt later and now has an agricultural economy. Inhibition of caspase, an essential enzyme in apoptosis, is a potential target for inhibition of apoptosis and thus for treatment of cancers and other diseases. Baculoviruses encode inhibitor of apoptosis (IAP) proteins that interfere with caspases, and we identified a baculovirus inhibitor of caspase-1 (casp-1) homologue from Autographa californica nuclear polyhedrosis virus (AcNPV), named brfv1. Amino acid sequence comparison and bioinformatics analyses revealed that brfv1 shares common features with other known IAP proteins. Recombinant Brfv1 protein contained a thioredoxin-like domain and inhibited caspase-1 and -3 with K(i) of 1.5 and 6 nM, respectively,

Omicron Delta Kappa (ODK) is a co-ed professional business fraternity founded at Miami University in 1875. Its primary purpose is the fostering of friendship and the development of competency in leadership, service, and success through the conduct of business and philanthropic pursuits. Although the organization is no longer active on campus, it is registered as a national fraternity with the Interfraternity Council. I am the new official Wikipedia editor for the Omicron Delta Kappa organization. We are a national professional business fraternity founded at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio in 1875. Our mission is to foster friendship and develop competency in leadership, service, and success through the conduct of business and philanthropic pursuits. Our co-eds are referred to as "Indigos." We are no longer active on campus, but we are registered with the Interfraternity Council as a national fraternity. While we are no longer on campus, we are committed to fostering leadership development in young men. We provide experiential learning by incorporating business and philanthropic pursuits into our programs. Our local chapters organize philanthropic events, such as Relay for Life and The Kappa Sig Thing. Our National Service Days in even numbered years focus on a specific community need and include service learning in partnership with our local chapter organizations. I encourage everyone to check out our Wikipedia page and if you have any questions, feel free to contact me. We are proud of our heritage and look forward to staying involved with the Miami community.

Broad Street School is a historic school at the intersection of Broad and North Broad streets in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It was designed by John Havill and built in 1881. It is three stories in height and nine bays wide. It features paired wooden doors with rounded hoods and windows with rounded sills and lintels. The building is located within the West Market district and is surrounded by commercial buildings. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1972 and was renovated in 2006. The building is owned by a developer and is set to become a 14-story building. Broad Street School was listed as one of the Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS) buildings in the region, and is included in a 1998 survey of historic public and commercial buildings in Philadelphia and the surroundings which was also published by the Library of Congress. In 2009, the Broad Street School was used as a location for a scene in The Social Network, a movie about the founding of Facebook. In 2013, it was announced that a reality show called School Pride, which follows a group of inner-city students through the process of transforming their school into a GCLS (Government-Controlled Living Site), would be filmed at the Broad Street School for its first season. In February 2020, it was reported that the Philadelphia school district was considering selling the Broad Street School due to its "skyrocketing" maintenance costs. It means you’ll be using more water Although you may not notice it right away, turning on a hose to do your dishes or taking a long shower uses more water than usual during a water short. If you haven’t been flushing the toilet as much or showering as often, you might notice increased water usage. But the big water hogs are your lawn and landscaping, your sprinklers, and car washes. The good news is that you can save water and reduce your water bill by doing simple things, like replacing your lawn with drought-tolerant plants and using less water while you’re washing your car. It’s not the end of the world, but it is bad California is in the midst of a historic drought, and it’s getting worse. As of July 2014, 44.5 million people in California were in some stage of water restriction, and some towns have been under a water emergency for nearly two years. While one might think of drought as temporary and a natural part of life in California, it actually caused the state to sell off 28,000 acres of land for redevelopment purposes, 11 million trees were removed to make room for the water they needed to survive, and six counties were declared natural disaster areas. Hurricane water restrictions means most people in California must reduce their water usage by thirty percent. This might sound excessive, but it’s not, because we depend on water for many things, like showering, filling pools, and irrigating lawns and landscapes. During a water emergency, residents are asked to use less water in-between watering schedules, instead of waiting until their next watering schedule, when the water will be even less effective. Empress Ma, wife of Emperor Wu of Han, was born in 26 BCE and died in 8 CE. She was of the Wang clan and was married to Emperor Wu of Han for more than forty years. Little is known about her life, as there are no records of her personally engaging in any acts of political intrigue, and all of what we know about her was recorded down by her second cousin once removed, Marquess of Liexinos, who may have aimed to celebrate her life and promote her legend. Empress Ma is famous in history for building thefirst summer palace, which was close to her home town, and for ending thebitterness of the fallout from the Rebellion of the Seven States by persuading Emperor Wu to pardon the surviving rebels. She is also known for gathering scholars and poets at her court to create an imperial library, and starting the Han Heraldry Office. She died of natural causes sometime in 8 CE. adharcdetails about her family and any other important contributions she made actin Details about her family and any other important contributions she made life Wang Linghao (王齎華), her father, was a government official. In 21 BCE, she married Emperor Wu of Han, who reigned from 8 BCE to 7 CE. Her second cousin once removed, Marquess of Liexinos, wrote an optional biography of her in the "New Book of Tang" (r. 7th century), stating that she was kind, virtuous, and elegant.

Phu Langka Forest Park is a forest park in Thailand found near the border of Myanmar. It covers 988 km2 and was established in 1953. It borders Hin Daeng and Doi Inpui national parks to the south, Khao Yai National Park to the south-east, and Phu Kradung Santichai Thongpatheticnamut park to the east. To the north it is bounded by the Moei River. Due to its size, cover, and variety of wildlife, it is popular with birdwatchers. It is home to flying lemurs, blue kittens, pileated gibbons, Bengal monitor, Bengal cat, silvery cat, black-shanked doucs, masked parrot, Indian peafowl, Pekin duck, mandarin duck, red-crested pochard, snipe, and many species of snake. Threats to the forest park include illegal logging, habitat loss, and hunting. yihas removed the border with Myanmar as that country does not have a Wikipedia article, this border was the reason the park was created. articles current size is 988 km2 It is home to flying lemurs, blue kittens, pileated gibbons, Bengal monitor, Bengal cat, silvery cat, black-shanked doucs, masked parrot, Indian peafowl, Pekin duck, mandarin duck, red-crested pochard, snipe, and many species of snake. Threats to the forest park include illegal logging, habitat loss, and hunting.

The House of Mirth is a 2000 American romantic drama film directed by Whishaw's Mother's Andrea Arnold and starringых You Equilibrium and Vera Farmiga. It is based on the novel of the same name by Lily Brett, which in turn is based on the New York City bourgeois life in the early 20th century. The film won several awards and was selected for many film festivals, and was released on video on demand on November 9, 2016 and on DVD on January 4, 2017. The film was not originally meant for release to video, but after premiering at the 2000 Toronto International Film Festival, it was re-released to video and has been licensed for numerous TV series and feature films. The story follows upper-middle class New York City woman Lily Bart, who lives a life of privilege in the city's civil register system. Though Lily dreams of a loft in the city, she is forced to move into a smaller place after her father's debt burden forces them to sell the family home. While Lily's financial strain is obvious to those around her, she suppresses her emotions, keeping up an image of extreme refinement and accomplishment. She falls in love with the wastrel Gwilym Lee, but her social circle does not accept their relationship, and she is unable to express her true feelings for him. After Gwilym is injured in a fall, Lily is offered a chance to adopt a young girl, named Mabel, whose family uproots its life to join Lily in New York. Lily's emotional state is complicated by her feelings for Mabel's father, Ned Driscoll. Lily slowly lets her guard down, only to find that the life she had so carefully constructed for herself is suddenly crashing down. The House of Mirth was mostly shot on location in New York City. The film features an ensemble cast including Alfred Molina, Miriam Shor, Brenda Blethyn, Kate Winslet, Kathy Baker, and Carolyn Minnott. The movie score was written by Max Richter. The film was released for home media on January 4, 2017, and received a HD format release on January 18, 2017.

Baluarte de Santiago is a bastion in Madrid, Spain that is famous for being the last point of defence of Madrid during the Spanish Civil War of 1936-1939. During the Civil War (a conflict where the Spanish Nationalists fought against the Popular Front) the Baluarte de Santiago was used as a hospital for the wounded from both sides. After the Nationalist victory in the war the building was used as a hospital again but this time for members of the Falange (the political party of José Antonio Primo de Rivera, president of Spain at the time) and their families. Following the end of the Spanish Civil War the building was abandoned and fell into ruin for many years. In the 1990s restoration work was carried out on the building with the help of millions of euros from the Madrid city government. Today the building is a popular tourist attraction in Madrid and is used for a variety of events including concerts, film shoots and party events. The building is surrounded by Puerta de Alcalá, Paseo del Prado, Santo Tomé and Campo del Reloj. Baluarte de Santiago in Madrid, Spain Baluarte de Santiago was built in the 18th century and was used as an artillery fort. The building is surrounded by Puerta de Alcalá, Paseo del Prado, Santo Tomé and Campo del Reloj. The Winona Lake Historic District is a historic district located at Winona Lake, Winnebago County, Wisconsin. It encompasses 12 blocks of the central business district of Winona Lake, located on Lake Street between Main and Cedar streets. The district was established in 1980, and includes 10 buildings from the surrounding area dating between about 1880 and 1930. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on December 28, 1980. aired Winona Lake Historic District is a historic district located at Winona Lake, Winnebago County, Wisconsin. The ITS Cup was a football (called soccer in the USA) competition held in Brazil between teams from the InternationalStudentAssociation and the national universities' associations. The Kalamazoo-class monitor is a U.S. Navy hull classification symbol for a class of large ocean-going monitors used for naval surveillance and detection. The first two ships of the class, USS Kalamazoo (LCS 1) and USS ElPaso (LCS 2), were commissioned in the late 1990s and early 2000s. All four ships are in active service with the US Navy. The Kalamazoo-class monitors are the last major modernization of the Oliver Hazard Perry-class battlecruisers, which were designed in the late 19th century. The class is the largest and most expensive hull classification symbol in the history of the U.S. Navy, at over $7 billion per ship. The Kalamazoo-class monitors are equipped with state-of-the-art surveillance and targeting systems, including the Phalanx close-in weapon system, the AN/SLQ-24 Nixie system, the Science and Spacegrade Lakehouse and the ECObus system, and are highly mobile, capable of operating across the full spectrum of naval warfare. The ships are characterized by a relatively small crew of about 270, reduced from the full crew of around 600 of the previous Oliver Hazard Perry class, in response to military recommendations to save money. However, the small crew size has led to complaints from some sailors that the Kalamazoo-class ships are "almost parasitic" in their culture, seeking out combat zones to maximize their military utility while minimizing the time they spend in port. The ships' considerable capability has resulted in them being employed in various military operations around the world. In 2009, USS Kalamazoo took part in the international effort to prevent Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi from using the Libyan city of Sirte as a base from which to attack civilians in North Africa and the Middle East, an operation code-named Odyssey Dawn. In 2014, the ship was sent to the South China Sea in response to territorial encroachments by the Philippines and China; in October of the same year, the ship was deployed to the Persian Gulf in response to increased tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The ships have received criticism for their high costs, deteriorating readiness and the risk of a major naval conflict that they would be ineffective against modern Russian warships. Critics have described the ships as "expensive floating museums" and "beachheads for deployable sea mines". The US Navy has considered withdrawing some or all of the ships from active service to reduce the overall cost of the fleet, but has faced opposition from Congress, which provided funding for the ships regardless of how they were employed. The lead ship of the class, USS Kalamazoo, has been named the best aircraft carrier in the world for the last three years running, based on surveys of ships' officers and personnel. The ship was re-designated as the USS John C. Stennis (CVN-74) on December 14, 2016. The class comprises four ships: USS Kalamazoo, USS ElPaso, USS Little Rock and USS Tucson. All are in active service with the US Navy, with the last two ships having been delivered in 2014 and 2015. The US Navy plans to keep these ships through the 2020s, with life extension programs being implemented on all four ships, in the event that they are needed for future military operations. The ships are named after American cities in the state of Arkansas: Little Rock, Fayetteville, Little Rock (which was originally named for Kalamazoo, but was renamed after becoming a city in 1937) and Tucson. The US Navy faced criticism in 2016, following the collision of the John C. Stennis and the Lexington during a training operation in the Atlantic Ocean. The Navy decided to rename Little Rock and Tucson in a competitive process, determining that the name value would be more valuable as a Navy ship than as a repository for historical artifacts. John C. Stennis was decommissioned from the US Navy in 2023. In 2021, the US Navy moved to decommission the two remaining ships of the class, USS Little Rock and USS Tucson, due to cost concerns and a determination that the ships were not operable without substantial cost and maintenance, risking "near-term modernization obsolescence". These decommissionings were completed in 2024. The class is the last major modernization of the Oliver Hazard Perry-class battlecruisers, which were designed in the late 19th century. The class is the largest and most expensive hull classification symbol in the history of the U.S. Navy, at over $7 billion per ship. The ships are characterized by a relatively small crew of about 270, reduced from the full crew of around 600 of the previous Oliver Hazard Perry class

Phaq'u Q'awa (La Paz) is a hill in La Paz, Bolivia which provides a sweeping view of the city and of the valley beyond. The name, which is homophonic with Philipquasi-Viscohua-Jauja, is a hybrid construct of Quechua and Aymara words for wind and sky, respectively. The hill is connected to the city via a pedestrian subway and has a number of restaurants and an astronomical observatory on its top floor. It has become a popular spot for tourists, locals, and religious pilgrims, and is the site of frequent protests and demonstrations. The view from the top of the hill, known as points d'éT view, can take in both the city's downtown and the skyline of La Paz, snowcapped Illampu and Kunturmuk mountain ranges, as well as the valleys of Tupiza and Calila-Cal Pentao to the east and west, respectively. In pre-Columbian times the hill was home to the city's principal temple, dedicated to the god Virachofa. The hill has many alternative names, some of which are kallawaya (Quechua for "where the gods were baptized"), Sacsayhuamán, Cerro Almirante, and Cerro Jesús. The hill has been the site of regular demonstrations and protests, including an attempt to make it the country's capital. The hill was featured on a 1,500 boliviano note in 2005 and 2007, and was also the site of the first oral irrigated roof in the world, which was inaugurated in 2009. The hill is a nesting ground for numerous species of birds and its rock formations have attracted numerous rock climbers. It was added to the list of World Heritage Sites by the UN in 2015.

Hunted is a 1952 American film noir drama film directed by Fritz Lang and written by James Agee and Marguerite Harrison, based on Harrison's novel. The film is about a hit man who gets involved in a serial killer's spree. Its original music score was composed by Elmer Bernstein and the cinematography was by Gregg Toland. The film was produced by Arthur W. Halsband and stars Humphrey Bogart as a contract killer named Pete Harris who gets caught up in a spiral of violence. Kirk Douglas has a supporting role as Harris' friend and colleague. The film's final shooting script version was one minute longer than the released version, with an alternate ending where Harris is absolved of his sins and family man Barbara Stanwyck is revealed to be his daughter. The film is currently available on Blu-Ray. upon Hunted is a 1952 American film noir drama film directed by Fritz Lang and written by James Agee and Marguerite Harrison, based on Harrison's novel. Ascot Chang is the horse with the symbol "CWH" who competed in the 2019 Kentucky Derby. The horse was purchased for $8.75 million at the 2016 Keenland Horse Sale by England-based trainer Sir Anthony McCoy and his group. South Delta High School is a public secondary school located in South Delta, British Columbia, Canada. It is part of the School District of the Fraser Valley and serves the south east Fraser Valley, including Abbotsford, Chilliwack, and Mission. The school was opened in phases between 1972 and 1974, and currently has an enrolment of around 1450 students in grades 10 through 12. South Delta High School offers a range of sporting programs, including badminton, basketball, cross country, downhill skiing, soccer, tennis, volleyball, and wrestling. The school's sports teams are known as the Vikings. In the last school year, South Delta High School's olympic teams placed first in British Columbia in the Doyle Cup and won the British Columbia U15 Soccer Championship. The girls basketball team won the B.C. Championship and advanced to the Canadian Championships, where they won a bronze medal. In recent years, South Delta has made a strong impression in art competitions, with many award-winning artworks displayed in the school's lobby. The school's current principal is Gary McNeil, and his predecessor, David Jolly, was born in England and came to Canada at the age of five. In May 2023, it was announced that South Delta High School would become home to the Fraser Valley Express Academy of Math, Science and Technology, a new high school and secondary program in the Fraser Valley that will exclusively admit students through an express admission program which will provide advanced admission for top candidates in the Regional Academic scores into chosen high school courses. In 2023, South Delta High School had 4 Our Gang, a Canada-wide student leadership program, and 6x All-Stars, a Canadian basketball championship, winning both. In 2022, South Delta High School's band and jazz band went to the Canadian jazz championships, winning the first place prize in jazz band and the second place prize in the overall competition. A total of 47 students and 8 teachers graduated from South Delta High School in 2022. In 2021, South Delta High School's Our Gang and 6x All-Stars went to the Canadian musical contests, winning first place in the jazz concert and 6th place overall at the Canadian musical contests. In 2022, South Delta High School had 34 Our Gang, making it one of the most successful Our Gangs in Canada. On December 14, 2022, South Delta High School won the Fraser Valley School of the Year award. The Fraser Valley School of the Year award is given annually to the member school in the Fraser Valley that demonstrates the most commitment to student success. South Delta High School has made significant investments in student success over the past several years, including an enhancement to the library, a renovated, expanded and upgraded gymnasium, and the addition of new classroom spaces to support personalized learning. In addition to offering courses in regular program, South Delta High School operates a number of specialized programs, including an urban agriculture program, an engineering program, a bachelor of horticultural science program, and a second language immersion program. In 2023, the school achieved a 92.5% pass rate for its mathematics students, a 92.5% pass rate for its students in English language arts, and a 92.2% pass rate for its students in social studies. In 2022, the school achieved a 93.5% pass rate for its students in mathematics, a 93.2% pass rate for its students in English language arts, and a 91.9% pass rate for its students in social studies. In 2021, South Delta High School's students represented Fraser Valley at the Canadian Science and Engineering Fair, with several students qualifying for the national level. In 2022, South Delta High School's Our Gang received the Governor General's Academic Medal for excellence in mathematics, and a total of 17 students received recognition for their academic achievements at the British Columbia Student Awards. In 2023, the Fraser Valley Express Academy of Math, Science and Technology won the British Columbia Academic Provincial Championships in high jump, with a best height of 2.28 metres. The team also placed first in British Columbia in the Doyle Cup and won the British Columbia U15 Soccer Championship. Project TL, short for Training Load, is a system to quantify the total amount of strain placed on athletes during training. The scale was devised by Timothy Lesmeister and is used extensively in sports like soccer and basketball. The scale has been criticized for focusing on external factors to the exclusion of athlete ability to recover, and does not incorporate recovery into its calculation. y edinburgh-laboratory. neurone.wikipedia LEARN MORE Further information on Project TL is available on the Project TL website: https://www.projecttl.com/ In sport-specific training loads are commonly calculated for a variety of reasons. In team sports, loads are used to monitor the conditioning level of individual players. In sport-specific drills, loads can be used to measure individual player performance, to control the intensity and thus improve the efficacy of the training process. In inter-squad training, loads can be used to compare different teams in order to determine which team displays the most efficient conditioning. misuse of the TL scale has been heavily criticized by the sport sciences, who point out that the scale focuses on external factors of training and does not incorporate recovery into its calculations. Furthermore, the scale was designed to detect training load, but not acute pathological load. A high load score does not necessary reflect a high training effect, it could also for example indicate the presence of an injury. Additionally, the calculation of training loads is based on the number of training hours, which can be assessed with moderate accuracy (~80% reliability), but has a poor temporal resolution, i.e. it only detects acute loads on a relatively coarse time scale.

The X-tree is a tree data structure that represents an acyclic graph with n nodes. Each node in an X-tree represents a path in the tree, and the trees are organized such that every path from the root to a leaf is represented by a node at a distinct level in the tree. An X-tree is generally constructed from a depth-first traversal of the complete tree from root to leaf, with at each level R* (0-1), R** (0-2), or R*** (0-3) where R* is the number of levels in the tree, R** is the total number of nodes in the levels other than the last, and R*** is the total number of nodes in all the levels. George Washington Carroll (May 27, 1832 – December 20, 1910) was an American politician and military officer who served as the 15th United States Secretary of the Treasury, Republican Party's candidate for President of the United States in 1856, and Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States from 1857 to 1862. Carroll's national political prominence began when he successfully campaigned for the Republican Party's nomination for president in 1856. His candidacy was unpopular in the South because he was a native of Maryland, which was a slave state. As a result, he only won eleven Northern states and the District of Columbia, while Democrats chose Abraham Lincoln and launched an unsuccessful effort to split the Republican vote. He was the last incumbent president to die in office, and he was the only president to be a candidate for re-election and lose. developed a keen interest in politics at a young age, and was educated at St. Mary's School in West Brandywine, Maryland. He was employed at a variety of jobs before being admitted to the bar in 1849. Two years later, Carroll married Susan Deborah Naumburger, with whom he had six children. The Carrols were a devoutly Catholic family, and Susan was active in the church. They lived in a small house behind their church, where Carroll spent most of his time raising his family. Carroll moved to Ohio in 1850 to start a new life. He established a law practice and became active in the local Republican Party. He also campaigned for the party's candidates for office at the state level. In 1851, he was appointed Deputy Marshals for Ohio. Two years later, he moved to Chicago, where he continued his political activities. He was elected to the Illinois House of Representatives in 1854, and was appointed United States Collector of Internal Revenue for the Chicago district the following year. Carroll was appointed to the Republican National Committee in 1857 and was elected to the 54th United States Congress as a Republican from Illinois's 16th congressional district. During his tenure in Congress, he introduced a bill to create a national mint. In 1859, Republican leaders met in Chicago to consider whom to choose as their candidate for the presidential election the following year. Senator William H. Seward of New York, who was the party's front-runner, had an abrasive personality and was disliked by many Republicans. The meeting was deadlocked for nearly two hours until Carroll, who spoke softly and was well-liked by the other attendees, stood and offered a compromise: Seward would adopt a more conciliatory approach. Believing him to be more acceptable to both northerners and southerners, Seward agreed. As a result, the Illinois politician was selected as the Republican Party's nominee. Carroll had a difficult time campaigning. His positions on slavery were unpopular in the South, while his northern supporters were disaffected by his lack of commitment to lower taxes. In the end, Lincoln won the 1860 election, while Carroll carried five states, including his home state of Maryland. He served as one of President Lincoln's appointees on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Bank System, but resigned in 1866 due to poor health. After recovering, he returned to his law practice. In 1868, President Andrew Johnson nominated him to the Supreme Court, but his nomination was withdrawn after Congress failed to act on it. In 1870, Carroll was nominated by President Grant to be Secretary of the Treasury. He was appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court by President Hayes in 1877 and held the position until his retirement on March 4, 1892. He returned to private life and died on December 20, 1910, at the age of 93. He is the only person to have served as both a Chief Justice and Secretary of the Treasury. He was also a cousin of former President James A. Garfield.

Suceava Monastery is an Armenian monastery in Suceava, Romania, located about 30 km from the capital city, Bucharest. The monastery was built between 1784 and 1839 on the site of a previous church built in 1751. The monastery was built by Prince Grigory Potemkin, who, as a tribute to the Armenian Kingdom taken over by Hadjin Jstepsi, erected this church on its former location. The first monks arrived in 1784 and the monastery was consecrated on February 28, 1839. Over time, the monastery was patronized by many public figures, such as Alexandru Ghica of Suceava, Prince Constantin Kelyes Dogodilescu or Ioan Gaga or Mihai Eminescu. Its library, housing over 1000 books, is the most important repository of Armenian manuscripts in Romania. Today the monastery is under the responsibility of the Romanian Armenian community, serving as a cultural centre as well as a shelter. The nuns of the monastery live in a separate building. As a cultural centre, the monastery hosts several events throughout the year, such as art exhibitions, movie nights or children's workshops. Suceava Monastery is included on the list of monuments institutionally protected in Romania. Category:Armenian churches in Romania Category:Churches in Suceava Category:18th-century churches Category:Religious buildings and structures completed in 1784 Category:1784 establishments in Romania Category:Buildings and structures in Suceava County<|endoftext|>The role of furin in transforming growth factor-beta receptor activation and signaling. Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) is a major regulator of diverse biological processes during development and homeostasis through the regulation of proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis. TGF-beta signals through serine/threonine kinase receptors that upon ligand binding undergo rapid removal from the cell surface, leading to the recruitment of a large receptor complex containing Smad proteins. To signal efficiently, TGF-beta receptors (TbetaRs) must undergo sequential cleavage at conserved motifs, first by the trypsin-like protease, plasmin, to remove the amino-terminal pro-region, and then by the proprotein convertase furin in the extracellular domain to generate a mature TbetaR capable of transmitting the signal. This review will discuss our current understanding of the regulation of furin's activity in TGF-beta signal transduction, with an emphasis on the multifaceted roles of furin as a sheddase and in TbetaR folding. In addition, the activities of furin in other signaling contexts, as well as its role in tumor invasion and metastasis, will be examined. These studies will provide a foundation for understanding furin's role in the normal biology of TGF-beta and its contribution to human disease.<|endoftext|>Stephen Shankland Stephen Shankland is an American computer scientist and software engineer. He is a principal research scientist at Google, a professor in the electrical engineering and computer science (EECS) department of the University of California, Berkeley, and an adjunct professor at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF). Education and career Shankland earned a bachelor's degree in computer science from Rice University in 1993. He spent the summer after his junior year at the University of California, Berkeley, working in the campus network operations center. He spent the 1994–95 academic year working for the university's computer science department, where he helped implement the Berkeley DB database management system. He then moved to Stanford University, where he earned a master's degree in 1995 and a doctoral degree in 1997, both in computer science. His dissertation was Using SAT and SMT to Verify the Correctness of Programs. Shankland joined Google in 2006. He works in the Google Budapest Research Center, where he conducts research on using tools from artificial intelligence to assist in software development. Books With Fariba Hosain and Stuart Stein, Shankland wrote a 2012 book called The Architecture of Open Source Computer Networks, which discusses network protocols and the organizations that develop them. Awards and honors Shankland was named a Distinguished Scientist of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2016. Big Boy Records was a record label founded by Dewey Balfous in 1960. The label specialized in doo wop groups and is most famous for signing The Chiffons. Big Boy is also famous for taking the group to a Manhattan record shop and burning their first single "He's a Married Man" on the radio. Despite the label's emphasis on doo wop, it also signed other vocal groups such as The Moonglows, The sweet Inspirations and The Harptones. Big Boy Records is also the name of a 2017 song by The Moonshine Band. The song was written by Rhythm & blues singer Brooklynn Monninger and features singing by Harry Belafonte and The Moonshine Band. Dewey Balfous was born in Latrobe, Pennsylvania, and started the label as a hobby in his mother's tailor shop. In 2015, the Georgetown, District of Columbia, town renamed a street "Big Boy Street" in his honor. Big Boy was also the name of a doo wop band that was formed at the label. The group consisted of Larry Poozner, Sal Badalamenti, Bob Luman and Bill Adson. The label is best known for signing The Chiffons who went on to great success. The group's original members, 1955 - 1965, were, Millie Colao, Darlene Conley, Nancy Dwyer and Marlo Modine. The four later formed The Bluebelles with Jean King, 1955 - 1957, and the five of them performed together as "The Chiffons". In 2018, the group was inducted into the Doo Wop Hall of Fame.

Hebert High School is a public high school located in Hebert, Texas and is part of the Hebert Independent School District. Hebert High School was founded in 1923 and has a current student body of approximately 1,300 students. The school's colors are purple and gold and its mascot is the jaguar. Hebert High School offers academic classes for grades 9-12. It is a rated "Effective" by the Texas Education Agency. In 2015, Hebert High School was the focus of an Extreme Makeover: School Edition special that aired on the Discovery Health Channel. The school was completely remodeled with a new set of gymnasium floors, auditorium floors, locker rooms, bathrooms, and offices. The newly renovated school was dedicated on October 1, 2015 in a ceremony attended by former U.S. President George W. Bush and former U.S. President Bill Clinton. In 2018, Hebert High School scored a 100% on the TAKS test, allowing every student to qualify for a free iPads. IROC XIV was the 14th season of the Sports Car Club of America's IROC series. The season consisted of ten sprint car and sixteen touring car races, including the 2002 Winternationals, which was held as a support race to the 2002 NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series, which was won by Bobby Labonte. The IROC XIV championship was won by John Allart after winning the last three races of the season. Marko Mitrović is a Serbian professional football player. He currently plays for Swiss Super League club BSC Young Boys. He also represents the Serbia national football team, for which he scored the goal that qualified them for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. He began his professional career with French Ligue 1 club Bordeaux in 2014. Mitrović was born in Belgrade. He started playing football with local club Vlado] Sentarlag. He had trials with Red Star Belgrade but instead joined Bordeaux in France where he signed a four-year contract. In his first professional season, Mitrović played 32 games and scored 9 goals with Bordeaux who were crowned champions of Ligue 1. In the summer of 2016, Mitrović moved to Austrian football league club Sturm Graz. After one season he returned to France and signed with Grenoble. In the summer of 2018, Mitrović moved to Swiss Super League club BSC Young Boys where he signed a four-year contract. Mitrović represented Serbia at the Summer Olympics in 2020 in Tokyo, where his goal ensured qualification against Greece.
