Jackson Laboratory is a scientific research facility in Maine, United States, operated by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Division of Comparative Medicine. The lab, located in Jackson, Maine, was founded by Frank E. Clayes, and was incorporated in 1953. The main mission of the facility is the preservation of biological and physiological material, especially for medical research. The building was designed by Eero Saarinen, and was constructed from 1960 to 1963 in preparation for the founding of the lab. The facility includes research labs, office space, and living quarters for staff. Jackson Laboratory is responsible for preserving a large collection of biological and physiological materials, including mouse, rat, and rabbit models used for medical research. The facility is also involved in various genetic research projects and was the origin of several genetically modified mice. The lab is situated in a natural environment and offers walking paths and views of Mount Katahdin, the highest mountain in Maine. Frank E. Clayes founded Jackson Laboratory in 1953, and the lab was operated by the MIT division of Comparative Medicine until it was transferred to the J. David Hughes Medical Center in 1974. Today the facility is funded by an endowment, managed by MIT, and overseen by a Scientific Advisory Board that includes distinguished scientists from multiple fields. The original building, constructed from 1960 to 1963, was designed by Eero Saarinen and cost $1.5 million to build. The lab and the surrounding property was purchased by the state of Maine in 1963, with Clayes subsequently founding the Jackson Wildlife Management Area on the property. Despite its name, Jackson Laboratory does not house any Labs owned by Jackson family members. Jackson is a common surname in the United States and Canada, and the name of the facility is derived from the Jackson Wildlife Management Area, which was purchased by the state of Maine in 1963. In 1974, the facility was transferred to the J. David Hughes Medical Center, which operates it today as the Jackson Laboratory for Medical Research.

Stade Mustapha Ben Jannet, is a multi-use stadium in Taounate, Morocco. It is used mostly for football matches, and it will be the home stadium of Taourni FC. The stadium holds 10,000 people. It is used for the 2023 U-20 World Cup and other competitions. The construction of the stadium began in 2017 and was completed in 2022. It will also host some matches of the 2023 Africa Cup of Nations. It is named after Mustapha Ben Jannet, a national of Morocco who was born in Taounate and died in 1962. He was a member of the Rawâidi tribe and was a commander of the Tananeya, one of the largest tribes of the region. He played an important role in the independence of Morocco from France. He became the mayor of Taounate in 1955 and was a councilor of the legislative assembly of La Mellah and Boulsa. He fought in the Oum El Bouaghi district for the preservation of the purity of the Moroccan race. The stadium's cost and expenses were funded by a group of private Moroccan companies and Taourni FC's owner, Abdelhamid Khiari. It was inaugurated on February 1, 2022, by the Moroccan president Mouhamad Ameur Jedidi and Taourni FC's owner Abdelhamid Khiari. It hosted its first match on June 9, 2022, a 0-0 draw between Morocco and the Ivory Coast. It will host some matches of the 2023 Africa Cup of Nations. Berseba Constituency is a constituency in the Oromia National Congress with the following zone: The town of Berseba is the administrative center of the zone. This constituency is one of nine for the Oromia National Congress. The distribution of constituencies was done using Population-based electoral districts (Waqfs) method, with each city and town becoming a constituency and the remaining space being distributed to other constituencies according to the population. This gave Oromia National Congress their current distribution of 9 constituencies per state. Marita Engzelius (born 1943) is a Finnish writer and politician, born in Kirkkonummi. She has written several books, most notably a series about a domestic service worker in a poor, multicultural neighborhood of Helsinki, called Punavuori. Punavuori has been translated to Swedish, Estonian and English. She was a member of the Finnish Parliament from 1995 to 2003 with Green Party of Finland. Engzelius was born in Kirkkonummi, Finland. She studied at the University of Helsinki and took an MA in English literature. She worked as a teacher of English and Finnish as a second language for several years before becoming a freelance writer. She was also active in the Green Party. She was elected to Parliament in 1995, representing the constituency of Kirkkonummi. Engzelius' first novel, Myös meillä on päälahti (Everywhere in the World there is Wind), was published in 1984. It was followed by Punavuori (Punavuori), which was published in Finnish in 1988 and in Swedish in 1990. Engzelius went on to write several more novels about Punavuori, the life of a domestic servant in Helsinki, including Sukupuoli (Sex), Kesän kalu (Spring Break) and Kun tähtitaivas loppuu (When the Starship Ends). She has also written about her experiences as a Green Party politician. Her eighth book, Punavuorit, was published in 2010.

Vidyapati (born 22 August 1942) is an Indian composer, singer, and music director, known for his prolific works in the South Indian film industry. He was the keyboardist of the south Indian music industry, and also helped form the record label, Saregama, of the same industry. His song "OAddr Ram" is one of the most popular soundtracks in the Indian community in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia. Vidyapati is from the Soippimal family, of Kumara Rathan Thurai Puthsal characters, and is from Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu. He has more than 5,000 songs to his credit, of which close to 1,000 have been published. Vidyapati has won nine Awards including four National Film Awards. The National Film Award for Best Music Direction was awarded to him in 1973 for Tamil film, Naatu Naatu. He was awarded again in the same category for the film, Enga Chandiram in 1978. In 2005, he received the Nandi Award for Ramesh Vaidhya S Name for the song, "Chandrayanmal". He has also written a book, called "Naatu Naatu", based on the film. He is one of the very few musicians who has managed to preserve the original violin used by M. S. Subbulakshmi, the legendary Indian violinist, composer and teacher, who was the first Indian woman to be awarded the Gold Medal for violin playing. The violin was donated to him by Subbulakshmi herself, after she retired. He has started his own music label, Saregama, with his son, Dharanipuram Sivakumar. In 2020, he was felicitated by the Rotary Club of Madras, by the title "Madras Has Many Moods - Ours Too"

Chicago City Railway was the third municipal railway in Chicago. It was operated by the Chicago Rapid Transit Company, a subsidiary of the City of Chicago. It operated between Chicago and Ashland/63rd on the Upper Side, and Kimball and the Loop. The last train on the line operated between the Loop and Chicago Union Station on September 30, 1958. The railway was created to help facilitate construction of the Chicago River aqueduct by providing an outlet to new areas beyond the municipal boundaries of the City of Chicago. The CRTC was formed as a private corporation in 1903, and constructed the railway using bond money. The railway was not involved in the rapid rise of the Chicago neighborhood from poor to wealthy beginning in the 1910s; it was too expensive for most residents. Public transportation on the railway became more practical with the advent of the automobile, and the city shut down the railway in 1958. In 1975, the CRTC made money by renting out its Union Station facilities to the Federal government for use as a post office. Because of this, the CRTC has retained the station and its immediate environs; various city landmarks are located nearby, including the Fredrick K. Berry Hall (home of the Chicago Architecture Foundation), the Art Institute of Chicago and several universities and schools. The last private owners of the railway were the Canadian National Railway (CNR) and Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR), who trackage rights over the Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railway (EJER) into Union Station. CNR and CPR kept the railway in service until 1995, when the new owner of CNR, the Canadian Transportation Agency (CTA), closed the railway down for good.

Scientific communication is a subfield of media studies that studies the processes by which scientific knowledge is communicated and the implications of such communication for science and culture. A major goal of scientific communication is to enhance the authenticity and thus the credibility of the knowledge communicated. Due to the ideal of objectivity that pervades much of the scientific community, the nature of the scientific communication process may at times lead to a situation where information and ideas are selectively presented or suppressed in a way that would not be tolerated in other contexts. The relationship between scientists and the public has also been impacted by advances in scientific knowledge; thus, a consensus has emerged that the public's right to know should precede its right to remain ignorant, at least in fields such as medicine or nuclear power. The scientific community has a wide range of attitudes toward communication. Many scientists feel they should not communicate their findings beyond their immediate peers. They may also be reluctant to publish negative or inconvenient findings, and this trait is sometimes called "grey literature." A 2011 survey by the Pew Research Center for the People & the Press found that most scientists were reluctant to share negative findings, with 71% citing the need to complete further research as the reason for not sharing data that does not show a result in a positive light. Nevertheless, many scientists are eager to communicate their research. For example, an analysis of the pages of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) journals Science and Nature found that most articles contained at least one figure or table that could be considered a "publication" in the traditional sense (i.e., that could be sent or shared via email or uploaded to a website). Due to the potential for positive or negative impacts, the nature of scientific discovery often means that scientists are not solely interested in understanding and communicating the implications of their own research but instead are focused on the communication of broader general knowledge. To meet this challenge, the scientific community has developed codes of conduct, standards of evidence and "translation" services. Scientific communication has also been called " spin", "communicated research", and "checked knowledge". History Ancient Greece and Rome During the Roman Empire and the succeeding medieval period, scientific communication was typically handled by members of the same profession, for example between a physician and a patient, between a lawyer and a client, or between a mathematician and a scholar. If the information was to be communicated to a wider audience, it was usually done so via books or oral lectures. For example, Democritus, who lived between 460 and 370 BC, is credited with the first scientific treatise, the Canon, discussing properties of matter and how they change over time. It was not meant to be read exclusively by its original audience of fellow Greek atomists but it was probably sufficiently clear for them to follow its basic messages. However, the Canon has not survived in its entirety, only a selection of sentences which have come down to us. However, in antiquity there were also a number of instances where a knowledge creator communicated knowledge to an audience that was not necessarily prepared to receive it, or even able to do so, for example when the knowledge creator was speaking to another audience of specialists. In these instances, the knowledge creator was mostly interested in engaging in a dialogue with the other specialists, rather than in reaching a wider audience. In this respect, the Canon of Democritus has been read continuously over the centuries, and even though the original audience was not identical to the current one, there is dialogue between them. As the concept of specialization became more firmly established, communication of scientific knowledge was increasingly organized along the lines of the tradition of oral or written lectures. The most important landmarks in this development are the establishment of university centres of learning (scholae) which combined lectures with the recruitment and residence of students, and the composition of textbooks that summarized the knowledge and transmitted it from one generation to the next. The most famous examples of such textbooks are Aristotle's works on natural history and medicine. Many different channels were available for the communication of knowledge, and in many cases more than one channel was used at the same time for the same purpose. In antiquity, this is exemplified by the sending of a physician to a patient not only in the form of a written prescription, but also by means of an oral explanation. Renaissance and early modern Europe During the Early Modern period, Western science and culture was also characterized by an increase in the number of people who were able to read. New opportunities to communicate science arose with the introduction of publications such as books, journals and newsletters. However, education was still primarily the prerogative of the elite, and so public interest in science was mainly limited to spectacular discoveries and spectacular applications of knowledge. A gateway station is part of a wireless network that lets phones connect to the Internet through the PAAC. The Gateway station sits on top of the wireless network that connects phones to the Internet. This network is usually owned and operated by a wireless carrier or Internet Service Provider. All phones on the network must send data through the PAAC, which is the country's most advanced and largest wireless broadband network. The PAAC network is available to anyone, but the best results are usually obtained using devices and applications that support the Draft Wireless Network standard. The PAAC network provides speeds of up to 100 megabits per second. That's enough bandwidth to stream hi-definition video. As of November 2023, PAAC has more than 20 million active users and 150,000 nodes. Together, these users and nodes represent more than 20 giga bytes of data being transferred every day. The PAAC network is connected to the Internet and runs its own DNS, DHCP and NTP servers. It also has a large network of nodes in schools, public libraries, and other public places that let users connect with little or no setup. Through the gateway, users can access the Internet without using a personal computer or Wi-Fi router. The gateway allows simultaneous voice and data connectivity, so you can check email or browse the web while on a phone call. Gateway stations can be used with all devices that have wireless Internet access, including laptops, web browsers, smart phones, and wireless speakers. The PAAC network is offered in seven countries: the United States, Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Japan and the United Kingdom. PAAC is managed by the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission (ECRCC). The PAAC network is operated by a consortium of global technology companies including Apple, Inc., Google, Ltd., Intel Corporation, Microsoft, and Samsung. The PAAC network is funded in part by grants from the U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and from the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission (ECRCC). More information can be found on the PAAC website and on the Draft Wireless Network standard.

A Little Princess is a drama television series based on the 1868 novel of the same name by autoregardedes toei minimal de Elliot that encapsulates the story of Christine Daaé, a French courtesan who becomes a performers under the stage name "Little Princess" and later an emotionally fragile but ultimately resilient young lady who finds love. The 1973 Japanese animated version adaptation follows the original novel more closely, though leaves out some of the philosophical aspects found in the book and has the character of Christine's brother Alan Graham pronounced as "Alrun" to more closely follow the English dub. Despite this, the original novel is still consulted frequently and heavily featured in the 2018 Netflix version which adapts it along with additional materials not present in the 1973 animated version such as Christine's relationship with her parents. Aditya Kapadia (born February 25, 1993) is an Indian-American singer and songwriter. He is known for his work in the vocal group Grey. Kapadia was born in India to an Indian father and a Swedish American mother. He moved with his family to the United States when he was three years old. He attended high school at Northfield Mount Hermon School in Massachusetts, and is an alum. After high school, Kapadia began studying at Boston Conservatory, where he received training in opera. He eventually moved to Los Angeles to study music at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). Kapadia auditioned for and was accepted into Grey. The group, which also includes Alex Salanos, Jorge Magalhaes and Julien Missigo, released their debut album titled Eyes in 2012. Grey released their second album, titled Awake, on September 10, 2017, through A&F Records and Interscope Records. The lead single, "Believe", was written and produced by Grey alongside Jake Gosling and Ben Wheatly of Takeaway, and features guest vocals from American rapper Travis Scott. Kapadia has released two extended plays, Love Lost and Love Found (2019) and Single (2020). He is currently signed to American record label Top Stop Music Group and American independent record label NNA Tunes. wait Aditya Kapadia (born February 25, 1993) is an Indian-American singer and songwriter. He is the first recipient of the Grey Cup in franchise's history. He is also a member of the Canadian Football Hall of Fame and was a part of the Ottawa Rough Riders' 1985 Grey Cup victory. Harriet Ward (1832–1915) was an English educator, author, and pioneer in the field of special education. Born in London, England, Ward was the oldest of nine children. Her father was a solicitor and a member of Parliament. Ward began studying at a school for young ladies when she was twelve years old. At nineteen, Ward began teaching at a school for children with disabilities. During this time, in 1862, Ward's friend, Julia Morgan, introduced her to other women educators, who were interested in forming an association for women in teaching. In April 1864, Ward became one of the founding members of the Women's Educational Association (WEA). In 1867, Ward published her first book, Manual of Intellectual Offences and DEFENCE, which was based on her classes at the school for children with disabilities. In 1871, Ward published her most famous work, The Duties of Special Teachers. In this book, Ward provided advice to women who sought to become special teachers. In 1872, Ward and her sister, Martha, started their own school for girls, in Saffron Walden. The school only accepted ten students; however, Ward taught over one hundred students while at the school. Ward remained active in the WEA until 1874. She then went on to author more books, including: A Voice from the Centre: a series of addresses on homeopathy, delivered before the Women's Educational Association in September 1877 (1877), Thoughts on Toys, delivered before the Women's Educational Association in November 1878 (1878), and The Principles of Teaching: a text book for primary schools (1880). In 1881, Ward was hired as the superintendent of schools for New Jersey. This is where she met and began to correspond with Susan A. Hersey, who would later become her colleague and a fellow pioneer in the field of special education. In 1888, Ward retired from her position as superintendent of schools. In 1895, Ward and Hersey opened the first school for the education of exceptional children in America. The school, known as the Jersey School for the Education of Exceptional Children, opened in East Orange, New Jersey. Ward continued teaching at the school until her retirement in 1896.

China–Malawi relations refers to the relations between the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Malawi. Both countries established diplomatic ties in 1964. Since the establishment of diplomatic ties, the Chinese government has taken multiple steps to support Malawi in various areas. These included extending technical and financial assistance. The two states enjoy close relations, with the president of Malawi becoming the honorary president of China, and the Chinese ambassador to Malawi representing China in the country. Since 1970, China has been Malawi's largest bilateral aid donor, providing over $1 billion in assistance. This included providing over 60 percent of the country's fund for agriculture and economic development. However, political tensions arose between the two in the late 2000s over the treatment of land in Malawi by Chinese companies, and in 2009, Chinese President Hu Jintao suspended all further military training for Malawi. However, since 2012, the assistance has increased, with China providing over $60 million in 2012 and over $70 million in 2017. As of 2017, around 20,000 Malawians work in China, primarily in the garment industry. In May 2018, President of China, Xi Jinping, became the first Chinese president to visit Malawi. This was the first visit by a Chinese president to Malawi since 2009, as well as the first by a head of state since the death of former President Qu Zhou in 2008. In November 2019, Malawi President Mutharika died, succeeded by Peter Mutharika, his second son, who is a politician by profession. The Chinese government made an effort to ensure Mutharika's son becomes the president, and donated boats and medicine to the country. Although relations between the two countries have remained cordial, there are some areas of tension. For example, Chinese companies have been accused of land expropriation in Malawi. Additionally, Chinese President Xi Jinping described the relationship as a "partner-client" relationship, which has been contested by the government of Malawi. President Xi's 2018 visit to Malawi was followed by an increased military presence from both nations. This included the deployment of several hundred Chinese military police to the area of the border between the two countries, the first such deployment. Additionally, Beijing has invested in several infrastructure projects in Malawi, such as a road and railway, and has increased political support for President Mutharika.

Delusional intuition is a term coined by Carl Jung to refer to a type of psychological phenomenon in which a person believes they possess special insights into what others are thinking. Psychologists have validated the subjective experience, though it is not considered a form of telepathy in the technical sense. Delusional intuition is considered to be a form of apophenia, the tendency to perceive patterns where there are none. This phenomenon was influential on Jung's theories on personality and shadow processing. Examples of notable people who claimed to have this type of intuition include George Orwell and Joan of Arc. matrix/recommended reading Jung's concept of Delusional Intuition is validated by psychologists as a subjective experience, though it is not considered a form of telepathy in the technical sense. Bahamut is the name of a fantasy album released in 1983 by the French metal band Ange on their record label Duranrecord. The album was recorded at The Abyss and Sound Technica Studios, and was mixed and mastered at Arouca Studios. Cover art is by Dominique Berthelemy. Bahamut received a limited edition of 1500 copies, with greenvinyl and gold, silver and blue cardboard box. Bahamut is the king of the gods of celestial realm in ancient mythology, and the unique horse-headed god, represent the God of justice and light, the god of the sky, the earth and the seas. Musically, Bahamut's tracks are very aggressive, with very strong compositions in long heavy tracks. The album cover, like the band's previous albums, continues the exploration of horror and darkness, with a lots of gothic and theatrical elements. This album is very successful in France, reaching fifth place in the French charts, and was elected the best fantasy album of the year in 1984. Fiona Jones (born Fiona Margaret Jones, 30 March 1964) is an English singer, songwriter and actress. She is best known for her association with the band Take That and its successor groups the ProgressIVE! and the Blockheads. Jones started her musical career as part of the band Bankstown Babysitting, which was formed in 1982. The band released one single, "Pacific County", in 1983. After leaving the band in 1985, Jones went on to have successful solo careers both as a singer and songwriter. She achieved international success with Take That. After the disbandment of Take That in 1996, Jones pursued a successful career as a songwriter for several artists including Christina Agulera, Kylie Minogue, Blue, James Blunt and Olly Murs. She has also pursued an acting career, appearing in a number of musical and television productions. Jones is the oldest member of the original line-up of Take That. She is also the only remaining original member to have made the transition into the band's subsequent successor groups, the ProgressIVE! and the Blockheads. She is the highest-paid member of the Take That entourage. Jones was born in New Cross, London. She moved to Maple Lodge, Hemingford Abbacee with her family at the age of eleven. She attended Abbots Bromley School. She went on to graduate in politics, philosophy and economics from the University of Kent. Jones' first venture into the music industry was when she formed Bankstown Babysitting with her sister Debbie in 1982. The band signed to Chrysalis Records and released one single, "Pacific County" in 1983. In 1985, Jones left Bankstown Babysitting to pursue a solo musical career. Her debut single as a solo artist, "Under Your Influence", was released in 1987 via MGM Records. Her debut studio album, Seven & the Days, was released in 1988 via MGM Records. Jones achieved worldwide success with the band Take That. She was a member of the band from 1985 to 1996. Jones is the longest-serving member of the band, having been a member for thirteen years longer than the second longest-serving member, Gary Barlow. Jones is also the oldest member of the original line-up of Take That. Jones was a mainstay in the band's music videos and campaigns, appearing on the front cover of several editions of the band's debut studio album, Nobody Wants to be a Superstar (1992), as well as the cover of the band's fifth studio album, Collection (1995). She was featured on the band's sixth studio album, A Whole New Beginning (1996), as well as the DVD release of the band's Greatest Hits (2001). Jones left the band in 1996 to pursue a successful solo career. She became a songwriter for various artists including Christina Agulera, Kylie Minogue, Blue, James Blunt and Olly Murs. Jones became a judge on The X Factor (US) in 2018. Jones was married to Chris Leonard from 1994 to 1999. In 2010, she began dating record producer Trevor Horn. She helped raise £17 million for Children's Hospice Association UK. She is the oldest member of the original line-up of Take That. She is also the highest-paid member of the Take That entourage. Jones' first musical venture after Take That was in 2017 with the band The Blockheads, which features former Take That member Howard Donald.

Further investigation showed that Read's lab had been working on similar projects, which were referenced in a draft thesis given to Read by Charles K. Lenfest. Lenfest gained control of the lab following Read's retirement in 2006, and continued to work on the projects, culminating in the release of "SCP Foundation Penrose" in 2022.

Ski boots are specialised footwear used for boarding and skiing. They vary in design, depending on use (e.g. rental or purchased) and intended use (a right boot for right-footed skiers and a left boot for left-footed skiers). There are several types of boots for different activities: alpine (for skiing), Nordic (for training and cross-country skiing), hockey, touring, and rock climbing. Ski boots are secured on the wearer's feet with bindings. These bindings may be either rigid (metal or plastic plates that flex but do not deform), or soft (a laced shoe with a moulded mid-sole that flexes). Soft bindings are more flexible but less stable; they are commonly used for off-piste or gym skiing. Ski boots also include an integral boot top (or overboot) that covers the lower part of the wearer's leg to keep snow out of the socks and lower legs. Ski boots are an essential piece of ski clothing and form a critical element of safety gear. Ski boots are relatively expensive, costing hundreds of dollars each. Lower quality boots can be ruined by deforming or tearing a soft binding in a high impact collision. While there are several types of ski boots, they generally all follow similar design principles. The lower leg is firmly secured inside the boot with a lacing system. This helps to keep the boots tight and secure the lower leg in the boot. A cuff surrounds the ankle to keep snow out of the boot and to provide stability. The tongue is designed to flex up and over the rider's foot to allow the boot to move with the feet's movements. The upper is commonly made from a pliant but rigid material, such as leather or plastic, with metal reinforcements inside the upper for strength. Ski boots also often include a soft midsole and stiff soleplate for additional stability. Ski boots are made and sold by a limited number of manufacturers. The largest of these is Ross, who also owns brand on their skis, Deerfoot. Other popular brands include K2, Blizzard, Black Crows, Nordica, Blizzard, Rossignol, True, Nordica, Kikau,... There are also many specialty brands such as Patta, Helly Hansen,... While the manufacture of ski boots is a multi-billion dollar industry, modern technology has led to the development of mass-produced composite materials that are lighter in weight and designed to more accurately reflect modern fabric technology. These designs have not caught on, likely due to the perceived cost premium and higher maintenance requirements associated with these boots.

Multnomah was a sternwheel-powered steamboat that operated on the Willamette River in Oregon, United States, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The vessel was built in1899 at Portland, Oregon, by owner and operator Russell Stover, and operated on Multnomah Channel into the early years of World War II. The sternwheeler was acquired by Douglas Munroe in 1946 and again served into the 1960s. The Multnomah was lost sometime after 1960. Multnomah was a business as well as a means of transport. Russell Stover started the business in 1898 as an importer and distributor of Portland-made goods. The company grew to include Multnomah Channel, a logistics and transport business centered around the vessel, as well as a real estate operation and a campground on Sandy River. Multnomah is the namesake of Portland, Oregon, and was an important part of the region's transport infrastructure from the early 20th century until it was lost by the early 1960s. The sternwheeler carried people and freight on the Willamette and Sandy rivers for nearly 56 years. The company built other vessels in the Multnomah series, all of which were lost to vandalism, collisions, or salvage. The most famous of these other Multnomah vessels is the upstreamFERD, which sank in 1926 and was salvaged in 1953. In total, Multnomah Company owned or operated six sternwheelers on the Willamette River, all of which were lost by the early 1960s. The company's last sternwheeler,, was acquired by Douglas Munroe and restored for use on the Willamette for a time but was damaged in a storm and sank in 1965. The loss of the Multnomah company fleet had a significant effect on the future of river transport on the Willamette, leading to the revival of the Skookumchas fleet and eventual revival of the Clipper navigation company. Today, the sternwheeler Portland is the only remaining vessel of the original Multnomah company fleet. The abandoned hulk of the UpstreamFERD is visible on the Willamette River just north of Hamilton Island Docks in Portland, and is sometimes referred to as the "missing link" between the old Multnomah fleet and the Skookumchas fleet. The company also has a legacy in real estate. Multnomah Channel Inc. owned and operated a campground and other commercial properties on Sandy River between Sandy Boulevard and Alameda Avenue, just south of the Oregon Zoo and east of the Lloyd Center. This property is now the site of the Oregon Convention Center and on the northern edge of the district that hosts the Portland Trail Blazers basketball team. Multnomah is a title given to many different sternwheelers, all of which were lost to obsolescence or else are in varying states of repair. The company named at least five different Multnomah sternwheelers, the first of which was built in 1898. The last Multnomah sternwheeler was acquired by Douglas Munroe in 1946. Some sources suggest that the historic distinction of "Multnomah" is more a brand name than a unique identity, and that the various ships bearing that name belonged to different companies. The term "Multnomah" may have been used as early as 1897 to describe a type of sternwheeler, but this is not universally accepted. There is no known documentation to show that the company formally adopted the name "Multnomah" until 1898, when the first Multnomah sternwheeler was built. The Portland company owned or operated five sternwheelers between 1898 and 1929. The names of these ships were the Multnomah, Columbia, Dalles City, Columbia II, and Clackamas. The last three of these were all built after 1900. In addition to these five sternwheelers, the company also may have operated or owned one or more unnamed sternwheelers between 1898 and 1929. After the company's 1929 bankruptcy, all five of the company's Multnomah sternwheelers were purchased by other companies, usually within the next five years. The last Multnomah sternwheeler, the Columbia, was purchased by Donald Ingram in 1933. The Dalles City was purchased by Samuel M. Scott in 1933. The company also did not own or operate the Columbia II after 1900, so it is unclear who owned that vessel between 1901 and 1903. In 1944, the Clackamas was being salvaged for parts when its owner, J.P. Harrell, was arrested for bankruptcy and the Multnomah was listed for sale at auction. The Clackamas was purchased by George P. Kirk at auction for $2,500, and the Columbia II was acquired by Munroe Dry

Disruptive selection is a form of selection that favors the evolution of traits that would normally be considered unfavorable. Disruptive selection acts to accelerate the evolution of change. Disruptive selection is often associated with Darwinian evolution, but can operate on alleles or other genetic units other than individual organisms. It was first proposed by George John Williams in 1951. Some examples of disruptive selection are: - artificial selection in plants and animals - the domestication of animals and plants - the divergence of pigeon breeds - the evolution of parasitic behavior - mutations that cause disease such as sickle cell anemia Williams proposed that disruptive selection would accelerate the rate of evolution of traits that negatively interact with the environment or other traits. For example, the evolution of sickle cell anemia would be accelerated by the positive selection for children with anemia who require larger blood volumes. In applied fields, disruptive selection is sometimes referred to as diversification selection. The importance of disruptive selection is that it can lead to rapid evolution and adaptation to novel challenges. This is important in modern agriculture, biological control, animal husbandry, and plant cultivation, where disruptive selection can lead to improved yields, more robust populations, and faster changes to better survive new environmental challenges. There is also evidence of disruptive selection at the species level in the form of extinction events. A well-documented example is the dinosaurs, who appeared to be favored by disruptive selection for their susceptibility toavian predators, but ultimately succumbed to extinction. Disruptive selection is sometimes difficult to demonstrate in applied fields due to the challenges of measurement. Genetic variability can obscure evidence of disruptive selection, and the statistical analysis to demonstrate disruptive selection is complex. Despite this, studies have shown that disruptive selection can explain a significant proportion of variation in observed data. Overall, disruptive selection plays an important role in evolution, and is an important mechanism of rapid evolution in applied fields. This topic is discussed in more detail in several publications, including - "The Selfish Gene" by Richard Dawkins - "The Genie in the Bottle: Heroism and Delirium in thepharmaceutical Revolution" by Julia Flynn - "Catching a Disadvantage" by Susan Greenfield These publications also provide additional context for disruptive selection. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disruptive_selection Note: The phrases "Darwinian evolution" and "disruptive selection" often are used interchangeably, but have different meanings. Darwinian evolution is a long process of small changes that can lead to big changes over time. Disruptive selection focuses on a specific form of change that accelerates the rate of evolution. George John Williams was a British evolutionary biologist who proposed disruptive selection in 1951. The selection theory he proposed has since been applied to a range of situations, including: - artificial selection in plants and animals - the domestication of animals and plants - the divergence of pigeon breeds - the evolution of parasitic behavior - mutations that cause disease such as sickle cell anemia Disruptive selection has been shown to explain a significant amount of variation in observed data, often more than Darwinian evolution. Studies have shown that disruptive selection can explain a significant proportion of variation in observed data. Overall, disruptive selection plays an important role in evolution, and is an important mechanism of rapid evolution. Giuseppe Pancaro (born 23 August 1933) is an Italian football coach and former player. He played as a midfielder, and was part of the Italian team that won the silver medal in football at the 1956 Summer Olympics. His professional career began with hometown club A.S. Roma before he was selected to play for the Italian national team. He won nine Serie A titles and one Italian Cup while playing for Juventus, Napoli and Roma. He later worked as a coach throughout Europe, including several roles with the Italian national team. Pancaro played in both the1956 Olympics and 1960 Olympic football tournaments. He was a key member of the Italian team that won the silver medal, Italy's first ever Olympic silver medal. He started all four of Italy's group stage matches and scored the only goal of the tournament in a 1–0 victory over hosts France. After Italy's 1–1 draw with Mexico in the round of 16, the Italians needed to win their next match by a two-goal margin to guarantee advancement to the semi-finals. The Italians fell behind early in the second half before Pancaro collected a through ball from Giovanni Galli, and proceeded to beat French goalkeeper Philippe Chapuis. In the semi-finals, Italy faced Uruguay and needed a win by any scoreline to advance to the final. The match remained 0–0 after 90 minutes, leading to a penalty shootout that Italy won 4–3. In 1993, Pancaro was one of the founding members of A.S. Roma. He turned 80 years old in 2017 and is still closely connected to the club, having served as vice president since 2011. Giuseppe Pancaro played professional football for nine seasons, from 1956 to 1965, representing A.S. Roma, Juventus FC, Napoli and Roma. After his playing career, he worked as a coach in various European teams, including the Italy national team. He is one of the founders of A.S. Roma and currently serves as vice-president of the club. Roma, 23 August 1933 - Giuseppe Pancaro, one of the founders of Roma, Vice-President, has turned 80 years old.

Sampling is a music theory concept and musical practice of using a small portion of a song to provide a foundation for new development, often taken from another song. The practice was developed byBritish musician James Brown, whose song "Papa's Got a Brand New Bag" was modeled after jazz musicianMaryOBellaLaurant's "Happy Phasing". The implementation in Papa's Got a Brand New Bag included sampling the elastic sound of a guitar string. The sampling technique has since been utilized in a wide variety of musical styles and has grown into a highly regulated art form, with publishers of copyrights for samples — often referred to as "sampleshells" —being paid high licensing fees. Sampling has had a significant cultural impact on mainstream popular music, inspiring entire genres of music, such as hip hop music, dance music and pop music. Well-known examples of musical compositions which incorporate samples of other songs include the Beatles' "While My Guitar Gently Weeps", "Helter Skelter", "Get Off My Cloud" and "Day Tripper", Pink Floyd's "Another Brick in the Wall", Roy Orbison's "Pretty Woman" and ABBA's "Dancing Queen", Kraftwerk's "Trans-EQuatorial Dot Matrix" and Lady Gaga's "Poker Face". Despite its importance in popular music, sampling is a widely misunderstood concept in the world of music theory. The exact definition and form of this music theory concept has been a subject of many academic studies.

The Bourgeois Government or the Republic Government is a term used by Karl Marx to describe the political systems in most countries in Europe in the 19th century. After the revolutions of 1848, the term was redefined by other socialist philosophers to refer to a minimum set of institutions and personnel needed to run a country effectively. The term was applied to several countries where the ruling classes converted to democracy and appointed parliaments, such as Finland in 1907, Sweden in 1909, Denmark in 1913 and Poland in 1918. The term was applied to describe the government of France in 1929, however the term was dropped after the two world wars. It was revived in 1955 by Jean-Louis Barrault in order to distinguish between the Third Republic and the Fourth Republic. Since then, the term has been used by socialists to describe any government which they consider does not fulfill the minimum requirements for a democratic government. The minimum requirements set forth by socialists are more extensive than the requirements needed to efficiently manage a country. The minimum requirements set forth by socialists are more extensive than the requirements needed to efficiently manage a country. This is the reason why these requirements have often been implemented in times of crisis, for example after World War 2. The requirements set by socialists include immunity for the upper class, necessary social services and minimum wage. The political spectrum usually splits governments into left-wing and right-wing. The left-wing governments usually set higher requirements than the right-wing governments. The left-wing governments usually establish public healthcare, subsidize education and regulate big business. The right-wing governments usually cut down taxes, leave social services to the states and regulate only big business. While the Bourgeois Government satisfies the minimum requirements for a democratic government, it fails to satisfy the more extensive requirements set by socialists.

Gramicidin B is an antimicrobial protein produced by the Gram-positive bacterium Bacillus polymyxa. It is a linear unit-ramεί antibiotic, which forms membrane-impermeable pores in Gram-positive bacteria cell membranes. Gramicidin was the first cationic peptide antibiotic and is closely related to the later-discovered antibiotics tetracycline and NFLD-26. The precise mechanism of gramicine killing bacterial cells has not been fully characterized but it is known to involve interaction with the cytoplasmic membrane. Gramicidin B is active against many Gram-positive bacteria, as well as some Gram-negative bacteria and some fungi. It is used as an antimetabolic agent to model Gram-positive bacteria. Gramicidin B was discovered in 1943 by Professor Johannes Grammel at the University of Copenhagen. It is made up of 31 amino acids (plus an N-terminal methionine), with a typical mass of 3602 Da. It is slightly soluble in water, particularly at neutral pH (1.9 mg/L at pH 7), and is quite insoluble in many organic solvents. It is an amphipathic peptide, containing both hydrophobic and positively charged residues, which contributes to its biological activity. Gramicidin was initially synthesized by hydrolysis of gramicidin S, the macrocyclic antibiotic produced by Bacillus graminis. Total synthesis of gramicine began in 1951 and was completed in 1954 by Stig Sondergaard (Stig Sonneborn) and Ragnar Vestbjerg. Its structure was determined in 1951. Gramicidin S is converted to gramicine by NaOH treatment and subsequent precipitation with acid; the product is soluble in water. Gramicidin B is mainly used in studies of bacteria model systems as a specific inhibitor of bacterial membrane potential-dependent aspartate aminotransferase, which is encoded by the gdpP gene in many bacteria. It is not harmful to humans. In addition to its antibiotic properties, Gramicidin B has been used in the chemical synthesis of several oligopeptides, including oligoarginine, polyarginine, and several model poly-L-amino acids. Gramicidin B finds continued use in biotechnology as a promoter for protein production in Escherichia coli. Gramicidin B was the first cationic peptide antibiotic and is closely related to the later-discovered antibiotics tetracycline and NFLD-26. Gramicidin is the first member of the cationic antimicrobial protein family of antibiotics. It is the shortest of that family, consisting of 31 amino acid residues; its structure was determined in 1951. It forms aqueous pores in membranes of gram-positive bacteria, causing leakage of cellular contents and ultimately cell death. Gramicidin was the first of a new class of antibiotics, the gramicidins, whose further investigation was impeded by its degradation into inactive sub-units by a proteolytic enzyme in the culture medium of some Bacillus species. The amino-terminal residues of gramicidin are oxidized, mainly to a succinyl derivative. The first total synthesis of gramicidin was achieved in 1954 by Stig Sondergaard and Ragnar Vestbjerg. Gramicidin has been used in biotechnology to induce protein production in Escherichia coli. The mechanism of action of gramicidin has not been fully characterized. It is known to involve interaction with the cytoplasmic membrane. However, the exact mechanism remains unclear. It has been suggested that gramicidin forms transmembrane channels, although other studies indicate that its primary mode of action may involve the electropermeabilization of cell membranes. Gramicidin B is active against many Gram-positive bacteria, as well as some Gram-negative bacteria and some fungi. It is used as an antimetabolic agent to model Gram-positive bacteria. Gramicidin B is a protein antibiotic with an amphipathic α-helix secondary structure, critical to its activity against Gram-positive bacteria. Lolium perenne is a species of grass in the family Poaceae, also called meadow foxtail, rennaire, perenne, or simply grass. It is native to temperate regions of the world, and it is important globally as a crop and for recreational grazing. It is often used in landscaping as an ornamental grass. Several cultivars have been developed. The grain can be used to make flour, and the foliage is used in top dressing for soil enhancement. The Latin specific epithet perenne means perennial. This grass typically forms small tufts of green leaves, but its rhizomatous roots form large colonies spreading by means of stolons. They can produce new shoots almost annually, even under unfavourable conditions. This growth makes the grass very aggressive and tenacious. It is consumed by livestock and is a common component of ruminant forage. It is sometimes used in roller sprinklers to reduce mosquito larvae, and it is also used in lawnmowers. In the United States, it is an important invasive species in some areas of the Great Plains. The abundant seed production makes it suitable for seeding or sodding. The grass has been used in history for thatching and as swatting in farming and war. The plant has become naturalised in many areas it has not been cultivated. Many cultivar have been selected for different purposes. This grass tolerates a wide range of conditions and is often able to outcompete less hardy species in unfavourable locations. A number of L. perenne accessions have been assigned to.Genomes 1N = 16, 29, 42. It is suggested that the subsp. durum be made a distinct species.

Cynthia Teague (born Cynthia Ann Teague; August 7, 1958 – January 11, 2023) was an American serial killer and sexual sadist who gained notoriety for her 2003 arrest in Texas, where she resided at the time. Her modus operandi was to lure men to their deaths through online personal advertisements, then kill them and, in some cases, skin them alive. Teague was convicted of murder and sentenced to death, whereupon she would have had the death sentence commuted to life in prison. However, she was found dead in her cell on January 2023, apparently having hanged herself. History Cynthia Ann Teague was born on August 7, 1958, in El Dorado, Arkansas, to Jesse Lee Teague and Bernice Ruth Teague (née Pruitt). She had one older half-sister, Gale Bivins, from her mother's prior marriage. Teague was raised in the small rural community of Robin, Arkansas, where she attended public school and began developing an interest in serial killing after reading SERIAL: The Sam Sheppard Case. At age 17, she left home, moving to Houston, Texas. There, she worked as a cocktail waitress and was active in the local heavy metal music scene. Career In 1983, aged 21, Teague began a relationship with Fredrick Clark, a Black Belt-turned-bricklayer. The couple soon moved in together and had two children, a boy and a girl, born in 1984 and 1986, respectively. In 1987, Teague was diagnosed with lupus, a terminal illness for which there was no known cure at the time. This greatly affected her health and emotional state, and caused her to become depressed. On July 28, 1989, Clark traveled to California to attend a family gathering. He was later unable to return home, with Teague's family claiming that he had simply run away. On August 10, Teague's brother spotted Clark's Saturn abandoned in front of a Homewood, Alabama motel, and notified the police. Clark's body, bearing signs of having been shot and tortured, was discovered later that day. The police arrested Teague for the murder, and she later confessed to driving Clark to Alabama in her car. She claimed that Clark had intended to surprise her family but became disoriented in the dark and accidentally drove to Alabama instead. Teague was extradited back to Texas, and on February 7, 1990, was convicted of murder and sentenced to death. In order to qualify for the death penalty, a Texas jury needed to find unanimously that the crime was committed "deliberately and with the intent to cause death", and that it was "beyond a reasonable doubt". The former finding relied on the state of Teague's physical and mental health at the time of the murder, while the latter required the jury to consider Clark's body, with the signs of torture. After more than 30 witnesses testified for the prosecution, Teague was found guilty. She unsuccessfully appealed her conviction to the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, and on April 19, 1995, her sentence was formally commuted to life imprisonment. Teague has stated that she would have gladly accepted a life sentence had she known that the sentence would have included eligibility for parole after 17 years, though parole was not available to lifers at the time. She was placed in the Gallego-Hoyt Facility in Tennessee, which houses prisoners on death row. Notable incidents Mutilation murder of Charles Fisher On November 1, 2000, Teague lured Charles Fisher, 52, a truck driver, to a secluded location using a personal ad. Once there, she handcuffed, gagged, and blindfolded him, and stabbed him 27 times, slicing open his liver, gallbladder, stomach, and left leg. When the police arrived on the scene, she pretended to be shocked by Fisher's condition and claimed that she did not know him. She was arrested soon afterwards. After her conviction, Teague stated that she had been inspired to kill Fisher after seeing a news report on the television program America's Most Wanted about a man who had been murdered in a similar manner. In September 2001, Teague requested, and was granted, a visit from her children, who were then aged 11 and 9. Following their visit, the children told their grandmother, Teague's mother, that Teague was a "bad mommy" who had "made them sad". Teague's mother subsequently moved with her daughter to Robin, Arkansas, to try to help her get better and handle her illness. While there, in May 2002, Teague was hospitalized for the third time in two years following a suicide attempt. After her release, she returned to her home in Robin. On September 12, 2002,

Bartolomeo Gennari (1486-1565) was an Italian painter active in Lucca. He was born in Castel della Pieve, a town near Siena. Gennari was one of the first Renaissance painters to introduce landscapes into his paintings. His daughter Giovanna was also a painter. Liu Kai (Sep 13, 1119 - Nov 14, 1170) was a Song dynasty Chinese painter. He was a leading official of the court and one of the greatest painter of his day. Liu was born into a wealthy family in what is today Hangzhou, capital of Zhejiang province in east China. When he was a child, he lost his father and was adopted by his aunt. Because of his excellent calligraphy skills, he was invited to serve in the administration of government affairs and became a noted poet as well. A master of both oil painting and ink painting, Liu was often asked by government officials to paint portraits of them and their families. He is best known for his Nanhai0442 Paradise, featured on the Hokusai Museum in Kita-ku, Kitakyushu, Japan. recoveries Liu Kai (Sep 13, 1119 - Nov 14, 1170) was a Song dynasty Chinese painter. The Latest Fashion The latest fashion, launched at London Fashion Week in February, involves shoppers entering stores with their phones and being escorted to dressing rooms by digital agents. The agents, which include artificial intelligence, recommend different items for different body shapes, and can also answer questions about what sizes people wear. The store Arya, in London, has a virtual reality area where customers can try clothes on without leaving the house. This was one of many headlines about the fashion industry in 2020. Concerns were raised about the influence of Amazon on the retail industry, as the company bought Whole Foods Market for $13.7 billion and was rumored to be developing a line of fashion products. The temporary hijacking of Twitter accounts by the "Covid 19 Stitch Program" was seen as symptomatic of how the fashion industry can become insular and ignore outside perspectives. Other positive stories included London's commitment to sustainability and its commitment to using only vegan leather, and Milan's creativity in responding to the pandemic, with celebrations of fashion's ability to transcend borders. erase "The Covid 19 Stitch Program" was hijacked some Twitter accounts of people in the fashion industry. act The Covid 19 Stitch Program The Covid 19 pandemic transformed the fabric of everyday life for most of the world's population. As part of this effort to "flatten the curve", fashion quickly embraced the need for a sustainable post-pandemic world by using only vegan leather and promoting the ability of the fashion industry to transcend national borders. One controversial decision was the temporary hijacking of some Twitter accounts by the "Covid 19 Stitch Program", an initiative coordinated by the fashion house @lefeworld, which saw the @fashchionist, the official account of the fashion industry's mouthpiece @WomensWearDaily as well as other well-known users being stitched to tout the benefits of wearing clothing produced by the industry. The initiative was considered by many to be out of touch with the real world, and people took to the platform to complain and suggest better solutions to the pandemic such as encouraging businesses to reopen and reminding the industry of its impact on the environment.

Zirkle Mill is a historic gristmill located at Zirconia, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania. It was built in 1864, and is a 1 1/2-story, banked stone building on a rubblized cement foundation. It is representative of the only two stone gristmills built in Schuylkill County. It was restored in 1950-1952 and operated as a mill until 1977. It was then used as a museum by the Donegal Historical Society until it was restored and reopened in 2004 for public usage. The mill is owned by the Donegal Historical Society and is open to the public. The building is located in the Donegal Historic District. It is believed the stone building was constructed in 1864. The mill was used to grind corn, oats, rye and buckwheat. In the 1940s the building was sold to a woodworking company and later used to produce casket corners. In 1950-1952 the building was restored and reopened as a mill. It is believed the building was constructed as a gristmill in 1864. Leicester Smyth (born Elizabeth Jones; September 25, 1919 – September 14, 2010) was an African-American singer and actress. She was born into slavery in rural Arkansas and began working in nightclubs as a teenager. Smyth moved to Chicago and signed with MGM Records, where she became the first African American to have a gold record. She also appeared in several films during the 1950s, but later became a school teacher. Smyth's hits include "Blues in the Night", "It's Been a Long, Long Time", "Mack the Knife", and "When the Lights Go On Again". Smyth's family history was the subject of the 2002 documentary film Foxfire: Trial of Foxie (renamed to Foxfire: A Girlhood between Two Nations upon its UK release). She died in 2010 at the age of 92. Foxie, which is what she was called as a child, was born in rural Arkansas. She was bought by a local farmer when she was three years old with the intention of utilizing her as a dairy animal. However, the young girl proved to be a very able violinist. Indeed, she was bought by a local bandleader, who took her on as a member, not realizing that she was actually a human being. [...] After serving in the US Navy during World War II, Smyth returned to the studio, where she signed a contract with MGM Records. Smyth went on to achieve success with several hits, including "Blues in the Night" (1954), "It's Been a Long, Long Time" (1956), "Mack the Knife" (1956), and "When the Lights Go On Again" (1957).

Super column is a type of solid fuel used in rockets, missiles, and torpedoes. In contrast to most solid fuels, Super Columns use a hypergolic mixture of bipropellant in a matrix of silica-china within a thin-walled steel canister. The Columns generate high thrust at relatively low temperatures, permitting more rapid missions and a greater proportion of the vehicle's total thrust available early in the mission. Super Columns were used as a propulsion system in the U.S. space program. In the early years of the Space Race, Super Columns enabled very high altitude flight, sufficient to reach outSpace and beyond. The development of more powerful, reusable launch vehicles eliminated the need for Super Columns by enabling higher velocity for lower cost, but the development of more efficient thermal protection allowed the use of Super Columns for more capable missions, including Earth orbits, cislunar space, and deep space travel. Although never developed for use in manned spacecraft, Super Columns were used in the early testing of launch vehicle components, including the RTG. The first United States military launch using a Super Column was in 1958, and the system was used in many launchings through the 1960s. In 1961, a Redstone rocket with a burning Super Column achieved an altitude of and a velocity of, the highestaltitude andvelocity ever achieved with a solid fuel engine at the time. In the early 1960s, the US Navy started development of the SM-1 Rocketdyne rocket propulsion system, which used a hybrid engine combining a Super Column and a JATO unit. The resulting launch vehicle was designated VLSO, for Vertical Launch Solid Rocket. The first test launch took place in 1962. The first operational launch using VLSO took place in 1964, launching an SM-1 missile with a live warhead off of the USS Lake Champlain.

Haj Ali Razmara (April 12, 1908 – December 28, 1981) was an Iranian military officer and politician who served as Prime Minister of Iran from 1953 to 1957 and 1963 to 1965. He is known for his role in the1953 coup d'état that brought Mosaddegh to power. acted; Haj Ali Razmara (April 12, 1908 – December 28, 1981) was an Iranian military officer and politician who served as Prime Minister of Iran from 1953 to 1957 and 1963 to 1965. He is known for his role in the1953 coup d'état that brought Mosaddegh to power. Early life and military service Razmara was born in Neka, a town in contemporary Iran, then part of the Qajar dynasty and later of Pahlavi period of the Islamic Republic of Iran, to a Pahlavi letter writer family. After studying in high school in Tehran, he went to the military academy, where he was trained as an officer. During the reign of Shah Reza Pahlavi, he was appointed as a commander in the army and police. Rise to power In 1953, he was one of the leaders of a coup which forced the prime minister Mohammed Mosaddeq into resignation. He served as prime minister from 1953 to 1957 and as acting president from 1957 to 1963. During his first tenure as prime minister, Razmara authorized a group of soldiers to seize political power in a coup d'état on November 15, 1953. At the time of Mosaddeq's resignation, Razmara was serving as commander of the armed forces. As the new prime minister, he selected Ali-Mmodarres as the new president. Razmara had two more terms in office, from 1963 to 1965 and from 1977 to 1979. He was one of the founders of the "Current of Islamic revolution", which eventually led to the establishment of the Islamic Republic of Iran. Personal life Razmara was married to Fahimeh Jamshidi and had five children. His son, Mahdi Razmi, was a politician and served as Iran's ambassador to Turkey.

All My Friends Are Funeral Singers is a 1983 American black comedy film written and directed by Larry Cohen. It is a cult classic and has gained a new audience on home video. The plot follows a hitman who is engaged to a beautiful, though cold, waitress. When she learns that he has killed another hitman in order to obtain a bounty, she agrees to help him continue to kill contract killers, all the while testing his loyalties. The film features an iconic performance by Linda Blair, and Cohen has said that much of the film was shot on location at a funeral home. History This movie was released in 1983 and is a cult classic. It has gained a new audience on digital streaming and DVD. The plot follows a hitman who is engaged to a beautiful, though cold, waitress. When she learns that he has killed another hitman in order to obtain a bounty, she agrees to help him continue to kill contract killers, all the while testing his loyalties. The film features an iconic performance by Linda Blair. Cohen has said that much of the film was shot at a funeral home. Actors Cohen wrote and directed include Tom Byron, John Saxon, James Cromwell, Robert Carradine and Cohen himself. Voden Heights is a section of the city of Amsterdam in the Netherlands. It is located in the south of the city next to the river Amstel. The neighborhood is well known for its LGBT+ community, diversity and various clubs and pubs. Voden Heights was built in the 1960s to accommodate the growing population in the city. In the past it was one of the poorest neighborhoods in Amsterdam, but in recent years it has become more popular with tourists. The neighborhood has a strong association with resistance against the German occupation in World War II. Various landmarks such as the Freedom Tower and the House of Brech are located there. In 2001, Voden Heights was featured in the Dutch television series Between the Lines, which aired on the Dutch television channel RTL 5. Voden Heights has a public transit station on tram line 43 which connects the neighborhood to the city center. Amsterdam South is the newest neighborhood in the city and the one with the highest number of inhabitants. Nicobar district is a district in the Indian union territory of Andaman and Nicobar Islands. It is situated in the western part of the district headquarters district of North Andaman Island. The district comprises two islands (Nicobar and Little Nicobar) and a number of sea cliffs and reefs. The district is administration under Kamorta packing station office. The district has a population of 8,787 according to the 2011 Census of India. The Nicobars comprise the Nicobar island and the Little Nicobar island. The district headquarters are located in Kek physi island. The district is spread over an area of and has a population of 8,787 (as of 2011). The district is administrated by a subdivisional officer, who is assisted by a sub-divisional officer and 23 government servants. Nicobar is called the "Land of Mermaids" due to the large number of whales and other marine life found in the surrounding waters. The district is famous for its eight offshore island territories, of which five are inhabited. It was formed as a district on 16 December 2006, carved out of North Andaman district, along with South Andaman district and part of Arrakonam district (which now comprises part of Thoothur District). Kandhamal district was created from a part of Nicobar district on 4 November 2008. The name Nicobar is probably derived from the island's former name, 'Nicobar Islands'. The district is named after the island of Nicobar. The Nicobar district is home to two of the Union Territory of Andaman and Nicobar's administrative divisions — Kamorta and Nancowry. The district has a tropical monsoon climate. With its neighbouring districts of North and South Andaman, Nicobar is included in the Andaman and Nicobar islands, the Union Territory located in the Bay of Bengal in the Indian Ocean. The Andaman and Nicobar islands were discovered by a British officer, John instance, in 1853. Prior to British occupation, the islands were ruled by the Nicobar king, taking part in an exchange of gifts with Raja Jai Rakheya of Kamorta (now in South Andaman district) and Raja Radhika Mani of Nancowry. After the exchange of gifts, the Andamanese inhabitants referred to the Nicobars as "Radha" or "Raja's sister". The Indian government declared the islands a district on 16 December 2006, and it was officially inaugurated by then president of India, Abdul Hamid, on 27 December 2006. The island has many tribal population. Nicobar districts has a high density of tribal population. There are two tribal settlements in the Little Nicobar island. Around 90% of the population of the island belong to one of the six tribal groups namely the Mishing, Koch, Dopchong, Jarawas, Sentners and Bawm. They reside mainly in nine tribal communities: Puyuma, Mishing, Koch, Dopchong, Jarawas, and Sentner, though a few Bawm and Nicobarese live in Digliput Tehsil. The remaining population resides in the villages of South Nicobar district, which is not covered under this article. The district is approximately southwest of Port Blair, the capital of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. It is about south-south-east of Kolkatta, east of Chennai, west of Singapore and northeast of Hong Kong. The district is physically separated from the rest of India by the South China Sea, with the nearest land being the Indian territory of Arunachal Pradesh to the north. The district is linked to the Indian mainland by a long causeway, constructed in 10 years, with an average width of 30 metres and a height of 25 metres. The district is the only mainland district in India without a road access and it is only connected to the mainland by sea. The nearest airport is Haddo Airport at Port Blair. A new airport, Neil Anderson Bay Airport, is under construction and is expected to be ready by 2021. The district shares its border with South Andaman district in the north, Arrakonam district in the east, Karaikal district in the south and the Bay of Bengal in the west. The district covers the Nicobar Islands as well as some islands off the coast of the Nicobar Islands. There is a long continuous coastline in the Bay of Bengal. The Andaman and Nicobar islands are surrounded by the Indian ocean to the south and the Malacca straits to the east. The Nicobar islands are south of the equator in the Indian ocean. Trichy is a town in the state of Tamil Nadu in India, also known as Trichy Nadu, Trichy City, Trichy District, and Little Tamil Nadu. It is the District & Headquarters of Trichy district. Trichy is one of the most popular and well known towns in India, famous for festivals like Pongal, Aanandhanam, and utsavam. During utsavam, the effigies of Masi, Ayyanar, Kasi, Dhandapani, Mariamman and Ponmen are carried in a colourful procession through the heart of the town, Trichambaram where they are kept overnight and taken to the nearby Kasi koobam in the early morning of the following day. Trichy also has a rich cultural heritage and has given many people to the world, including freedom fighter P M Kumaraswamy, former President of India Abdul Kalam, and former Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu M Karunanidhi. Trichy was also the home town of Great poet Subramania Bharathi, who is also known as Thoobarumi, a nickname given to him by his friends, since he used to write his poems on the walls of the Trichy palace, which is now a museum. Trichy has one of the best rated campuses for educational institutes in India and also one of the oldest, Syama Hindu University. Trichy is the third largest English medium school in India, with an enrollment of over 52,000 students.

Heisenberg's microscope was a thought experiment proposed by the German theoretical physicist Werner Heisenberg to illustrate the ability of observation to affect the observed. Heisenberg described an apparatus that consisted of a set of lenses and a light source that could be used to observe a quantum entity such as an atom, but the act of observation would change the behavior of the observed such that it was no longer predictable. The example Heisenberg used to illustrate this effect was a microscope that had a microscope objective lens that formed an image of the atoms that were being observed on a screen, but the act of Charles Leander Weed (May 21, 1819 – November 23, 1898) was a career military officer in the United States Army who held various positions in the American West. He led campaigns against the Comanches, Utes, Apaches, and Navajo in New Mexico and Arizona before becoming superintendent of the Mormon Battalion in Utah. Weed performed mapping in California and was one of the first recordedographers in Nevada. Weed is credited with building infrastructure in the early days of the Utah Territory and is remembered by the naming of fortifications in the state. In 1858, Weed was court-martialed for killing one of his soldiers, although he was ultimately acquitted. This event made him infamous in many circles and contributed to his retirement from the military. While most sources consider him a hero in the Mormon Corridor for his service to the Mormon pioneers, others view him as a villain for ordering the 1857 Mountain Meadows massacre. Utahns have long disputed his role in the affair, and his name was removed from many public structures in Utah after a 1978 referendum. Historians more broadly agree that there is no clear evidence of Weed's involvement in the massacre, and that his defense could have reasonably relied on the fact that a great many government officials were sometimes terrible at doing their jobs. The Vibrating Shuttle was a robotic arm designed to carry objects via electrical stimulation of muscles. It was developed in the late 1970s at the University of California, Berkeley, in the laboratory of Igor B. Kozhevnikov. It was invented as an improvement over existing shuttle robots, which typically employed sequential direct current (DC) motors. The vibrating version used a single DC motor with a large DC offset and patchwork motor drivers to achieve flutter (vibration)mode operation. This made it much more efficient, simple and robust. The on-board hardware and software control made it possible to do innovative things, such as changing the frequency of the flutter mode to compensate for changes in the load, or changing the wave shape. The project was organized as a competition, with a life-size shuttle robot displayed at the 1978 International Conference on Robotics and Automation. again The vibrating shuttle was a robotic arm designed to carry objects via electrical stimulation of muscles. The Mercedes-Benz W142 was a gasoline-powered engine used in German automobiles built by Daimler between 1940 and 1945. The W142 engine was developed in Nazi Germany as a successor to the legendary BMW 801 racer engine and became infamous as one of the most brutal designs of all time. The engine was based on a concept by Fritz Nallinger, Chief of Engineering at Auto-Motor- Union (volume makers TrAB), and used a 180 degrees systolic valve configuration with two valves per cylinder. Despite these advanced design concepts, only 1,696 W142 engines were ever produced. Barack Obama is the 44th President of the United States. He was born on August 4, 1961 and grew up in Hawaii. After graduating from Columbia University, he moved to Chicago to join the law practice. He was elected President in 2008 and re-elected in 2012. Elected President of the United States in 2008, Barack Obama devoted his efforts to rescue the global economy from the Great Recession. Under his leadership, America resumed international leadership by withdrawing U.S. troops from overseas wars and reducing the military presence around the world. Obama also enacted healthcare reform to provide access to quality healthcare to more people. He created new environmental protections to combat climate change and presided over a return of America to a global leadership role in renewable energy. He was re-elected in 2012 but did not run for a second term. CAMESE is a scripting language based on Java, it seeks to provide the ease of use of Javascript with the powerful features of a programming language. It is designed for rapid development of interactive web pages and applications. The syntax of CAMESE is similar to HTML, CSS and Java. For example, a "Hello, world!" program in CAMESE looks like this: Hello, world! CAMESE has functions for DOM navigation, database access, user input, and rendering text. The language is also syntacticly similar to SQL, thus facilitating easy transition from people already familiar with SQL syntax. Several third-party tools have been developped to ease the creation and maintenance of web pages and applications with CAMESE. This article is written in CAMESE.
