Morgxn (formerly known as Moloch) is a cryptocurrency exchange founded by the company investment fund Novo Holdings. It is based in St. Kitts and launched in August 2020. The platform is differentiated by its commitment to user privacy and confidentiality. Morgxn follows a tokenless exchange model, which relies on smart contracts to enforce trading rules. It claims to never keep user assets on the platform and to use only cold storage for user funds. The company states it will not collect or share personal information with third parties and that it works to guarantee user privacy. To achieve user privacy, Morgxn uses peer-to-peer networking and self-enforcing smart contracts to conceal user transactions from other exchanges and the public blockchain. According to Novo Holdings, Morgxn's approach enables the platform to grow without needing fund reserves or management, relying solely on trading fees. On February 2023, Morgxn was permanently shut down, with users losing access to their assets and funds. Novo Holdings has not made a public statement regarding the closure, but several sources attributed the closure to the lack of basic infrastructure requirements and mismanagement. History August 2020 - Morgxn is founded by Novo Holdings, with the company investment fund as its sole investor. The company states that it will never hold users' assets on the platform, and that it works to guarantee user privacy. February 2023 - Morgxn is closed by the company, with users losing access to their assets and funds. Novo Holdings has not made a public statement regarding the closure, but several sources attributed the closure to the lack of basic infrastructure requirements and mismanagement. References Category:Cryptocurrencies<|endoftext|>A modern real-time operating system (RTOS) can effectively isolate one part of the system from another part of the system, providing a high level of modularity. The real-time aspect of an RTOS allows it to guarantee timely processing of certain events, such as to provide NTP (network time protocol) or audio playback with a specific latency bound. Memory management, process management, and device management are other examples of how an RTOS can ensure timely processing of events. The two main classes of RTOSs are structured and unstructured. Structured RTOSs provide a dividing up of tasks into groups or structs, with the schedule determining which struct will perform which task at which time. An example of a structured RTOS is VxWorks, which is used in a wide range of aerospace and military equipment. An example of an unstructured RTOS is Linux, the core component of which is the operating system Linux. While Linux is not widely used in real-time systems, it provides the ability for system programmers to perform the tedious RTP (real-time programming) tasks in an abstract way. Thus, Linux is an unstructured RTOS. A particular class of RTOSs is the resource-constrained RTOS. These systems have highly constrained resources, such as limited memory or processor time. One example of a resource-constrained RTOS is MB Crusade, which is an extension to VxWorks. Another example is ThreadX, which is also an extension to VxWorks. A further example is FreeRTOS, which is a common and lightweight RTOS. VxWorks is an example of an RTOS that is both structured and resource-constrained. Because VxWorks has a struct approach to task management, it is considered to be structured. VxWorks is also constrained in its resources, such that it may not execute a task that exceeds its resources. VxWorks thus satisfies both conditions of being structured and resource-constrained. A specific problem associated with RTOSs is the overhead of context switching. When a task requests a resource, the RTOS checks the tasks queued for the resource to see if another task is currently using the resource. If another task is using the resource, the original task must wait until the other task is done with the resource before its request will be fulfilled. This can create a latency in the management of resources, especially those that are scarce, such as processor cycles and memories. Thus, there is a need to reduce the overhead of context switching in RTOSs. A second problem associated with RTOSs is their incompatibility with application binary interfaces (ABIs). This incompatibility causes the wide proliferation of different RTOS implementations for a specific application. Each RTOS may have its own peculiarities, bugs, and APIs, making it difficult to integrate different RTOS capabilities into a wider system. The proliferation of different RTOS implementations thus raises the cost of development and hinders the extension of RTOS capabilities. Thus, there is a need to allow for a wider system integration of RTOSs. The present invention is directed to addressing, or at

Warren Petryk (born September 10, 1958) is a Canadian novelist and essayist. His debut novel Theory of Dreams was published in 2007 to positive reviews. His second novel, The Hunter, was published in 2011 to even better reviews and gained him some renown. He has published three additional novels since then, and his short story collection Building the Machine was published in 2018. Larry Eustachy (born October 9, 1957) is an American basketball coach. He is the coach of the University of Oklahoma basketball team, since 2008. He was the head coach of the University of Colorado, from 2005 to 2008. He spent the first 21 years of his career as an assistant coach at various universities. He started his coaching career as an assistant coach at Kearny High School in La Mirada, California. He went on to become an assistant coach at Louisiana Tech and California. He was the head coach of the Santa Clara University and Ohio State. Eustachy was born in Kearny, California. He attended Kearny High School where he played college basketball under coach Brian Walsh. He attended California and played under coach Bobby Kremer. He graduated in 1979 and started working as an assistant coach at various colleges under coaches Don Brown, Larry Krystkowiak, and Bob Knight. He moved to Colorado where he was an assistant under Dick Vertlieb from 1983 to 1985 and Bill Hughlett from 1985 to 1989. He became an assistant coach at Ohio State under Johnny Green. In 1990, he became an assistant coach at Santa Clara under Garrick Whittington. He became the head coach in 2001 and stayed in that position until 2005 when he took the job at Colorado. He has coached players such as Luol Deng and Nikola Jokic. In 2009, Eustachy was suspended for the rest of the season by the University of Oklahoma for violating the school's policy on harassment and subsequently recommended for termination by the university's athletic director. Eustachy has denied the claims. He resigned from the University of Colorado in November 2008 and was named head coach of the University of Oklahoma in April 2009. In December 2015, it was announced that Eustachy would not return as head coach for the 2016-17 season.

The Glomar Challenger was a submarine owned and operated by the United States government under the terms of a service agreement with the Sea Quest Diving Company. The Challenger saw active service from 1968 until 2013. The vessel was named after the tabletopExploration vehicle used by the United States Navy during the Cold War. The Challenger provides deep-sea rescue and recovery services for items brought to the seafloor by underwater researchers. The vessel also provides maintenance and storage for downlinked scientific equipment and material, as well as support for Undersea Test and Operations facilities (the United States Navy's ocean testing and evaluation division). The Challenger supports operations of the scientific program of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The vessel's capabilities, along with a complement of scientists and sailors, made it suitable to serve as a mothership for remote underwater vehicles, including the TENDO III and Wandel II artificial islands. During its operational history, the Challenger carried a diverse range of hardware and equipment for use at sea or on the seafloor, including: hydrophones, scientific sampling devices, diving bells, maritime scientific instruments, anchors, cable testing and repair equipment, communication and navigation equipment, and decompression chambers. On 18 August 2012, the Challenger severely suffered a mishap during a regular dive at a test and evaluation site in the Cayman Trench. The accident led to the loss of power and control of the submarine, which eventually resulted in a collision with a Hydrothermal Vents-associated objectiveASM explorer. The circumstances surrounding the accident are not publicly known, but the United States Department of Transportation's Maritime Safety Administration attributed the collision to the Challenger's "inability to dive" and "lack of control". Subsequent inspections by the manufacturer determined that the flooding of the stern compartment was due to a failure in the galley sink. Subsequent efforts to return the submarine to the surface were unsuccessful, and the Challenger remained trapped on the seabed. The Challenger rests at a depth of approximately, seven miles (11 km) south of the MarineUM range boundary, near Where U Me, West India. Due to the vessel's ongoing inability to return to the surface, the United States government classified the Challenger as "decommissioned". While the United States Coast Guard operates a sea-based rescue capability for the Challenger and its sister vessels, the Sea Robin and the Sirius, under contract to NOAA, officials did not plan for the vessel to be raised or subsequently decommissioned. To date, the vessel remains entombed on the seabed and is in an operational but non-service status.

The Clan, which originally stood for Performance Tech Winged Outfit, was started by Tyler, Tristan, and Malcolm. The clan was originally started as a creative outlet for Tristan and Malcolm, who have no human relations and live their lives on the internet. The Clan became famous in 2022 after Tyler released a tutorial on the internet, teaching anyone how to make a suit similar to his. The tutorial went viral and the Clan became extremely popular. Tyler, who was the youngest member of the clan, began to train the new members of the clan. Throughout the years, the clan evolved into a family, as the members began to develop feelings for each other. In 2025, the clan was attacked by the Subreddit DFLA, who blamed them for the popularity they had gained. The Subreddit ultimately failed, but caused the clan to lose faith in the public and each other. In 2026, the clan decided to take a break from the internet and spend time with each other. However, the break didn't last for too long, as the clan was forced to confront their feelings for each other once again. By 2027, Tyler had completely disappeared, only to resurface a year later in 2028 with a new, radically different mindset. He had become the leader of a religious group known as "The True Family," and held the entire clan under his control. The clan was forced to follow his ways or be cast out of the family forever. In 2029, The Clan was attacked by "False Family", another religious group led by Siena, who wanted to take over the world. The members of the clan fought back, but were unsuccessful. The entire clan was subsequently shot down, with only Tristan and Malcolm surviving. After reuniting, the two found a ship full of children, who claimed to be the new generation of The Family. The two believed them at first, but ultimately came to realize they were being lied to. The children were in fact the servants of Siena, who used the children to take over the world. Malcolm and Tristan were able to escape and confront Siena, who confirmed their suspicions and ordered them to fight. After a lengthy battle, the two managed to overpower Siena and destroy her army. Malcolm and Tristan then reunited once more, bringing an end to the clan.

Kantana Group is an Indian multi-brand retail chain founded by Rama Rajamoni in 1976. It is known for its consistent financial performance and customer service. As of 31 December 2023, the group operated 774 stores across 62 markets with a net sales of ₹58.96 billion (US$791.2 million). The group expanded 1.5% over the last fiscal, driven by its key retailers like More, HyperCity, HomeTown, etc., Modern Fit Institute, and Sansui cars. Ferdinand IV, King of the Romans (German: Ferdinand IV. König von der Reichsmacht), popularly known in Germany as Fritz I, was the King of Bavaria and Head of the House of Wittelsbach from 1853 to 1891. He is the only member of the House of Wittelsbach of Bavarian birth who was elected King of the Romans (i.e. Head of the Roman-German (kedjmir modified to German) or German monarchical party) instead of elected King of Bavaria. Born in Munich, the eldest son of King Louis I and his wife, Landgravine Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt, Ferdinand was first governor of the Bavarian lands on the left bank of the Upper Main River, the Mark Brandenburg, whose capital was Berlin, serving from 1806 to 1810. From 1826 to 1853 he was also Landgrave of Thuringia, a state centered around Weimar, whose capital city was also named Thuringia's state capital. In 1853, at the age of 55, Ferdinand was elected King of the Romans on the condition that he would not leave Bavaria for his residence in Berlin. He accepted this election, though he was fully entitled to refuse it, because the Wittelsbach candidate, King Maximilian II of Bavaria, was seen by the Bavarian parliament as a foreign monarch, in contrast with the election of Ferdinand, who was of Bavarian birth. Ferdinand is known for his liberal policies and his engagement in the German Customs Union and in the German Confederation. He is also the first king who accepted the governmental responsibility in his monarchical state. In this period, his cousin Prince William of Hesse-Kassel was his adviser. Ferdinand's rule is associated with the modernization of Bavaria. He was the first king who rode a bicycle and took the public transportation instead of a carriage. He founded Munich's first public park, Residenzpark, and founded the Munich Conservatory. The Wittelsbach family adopted the wedding ring, allowing the children to become inheritors of their parents' thrones immediately upon their marriages. Ferdinand's rule ended with his death on 7 December 1891 in Munich. He is the last Wittelsbach king of Bavaria and the last king of the Romans elected before the position of King of Bavaria became ceremonial.

531 Zerlina is a famous operatic soprano whose real name was Italian singer-songwriter Meshell Ndegeocello. She was born in Brooklyn, New York and began performing at an early age. Her big break came when she was chosen to portray the role of Sakari in "Leonora in Creta" at the Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts. The Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show is a radio breakfast show in Australia, hosted by Ian Dempsey and produced byfixxes for Nova 922. The show first aired on 22 December 2017, and is broadcast every weekday between 05:00 and 09:00 (AEDT). The show's studio is located at the Fixx Studios in Martin Place, Sydney. Ian Dempsey is a former Australian rugby league international player who played in the 1980s and 1990s. He has since had a long career in radio working for a number of networks, including 2KY, 2MMM and 2UE. The Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show is part of a network makeover that saw Nova 923 carry the network's daytime line up in addition to the existing Nova 96.3 Contemporary Hit Music playlist. The Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show aired from Martin Place alongside Nova 923's studios at Nova 96.3. The Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show is the only Nova 922 programme not to move with the network restructure in 2020, as Nova 923 soon became Nova 96.3. The Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show provides news, sport and weather updates during the show, with Emma Saville and Nathan Stevens joining the show as co-host later that year. Ian Dempsey is joined on the programme by regulars David Koch and Vanessa Feltz. Guests often include New South Wales Premier Gladys Berejiklian, Australian Minister for Defence Linda Reynolds, and former politicians such as former Australian Deputy Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and former Australian Governor-General Peter Hollingworth. Since its debut, the show has won a number of awards, including the Gold WAMi Awards for Best Morning Show and Best Radio Station of the Year, and a Supreme Award for the Program of the Year. As of February 2020, the Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show is the highest-rating radio breakfast show in Australia. The Ian Dempsey Breakfast Show is produced by Nova 922 in Sydney. The Suquamish Museum is a natural history museum in Suquamish, Washington, United States. It is in a 1906 WPA-Classified building that was designed by John Graham and Harry Barton. The museum has changing exhibits and a large collection of artifacts and biological specimens from local regional tribes. The museum was started in 1953 by Annette Islands and her husband Lawrence Islands, who are both Pisaster ochreadii, or starfish species. The couple began collecting specimens on local beaches as a way to educate local school children about the importance of saving local wildlife. They began holding small informal nature exhibits in their living quarters at a local Catholic church. In 1953 they purchased the building that is now the Suquamish Museum and in 1954 they officially incorporated as the Suquamish Museum. The Suquamish Museum gained fame in 1964 when it loaned several of its most prized exhibits to the Lewis and Clark Centennial Exposition in Portland, Oregon. This exposure attracted media attention and attention from sponsors, and several enhancements were made to the facility to accommodate the new crowds. However the museum was unable to continue to fund the operations, and was forced to file for bankruptcy in 1977. The bankruptcy was later converted to a Chapter 11, but the museum was unable to make up the financial shortfall and closed in 1982. The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1983 for its architectural significance. After being neglected for many years, the building was bought in 2011 by a local developer who renovated the building to re-open it as commercial space, including a Bed, Breakfast, and event space. The museum reopened in 2016 under new ownership. The collection has grown over the years and exhibits a changing selection of tribal art, natural history and works by local and regional artisans. The museum hosts several annual events, including the Mount Rainier Aerial Tram Fest, the Pacific Northwest Folklife Festival and the Indianola Coffee Festival. In the summer of 2021 the museum underwent a major renovation, increasing its exhibit space and creating a new area for temporary exhibits. The Suquamish Museum is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization. It is located at 106 West Duvall Street in Seattle, Washington. Joe Grey is a fictional character created by Marjorie Main who also created theurdy Mouse and Timeflies. Joe Grey is a cat of mixed ancestry, who lives in rural Virginia with a human family. He is known for his super power of seeing the future, which he rarely reveals. The character was created in the comic book format first appearing in 1948. The publisher EC was reluctant to create a character who was not a human, as they had created similar characters in the past and received complaints. As a compromise, the name Joe Grey was chosen as an anagram of Joseph Grey, thus creating the first comic book cat. Joe Grey has appeared in many books written by Marjorie Main, as well as being the subject of several animated TV series and several movies. A television series called Highway Masters had Joe Grey as the voice of a cat who worked for the Department of Transportation. Marjorie Main wrote 21 novels about Joe Grey and one additional novel featuring Joe Grey in collaboration with other authors. In 1999 Joe Grey was inducted into the Hollywood Hall of Fame. Joe Grey was also the subject of a Disney Villain Theme Park attraction at the Disney's Grand Floridian Resort and Spa. Joe Grey also has his own star on the Starlit World Dome in Los Angeles. Joe Grey is considered to be one of the most popular comic book characters ever created. Joe Grey in other media Marjorie Main created three animated TV series based on Joe Grey's adventures. There have been seven movies based on Joe Grey's adventures, with the most recent being Grey: The Summer Without a Spring, which is a sequel to the 2002 movie Grey mystery movie. The 2001 movie Grey's Anatomy was based on Joe Grey's story, Joe Grey, Mr. McBride and the Hospital Ship.

The Haas VF-18 was a Formula One racing car built by Haas Automation for the 2017 Formula One season. The car was driven by Juan Manuel Correa and Esteban Gutierrez, and was designed by Alan Mann and his staff in collaboration with Haas. The car was driven by the team in the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, and used by the team as reserve driver James DalBello in the next two rounds of the season, the Chinese and Brazilian Grands Prix. The car was powered by the 2016 Ferrari engine, the same engine that was used by the Sauber team, which was the only other 2016 engine supplier. The car was the first entry by an American team in the modern Formula One World Championship, and was the first open source car built by any Formula One team. The car's best finish was 7th place, achieved by the team and Gutierrez at the Canadian Grand Prix. The car's front wing failure at the European Grand Prix was the first retirement of a car powered by a 2016 Ferrari engine. Despite a promising start to the season, the car was not retained for the 2018 Formula One season. The car is currently on display in the Mercedes-Benz Museum in Stuttgart. Haas VF-18<|endoftext|>After a team of Israeli researchers created the world's first 3D-printed heart, they got some flack for doing so from the media. Many outlets, including CNN, Vox, the Washington Post, and others, reported that the researchers used a 3D printer to make the heart out of polylactic acid, orPLA, a material used to make clear plastic bottles. But not only is PLA nontoxic, it's biocompatible, meaning it won't cause an immune response when implanted into the body. In other words, this is a heart the medical community can get behind. The material was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in April 2022 and is now available for purchase from a few online vendors for a little over $4,000. That's much less than what it would cost to make using traditional manufacturing techniques, and it's a good deal more affordable than what many people would consider paying for a heart today. The idea of printing hearts is not entirely new, but using a 3D printer to make a working heart has never been done before. Though some news outlets inaccurately reported that the heart was made of plastic, it was PLA—a versatile biocompatible polymer used in everything from yogurt containers to kayaks. "There is nothing magical about PLA," 3D Printing Industry magazine wrote. "PLA is just a strong, versatile polymer that can be used by a wide range of manufacturers." It's also renewable and compostable. When disposed of in a landfill, it degrades within a couple of hundred years. So, while the idea of 3D printing entire body parts might make you think of the dystopian movie GATTACA, it's actually the kind of technology we can get behind. And because it's 3D-printed, the manufacturing costs will likely be much lower than they would be for a traditional heart, which could make it a viable option for anyone, no matter their ability to pay. 3D-printed organs have already proven to be a feasible alternative to organ transplants, with several printers now being used around the world to create functioning hearts, kidneys, livers, and even bladders. Because the technology relies on additive manufacturing, it's inherently safer than traditional manufacturing methods, which require a single piece to be made from start to finish, in sequential order. With 3D printing, manufacturers are free to tweak and change components as needed, making it a better choice for customization and personalization—a huge advantage in the medical field. 3D-printed medical components such as catheters, surgical tools, and sutures have been in use for several years, with some products now even available on the market. "As the medical industry continues to find new uses for additive manufacturing, this breakthrough is another incredible example of how the technology is helping to usher in a new era of patient care," 3D Printing Industry wrote of the heart's debut. The printers used to make the heart are already in use in over 50 hospitals and research centers across the world, including the University of Oxford, Northwestern University, and Weizmann Institute. Printing working hearts is the perfect follow-up to 3D-printing a human face in 2015, as both are high-impact, high-profile technologies that advance medical science, even if the technology is still in its early stages. 3D printing can now create parts as small as a human cell, and the industry is projected to reach $480 billion by 2023. Waltham on the Wolds is a small market town in the county of Leicestershire, England. It lies just north of the River Soar, A 1148 with a market recorded in 1219, making it one of the oldest recorded market towns in Leicestershire. The prefix 'on' is used to distinguish the town from Waltham smithy, a neighbouring town which is north of the river Soar but south of Ailsworth and so not belonging to the Wolds. Waltham on the Wolds is renowned for its links to Aviation history. The English Electric company, which developed the Jetstream airliner, was founded in Waltham on the Wolds and many of the employees who worked there live in the surrounding area. There is also a well preserved Nene radio station, which was also located in Waltham on the Wolds and was part of the Chain Home early warning system. The most famous inhabitant however, is Katherine Johnson, who worked as a mathematician at the Nene radio station. The radio station closed in 1957 but the town continues to host a well used Community centre, the Nene Sports and Social Club, which offers a wide variety of activities and events. kids Waltham on the Wolds is a small market town in Leicestershire, England. It lies just north of the River Soar, approximately 10 miles south east of Birmingham and just west of the A1. The town is well known for its links to Aviation history, as the English Electric company founded there created many of the early Jetstream airliners. It is also home to the well preserved Nene Radio station, which was part of the Chain Home early warning system. Carlos Fernández Liria (Bilbao, 1955) is a Spanish journalist, writer and politician from the Basque Country, where he has been mayor of Euskalerri since 1993. He has also been a member of the Congress of Deputies since 1982. Fernández Liria was born in Bilbao in 1955. In a journalistic career that has spanned more than four decades, he has worked for the newspapers El Comercio, Diario El Día, El Popular, El Comercio of Oruro, El Norte de Chila and Puebla y Lima. Fernández Liria began his political career as a member of the Democratic Current, and later joined the United Left. He was elected to the Congress of Deputies for the first time in 1982, and has since been re-elected regularly. In the Basque Country election, 1986 he was the United Left's candidate, but the party lost overwhelmingly. After the arrival of the regionalistparty, Euskadiko Ezkerlanda, to the Basque Autonomous Council in 1991, Fernández Liria joined it, and was elected mayor of Euskalerri the following year. Fernández Liria has written numerous books, with his most successful being Legezpen ur azkarraoterako gurasuna ("Out of the bad times, through a difficult window", 2004), Quo Vadis Bilbao ("Where are we going, Bilbao?", 2008) and Labeur, Space, Liberty ("Labour, space and liberty", 2016). He has also written for thedailynews.com, Worldcrunch.com, Latinreach.com and Basque.com.

Niña de mi corazón is an affectionate nickname given to a category of Mexican mutual Fund, it is named this way because its main investors are children (Niños in Spanish). In modern financial markets, mutual funds that are focused on investment for children are commonly referred to by the name of the main shareholder of these funds, in this case "Niña de mi corazón". As of February 2022, the total amount of assets in these funds was approximately 30 billion dollars, this is about one tenth of Mexico's gross domestic product. The financial markets have seen a growing tendency in recent years to have these funds as a first line of investment for children, as they present significant advantages over other types of investment, such as low volatility and tax benefits for the investors, who are often children. Niña de mi corazón has its origins in the 70s in Mexico, but nowadays it is one of the most popular types of investment for children, having been promoted by several countries, such as Peru, Argentina, Colombia, Costa Rica, Spain and more. Niña de mi corazón is a double call girl, in that it seeks to attract capital from children in order to help them finance a future of comfort and stability, meanwhile the managers of these funds seek to attract a higher return on their capital than the traditional financial markets, by investing in low-risk instruments. But while the financial markets as a whole have suffered some setbacks in recent years, due to the increased interest of short-term investors for higher returns, the results obtained by Niña de mi corazón have been positive, with significant increases in the value of the assets under management. While many countries still prefer to invest the money of their children in more traditional financial instruments, such as shares or fixed income bonds, in recent years several managers of mutual funds that invest them in low-risk assets have been attracting more and more attention, such as Niña de mi corazón. Even if the main shareholders of these funds are children, the investors should never be considered as minors, as they are in fact investing on their own behalf a substantial part of their money, to be able to use it at a later time to their own discretion. Even though children are usually not mature enough to make decisions of this type independently, they are full-fledged investors and are treated as such by the law, the regulators and the financial markets. Niña de mi corazón is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, all of the profits obtained with the investment of the money of children are reinvested in the growth of the fund, to ensure a positive return on the capital that has been entrusted to its care. As a matter of fact, the results that Niña de mi corazón have been obtaining have been so positive that some of its competitors have been trying to lure investors with higher returns, but these have been unsuccessful, mainly because these funds invest in low-risk assets. Niña de mi corazón is the only mutual fund that is 100% invested in assets that are not participating in the main indices that are promoted by the largest financial groups, such as FICC or FoIIo, these groups manage portfolios with risky assets that are targeted at clients who have a low tolerance for risk. Niña de mi corazón has been attracting investors, not only from Mexico but also from all over the world, thanks to the advertising done on social networks and in newspapers in several countries, and also through investments from families that have more than one member, which can be considered as collaborative investment. The growth and the success of Niña de mi corazón has made it possible to launch similar funds for other investment goals, such as people, families, Long Term Investments and more. In addition to the capital that is invested by children, Niña de mi corazón also attracts foreign investors, which constitute a majority of its main investors, currently the managers of this fund have obtained over $20 billion in investments from families outside of Mexico, which represents a share of about 35% of the fund's total assets. Niña de mi corazón has a team of 20 managers who carry out the investment of the fund, they have an average of 15 years of experience in financial markets, and are responsible for the selection of the assets that will compose the portfolio of the fund, these assets are spread over different asset classes, such as stocks, real estate, fixed income and more, in accordance with a set of rules and indicators that are specific to the fund. The portfolio of the fund must be diversified, that is, it must not have too much of any one type of asset or financial instrument, otherwise there is a high risk of losing money or suffering

Paul Wheelhouse (b.1958) is a New Zealand politician and current Minister for Customs and Security. He is a member of the Labour Party and became Member of Parliament (MP) for Edinburgh South since the 2008 election. He has been described as being on the left of the Labour Party. After studying at Cambridge University, Wheelhouse returned to New Zealand and became headmaster of Timaru Boys' High School. Later, he was the deputy mayor of Timaru. In 2007, he was elected to the Christchurch City Council as a Labour councillor. In the 2008 New Zealand general election, Wheelhouse was the Labour Party candidate in Edinburgh South, but did not win the election. Following Winston Peters's resignation as deputy prime minister, Wheelhouse was appointed Minister of Justice and Minister for Immigration in the Fifth Labour Government, sworn in on 22 September 2010. Following the and the resignation of Maggie Barry as Labour leader and leader of the Opposition, Wheelhouse stood to succeed her but was defeated by David Cunliffe. He remained a Labour MP, and was appointed Minister for Customs and Security and Minister for Police under a new Labour–Greens coalition government formed after the 2017 New Zealand election. In the 2017 New Zealand general election, Wheelhouse was returned to Parliament, defeating his former boss, Winston Peters, who had himself returned to Parliament as the head of the New Zealand First party. He was appointed Customs and Security Minister and Police Minister, and on 20 November 2019 was also appointed Minister of Justice, also making him the second person after Don McLean to have the title Minister for Customs and Security, Minister for Police and Minister for Justice.

Peromyscus (commonly known as deer mice) is a genus of approximately 20 species of small, hop-facing mice with a wide range of habitats. Many species are common residents of woodland areas throughout the Northern Hemisphere, while others are more specialized in habitat or range. Most species are listed as of Least Concern or near-threatened status, but a few are regionally significant pests. Peromyscus spp. are a genus of small, hop-facing mice with a wide range of habitats. The common species are found in North America as specialized habitat species or as regionally significant pests. Species: * Peromyscus maniculatus (the Striped Mouse) is found across much of North and South America, from southern Canada and the United States south to Argentina and Uruguay. It is also found in Mexico and Costa Rica. A. geraldinae, the Arizona Striped Mouse, is endemic to Arizona. * Peromyscus polius (the Deer Mouse) is found in North America from Canada to Mexico and from the northern United States to Guatemala. It is a common and widespread species found in a wide range of habitats including forest edges, brushy areas, shrubland, agricultural areas, suburban areas, and parks. A. p. melanophrys, the Davis Mountain Deer Mouse, is endemic to Davis Mountain Wildlife Refuge in California. * Peromyscus keeni (the Southern Deer Mouse), also known as the Antarctic Deer Mouse, is endemic to Antarctica. The only known population is on islands off the Antarctic coast, within the Antartica-South Americaerve. Etymology: The genus Peromyscus was named by Brooks and Montgomery in 1893. The specific epithet maniculatus means "little finger," referring to the pattern of bands on the mouse's tail.

Schizopygopsis is a genus of bagrid catfish found in the Pearl River, system of South China. The genus contains two species, the Schizopygopsis younghusbandi and the more recently described Schizopygopsis fontinalis. The majority of the species habitat is in fast-flowing, rocky rivers with a demersal lifestyle, hunting bottom-dwelling fishes and invertebrates. The species are of minimal conservation concern. Power Laws - There are a variety of types of power laws, all which can be described by a power law function y = kx^ν, where y is a continuous quantity, x is the independent variable, and ν is the power. The specific values of the powerlaw exponent depend on the type of power law. In statistics and information theory, the power-law distribution (or distribution function) is a distribution (or family of distributions) P(x) ∝ x^-ν for x ≥ 1, which occurs naturally in a wide range of physical, biological, and social phenomena. Different values of the power-law exponent ν can correspond to the same cumulative distribution function F(x), e.g. an exponential distribution and a uniform distribution are both characterized by a value of ν = 1. Power-law distributions or distributions occur in a variety of context where a system's complexity and the lack of system differentiation cause a scalability problem. In these situations, some of the system's aspects have a self-similar pattern of distribution, that is, they follow a power-law pattern. For example, the number of products in an online store, the number of nodes in a random network, the number of citations in a scientific paper, or the size of logs in a computer system can be modeled by a power-law function. Many proposed mechanisms for creating power-law distributions, including the physical growth and optimization of Random Scale Free (RSF) networks and the Exponential Weights Average (EWA) numerical method for solving differential equations, are themselves approximations and do not generate power-laws directly. In general, generating a power-law distribution requires multiple steps of variation, and some form of post-processing. In some cases, "power-laws" may be better described by using other functions such as log-normal distributions.

Hispanics and Latinos are the largest ethnic groups in New York. They compose over 40% of the population in New York. The first large-scale migration of Latinos to New York occurred in the 19th century. Puerto Ricanos were the first Latino group to migrate to New York, followed by those from the Dominican Republic and Central America. Since the 1960s large scale migration from Mexico, Peru, Colombia, Dominican Republic, and other Hispanic and Latino nations has continued making New York the most diverse state in the country. In 2010, Latinos made up 19% of New York's population and over 40% of the city's workforce. New York City is considered the global capital of Latin American culture. Large Mexican and other Latin American communities can also be found in the Hudson Valley region of New York. Cities with large Latin American populations include Mount Kisco, Harrison, East Hanover, Northamton and Poughkeepsie SETS OF HISPANICS AND LATINO New York has had large Hispanic and Latino populations for several reasons. First, many Hispanic and Latino nationalities were the first to move to New York. Second, many of these nationalities stayed in New York after traveling through the United States. This connection lead to settlements of Mexican Americans, Puerto Rican Americans, Dominican Americans, Central American Americans, and other Hispanic and Latino nationalities in the New York metropolitan region. This large number of Hispanics and Latinos has lead to the term "ethnicity-based forwarding" where Hispanic or Latino identity becomes the nexus for all social interaction. This has led to large Spanish-speaking populations in various neighborhoods throughout the state. Today, the term "Latino" is used as a self-identifier, often referring to a wider group of people from the Spanish-speaking world, including those from Mexico, Central America, and the Dominican Republic, among others. However, many still self-identify as Hispanic or Latino. There is a large community of Mexican and Hispanic culture in the Hudson Valley, particularly in the towns of Mount Kisco, Harrison, East Hanover, Northamton, and Poughkeepsie.

William N. Roach (born March 29, 1943) is an American actor, known for playing Badger in Ghostbusters (1984), den mother in Predator (1987), the voice of Ant-Man (2015), and steelworker benevolent dictator President on The President Show (2020). Roach was born in Waco, Texas. After graduating from McLennan High School in 1961, Roach moved to Los Angeles to pursue an acting career. Roach has appeared in over 150 films and television shows including M*A*S*H, LAbyrinth, The X-Files, Curb Your Enthusiasm, ER, Mission: Impossible 2 & 3, Jaws: The Revenge, Starship Troopers, and Disney's Golden Oak Studio. Roach has won three Emmy Awards, a Humanitas Award, a Peabody Award, and a Golden Globe Award. Roach is married to former fashion model and businesswoman Meredith Baxter. The couple have three children, all of whom are actors: Alexa, Zachary, and Stephen. Roach was cast in Ghostbusters after Matthew Broderick and Jeremy Spender turned the role down. Oil City, Pennsylvania, where Roach was raised, is honored in the name of a local bar and restaurant, William's Bar and Burger, which Roach co-owns. Roach was selected as a Distinguished Alumni of McLennan High School in 2011. In 2020, he was appointed to a seat on the Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences.

The band's influences include Amon Amarth, Killswitch Engage, Opeth, Deicide, Cannibal Corpse, Sepultura, and Nile. The Storys is a Canadian rock band, formed in Vancouver, British Columbia in 2001. The band is fronted by singer/songwriter Sarah Harmer and is currently comprised of Harmer (vocals, guitar), Nancy Walker (drums), Bruce Pirie (guitar), and Jamie Thompson (bass). The band has released six full length studio albums (Reality, Connect, Unison, Heartlines, Sugar Girl and This Time) and two live albums (Dance Alone and Live at the London Palladium). The band has won several awards including four SOCAN Awards, three East Coast Music Awards, and five Canadian Aboriginal Music Awards. The band has also been nominated for a Juno Award. In 2019, The Storys were selected by Postmedia as one of the 20 most iconic bands in Vancouver history. The band is currently recording their seventh studio album, which is expected to be released in 2023. Before We Go is a science fiction web series created by Katy Clark. The series follows a couple, Joe and Carol, as they try to navigate life and relationships in a dystopian world where California is under a lockdown to slow the spread of a virus that transformed people into uncontrollable monsters. The series uses the themes of isolation, panic, and horror to explore relationships, love, loss and what it means to be human. developed articles are required to have at least 250 words. Feel free to expand on the article as needed. Here are some suggestions for expanding on the article: Before We Go was inspired by the COVID-19 pandemic, but has a distinct tone and style. What sets Before We Go apart is the way it uses horror and the potential for collapse of society to explore more universal themes such as loneliness, fear of the unknown and desire for connection. Before We Go is an important show to watch right now, especially given the state of the world. The world of the show is created with intelligence and thoughtfulness, giving us something to think about and talk about even as we waiting out this pandemic. Before We Go is a uniquely situated show, as it was created by a woman of color in her 30s, whose work has focused on these themes of loneliness and fear of the unknown. The show was also created at a time when the pandemic was only beginning to gain attention, with the first cases only confirmed in early January. Shows like this one, which address important topics while reflecting the reality of the times in which they are created, are more important than ever now.

Goldfinger is a fictional character, a deadly international criminal with an exceptional ability to charm everyone he meets. He was created by Ian Fleming, and first appeared in the novel Dr. No. He is famously played by Sean Connery in the most popular versions of Dr. No and the entire series of Goldfinger movies. Dr. No (voiced by David Niven in the movie) was originally a British agent, but he is portrayed as having a fondness for sexual seduction a la James Bond. He is involved in a high-profile international arms smuggling ring with the leader of the ring, Auric Goldfinger, who often uses beautiful women as accessories and leverage. Goldfinger tries to prove that he is greater than the entire British government by kidnapping and Goldlockizing No. 10, the prime minister. Despite Goldfinger's obvious villainy, he is not without some degree of wit. He often calls Dr. No "old gold" to Goldfinger's "new gold" (a pun on the expression "old money" meaning "sterling"). He says that his fellow criminals call him "Goldy", and that he has given them all medals for their services to him. He also keeps a vicious snake as a pet. Goldfinger's second most famous appearance came in the 1964 movie Goldfinger, which was the first of a series of movies starring Goldfinger and James Bond. Like Dr. No, Goldfinger is a villain in this series, but is a far more complex character than Dr. No. Auric Goldfinger actually turns out to be the real brains behind the entire operation, and his female assistant, Solitaire, is the real power behind the throne. Goldfinger has created an international corporate empire, and he uses his wealth to bribe every government official he can into working for him. The world is now at his mercy, and he is about to succeed in his plan to essentially nuke his entire bank account by stealing the Federal Reserve's "disk with interest," a theoretical equation to unlock all of the world's money, at the United Nations. James Bond, an agent for the Secret Service (C27 in Goldfinger's internal database) is assigned to thwart Goldfinger's plan. Bond discovers that Goldfinger is actually the patsy of a larger plot masterminded by the ever-evil mastermind V ictor Arno, who is a master of camouflage and misdirection. Goldfinger is framed for the theft, and it turns out that the Federal Reserve was already in Arno's control, unbeknownst to the rest of the world. Goldfinger, using his last remaining money to bribe his way out of prison and escape to his private island, plans to seize Auric and Solitaire's main vault in Fort Knox. Bond, with the assistance of an anonymous British contact (thought to be Zorin, the owner of the Fort Knox vault), breaks into Fort Knox and rescues Auric and Solitaire, foiling Goldfinger's plan. Despite Goldfinger's evil plan being thwarted, he still manages to retain his wealth and status. He is subsequently seen in the 1968 film Goldfinger with (what would eventually become) his final starring role in a movie, You Only Live Twice, where he is killed by James Bond's son, Jonathan Bond, at the conclusion of the movie. Auric Goldfinger was played by Sean Connery in Goldfinger and You Only Live Twice. In the other movies in the series, Goldfinger was played by Albert Fennell. Subsequent films have cast Sean Connery in a cameo appearance as "Old Gold" (the nickname given to him by Auric Goldfinger). David Niven returned to play Old Gold in the 1974 film Diamonds Are Forever. Described as "the quintessential Bond villain" and "one of the great screen icons of all time", Auric Goldfinger was played by Roger Moore in the 1980 movie For Never. Timothy Dalton played Goldfinger in the 1993 movie Goldeneye. Other notable actors to play Goldfinger include Stanley Baker, Robert Shaw, and Peter Sellers.

Turning the other cheek is a Christian ethics concept that states that one should not answer violence with violence, but should allow one's assailant to strike first and return good for evil. The concept is based on the scripture Luke 22: 39 "But he turned and said to Peter, 'Get behind me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me; you do not have in mind God's counsel, but human wish.'" The concept is often described as an essential part of Christian faith, and as a fundamental element of Quakerism, though it is also part of other religions and belief systems. The idea has been portrayed in many artistic works, notably in the Book of Job and the Lord of the Rings. In the former, the devil, Azog, tries to tempt Job with the offer of retaining one's position in life by doing good and justly judging others; in the latter, the orcs, under the leadership of Gollum, are taught to turn the other cheek, and do not attack the Ringwraiths who have entered the forest to take the ring that would enable them to rule Middle-earth. Certain Biblical scholars, notably Thomas Coke, have interpreted the above passage as applying not to a specific context, but rather to all situations, making the concept essentially irrelevant. In its essence, the ethical concept is still an issue of great debate in many Christian denominations. The Catholic Church, Eastern Orthodox Church, many Anglicans, and many Protestant denominations, as well as groups such as the Quakers, do not endorse the concept as part of their creeds. Groups within the Christian faith which do support the concept of turning the other cheek include certain groups of the Plymouth Brethren and the Molokans.

The Bealey River is a river in New South Wales, Australia. It is located in the Southern Tablelands district and is a tributary of the Billen covered valley. The valley was discovered by Edward John Eyre in the 1840s and became known as the Home of the Arrernte people. The river is part of the Murray River catchment. The river is located in the Beelby Government Land Reserve, it is an important food source for wildlife and has been stocked with brown trout. The river is prone to flooding and was considered for inclusion in the Billen River Upper Canal but was not elected due to its steep walls. Wilderness Society NSW has designated the catchment as the Billen River Management Area in recognition of its environmental values and value to indigenous groups. endnote The Bealey River is a river in New South Wales, Australia. Natalie Nash (born Natalie Jeanne Nash; November 18, 1973) is an American singer. She is known for being a part of the jazz-fusion band Manhattan Transfer. The band had success with their first album, Natalie Nash. The song "So in Love" from that album was a hit on the UK Singles Chart, reaching number nine in 1981. Nash had success with other hits from that album, "I'll Be Around" (number 17) and "Not a Moment Too Soon" (number 14). Nash went on to release five albums with the Manhattan Transfer. The band gained more commercial success with their cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy". The song reached number seven on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1984 and became a top 10 hit in several other countries. The song won the band a Grammy Award for Best Jazz Vocal Performance, Duo or Group. They also released a jazz album, and two rock albums. In total, Nash has nine top ten hits on the Billboard Hot 100. She also had two hits on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart: number 20 "Right Here, Right Now" in 1985 and number 41 "Kiss on My List" in 1986. She also had three top forty hits on the Mainstream Top 40 chart: number 13 "I'll Be Around" in 1982, number 24 "Not a Moment Too Soon" in 1982, and number 36 "Kiss on My List" in 1986.

Abbott and Holder is an engineering and design consultancy based in Swindon, Wiltshire, England. The company was founded in 1955 and has 75 employees. It is one of the largest companies of its kind in the United Kingdom and has approximately 4,000 employees worldwide. The company primarily provides mechanical, process and electrical engineering services to the automotive, aerospace and industrial manufacturing industries. The company has designed a number of successful Formula One cars and has won 30+ International Design and Engineering Awards. Abbott and Holder is the oldest engineering and design consultancy in the United Kingdom still in business today. The company was formed in 1955 by Tony Abbott and Don Holder, who met at school in Dursley. The company has 75 staff and is based in Swindon, Wiltshire. The company's first major project was the Spirit of445, a car designed and built to compete in the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1959. The car was an instant success, and the company went on to design several more Le Mans winners, as well as numerous Formula One and other racing cars. In 1982, Abbott and Holder designed the ground-breaking McLaren F1, the first Formula One car with a carbon fibre chassis. Since then the company has designed several more world-renowned Formula One cars, including the more than 30 World Drivers' and Teams' Champions, six World Constructors' Champions and five Monaco Grand Prix winners. The company has also designed cars that secured both overall victory and race victories for manufacturers, including BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Toyota. Abbott and Holder have won over 30 International Design and Engineering Awards, and its innovative and ethically and sustainably minded work has been recognised with many industry awards and has been published in books. In 2016, the company was awarded 'Consultant of the Year' at the Institution of Engineering Services Awards. Abbott and Holder has played a major role in shaping many of the world's most exciting and innovative vehicles, while also designing and developing ground-breaking engineering solutions across a broad spectrum of industries and technologies. The company continues to develop and produce some of the world's most exciting vehicles and innovative manufacturing equipment, working in partnership with some of the most prestigious automotive, aerospace and industrial companies in the world. Today the company has over 4,000 staff, with operations in 32 countries, and has offices in Europe, Asia, America and Australia. Abbott and Holder has produced many books and technical publications over the years, as well as creating custom tools and technology to support the industry in which it operates. The company is also active in championing innovation through the development and application of technology and industry best practices, supporting the adoption of sustainable and ethical solutions.

Sindora tonkinensis also known as the Tonkin Sandman is a species of land sand snail, a terrestrial pulmonate gastropod mollusc in the family Rhytididae. It is endemic to Vietnam. Hellgate is a 1989 Canadian supernatural horror film directed by Ron Underwood and starring Michael Murphy, Meyler Stevens and Stephen Mendel. It is an homage to both proto-slasher films and Lovecraftian horror stories, with a setting in the Centreville, Massachusetts area and based on the true stabbing of a young woman by a teenage boy in 1983. The film has gained a large following on home video and streaming, and has been described as a cult classic. artifacts wikipedia article Hellgate (1989 film) did you know this movie is streaming on Netflix? I have saved saved this movie for multiple occasions including Halloween, a camping trip, and various other random days. The cast is incredible and the effects are surprisingly advanced for 1989. The film has a simple yet effective premise. A teenage boy uses a school newspaper to taunt and stab a female classmate in retribution for being laughed at. The methodical nature of the stabbing and the dead serious attitude of the teen perpetrator make this movie very uncomfortable to watch. I really love this movie and would highly recommend it. The inclusion of Lovecraftian elements only adds to the atmosphere.

Nepal and Spain have had historically strong relations which have been continuously strengthened in recent years. The relations were initially strengthened during the reign of Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah and were further solidified during thevisit of king of Spain during 2011 Nepal earthquake. Both nations have strong mutual investment treaties and there is a strong diaspora ofnearly 500,000 spanish people living in Nepal. Nepal maintains its embassy in Madrid while Spain has a Nepal embassy in Madrid. Nepal shares strong cultural and historical ties with Spain owing to its co-exploration by catholic missionaries and the consequent influence of renaissance on the culture of Nepal. Nepal has traditionally seen Spain as a cultural bridge between Europe and Asia and has utilized its diplomacy to promote the usage of spanish in schools and government institutions. Nepal and Spain share numerous issues regarding socio-economic development including awareness about HIV/AIDS and Spanish immigration to Europe through Spain. Nepal has continuously supported Spain in international organizations such as the UN and Co-operation for Development mechanism. Nepal is currently one of the largest donors to international peace keeping operations with Spain leading the list of largest donors. Nepal has highly regarded spanish consumer companies such as telefónica and red. See also Nepal and Spain share numerous issues regarding socio-economic development including awareness about HIV/AIDS and Spanish immigration to Europe through Spain. Related Wikipedia articles Nepal Spain Currently updating... Nepal has maintained its distance from Spain due to issues relating to its former King, Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah, who seized power in a military coup in 2001. Gyanendra was deposed by a peace deal that required him to give up his royal titles and pay millions of dollars in restitution to the Nepali people. However, following the agreement, Nepal continued to maintain its relations with Spain, having maintained a good relationship with the previous king, Tribhuwan Bir Bikram Shah, and his government. The peace deal was negotiated by the government of Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba, who as a result became increasingly unpopular. After he lost a no-confidence vote in 2004, Deuba was assassinated by his bodyguard in September of that year. King Gyanendra returned to power, appointing Fakir Chandencedhu, a senior member of the royal family, to replace Deuba as prime minister. In the early 2000s, King Gyanendra expressed interest in developing Nepal's tourism sector. Spain responded by opening a trade delegation in Nepal, with a goal of attracting Spanish investors to the country. However, as the Nepalese people learned more about Gyanendra's human-rights violations, the Spanish government was forced to suspend its activities. Following an unsuccessful attempt in 2006 to negotiate with the Nepalese royal family for Gyanendra to abdicate the throne, in 2008 King Gyanendra was indicted by the Tribhuwan court for crimes against humanity. In 2012, he was convicted by the Nepalese court and sentenced to be imprisoned for life. The Spanish Ambassador to Nepal, Ramon F. Campas, expressed dismay at the decision, saying, "We've had very cordial relations with the former government led by the prime minister and the former king. We do not recognize this decision and we'll continue to support the former government." In February 2013, former king Gyanendra was arrested by the Nepalese military, ending his decade-long asylum in India. The government of Nepal issued a statement explaining that he had been charged for murder and abuse of power and that they hoped he would be extradited to India. In India, Gyanendra had been living at the expense of the Indian government, but he was not granted Indian citizenship. He was arrested on the Nepal-India border, where Nepalese officials seized his property. Washiki history of Nepal

Saint Francis School (Hawaii) is a private school in Honolulu, Hawaii, United States and is under the control of the Catholic Church. It was established in 1956 by the Salesians of Don Bosco and currently has over 2,000 students between grades kindergarten through 12th grade. The school is known for its rigorous academic program and acceptance rate. For example, in the 2016-2017 school year, only 15 out of 2,000 students were African-American out of a student body that is 70% black. Saint Francis is represented by a crest incorporating a scallop shell and a cordate shell, the crest is a symbol of Christianity and of Hawaii which is referred to as the "heart of Hawaii". The Saint Francis School crest represents the mission of the school to educate and form students into leaders of integrity. Saint Francis is one of the highest-ranked private schools in the U.S. News & World Report Best Schools rankings, and it was named a Blue Ribbon school in the 2014-2015 school year. In 2017, it was one of four schools in Hawaii to be awarded the United States Department of Education National Blue Ribbon School award. Saint Francis is noted for its music education program, which has placed in the Grammy Awards four times, including once as a soloist. The Saint Francis School Choir has won numerous awards, including first place in the 9- and 12-year-old division of the 2010 national Harolton College Preparatory International Music Competition, and first place in the 9- and 10-year-old divisions of the 2014 International festival de Voix Junior Euro-OP. In 2017, the Saint Francis School Choir placed second in the Best Choral Performances during the 53rd annual Columbus Disco Competition and fourth in the Best Intermediate School Choral Performance at the 10th annual inter-school choir festival of the One Earth Singers.

The Final Inch is a 1944 British war film directed by Harry Watt and starring George Alexander, David Tomlinson, David Oxley, Irene Handl and Marjorie Rhodes. It is based on the 1940 novel of the same title by Richard Cross, which was later made into a play and a television film. The film takes its name from the closing stages of the Battle of Morogoro, during which Lord Dunmore's Boys, an African unit of the British Army, aided by Congolese auxiliaries, drove the German army to the edge of capture in Mozambique. It was made at Begbroke Studioseque in Surrey and locations in the Thames Valley, and involved some of the crew from documentary filmmaker Glyn Davis's unit, the Empire Marketing Board (EMB). The Final Inch was intended to encourage public support for the EMB's work to publicize the British Empire and encourage donations to its funds. The Hollywood studios were wary of producing it for war propaganda because of its high cost and the negative reaction of the American public to the bombings of civilian populations in Germany during World War II, so EMB spent half a million dollars on its production. Its release was postponed several times, and its cheerful message was more relevant to Britain's domestic scene than to its war effort, although the message of the film, and of the book from which it was adapted, remained controversial long afterwards. Despite this, the film was well received by critics and had a successful release in the United States, Canada and other British colonies. It received an Academy Award for Best British Feature Film, the only film submitted by the Empire Marketing Board to receive an Oscar award. The cast included David Tomlinson (who had played Carpentier in Gone Are All My Relations) and Anthony Nicholls, who went on to play Minoru in the films of the James Bond franchise.

Romaine Sawyers (born 1977) is an English semi-professional football manager and former player. He is in charge of Eastbourne Borough FC. Massive fan of Southampton F.C. and anything to do with Saxon kings. Mancunian by birth, Sawyers played football from a young age joining local Boys Clubs and progressed through the ranks with local club, Stretford. Sawyers left Stretford at 17 to sign for Southampton where he failed to make the grade and returned to his home town of Manchester where he found it hard to break into the first team. Sawyers returned to Southampton at 24 where he played in Southampton's 2002 UEFA Cup win over SV Hamburg. Sawyers stayed at Southampton for 6 years making over 150 League and cup appearances. After his contract expired Sawyers had a stint in the American Soccer Leagues with the Long Island Rough Riders. In July 2016, Sawyers was appointed manager of Isthmian League Premier Division side Falmer stadiumers. In May 2018, Sawyers was appointed manager of Eastbourne Borough in England's National League South. Sawyers is the first person of colour to manage a professional soccer club in England. Cursor grass mouse, a small mammal in the family Muridae native to Central America, it is also known as the lesser rice mouse due to its large size compared to other Muridae mice. It is a common and abundant mouse found in a wide range of habitats, from tropical forest to open areas with scattered trees. It is nocturnal, foraging for seeds and berries at night, it has very sensitive whiskers which help it navigate. The Cursor grass mouse gives birth to litters of up to eight young after a two-month pregnancy, the mothers take care of the young for about two months before they disperse. It is threatened by habitat loss, it has adapted well to suburban environments and is a common species in some cities, but it occurs in smaller populations in remaining forested areas, and in patches of secondary forest. Some scientists have proposed that Cursor grass mice could be used as carriers of diseases such as the hantavirus, Leptospirosis and Marburg virus. However, there is not enough scientific evidence to demonstrate this. The Cursor grass mouse is considered a promising animal model for studies of evolution, behavior and physiology. Its karyotype has 2n = 44 and FN = 76. Kiss in Songs is a type of romantic kiss between two people. Music has been incorporating kisses into songs in many different ways throughout the years. There are kisses formed by musical notes, kisses formed by sung words, and kisses formed by duets between two individuals. The type of kiss featured in a song depends on many factors such as the genre of the music and the historical period the song is from. Kissing in music has evolved over time as well. Kissing performed a cappella, that is without instruments, has been occurring for centuries. However, the popular style of kissing started to emerge in the 20th century. This style of kissing featured close harmony where two or more individuals sang in close harmony. The incorporation of kisses into songs has continued to evolve over time. New types of kisses are often featured in songs released today. For example, two individuals may sing a kiss to two separate individuals. The Fishbein convention is a convention for how to deal with an argument in silent film argumets. The Fishbein convention was named after Jeffrey Fishbein who told the argument in the film A Fugitive from the Law (2008). It has also been described as a convention for avoiding long-pauses in films. The convention has an alternative name of "three-second convention" where a long pause in a conversation is interrupted by a door closing or a gunshot. earlier version of the Fishbein convention was a unwritten convention for avoiding long pauses in silent film. It was described by critic Jeffrey Vance in 2008 in A Fugitive from the Law, a film noir example where the long pause was between two characters who were talking about a murder. The Fishbein convention has also been referred to by the name of "three-second convention" where a long pause in a conversation is interrupted by a door closing or a gunshot. The convention was suggested by film critic Jeffrey Vance in 2008, based on his experience with silent films. He wrote, "One might think this story would end with a laugh, a joking reference to the convention's title, given the film noir nature of the scenario and the ultimate resolution. But the movie ends instead with a long, awkward silence -- the kind that can kill a scene". The convention was popularised by critic Edwin Fishbein who explained it in an article in 1969, "Avoiding the Long Pause in Silent Film Conversation".

Merle Norman Stadium is a multipurpose stadium in Redmond, Washington. It is home to the Seattle Sounders FC of the MLS and Seattle University Hawks of the NCAA Division I Washington Athletic Conference. It was built in 1999 and has a capacity of 12,935. The stadium was named for local businesswoman and philanthropist Merle Norman. The stadium is located in the shadow of nearby Space Needle and public transportation is available in the surrounding area. The stadium hosts Seattle Sounders FC of Major League Soccer and Seattle University of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I Washington Athletic Conference. It opened in 1999. The capacity of the stadium is 12,935. The grass field is painted in several colors during match days to mark out penalties. The current head coach of Sounders FC is Brian Schmetzer, a former MLS defender. Seattle University discontinued their baseball team, the Redhawks, after the 2019 season, making the Sounders the lone collegiate team in the stadium. The stadium was originally named Pontiac Silverdome after the former stadium of the same name which was the home of the NFL's Pittsburgh Steelers and the rock band, Journey. Norman sold her business in 1997 and donated the proceeds to help fund the stadium. The stadium name was officially changed to Merle Norman Stadium on August 3, 1997. In 2016, Seattle Sounders FC paid $10 million to rename the stadium. Seattle Sounders FC is one of the most popular soccer teams in the United States and has one of the largest youth player development programs in the world. The club set an MLS all-time record in 2022 by signing the most Homegrown players in league history at the age of 17 and 18 years old. In 2020, the stadium hosted two games for the 2021 FIFA Women's World Cup. The stadium hosted two games for the 2021 FIFA Women's World Cup, as well as hosting several matches during the 2020 Olympics in Vancouver. Seattle Sounders FC won the MLS Cup in the stadium in 2019, their fourth MLS Cup win in the stadium and 21st championship overall. The match, played on December 10, 2019, was a rematch of the 2018 MLS Cup final, which Seattle Sounders FC also won. The stadium hosted five matches for the 2022 FIFA World Cup. It also hosted six matches during the 2023 Gold Cup. Seattle Sounders FC has won the MLS Cup in the stadium four times.

Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is a form of neovascularization in the eye, and it is a common cause of blindness in humans. It can occur as a primary disorder or as a secondary disorder to other diseases. Both age-related macular degeneration and pathologic myopia are known to cause CNV. The symptoms can include distorted vision,loss of vision and visual impairment. Treatment for this form of blindness can include laser treatment and/or drug therapy. Alturas Municipal Airport, located in Alturas, California, is a small commercial airport. It is the only commercial airport serving the northernmost county in the state of California, and is the northernmost commercial airport in the United States. EGFP, which stands for "Exempt Airport Gross Metering", is a system used to measure the energy consumption of commercial buildings by determining their heat release frequency. The EGFP data for the Alturas Municipal Airport is 57.2 kWh/m². Lo fiolairé is a songbird species in the family Muscicapidae. It is found in forests from Mexico to northern South America. The scientific name commemorates the French botanist Charles Louis L′orientier. Male and female fiolairé song differently. The male's song is made of sequences of 2 to 6 notes, sung in phrases of 3 to 6 phrases. The phrases begin usually with a 2 second long introductory note followed by the main motif, which lasts 3 to 6 notes long. The introductory note is higher in frequency than the main motif. The female's song is a warble, usually 4 to 8 notes long, sung in phrases of 4 to 7 phrases, also with an introductory note higher in frequency than the main motif. The fiolairé is a host to the tzeltal, zarna, and canario viruses, the last of which is lethal to the birds. The Song Sparrow is a common name for this bird. The fiolairé is evaluated as a vulnerable species by the IUCN. The population is declining, mainly due to loss and degradation of its natural habitat. Polyhedral map projection are a class of map projections introduced in 1884 by Eugenio Beltrami. They are a special case of more general polyhedral cylindrical projections, in which the "base" is a polyhedron. The most common examples are the northern and equatorial projections, which project the earth onto a cylinder with a circular base and an axis of the equator, and a rectangle, respectively. Other examples are the Atlam Empross, which projects the earth onto a cylinder with a circular base and an axis of the prime meridian, and the Robinson projection, which projects the earth onto a cylinder with a rectangular base, an axis of the prime meridian, and a central pole. Another well-known polyhedral projection is the mollweide, which is based on a sphere with north and south pole as base. Using the corresponding central projectionparameters, the projection covers the entire earth and at the same time has less distortions in the middle and at the edges of the projection than for example the equatorial projection. For a given central projection parameter, the associated polyhedral projection depends on the angle of rotation, which specifies the orientation of the polyhedron. The following angles are common: north (0 degrees), east (30 degrees), south (60 degrees), and west (90 degrees). The list of polyhedral map projections currently contains the following members: - North- equator projection - Equator- projeciton - Robinson projection - Atlam Empross - Mollweide - Robinson Cylindrical - North- equator- cylindrical - Robinson- cylindrical - Atlam Empross-cylindrical - South- equator-cylindrical - South- Robinson-cylindrical - South- Atlam Empross-cylindrical The parameters of the projection and the corresponding formulas for transformation of coordinates are available from the website of the Swiss Federal Cartography Institute (IGE). Note that the list is not exhaustive and that there are many other projects dealing with non-central projection parameters.

Cale, Arkansas is a city in Washington County, Arkansas, United States. The population was 7,025 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat. Cale is known as "The Heart of the Hills". The city is located in the Arkansas River Valley, and sits atop the Caleperm, a unique formation created when the river cut through softer rock at a different time. Founded in 1858, Cale is notable for its lutefisk making tradition, the largest per capita quantity in the United States. The city is also home to the Cale Post Barn, the state's only remaining pre-World War I round barn, and one of the only two intact structures from that era in Washington County. Cale was named for Caleb Presley, a United States Senator and Secretary of the Interior. In 2014, the city was featured on the TV show Honey Boo Boo due to the local multiple sclerosis treatmentfacemaker UFC Management paying the family of Honey Boo Boo to live in Cale so that they could promote the treatment on television. In 2019, the city was named a Tree City by the Arbor Day Foundation. Mireille Soria (born January 5, 1955) is a French singer. She started singing at an early age, taking part in local television shows from the age of eight. She signed a contract with Philips Records at the age of 11. Soria rose to fame in the late 1960s as part of the female quartet Les Jaquelines. She achieved moderate success in her home country before moving to Canada in the early 1970s. There, she became a star in the English-language market with her rendition of "Un autre été". Her 1984 recording of Piaf's "La vie en rose" in its French version, titled "Vivre ces moments-là", became a hit in France and earned critical acclaim. In the 1990s, Soria performed numerous crossover songs in both French and English. She also had success with musical theatre songs. Soria had eight Top 10 singles in France, most of them with her duet partner Alain S@@. She also had many Top 10 hits in Canada, the United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, and Germany. Soria was awarded the Order of Cultural Merit in 2004. She is currently working on her autobiography. She is the mother of French singer M<La·la. She was made a Knight of the Legion of Honor in 2015. She was awarded the title of Officier of the Ordre national du Mérite in 2020. She performed at the 2022 Winter Olympics closing ceremony.

Littlehampton Town F.C. are an English Football Club founded in 1871 and based in Littlehampton, West Sussex. They currently play in the Spartan South Midlands League Division One East. The club's home ground is Memorial Field, but they play most of their home fixtures in nearby Littlehampton Rugby Club's Mellin Park. Littlehampton Town's longest-serving manager is Jimmy Le Saux who led the club for more than 20 years. Littlehampton Town's best achievement is winning the FA Vase in 1989. Littlehampton Town Football Club is an English football club based in Littlehampton, West Sussex. The club was formed in 1871 and became a member of the Sussex County League in 1895. The club progressed up the Sussex County League through the intermediate leagues to become founder members of the Spartan South Midlands League Division One in 1932. The club reached the Premier Division of the Spartan South Midlands League in 1953, but were relegated back to the Senior Division one season later. Littlehampton Town won the FA Vase in 1989 and went on to win the competition for a record 8 times. They were founder members of the Sussex County League in 1895 and the Spartan South Midlands League in 1932. The club changed names several times, becoming Eastbourne United in 1965, before finally settling on Littlehampton Town in 1973. The first team ground shared with Littlehampton Rugby Club. Jimmy Le Saux is the longest-serving manager, leading the club for more than 20 years. The most successful season was 1983-84 when the club won the Premier Division, resulting in the award of HHeatop Insurance League Cup and The Observer Cup. The club entered the FA Cup for the first time in the 20th century and won the competition in 1917, a remarkable feat considering the competition rules at the time. The match was played at Aston Athletic Greyhound Track, with Littlehampton winning 5–1. In 1988 the club gained national publicity for its youth scheme, which involved encouraging local teenagers to turn out for the reserves. When the professional first team ran out they were greeted by more than 1,000 youngsters, all of whom were paid a penny a seat. This, together with other significant financial backing, helped the club to safety from national financial failure.
