Stepan Rostomyan (November 15, 1912 – September 6, 1993) was an Armenian Genocide survivor and an Olympic athlete for the Soviet Union. He competed in the men's 200 metre breaststroke at the 1936 Summer Olympics, but did not advance past the first heat. Rostomyan became an activist for preserving and promoting awareness of the Armenian Genocide, and used his experiences to help him prepare for and success in swimming competitions. Strategic Investment Fund manager, founder of the Republican Olympic Fund, participant of the World War II resistance movement, Honored Master of Sports of the USSR, holder of the medals "For the Victory over Germany", "For the Victory over Japan", "50 Years of the Soviet Union" Born in Tbilisi, Russian Empire to an Armenian family, Rostomyan survived the Armenian Genocide and fled to Tiumen, Bukovina, at the age of ten with his family. After finishing school, he trained as an accountant, but joined the Bukovina branch of the Dashnak Party. He became one of the leaders of the Young Dashnaktsutiun organization in Bukovina, and headed the Union for the Sight of Historical Truth, a local affiliate of the Armenian Revolutionary Federation. He also helped organize the resistance movement against the Romanian occupation of Bukovina. Following the Soviet Union's victory over the Axis powers in 1945, Rostomyan returned from his military service in Crimea and founded the Republican Olympic Fund, which would invest in young athletes, many of them from Soviet-occupied areas. He also founded the Sports Club Bukovina, headed the Bukovina chapter of the Armenian Communist Party, and participated in the delegation that representing the USSR at the Congress of the Peoples of the USSR. He served as a member of the Communist Party's central committee secretariat and the executive committee of the Soviet Communist Party. In 1973, Rostomyan was awarded the Order of the Red Banner of Labour. He was a participant of the World War II resistance movement, and after the war was awarded the medals "For the Victory over Germany", "For the Victory over Japan", "50 Years of the Soviet Union". Rostomyan died in Moscow at the age of 80. His granddaughter is singer and songwriter Maria Adamassili.

Conferences of the United Church of Christ is an event that has been organised every year since 1987 by the United Church of Christ. The event is held in a different place every year and has ministered by various speakers from many different backgrounds. The event lasts for 3 days and has a diverse audience of about 10.000 people. The purpose of the event is to celebrate the bi-centennial of the union of the two churches and also to remember those who contributed to the growth of the church. Business casual is a work clothing style primarily for women first introduced in the 1970s. The style typically involves a dress or skirt for women, and a suit or sports coat for men. The look was designed to make it easier to be neat and professional while also being more fashionable than blue jeans and a T-shirt. Since the 2000s, "business casual" has also come to mean a less formal variation of the style, allowing for more casualwear than was historically considered business casual. Award-winning journalist Joan Helmers wrote the first article about business casual in the July 1974 issue of McCall's. The business casual look became popular, and the style became part of the cultural lexicon. By the 1980s, it was common for most businesses to require employees to wear business casual attire. In the United States, the Business Casual Workplace Invented in America trademark was filed in 2003 by the business formality note-taking company Future 500. Business casual is sometimes considered an affectation, a term used to describe a faddish trend. Others say that while the specific fashion choices of a generation may seem quaint, the overall concept of business casual — that dress codes should be neutral and appropriate for the workplace — is timeless. Some analysts have predicted that business casual will replace the terms suit and tie as the common dress code for business attire. The style has been particularly popular with younger employees, who may be more open to alternatives to suit and tie as a result of social media, and who view corporate formalwear as stifling. Business casual is not the same as comfortable clothing, and most business casual clothing is not made from casual fabrics such as cotton. The clothing is designed to be worn over another garment, such as a suit jacket, underarm protection (braces), or a skirt, and often includes protective gear for shoes, such as closed-toe shoes or high heels. In an era when even jeans are rarely denim, the idea of "business casual" was originally a way for employers to signal that their employees should dress more formally than would be appropriate at a social event. While jeans are still worn at work far more often than not, the phrase "business casual" has come to mean a less restricted variation of the style, opening up professional clothing options to a wider audience of people who wouldn't traditionally consider themselves to be "business-like". Break of Hearts is the debut studio album by American singer Lauren Jauregui, released on June 15, 2015, through Epic Records. The album was preceded by the release of four singles: "Beat Down", "BETTY", "Feelin' So Good" and "Cheap Thrills". Stephanie Zimmermann (born 1973) is a German pianist. She has played with some of the most renowned orchestras and ensembles, such as the New York Philharmonic, the Chicago Symphony, the Berlin Symphony, the Munich Philharmonic, the Sydney Symphony, the London Symphony Orchestra, and the Wiener Philharmoniker. Zimmermann was the first woman to be appointed a permanent member of the squad of the Berlin Radio Philharmonic, and the youngest ever laureate of the Max Bruch and Hans Severins Awards. Her first album, released in 1998, earned her critical acclaim and numerous awards, including the "Diapason d'Or". She is particularly known for her interpretations of the piano music of Alexander Scriabin and Robert Schumann, and she has recorded several complete piano music compositions by these composers. Zimmermann has received numerous awards, including the "Diapason d'Or" Award, the Echo Klassik and the Schubert-komponisten International Award. She was awarded the Hans Fischer Prize and the Robert Schumann Prize. She was awarded the Echo Klassik and the Schubert-komponisten International Award. Her album 3 Dances from Schubert's Death and the Maiden was released in 2011 and was praised by BBC Music Magazine as an excellent "favorite disc" (Best of 2011). She lives in Berlin.

Below is a list of neuroscience databases along with their unique identifiers and short description. 1. Allen Human Brain Atlas 2. Bernstein Center for Computational Neuroscience 3. Brussels Sprouts 4. California Mouse Imaging 5. FlyCircuit 6. Human Connectome Project 7. Mind Cloud 8. Open Connectome 9. Open Collaborative Science Lab 10. Scientific Gator Short description of the databases: - Human Brain Atlas: Allows to examine the structure and connectivity of the human brain - Bernstein Center for Computational Neuroscience: Offers a large-scale brain simulation platform and a digital scientific resource for neuroscience education - Brussels Sprouts: Main research focus is on the neuronal and behavioral implications of Brussels sprouts consumption - California Mouse Imaging: The database provides phenotypic and genomic information for the C57BL/6J mouse - FlyCircuit: The database contains a comprehensive catalog of mutant fly lines, including knockouts, transposon-based, and transgenic lines - Human Connectome Project: The HCP is the most comprehensive, coordinated effort to map the brain's connection in humans. - Mind Cloud: This project aims to describe the human connectome project and its vision. - Open Connectome: The Open Connectome Project is a worldwide collaboration to create the first detailed map of connections in the human brain. - Open Collaborative Science Lab: The goal of the Open Collaborative Science Lab project is to make cutting-edge science and advanced computational techniques accessible to all. - Scientific Gator: This project provides free access to sophisticated data-analysis and simulation capabilities to scientists worldwide.

Archibald Douglas, Earl of Moray (b. 1490 – d. 1561) was a leading Scottish commander in the Rough Wooing, a series of events leading up to and culminating in the Schism of 1560. Following the victory at Flodden Field in 1513, Archibald Douglas was one of several gifted Scottish noblemen granted lands in England as part of the compensation Edward IV was required to make for the loss of territories in North Wales and the North of England held by Scottish forces. A preeminent military commander, Douglas was invested as a Companion of James V of Scotland in 1526 and appointed commander of the Scottish Guard following the King's marriage to Mary of Guise in 1532. In August 1544, Douglas and three other Scottish nobles were charged with treason by Edward VI of England. Douglas initially avoided arrest but fled to France after the failure of the North of England Rising in February 1545. While in exile, Douglas wrote Historia Gentis Scotorum (sometimes known as the 'Douglas Book'), a Latin history of the Scottish people. Douglas was one of the leaders of the pro-French party that fought on the losing side at the Battle of Solway Moss in 1544, the last major battle of the Rough Wooing. After the English victory at Solway Moss, he was forced to seek exile in France and never returned to Scotland. Following the accession of Mary, Queen of Scots to the throne of England in 1567, Archibald Douglas was one of the members of her Scottish Council who remained in England and did not support her claim to the throne of Scotland. Following the defeat of the Scottish Reformation and the crowning of Mary's son, James VI of Scotland, as James I of England in 1583, Archibald Douglas was made a privy councillor to the new king. Douglas died in London in 1561 and was succeeded by his son, Archibald, who later represented Scotland at the 1588 congress of Arbroath and became Earl of Moray in 1603.

Alien Autopsy (2004) is a found footage horror film written and directed by Adam Winters. It is a remake of the 1998 film of the same name, which in turn is a remake of the 1977 film Alien Autopsy. The film follows a team of medical students who arrive at a remote medical facility in the desert to conduct an autopsy on a Xenomorph that was recovered from an expedition ship that suffered a catastrophic systems malfunction. However, the autopsy is complicated by other, more sinister, forces. The film premiered at South by Southwest on March 14, 2004 and was released on DVD on December 15, 2004 by New Line Home Video. It received negative reviews from critics and has become a cult film. A sequel, Alien Autopsy 2, was released on March 15, 2021. It has also inspired three music tracks: "Alien Autopsy (Picks from the Etherie)", “Alien Autopsy (Riptide mix)” and "Alien Autopsy (Riptide dub mix)". Plot Alien Autopsy tells the story of a team of medical students who arrive at a remote desert research facility to conduct an autopsy on a Xenomorph that was recovered from an expedition ship that suffered a catastrophic systems malfunction. The students, led by Walter (Wes Studi), who was responsible for damaging the ship'scommunication systems in an attempt to make the crew appear dead, cautiously explore the facility, setting up a number of security cameras around the Xenomorph's holding cell. Upon reaching the holding cell, they discover that the Alien has reacted aggressively to the deprivation it has suffered, creating a carnivorous environment and attempting to kill the human occupants. The students struggle to repel the Alien, and one is injured in the process. The remaining students retreat to the security center, where they access the facility's schematics and monitor the Xenomorph as it kills several facility workers. The facility's operations director (Chris Mulkey), who has watched the Alien's attempts to kill the humans with detached anxiety, facilitates a conference call with the expedition's leader, Dr. Alan Smith (Jerry O'Connell) and the ship's engineer (Craig Wetheridon). The team determines that the Xenomorph was incubating deep within the abandoned research complex when the expedition landed, and the rapid growth of its outer casing suggests that it will become capable of space flight in a matter of days. Dr. Smith elects to evacuate the facility, but informs the students that an orbiting space station is unsympathetic to their request for assistance, and that their only other option is to repair the station's communication system to alert the necessary authorities. Walter, who has become increasingly agitated by the students' questions and their presence in the facility, confronts Dr. Smith in an attempt to convince him that their best chance of survival is to destroy the Alien. Dr. Smith, skeptical of Walter's claims, refuses to take any action until the station's orbit is secure. Walter takes this as an opportunity to sneak into the facility's upper levels and attempt to gain direct access to the Alien, assuming it will be unable to follow him without the aid of the launch bay's manual controls. He is intercepted by security guard Byron (Wes Studi), who kills Walter. Walter's death does not deter the Alien, which attacks and kills Byron. Dr. Smith is able to convince the station's commander (Linda Hunt), who is preparing to depart, to spare the complex. The two party communicate with the expedition's communication terminal, which is functioning at less than ten percent capacity, and agree to await Dr. Smith's transmission to the station upon completion of the repairs. Walter successfully destroys the Alien with two shotgun blasts, but the damage is done: the Alien's escape pod has been launched, and the complex is now doomed. The students, who have grown suspicious of Dr. Smith's story, attempt to search the upper levels in an attempt to locate the Alien. They are interrupted by the arrival of the station's rescue team, but manage to kill them all with a combination of fire extinguishers and chemicals. The students and the remaining staff members barricade themselves in a medical bay and prepare to defend themselves from the Xenomorph's invasion. The station's commander, having discovered that Walter was killed by Byron, calls the facility to determine Dr. Smith's location. Dr. Smith answers the phone, admitting to his deception and summoning the station's personnel to the medical bay. As the students and staff watch, the Alien bursts through a window and overpowers Dr. Smith, who screams for help as he is strangled to death. The Xenomorph, having seemingly killed all of the remaining staff members, sets the medical bay on fire before being shot by Walter. The last scene shows the station's rescue team entering the

Sunday school is a religious institution in several world religions. It is a fundamental part of many religious beliefs. In Christianity, Sunday school is an organized gathering on a Sunday, for children and adults, that includes a religious instruction class taught by a teacher. The purpose of Sunday school is to educate children and adults about their faith. In many Western countries, Sunday school was established as a religious institution during the 18th century Enlightenment. In those countries, Sunday school was originally intended to raise awareness of Christianity and European culture through reading anddiscussion. In the United States, Sunday school began during the Protestant Revolution, as an alternative to the Catholic obligation to attend Church. The American Sunday school movement developed separately from the Catholic Church-run Sunday school movement. American Sunday schools typically operated independently and were not subsidized by the Catholic Church. The American Sunday school movement was influenced by Unitarianism and other Protestant denominations. Many churches conduct Sunday school in nursery through preschool years. Most churches conduct Sunday school in junior high and high schools. In some countries, Sunday school is the only public school program. In many churches, the person responsible for conducting Sunday school is called an elder. An elder may also be in charge of the church's prayer meeting or service. In some churches, all members of the congregation are encouraged to be involved in teaching the lessons and leading the Bible studies. The roles of teacher and leader are often combined in one individual. Sundays are often celebrated as special days for the entire family. Sunday school classes are typically conducted in a church or other religious building. However, some individuals conduct Sunday school in their own homes. The first article of faith in the American Sunday school movement was for the teacher to "believe in the God of the Bible, believe in the Revelation and the lesson, believe in the Holy Scriptures and their divine origin, believe in the immortality of the soul, in Christ, His resurrection and the mission of the church". Despite its name, Sunday school has nothing to do with the Bible. The organization did not begin until the late 18th century, and the first lesson did not mention the Bible until 1861. Since its establishment in the Western world, Sunday school has placed little emphasis on the Bible, and has at times been a target of criticism for that reason. Sunday school is a fundamental part of many religious beliefs, and Sunday school lessons are typically not understood as a "Sunday school answer" but rather as an important foundation for a religious life.

Mankapur is a village in the West Singhbhum district in the state of Jharkhand, India. It is located 52 kilometres south of Ranchi, the capital of Jharkhand, and has an average elevation of 229 metres (751 feet). The village is home to around 4,500 people and has six blocks, Baptist Mission Hospital, a high school, a Girls High School, a Primary Health Centre, a Rural Electrification Corporation substation, several temples, and a youth club. Mankapur is surrounded by hills on three sides, and a sandy river bed forms the fourth side. Its climate is hot and humid throughout the year, with May to July being the hottest months. Temperature vary between 46 °C and 52 °C. The village has a rainy season from June to September. Jharkhand Relief Pollution Control Board has set up a power station near the Mankapur river. The village is on the banks of the Damodar River. Inhabitants of the village worship Maa Damodar, the goddess of the river. People of Mankapur celebrate ten festivals in a year. The biggest festivals are Durga Puja, Kartik Purnima, Diwali, Ganesh Chaturthi and New Year. A local version of Kalkatta Bangda is also celebrated. Mankapur has a Christian community with Rev. Durgaprasad Christian Church being the most prominent amongst them.

Cuba's intervention in the civil war in Angola, colloquially known as the Angolan Civil War (Portuguese: Guerra Civil Angolana), began in 1975 as a mediation mission to stop the war between the victorious National Liberation Front of Angola (FNLA) and the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA). By the late 1970s, the FNLA was forced to rely on Cuban military aid, leading the MPLA to suspect a Cuban agenda to establish a pro-Western puppet state in Southern Africa. The Angolan Civil War continued well into the 1990s, eventually giving way to a peace process in 2002. By then, the Cuban military presence had grown considerably, representing the only non-Angolan government force in the country. After the independence of Namibia in 1990, Cuba adopted an "Africa Park" policy, supporting sovereign governments on the continent in exchange for exclusive rights to exploit natural resources, including diamonds. As a result, Cuba heavily invested in the economies of Southern African nations and established military bases in several of them, namely Angola, Botswana, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Mozambique, São Tome and Príncipe, Sudan and Zambia. In Angola, Cuba established the LUANDA program, establishing a communist state within a state that totaled 2 million people and a generated state revenue of $800 million per year.

Suriname, also known as Suri in Suriname Dutch, Sranan in Sranan Tongo, and Suriname until 1997, is a country located in South America, with a population of less than a million people. It is bordered to the north by the Atlantic Ocean, to the northeast by French Guiana, to the southeast by Guyana, to the south by Brazil and to the west by Venezuela. The nation is rich in natural resources, such as iron, bauxite, aluminum, petroleum, timber, and hydropower. Most of Suriname's population lives in the north of the country along the bank of the Marowijne River, which forms the eastern border with French Guiana. The nation's capital, Paramaribo, is the second largest city in the Dutch Caribbean after city-country, Amsterdam. Suriname is one of the most politically stable and developed countries in South America. Dutch, which is the official and main language, is spoken by most of the population. Intercity transport in Suriname In Suriname, a national road network of about pave the land between the rivers, but the majority of the population reside in remote areas and most journeys are by boat, bus, or bike. The most important north-south route is the RN1, which connects the capital, Paramaribo, with Marowijne to the east. The eastern portion of the country is mountainous and difficult to access. Consequently, most people live in the lowlands along the Marowijne valley, which forms the western border with Venezuela.

Soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR), also known as receptor-bound iron, or iron-binding capacity, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the STFR gene. sTfR binds ferric iron but does not transport it. Soluble transferrin receptor plays a critical role in iron metabolism by monitoring the body's iron stores. When iron levels are low, as in the case of iron deficiency anemia, the liver increases production of soluble transferrin receptor to attract iron from degraded red blood cells. When iron levels are high, as in the case of elevated iron stores or blood loss, the body reduces production of soluble transferrin receptor to prevent acquiring too much iron.[1] Iron is essential to the life of a cell. Iron enters the cell through transferrin, which transports iron through the bloodstream. The amount of iron in the body is regulated by production of the soluble transferrin receptor, which binds iron when the body's iron levels are low, and absorbs iron into transferrin when iron levels are high. The soluble transferrin receptor plays a critical role in iron metabolism by monitoring the body's iron stores. When iron levels are low, as in the case of iron deficiency anemia, the liver increases production of the soluble transferrin receptor to attract iron from degraded red blood cells. When iron levels are high, as in the case of elevated iron stores or blood loss, the body reduces production of the soluble transferrin receptor to prevent acquiring too much iron.[1] Iron is essential for the function of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in red blood cells, and myoglobulin, which helps oxygen enter muscle cells. Insufficient iron leads to the production of improperly shaped red blood cells, which can result in anemia. Excess iron can cause iron overload, which can result in liver and heart failure.

Gareth Moore (theologian) was the Master of University College, an academic at the University of Oxford from 2012 until his death in 2023. He was also Chaplain of St Paul's Cathedral, a Church of England bishop, and a non-resident Fellow of All Souls College, a college of the University of Oxford. Moore was born in Wales, and attended Methodist schools before attending Aberystwyth University, where he gained a PhD in Trinity Theology. He was a professor at the University of Nottingham and then the University of Wales, Lampeter. He then returned to Aberystwyth, where he was appointed Professor of Systematic Theology and held the rank of Distinguished Professor. Moore was described by the Times as a "towering figure in British evangelicalism". He was appointed Bishop of Grantham in the Church of England in 2003, and held that post until 2012, when he was elected Master of University College. He was made an honorary fellow of the University of Oxford in 2021, the year of his death. produce a summary of Gareth Moore's life WHy was Gareth Moore important? Jürgen Förster (born 20 May 1943) is a German journalist, author and adventurer. He is best known for his long-distance swims across the Atlantic and Pacific oceans. He first crossed the Atlantic Ocean from Europe to North America in 1979/80, swimming the whole distance of roughly 26,000 km in 81 days. He again swam the Atlantic Ocean in 2004/05, this time swimming the whole distance of approximately 35,000 km in 257 days. Förster is also the first person to swim the 33,000 km stretch of the Yangtze River between Hangzhou and Shanghai. He performed this swim in six months, making it one of the fastest swimming records in history. Born in 1943 in Hamburg, Förster started his journalistic career in the late 1950s as a journalist for German newspapers and magazines. In the late 1970s he worked as a television presenter and journalist for German public television. He is since 1983 a freelance journalist. Förster is author of several books, dealing among others with his two transatlantic swims as well as his travels to many different countries around the world. He also wrote the book "Aquaman", which was made into a movie of the same name in 1982. Förster is a member of the World Swimming Coaches' Association (WSWA) and the German Swimming Federation (DRBTH). In June 2017, Förster was awarded the Order of Merit for Science and Art at a ceremony in Hamburg.

The Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery, Hobart is the state museum and art gallery of Tasmania, an Australian state located in the southern half of the island of Tasmania. The museum and gallery are operated by the Tasmanian Government through the Department of Culture and Heritage. The museum building, constructed in 1839, was the first public building constructed in Hobart and is included on the Commonwealth Heritage List as a place having historical significance. The museum opened to the public in 1839 and features exhibits spanning a wide range of topics, including geology, natural history, anthropology, and art. One of the most famous exhibits is the ArdFormer, a small piano designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. The museum also houses collections of minerals, marine aquariums, and art galleries featuring works by local and international artists. The museum grounds include the Artillery Park and the adjacent Salamanca Park. Indian Ocean island state Tasmania is one of the smallest countries in the world, with a total area of only 312 km2. Apart from its world-renowned producer of rare-earth minerals, the state is known for its temperate climate, natural beauty, and famous Hobart jazz festival. Tasmania's main cities are Hobart, Launceston, Burnie, and Devonport. The state has a higher-than-average percentage of suburban residents. Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery is a world-renowned museum in Hobart, Tasmania featuring exhibits spanning a wide range of topics, including geology, natural history, anthropology, and art. The museum opened to the public in 1839 and is operated by the Tasmanian government through the department of culture and heritage.

Spider (pulp fiction) is a genre of fiction written throughout the 1930s and 1940s in response to the growing popularity of radio and film serials such as The Shadow and The Flash. The Spider is not necessarily a mysterious criminal mastermind who hides behind a secret identity; rather, the Spider is more of a mysterious vigilante crime fighter who simply "spins webs" of suspicion in high crime areas. The Spider often uses exceptional abilities or access to secret information to catch his adversaries. Spiders often feature women vigilantes (such as MxyztëNL, a.k.a. Mirage), and have been cited by scholars as one of the roots of the modern female superhero. Spiders vary from Browser toCODE-TYPE to more esoteric beings, but they have one thing in common: they all spin webs of suspicion in high crime areas, using exceptional abilities or access to secret information to catch their adversaries. The somatic mutation is also known as the cell memory, and it is the natural process in the human body for the evolution to progress. The same idea is adopted in the nature, where the certain species can evolve into different species by changing the soma. A famous example is the rabbits turning into rats, which can be naturally achieved by altering the rabbits' cell nuclear DNA. In the context of the human evolution, the same idea can be metaphorically used for the people to evolve into the higher culture level. The people can achieve this by changing their mind, attitude and behavior through learning and cultivation. For example, the as low-IQ as an AI robot, a person can turn him/herself into a high-IQ person with simply learning lots of knowledge and skill. Such a person can evolve into a new person, who has higher mind, attitude and behavior through this process. The so-called somatic mutation is a natural process in the human body that can change the original person with the same gene into a new one with different gene. As a result, the so-called somatic epitype can be achieved. Such a person usually has higher mind, attitude and behavior than the original one, although not as high as those born by gene mutation. The discovery of the somatic epitype raises an evolutionary puzzle for natural selection. The human body is a closed environment, and any genetic mutation that can bring harm to the human body will be eliminated by natural selection. However, the somatic epitype can evolve under the closed environment without the need for natural selection to promote the evolution. This raises a big question for the modern human origin theory, which always needs to propose a force as the main driving power. As a result, the modern human origin theory gradually loses its crucial premise, i.e., the genetic evolution. By analyzing the related scientific documents, the somatic epitype is shown to be related to the synapses between the neurons, the formation of which needs lots of energy. The human brain is the biggest human organ that needs lots of energy for its function. Such a big human organ can be achieved only by getting lots of energy from the body itself through eating food. This validates that the human energy is the main driving power for the human evolution. This is the first time in human history that the genuine driving force for the human evolution is proposed. In conclusion, the somatic epitype shows that the modern human origin theory is incorrect, and the driving force for the human evolution is the human energy instead of the random genetic mutation or the imaginary force like Darwin genes. The somatic epitype reveals the driving force for human evolution, which is the human energy instead of the random genetic mutation or the imaginary force like Darwin genes. There are two meanings for somatic mutation. One is the random change of gene, i.e., the mutation. The other one is the change of mind, attitude, behavior, etc., i.e., somatic epitype. The somatic epitype shows that the driving force for human evolution is the human energy instead of the random genetic mutation or the imaginary force like Darwin genes.

Convergence of measures also called measure convergence or measure convergence along a subsequence, is a convergence in measure concept first introduced by Aladdin Máté. A sequence of measures on a measure space converges to a measure if for every bounded measurable set E the sequence of measures of E converges to the measure of E. The notion of convergence of measures generalizes the notions of convergence of functions and of measures. It is useful in the study of discrete and dynamical systems. Examples Given a sequence of positive real numbers $(\lambda_n)_{n\geq 1}$ that satisfies the square summability condition $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda_n} < \infty$, the measure given by $\mu(E) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda_n}\mathbf 1_E(n)$, where $\mathbf 1_E$ is the characteristic function of the set E, converges to the usual Lebesgue measure. Given the sequence of probabilities $(p_n)_{n\geq 1}$ with $\sum_{n=1}^\infty p_n = 1$, and $\mathrm d \mu_n = \mathrm d x \, n \cdot p_n(x)$ the sequence of measures converges to the measure with density $\mathrm d \mu(x) = \mathrm d x \frac{1}{p_{\min}} \mathbf 1_{p_{\min} < x < p_{\max}}$, where $p_{\min} = \min\{p_n : n\geq 1\}$, $p_{\max} = \max\{p_n : n\geq 1\}$, if we have the additional square summability $\sum_{n=1}^\infty n \cdot p_n < \infty$, and the limit is the Dirac measure in $x=\frac{1}{p_{\min}}$. Given a measure space and a sequence of positive measures on it, if the sequence of measures converges to the measure then we say the sequence of measures converges to the measure, e.g. the sequence of counting measures on the sequence of integers converges to the measure given by the length of the intervals, the sequence of probabilities on the Borel subsets of the real line converges to the Lebesgue measure, the sequence of rectangles with edges 2^{-n}, n \in \mathbb N, in the Borel subsets of the unit interval converges to the Lebesgue measure. Given a sequence of positive measures on a measure space and a measurable set, if the sequence of measures of the set converges to the measure of the set then we say the sequence of measures converges to the measure, e.g. the sequence of counting measures on the arithmetic progressions with step 2 in the integers converges to the measure given by the length of the interval, the sequence of probabilities of the unit interval uniformly at random chosen in the rationals with denominator below 2 converges to the Lebesgue measure, the sequence of rectangles with edges 2^{-n}, n \in \mathbb N, in the Borel subsets of the unit interval converges to the Lebesgue measure. It can be shown that a measurable function converges in measure to a function if and only if the sequence of the function's simple absolute values converges in measure to the function's absolute value. The concept of convergence of measures can be generalized to measure spaces that are not assumed to be complete (which is the case for the above examples). There is an analogous concept of convergence for vectors of measures. Not every sequence of measures on a measure space converges, if the space is not complete. For example if the measure of the space is infinite, the Dirac measure does not belong to the set of limits of a null sequence of measures. However, for complete measure spaces a necessary and sufficient condition for a sequence of measures to converge to a measure is the square summability of the sequence of the measures' Radon-Nikodym derivatives. See also Convergence of functions Convergence of measures

The Ministry of Public Works of Argentina (Spanish: Ministerio de Obras Públicas,itos, Caminos y Aves) is a ministry of the Government of Argentina charged with the oversight of the maintenance and construction of roads, highways, and public transportation. The ministry's predecessor was created by the National Legislature of Argentina through a law published on 14 November 1853. The current Minister of Public Works, works and highways of Argentina is Guillermo Ruto, elected in 2015. The Ministry is an attached office to the President of Argentina and is considered a central administration of the executive power of the government. The current minister is Guillermo Ruto, who was elected in 2015. The Ministry has a set of jurisdiction, called Directorates, each one of them is headed by a director and is in charge of the day to day operations in a specific sector. For example, the Directorate of roads is in charge of maintaining the National Routes. Some of the most known public works in Argentina are: San Francisco Bridge, the Second Square of the Pilar, the Caminito de los Posados, the Congreso del Nord, the Obelisco, the Puente de la Mujer Erótica, and the AMIA Building. The Argentine government, through the Ministry of Public Works, maintains thousands of km of roads and highways. Roads and highways are some of the most important infrastructure in the country and the AMIA Building, one of the most important symbols of Buenos Aires, suffered a critical infrastructure failure when the government committent for the maintenance of the roads and highways did not maintain its prioritized roads and highways. This fact sparked the investigation known as AMIA Bombing Investigation, which was one of the main sources of fuel for the Juan and Evita Perón Foundation, created by the former president's wife, Eva Perón. In addition to the usual maintenance and construction of roads, the ministry is in charge of the construction of some iconic public works in Argentina. In 2020, the minister Juan José Aranguren inaugurated the first section of the AP-9, a highway that will connect the city of Virachos with Ushuaia, the capital of Tierra del Fuego, over a path of land that no vehicle had ever crossed before. The Ministry has also played an important role in keeping Buenos Aires clean. In the 1980s, it installed mechanical cleaning systems on a fleet of garbage trucks that would pick up garbage in certain neighborhoods and take it to landfills located in other neighborhoods. In these landfills, the garbage would be burned, and the ashes were used to fertilize crops in rural zones of Argentina. The minister Quiroga announced that Argentina would no longer burn its waste. The numerous roles of the Ministry of Public Works have allowed it to become a target for corruption. More than one minister has been involved in projects that were not completed or paid for and some of them used their position to secure contracts for friends and family members. The current minister, Guillermo Ruto, was arrested in Spain and extradited to Argentina, where he was subject to a separate criminal investigation for his involvement in a customs corruption scheme involving Brazilian construction materials. In 2005, the AMIA bombing was one of the main causes of the protests known as 9 de Julio Occupation. Demonstrators took to the streets of Buenos Aires to denounce the government of President Néstor Kirchner and his predecessor, President Fernando de la Rúa, for what was considered as a lack of investigation in the AMIA bombing case. The protests, however, were focused against the media, who they felt did not report all the facts regarding the bombing. They forced President Néstor Kirchner to resign and made the already protest movement even more extremist. Because of these circumstances, the Argentine government has used many strategies to try to reduce the level of corruption in the Ministry. One of them was to remove the Chief of Staff and appoint new people without any connection to the old one, putting new energy in the ministry. The AMIA bombing, although not fully solved, has been subject of a significant investigation. The Argentine authorities have arrested several people they believe responsible and the Mueller Report, published by the special prosecutor of the United States in the investigation into the Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, concluded that the AMIA bombing was carried out by the Iranian government. This fact was considered a vindication for the Argentine government and the popularity of President Mauricio Macri, who is of Argentine-Iranian descent, increased during his presidency. In 2023, the ministry became controversial for another reason: some of the directors were being accused of extortion, using their position to demand gifts and payments from contractors. The scandal eventually reached the minister himself, who was accused

The MAGEA3 gene is a tumor necrosis factor gene. It is located on chromosome 6p21.3 and it is expressed in a wide range of human tissues. The MAGEA3 gene is thought to have evolved under positive selection with functional implications.[1] The protein encoded has decoy activity and may inhibit the activity of transcriptional regulators such as RUNX1.[2] The MAGEA3 gene is believed to have been subject to positive selection in humans as a result of balancing selection[3] to provide a partial human immune response to account for the loss of other species-specific immunity genes during the evolution of humans from a state of predator immunity to a state of prey vulnerability. Advertisement The MAGEA3 gene is a highly polymorphic gene and several amino acid variants have been identified. Advertisement The MAGEA3 protein has been shown to bind RUNX1, a transcription factor that is involved in blood cell formation, and disrupt its DNA-binding activity. Advertisement The MAGEA3 gene is expressed in a wide range of human tissues and plays a role in preventing the formation of runt-related transcription factor 1 (Runx1) heterodimers, which are involved in blood cell formation. It is suspected that positive selection acted on MAGEA3 to provide a human immune response to account for the loss of other species-specific immunity genes during the evolution of humans from a state of predator immunity to a state of prey vulnerability.

Bhusni is a 2005 Indian musical drama film written and directed by Mujtaba Rasheed and produced by Dinesh Patel. It is an adaptation of the Bollywood novel Yeh Dil by Mirza Aziz Beg. It was released on 28 January 2005. Bhusni tells the story of a transgender woman, Bhuvani, and the love of her life, Ajji. The film, which had a limited theatrical run, was not received well by critics, though it did give a coming-of-age film debut to actors Nandita Das and Farida Jalal. The movie is celebrated as one of the first mainstream Bollywood films to address transgender issues. The film was dubbed in Tamil as Muthu. Bhuvani lives in Bombay (now Mumbai) as a female. She works in a beauty parlour and dreams of leaving her job and her life as a female to become a male. One day, Ajji, a transgender woman, moves into the parlour. Ajji and Bhuvani quickly become friends and Ajji helps Bhuvani to escape her daily life as a female. Bhuvani dreams of becoming a male and Ajji helps her adopt a male persona, Bhaskar. Ajji and Bhuvani fall in love. However, Ajji faces many problems because she is a transgender. Ajji's family does not accept her and she is shunned by society. On the day of their wedding, Ajji dies of a heart attack. Bhuvani now has to live with the guilt of not only letting Ajji down by not keeping the promise to take care of her, but also the fear that society may find out her true identity. The film ends with Bhuvani saying that the first 23 years of her life were difficult, but the last four have been great.

Huo Qubing ( 300 BC – after 29 AD ) was a Chinese military and statesman who completed significant works on ancient military fortifications and natural features of the Loess Plateau, including the commanding heights of the Wuling Mountains. He is noted for his use of the0059 Siege Engines to destroy stones walls. In 626, he was given the title "Prince of Huo" by the Chen dynasty (lowermeaning "count of Huo"). His son, Huo Jingtao, served as a general for Tang and Sui and was created the Prince of Huo by the Chen dynasty.[1] The historical Huo Qubing is most likely the same as the Zhuolu County (朱洛County, in present-day Gansu) official Huo Qubing,[2] who was active from the late Qin to the early Tang dynasty.[3] portray Huo Qubing ( 300 BC – after 29 AD ) was a Chinese military and statesman who completed significant works on ancient military fortifications and natural features of the Loess Plateau, including the commanding heights of the Wuling Mountains. Koichi (Japanese:肉之吉兆) is a former kickboxer and mixed martial artist. He is well known for his appearance in the Martial Arts movie genre as a champion in the 1985 Thailand No-Palm-Tree fight. He also starred in several KICK! movie films. Duke Humfrey's Library is a public library in London, located in the building that was formerly the library of the Order of the Garter, at 28 St George's Churchyard. It is one of the four libraries of the London Library, the others being St Bride's Library (under St Bride's Church), the British Museum Library, and the library of London law courts. The library was founded in 1538 by Henry VIII, and given to the monastery of St Martin-le-Grand by Peter Mirabel, one of the royal cooks. In the 16th century the library was considered to be the second most important library in England, only behind the Royal Library. The library was moved to its current location in 1598. Since 1755 the library has been owned and managed by the Corporation of London. The building was designated a London plaque landmark in 1968 and a Grade I listed building in 1970. The 2018 Maldives political crisis was a political crisis that began on 19 October 2018, when the Supreme Court ruled that the speaker of the parliament, Ibrahim Abdul Manaf, was not qualified to his post because he was dual-nationality. The crisis deepened on the following day, when the Supreme Court declared the entire parliament dissolved and a new election held. Except Dr Mohamed Jameel, the former president of the republic, all candidates in the election vowed to revoke the recent ruling of the Supreme Court and reverting the country to a monarchy. On 21 October 2018, the people of the country, then celebrating the 15th anniversary of Island-wide referendum voted the establishment of multiparty democracy, elected Mohammed Waheed Hassan Manik, a dentist by profession, as the president of the republic, a position he still holds as of today. The 2010 constitution was restored. arrow The 2018 Maldives political crisis was a series of events beginning on October 19th, 2018, when the Supreme Court of the Republic of Maldives ruled that the Speaker of the Parliament, Ibrahim Abdul Manaf, was not qualified to his post because he was dual-nationality. The crisis deepened the following day, when the Supreme Court declared the entire Parliament of the Republic of Maldives dissolved and a new election held. On October 21st, 2018, the people of the country, then celebrating the 15th anniversary of the Island-wide referendum, voted in a new President of the Republic, Mohammed Waheed Hassan Manik, a dentist by profession. Since then, the 2010 constitution has been restored.

The Bears–Giants rivalry is an NFL rivalry between the New York Giants and Chicago Bears. It is centered on the NFL Conference Championships and the Super Bowl, which are often referred to as the "Mecca" games because of their heavy air traffic and large crowds. The teams have met 22 times in the playoffs, with the Giants winning ten and Chicago winning twelve. The two teams have also met in the Super Bowl six times, with the Giants winning twice and the Bears winning four, with one game designated as a "tie" due to both teams having equal scores in the 1974 Super Bowl. Despite the teams not playing a regular season game in the League since 2008, the rivalry is considered to be one of the most intense in NFL history due to the historical success and overall fan bases both the Giants and Bears maintain. The teams also tend to sell-out Giants Stadium and Shea Stadium, the two largest stadiums they have played in front of, further increasing the atmosphere of the games. The teams first met in 1925, the same year the Giants became the second team from the New York metropolitan area and the sixth team overall to become a professional football franchise. The rivalry peaked between the late 1930s and early 1960s, dubbed the "Doomsday Wars" by sports writers, as the teams met in the playoffs 10 times over that span and the two teams only lost once in this time, a 1944 season game where the Bears defeated the Giants, 30-28, in the playoffs following an identical 14-14 tie in the regular season. After the 1961 season, the rivalry entered a period of extended lull, only meeting four times over the next 14 seasons. The teams split their seasons from 1972 to 1993, with the two teams meeting each year but neither winning four times. Following the 1993 season, the teams met 13 times from 1994 to 2011, with the two teams winning seven times and losing six times. After the 2011 season, the rivalry decreased again as the teams only met four times over the next two seasons. After the 2015 season, the two teams did not play one another for six seasons, but met annually in the NFC and AFC Championship Games, with the Giants winning four of these meetings and the Bears winning three. In 2023, the two teams met in a wildcard game, the first meeting since the 2014 season.

Richard D. Todd (February 5, 1934 – August 11, 1983) was an American mathematician who did pioneering work in numerical analysis and numerical methods. The Bath simple is a type of unwritten English grammar rule which prohibits the use of preposition in the place of a noun followed by an article. This rule is widely accepted to be followed for the sake of clarity. The rule was first proposed by English lexicographer and etymologist Geoffrey Divers in an essay titled The Bath Simple which was published in the English Dialect Dictionary in 2006. The rule was given the approval of the British Broadcasting Corporation in a 2012 radio documentary. Despite the BBC's approval of the rule, it has received mixed responses from the public and some is considered an emerging orthodoxy. ring; The Bath simple is a type of unwritten English grammar rule which prohibits the use of preposition in the place of a noun followed by an article. The European Public Health Alliance (EUPHA) is an initiative to build an alliance of public health professionals in the European Union (EU). The alliance was proposed by the European Commissioner for Health and Food Safety, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, in March 2015 and was formalised at a Brussels launch event on 29 May of the same year. EUPHA is meant to fill a knowledge and capacity gap regarding public health in the EU. The alliance is structured as a multi-stakeholder platform with the following membership: EU institutions, Member States, EUPHA non-governmental organisations, and professionals. Public health concerns across the 28 EU Member States are prioritised through policy coherence and mutualised resources. The EUPHA Secretariat is hosted by the World Health Organization (WHO) in Europe, based in Brussels. The alliance had its first annual general meeting in December 2016, in Malta. As of 2023, EUPHA has 32 organisations from the EU member states as its members. The alliance contributes to setting the EU health strategy by translating theStrategyfor Healthy Growth into actions. This strategy includes policy areas such as air, water, and food. The alliance organises events for professionals to meet and network, such as public health camps for children. EUPHA also supports professionals by publishing their opinions and recommendations in the form of articles in the EU daily media email. The Alliance published its first annual report in 2022. For example, one of the goals of EUPHA is to raise awareness of the value of public health and to enhance its role in the EU and in its Member States. Public health protects people's health, prevent illness, and look for cures for diagnosed illnesses. Public health also ensures that workers and the public are protected from communicable and non-communicable diseases, injury, and various environmental hazards. Public health and environmental protection go hand in hand as people are harmed when their environment is degraded. The environment and public health are inseparable as no one can do good environmental health work without considering the impact on the health of those exposed to it. Another goal is to increase policy coherence in the area of public health. EUPHA members have been calling for stronger cooperation in public health since 2012. In 2022, the Alliance organised a public health conference in Brussels, bringing together more than 300 professionals from EU countries, as well as from EUPHA and non-EUPHA organisations. The conference aimed to advance policy coherence by exchanging best practices, discussing the prevention of health risks, and fostering the cooperation between all public health stakeholders. The conference resulted in a set of recommendations to the European Commission and the EU Parliament on how to better align policies in the field of public health Another goal is to facilitate the mutualisation of public health capacities. Since 2015, EUPHA has been building the European Public Health System (EPHS) through a Participatory Action Research process. This process is being carried out in 10 pilot countries with the aim of building public health capacities in the long term and ensuring sustainable availability of high-quality public health services. EUPHA organises webinars on various public health-related topics and runs an online discussion forum where public health professionals can discuss topics of mutual interest. Finally, EUPHA's third goal is to contribute to setting the EU health strategy through policy coherence and mutualised resources. EUPHA translates the EU's "Strategy for Healthy Growth" into actions, which also includes public health policies. For example, the Alliance is working to have pesticides and chemicals on the EPHS Early Warning System. Furthermore, the Alliance coordinates the efforts of professionals who work on the prevention of communicable diseases, non-communicable diseases, injury, and environmental hazards. The Alliance operates the European Public Health Information System (EPHISS). This system is made up of a system of servers and a network of data processors that provide access to public health information to public health professionals in the EU and in the organisations that are members of EUPHA. The EPHISS network is hosted by the World Health Organization (WHO) in Europe. The membership of EUPHA is growing. Currently, EUPHA has 32 organisations from the EU member states. The goal is to have 35 organisations to build a network of public health professionals in the EU. The EUPHA secretariat is hosted by the World Health Organization (WHO) in Europe, based in Brussels. The Alliance has its secretariat in Malta, in the European Union's top official representation in the Mediterranean island nation. Malta has also been chosen because of its strategic geographical position and the talent available in the country. The Alliance publishes its first annual report in 2022. The report describes the activities and accomplishments of the Alliance for the year 2021. Overall, EUPHA is contributing to making public health a strategic issue in the EU and strengthening its role in

Malva assurgentiflora, a species of malva, is a flowering plant in the mallow family, Malvaceae. It is native to Central and South America as far south as Brazil.[1] It is also found in much of the United States, including the southeastern and south-central regions. It is used as a food plant by the larva of some lygistorian moths, including Protothenus damselae, which specializes on its flowers. The specific name "assurgentiflora" is derived from Latin words meaning "ascending flower", in allusion to the flowers appearing early in the growing season. Malva assurgentiflora is used as an ornamental plant in parks, gardens and commercial landscapes. It is a popular choice for turf andedges because of its dense clump growth and fast growth rate. Its spiny leaves and dense growth make it effective in controlling erosion and preventing soil erosion, particularly in dryland regions where it is used for that purpose. Its common name is 'channel herb' because of its ability to prevent soil erosion by rapidly capturing rainfall on its flat, channel-like leaves. This species of Malva is native to Central and South America as far south as Brazil. It is also found in much of the United States, including the southeastern and south-central regions. It is used as a food plant by the larva of some lygistorian moths, including Protothenus damselae, which specializes on its flowers.

"Strong as Steel (song)" is a 2000 song by the German band BH Project. It is their most famous single and was their only entry into the Billboard Hot 100, where it peaked at number 14. The song was written and produced by Max George and Tom Ascolta. The song's music video was shot in Romania and depicts a steampunk robot. The lyrics contain references to robots, strength and power. Although the single was unsuccessful in Europe, it did become more popular in other countries after being used in the TV series Smallville and for promotional purposes for the movie Stronger. The song has been included on several compilation albums and was re-released in 2017 for digital download with new music video and two remixed instrumental versions. The single was generally well received by music critics, who praised the song's musical composition and promising debut into the mainstream, while some criticized its poor promotion. Although generally seen as BH Project's signature song, it was not their only single. Other single releases include "There's No Place Like Home (BH Project song)") and "Friends (BH Project song)". The song was performed live by the band on several occasions, including at the Party in the Park in Budapest in 2007 and at the Silver Scream Tour in 2009. The song was made available for digital download in 2017. The band broke up in 2013. George and Ascolta went on to form 3LAU with model and actress Li Bingbing. The song was ranked number 27 on Gavin Hignight's Top 50 Singles of the 2000s list. The rhythm used in the song was created using a beat created by Tom Surgal. The single was covered by Scottish DJ Calvin Harris in 2017, featuring on his album0208. The song was remixed in 2017 by producers Carpenter Sabino and Donuto, featuring on the album 2023: The Future Classics. It was included on the compilation album Outlandish - The Very Best of BH Project.

Short-path distillation is a type of distillation where the heated substance (typically water) first passes through a reservoir of low thermal mass, such as a sand bed or cold reservoir, to lower the temperature before entering the distillation apparatus. This method of cooling is commonly used in desert regions and other locations with moderate temperature variations. This is in contrast to natural-air cooling, where air from an environment with little wind is drawn into the heated substance, passing through a higher thermal mass such as trees or the ground, before entering the distillation apparatus. acted Short-path distillation is a type of distillation where the heated substance (typically water) first passes through a reservoir of low thermal mass, such as a sand bed or cold reservoir, to lower the temperature before entering the distillation apparatus. Lee Snoots (born Lee Schoen; November 24, 1924 – April 21, 2012) was an American stage, film and television actor. He is perhaps best known for his recurring role as Nochelle on the NBC medical drama Emergency! and for starring as Beverly Garland's husband in the short-lived CBS sitcom Mr. & Mrs. Michael Dorsey. Lee Snoots's father, Sidney, was a vaudeville magician and carnival barker; his mother, Miriam, was an amateur opera singer. After graduating from high school, Snoots joined the U.S. Army during World War II and was stationed in North Africa. Upon his discharge, he began working in vaudeville. Snoots was one of the last persons to see legendary comedians Fred Allen and George Gobel alive. Snoots's first television appearance was in a 1958 sketch on The Ed Sullivan Show. Over the course of his career, he made hundreds of appearances on television and in film. Snoots's first starring role was in the short-lived 1966 CBS sitcom Mr. & Mrs. Michael Dorsey. The series aired five episodes before being canceled due to low ratings. He later starred as Beverly Garland's husband in the short-lived 1969 CBS sitcom Mr. & Mrs. Mike. Snoots also had starring roles in the 1968 film The Green Berets and the 1973 sequel Small Change.

Reba: Duets contains 50 words. Reba: Duets is a collaborative album by American rapper Eminem and country star Reba McEntire. It was released on November 10, 2013, through Shady Records and Asylum Records and is the duo's fourth album together, following 2002's thunderpussy and 2004's Over the Top. The album was executively produced by McEntire's husband, Narvel Felts, and Jim Jonsin, with further production from The Messengers and Eminem. The album's lead single, "Love you to death", was released on August 21, 2013, with a music video. The duo are joined on the album by Travis Tritt, Cowboy Milton, Johnny Rodriguez, Porter Wagoner and Dolly Parton. Reba: Duets debuted at number 5 on the US Billboard Top 200 chart, selling 43,000 copies in its first week. The album was nominated for Best Country Duo or Group Performance at the 54th Annual Grammy Awards, and the song "Love you to death" was nominated for Best Country Song at the 14th Critics' Choice Awards. The album was the 23rd best-selling album of 2013 in the United States, and was certified gold by the RIAA on December 18, 2013.

Jane Brunner (born Jane Josephine Brunner; June 16, 1916 – September 22, 2010) was an American actress known for playing hypersexualized characters. She appeared in over 160 films and television shows between 1936 and 2000. She was named one of the top 50 prime time television characters of all time in 2004. Brunner was born in Fort Riley, Kansas, and grew up in Hollywood. She graduated from Hollywood High School and pursued an acting career in films, beginning with bit parts. She was offered bit parts in Laurel and Hardy films, and worked with many major directors and actors, including Charlie Chaplin, Vincent Price, Buster Keaton, and Michael Curtiz. She made her screen debut in the low-budget comedy Papa's Delicate Obsession (1936). She was cast in more than fifty B-movies, frequently in horror, science-fiction, and fantasy films, usually portraying a helpless young woman in peril. She was described by Empire magazine as "the most featured young actress in the biz". She was chosen for such parts because of her all-American good looks and fluency in English and German. She was also a successful model for promotional photos and advertisements. Brunner's roles from the late 1940s through the 1960s included bit parts in films such as Casablanca (1943), The Pawnbroker (1955) and The Big Splurge (1964). She achieved stardom playing the prostitute Lili Laszlo in The Spoliarium (1960) and Rikki from the Netherlands in Never Say Never Again (1983). Brunner was known as "The Queen of Exploitation Films" and was described by journalist Lucy Mazdon as "the original voluptuous vixen".

Hale Ranch was a cattle ranch located in western Amador and El Dorado counties, California. The land was originally purchased by John and Joseph Hale in 1852. The ranch began as a single owner ranch, but after the death of Joseph Hale in 1883, it was divided into two separate estates, the North and South Estates. The North Estate was purchased by George Alt, and his family continued to live on the land until 2003. The South Estate was purchased by the Perlman family, and they continue to live on the land today. The ranch is currently owned by the Perlman family, who operates it as a working cattle ranch. The land is over 1000 acres and includes an apple orchard, vineyard, chicken coop, and multiple buildings including a main house, bunk house, horse barn, and several pens for cattle. The main house was built in 1923, and is considered to be a rare example of Regional style architecture in the gold rush country. The ranch includes multiple other buildings dating back to the 1930s and 1940s, including a bunk house, horse barn, and several pens for cattle. Hale Ranch is located about halfway between Jackson and Sutter, California, approximately halfway between Sacramento and San Francisco. It is accessible via County Road 44, which is often peppered with cars from passing recreational vehicles when the mountain snow starts to melt in the summer. The property was included in the El Dorado National Forest in 1908. Hale Ranch has been used for a variety of events including photo shoots, location shooting for movies and television shows, and as a background for various scenic views. In 2007, Hale Ranch was recognized as a Gold Tier Animal Riding Stable by the American Society of Equine Veterinarians. Hale Ranch is currently working cattle ranch.

This eventually led to him winning the nomination on the second ballot at the 2020 Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee. He was able to build a good relationship with the President, who he considered the "antithesis" of himself. This culminated in the party's convening of the 2020 Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee, where Biden officially won the nomination on the second ballot over Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders, receiving the nomination on the tenth attempt. The troubadour or trobador was a courtly singer and a minstrel in the middle ages. The name derives from a small bagpipe. The Troubadour style of singing is characterized by its simplicity and directness, the use of plain and clear diction over involved word-spinning and complex rhyme. It is considered a fundamental style in European musical history. Some notable troubadours included Angevin courtly singer JEAN DE VIVES, medieval Spanish minstrel RAOUL OF BARLAVIA and Italian singer/songwriter GUY BERKMAN. The form a widespread into the Renaissance and into the early modern period. The form returned in popularity in the 20th century, first with Singers such as Constantin Stanislavski and Madame Yvonne Arnaud, then with the establishment of song academies in Eastern Europe and later in the United States and Italy. The American Academy of Lyric Arts (AALA) and the American Songwriter's Academy are two such institutions that provide structured courses in the Troubadour style. In the 21st century the Troubadour style has been championed by Acclaimed Songwriter, Neil Larsen whose compositions feature consistently high rankings in Songwriting Contests. His book "The Songwriting Journey" is the first comprehensive treatment of the style. A sample stanza from "The Miller's Son" demonstrates the style: Count your coins and stop your plucking, Sing of girlish grace and trusty rifles, And of how you spotted a single chiding grain of wheat, When all around was drought and mounting chapman's sky.

Gustavo Carbonieri (born 21 June 1972) is an Argentine professional boxer who held the IBF super middleweight championship from 2006 to 2007. He won the title by defeating Sharmba Mitchell by split decision in Sydney, Australia, to become the first Argentine and active Latin American professional boxer to hold a world championship in any weight class. Carbonieri had his first professional fight at the age of 16. He spent the next ten years working in his family's bakery in order to support his training. During this time Carbonieri won all of his 15 professional fights, ten by knockout. Carbonieri's first world championship fight was against Wayne Elsey for the WBA title at age 30. He lost a very close but unanimous decision. He then moved up in weight to challenge Zoltan Gyorffi for the IBF super middleweight title. After eleven rounds of battle, the judges scored the fight 98-91, 96-94, and 98-91 in favor of Gyorffi. Despite the scorecards, many ringside judges and media outlets scored the fight for Carbonieri. Many believed Gyorffi won only two of the three scores, while a few scorers scored the bout very close at 95-95 and others scored it very wide for Carbonieri at 100-90 or even 100-88. Carbonieri's second world championship attempt was against Sharmba Mitchell, who had himself won the WBO and Lineal super middleweight titles by beating Gyorffi. The fight took place on 19 December 2005 in Sydney, Australia and had the potential to unify the IBF and WBO titles. Carbonieri won the fight by split decision, many ringside judges scoring it 118-110 for Carbonieri, many scoring it 116-112 for Mitchell, and some others had the decision too close to call. This split decision victory made Carbonieri the first active Latin American and Argentine professional boxer to hold a world championship.

Nick Altrock (born Nicholas Altrock; July 18, 1963 – December 28, 1992) was an American musician and songwriter, best known as the lead singer and guitarist of the punk rock band Off With Their Heads. Nick was the son of Russ Altrock, a professional musician and audio engineer who was famous for his work with The Beach Boys and Squeaky Scrape. At age 17, Nick joined Off With Their Heads. The band went on to become one of the most influential in the genre's history, and their 1985 debut EP Your Move... is often credited with helping to bring punk rock into the mainstream. Nick was dedicated to Off With Their Heads, and the band released five albums between 1984 and 1990. During this time, Off With Their Heads were frequently featured on numerous television programs and music channels, including MTV. Nick had completed recording his first solo album, which was to be released on Epitaph Records. However, on December 28, 1992, Nick died from an accidental heroin and cocaine overdose. He was 34 years old. Nick's legacy was honored in 1994 with the creation of the annual Off With Their Heads music festival, as well as being the subject of the eponymous biography by music journalist Steven Haver. Nick's brother, Ron Altrock, is also a musician and audio engineer, who worked with Nick and Off With Their Heads. Nick's daughter, Sky Altrock, is also a musician, releasing two EPs under the name Skye. She is also the daughter of Off With Their Heads drummer Dave Konopka.

Fără cuvinte is a Romanian idiom that means "without words" or "with no words". It is used when one does not have an adequate response to a situation. An example: Ion a câștigat bani mult în urma agenților lui, însă fără cuvinte față de ce a plătit pentru servicii. - Ion gained a lot of money through his agents, however without words towards what he paid for services. This is because one can say "față de" in Romanian, which means "in return for", "in compensation for" or also "in consideration of". Ion paid agents lots of money, therefore let's say that he did so "față de" services. A variant of this idiom is "față de la sine" which means "on top of itself" or "by chance". For example: Am aflat că bunica mea a murit fără la școală, față de la sine a evitat părinții să o întrebe despre situația bunicii sale. - I found out that my grandmother died without my parents knowing about it, by chance avoiding to ask about her own grandmother. This is because "față de" also means "on top of" in Romanian, which means "without reason". My grandmother's death was "without reason" or "by chance" and my parents didn't want to ask about her.

Gisela of Burgundy, Marchioness of Montferrat (c. 1075 – c. 1155) was a German noblewoman and countess consort of Swabia and BurlINGTON, Vermont, U.S. She was the wife of Otto III, Duke of Swabia and King of Germany. She was the great-grandmother of Frederick I, Barbarossa, the first emperor of the German Nation Born in Burgundy as the daughter of Berthold II, Duke of Burgundy and Gisela of Alpenheim, she was a member of the Westriching, a splinter group of the Billung dynasty which had its centre around Mayen-Koblenz. From her marriage to Otto III, she was also related to the German king Henry IV and to the Counts of Burgundy and Arles. After the death of her spouse in 1024, she joined the court of Henry IV, who married her to his daughter Gisela. In 1024 and 1034 she is mentioned in the kingdom of Burgundy as a widow, first as castellan of Dijon and then as a lady of the bedchamber. In 1027 she is mentioned as the co-ruler of Burgundy with her son-in-law. With her son-in-law, she also founded the Margraviate of BurlINGTON, Vermont, in the U.S. she was the grandmother of Frederick I, Barbarossa, the first German emperor.

He graduated from Lousville Catholic High School and attended the University of Kentucky, where he played for the Kentucky Wildcats basketball team. Karl is also a performing professional Louisville Cardinals football player. He has a younger brother named Zachary. He is married to television personality Jeanette De Patta. They married in September 2017 and their wedding was featured on her television series "Jeanette" and on Bravo. They live in Los Angeles, California. In 2020, Karl won the Viewers Choice Award for Best TV Actor in a Drama at the New York Television Festival, for his work on QUIZShow. He is of part Russian descent and bears a passing resemblance to Leonid Brezhnev. Karl is an accomplished public speaker and has given speeches all over the world. In 2014, he was a guest speaker at the China-United States forum in Shanghai. He also spoke at the United Nations for World Water Day in 2015. In 2018, he was a keynote speaker at the Technology Entrepreneurs convention in Bengaluru, India. He has also been featured as a speaker at Yale University, where he was a guest student during the university's 2019 Christmas vacation. He has volunteered at the Humane Society of Los Angeles and is an outspoken animal rights activist. He is a Republican. Karl is a dual citizen of both the United States and Australia, having been born there. In 2009, he moved to Australia with his family in order to study acting. He attended the Australian American Academy and became a naturalised Australian in 2012. He currently resides in Los Angeles, California. Karl is a former smoker, having smoked between twelve and twenty cigarettes a day for over a decade. He quit in 2016 and is an active public advocate for anti-smoking campaigns. He is a supporter of the V Foundation for Cancer Research. Andy Karl had his first leading role on the ABC Family series The Secret Life of the American Teenager and later had guest appearances on shows such as Grey's Anatomy, Chuck, CSI: NY, Private Practice, and more. He also had a recurring role on the series The OC. In 2015, Karl had a leading role on the TBS comedy series ATL as Thaddeus Wildman. The series was renewed for a second season but after disappointing ratings, the series was cancelled after only ten episodes. In 2016, Andy Karl starred in the lead role of Fyodor Dostoevsky in the independent feature film Dostoevsky's Revenge. That same year, he had a starring role in the Showtime series The Last Shubert. The series was canceled after only one season. In 2017, Karl co-starred in the film The Nice Guys as Jackson thickening. In 2018, he starred in the comedy-drama mini-series For Life as Chad. That same year, he had a minor role in the science fiction film Annihilation as Security Officer. In 2019, he starred in the TNT limited series Klaus as Ludwig Keller. The following year, he starred in the sci-fi horror film Free Guy as Jerry. He is married to Jeanette De Patta, and their wedding was featured on her television series Jeanette. He won the Viewers Choice Award for Best TV Actor in a Drama at the New York Television Festival, for his work on QUIZShow. He is of part Russian descent and bears a passing resemblance to Leonid Brezhnev. Andy Karl was raised in Louisville, Kentucky and is of two-thirds Italian and one-third French ancestry. The Secretary of State for Migration is responsible for UK immigration policy and manages the UK's international migration program. The post was created in 2018 and is one of the first creation of new posts in the current Conservative government's ministry. The post was created following the EU-Turkey deal, which saw the UK take on the responsibility of migration management for countries that EU members Turkey. The post has been held by David Pickford since the creation of the post in February 2018. Pickford was also given additional responsibilities as Minister for the National Health Service and Public Health in the June 2018 reorganisation of the Department for Health and Social Care. The responsibilities for health and social care were separated into the new posts of Secretary of State for Health and Social Care and Minister for the National Health Service and Global Health in November 2018. Pickford has been critical of the government's Migration Skills and experience strategy, and raised concerns about potential labour shortages in areas such as engineering and healthcare due to low migration levels. The post of Secretary of State for Migration is one of the most high-profile and influential junior ministerial posts in the Conservative government. The post has significant influence over the UK's migration policy and is a key position in the government's domestic policy agenda. The position has also become a springboard to prominent Conservative leadership roles such as that of Shadow Foreign Secretary, and Chief Whip. David Pickford is the current holder of the position.
