Salesbury is a city in northeastern Louisiana United States and part of the Lafayette metropolitan area. The city is located in St. Landry Parish and is approximately 20 miles southeast of the city of Lafayette and 35 miles north of New Orleans. The official city name is a hybrid of the first two letters of each of the city's three main cross streets:Sales, Louisiana, Bossier and St. Bernard. Salesbury has a population of approximately 11,000 people. It is renowned for its football team, Salesbury football, which has won five state championships and produced notable players such as Ronnie Brown, Barry Sanders, and Charles Woodson. Salesbury was founded in 1904 along the rail line of the New York, Texas and Mexico Railway and named after WilliamSales, a Central Office manager for the railway. Salesbury is home to Salesbury University, a small liberal arts university founded in 1904 that is affiliated with the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). Being located in northeastern Louisiana, Salesbury is a bedroom community for business, medical and technical operations associated with Louisiana State University and the Health Sciences Center and popular with commuters who work in the New Orleans metropolitan area, as well as Lake Charles and Baton Rouge. The area is also known for its restaurants, many of which are independently owned, including several branches of Shops atfit Foods, the first ShopKo store in Louisiana. Salesbury is also home to the annual Three Notch’d Sportsman's weekend, which includes fishing, wildlife watching and a boat parade. Salesbury is a small but vibrant city that has grown significantly in recent years, experiencing a boom in popularity following the success of Salesbury football. Salesbury has since expanded its employment base and developed other industries, including hosting national auditions for The Next Star and The Jamie Foxx Show.

Ephippiger terrestris, also known as the great American chigger, is a blood-sucking parasite that lives on grass and leaf litter in temperate regions around the world. It is one of the most prevalent and successful mammals in the world, and females can grow to a length of approximately 5mm. They live on the skin of warm-blooded animals, and can often be found on humans and pets. They are most active at temperatures of 15-30 degrees Celsius, and are thought to transmit disease such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, tularemia, and relapsing fever. Ephippiger terrestris, also known as the great American chigger, is a blood-sucking parasite that lives on grass and leaf litter in temperate regions around the world. It is one of the most prevalent and successful mammals in the world, and females can grow to a length of approximately 5mm. They live on the skin of warm-blooded animals, and can often be found on humans and pets. They are most active at temperatures of 15-30 degrees Celsius, and are thought to transmit disease such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, tularemia, and relapsing fever. Despite their name, chiggers cannot fly and are not related to True Flies. They do, however, have well developed sense organs capable of sensing movement. They spend most of their time concealed in protective cups on the skin of their host, but rapidly attack any nearby surface such as grass, leaves, or clothing.

Pierre-Paul Margane de Lavaltrie (July 24, 1752 – December 31, 1834) was a Canadian Catholic priest and a notary public. De Lavaltrie was born in Montreal, Province of Quebec, to a French father and a mother of Scottish and Irish descent. He studied in Montreal and became a priest in 1780. He was appointed a notary in 1784 and became a bishop in 1814. De Lavaltrie Street in Montreal is named after him. De Lavaltrie was a representative for the third estate of Lower Canada to the Legislative Assembly of Lower Canada from 1791 to 1805. He was a member of the democratic-philosophical club and corresponded with François Bigot, Pierre Corail and Jean-Charles Pierrard. In 1807, De Lavaltrie was named a bishop by King Louis XVI of France. In 1814, he was named a peer member of the Parliament of Upper Canada. During the War of 1812, De Lavaltrie, along with Alexis de Redin, Joseph Brune and Jean-Jacques Boissin, was part of a negotiation party that went to Burlington Heights to negotiate with General Isaac Brock, commander of the British troops in Upper Canada. De Lavaltrie negotiated on behalf of the Canadian Catholics, who were part of the British Empire, and their roles in the militia. De Lavaltrie died in Montreal in 1834.

Irma Schoennauer Cole (February 14, 1901 – July 29, 1983) was an Austrian-born American actress of film, stage, and television, who became a U.S. citizen and was credited as "Ann Schoennauer" to cash in on the fame of TV's The Abbott and Costello Show. She was born in Vienna and had small roles in movies such as The Midnight Express (1978) and Once Upon a Time in America (1984). In 1955, she and her husband, actor Leonard Mudie, appeared together in a stage production of Death of a Salesman. When they divorced, she retained the use of their property and hired an agent to maintain her career. She is perhaps best known for her role as Aggie in the TV series The Jacksons: Next Generations She was born Irma Schoennauer on February 14, 1901, in Vienna, Austria, and arrived in the United States at the age of 17 in 1925. She married her first husband, actor Leonard Mudie, in 1938. They appeared in a stage production of Death of a Salesman in 1955. The couple later divorced. After arriving in the U.S., she worked in film, stage, and television. In 1978, she had a minor role in the movie The Midnight Express. Four years later, she appeared in the TV series The Facts of Life as a guest star. She also had a role in the 1984 movie Once Upon a Time in America. In 1985, she won an Emmy Award for her work on the TV show The Facts of Life.

Dun Ringill (Gaelic: An Drochaid na Croise), in County Kerry, Ireland is a pre-Roman fortified village and national scenic area. The village is located near the Ring of Kerry, about halfway between Killorglin and Brandon on the cliffs overlooking Caha Mountains. The name Dun Ringill translates as the 'ring fort'. Ring of Kerry is also the name of a major tourist route in the area. The village has a heritage centre with archaeology, ancient and modern art exhibits. Dun Ringill has a self-guided walking tour which takes in the sites of the village and the surrounding landscape. Dun Ringill is on the traditional boundary of Fir Tuatha andmarkdown of East Kerry. The village was the site of a monastic settlement in the 12th century, and later a pilgrimage centre. The ringfort is at a great example of a classic monastic site with a graveyard, structures for religious worship, an infirmary, a school and other domestic buildings. The village is protected within a national scenic area. The graveyard contains some notable interments, including Aodh Buidhe O'Brolchain (O'Briene of the speckled hair), fl. 16th century, who was an Irish scribe and scholar who worked in Rome. Another burial site contains 14 babies who died in the 17th century, probably of Typhus, who were buried on the spot out of concern that they would defile the sanctity of the church if interred in the churchyard.

Municipalities are first level administrative divisions in Mexico. There are 32 municipalities in the state of Chiapas. The first municipality is Tuxtla Gutiérrez, the capital of the state, followed by San Cristobal de las Casas. The largest municipality by population is Altamirano with 21,457 inhabitants. The smallest is Huimarkanan with 930 inhabitants. The largest by area is San Juan Chamula with 82.37 km2. The smallest is Huimanal with 0.32 km2. The municipality that borders with Guatemala is Suchiate, in the east, the Yucatan peninsula is the sea in the west, the state of Mexico is to the north and the state of Guerrero to the south. The municipalities of Chiapas include two indigenous languages: Nahuatl and Ch'ol, these are the most important languages in the state. The most populated municipalities are 90% indigenous, and have the highest representation of Mayan languages, this is because the ancient Maya occupied the lands for thousands of years before the colonization of the Americas. Chiapas is one of the states that make up Mexico with the most geographical space. It is located in the center-south of the country and borders with the following states: Morelos, Tabasco, Veracruz, Guerrero, Oaxaca, and Guatemala. A new map of Chiapas was published in March 2023 with 32 municipalities, the printed material received negative reviews for changing San Andrés Ch Harm unimplemented the name to "San Andrés Chriqueremos".

Antoine Wehenkel (born 1947) is a French theoretical physicist best known for his work on anomalies and anomallies in particle physics. Wehenkel received his PhD from the École Normale Supérieure in 1976 under the direction of Pierre Ramond with a thesis on Paramagnetic particles and the magnetic interaction. Since 2011 he is professor of theoretical high energy physics at the University of Geneva. Wehenkel has worked on the effects of parity violation, explaining the Magnetic moment of the electron, nuclear anomolies and the Weak angle, electric dipole moment of the electron. He was one of the founders of the field of effective field theory, where he formulated the concept of effective field theory. New Mexico United is a club-centric ward-based political party in the state of New Mexico, United States. Founded in 2017, the party primarily runs candidates for offices at the municipal and state levels, with the ultimate goal of creating a United States of New Mexico with electoral power at the federal level. The party officially started with the selection of John Fraley as its chairman at the July 2017 Albuquerque Signal Party. The party organized its first election in November 2018, when New Mexico voters will select members to the New Mexico Legislative committee, and nominate a candidate to run for the United States Senate. The party won all of its seats in the state legislature in the election, as well as its first-ever congressional seat with Xochitl Torres Small, who won a special election in 2018. In the 2020 state election, the party won a majority of county committee seats, as well as the governor and lieutenant governor offices, further strengthening its position in New Mexico politics. The party has local subgroups called "d heedons" which focus on particular regions or issues, such as education, local government, or health care. The party considers itself a democratic socialist, and advocates for single-payer health care, a living wage, and social ownership of businesses. The party has been vocally critical of sitting Republican Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham, calling her a "business-backed politician with a résumé of millionaire cheerleader[s]" who has "betrayed" the state by signing "job-killing" legislation such as the New Mexico Legislative targeting of the Santa Fe Wine Lands. The party frequently protests against laws it deems regressive, such as a state ban on religious housing deeds, or against legislation it sees as supportive of the LGBTQ community, such as a bill to outlaw conversion therapy. The party supports abolishing the New Mexico Personal Income Tax and replacing it with a 2% state sales tax. In the 2022 legislative elections, the party nominated a full slate of candidates for the first time, and doubled its vote share, winning 13 of the 21 seats in the state legislature. The party has supported Bernalillo County, home to the state capital, Albuquerque, as its core geographic region. New Mexico United is the most prominent club-based political party in the United States. Other notable club-based parties include the Washington Conservative Clubs and the Colorado Democraticony Caucus. New Mexico has only had Democratic governors since 1953. Since 1990, New Mexico has voted for the Republican presidential candidate only three times: four years after the establishment of the party, George H.W. Bush, with 46.8% of the vote in 1992; the two terms of George W. Bush, with 48.5% of the vote in 2004 and 52.6% of the vote in 2008; and Donald J. Trump in 2016 with 47.9% of the vote. The party currently holds both houses of the New Mexico State Legislature, and the office of governor. The party's co-founder and chairman, John Fraley, ran for governor of New Mexico in 2018 as a write-in candidate and received 1.3% of the vote, the highest any candidate from a club-based party has ever achieved in the state. In the 2022 legislative elections, the New Mexico United club won a majority of seats in the New Mexico House of Representatives for the first time, receiving 51.5% of the vote and 61 of the 90 seats. The United club also won a majority of seats in the New Mexico Senate for the first time in 2022, receiving 39 of the 51 seats. The current chair of the New Mexico United club is Marty Irby. The party's national chair is Bryan D. Rick, a professor at Metropolitan State University of Denver, who ran for Governor of New Mexico in 2022. In the 2022 state election, the party achieved the biggest increase in votes since it was founded, with a 15.3% increase from the previous election. The party is managed by a five-member steering committee, chaired by Brian Sanderoff. The rest of the committee is composed of Bryan Rick, Tara Mitchell, Mark Staples, and Marty Irby. New Mexico United club-members, also known as "d heedons," are primarily volunteers that organize local activism and canvassing for the party. The New Mexico United club is officially affiliated with the national Democratic Party, although the party is not affiliated with any national organizations. The New Mexico United club has several subgroups, such as "d heedons" for education, local government, and health care. New Mexico United was founded in 2017 by John Fraley. Francesco Ardizzone (born Francesco Alunno; 15 November 1921 – 14 November 1942) was an Italian resistance fighter and fighter pilot of the Italian Air Force (Alpini), who was posthumously awarded the Gold Medal of Military Valor. Ardizzone was born in Pinerolo, Italy and was passionate about sports from a young age. He worked in his family's wool business and was editor-in-chief of his local newspaper Nuovo Pinerolo. In 1940, Ardizzone joined the 29th Alpini Regiment in Chiavenna as an aujaculated lieutenant. In 1942, he took part in the fighting near St. Nazaire. On November 14, Ardizzone, along with his pilot Michele Mancuso, was shot down and killed in action. {#Sec1} Born in Pinerolo, Ardizzone was passionate about sports from a young age. It is awarded in the name of all Italy to non-Italian military personnel who fought in Italy's armed forces during World War II who, while serving under foreign military occupation, contributed to the organization of the Italian resistance movement or helped Italians oppressed by the occupation forces. The award includes a Gold Medal of Military Valor and a silver medal for military valour and a Bronze Medal of Civil Valor. {#Sec7} The Francesco Ardizzone Award, established in 1955, is the highest Italian military decoration awarded to non-Italian military personnel who fought in Italy's armed forces during World War II. It is sent by the President of Italy on request of the Ministry of Defense. Recipients are posted on the walls of the Chapel of the Major of the Alpini at Chiavenna, where his name is kept in a golden shrine.

Heinrich Richter (20 August 1811 – 23 March 1893) was a German astronomer, optician, and inventor. He joined Carl Friedrich Gauss's observatory in 1832 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1839. In 1848 he became professor of astronomy and director of the observatory at the University of Berlin. Richter made significant contributions to the field of metrology, developing the centimeter scale and the metre scale. He also made fundamental contributions to the measurement of optical intensities and to the theory of propagation of light in a medium. He was one of the first to formulate the Cauchy principle of finite differences, which is important in the theory of differential equations. Richter served as president of the Prussian Academy of Sciences (1849–1862) and as president of the German Mathematical Society (1869–1870). He was the recipient of the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1853 and of the Grand Prix of the French Academy of Sciences in 1858. The lunar crater Richter and the crater Richter on the Moon are named after him. The lunar crater Richter Y was also named after him, but this crater has since been renamed. Richter married twice, first to Klara Margarete Siebold and from this marriage had one daughter, and then to Minna Kötz. He died in Berlin and was buried at the New Cemetery in Berlin. In 1935, his remains were moved to the Friedrichstadt cemetery. Among his sons was the mathematician Heinrich Richter (1838–1871). His daughter was the educator and writer Auguste Richter (1843–1899). His grandson was the architect Hans Richter (1888–1976).

An air-start system is a launch system that uses an air compressor to start an engine via an air ram. This is in contrast to other launch systems that use a liquid fuel rocket motor that requires a liquid fuel tank, plumbing, and typically a stored energychemical propellant to get the engine started. The air-start system does not use fuel once the engine is running so the only equipment needed is the air compressor and the piping to connect the air compressor to the engine. This simplicity makes the air-start system useful for small launch vehicles where carrying liquid fuel tanks and the plumbing to connect them to an rocket is challenging. It is also more flexible because if only a subset of the launch vehicle uses the air-start system then it is possible to make the plumbing for the other systems detachable so the vehicle can use the air-start system to launch out of restrictive areas or ondemand if an operator wants to minimize the launch cost. Currently the Perseus launch vehicle and Cygnus cargo spacecraft use an air-start system to get their engine started. A larger air-start system used on the Antares launch vehicle allows two separate engines to be started simultaneously. In some situations starting an engine using an air-start system will be the only option. This can be the case if the engine was designed to be started using a liquid fuel but that required plumbing was not included in the design of the vehicle. An example of this is the Space Shuttle main engine which was designed to be started using a mixture of liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen but the plumbing to feed those fluids to the engine was not included in the Space Shuttle design so an air-start system had to be used. Because of the simplicity of the air-start system and the ability to get engines started in challenging locations this system has been used on vehicles in a wide variety of space technology application. This includes launch vehicles, aircraft, satellites, and even hot air balloons. Currently the most challenging application of the air-start system is getting large heavy engines started in Earth orbit. The most common use of the air-start system in this setting is to start the large Liquid Oxygen tank in the first stage of a two stage launch vehicle. These large oxygen tanks are typically over 100 tons and are often the largest and heaviest objects launched into space from the Earth's surface. There are some ongoing work doing on groundstart versions of the large liquid oxygen tank to make these launches easier but even these workable have a maximum weight limit of about 150 tons so they cannot be used to launch very large or very heavy satellites. The second most common application of the air-start system is in aircraft. Most jet aircraft use a small air-start auxiliary engine that is used for starting the main jet engine or to provide electrical power during flight. These auxiliary engines typically only weigh a few hundred pounds so they are a small portion of the weight of the full aircraft. The vast majority of air-start engine applications are smaller than what is needed for launching a launch vehicle. This includes hot air balloons, passenger airplanes, ground support equipment for aircraft, and industrial equipment. An example of an industrial application is an air-start diesel generator that can start a diesel engine under emergency conditions where there is no other source of power (such as after a plant explosion which prevents use of other power sources). Another interesting application of the air-start system is for starting other vehicles. A motorcycle can use the air-start system to start if out of gas or if the motorcycle gets hit and can not start normally. The air-start system can also start cars that have run out of gas. The air-start system works by sending very high pressure air through a length of rubber or plastic tubing. This air-started engine will not run at high speed but it will be able to start the vehicle because of the momentum of the air sent to the engine. There are some disadvantages to the air-start system. It takes a few minutes for the engine to start when air is initially sent to the engine so if the vehicle being started is in an emergency situation it will be unable to help until the engine has started. An air-start engine that is used in an aircraft will typically require a longer time to start than a liquid fueled engine because starting an engine using air requires more oxygen than starting an engine using a liquid fuel. However, this length of time is often shorter than other liquid fuel based launch vehicle engines so this is not generally seen as a problem. Overall the air-start system has many applications and is an excellent way to start an engine that does not require liquid fuel. This simplicity allows the system to be used on a wide range of vehicles and in a variety of challenging environments where starting an engine

J.B. Nethercutt (born Jerome Bernard Nethercutt; July 24, 1917 – January 14, 1994) was an American historian and professor emeritus at the University of California, Santa Barbara. He specialized in the military history of China, American military history and World War II. In the 1960s and 1970s, Nethercutt advised the U.S. government on historical research, and his expertise was used in the production of several films about the war. He was a consultant on the 1960 film The Black Swan, which was based on his doctoral thesis, and was an associate producer on the 1970 film Helldorado, for which he also provided the source material. He taught at the University of California, Santa Barbara, from 1959 until his retirement in 1980. Nethercutt was born in San Francisco, and his family later moved to Berkeley, where he graduated from Berkeley High School. He received a bachelor's degree in history from the University of California, Berkeley in 1937 and a PhD from Harvard University in 1941. He joined the United States Army in 1942 and was assigned to the Pacific theater of World War II, where he participated in combat operations in the Pacific campaign against the Japanese. After the war, he returned to the University of California, Santa Barbara, where he taught and served as a professor emeritus until his retirement. He continued to lecture at UC Santa Barbara until his death at the age of 77 in 1994.

Brigitte Meijns (born 3 June 1962) is a retired Dutch sprinter, who specialized in the 400 and 800 metres. Meijns was born in Ridderkerk and became famous after winning two bronze medals at the 1983 World Championships in Athletics, where she also reached personal bests of 48.84 minutes for the 400 metres and 1:55.18 for the 800 metres. The following year she won the 400 metres at the 1984 European Athletics Indoor Championships. This was followed by the 800 metres title at the 1985 World Indoor Games and a gold medal at the 1985 Mediterranean Games. After ending her track career she remained active in the sport as a coach. She has a son with her former husband Erik van den Hoek and lives in Sissach, Switzerland. YPT 22 Upper body strength. Professional athletic career. Olympic medalist. World Championships medalist. Al-Nizamiyya of Baghdad was a community of Sufi monks, and later a mosque, located in Baghdad, Iraq. It was founded by Al-Nizami, an Arab Governor of Baghdad, in the 10th century. In the 11th century it was the site of a major dispute between the Sunni and Shia Muslims, with Ali ibn Mohammed al-Nizami defending Shia beliefs against a Sunni challenge. The Al-Nizamiyya community survived the Mongol invasion of Baghdad in the 13th century, but was eventually converted into a public school by the Ottoman governor, and was closed down by the Ottoman authorities in the 19th century. It was then used as a club and also as the headquarters for the Department of Antiquities in Iraq. After the fall of Saddam Hussein, the building was handed back to the community, and is now being restored. Premier League Productions is the production company of the English Premier League. The company was founded in 1992 as Middlemarch Entertainment, renamed Silver Supplements Ltd in 1996 before being renamed Alliance Entertainment in 2002 and finally Premier League Productions in 2013. Riverhead is a market town and civil parish in the East Kent district of Kent, England. It is located nine miles (14 km) south-east of London via the A2 road and close to the coast, with a large creek at the north of the parish separating it from the market town of Whitstable. Riverhead was recorded in the Domesday Book, with its main industry being fishing. It has a long sandy beach that is popular with tourists, and a 19th-century theatre known as the Royal Hotel. In the 2011 census, Riverhead had a population of 9,088. Riverhead railway station is on the Folkestone to Hythe line and is served by both Kent Coast Line and Littlehampton line trains, which run between London Victoria and Littlehampton. Riverhead is well known for its traditional thatched cottages, much like those seen in the TV series _Ted Lonson_, _Lancaster Sound_ and many other British TV programmes and films. The origins of Riverhead are lost in antiquity, with finds dating back to the late Stone Age. The toponym 'Riverhead' first appears in the 10th century as two separate place names: Richæwarda and Hydestæmon. In about 1050 it was recorded as Rewardæhod or Regnumidedune in the Domesday Book. The 13th century archaeological site of Rose Hill, to the south of the parish, is an Iron Age fort and later a medieval castle. It is a scheduled ancient monument.

Etelvina Lopes de Almeida (born September 13, 1947) is a Brazilian politician, businesswoman and doctor in the field of Psychiatry. She has spent her political career representing São Paulo, having served as member of the Legislative Assembly of São Paulo from 2003 to 2019. She is a member of the Social Liberal Party (PSL), and was elected President of the party in July 2019. Early life and education Etelvina Lopes de Almeida was born in São Paulo, the daughter of Francisco de Assis Lopes de Almeida and Maria Eugênia da Rocha. She has four siblings. Almeida completed medical studies at the University of São Paulo. She obtained a master's degree in Psychiatry from the University of Oxford. Political career Almeida was elected to the Legislative Assembly of São Paulo in 1999, serving from 1999 to 2003. She was elected state secretary of education in the second administration of Geraldo Alckmin, and was a member of the Social Democratic Party (PSD) in the National Legislature from 2003 to 2011. Almeida was elected to the Federal Chamber of Deputies in the 2010 election, serving from 2011 to 2013. She was reelected in 2014, and became national president of the PSD in June 2015. She served on the Security and Communication committees of the Chamber. In 2018 Almeida was elected to the Legislative Assembly of São Paulo, and was chosen to preside the Social Liberal Party in the state. She led the party's list of candidates for the presidential election of 2019, and was elected with 8.5% of the vote, becoming president of the party. Almeida is a supporter of LGBT rights, and has stated that "marriage is not an instrument of child abuse". She has described herself as "a free-spirited lesbian, feminist and integrative Catholic". She has described her political philosophy as "humanist liberalism", and has characterized her economic policy as "fiscal conservatism and social liberalism". She has also been described as a "staunch opponent of the impeachment process". Almeida is a supporter of education, and has advocated for "the defense of public education in Brazil and the fight against educational appropriation by the market". She is in favor of legalizing abortion, describing the crime as "an aggravated homicide that violates the right to life and health, as well as the right to personal integrity". She has also expressed concern about "the consequences of the increase in the adoption rate, especially among the poor". Personal life Almeida is in a civil union with Maria Isabel Campelo Vellozo. They have two children. She resides in the São Paulo neighborhood of Vila Madalena. Terisa Griffin (born August 28, 1969) is an American actress. She is known for her role as Jeri Hogarth on the television series The Mary Tyler Moore Show (1977-1977), for which she received a Humanitas Award and a Primetime Emmy Award nomination. OpenIVisitions.com Terisa Griffin in The Mary Tyler Moore Show (1977-1977) From The Mary Tyler Moore Show (1977-1977) Wiki Jeri Hogarth, played by Terisa Griffin, is a character on the television show The Mary Tyler Moore Show (1977-1977). Griffin received a Humanitas Award and a Primetime Emmy Award for her performance.[1] Personality Jeri is often brash, straightforward, and blunt. She has little patience for people who are weak or easily swayed, and strongly advocates for her own beliefs. However, she cares deeply about her friends and family, and will go to great lengths to protect them. She is a groundbreaker, and not afraid to speak her mind. In her earlier years, she was a heroin addict and prostitute. She gained employment at WJM-TV in Minneapolis, Minnesota as a receptionist, and met Roger Malina (played by Ed Asner), the manager. Their relationship was that of a father and daughter, and upon Roger's encouragement, she became sober and gave up prostitution. She took his last name.[2] She worked in the station's control room and had an on-screen partnership with Mary Richards (anchored by Ted Hartley). As the series progressed, she moved away from her father figure role as a friend and co-worker to taking on the role of Mary's rival. As Mary and Roger got married, Jeri was a bridesmaid. She became more of a self-centered, egotistical person as the show progressed. However, she became more selfless later on during her career. She was born on August 28, 1969, which is also the date the series premiered.[3] She is Jewish, and her religious beliefs play a large part in several storylines on the show. Career While she had been an actress, her résumé was too short to get many acting jobs. After settling down and getting clean from her drug addiction, she auditioned for the role of Jeri on The Mary Tyler Moore Show. When the casting director passed her name on to producers, she received a call saying that they wanted to meet her for the part. The producers thought she was too plain, and was in fact one of the only people who didn't get the role. She was told to come back the next day for a callback. After she convinced the producers that she had the right personality to play the part, they gave her the role. She received a Humanitas Award for 1978 for her work on the show. Trivia She originally auditioned for the role of Pam Morgendorffer, but didn't get the part. She had previously auditioned for the role of Pam Morgendorffer on The Mary Tyler Moore Show, but didn't get the part. Her birthdate, August 28th, is the same as the date that the show premiered, September 26, 1970.

Ulfert Wilke (born 7 December 1965) is a German sport director and former football (soccer) player. As a player, he represented West Germany from 1983 to 1998, and he won the World Cup in 1984 and the European Championships in 1992 and 1996. Since 1999, he has worked as a sport director for various football clubs, including Borussia Dortmund and Bayer Leverkusen. He is one of the most successful German players in the club game and was named German Footballer of the Year in 1996. Wilke was born in Düsseldorf, and he started his career with local club, TSV Armsfeld. He made his debut for the West German national team in 1983 and went on to win 80 international caps and score nine goals. He represented his country at the 1984 Summer Olympics and the 1986 World Cup, and he won the UEFA European Championship in 1992 and 1996. Wilke began working as a sport director after his retirement from professional football. He started out with Borussia Dortmund, and in 2013 he was named director of sport for the entire club. In this position, he works with the club's youth team and the first team on the administrative side of the club. He was named director of the club's board of directors in 2016 and took over the position of general manager in 2017. Wilke has three sons. He is married and has been a Lutheran since 1989.

Fogo, Newfoundland and Labrador is a community on the island of Newfoundland. It is located to the west of Bay of Islands, to the east of Twillingate and to the south of Iceland Bay. Fogo is famous for its large, active volcanic complex, L'Ansonge Ventar Cataldo, which last erupted in 2018. Fogo's rockcastle, named Buccaneer's Haven, is one of the largest in the world. Fogo has a rich fishing and seafaring history, and in 2015 was named a Heritage Town. The most well-known son of Fogo is singer Robbie Robertson, who was born and raised in the community. The area was hit hard by the 2018 oil spills from the offshore platform fire and the devastating tornado on June 29, 2019. As of 2023, the community has begun to rebuild, with help from the federal and provincial governments as well as local fundraising efforts. Advertisement: Fogo, Newfoundland and Labrador is a great place to visit in the summer. The heat is bearable and the scenery is absolutely stunning. The main industry is fishing, with millions of dollars of fish being hauled in each year. The famous Buccaneer's Haven rockcastle is also located in Fogo and is worth a visit. It is huge and the view from the top is amazing. I recommend spending a night in Fogo, if you can get there during the summer - the food at the Oak Tree Pub is absolutely amazing!

Chiao Chiao (Chinese: tertiary nest swift) is a small passerine bird in the twite family, named for its unusual habit of building its nest in other birds' nests. Chiao Chiaos are native to East Asia, ranging from eastern China to far northern Japan. They are obligate nest parasites, with the female laying its eggs in the nests of host birds, such as storks, whose embryos will later be raised by the Chiao Chiao chick after the host parents have abandoned the nest. The Chiao Chiao is the only member of its family with a worldwide distribution. In China, its range is largely restricted to the Yangtze River valley. Because of intense trapping for the wild bird market, the Chinese population has drastically declined, with a 2018 survey noting just 2,501 individuals. In 2013, the IUCN classified the Chiao Chiao as "vulnerable", but it was removed from the Red List the following year after a global petition organised by the International Crane Foundation. A 2018 survey noted a small but stable population, and the species was re-instated on the IUCN Red List the following year. The Chinese name for Chiao Chiao is "" (""). Description The Chiao Chiao is about 12.5 cm long and has a pinkish brown back and wings and grey underparts. Unlike many birds, the Chiao Chiao has distinct dark and light stripes on its head. Chiao Chiaos primarily eat insects and seeds. They have also been known to take small vertebrates, such as baby mice and lizards, as well as dragonfly nymphs. The nest of the Chiao Chiao is flat and rudimentary, usually made of vegetation and feathers taken from the host bird, and is attached to a tree or high up in a bush. The eggs are blotched with brown or green, and number three or four, sometimes five, and are incubated by both sexes. The host bird usually raises the Chiao Chiao chick after its eggs are laid, but not until the host parents have abandoned the nest. The hosts are sometimes aware of the Chiao Chiao egg in the nest but unable to detect its hatching. The Chiao Chiao is the only member of its family with a worldwide distribution. Seismometers are devices that record ground motion caused by earthquakes. Seismometers are essential tools in earthquake science and detection, as well as in monitoring volcanic activity and detecting subterraneal explosions. Although seismometers are very sensitive, they are not capable of determining the location of an earthquake. This information can be obtained by using a GPS receiver and directions from satellites. Seismometers are used in a complex called a seismic network that consists of many seismometers spread across a region. As an earthquake occurs more seismometers are able to detect the earthquake providing more data to create a more accurate image of the earthquake's area and strength. Seismometers are made up of a series of coupled springs and accelerometers. The springs are used to set the resonant frequency of the device while the accelerometers measure movement. The accelerometers are used to detect ground motion caused by earthquakes. As the accelerometers detect ground motion a signal is sent to a person observing the device or, in some cases, the signal is stored in a list for processing later. Seismometers must be coupled to a surface in order to work. They work well in calm weather as surface winds can propel the seismometer out of position. Seismometers are made by a number of companies. Else Holmelund Minarik (March 20, 1901 – December 9, 1983) was a Norwegian-American children's book author best known for her 47 books about a fictional character, Annabelle Lane. Annabelle Lane is a spunky young lady who often interacts with anthropomorphic animals. The books were generally intended for young children and were popular during the 1930s through the 1960s. Many of Minarik's books were adapted to animated films, a few were made into television series and one was made into a stage musical. Minarik was born in Norway and came to the United States as a child. She wrote children's books in the 1930s through the 1960s, getting her first book, The Bear Family, published in 1935. Several of her books were inspired by her own experiences as a child in Norway. Many of Minarik's books featured a fictional town called St. Paul's Acres. In some of the books, Annabelle Lane's Uncle Morgan lived in St. Paul's Acres. Morgan was inspired by Minarik's father, who in real life was an engineer with the railroad. One of Minarik's more famous books, The Gingerbread Man, was published in 1960 and featured a gingerbread man as the protagonist. The story takes place in a period when people still feared witches. Minarik's father died when she was 12 years old. The death had a profound influence on her, and many of her books dealt with death and loss.

DansGuardian is a free open-source Internet security suite written for the GNOME desktop. It is a popular option for securing home and small businesses networks against cyber-attacks. DansGuardian supports various protection methods including Anti-Virus, Anti-Spam, a firewall, a web proxy, URL blacklist, and a spam filter. The project's goals are to be user-friendly, minimal in resource consumption, and highly effective at securing home and small businesses networks. Functional-Level breakdown: - Anti-Virus: screens incoming email and files for malware. - Anti-Spam: prevents spam messages from being sent over the network. - Firewall: protects the computer from unauthorized access and intrusion. - Proxy: protects the computer from accessing content that is blocked by the Firewall or prevented by DansGuardian's filters. - URL Blacklist: prevents access to particular websites by blacklisting the websites' IP addresses. - Spam Filter: protects the computer from junk email, which places a heavy load on the SMTP server. DansGuardian uses a single daemon, so it can be run on single-user machines or large networks that require remote administration. DansGuardian works by scanning email and files using ClamAV, a highly effective antivirus engine. DansGuardian can also block explicit content by using the free online service YouTube Fairy. DansGuardian's stable upstream release (0.9.8.2) has no known critical security flaws. However, it is not being actively developed. New releases of DansGuardian are usually packaged with critical security fixes, but the project has not issued a new stable release in four years. DansGuardian is translated into many languages, and has a very active community of users, developers and contributors. DansGuardian runs on all major Unix-like systems, and also runs on Microsoft Windows through WINE. DansGuardian is Free and Open-Source software, and the entire code is available on Github. DansGuardian is being maintained by a small team who launched a Patreon page in June 2023. The Patreon page funds the maintenance and development of DansGuardian and is used to pay the project's contributors. DansGuardian is used in many classrooms around the world as part of the SANS Institute's Internet Security Program. DansGuardian has few dependencies and works well on older hardware. It is easily installed on Linux systems using standard package managers like YUM or APT. DansGuardian is highly customizable and supports user defined filters. It also has extensive logging capabilities. DansGuardian is used by many system integrators and service providers, such as Avast, Kaspersky Lab, Trend Micro, Symantec, Amazon, Google, Yahoo, Microsoft, and Twitter. DansGuardian is under constant development. The project's official website, Github page and forum have detailed announcements of new versions and major changes. DansGuardian has been downloaded millions of times and has a strong, worldwide, open source community. DansGuardian is considered to be one of the most secure and easy-to-use pieces of Internet security software for Windows and Linux systems. DansGuardian is used by people around the world for securing home and small business computer networks. DansGuardian secures home and small business computer networks by filtering out malicious URLs, spam, junk email, and malware. The Wengernalp Railway was a metre gauge railway in the Canton of Lucerne in Switzerland. It connected the village of Wengernalp with the rail network at Balsthal (Switzerland) and was in operation from 1894 to 1954. The railway was opened in 1894 and initially operated with steam locomotives. It was later expanded to metre gauge and, by 1911, included a branch to the resort of Lenk. In the later years of its operation, it was used predominantly for the transportation of construction materials for the building of the St. Gotthard Passtunnel. The Wengernalp Railway ceased operation in 1954. It was one of the last passenger railway lines in operation in Switzerland and was, along with the Bernina Railway, one of the last railways in operation in Switzerland with a narrow gauge of 1009 mm. Advantages The Wengernalp Railway had the following advantages over the standard gauge railways at the time it was built: it operated with metre gauge, thus reducing the costs of infrastructure and material transport the gradients on the Wengernalp Railway were much easier than on the standard gauge railways, facilitating the transport of construction materials over the line the extensive use of the St. Gotthard Pass (which at that time operated as a single track) necessitated the building of a much higher track than on the standard gauge railways the narrow gauge of 1009 mm was already in use on other railways, thus it was possible to more cost-effectively lay down the tracks Disadvantages The Wengernalp Railway had the following disadvantages over the standard gauge railways at the time it was built: the line was built in a remote area with few inhabitants, thus a steep decline in traffic was to be expected a further decline in traffic was caused by the entrance of the electrically powered Stroway Railway into operation in 1936, since that line went directly to the village of Wengernalp and did not require a change of train at Balsthal. Society today Despite the disadvantages, the Wengernalp Railway is still operated as a hiking trail. In 2010, a group of enthusiasts established the Wengernalp Railway Company (WVR) and, since May 2014, has been carrying out voluntary maintenance on the track, including clearing fallen trees from the track. In addition, the WVR operates a small museum at the station in Wengernalp, the museum exhibits are drawn from an old butcher's shop that used to stand next to the station. Gallery of old locomotives The following locomotives have been used on the Wengernalp Railway: 1894: ABeyer, only machine in the canton of Lucerne with a three-tire adhesion wheel 1901: DRG Class KMax, the first metre gauge locomotive in Switzerland 1904: Krauss Maffei, the first steam engine with a three-tire adhesion wheel 1907: Krauss Maffei, the first metre gauge steam engine with a three-tire adhesion wheel 1911: Krauss Maffei, the first metre gauge steam engine with a three-tire adhesion wheel 1921: Krauss Maffei, the first metre gauge steam engine with a six-axle adhesion wheel 1928: Krauss Maffei, the first metre gauge steam engine with a six-axle adhesion wheel 1932: Krauss Maffei, the first metre gauge electric locomotive in Switzerland 1936: Krauss Maffei, the first metre gauge electric locomotive with a three-phase induction motor 1950: Krauss Maffei, the first electric metre gauge locomotive in Switzerland 1954: Krauss Maffei, the last steam engine in Switzerland with a six-axle adhesion wheel Gallery of old carriages The following carriages have been used on the Wengernalp Railway: 1874: Bock, an exhibition carriage from the Swiss Industrial Museum in Winterthur 1898: Vernier, restaurant carriage 1903: Bartholdi, a restaurant carriage 1907: Von der Weiden, wedding carriage 1911: Römer, a wedding carriage Gallery of old road vehicles The following road vehicles have been used on the Wengernalp Railway: 1894: Ford Model T, first automobile on the Wengernalp Railway 1901: Jäger, the first ambulance on the Wengernalp Railway 1905: Kübelwagen, the first motorized civilian car on the Wengernalp Railway 1907: Steiner, first motorized commercial vehicle on the Wengernalp Railway Gallery of old station buildings The following station buildings have been used on the Wengernalp Railway: 1894

Adam Fetterman was an American inventor, test pilot and aerospace engineer. He participated in the development of some of the first successful aerial refueling tanks, invented the piccolo trumpet, and was the first person to fly a helicopter in Wyoming. Raised in California, Fetterman moved to Alaska in his early twenties and worked as a pilot for United States Air Mail service. He joined the military in 1940 and, after graduation from the Arizona Technical college, was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Forces. Fetterman flew a number of different aircraft during his military service, including the P-39 Airacobra, P-63 King Cobra, P-63 Black Widow, P-80 Twin Mustang and F-82 Twin Mustang. For his service, he was awarded the Air Medal and the Distinguished Flying Cross. After the war, Fetterman became a technical adviser for United States Air, studying flight testing of aircraft wings in order to improve the procedures. He invented the piccolo trumpet while living in Wyoming and performed with the California Philharmonic. Fetterman later worked for Bell Helicopter where he helped develop the prototype for the first successful aerial refueling tank. The tank, known as the "Ford Trimotor", was successfully tested in 1951.

Exile of Ovid refers to the event in which King Augustus of Rome ordered the poet Ovid to become an exile, following Ovid's composition of poems critical of Augustus. The exact date of exile is unknown, but it was most likely around 8th or 9th September AD 16, most likely due to the fact that on that day, Ovid addressed a poem to his exiled friend Gallus. The Warsaw Theatre Directorate is the headquarters of the Ministry of Culture and National Heritage of the Republic of Poland, located in the heart of the city, at Zwolińska and Muranowska streets. The building was constructed in 1905-1907 on the site of an earlier wooden theatre, built in 1794. The edifice was designed by Tullius Gronenberg and Jerzy Nowosielski, with contributions from Jan Czarnowski, Eugeniusz Engel, Stanisław Zamoyski and Henryk Reidel. The building hosted the Warsaw Dramatic Theatre from 1907 to 1940, and later the State Film School (from 1940 to 1945, the Theater of the Ministry of National Defense). In 1945, after the destruction caused by the Nazi occupation, the building housed the Main Library of Poland, as well as the Film School and the Repertoire Office of the State Radio and Television. In 1964, it was acquired by the Ministry of Culture, and since then it has been the home of the Warsaw Theatre Directorate. The current director of the Theatre Directorate is Daniel Olbrychski, a graduate of the Dramatic Arts Faculty of the University of Warsaw. The Theatre Directorate organizes performances by the National Theater, the State Opera and the State Ballet, and it is responsible for stage art in Poland. The building also hosts a cinema, a publishing house, a Polish Radio station, as well as the Polish national cemetery.

Andreas Jonsson is a Swedish composer and musician. He is known for having contributed the music to the adventure game Obduction by Fantasy Flight Games. His other credits include music for such shows as Tales from the Borderlands, The Sopranos, Westworld, Game of Thrones, and Lost. He is a member of the band The Agonist. Andreas Jonsson was born in Gothenburg. He studied at the Music Conservatory in Gothenburg under Magnus Lindberg and Ingvar Lidholm. His notable teachers included Björn Ulvaeus of the Swedish pop group ABBA. He has been a member of the band The Agonist since 2010. In 2016, Jonsson contributed the music for the adventure game Obduction, which was written and directed by Matthew Sturtevant. He won several awards for his work on the game, including a Worldwide Studios Award for best soundtrack, as well as nominated for a Games Critics Award for best soundtrack. Jonsson currently resides in Los Angeles. He is married to fellow Swedish musician and singer Lene Nyströmer. They have two children. Jonsson's work often has themes of isolation, exploration and otherworldliness. His style has been described as being inspired by his listening to doom metal, electronic music and other similar genres. He is a member of the band The Agonist along with his brother Jon, Svavels Vasen and Thomas Garmers. Jonsson's father was a cab driver. He is a fan of the band Tool.

The Gjemnessund Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge over the Great Belt in Denmark, connecting the island of Zealand with the North Jutland Island. The 16,5 km long bridge has two main spans of 8,9 km and 6,7 km and was inaugurated on 28 October 2012. It is the third bridge across the Great Belt since the first one was built between 1919 and 1920, and the second was built in 1970. The total cost of the bridge was about 350 million DKK. The Gjemnessund Bridge was designed by the British company Arup and constructed by Aarhus Langelandgaard, a subsidiary of DSME. The main cable-stayed system is made of steel, supported by dual top-lines. updates The Gjemnessund Bridge is the third bridge across the Great Belt since the first one was built between 1919 and 1920, and the second was built in 1970. ice layer The Gjemnessund Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge over the Great Belt in Denmark, connecting the island of Zealand with the North Jutland Island. Scott Perry (born Scott James Perry; August 7, 1949 – December 20, 2019) was an American politician and business person who was the 39th governor of Ohio from 1983 to 1994 and the chairman and CEO of Perry Homes, an American homebuilding company, from 1994 to 2019. He also served as the president of the National Association of Home Builders from 1995 to 1997. Perry was a Republican and his predecessor as governor, Edward Tippetts, was also a Republican. Born in Chillicothe, Ohio, Perry graduated from Chillicothe High School in 1967. He attended Kent State University, where he played on the basketball team and earned a degree in business administration in 1971. After college, Perry worked as a bank teller and operated a savings and loan. He later worked in sales for a plastics company before starting a lawn mower business. In 1976, Perry was elected to the Chillicothe City Council and two years later he won a seat in the Ohio House of Representatives, where he served from 1977 to 1983. In 1982, Perry won the Republican nomination for governor but lost to Tapperts in the general election. Perry served as lieutenant governor from 1983 to 1988. In 1988, Perry defeated Tapperts in the primary and then won the general election and became the 39th governor of Ohio. As governor, Perry advocated for reforms to business regulations and reduction of state spending. In 1993, he won re-election by defeating Congressman Dennis Kucinich, a candidate backed by a popular Democratic governor of neighboring Michigan, James Blanchard. In 1994, Perry became chairman and CEO of Perry Homes, a construction company in Perrysburg, Ohio. In 1999, he was named businessman of the year by the United States Conference of Mayors and in 2002, he founded the National Association of Home Builders' Building Futures Fund. Perry resigned as chairman and CEO of Perry Homes in 2004. Perry stepped down as governor in 1994 but remained active in local and state Republican politics. From 2001 to 2012, Perry was a member of the Board of Trustees of Kent State University. He was also a member of the Warren County Board of Commissioners and a member of the Economic Development Committee of the Businessman's Advisory Council of Akron. Perry died of heart failure on December 20, 2019, at the age of 73. County Route 41 (CR 41, CR 41a and CR 41b) is a major north-south highway in Onondaga County, New York, in the United States. It continues south as New York State Route 394 (NY 394) to the village of Onondaga, and continues as New York State Route 79 (NY 79) to the city of Syracuse. CR 41*s run concurrently with U.S. Route 11 (US 11) for about, following that route from the village of Lehman through the town of Skaneateles to the hamlet of Genoa. From there, CR 41*s head east along New York State Route 29 (NY 29) to the village of Bethany. The roadway was originally designated as an unsigned legislative route in the early 20th century. The southwestern extension, from the hamlet of Genoa to the village of Skaneateles, was originally designated as State Highway 49 in the 1920s. State Route 79 was extended north from Syracuse to the Massachusetts border as a re-alignment of CR 41 in the early 1930s. The routing was further extended north to Worcester, Massachusetts, as an extension of NY 35 in the late 1930s. The unsigned legislative route was designated as New York State Route 41 in the early 1940s. NY 41 was extended north from Massachusetts to the Canada–US border as a re-alignment of NY 35 in the early 1950s. A replacement for NY 41 was established as part of the surface route of NY 79, and CR 41*s were assigned to NY 79 between the village of Bethany and the city of Syracuse and the Skaneateles branch. The Genoa–Skaneateles segment was converted into an extended NY 29 in the early 1960s. The portion of the Skaneateles–Bethany segment between NY 394 and NY 29 was removed from the state highway system in 1965. CR 41*s have occasionally seen various routes over the years. The Skaneateles–Genoa segment was turned back to local control following a November 2008 referendum. In 2010, the state of New York placed a request with the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) for designation of the northernmost section of NY 79 from the Canada–US border south to the Pennsylvania border as a part of Interstate 86 (I-86). The section of the roadway within the state of New York has not been part of the Interstate Highway System; however, the New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) has been maintaining the highway as part of its maintenance of US 11 and NY 29. The section within the city of Syracuse is unsigned; however, the City of Syracuse maintains a separate county-maintained section of the highway within the city. The section within the town of Lehman is entirely urban in nature and not part of the state highway system. The section of CR 41 from Skaneateles to Genoa was removed from the state highway system in 1965, but the section between the village of Skaneateles and the Massachusetts border remained under state maintenance until the early 2000s. The section of NY 79 between the village of Bethany and the city of Syracuse was transferred to Onondaga County in the 2000s. However, CR 41 remains the principal highway through the town of Skaneateles as the result of a 1998 court ruling. There have been plans to improve the highway between the villages of Skaneateles and Bethany, such as by replacing the dangerous curve near the Lower Skaneateles Dam with a wider bridge, though the priority for funding has not been established. History CR 41*s were first assigned to two legislative routes in the early 1920s. The first was a segment extending from the hamlet of Genoa to Skaneateles. The second was a southwestern extension of CR 41 from Skaneateles to Bethany. The Genoa–Skaneateles segment was originally designated as State Highway 49 in the 1920s. The CR 41 designation was extended north from Skaneateles to Syracuse as part of an extension of NY 79 to Syracuse via Skaneateles in the early 1930s. The Genoa–Skaneateles segment was originally designated as NY 41 in the early 1940s. The Genoa–Skaneateles segment was turned back to local control following a November 2008 referendum. On April 26, 2010, the New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) officially requested that AASHTO add the portion of NY 79 from the Canada–US border south to the Pennsylvania state line as part of the Interstate Highway System. Keith A. Petty (born December 7, 1945) is an American business executive, serving as the CEO of Marvell Technology Group from 2010 until his retirement in 2021. He also served as the chairman of the board from 2012 until his retirement. He previously served as the CEO of Adaptec from 2000 until 2010. He attended San Jose State University. Petty was born in San Francisco, California. He is married to Louise B. Petty and has three children. After graduating from San Jose State University, Petty worked at Adaptec as a applications engineer before being promoted to senior director of marketing in 1996 and vice-president of marketing in 1997. He then served as the company's president and CEO from 2000 until 2010. In 2010, Petty became the CEO of Marvell Technology Group, a position he held until 2021. He also continues to serve as the chairman of the board since 2012. As of 2021, Petty is on the board of directors of Apple Inc., eBay Inc., Amazon.com, Inc., Yahoo! Inc., Micro-Star International, Inc., and Caterpillar Inc. He is also a member of the audit committee of eBay Inc. and a consultant for Patton whistle &Window. He is a member of the Board of Trustees of San Jose State University. Petty is known for his reputation for having a hands-on management style and his leadership in the industry. In 2005, he was included on Fortune magazine's list of the "100 Most Powerful People in Business." In 2015, he became a lifetime achievement award recipient from the PC Magazine Hall of Fame. His autobiography, "From the Boys' Club to the Ball Game" was published in 2008. Petty is of Irish and German descent. Petty lives in Scotts Valley, California. Petty is a Republican. Petty's wife is Louise B. Petty, who is also a professor and business executive. She is the co-founder and CEO of Aranzullo Scientific and co-founder and former CEO of InventivBio, a company specializing in intellectual property management. His son, Keith A. Petty, Jr. is the Chief Technology Officer of Marvell. His other son, Michael is the Chief Financial Officer of Marvell. Petty was ranked number 11 on the 2019 BusinessWeek list of the richest people in tech, with a net worth of $4.2 billion. In 2013, the 75th anniversary issue of Marvell Technology Group featured a faux-news article that was initially interpreted as satire, concerning an imagined war between the United States and China over the South China Sea. The war was hypothetically being waged by Marvell, who was characterized as the "World War III winner". Petty stated, "That was never our intention... when you're young and crazy, you say things". In October 2019, Petty's group was reported to have joined Apple in banning Google hardware executive Andy imel from the company after he agreed to be acquired by the company. Petty responded, "The reason he was banned is because he was planning to join Apple, and then publicly divulge trade secrets that we thought would be highly disadvantageous to us. That is a no-no". Petty's stepson Keith A. Petty, Jr. stated, "the idea that he would purposefully and intentionally give Apple trade secrets was far-fetched. It was a PR move by Apple to save face after a major security breach". In January 2020, Petty, commented on the novel COVID-19 pandemic, saying, "I hope we will overcome this challenging situation. We can do it because we have the best medical professionals in the world, extraordinary courage from millions of front-line medical workers, and the devotion of our customers who are continuously supporting our business through the difficult time. All of us need to follow the guidelines and be sensible to what is going on and be careful. But I'm confident that, together, we can overcome this crisis". On April 11, 2020, Petty announced his retirement from Marvell on March 31, 2021. Facet (geometry) is a concept in geometry that is the study of convex polyhedra. A facet of a convex polyhedron is a flat surface (defined by a group of atoms or molecules) that sticks out from the polyhedron like a facet of a piece of rock-cut architecture. In this analogy, the facet is the column (piece of rock) and the flat surface is the lintel (the thing sticking out). In this analogy, the vertices of the polyhedron are the columns, and the faces are the lintels. In the geometry of polyhedra, every vertex is surrounded by three facets, every face by two facets, and every edge by one facet. The facet concept was introduced by Bernard Riemann in 1854. Riemann's original definition involved cutting away all portions of the polyhedron behind the plane of the surface. A more recent equivalent definition, due to Alfred Kinsey, starts with a surface that is given a color, and colors all portions of the space behind the surface the same color. A non-convex polyhedron is a polyhedron that is not convex. A non-convex polyhedron may have flat faces that are not facets. For example, a book dropped on its back has a mostly flat face (the book back) that sticks out from the book, but the book back is not a facet, because the book back is concave. The study of facets in non-convex polyhedra has given rise to distinct fields, such as non-convex geometry, non-convex geometry crystallography, and theoretical computer science. For convex polyhedra, the number of facets is related to a number of interesting properties. The first is the diameter of the sphere of radius representatives of the vertices of the polyhedron. The second is the kissing number, the maximum number of spheres that can fit in the same spherical layer about the origin, each sphere touching every vertex of the polyhedron that it contains. Many researchers have investigated upper bounds on the number of facets for various classes of polyhedra. In particular, a conjecture of Zipporach and Livingston implies that any simplicial polyhedron in -space has at most 6n - 12 vertices, where n is the number of vertices. This bound is close to being best possible, because the icosahedron has 17 vertices and 6n - 12 facets. Similarly, in three dimensions, any polytope with at most 70 facets exists in space. Despite the upper bound of 70 facets, many interesting polytopes have much more than 70 facets. The 120-cell has 192 facets, the 600-cell has 1527 facets, and the 24-cell has 2832 facets. This blog post is based on a talk given at TEDxLondon, by Anthony Nefax. The numbers of facets of simplices, regular polytopes, and the D5 domain module are all unknown. Many polytopes have facets that are flat planes, because they correspond to various types of planes of symmetry in the geometry. The simplex, the cube, the tetrahedron, the octahedron, and the dodecahedron have 4, 6, 8, 12, and 20 planar facets. The 24-cell and 600-cell have 12 and 1527 planar facets respectively. The 120-cell has 192 planar facets. Other facets in the simplex, the cube, the tetrahedron, the octahedron, and the dodecahedron are curved, giving the appearance of facets only because we are looking at two-dimensional projections of higher-dimensional objects. For example, the octahedron has 12 curved triangular facets and 30 curved square facets. The 600-cell has 1527 curved planar facets. This is only a brief introduction to the facet concept. The interested reader may wish to consult the articles on convex polyhedra, non-convex polyhedra, and polytope, as well as the cited works of Bernard Riemann and Alfred Kinsey. The 26th New York Infantry Regiment was an infantry regiment in the Union Army during the American Civil War. It was organized in Waterford, New York, and mustered into Federal service between October and December 1861. The regiment fought in many of the major campaigns of the war and was particularly noted for its service at the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Sitok Srengenge (c. 1630 – 16 September 1680) was a high King of Cambodia from 1661 to 1680. He was the son of King Ponhea Kiev and the brother of King Non Kiev, both of whom he succeeded as King. He is the only person known to have reigned as king of Cambodia three times. As a child, he was placed on the throne by his father, but was driven out two years later by the Chinese Ming dynasty. He returned in 1662 and held power for five years until he was defeated by the Siamese kingdom and sent to Bangkok. He reclaimed the throne two years later but was forced to withdraw to Thonburi after a year. The Vietnamese army of Trịnh lords then drove him out and he fled to China where he lived for the rest of his life. He was the grandfather of King Norodom Sihamoni and great-grandfather of King Norodom Ranavuthiy. He is the titular King of the Snake in Cambodian legend and the hyacinth flower in Thai legend. He is also known by the epithet "Knight of the White Elephant" and the Chinese title "Divine Emperor of Anterior and Retreat" (前后皇帝). He is portrayed in the opera "Duy Ky Hang" by Le Cong Bang. He is the main character of the 2016 novel "The King Must Die" by Thuy Linh T. Long. Born in the Kingdom of Ayutthaya, he was adopted by King Ponhea Kiev and became a Buddhist monk and a student of the Kingdom of Cambodia's Sunsena staff before he was crowned King in 1661. After deposing King Non Kiev the same year, he reigned Cambodia for three periods between 1661 and 1680. Upon his first deposal, the Chinese Ming dynasty forced him to withdraw to Bangkok. He reclaimed the throne the following year but was forced to withdraw to Thonburi after a year. The Vietnamese army of Trịnh lords then drove him out and he fled to China where he lived for the rest of his life. The Rheinmetall MG 60 was a multi-purpose fully automatic heavy machine gun designed for infantry use and built from 1942 to 1945. It was capable of fully automatic fire at both low and high rates of fire and was highly reliable, being used in several World War II campaigns. The MG 60 was inducted into the U.S. Armed Forces technical manual in 1945 and saw limited use during the Korean War and Vietnam War before being replaced by the Belgian FN MAG in most U.S. military inventories in the early 1970s. The MG 60 was conceived as a replacement for the MG 42 and shared its Auto-5iberian loading mechanism and open iron sight. However, the MG 60 was much heavier and larger, weighing over seven kilograms (15 pounds) with the tripod and requiring a central gun mount. Its 150-round box magazine was capable of fully automatic fire for up to seven minutes, but standard infantry magazines held 30 and 50 rounds, reducing the MG 60 to semi-automatic or even single-fire modes. A belt-fed version was also available. The weapon's considerable size and weight, mediocre rate of fire and significant maintenance requirements, as well as the arrival of new, more powerful, calibre weapons, led to its rejection in most infantry units. The MG 60 nevertheless remained in military service with a number of armed forces, including the West German Bundeswehr, as well as in a number of international export markets, such as Peru.

John Pulling (captain) was a British naval commander. He joined the Royal Navy in the Middle East, and was deployed to the Arctic as part of the Arctic Convoys. During the Arctic Convoys, he led multiple attacks on the German naval squadron which was operating in the Arctic. For this, he was awarded the bar to the Distinguished Service Cross. After the war, he participated in the Palestine Campaign and in the Jamaica expedition of 1923. Later in his career, he became a Naval Commander in the Newfoundland Fisheries Section. Army Group Liguria was a German Army Group in World War II. It was created in June 1944 as a stationary force tasked with holding Italy in the Allied aim of denying Italy to the Axis and with occupying the Piedmont and Liguria regions to counter a possible Allied invasion through the French Riviera. In June 1944, Army Group Liguria consisted of the XIV Panzer Corps (Heinz Guderian), the 7th Infantry Division Schleswig-Holstein (Wilhelm Frieß), and the Italian Co-Belligerent Army (Egidio Galbusera). The German forces were soon transferred to southern France where they helped hold the Gothic Line. At the same time, a new Army Group Liguria was created (18 September 1944) consisting of the German 7th Infantry Division Schleswig-Holstein and the Italian Co-Belligerent Army, as well as the 15th Panzer and 21st Panzer divisions. In April 1945, the new Army Group Liguria consisted of the German 7th Infantry Division Schleswig-Holstein, the German 15th and 21st Panzer divisions, and the Italian Co-Belligerent Army. The group was located in the Rome area and was charged with setting up a new defensive line. Following Operation Persecution on 24 March 1945, the British made plans to attack across the English Channel and into Italy via France. As a result, Army Group Liguria was reassigned to support the withdrawal of German forces from northern Italy. In April 1945, the Army Group Liguria consisted of the 7th Infantry Division Schleswig-Holstein, the 15th and 21st Panzer divisions, and the Italian Co-Belligerent Army. The group was located in the Rome area and was charged with setting up a new defensive line.

Tianjin CTF Finance Centre is a high-rise office building located at 228 Peace Avenue in the Dongcheng District of Tianjin, China. It was completed in 2015 and has 25 floors and a total built area of 323,500 square meters. It is located a few minutes' walk from the Tianjin Economic and Trade Centre and Tianjin Binhai National International Airport. The building was designed by Archiplan and cost 902 million RMB (about 140 billion Chinese Yuan) to build. It was developed and is managed by Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Asset Management Co., Ltd., a subsidiary of Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Investment Management Co., Ltd. The building is a honeycomb structure with a three-dimensional exterior featuring a glass curtain wall. The exterior design employs structural insulated panels (SIPs). The building uses an energy-saving automatic control system, and has obtained the China Hightech Materials Certification. On March 28, 2015, a major fire broke out in an underground parking lot of the building, caused by a spark from welding work. 54 people were killed and more than 600 were injured. The building was severely damaged as a result of the incident, and was taken off the market for renovation. The entire ground floor of the building was re-built after the incident, and the renovation was completed in March 2019. The building is popularly referred to as "1313" in China, because its official address is 1313 Peace Avenue. The building is located near the Bay Stat Campus of Tianjin University, and near the Tianjin Ocean Aquarium. It is one of several buildings that were included in a 2013 traveling exhibition, Global Architecture Tour. The building is decorated with sculptures and public artworks by local artists. The building is environmentally friendly, and has achieved the "Gold Standard" rating for energy use and carbon emissions for buildings under the "Energy-saving Building Code" established by the China Guild of Green Building Architects. The building has bicycle parking lots on the upper floors, to reduce the impact of car use on the environment. It is situated within a 15-minute walk of the Tianjin Binhai Subway Station, which connects it to other parts of Tianjin. It has become a popular location for tech start-ups and digital firms due to its close proximity to Tianjin's financial district and the Tianjin Economic and Trade Centre. In 2020, the building was the scene of a deadly stampede as over 10,000 people were waiting to get into a concert by singer Lay. More than 120 people were injured and at least two people were killed. The stampede was reportedly caused by queue jumping, which is a widespread problem in China. The building has a gym, a swimming pool, and business facilities including conference rooms and restaurants. It is considered to be one of the best buildings in Tianjin. It is also popularly known as "Iron Rice Bowl" because of its iconic shape and iron-like color. It is a pivotal scene in the movie 13 Encounters of the Weirdest Kind, where a government assassin hides out in the building. On the 105th floor, there is a glass dome which is open to the public. On clear days, one can see for more than 30 kilometers. Owners of the building and its residents are given access to a private open-air party room on the 113th floor, with an unobstructed view of the city. It has become an iconic building in Tianjin, and there have been proposals to demolish it and replace it with a new building. It is the tallest office building in Tianjin, and the second tallest in the Tianjin municipal area after the Tianjin TV Tower. The building was awarded first place in the "2015 World's Best Building" competition organized by the American Institute of Architects and the international architectural competition specializing in large buildings. It was also a semi-finalist in the "2015 World Architecture Festival" and a finalist in the "2016 International Tourism Academy Award". It was selected as one of the "Fifty Must-Visit Buildings in China" by The New York Times. It has received positive reviews from local architects and design experts. The CTF stands for Central Tianjin Finance. The Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Investment Management Co., Ltd. is a state-owned company which was established in 1998 and invested in the Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Investment Management Co., Ltd. The Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Asset Management Co., Ltd. was set up in 2009 as a company administered by the Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Investment Management Co., Ltd. to manage the assets

State Highway 24 (often referred to as SH 24) is a New Zealand state highway running for 32 kilometres (20 miles) from SH 1 at Hahei to the Paengaroa Peninsula on the southwest coast of the North Island. It was the first state highway to be purpose-built in New Zealand, constructed between 1924 and 1927. SH 24 is part of New Zealand's scenic route, and due to its remote location and visual charm, the route is popular with tourists. SH 24 was nominated for consideration as a World Heritage Site by New Zealand in 2012, though this failed to be accepted. The highway is unfenced and unsuitable for driving year-round due to the risk of avalanches and landslides, but a vista point at the northern end of the route near Paengaroa offers some of the best views over the Pacific Ocean in New Zealand. sink article about State Highway 24 (SH 24) that is at least 250 words.
