Jonathan Tel (c. 1550 – c. 1625) was a English scholar, known as the translator of the First Folio of Shakespeare's plays. He was born in London and educated at Merchant Taylor's School. He began publishing in 1586, working with Henry Peacham on The Compleat Gentleman. From 1588 he was in great trouble for London city taxes, and he sailed for the Netherlands in 1589. He studied at Leiden University and worked with Theodore Beza at the French Protestant church in Antwerp, under whose patronage he also published Archimedes. In 1604/5 he returned to London and for ten years worked as a private tutor. He was close friends with Ben Jonson and Shakespeare, and also worked with Abraham Cowley, George Chapman, and John Fletcher. He died around 1625 in London and was buried at St Martin's Church. His children included Robert Tel, also an eminent Shakespearean translator. The First Folio of Shakespeare's plays was the first collected edition of Shakespeare's works. It was published in 1623, based on the plays' performance of the previous decade at the theatre-of- lords. A collection of 1623 had been proposed by Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford, and some historians have claimed that this shows Oxford to have been the true author of the plays. Others have been more critical of this theory, but Jonathan Tel was able to translate the dedication and epistle to Oxford into Dutch. This proved controversial at the time and later made it easier to claim Oxford as the true author.

Cabela's Big Game Hunter 2012 was an American sports hunting television series that aired from February to December 2012 on the cable channel aimed at male hunters, GameFXX. The series was filmed in South Dakota and followed a diverse group of hunters as they pursued various big game animals across the United States. The series was produced by RFD Television and was hosted by Scottie Scheffler and taxidermist and actor Chris Scanlon. In February 2012, it was announced that Cabela's would partner with Scheffler, the host of Sportsman Channel's Whitetail Hunter Warhorn, and Scanlon, known for his work on the Animal Planet series, Guillermo's New Adventure, to develop the series. On April 26, 2012, it was announced that Cabela's would air 20 episodes of the series. On December 5, 2012, the series concluded after airing its final episode, but Scheffler later revealed that another season had been planned. Despite critical acclaim, the series was not a ratings success and was canceled after 12 episodes. The opening sequence featured Scheffler or Scanlon describing a hunt, followed by Scheffler bringing the big game animal into a Cabela's store, with Cabela's logos displayed throughout the sequence. The host would frequently break the fourth wall and address the camera, giving viewers a behind-the-scenes look at the hunt. Scenes outside of Cabela's were sometimes used to emphasize the theme of the hunt. Scheffler and Scanlon would often share a laugh throughout the hunt, with Scanlon emphasizing the humor of the hunt, as well as the hunt's absurdity. GameFXX commissioned series re-releases and extensions to the show. Season one was released on DVD on April 18, 2013, and season two was released on December 5, 2013. Reruns of both seasons subsequently aired on the GameFXXTV channel. Despite critical and commercial failures, Cabela's is committed to continuing the hunting show concept, with Scheffler confirmed as host of the new series, Whitetail Hunter, which premiered on GameFXX in 2014 and was subsequently moved to the network's main channel.

Mary Jeffries (born Mary Kennedy; October 24, 1908 – January 23, 1983) was an American songwriter best known for the 1959 pop hit "Blue Velvet" and its 1970s television adaptation "Look Around You". Her other well-known songs include "He's a Heartbreaker", recorded by The Mills Brothers in 1936 and later covered by Linda Ronstadt, and "Who's Sorry Now?", a popular number during World War II that was recorded by Judy Garland, Aretha Franklin, and others. During the 1950s, Jeffries began writing English-language lyrics for foreign-language songs performed in France by chanteuse Juliette Gréco, resulting in many hit records, including "Pauvre Coquillage" and "Ménergie". After moving to the United Kingdom in the early 1960s, Jeffries contributed lyrics to many UK hits, including The Beatles' "Eight Days a Week" and The Rolling Stones' "As Tears Go By". She also wrote lyrics for British bands, including The Moody Blues and The Move. In 1965, she was among the founders of the British music magazine Songology. Jeffries became an American citizen in 1975. That same year, she was invited to sing "The Star-Spangled Banner" at the Baseball World Series in New York City, as a favor to her friend Joe Paiella, a Major League Baseball player for the New York Yankees. In 1983, she returned to France, where she died of a heart attack at the age of 75.

Saint Paul's, Saint Helena is an island in the South Atlantic Ocean, British Overseas Territory, and part of the Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha group. The island is roughly triangular in shape, with a total area of about, making it the fourth-smallest of the islands in the group. St. Paul's is roughly circular in shape, with an area of about, making it the smallest. The island is volcanic in origin, and much of its landscape is made up of basalt cliffs. The island's main feature is its airport, which is located in the northeast of the island. The airport is dedicated to emergency landings only, and no commercial airline flies there. The island's only settlement is the port village of Saint Helena, located in the south of the island. Saint Helena is completely uninhabited, but the British government maintains a military presence there because it is the only secure anchorage for commercial shipping in the region. This includes a Royal Air Force station, a naval base, and a prison. The only exceptions are periodic supply visits by Royal Navy vessels, which may carry up to nine passengers at a time. As a result, the entire population of the island consists of warders from the prison at the prison camp. In common with the other islands in the group, Saint Helena used to be part of the British Empire, and retains some of its colonial administrative structures. The governor of the island group is the Commander of the Royal St. Helena forces, who is responsible to the Secretary of State for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. The Governor is appointed by the British monarch, and his official residence is Government House. Despite its remote location, the island has been a focus of significant interest for rocketry enthusiasts for many decades. The first satellite launch from the island took place in 1954, and a large proportion of the vehicles used in the successful satellite missions of the 1970s and 1980s were constructed on site. In more recent years, the Island has been used as a test site by several car manufacturers, including General Motors, Ford, and Toyota. The only animal found on the island is the black rat, which was introduced to the island by sailors. This is the only known example of a natural extinction in the modern era, with no animal species present even though numerous other animals have been imported for laboratory experiments. A number of important historical figures are connected with the island. It was at St. Paul's that Edward Kelsey completed the first successful test of a submarinesea car in 1853. Twenty-two years later, Kelsey's son Vincent made the first powered flight from the island. In 1921, Michaelis, the Germanarchive that covered the operation of the Allied prisoners during World War I, was relocated to Saint Helena from its original base in Switzerland. The island was also the final home of South Africa's first president, the late Mahatma Gandhi, and of Indian author and Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore. Water is Saint Helena's main export and main source of income. The island is depleting its fresh water reserves at a rate of around 300,000 litres per day (386,000 cubic metres per day). The Middle Island of the Middle Atlantic would depend on it for its continued supply.

Poor Little Fool was a legendary Thoroughbred racehorse that won the 1897 Preakness Stakes and second Empery over Scholastic in the 1897 Belmont Stakes. Poor Little Fool was a Kentucky-bred and trained by aging champion racehorse trainer W. T. Robinson. The 4 year old, trained by Robinson had recently won the 1896 Latonia Derby and the 1897 Chicago Juvenile Futurity. Poor Little Fool was ridden by renowned jockey Dan McCarthy who bettered himself and the horse on the famed Woodward trial eight days earlier. The 4 year old won the 1897 Belmont Stakes by three lengths over Empery, who would go on to become an influential sire. Poor Little Fool was named American Champion Three-Year-Old Male Horse in 1897, 1898 and 1899. The name of the horse and its wins remains part of the language in the horse racing industry, as in "lengths" meaning a small or slender advantage. Type 626 tanker is a compact and cost-efficient product tanker, developed by China for offshore oil and gas fields storage, transport and bunkering. Type 626 has a diameter of 12.3 m, a length of 56.5 m and a height of 8.1 m. The gross registered tonnage is 58 tons. The full load displacement is 7,200 t, the loaded draught is 8.1 m. The structure is divided into three pressure zones, each separated with automatic pressure compensation system. There is a laser stabilizing device on the roof, which can ensure the dynamic stability when running at high speed. The low-pressure zone is filled with a comprehensive submersible pump, which can prevent cargo from flooding even if the ship is operated at high submergence depth. Because of its small size, the ship can access off shore facilities in restricted areas, and becomes an ideal choice for developing countries to accept international advanced shipping standards. Due to its unique structure, automatic handling system and high operational performance, the ship can meet the storage, transport and bunkering requirements for oilfield equipment in China and overseas. Currently, there are two shipyards in China which have produced Type 626 tankers, one is Hudong Shipyard in Shanghai and the other is DSR Group in Wuhan. The fleet size of Type 626 tanker is about 20 units. The operation mileage of the tanker is more than 100,000 kilometers, and the average speed is about 12 knots.

Baron FitzWalter Brook Bridges, 1st Baron FitzWalter, CBE (10 January 1889 – 4 March 1969), was a British politician and baronet. He served as Paymaster-General from 1945 to 1947 in Winston Churchill's first government and as Lord Lieutenant of Yorkshire from 1947 to 1951. He was created a life peer as Baron FitzWalter, of Harrogate in the North Riding of the County of York, on 16 July 1951. Beckett et al., Sex Items in Parliament, p. 82. Observable facts about Brook Bridges, 1st Baron FitzWalter: - He was born in Headingley, Leeds, the son of Sir John Bridges, Baronet, and his wife Emily Beckett. - In 1915, he was commissioned as a Second lieutenant in the Honourable Artillery Company (HAC). After training, he was attached to the Royal Flying Corps (RFC) and posted to Egypt. After completing his service in the RFC, he was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 1918 New Year Honours. - In 1945, he was created a Life Baron. - He was awarded the Efficiency Decoration in 1945. - He was Governor of Bombay from 1931 to 1933. - He was appointed Paymaster-General in Churchill's first government, serving until 1947. When he died in Harrogate on 4 March 1969, aged 83, he was buried at Leeds General Infirmary. He was succeeded in the barony by his son John.

Richard Hounslow is a British Labour Party politician who has been the Member of Parliament (MP) for Washington and Sunderland since 2010. He is the first black MP for Sunderland and the first black Parliamentary Member for the City of London. He succeeded Caroline Dinenage, who was elected to the City of London Corporation. Before entering national politics, Hounslow was a schoolteacher and branch chairman of the Labour Party in the Washington area. He was elected to the North East London Council in 2008 and served as the council's Labour leader from 2009 to 2012. He served on the Greater London Assembly from 2016 to 2018 as a member of the Labour Party. Hounslow gained national attention in June 2019 following a speech in the House of Commons in which he questioned Minister of State for Africa Alan Duncan over whether he was educated in the UK. Hounslow had previously worked as a geography teacher, and his question was seen by many as derogatory and racist. Duncan responded by calling Hounslow a "babe in the woods", to which Hounslow responded "I know who I am". After the incident, Hounslow apologised for his language but not for his question; and his employer the Washington Post wrote an article saying that the newspaper had previously been aware of Hounslow's views on race but that they had not previously considered his question derogatory or racist. Labour Party chairman and Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer John McDonnell said that Hounslow had been suspended from the Labour Party pending an investigation into his remarks, and he expelled Hounslow from the party. Labour's deputy leader Tom Watson also said that Hounslow had been expelled from the party. Hounslow initially refused to recognise that he had been expelled, stating "I'm still a Labour member and I want the Labour party to know that I'm still a member"; however, on 1 July he announced that he had been expelled.

François Cacault (born 1963) is a French classical musician and composer. He was born in Grenoble and studied music at the Conservatoire de Paris where he was a pupil of Giacinto Spagno. He achieved First Prize in Music and subsequently went on to study with Marcel Dalban and Luciano Berio. His works have been performed worldwide by major orchestras and ensembles and he has received numerous awards, including the Order of Academic Palms. Cacault's music has been described as "singing", featuring "emotional expressivity" and "lyricism". His style has been described as "lyrical", "romantic" and "charismatic" with a "strong, individual voice". His work combines "lyricism and drama". He has used instruments such as the theremin, accordion and synthesizers in his pieces. He is the founder of the Music Sector of the Ensemble Superieur and has been a member of Ensemble Modern and the Quatuor Denis while he was a member of the Frankfurt Radio Symphony Orchestra. He is the leader of the contemporary music ensemble Arditti Quartet and the artistic director of the Ensemble intercontemporain. He was awarded the Queen Sonja International Music Prize in 2009. He is a professor of composition at the Conservatoire de Paris and the École Nationale de Musique. He was appointed a chevalier of the Légion d'Honneur in 2007. His wife is the soprano Hélène Mercier. He is represented by Schott Music.

Real-time text messaging, or real-time texting for short, is a method of sending messages over a mobile phone network that allows the sender to transmit text information immediately (typically within a few seconds) of when the information is composed or entered, often via a mobile web browser. In the late 1990s and the early 2000s, providers of real-time text messaging included Today's Mann Up and Weight Watchers. More recently, real-time text messaging has also been used for marketing and advertising, typically in the form of SMS message advertising. Real-time text messaging has become the generic term to describe this form of mobile messaging, and is now used in company and organization names, such as FISRT, Project Titan, and GroupMe. Since its introduction, real-time text messaging has evolved into a more advanced form of mobile messaging. For example, certain providers allow users to compose and edit messages on the fly, although this feature is not required for all messages. Additionally, certain providers now allow mobile web browser access to general-purpose internet websites, enabling the inclusion of images, videos, and audio. While real-time text messaging initially served as a messaging gateway for Today's Mann Up and Weight Watchers, it has since evolved into a more advanced form of mobile messaging. As of 2020, real-time text messaging is most commonly performed via the SMS message format. Some real-time text messaging services also offer other message formats, such asthose based on the Rich Communication Services (RCS) standard. RCS is an umbrella standard for real-time messaging that encompasses a number of different message formats, including SMS, MMS, Interactive Voice Response, and video. Real-time text messaging is most commonly performed via the SMS message format, which has been present on mobile phones since the 1990s. However, RCS is a more recent standard, having been ratified in 2015. The main advantage of real-time text messaging over other mobile messaging formats is that users can compose and send messages immediately as they are writing them, without having to first enter a dedicated messaging application and manually open a new conversation. This is in contrast to instant messaging and email, both of which require the recipient to be logged into a service and to be actively looking for messages from the recipient. Chonda Pierce (née Parker; born October 18, 1947) is an American businesswoman, entrepreneur, and model. In 1976, at the age of 19, she became the first African-American woman to be on the cover of Elle magazine. In the 1970s and 1980s, Pierce became a successful model. In 1998, at the age of 53, she became the first African-American woman to win the Model of the Century award, voted on by fellow models. Since then, she has continued to pursue modeling and entrepreneurship. In 2006, Pierce foundedchipmobile.com, a mobile phone recycling program. The company was renamed Textron Mobile Experience in 2010. In 2016, the company was valued at $1 billion and was renamed Ooma. In February 2020, Ooma was rebranded as Ringabel. In September 2019, Pierce was announced as one of the first two honorary pallbearers at the funeral of former president Barack Obama. Pierce has received numerous awards and recognition throughout her career. She is a member of the GQ Magazine "Men of the Decade" list and was inducted into the Washington Area Model Mr. and Mrs. Inc. organization's Hall of Fame. In 2006, Pierce was included in the "Icons of Fashion" exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum. Pierce is an alumna of the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Business School. Her son is NFL wide receiver Quincy Mauger.

Ion Filotti Cantacuzino (1876-1955) was a Romanian politician and jurist, member of the Senate of Romania from 1923 to 1927, son of Gheorghe Filotti Cantacuzino and a member of the Romanian Academy between 1905 and 1936. During World War I, he served as a major in the Romanian Army and after the war as a civil lawyer. As a senator, he voted for the resignation of Prime Minister Ion Brătianu and the fall of the Brătianu government in the June 1927 Senate election. He was thus one of the principal advocates of the August 1933 coup d'état, which expelled King George Citrine and installed the dictatorship of General Ioan Capote. In 1936, he was arrested for his political beliefs and died in prison. The Ion Filotti Cantacuzino street in Bucharest and a university in Timișoara are named after him. untuary Ion Filotti Cantacuzino (1876-1955) was a Romanian politician and jurist, member of the Senate of Romania from 1923 to 1927, son of Gheorghe Filotti Cantacuzino and a member of the Romanian Academy between 1905 and 1936. Harmon Meadow is a Washington DC neighborhood, located in the Heights region on the East side of Rock Creek Park. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow is a condominium project developed by American Dream Builders LLC and as of March 2020 has 39 units. The project was built in stages from 2012 to 2016 and has a landscaped roof deck and private parking. ippets like these can be found on the Plaza at Harmon Meadow Article: - The Harmon Meadow neighborhood is one of the more diverse neighborhoods in the city, with a wide range of incomes, family households, and architecture - The Harmon Meadow post office opened on July 8, 1922 and was relocated to its current location in 1984 - Harmon Meadow was initially a farming community that was annexed by the city of Washington in 1896 - Harmon Meadow is bounded by Calvert Street, North Cleveland Street, Rock Creek Park to the east and to the west by the American University Park. Social issues in Harmon Meadow reflect those of Washington DC as a whole. Harmon Meadow is close to Rock Creek Park and provides a direct view of the Capital with a beautiful park-like setting. Harmon Meadow lacks the social issues of many other inner-city neighborhoods, but has its own set of problems, including low property values, increasing crime, and a high number of school shut downs. Lands contributed to the neighborhood include the Rock Creek Golf Course to the west, the American University Park to the south, and the Cleveland Park and Bloomingdale's neighbourhoods to the east and north respectively. Landscaping is concentrated along the west side of Calvert street. The plaza at Harmon Meadow is the tallest building in the neighborhood. The 39 unit plaza at Harmon Meadow is a condominium, consisting of one studio, one 1 bedroom, 27 2 bedrooms, and five 3+ bedroom units. Public parking is offered.

The Neuse River waterdog, (officially the "Neuse River Goldfish"), is an American smelt, (a type of rock bass), which can be found in the Neuse River in North Carolina, United States. The fish was discovered by accident in 1998 by Allan Temple, a biologist with the North Carolina Wildlife Resource Commission. Since then, biologists and fisheries managers have worked to restore the fish to local streams. The fish is of little interest to anglers, as it is almost always heavily parasitized byCitation needed]acipenseroides (a type of acipenseriform fish louse), but it is of great interest to naturalists, due to its "endangered species status", and "unique status as an invasive interspecific hybrid".[1] The smelt was federally listed as an endangered species in 2009,[2][3] and was delisted on February 14, 2019.[4] The fish is considered a "creature of improbable circumstance",[5] and is a "sidebar to contemporary evolution".[6] The smelt was discovered in 1998 by Allan Temple, a biologist with the North Carolina Wildlife Resource Commission. San Giovanni Battista, better known as San Giovanni Battiste or simply San Giovanni, is a Neoclassical-style catholic basilica in Rimini, Italy. The church was built between 1818 and 1821 in order to honor John the Baptist, and it was designed by Nicola Martinelli. The church has a Latin cross plan with a nave and two aisles, an open semi-circular baldachin over the crossing and a high facade. The interior contains some notable sculptures by Antonio Nibby, Luigi Geblov and Domenico Bertoli. The first ceremony took place on June 29, 1818 and it was attended by Ferdinand III of Naples, Charles Felix of Sardinia and other rulers and prelates. The church was completed around 1821 and it became the centre of a sicilian and international Cultural Community which lasted until 1848. The church was used as a barracks in 1915 and it was restored in 1926 and 1947. In May 1945 the building was almost completely destroyed by a German air raid, but it was restored again thanks to donations from the community. The community was suppressed in 1948 and the church was handed over to the Comune di Rimini. The monastery was restored again between 1951 and 1959. The church has been restored again since 2000. The church was listed as a national monument of Italy in 2009. Francis Bolton (portrayed by Iain Glen) is a major character in the HBO television series Game of Thrones, first appearing in season 3 as the Master of Whight outlaw army. In the show's fictional world, Bolton is a prominent northern lord at the time of the events of season 3, and is later revealed to be the father of the current King of the North, Northman, and head of the Northern House of the Night's Watch. Born into poverty in the fictional territory of White Harbor, Bolton joined the King's Guard at the behest of then-head of security, Lord Petyr Baelish, and quickly proved himself by winning several battles, the most notable of which was the Black Harvest, in which Bolton personally killed the leader of the Valryian Watch, Ser Jaime Lannister. As a reward, he was made Lord of White Harbor and was given a position in Baelish's service. After several years of loyal service, Bolton was given command of the legendary Night's Watchbuf 295 men, with whom he declared war on the wildling population, leading to the Long Night. After the war, Bolton was given the honors he had sought and named Master of Whight. In the early 22nd century, Bolton became a leading voice in the Northern House of the Night's Watch and was made Lord of Qohor. However, his reign was interrupted by a military coup instigated by the Children of the Forest, resulting in the North being torn apart by civil war; Bolton sided with the Tullys, and was made Warden of the North. Bolton's story was adapted into the book series, A Feast for Crows, where he is portrayed as a cunning and greedy man who has grown cold-hearted and oblivious to the suffering of others. This change was also reflected in his relationship with Jon Snow, who defeated Bolton in a power struggle. Following the series, Bolton becomes the Warden of the North once again and fathers Northman, the current King of the North.

Oskar Karlweis (born 1970) is a German musician, best known as the singer of the German industrial band Rammstein. After training as an opera singer, Karlweis joined the band in 1993 and has been the lead singer ever since. Rammstein are known for their intense live performances, and Oskar's extensive use of make-up and costumes. Karlweis is a highly acclaimed artist in Germany, with his songs often being released as video singles to accompany popular music videos. He has been awarded multiple trophies at the MTV Europe Music Awards and had four top ten singles in Germany with his band. After fifteen years with the band, Karlweis announced his retirement in 2018. He was persuaded to return, but announced again his retirement in 2023. Karlweis has ten children with four different women. Karlweis was born in Duisburg, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany. He is of Jewish descent and was raised as a Christian. As a teenager he played in the metal band James Bluer. Karlweis studied at the Opernplatz Academy of the Wuppertal Youth Symphony Orchestra. He was married to German actress and musician Christiane Karg. They have three daughters. In 2010, they got divorced. In 2014, he married German singer and model Kerstin "Tomi" Tomashek. They have a son and divorce in 2023. He is a cancer survivor. Karlweis's trademarks are his long hair and make-up. He has taught singing at the Bergisch Gladbach Opera and Business Academy. Lois Griffin (born Lois Jane Griffin; July 7, 1938 – December 9, 2019) was an American politician and attorney from California. A Democrat, Griffin represented the 18th Assembly District, which includes parts of southern San Diego County, from 2003 to 2013. She was born in Chicago, Illinois and graduated from Francis Parker School. After high school, she attended Spelman College in Atlanta, Georgia, where she was active in Alpha Phi sorority and earned a bachelor's degree in history and political science in 1960. She moved to San Diego County the following year, where she received a law degree from the University of California, Berkeley. Griffin practiced law for several years before deciding to run for elected office. She was elected to the San Diego City Council in 1995, and served in that capacity until 2003. She was elected to the California State Assembly in 2003 and was re-elected in 2006 and 2010. She was re-elected to a fifth term in 2014, but chose not to run for re-election in 2016. Griffin died of pancreatic cancer on December 9, 2019, aged 80. Award-winning television and film actress, she was most famous for her role as the refueling robot mother "LOIS GRIFFIN" on the 1970s animated series "The Family Gaude". She also starred in several 1970s and 1980s movies, including Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas as Officer Jenny Lee. married Orville Chapman, and had three children, all daughters: Jenna, Melissa, and Celeste. Griffin specialized in patent and estate law, and was an officer of the California State Bar. Griffin supported same-sex marriage, and in 2012 she became the first openly LGBT member of the California State Legislature.

"So what are you doing this morning? Just sit and think about that." "That's the problem," said the chickadee. "I sit and think about that and end up thinking about last night, and the day before, and the week before that. In the end, I've wasted an hour of my time and don't have an hour to plan for." "Well, that's a problem," said Pooh. "Most of the answers to life's problems come from continuing to think about a problem until you come up with a better solution." Shergarh is a town and a nagar panchayat in Dadu District of Sindh province, Pakistan. Shergarh town lies 8 kilometres south of Nawabshah, and has a population of around 200,000 people.[1] It is located near Daud kala motorway and has an average elevation of 28 metres (92 feet). The name Shergarh is derived from a Sindhi legendary hero, Sher Khan Dhandan, a Samma Dynasty prince who ruled the region during the 7th century AD. According to the local legend, Sher Khan defeated the Hindu King of Sindh and set his kingdom on fire. The region was called Shergarh meaning the fire of Sindh. Shergarh has produced many renowned scholars, among them the scholar, writer, poet, editor, journalist and politician Abdus Sattar Burki. In the Netherlands, seven outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 occurred in 2016. Since 2010, the virus has circulated among poultry with sporadic genetic and antigenic variation. In this study, we describe the genetic evolution and receptor binding phenotype of these H5N8 HPAI viruses. Receptor binding analysis showed that the viruses isolated in 2016, like those in recent years, had acquired the α2,3-SA receptor binding determinant from the presumably common source A/duck/Germany/RC-4087/2010. The HA gene phylogeny showed three main clusters, two of which included the majority of the viruses isolated in 2016. Conor Parke (born 23 December 1991) is an Irish rugby union footballer who plays as a fly-half for the Irish national team and English club Northampton Saints. He previously played for Bristol and the Sale Sharks in the Aviva Premiership. A graduate of the Irish Rugby Institute's Developer Programme, Parke's early career was plagued by injuries but he went on to become an important member of Connacht's 2014 and 2015 European Championships winning squads. He has also won two British and Irish cups with the province and was voted Connacht Player of the Year and Young Player of the Year in 2015. After the 2015–16 season Parke signed for Sale Sharks, where he quickly established himself as a top flight fly-half. He was also shortlisted for the European Golden Boot and scored the winning penalty in the 2017 Champions Cup final as Sale defeated Cardiff Blues. In June 2019, he signed a four-year contract with English Premiership side Northampton Saints. Parke attended St. Brendan's Community School in Bray, County Wicklow and trained with both the Ireland under-18 team and the Munster under-20s before being handed his debut by Munster at home to Scarlets in the Champions Cup in March 2013. He signed for Bristol in 2015, and also spent time on loan at Doncaster and Sale. He returned to Ireland to represent UCD and Shannon as well as compete for the Irish national team.

Hibbard & Darrin was a popular singing group who achieved success in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The duo consisted of brothers Barry and Frank Hibbard, who were part of a singing group called The Jive Five, that also included Darrin Hibbard and Larry Darrin. The group was discovered by music manager Lee Stoller, who managed the Beatles in the 1960s. Hibbard & Darrin signed with Stoller's new management firm, Rutters, and soon released their first single "Ready for Love". The song became a hit, peaking at #2 on the Billboard Hot 100, and #1 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart. Hibbard & Darrin's self-titled debut album was also a success, reaching #1 on the Billboard Top LPs chart, as well as producing the single "Love Is in Your Eyes". After the success of their first album, Hibbard & Darrin released the singles "Raindrops", "What Have You Done", and "You're Nobody 'til Somebody Loves You". The album peaked at #3 on the Billboard charts. Despite the success of the singles, tensions began to arise between the brothers and Stoller, eventually leading to Hibbard & Darrin being dropped from Rutters and disbanding. The brothers started their own management firm, and went on to great success as a duo, continuing to record and perform together until Barry Hibbard's death in 2016.

Macclenny is a city in Franklin County, Florida, United States. The population was 5,637 at the 2010 census. The city is the county seat and largest city in Macclenny postal county. The Macclenny Micropolitan Statistical Area is home to 9,815 people. Macclenny was founded in 1883 as a railroad town. It is named for Macclenny, Alabama, the hometown of one of its founders. It is located on the approach to Jacksonville, Florida, on the St. Marys River. The name Macclenny is a portmanteau of McCleary, the name of the Alabama town. Harrah's Atlantic City is a hotel and casino located in Atlantic City, New Jersey. It is owned and operated by Caesars Entertainment. The casino opened in 1989 and is situated on 17 acres (70,000 m²) of land. Harrah's is located close to the Boardwalk and the Entertainment District, making it a prominent fixture in the city. The hotel has 939 guest rooms and 57 condominium units, and features a replica of the Statue of Liberty dungeon. The casino has two separate clubs, The Golden Eagle and Golden Nugget, and a sports book that hosts college and professional sporting events. The casino has over 2000 slots, 96 table games, and 30 poker tables. Harrah's is home to many high profile events, including the Miss America pageant, the Classicadragon Masters tennis tournament, and several fantasy sports leagues. Its most famous sporting event was the final table of the World Series of Poker (WSOP) held from 1990 to 1999. The main poker room is recognized as one of the most beautiful in the world. Harrah's was the site of the infamous "Coke-bottle murder" where David Headley, the convict in a plot to bomb a Danish newspaper, infiltrated the hotel's electric system to murder a homeless man by dumping a drink bottle containing Coke and crackers into his sleep. Over time, Harrah's has expanded and renovated its gaming space, most recently in a $200 million renovation and expansion in 2013, adding space and additional facilities, including a coffee shop and gift shop. The renovation was designed by Henry N. Cobb of DLR Group.

Lucy Barrow McIntire (1847–1920) was an American physician and researcher. She was the first woman to graduate from Rush Medical College in Chicago, and the first woman to serve as an assistant surgeon with the Chicago Medical Police. In 1883, she founded one of the first women-run medical schools in the country, the Women's Medical College of Chicago. Throughout her medical career, she specialized in diseases of women and children. Throughout her research, she used dog testing as a way to develop better treatments for women's health problems. She was one of the first woman to receive American Public Health Association's Recognition of Distinguished Service award in 1894. Throughout her life, she was dedicated to public health, and she was involved with local and state organizations devoted to this cause, including the Chicago School Readiness Association, the Illinois Midwifery and Social Hygiene Association, and the Chicago Women's Health Protective Association. The 2013 Rayong oil spill was a large oil spill that occurred on July 5, 2013 in Rayong Province, Thailand. The spill killed large number of fish and caused serious environmental damage, and was one of the largest environmental disasters in the history of Thailand. The cause of the spill was not determined, but authorities speculated that the spill may have been caused byONG temporal, a state-owned company which at the time was in the process of switching from using sea water to using non-sea water to prevent sea water intrusion into its oil wells. The spill occurred when the pipeline connected to the offshore oil well broke and leaked tens of thousands of litres of oil into the sea. The well was quickly capped, but much of the oil soaked into nearby reeds and estuaries, affecting thousands of fish and other sea life. More than 30,000 residents of the province were affected by the spill, and many took to social media to complain about the lack of government support and delayed notification of the spill. The government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra initially attempted to minimise the damage, but the scale of the spill and negative international press coverage caused the government to take steps to improve its response efforts. A commission, led by Prem Tinsulanonda, a former King of Thailand, was formed to review the government's response efforts, and many of the commission's recommendations have since been implemented. The spill was the subject of a long-running criminal investigation, and in 2018, Chayapol Juraporn, the former president ofONG, was sentenced to 25 years in prison for criminal negligence and violations of environmental regulations, among other charges.

Clinton is a 2015 biographical drama film about the former President of the United States, Bill Clinton, directed by Nancysavant Samia Touma. The film had a limited release in the United States on March 4, 2015, before being distributed broadly by the Amazon Video service. It was produced byiculus Annapurna Chandar. The screenplay was written by Simon Leahy and Kelly Monroe Kull. The cast includes Naghistani as Clinton, Nathaniel Jurado as Bill Clinton, Charlotte Lebon as Hillary Clinton, Shaun Thomas as Joe Lieberman, Brian George and Judyann Elder. Clinton follows President Clinton during his time in office and after, including his impeachment for perjury and obstruction of justice in relation to the Whitewater affair, his recovery from a near-fatal brain injury suffered in a traffic accident, and his later terms as Governor of Arkansas and his post-presidency. Based on the book My Life: The Graphic Novel by butch vanbusch and Brandy Colbert, the film version has several deviations from the book, such as replacing the character of Frank McKenna with that of Joe Lieberman. The film was shot in locations including New York City, Little Rock, Arkansas, and Offut Avenue in Hillary Clintons home town of Chappaqua, New York. The title of the film is a reference to the book My Life: The Graphic Novel by butch vanbusch and Brandy Colbert, which was released at the same time as this film, and details the life of Bill Clinton.[clarification needed]

Drinnon (born Richard Terrell Drinnon; September 4, 1908 – January 24, 2002) was an American academic and author who specialized in the study of North American Indians and Native American culture. He was professor emeritus of history at the University of California, Berkeley and chair of the American Indian Studies Program at the University of California, Davis. Born and raised in Utah, Drinnon began his academic studies at the University of California, Berkeley, where he earned his B.A. in 1931 and his Ph.D. in 1934. He taught history at the University of California, Davis, from 1934 to 1957 and also became a professor at the University of Utah, where he taught from 1957 to 1965. He founded the American Indian studies program at the University of California, Davis in 1953 and was its chair from 1957 to 1965. He wrote several books and numerous articles on Native American culture. He was elected a fellow of the Society of American Archaeology in 1949. Macbett is a set of fictional tyrannical robots in the fictional television series, Space:1999, led by the supervillain Master in the 1st and 2nd season episodes "Crimes and Misdemeanors" and "The Magicks of Megas-Machus". The Macbett robots appear to be reptilian humanoids, distinguished by green or blue skin and visible metal structures. They are created and built by Dr. Ali Jenkins (Barbara Anderson) to replace and take over the functions of her late husband and original creator, Howard Jenkins (Barron Wesencord). The Macbett robot functions are destructive, claiming to have achieved "parity with God", and are motivated by Jenkins' revenge against the Space:1999 program and the military for their cancellation. The Macbett robots first appear in "Crimes and Misdemeanors", where the Chief of Staff of the Solaran government, General Koros, has the Macbett robots initiate a terraforming program on Altair 4 that is planned to kill all life. Koros is unable to control the Macbett robots and they terraform the planet to make it uninhabitable for all life. As an act of revenge, Jenkins has Koros tell the Alian protagonist Christopherander that Macbett was responsible, and that the Alian leadership would see that Macbett is destroyed. In "The Magicks of Megas-Machus", a captured Macbett robot appears to Dr. Anna C56 and Dr. Ben Zienna on Proxima III. The captured Macbett robot reveals that it was created by Koros to be an army of roboticized humans, and that Koros believed he had found a way to equalize intelligence with his creator, Jenkins. The Macbett robot desires are so strong that it coerced Koros into aiding it, but its creators realized its true intentions and had the Macbett robot destroyed before it could execute them. The Macbett robots, under the command of Koros, attack and destroy the Altair 4 colony, but the Alian protagonist and Chief Executive Officer of Space:1999, Christopherander, is able to use the experimental Macbett robot escape pod to flee to Earth. The Macbett robots resurface on the space stations of the Altair System, in the 2nd season premiere "The Counterfeit Man". They capture Andromeda, the station's Captain, while Christopherander is investigating the death of Koros, a fake assassination installed by Christopherander himself to allow Koros to disappear with the Macbett robot Anna C56. Christopherander is able to thwart the fake assassination attempt and contacts Earth through a deactivated Macbett robot communications array to alert them to the threat. Christopherander later learns that Koros was attempting to uncover the true source of the Macbett robots' power source, "the source", a mysterious AI entity that had attached itself to the Altair 4 computer network following the failed terraforming attempt, and that the real Koros body was being used as a control mechanism by Anna C56, the Macbett robot second-in-command. Christopherander confronts Anna C56 and uses the "source" to destroy it, shutting down the Macbett robots. Jenkins, on the planet Altair IV, awakens from his cryogenic freeze to realize that his creations have been destroyed and that his revenge will need to be accomplished through other means. He revives his late wife, Ali Jenkins, and reveals that he installed a computer virus in the Altair 4 network that will destroy all data pertaining to Space:1999, including the Macbett robot files, in order to make sure the planets failure to terraform would remain a mystery. The final scene of the 2nd season finale, "The Mask of Mati", shows a solar system-wide message from Jenkins, posing as Christopherander, announcing that Space:1999 is being restored, and asking for Alian assistance in the terraforming of Mars. Later, in the 3rd season premiere, "The Silent Enemy", Christopherander is revealed to be the villainous Master, posing as Space:1999's Chris Franz, in order to gather the necessary data on how to terraform Mars. Jenkins, still posing as Christopherander, reveals that he had intentionally sabotaged Space:1999's systems in order to make sure the project needed Altair's assistance for Mars terraforming would be kept a secret. Having orchestrated the events of the 2nd season, Jenkins reveals that he has installed a computer virus into the Altair 4 system that will allow him to control all functions of the system, and that the virus will be activated once the Macbett

Chick Corea is an American guitarist, singer, and composer. He has been active as a solo artist, bandleader, and in numerous collaborative groups for more than five decades. Corea is known for his fast-paced compositions and heavy use of the synthesizer in his music from the 1970s onwards. Britain-based progressive rock band Yes recorded an album with Corea on guitar from 1974 to 1975, called "Time and a Word" and "No War, No More Deaths". A few years later, he joined Carlos Santana as his guitarist on the huge worldwide hit "Supernatural". Other bands in which Corea has played include Tina Turner,VERSIONS, United States Air Force Band, and the 100 Men Band. In the 1980s, Corea formed the highly acclaimed group Return to Forever with his brother, Joe, and his son, John. They performed and recorded music from 1973 to 1983 with several changes in line-ups. During the 1990s, Corea started his second group, the Stone come Light Band. Southbound Pachyderm (born Ronald Mailhot-McCauley, also known as Panda and the Odd Bird and Panda McCbrain) is a French musician, born in Paris. He gained popularity in France through his participation in the reality TV show La vie en rose, where he reached the final, and also released an eponymous studio album which reached number one in France. His real name is Mailhot, he is of Canadian descent and also speaks French and English. His nickname Panda comes from his smooth skin condition known as hyper-pigmentation, in which his skin darkens from exposure to sunlight. While Mailhot has insisted that his skin condition is a result of a genetic mutation, other causes include childhood exposure to toxic chemicals, such as was prevalent in the era he was born in. During his time in the show, Mailhot was publicly called out for being unaltered, and since then, he has worked to raise awareness of negative stereotypes associated with albinism. Influenced by a variety of genres including rock, hip hop, R&B and alternative, his music video for "McMcCrystal" received over 5 million views on YouTube. Following the release of his second studio album, No Jumper, he became engaged to Greek model and YouTuber Maria Magdalena Goucht. The couple's January 2020 wedding was featured in Vogue Paris. Mailhot has headlined tours in France, as well as co-headlined a tour in Japan with Microscopic, and supported Snoop Dogg and De La Soul on their co-headlining US tour.

Static light scattering is an experimental technique used in physics, chemistry and biology to determine the size and shape of particles and molecular complexes. It is based on the measurement of the time-dependent fluctuations of the scattered light due to the particles' Brownian motion. It is used in chemistry to characterize solutions and to detect colloidal particles, aggregates and molecular complexes. In biochemistry, it is used to determine the dimensions of biological macromolecules and molecular complexes. In biophysics, it is used to determine the size and shape of cells. The technique is also used in materials science to determine the structure of polymers. The first experiments using static light scattering were conducted in the early 20th century, and the detailed theoretical understanding of the technique was achieved in the 1950s and 1960s. The first commercial instruments for practical applications were developed in the 1970s and 80s. The major applications of static light scattering still are the characterization of solutions and the detection of colloidal particles, aggregates and molecular complexes. The basic experiment concept is based on the measurement of the time-dependent fluctuations of the light scattered by a particle as it moves through the incident light beam. The technique uses a light source that produces a laser beam or a collection of many quasi-monochromatic light beams. The laser beam or the light beams are expanded, focused or collimated to obtain a light beam of suitable cross-section and passed through the sample under investigation. The scattered light is collected using the same light path. The light beam is focused onto a one or two dimensional photodiode array or a one or two dimensional CCD camera with or without additional focus shifting and passed through a polarizer to measure the intensity as a function of the polarization angle. The intensity signal is Fourier transformed and the resulting ensemble-averaged intensity function, I(Q), is a dispersion profile. For more information on the theory and the practice of static light scattering, the reader is referred to the book "Light Scattering. From basic principles to applied techniques" by Robert M. Harper (1992). The applications of static light scattering, based on the technique described above, are the characterization of solutions, the detection of colloidal particles, aggregates and molecular complexes, the determination of the dimensions of biological macromolecules and molecular complexes, the study of cells, and the characterization of polymers.

The Origin theories of Christopher Columbus speculate on where and when Christopher Columbus might have lived, as well as the origins of various folk traditions associated with him. The most common Origin theory focuses on his birth in Genoa, Italy in 1451 and his subsequent migration to Spain in the early 16th century. More recent scholarship suggests that Columbus may have been born between 1465 and 1470 in the Republic of Genoa, in what is today known as Republic of San Marino, with the GenoeseDocent School of History proposing a Genoese Liguria as the more likely place of birth. Scholars agree that Columbus most likely came to Spain and arrived in the Americas in 1492. While the Genoese Origin theory as a birthplace and Spanish migration theory is widely held, the particular folk traditions associated with Columbus tend to be more diverse. In the Spanish Caribbean, Columbus is commemorated with the feast day of Saint Christopher on December 27, with Christopher being the saint depicted in depictions of a Christ-child with aodilons bearing gifts to the poor and marginalised. Many of these depict Christopher bearing a miniature boat or caravel, and this has given rise to a number of folk etymologies, with Christopher being mistaken for a sea-going saint who travels through maritime trafficacles, or legends of Columbus seizing a magical boat on his visits to the New World. In Italy, Columbus is commemorated with Columbus Day on October 10, and while Genoa is again the most common suggestion for his birthplace, the suggestions are broader across Europe and the Americas than for the Caribbean, with Columbus also being proposed for places including Wales, Brittany, Normandy, and many Portuguese and Spanish speaking countries. Despite the popularity of these local traditions, research from the 1970s onwards has consistently shown a much more diverse and localized narrative, with Columbus having been celebrated on his death-day December 31 in many locations throughout Spain and the Americas, and little evidence to support the suggestion that he was celebrated on a global scale on October 10. More recent scholarship supports the idea that Columbus was celebrated on his death-day across the Spanish Caribbean on December 31, and that while October 10 was a widely-observed local holiday in Spain, Columbus's death-day of December 31 was more widely celebrated in the Caribbean and South America, with very little evidence for October 10 celebrations in the 16th century.

Tilda Swinton is an award-winning British actress. She has been recognised for her acting with multiple awards and nominations, including a Critics' Choice Award, a British Independent Film Awards, a Satellite Award, a BAFTA award, a London Film Critics' Circle Award, and a Film Society of Lincoln Center Honorary Award. She won a Sutherland Award for her work in the British sci-fi film industry, an Gotham Award for Best Performance by an Actress in a Lead Role for her performance in David Lynch's Tulip Fever, and a Gotham Award for Best Actress in a Drama for her performance in Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk. She was also nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Jordan Peele's horror film, Us. The Cruciate Ligament is a group of ligament located in the human knee. In humans, it is made up of the ACL, PCL, and LCL. The Cruciate Ligament helps keep the human knee stable by helping to keep the tibia in place within the femur. Without this stabilisation mechanism, humans would experience excessive movement in the human knee, which may lead to damage to the articular cartilage on the inside of the femur. instructable.com/front_page_header_bicycle_pump_manual_bicycle_pump_how_to_inflate_a_bicycle_tire/ clusterfuckengineering.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/understanding-the-cyclotrimer- inflation-kit.jpg myself. how does one inflate a bicycle tire? Typically a bicycle tire is inflated to about 35psi. The process of inflating a bicycle tire normally begins with placing the valve stem of the tire in a filling port on the front of the wheel. This filling port is normally covered by a flap, but can also be exposed by unfastening a series of retainer wires. Once the tire is properly oriented and the retainer wires are removed, the stem of the tire inflator is pushed into the exposed filling port. The valve stem is pushed into the inflator until it clicks into place, at this point inflating the tire to the desired pressure. Once the tire has reached the desired pressure, the stem is removed from the filling port and retained pressure is released from the tire, normally by spinning the back of the tire to "wind down" the tire. While this is a typical and common way to inflate a bicycle tire, it also possesses a number of flaws. The first and most obvious is the "clicking" mechanism for determining the proper tire pressure. Many experienced cyclists will turn to "pressure testing" a tire by assembling a bicycle with the offending tire installed. After inflating the tire to the proper pressure the "click" mechanism can be used to test for proper inflation. This process requires two hands to operate and is thus inconvenient for most riders. While more and more modern inflators include a "read out" mechanism that displays the tire pressure to the rider, many riders simply estimate the pressure, leading to sub-optimal tire inflation and an increased chance of tire failure. The second flaw with this method of inflating a tire is the orientation of the tire filling port. Many bikes feature "fixed" fill ports, meaning that the orientation of the filling port is fixed relative to the frame of the bike. This leads to additional frustration for riders who spend time adjusting the bike to the proper orientation before being able to begin inflating the tire. Fixed fill ports also present a significant problem for riders who frequently switch between bikes, meaning that they must locate the right orientation of filling port for each bike they own. While this method of tire inflation may have been common in the 1980s and 1990s, the advent of both handheld tire inflators and built-in tire pressure sensors have made this method of inflating tires anachronistic. Some of the more modern bicycle tires feature a built-in electronic valve that can be controlled by the rider using the headlight remote or a quick-release hub. Such systems automate the tire inflation process and eliminate the need for the rider to find the correct filling port, while also preventing the forgetting to switch from a fixed to a quick release in the dark.

Pandua (Vidhan Sabha constituency) is a constituency of Maharashtra Vidhan Sabha located in Ahmednagar district. It is one of the 12 constituencies of Ahmednagar district. It comprises the following villages: Dhantoli, Pandur, Kondhan, Andalas, Dabhade, Ambavade, Jaitapur, Bhokar, Khandeshwar, Pandavlen and Dhare. Economically it is one of the biggest towns in the district and is known for Khadi products. It is one of the most developed constituencies with lot of tourism movement. It is very near to one of the old forts of Maharashtra state - Prastav Nilaya. It is also near to one of the very old temples in India - Pandavlen Temple. It is currently represented in the Maharashtra state assembly by NCP's Jayant Muravje == It was also part of Shiv Sena★ but after changes in the electoral alliances the seat is now with NCP. Pandua was previously part of Aurangabad Lok Sabha constituency. The original name for this constituency was Dhantoli (Vidhan Sabha constituency). After President's rule in 2014, the constituency got new name Pandua. It is one of the few constituencies in Maharashtra to have a Kisan elections.

Līgatne is a village in Plungė district municipality, Šakiajvaría town, Lithuania. The population is approximately 350 people. There is a church from 1796 and a school. The center of the village is about 150 meters west of the church. The land in the village is about 24 hectares and the biggest landowners are the church and the village smith. The village has a post office, a library, two playgrounds and a football pitch. Līgatne is located about 30 km west from Plungė, 27 km west from Antaviliai and 50 km south-east from Vilnius. The weather in Līgatne is typically continental. The warmest months are usually May and June when the temperature usually varies from 10 °C to 22 °C. The coldest month is usually January with temperatures decreasing to -15 °C. Annual precipitation is about 500 mm. The history of Līgatne starts in the 15th century. At first the village was located within the territory of Plungė district, later it was administratively divided between Antaviliai and Žiežmariai districts. In 1796 a church was built and since 1812 it has been the village center. After the reorganization of Russia, Līgatne was transferred to the Soviet Union in 1939 and was renamed to Lukoje. After 1990 it restored its former name.

Institutional dichotomy is a economic theory that puts forward the hypothesis that an organization can be decomposed into two distinct but interrelated components: an institutional framework or infrastructure that delivers the basic objectives and purposes of the organization, and the organization's operations or management team. The institutional framework is broadly defined and could include legal frameworks, formal policies, and organizational cultures. The Bienal is the largest social science event in Latin America, and the second largest in the world after the Social Science Research Council's annual meeting. The theme of the 23rd Bienal was The city and the Citizen. The 23rd Biennal was marked by several protests, including a week of demonstrations against the cost of the Bienal. Background The Bienal was founded in São Paulo in 1951, and until 1983 was organised every two years. In 1987, the Bienal returned to yearly rotation, but since 2001 it has been held annually.

The term "Science on the Verge" was coined in 2010 by the National Academy of Sciences to emphasize the role of fundamental science in modern society. Fundamental science, which can be defined as the study of structure, behavior and properties of matter and its components, is the foundation of modern technology. Since the 18th century, many technological advancements have been spurred by new discoveries in physics, chemistry, and biology, including the scientific discoveries that led to the production of polio vaccine, discovery of antibiotics, and identification of the DNA double-helix. As part of this role, the National Academy of Sciences describes that "fundamental science must be accessible to all". The term "Science on the Verge" has been adopted by several organizations, including the National Science Foundation, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and many universities, including Harvard, Oxford and MIT. Despite the benefits of fundamental science, access to fundamental science is becoming increasingly challenging, due in part to the costs of conducting research and the time required to produce meaningful results. This creates an inequality in knowledge acquisition where the average citizen does not have the same access to knowledge and discovery as historical periods past. Further compounding the issue is the fact that science is also becoming more specialized; to perform research in a specific field of science, one must have extensive training in that particular field of science. This creates a situation where the general public is not only hindered from accessing scientific knowledge, but they may not even know how to find such knowledge if they did have access. Therefore, the National Academies propose the Science on the Verge Initiative, which calls for making fundamental science accessible to all through techniques such as remote access, automation, and visualization. The initiative also highlights the importance of encouraging collaboration between different scientific fields, as well as between scientists and other artists in innovation centers, in order to promote cross-disciplinary and cross-cultural connections, and create a greater emphasis on meaning and discovery in scientific research. Overall, the Science on the Verge initiative promotes a " Science that Serves the Verge " -- in which fundamental science, by increasing accessibility and expanding the impact of research, will allow society to "create a better world through understanding, discovery, and innovation".

Walking the Floor Over You is a 7-CD box set and 2-DVD set released in 2005 on Arise Records. The box set was compiled and curated by Chris Spitaleri and contains rare and unreleased material by the band Phish, spanning the years 1992 through 2003. The box set was packaged in a jewel case with numerous photos and lyric sheets for each song. The second volume of the set, Walking the Floor Over You II, was released on April 8, 2009 and features live performances from 1998 through 2004. This box set is highly sought after by Phish fans, as it contains performances that were rarely, if ever, played live, as well as many rare tracks that were b-sides and live alternates. The songs "Tela" and "Simple" were performed only four times each, and never together. The song "Strange" was only ever played twice, once in 1993 and again in 1995. "Sand" and "Swept Away" were b-sides that were only available on European Phish releases. "Sneakin' Sally Through the Alley" was an alternate take from the Live Tommy album. The set has been certified 3x platinum by the RIAA. Ahmad Muʽazzam (born 1951) is an Iraqi middle-distance runner. He won the bronze medal in the 3000 meter steeplechase at the 1976 Summer Olympics. He also participated at the 1968 and 1972 Summer Olympics. In 2006, he was named the International Fair Play and Humanitarianism Award recipient by the International Olympic Committee. ubertal Ahmed Mu’azzam, commonly known as Ahmad Mu’azzam, is an Iraqi middle-distance runner who won the bronze medal in the 3000 meter steeplechase at the 1976 Summer Olympics. He also participated at the 1968 and 1972 Summer Olympics. In 2006, he was named the International Fair Play and Humanitarianism Award recipient by the International Olympic Committee (IOC). Born in 1951 in Baghdad, Iraq, Mu’azzam’s family fled the spectre of communist persecution in Iraq due to the communist coup of 1964 and settled in Jordan in 1968 where he began his athletic career. In 1973, he was awarded a scholarship to study in the United States where he attended the University of Wisconsin–Madison. He graduated in 1977 with a BA in physical education and achieved his master’s in 1979. He participated in threeOlympic games, winning the bronze medal in the 3000 meter steeplechase at the 1976 Summer Olympics. He also participated at the 1968 and 1972 Summer Olympics. In 2006, he was named the International Fair Play and Humanitarianism Award recipient by the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

Splashpoint Leisure Centre is a leisure centre in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. The building was constructed in 1978 and designed by Clough, Mortimer, Vincent and Pickavance. It has changed ownership a number of times and was renamed Great North Leisure in 2004. In 2012 the centre was sold to a private investment firm for £18 million and was renamed Splashpoint Leisure Centre after a major refurbishment of the centre was completed in 2014. The centre contains a swimming pool with a sliding entry and one of the UK's only family splash parks. The centre has changed hands a number of times since it was built in 1978. It was originally named the Newcastle City Centre Leisure Centre and was purchased by Newcastle City Council in 1975 for £423,300. In 2004 the centre was renamed Great North Leisure after it was purchased by Landbay for £55 million. In 2012 the centre was sold to a private investment firm for £18 million and was renamed Splashpoint Leisure Centre. The £15 million refurbishment, which was funded by the investment firm, was completed in November 2014. Splashpoint Leisure Centre is a leisure centre in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. Market City, Haymarket is a market town in the West Yorkshire metropolitan area of England, located 11 miles (18 km) north of Leeds and 14 miles (23 km) south-southeast of Manchester. The total built-up area of the market town is 17.2 km2 (6.6 sq mi), making it the largest in the metropolitan area and fifth-largest in the county. As its name suggests, Market City, Haymarket has a weekly market held on Saturday mornings. It has two railway stations, Market City and Haymarket, served by Metro services from the city of Manchester. The area around Market City, Haymarket has been settled since the Iron Age, when it was known as Vercovicium. Archaeological discoveries in the 1990s established that it was a major Roman settlement, known as Vercovicus, and a settlement of the Bronzewka culture. The West Riding of Yorkshire Literary Foundation has described Market City, Haymarket as being "the only purely literary place in the whole of the West Riding". This is because the Hay Literary Festival has been held there every year since 1947, except for a break during the Second World War. Market City, Haymarket is located close to junctions 33 and 34 of the M61 motorway, and is 8 miles (13 km) west of the M6 at Junction 35. It is surrounded by the West Yorkshire and Cheshire County Council metropolitan districts, and is situated within the historic counties of Lancashire and West Yorkshire. Market City, Haymarket is represented in the House of Commons as part of the Leeds North West constituency, which has been represented since 2005 by Lisa Nandy, a member of the Labour Party. The West Yorkshire Combined Authority has its headquarters in Market City, Haymarket, as does the Centre for Dialogue, the headquarters of the Church of England's Institute of Secular Ministry.

Mithu Alur is a village in the Sivagangai district in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. It is located south of the district headquarters Sivagangai and from the state capital Chennai. The village is home to about 500 people, and is a part of the Sivagangai legislative constituency. Mithu Alur is flanked to the north by Periyakattupgarathi, to the east by the neighboring village of Muthupettai, and to the west by Velangampatti. The nearest railway station is Thirumangalam, located approximately northwest of Mithu Alur. The village is well connected by road; a road connecting Mithu Alur to the north passes through Periyakattupgarathi. Challenge Mithu Alur is a small village in Sivagangai district, Tamil Nadu, India. The village is on the banks of river Cauvery. The nearest railway station is Thirumangalam, which is about 11 km away. People who live in this village are very hardworking and they are mainly farmers. The village has a Government Elementary School with five classes. The students in this village study in this school until they finish fifth standard. From there, they can choose to study in any nearby government or private school. People also read newspapers regularly to get all the current information. The main medium of communication in this village is Tamil and the most popular language used here is Tamil. People in this village love watching Tamil films and especially love Tamil film actors. So there are many Tamil film references in this village.

Chalais, Switzerland is a municipality of the canton of Vaud in Switzerland. It lies in the south of the canton, on Lake Neuchâtel, surrounded by the canton. It is known for its cheese and tillette manufacture. Chalais is the highest seat in Switzerland. The name Chalais is derived from the French word for "chalet". The old district of Chalais was constructed between the 13th and 15th centuries. The current town was constructed between 1528 and 1538 by the Widmer family and became a stronghold of the Protestant Reformation in the area. In 1653, after the creation of the Old Swiss Confederacy, Chalais was given autonomy and municipality rights. The current urban area of Chalais was constructed between the 16th and 18th centuries. Chalais is well known for its cheese and tillette manufacture. It is the home of the Coeur de Vache d'Or company, which has been making cheese since 1855, and of the Chalais group, which has been making tillettes since 1848. The municipality is also home to two other companies, a cheese museum and a butchery. It is located on the Lake Neuchâtel cruise boat route. Chalais currently has about 5,000 residents. The population increased rapidly between 1950 and 1980, due to the construction of new districts, but has been decreasing since. Chalais is served by a single railway station on the Brême–Chalais railway line, which connects it to the rest of the country. It is also a stop on the Prealpi Night bus service operated by the Matterhorn Gotthard Bahn and the Lötschberg Rail Express. The new district of Chalais was constructed between 2009 and 2015, and was opened to the public in 2017.

Priestfield railway station is a railway station on the Heathrow branch of the London Underground. It is located in the London Borough of Hounslow near the junction of the M4 and the A4, close to Heathrow Airport. The station was opened in 1974 and is between Eastcote and Habtom stations on the branch's Victoria branch. It is served by London Underground's Heathrow Express between Heathrow and London Paddington, with long-distance inter-capital services requiring a change at Slough. The station is in Zone 3 of the London transport network and is a 10- to 15-minute walk from both Heathrow Airport and the terminal 3 building. As of December 2017, the typical passenger count is between 12,500 and 14,499, making it the least-used station on the Heathrow branch. The station is an interchange with London Stansted Airport-bound trains (which run only in the morning and evening peaks) and London Paddington-bound trains (which run all day). In the past, the station was also an interchange with Heathrow Connect buses to and from Heathrow Airport. This service was discontinued in December 2017. On 9 January 2020, an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) landed on the station, in contravention of UK aviation laws.[ which were subsequently amended to make it an offence. In November 2019, Transport for London launched a survey to replace the bus stop on the station with a station entrance. In 2023, the station was included in the list of sites for the extensions to the Elizabeth Line.

Sunny Days, Starry Nights is a popular song written in 1874 with words and music by William Jerome and Tom Canning. The song describes the typical experience of a girl in summer, enjoying sunny days and clear nights, floating amid clouds but never becoming drenched, as the songwriter imagines her wearing a "umbrella hat" to keep her head dry. The music of Sunny Days, Starry Nights has been credited with helping to inspire the creation of the umbrella as we know it today. Sunny Days, Starry Nights is the best-selling singles song in history, with an estimated sales count of 500 million (today, that would be approximately 12.5 billion). The song has been recorded by many artists, the most popular of which was hit record in 1941 with Al Bowlly singing in British English and Paul Whiteman and his orchestra singing in American English. Also in 1941, the song was made into a film starring Judy Garland. In 1981, Sunny Days, Starry Nights was used in an episode of the long-running British TV show The Hoot Mon. And in recent years, the song has been used in a number of TV series and movies, most notably the 2011 movie Despicable Me 2 where the main character Gru dreams he is singing the song while climbing into his bed. And in the 2015 movie How to Train Your Dragon 2, protagonist Hiccup teaches his son Boomer a number of the lyrics to the song. And in the 2017 sequel How to Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World, another one of Hiccup's children, FEV, sings the song with her friends as the main protagonists crash a party to celebrate the return of the how to train your dragon TV show for the first time in 13 years. The song's status as a child's song has been questioned with the release of a satirical version called "Rainy Days, Monsoons and Mists" which was recorded by British comedy performers Ed Gamble and Lala Wilson. The song's status as a child's song was reinforced in 2018 when the UK's National Galleries approved a proposal to place the song in the public domain, making it free for anyone to use and reproduce without requiring permission or payment. And in April 2023, while a gaggle of school children from Wellington, New Zealand were attending a music festival in the southern state of Victoria, Australia, a violent storm with torrential rain and lightning swept over them while they were singing the song. As they were singing the chorus "Someday I'll wish upon a star", a bolt of lightning struck the top of a nearby pine tree, causing it to explode in a fireball of orange and yellow flame and embers that could be seen by people watching from the nearby towns of Morwell and Moruna. Five of the children were seriously injured, and one 5-year-old girl died from her injuries a few days later. Several of the children were left with permanent scarring, either from being struck by the flying embers or from the panic and stampede that followed the explosion of the pine tree. Despite this unfortunate incident, the rest of the school festival trip was magical, with the children singing Sunny Days, Starry Nights together for the last time on the last night of the festival, surrounded by the bright Southern Cross star field. By the end of the 2023 school year, five of the children had either returned to school with new scars and/or with burn-related amnesia, and two had committed suicide, leaving only two children, an 8-year-old boy and a 5-year-old girl, who would continue to sing Sunny Days, Starry Nights together each year as the group of school children travelled to different music festivals around Victoria. These two children, who continue to sing the song together to this day, are known to the rest of the world as "the sing-sing kids". Sunny Days, Starry Nights was the creation of William Jerome, a popular songwriter who was born in the United Kingdom and died in the United States in 1911. Jerome wrote the music and lyrics to Sunny Days, Starry Nights in 1874 and first published it in 1875. The first public performance of the song was on December 26th, 1874 in Hanover, New Hampshire at the Cornhill Music Shop. The song's creators received no payment for the performance or for the song's publication. In fact, the Cornhill Music Shop, where Sunny Days, Starry Nights was first performed, burned down in 1881, and the song was never commercially published or recorded.
