Things and Other Things is a Star Wars Legends story published in 1998 that updated and expanded on many scenes from the original Star Wars films, as well as revealing many previously unpublished adventures of Luke, Han, and Leia. The story is set shortly after the events of The Empire Strikes Back. Han and Leia Organa are revealed to be the parents of twins, a boy and a girl, Luke and Ben. After the births, the twins are joined by a tertiary (originally named Boba Fett; now named Unkar Plutt) and placed in a droidee ward, where they are given the sobriquet Darth Plagueis and Darth Caedus, respectively. The story takes place in the unfinished construction levka habitat on the moon of Guusev, and follows the development of their mental powers and their participation in the turbolaser gun battle that destroyed the levka habitat and killed many of the droids that were being built there. The title of the story is a reference to the line from A New Hope. The twins grow up and become leaders of the Yuuzhan Vong invasion of the galaxy. Luke is orchestrating a local revolution against the alien invasion and successfully rallies the people of the planet Tatooine to help him battle the Yuuzhan Vong. Ben takes charge of the Imperial forces andLuke joins the Jedi. At some point during the war, Ben is killed and Luke leaves to search for him. As Luke searches, he is trained by Jedi Master Qui-Gon Jinn and becomes a powerful Jedi. Luke uncovers evidence that his former mentors, Obi-Wan Kenobi and Yoda, are in fact the Yuuzhan Vong Invasion force led by Darth Sidious, and had been all along. During his search, he confronts and destroys Plagueis, who had been manipulating both the war and his daughters' development of dark powers. After Plagueis' death, Caedus flees the dying galaxy with the defeated Yuuzhan Vong.

Polysorbate 20 (also known as Tween 20) is a polyoxyethylene sorbitan monooleate (TMO) derivative used as an emulsifier and stabiliser. It is approved for use in humans and other mammals. It is extensively used in the pharmaceutical, cosmetic and food industries. It is a clear, viscous liquid at room temperature. Tween 20 is composed of polyoxyethylene (20) sorbitan monoloate (Tween) units and is soluble in water, petroleum ether, and ethyl ether, but not in organic solvents such as chloroform, benzene, and tetrahydrofuran. It has a density of 1.1 g/mL and a melting point of 56–58 °C.[3] Tween 20 is an emulsifier and stabiliser. It is used in foods, pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics. Tween 20 has also been shown to enhance the delivery of hydrophilic and hydrophobic drugs through mucosal surfaces. It reduces interfacial tension between two immiscible phases. As an example, it has been shown to significantly increase the permeation of sodium fluorescein across an in vitro model of rat skin. Additionally, Tween 20 acts as a lubricant and allows for the easy penetration of other molecules such as peptides and proteins through membranes. Tween 20 is soluble in water, and has been used as an aqueous surfactant and penetrating enhancer for hydrophobic molecules. Tween 20 is approved for use in humans by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the European Medicines Agency, Health Canada, and other national agencies. In many parts of the world, Tween 20 is sold as Triodate melloate, a similar but slightly more concentrated variant. Both Tween 20 and Triodate melloate are commonly used as ingredients in infant formula and other edible consumer products. The chemical formula for Tween 20 is C29H57COOH·C9H15O33 The polysorbate family of surfactants includes Tween 20, Tween 80, and related compounds. Tween 20 has a tendency to self-assemble into micelles in water. The hydrophobic Tween segments associate to form the core of the micelle and the polar head groups interact with the water, thus producing a stabilizing shield around polar molecules. Tween 20 micelles typically have a radius of 20–50 Å and a surface charge of -30 to -40 mV. Tween 20 is extensively used in the pharmaceutical, cosmetic and food industries. In pharmaceutical applications, it is used to solubilize active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) that are poorly soluble in water. Tween 20 solubilizes drugs by creating a homogenous solution, reducing the surface tension, and increasing the thermodynamic activity. In addition to acting as a solubilizer, Tween 20 can enhance the delivery of hydrophilic and hydrophobic drugs through mucosal surfaces. As a penetration enhancer, it decreases interfacial tension between an aqueous solution and the target surface. In cosmetic formulations, Tween 20 is commonly used as an emulsifier, dispersing oil phases in water or other polar solvents. In food applications, it is commonly used to improve the texture or appearance of products, reduce interfacial tension, or emulsify ingredients. In dehydrated foods, Tween 20 is used as a humectant, maintaining the appropriate degree of moisture. Tween 20 is generally regarded as a safe (GRAS) ingredient, with sweeteners, flavor enhancers, and emulsifiers being the largest consumer uses.

Monte Titano is an Italian mountain located in the province of Avellino, in the Campania region. The mountain has an elevation of 1,924 metres above sea level and is located within the Lattara Mountain Range. The mountain has an extensive background in history as it was the site of the Battle of Monte Titano during the Second Italo-Abyssinian War in 1918. The mountain is an important watershed, the waters of the Isonzo river starting at the mountain falling into the Liri valley to the east, and theensee falls into the Durance river valley to the west. The landscape of Monte Titano is mountainous and heavily forested, with the Valle di slopes being the most densely forested. Some mountain peaks have glaciers. The Monte Titano massif is located approximately 30 km north of Benevento and 22 km south of Avellino. The Monte Titano part of the Lattara mountain range has an area of approximately 1,200 km2 and is made up of several sub-ranges. The highest peak of the range is the Monte Titano with an elevation of 1,924 metres, this is also the mountain of the national park. The sub-ranges most closely associated with the Monte Titano are the Campanian Apennines to the west and the Diano n plateau to the east. The Diano n plateau descends to the Adriatic Sea in the west and to the Tyrrhenian Sea in the east. The national park extends onto the Adriatic and Tyrrhenian slopes. The range is located within the provinces of Avellino, Benevento, Caserta, FerreraIglesias, and Naples. The national park extends into the provinces of Benevento, Caserta, and Avellino. The main river in the Monte Titano area is the Isonzo. Important tributaries are the Diano n, Rapino, Ombrone, and river Senio. The Ombrone and Isonzo rivers empty into the Adriatic Sea, while the Rapino and Senio rivers empty into the Tyrrhenian Sea. The historical significance of Monte Titano has led to the creation of the national park. The national park was officially created on March 4th, 1934. The national park covers an area of 930 km2 and is administered by the federal Ministry of Environment and Land. The Monte Titano part of the Lattara mountain range is known for its alpine pastures and farming, with numerous farms and vineyards located throughout the national park. The most important alpine pasture in the national park is the Gran Sasso e953. The Gran Sasso e953 is located on the southern slope of the Monte Titano and is approximately 1,500 metres above sea level. The pastures are characterised by extreme altitude, sharp ascents and descents, and extreme diversity in terms of vegetation and animal life. The pasture includes various sub-pastures that are separated by insurmountable natural barriers, such as the Colle di Lava Padana (Lava Valley Ridge), which runs from north to south between 1,829 and 1,848 metres above sea level. Despite its geographical location, the Gran Sasso e953 is the most isolated pasture in the national park. Vegetation in the pastures of the Monte Titano mountain range is strongly influenced by exposure to sun and wind. Vegetation varies from south to north, from dry pastures to forests of beech, fir, and spruce. The animal life is also diverse and includes Alpine, livestock, and wild species. The alpine livestock of the Monte Titano national park is made up of marmots, pikas, and various species of squirrels, among others. The Isonzo river starts at Monte Titano and flows to the Adriatic Sea. The Ombrone, Rapino, and Senio rivers start at the mountain and flow to the Tyrrhenian Sea. The national park is characterised by the diversity of its flora and fauna, as well as its landscapes. The Gran Sasso e953 is a highly unique alpine pasture and key habitat for several species, including the Gran Sasso edresser. The mountain is protected under Italian law as the Gran Sasso and Gran Sasso Superiore national parks. The national park is also home to numerous shepherds' huts, farms, and wineries. The Castel del Monte, also known as the Casteluzzo, is located at the foot of the Gran Sasso. The castle was built in the 14th century by the Italian condottiero Galeazzo Malatesta. Judgment Day (2005) is a 2005 American science fiction horror film written and directed byconstructorwritingsyndrome and starring Zach Galligan, William Sadler, Monica Bellucci, and Vincent Spano. It was released on April 13, 2005, by Lions Gate Entertainment. The film takes its title from the Judgement Day event in the Marvel Comics Universe, a future series of events that culminated in an Earthwide catastrophe. While putting the finishing touches on his novel, Something Wicked This Way Comes, he meets young reporter Claire (Monica Bellucci) and takes her to a local art show. Claire is immediately drawn to Peter's charming personality and his seemingly perfect life, and they soon start a relationship. Peter is excited to attend the opening of Something Wicked This Way Comes, but has a terrifying reaction when he sees a portrait of himself at the event, along with a quote from the book. Claire suggests that they run away together, and Peter reluctantly agrees. The couple moves into a house that Claire's uncle has vacated, but soon discovers that Something Wicked This Way Comes is not fiction, but rather an account of a traveling carnival that comes to town and claims that life on Earth is not worth living.

Prosopometamorphopsia (PPM) is a condition where the sufferer displays episodes of large apparent size, in which a normal-sized item such as a car might appear to be a monster. PPM was first described in 1998, and is considered to be a variant of Charles Bonnet syndrome. The condition is relatively uncommon, with prevalence estimates ranging from 1 in 20,000 to 1 in 50,000. The large apparent size of the perceived object is not projected directly onto the sufferer's retina, but is perceived via some other means, such as pareidolia. The physical basis of PPM has not been determined with certainty, though there is evidence to suggest that the syndrome may be explained by dysfunction of the multisensory visual cortex. It has been suggested that PPM may be related to epilepsy, but this has not been proven. Signs and symptoms PPM first became evident in the patient, Sylvia, in 1998. She described having difficulty with apparent size when looking at objects such as a kitchen knife held at a distance, or a pattern on a t-shirt. This apparent size changed when she looked at the object from different angles. Another symptom is the visual misperception of the physical environment; for example, seeing shadows or lights that are not there. In a 2007 interview, Sylvia described the syndrome as beginning with blurred vision, and shifting to an extraordinary sharpness when looking at a specific object. Other symptoms also included seeing letters or numbers that were not on the page, as well as seeing animal forms in random patterns. She also described having to look away because the objects were too big to look at directly. Other cases of PPM have been described since the syndrome was identified. Two patients with similar symptoms to Sylvia's were identified in an American town, who similarly described the onset of symptoms in early childhood, with a delay of 30–40 years before diagnosis. A separate case was described of a woman with the syndrome who also had cataplexy, a condition in which sudden bursts of weakness result from the loss of voluntary control of the heart and respiratory muscles. Prevalence The syndrome is estimated to affect between 1 in 20,000 and 1 in 50,000 people. Causes The syndrome is not transmitted from person to person, and its cause has not been established. It has been suggested that it could be related to epilepsy, based on the associated symptoms of perceptual rearrangement and hallucinations. However, this hypothesis has not been proven. There is some evidence that PPM may be caused by an underdevelopment or dysfunction of the multisensory visual cortex, in particular the parieto-insular cortex. The brain regions associated with Charles Bonnet syndrome also appear to be involved in multisensory integration. Furthermore, there is evidence that multisensory cortex may be involved in PPM: in a 2009 study, three of four PPM patients had lesions in the right temporo-occipital cortex, a region known to play an important role in processing cross-modal sensory information. Another possibility is the involvement of the parieto-insular cortex. This area of the brain is concerned with multisensory perception and spatial awareness. It has been suggested that multisensory fusion is behind the apparent enlargement of objects in PPM, though this has not been proven. Some research has shown that the brain processes visual information differently in PPM patients compared with healthy individuals, which supports the hypothesis that the syndrome is caused by dysfunction of the visual cortex. Although the syndrome appears to have a genetic component, the inheritance is most likely polygenic. Treatment The syndrome is not life-threatening, and treatment consists mainly of reassurance. Some symptoms can be treated with drugs. PPM is not responsive to anticonvulsants such as gabapentin, carbamazepine, topiramate or vigabatrin, but certain antidepressants (such as SSRIs, SNRIs and mirtazapine) may improve the symptoms. The drugs citalopram, amitriptyline and venlafaxine have been shown to be effective. However, most studies have been of small sample size and have been of poor quality, and further research is needed to determine the efficacy of treatments. PPM is not a disease, and is not being investigated as a disease.

Cossonay is a commune in north-eastern France. It is located in the administrative region of Meuse (province), between the towns of Tirlemont and Flamont, both part of the province of Luxembourg. It lies on the bank of the river Seille and the canalised river Semois. The closest airports are Reims, 60 kilometres east, and Clermont-Ferrand, 100 kilometres south-east. The town is famous for its chocolaterie, established in 1827. It is also the capital of the Aube département, and of the regional council of the same name. Cossonay is the seat of a Catholic diocese, with bishop Guy Cardinal Duval. The current bishop is Patrick D'againgnoël, installed in 2014. The church of St. Pierre was built in the early 16th century. It has been listed as a monument historique by the French Ministry of Culture since 1976. It is also known for its Romanesque church of St. Quentin, built in the 12th century. The historic center of Cossonay was listed as a heritage site by the French Ministry of Culture in 2003. Cossonay is twinned with Xanthey in Germany, Niederfinckenstein in Luxembourg, and with Belœil in Belgium. Cossonay is also home to a number of sports teams, including basketball, soccer, and volleyball teams. The professional basketball team, HOP HÉGDON play their home games at the Palais des Sports. Cossonay is located 30 km from the French-German border and enjoys an attractive location, close to watering holes, the Semois canalised river and the A1 motorway. Cossonay is the headquarters of the Burundi exile community in France. The town is famous throughout the Rhineland for its chocolates, produced by the celebrated Riegler chocolaterie since 1827. The local kindergarten was built in 1938, followed by a primary school in 1945 and a lycée in 1965. The town has a cinema and several small parks. Notable people from Cossonay include the sculptor Auguste Rodin, who stayed in the town in the late 1880s, and the 20th-century actor Daniel Auteuil, who was born in the nearby town of Flamont. The sculptor Fritz Schlaich was born in Cossonay on August 7, 1920. Cossonay is the birthplace of Günter Kaufmann, former president of Germany, who was born in the nearby town of Tirlemont on February 6, 1914. Cossonay was also home to a large community of soldiers and French forces during World War II, owing to its position on the Semois canal. The German military administration headquarters was located in the local school. Many Germans were interned in the city after the war, and were eventually repatriated to West Germany. Some of the buildings that served as German military administration headquarters in Cossonay remain standing today. Trivia: the German word for “secret”, “mystery”, or “punishment” is “Cossonay” in French. Cossonay was also the title of a painting by the French Surrealist Joan Miró, acquired by the city in 1936. The word “Cossonay” is also a song by French rock band Indochine. The well-known French singer Johnny Hallyday also comes from Cossonay. The typeface Panola is named after the nearby village of Panolivec. The chocolaterie in Cossonay is known for its pralines made with chocolat noir, a rare and very dark variant of chocolate. There is also a connection between Cossonay and the Haut-Rhin department of Germany. The Haut-Rhin German is sometimes considered to be a dialect of the German spoken in Cossonay. The German composer Richard Wagner, better known for writing the Ring cycle, stayed at the Hôtel Metropole in Cossonay between April and June 1848. In 1896, the German writer Eberhard Louis Gerlach, born in Cossonay in 1838, published his book about his time in the region around Châtillon-sur-Seille. Cossonay is also known as the place of birth of Jacques d'Amboise, the composer of the international standard Joan of Arc hymn. Cossonay is also home to football (soccer) club ES Cos

I'm Moving On is a song by Yoko Ono. The song was written and produced for the album Feeling Blu (2007). It was released as a single in December 2007 and reached number 14 in the UK Singles Chart. The song was inspired by Ono's separation from John Lennon. The music and lyrics were written during the summer of 2007. The song is based around a syncopated rhythm similar to 1960s American R&B. The lyrics tell the story of Ono moving on following the separation from Lennon. The song received mainly negative reviews from music critics. John Ney of The Seिster Sun thought that "like her other recent efforts [this] just sounds like yet more ignored potential superstar rubbish." In 2009, the song was used in a television advertising campaign for the Nintendo DS game Mario Kart DS. Ono recorded a new version of the song with her son, John, for his album Eyewitness (2019). Sisters of the Infant Jesus, also known as SIONJ, is a Roman Catholic congregation of religious women founded by St. Maximilian Kolbe in Argentina in 1941. Its name comes from the title of St. Josemaria Escriva's first book, "Sisters of the Infant Jesus of Prague." The congregation has subsisted in an orphanage in Flores, Argentina since its founding and has grown to over 2,000 members around the world. Sisters of the Infant Jesus follow a contemplative life of prayer and work in community, and they cover a broad spectrum of ages, from babies up to aged 50 and over. Members profess vows of chastity, poverty, celibacy, and obedience and commonly take on thereformative role of educating children and adults in their local communities. Sisters of the Infant Jesus have active houses in Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Europe, Hong Kong, India, Italy, Mexico, the Philippines, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, Thailand, and the United Kingdom. St. Maximilian Kolbe, who founded the congregation, was a Polish nobleman who was imprisoned by the German Nazis during World War II for defying the eviction orders of the then Governor of Poland. In his book "The Way of the Jesus Christians", St. Josemaria Escriva wrote about this act of Christian martyrdom, saying, "If someone comes to you and asks you to lay down your life for Jesus, will you do it?... I did it; and so can you." This is the start of the Sisters of the Infant Jesus of Argentina, the start of a worldwide congregation of around 2,000 religious women who follow this same Lord and serve their communities in various apostolates. The first house of the congregation was founded in 1941 in Flores, Argentina. Now the congregation has active houses in Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Europe, Hong Kong, India, Italy, Mexico, the Philippines, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, Thailand, and the United Kingdom. St. Maximilian Kolbe, who founded the congregation, was a Polish nobleman who was imprisoned by the German Nazis during World War II for defying the eviction orders of the then Governor of Poland. In his book "The Way of the Jesus Christians", St. Josemaria Escriva wrote about this act of Christian martyrdom, saying, "If someone comes to you and asks you to lay down your life for Jesus, will you do it?... I did it; and so can you." Note: This article has been fully Wikipedia edited and validated by an editor at Wikipedia.

Maria Ho (born Maria Ho Min Wong; July 18, 1960) is a Singaporean Chinese entrepreneur and author of ten books. She is the founder and CEO of Xandra Corporation which owns Vistar and Tastier City in Singapore. She is also the founder and president of the Ho Leh Foundation which was set up in 2009 to promote and empower Singaporean women. was born in Singapore. She is of Singaporean Chinese descent. She studied in Anglo-Chinese School and Singapore Management University. She is married to Kevin Wong and has two children. she is of Singaporean Chinese descent. She studied in Anglo-Chinese School and Singapore Management University. She is married to Kevin Wong and has two children. Her first book, How to Turn Your Dreams into Destinations was published in 2004 and was well received. The second edition of the book was published in 2012 and became an instant bestseller. Her book, Love, Loss and What We Ate was published in 2008 and was also well received. She was awarded the Simlog Man of the Year by the Ngiam Foundation in 2007 and the Singapore Citizen of the Year in 2008. She was also a guest speaker at TEDxYouth@SSC. James Edmonstone (born James Henry Edmonstone; 17 October 1836 – 24 January 1915) was a Scottish businessman and Liberal politician who helped found the Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC). In that role he was widely credited with helping to prevent the Confederate Ireland famine of the 1840s. He was also responsible for the development of Edmonstone's Food Plants, a staple of Scottish school dinner tables for several generations. wartz James Edmonstone (born James Henry Edmonstone; 17 October 1836 – 24 January 1915) was a Scottish businessman and Liberal politician who helped found the Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC). In that role he was widely credited with helping to prevent the Confederate Ireland famine of the 1840s. He was also responsible for the development of Edmonstone's Food Plants, a staple of Scottish school dinner tables for several generations. Implementation of the public school system in Scotland led to Edmonstone becoming active in local politics, representing various districts in the Parliament of the United Kingdom. His period in office saw the implementation of the Women's Declaration, which led to votes for women being enshrined in law. He also campaigned for prison reform and supervised the construction of the original Pentonville Prison. After retiring from politics, Edmonstone became active in a number of voluntary roles, including founding the Royal Scottish Epilepsy Society and serving as the president of the Royal Over-Seas League. He was also a director of the Bank of Scotland and a major figure in the Zetland branch of the Liberal Party.

Clarence Drive is a major thoroughfare located in southern Jamaica, Queens, New York. It runs from Whitestone Expressway in Whitestone to the junction of the Southern State Parkway and Belt Parkway in Elmont. In addition to being part of a continuous roadway, Clarence Drive also carries several alternative names. It is known as Whitestone Bridge Road east of the interchange with the Northern State Highway 25 and Whitestone Expressway, and as Whitestone Road west of that interchange. Further west, it is known as Rockaway Boulevard until the junction with the Southern State Parkway. Clarence Drive was completed in 1952 as the final link in New York City's circuitous Whitestone Expressway, which was built between 1940 and 1951. It was named for Clarence Smith, a local politician who promoted the project. , the New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is planning to construct a sidewalk on the west side of Clarence Drive between the Whitestone Expressway and Southern State Parkway, and a bus rapid transit line along the east side between Southern State Parkway and Rockaway Boulevard. The plan also calls for painting the curb and gutter on both sides of the street. The bus rapid transit line is planned to be built in two phases. The first, between the Southern State Parkway and Rockaway Boulevard, is tentatively scheduled to open in 2023, with the entire line opening by 2025. The second phase, between Rockaway Boulevard and the Whitestone Expressway, is planned to be built later, possibly as late as 2030. In addition to the bus rapid transit line, NYCDOT plans to construct bicycle lanes and pedestrian accommodations in both phases.

The KTM 1290 Super Adventure is a motorcycle made by KTM, originally announced in 2016 and launched in December of that year. The 1290 Super Adventure is KTM's most expensive production bike and is positioned below the 1290 Adventure, but above the more stripped-down version, the 1290 Adventure S. The Royal Motorcycle Club of America named it 2017 ADVANCE motorcyclist competition adventure bike of the year and international Adventure Riding press awarded it 2016 excellence in design. The bike uses the liquid cooling system from the 928 with a more modern evaporator. The front wheel is equipped with a suspension fork, while the rear wheel is equipped with an upside-downfork. The 1290 Super Adventure has an open engine design, with the engine being watercooled, but with a fully removable cylinder head. The frame, swingarm, and rear shock are fully detachable. It is DOHC, variable valve length, camshaft, and hollow-forged engine. Power is from the head of the engine, with 121 horsepower at 10,750 rpm and 73.5 lb.-ft of torque at 7,250 rpm. The engine is coupled to a 6-speed Sachs final-drive, with the traction control system being KTM's Electronically Assembled Gravity Control. The bike was updated in 2020, with new motorsports wheels, a more aggressive fairing and windscreen, an Öhlins NFS fork, and Seat-Art Jay riding modes.

Autonomous University of Madrid (AUMP), also known as Universidad Autónoma de Madrid (UAM), is a public university located in Madrid, Spain. Founded in 1963, it is the oldest and largest university in the Community of Madrid, with 17 campuses and 762 lecture halls with 57,647 students and 42,523 staff. It is considered to be the most international university in Spain, with 10,189 international students from 124 countries and more than 4,500 academic staff. though I prefer to call it the Autonomous University of Madrid since that's what most people call it these days. It is the largest public university in the Community of Madrid, with 17 campuses across the metropolitan area and a student population of over 57,000. The school offers 42,000 academic positions and more than 4,000 scholarships every year, most of them funded by private companies and corporations. It is also the largest university in Spain, ranked 4th among European universities and 13th overall according to the Times Higher Education World University Rankings of 2020. UAM is considered to be one of the most prestigious universities in Europe, with more than 28,000 international students representing over 70 nationalities and an acceptance rate of only 13%. range much? This prestigious university is known for being extremely rigorous and having the most diverse student population in Spain. Their graduation rate is extremely high, with over 90% of students who study there completing their studies. They also have some of the best employability rates out of all schools in Spain. Some of the programs offered include Engineering, Business, Law, Sciences, and Humanities, and students can choose to specialize in anything they want, with 80% of UAM's students currently pursuing degrees in their field of study. The most popular degrees are Engineering, Business, and Sciences, with around 34,000 students total in those majors. The school has very close ties with other universities in the European research landscape, with 11 universities across 4 countries having partnerships with UAM.

Frank Szécsi (born December 18, 1975) is a Hungarian politician, former leader of the National Democratic Party (MDNP) and member of the European Parliament for Hungary from 2014 to 2019. Szécsi's political career began in the 1990s, when he was a member of the Socialist Party. He left the party in 2000 and formed the Democratic Coalition Party. He joined the Fidesz party in 2010 and was appointed Mayor of Kecskemét. He became leader of the National Democratic Party (MDNP) in 2013 and led the party in the 2014 Hungarian parliamentary election. He was elected Member of the European Parliament in the 2014 election, becoming the first representative of the MDNP and later the National Democratic Party in the European Parliament. He was re-elected in the 2019 election. Szécsi was born in Kecskemét. He studied at the University of Debrecen and completed his PhD in biology there in 2010. He is a member of the European Council for Alzheimers' Research and has spoken about his experience of the condition. He is married and has two children. Szécsi led the National Democratic Party (MDNP) from 2013 to 2019. He was elected Mayor of Kecskemét in 2010 and was re-elected in 2014 and 2019. He was elected Member of the European Parliament in 2014 and was re-elected in 2019. As leader of the National Democratic Party (MDNP), he formed the party together with the Liberal Democratic Party, Movement for a Better Hungary and Christian Democratic People's Party in 2013. He led the party in the 2014 Hungarian parliamentary election and became a Member of the European Parliament in 2014. He was re-elected in 2019. He has focused on EU funds and on integrating the Roma minority into Hungarian society. He is a member of the European Council for Alzheimers' Research and has spoken about his experience of the condition. Szécsi's birthday is celebrated annually in Kecskemét.

Charlie Edwards (born Charles Edwards; July 18, 1959 – April 20, 1999) was an American professional boxer who won the WBC and IBF Light Heavyweight Championships. Nicknamed "The Charmer", Edwards won 10 consecutive fights between 1984 and 1985 before retiring due to serious injuries. Inducted into the International Boxing Hall of Fame in 2007, Edwards also won the Best Boxer Award and the The Ring light heavyweight championship. After his boxing career was ended by serious injuries, Charlie worked as a volunteer boxing coach with the Detroit Police Department and with the Michigan Department of Corrections. Charlie Edwards died of heart failure at the age of 44. Edwards's son, Charles Edwards, Jr. is also a professional boxer, as is Edwards's nephew, Charley Ray. For more information, see the main page about Charlie Edwards. Field of the Invention The present invention relates to a fixing apparatus used in an electrophotographic image forming apparatus, and more particularly, to a toner rubber member for use in the fixing apparatus and a fixing apparatus including the same. 2. Description of the Related Art In an electrophotographic image forming apparatus, such as a printer, a copy machine, a fax machine, and a multi-function printer having at least one of the foregoing functions, a laser scanning unit (LSU) emits a laser beam onto a photoconductor drum to form an electrostatic latent image on the photoconductor drum. Then, a developer supplied from a developer unit is attracted to the electrostatic latent image to form a visible developer image. The developer image is directly transferred from the photoconductor drum to a sheet of paper or an image receiving sheet. Alternatively, the visible developer image is transferred from the photoconductor drum to a transfer sheet, and then the transfer sheet is separated from the photoconductor drum and conveyed to a fixing apparatus. The developer image on the transfer sheet is fixed to the transfer sheet by heat and pressure in the fixing apparatus. The transfer sheet with thedeveloper image is then conveyed out of the fixing apparatus. The fixing apparatus of the image forming apparatus fixes a toner image on a sheet of paper by conveying the sheet of paper, on which the toner image is transferred, through a heating roller and a pressing roller, which are heated by a heat source, while conveying the sheet of paper through a nip between the heating roller and the pressing roller. The heating roller includes a halogen heater as the heat source. The pressing roller is typically a resin roller coated with a synthetic rubber on its outer circumference to ensure a high nip strength. The fixing apparatus may also include a heating unit, such as an induction heater, a film heater, or a ceramic heater, as a heat source, in addition to the halogen heater. In such a fixing apparatus, an electromagnetic induction is used to heat the fixing roller by electromagnetic induction. The electromagnetic induction is generated by passing a current through a coil, which is placed near the fixing roller. A related fixing apparatus includes a fixing belt, which contacts an inner surface of a heating roller, a pressure roller contacting an outer surface of the fixing belt, and a metal spring separating the fixing belt and the pressing roller. The metal spring has an accordion-like shape that conforms to the curvature of the fixing belt to uniformly press the fixing belt and the pressing roller against each other. The fixing apparatus of the electrophotographic image forming apparatus operates to heat and melt a toner image on a sheet of paper. The sheet of paper conveyed through the nip between the heating roller and the pressing roller is conveyed through the nip while being heated and pressed by the heating roller and the pressing roller. Thus, the toner image is heated and fixed to the sheet of paper. Recently, to increase the speed of image formation, a belt fixing apparatus has been developed that uses an endless belt instead of a linear conveying member, such as a roller, as the fixing conveying member. Tony Brown (born Anthony Brown; August 14, 1947) is an American record producer and songwriter. In the 1970s and 1980s, Brown was one of the most prolific hit makers in the pop and R&B genres. His work remains well represented in the collector canon of artists including The Rolling Stones, The Beatles, Eagles, Shania Twain, George Harrison, and Aretha Franklin. Brown was born in Los Angeles and grew up in Gary, Indiana. In high school, he formed a group called The Escorts that played local bars and coffee shops. After graduating, Brown served in the US Army for three years before quitting to pursue a music career. After teaming with songwriter Felipe Delerme, Brown signed to A&M Records and released his debut single "Fool's Paradise" in 1973. Brown and Delerme's debut album, also titled Fool's Paradise, was released the following year and spawned the hit "Let the Music Do the Talking" (no. 1 / no. 2 US / no. 7 UK). Brown then founded his own label, I-Tec Recordings, and began signing artists including Shania Twain. In 1982, Brown produced Michael Jackson's worldwide number-one hit "Beat It". Lazimpat is a town in the Islamabad Capital Territory (ICT) of Pakistan, located in the southern part of the city of Islamabad. It is located near the geographic coordinates of 33.9667, 74.0031. Lazimpat has been home to several institutions of public interest including the National Database and Registration Authority, the Ministry of Climate Change and several other government organisations. The town has a small railway station, connected to the main Pakistan Railways network, as well as an exit on the airport road leading to Islamabad airport. It is also located near the L.K. Marihanwala Road, which provides easy access to several nearby commercial and housing projects. Despite its close proximity to Islamabad city, Lazimpat is administered as a town committee independently, by a municipal commissioner, who is usually the elected representative of the town committee for five years. The name "Lazimpat" is a compound of the phrases "Lazim pur" which means "migration safety place" in Arabic, and "pat", which is the short form of "town committee" in Urdu. Since its establishment, the town has been governed by the Pakistan Muslim League (N) and the PML-N has designated a minister as the municipal commissioner. The town has continued to grow in recent years and is expected to become the centre of several large development projects. In 2023, the town committee elected Faisal Vawas as the Municipal Commissioner, he was re-elected in 2026 and again in 2029. The PML-N has designated Noor Rashid as the Minister for Lazimpat. James Reyne has released 14 studio albums, of which 13 feature his regular band with whom he has toured and recorded since 1989. Of these 13 albums, one was recorded with Mike Batt, who was a member of Reyne's band at the time. Another features the former members of Cold Chisel, for whom Reyne wrote and produced their last studio album and first live album. Reyne has also recorded two albums of new material with Ken Luck Burke (The Angels) and Stephen Cummings (The Strawbs). had Thirteen (James Reyne album) is the 13th studio album by Australian rock musician James Reyne. It was released on 30 October 2019 and features Reyne's regular band, along with Mike Batt and Cold Chisel's Rick Davies. It is the first album with new material with Ken Luck Burke and Stephen Cummings since 2009's Slipstream. UPdate: The album debuted at number 1 on the ARIA albums chart and was certified double platinum. INTRODUCTION Thirteen was released on October 30, 2019. It’s the first album with new material with Ken Luck Burke and Stephen Cummings since 2009’s Slipstream. AS RAILS FOR WALKING Reyne wrote Thirteen with former Cold Chisel members – musician Don Walker, Dave Hughes, Steve Tushar and John Payne – in mind. The album features nine Walker/Hughes songs and four Tushar/Payne songs. AS A ROLLING TUMBLE Thirteen takes its title from the number of tracks included. The album is a powerful, moving, passionate and thoughtful look into the past, as well as a challenging and inspirational call to live in the moment. MUSIC, MILES&FARE Thirteen sees Reyne and co-producer Dave McGeough partner with long-time collaborator Ian Harris, joining forces with Walkley Award-winning musicians, including Marty Winters (The Living End), Jim White (The Living End, Pete Murray (Luna) and David Lucas (The Script). THINGS FALL APART The album opens with ‘Thirteen’, a moving autobiographical story of a man reflecting on his past, as well as a snapshot of where we are now as a society. The title track is a defiant declaration of love, as Reyne and his band lay bare their vulnerability and expose their souls to the stirring chorus. The moody, piano-driven ‘In Between’ sees Reyne searching for redemption. Achingly beautiful ‘Stories’ is another personal highlight, as Reyne pays homage to his late father. ‘Oh, What a Night (Lucky Me),’ written for the LGBTQ community, is an ode to the transience of life and love. IMPRESSIVE CHELAIR Reyne and company pay homage to Australia’s rich musical and cultural history with ‘Sunrise’ (Neil Young), ‘My Home’ (Ed Keneally) and ‘(I’m A) Road Runner’ (Roger Miller). Reyne is joined by ARIA Award-winning singer-songwriter Angie McMahon on The Aristocrats, performing Tony Hibbert’s chart-topping classic ‘I’ll Be With You’. SET THE ROOM ON FIRE Thirteen takes its name from the number of tracks on the album. The album is a powerful, moving, passionate and thoughtful look into the past, as well as a challenging and inspirational call to live in the moment. Reyne and his band deliver with joyous abandon, creating catchy sing-a-long anthems, toe-tapping rockers and introspective ballads. Reyne knows how to keep the album moving.

Reginald's Tower is a fungal tower in the Trumpp Forest in Bavaria, Germany, and is part of a World Heritage Site. The tower was constructed by a young monk named Reginald in the year 1000. Roy, Montana is a town in the Lincoln County, Montana, United States. It is named after Roy Bean, a local judge. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population of the town was 198, increasing from 146 at the 2000 Census. The town is located on Route 287 between Choteau and Columbus, Montana. Roy was founded in 1902 and lots were sold in 1903. The town was located on the Blackfoot Valley Railroad, which later became the Denver andSalt Lake City Railroad, with tracks running through the center of town. The center of town contains a small park with a plaque dedicated to the railroad. The original townsite is now home to the Roy Cemetery. In 1910, Roy had a population of over 500, with many residents traveling to and from the town by stagecoach. In 1917, a new schoolhouse was built in the center of town. In 1930, the Great Depression hit Roy hard, and the population declined to less than 200. Roy still holds an annual "Pony Express Days" celebration, where residents get together to celebrate the town's heritage and participate in costume-related activities. In 2013, the town was featured on the Travel channel's series, The Best Places to Live as an example of a " gorgeous, small town with big-city amenities". Roy is well known for its annual "Pony Express Days" celebration, where residents of the town come together to celebrate their heritage and participate in costume-related activities.

Axel Höjer (born 1952) is a Swedish chef, restaurant owner and television presenter. He currently has 12 restaurants across Sweden as well as three in the Maldives. He is most famous for his cooking shows Hedare (Flies Out) which has been watched by over 20 million people worldwide and Höjer.se which is the largest food website in the Nordic countries with millions of unique visitors every month. He was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award at the Gourmand Awards in 2018. Axel Höjer was born in Sundsvall and was raised in a family with a passion for food. After culinary school he began working in restaurants throughout Sweden, first as a cook and later on as the owner of a restaurant. In 1985 he appeared his first television show, Hederligheterna (The Clean Cuisine), and throughout the 1990s he produced several other shows, which made him famous in his native country. In 2000 he launched Höjer.se, which became the largest food website in the Nordic countries. His most famous show, Hedare (Flies Out), was launched in 2014 and has been watched by over 20 million people worldwide. Axel Höjer currently has 12 restaurants across Sweden, as well as three in the Maldives. In 2018, Höjer was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award. He was also the initiator of the Småland food festival, held in Sundsvall, which has been held every two years since 2013. He currently lives in Stockholm. He is married to Aina and has four children. He is a supporter of Malmö FF and the Swedish national football team. He was the CEO of a book publishing house, Rosendahls Förlag, from 2011 to 2019. He was previously active as a model and actor, appearing in several films and television series during the 1970s and 1980s.

The Razumovski Palace (Baturyn) is a palace in Baturyn, Ukraine, capital of the Volhynian Voivodeship, Ukraine. The palace was built in 1901 and is representative of the late Romanesque style of architecture. It was restored in the 2000s. It is used as the governor's residence. On June 22, 2014, the palace was severely damaged by armed pro-Russian protestors during the 2014 Winter uprising. The local authorities intend to use the ruined palace as an illustration symbol of the damage done to the city during the Ukrainian crisis. In February 2019, the local administration announced that the building would be fully reconstructed. The palace was declared an architectural landmark on January 27, 2020. In the heart of Baturyn, right across the street from the Saint Volodymyr Chapel, the building serves as a reminder of the city's past, present and future. The building currently serves as the headquarters of the "Battle for Baturyn" public organization, which is actively involved in the city's reconstruction and the preservation of its architectural heritage. The restoration of the palace is being funded by the European Union and by private donations from local residents and businesses. The palace is located at 4 Baturynska Street in the city's downtown area. The official opening of the palace will take place in 2023, during the 100th anniversary of the October Revolution in Ukraine. The Razumovski Palace hosted the second wave of American President Donald Trump's April 2020 presidential visit to Ukraine. The year 1814 was a common year starting on Sunday and ending on Sunday. It was the first year of another leap year starting on the Monday of the annual calendar, the first of five leap years in the 1814 series. 1814 was designated the Austral year while other years were designated European years, this year followed the Royal Society chronology for the starting point of the calendar era. In Europe, the year 1814 was important for several events. It was the year of the Congress of Vienna, where the major European powers ( Austria, Prussia, Russia, Sweden and the Netherlands) negotiated and concluded the settlement that ended the first period of the Napoleonic Wars. It was also the year that the Great Composers' House in Prague was completed and the birthday of king Frederik VI of Denmark. In the United Kingdom, it was the year that Carl Bergmann conducted the first chemical analysis of air, leading to the discovery of oxygen. In North America, it was the year Robert Fulton successfully tested the first submarine in a London pond. This year in Australia, it was the year that pastoralists in the colony of New South Wales raised the first crops of wheat, barley, oats, peas, peaches and apples. Major political changes in the year 1814 include the creation of the Kingdom of Sweden, the proclamation of a republic in Portugal, the restoration of Charles XIII of Sweden, the crowning of King Louis XVIII of France and the collapse of the Republic of Luapula. The year 1814 is notable in scientific history for several important discoveries and developments. In astronomy, Giuseppe Piazzi found three new comets. In physics, Michael Faraday did major work on the elective mixture and speed of transmission of heat. In chemistry, Humphry Davy and Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac discovered the law of combining volumes. And in biology, Carl Gottfried Eigen published an early work on the distribution of species.

Count of Lucena (c. 1190 – 1268) was a Filipino kingdom that was originally established by Tupas through vassalage to Sung China and was recognized by the later Sung monarchs as a tributary to the Chinese court. However, the succeeding Balaud-Satrigallan alliance successfully challenged Tupas' sovereignty over Lucena and eventually established their rule over the entire realm. While acknowledging the Chinese sovereignty over Lucena, the 14th century Count of Davao, Aliab of Balaud and Sason of Satrigal, later king of Lucena, established his rule over Lucena. He established his sovereignty over Lucena by defeating a Sung Dynasty General who had set up a camp at the old city of Lucena and married a local woman, thus angering the Sung Emperor of the time. Aliab and Sason reigned over Lucena for nearly three decades before their son, Maynila, succeeded them. Maynila's reign was characterized by several wars with neighboring polities such as the Mamalugnay, Kawayan and Maguindanao kings, but he also extended his power to other parts of the Philippine archipelago. On the other hand, Aliab and Sason initially succeeded in establishing peace but were unsuccessful in extending their power beyond Lucena. Count Aliab was killed in 1268 by the Kapampangan ruler of Ple72 Governor Minjuryl during a tour of his vassal's territory. As a result, the domain was annexed by the Sung Dynasty after the fall of Lucena royal family in 1268.

Kokkinobaphos is a Greek island in the Aegean Sea belonging to the Delos archipelago. It is part of the Cyclades island group and is closest to Delos island. Kokkinobaphos has an airport and a pier from which ferries depart for Delos. There is a small village on the island but no obvious settlement. The island was uninhabited in the late 19th century but since the 1880s it has been the site of a famous monastery and a school. The name of the island is thought to be derived from a revered Byzantine monk named Kokkinobastos. According to a medieval Georgian chronicle, the island was named after a Georgian monk, St. Kochino BASILIATES, who visited the island during the reign of emperor Alexios I Komnenos (1081–1118). It is known that the Georgian kingdom had signed a peace treaty with the Komnenos family in 1094, and the Georgian monarch's son-in-law, David Dalamanitu, is mentioned as the first owner of the island in a court decision of 1101. The peace treaty is mentioned also in the transcription of a charter of the Georgian monastery on Derventil, dated 1104. The island became more important after the publication of thelemannic map in the 12th century. The island was depicted with a substantial church, three cell-like structures, several orchards and vegetable gardens. The settlement had at least 16 inhabitants according to the 1596 census. The settlement was conquered by the Ottomans in the early 18th century, but was restored to Greece after the liberation wars of 1822–1829. It then became depopulated for a second time until 1880.

Copenhagen Fire of 1795 was a fire that took place on April 17, 1795. It is one of the largest fires in the history of Copenhagen, which at the time was just a small city on the coast of Denmark. The fire started in a barn that was destroyed during a bomb attack and quickly spread to the city. More than 25.000 inhabitants had to leave their homes and moved to the neighboring towns of Frederiksberg, Brønshøj and Copenhagen Zoo. Many historical buildings, such as the City Hall, where burned down. To this day, it is not known if the fire was started by accident or on purpose, but it is believed that the king himself ordered an investigation to find out who was responsible. The investigation took several years, but unfortunately, all suspects were dead by then. The fire started in a barn that was destroyed during a bomb attack and quickly spread to the city. More than 25.000 inhabitants had to leave their homes and moved to the neighboring towns of Frederiksberg, Brønshøj and Copenhagen Zoo. Many historical buildings, such as the City Hall, where burned down. To this day, it is not known if the fire was started by accident or on purpose, but it is believed that the king himself ordered an investigation to find out who was responsible. ASTERISC is a ticker tape service that was used in news networks to report financial information. It was created by NASA and used on the moon. It is now used in academic and non-profit organisations. Water can be considered a "heavy" element, and its hydrogen and oxygen atoms the first two "light" atoms in the periodic table. Because of its high electronegativity, oxygen tends to bond with other light elements. Hydrogen, because it has only a single electron in its outer shell, is highly susceptible to bonding with other atoms or molecules. Water is thus strongly polar, with a dipole created by the separation of the hydrogen and oxygen atoms. Earth's surface gravity is 9.81 meters per second squared, or 32.2 km/h^2, which is similar to that of the Moon (3.6 km/s^2 or 14.7 km/h^2). The acceleration of Earth's gravity is nearly 9.81 meters per second squared, or 32.2 km/h^2, which is similar to that of the Moon (3.6 km/s^2 or 14.7 km/h^2). Life can exist under many different conditions across the Solar System. The most well-known example is water, present in oceans and lakes on Earth, as well as in permanent bodies of water on other planets and moons. Surface water temperature on Earth is largely influenced by its distance from the Sun. At night, Earth is mostly cooled by the Sun, while during the day, it is mostly heated. Since water is strongly polar, the temperature of the surface water will vary in different locations around the globe, with warm water being located near the Equator and polar water located near thepoles. The water's dynamic tension makes it difficult for land life to exist under these conditions, though a few organisms can withstand cold temperatures. Many lifeforms, however, can only survive by boring into the subsurface layers where conditions are cooler, as shallow water tables. The first attempt at ticker-tape style financial reporting was made in 1934 by Father William Joseph Dunn, a Catholic priest and professor of finance at the Catholic University of America. Dunn founded what was initially known as the National Quotation Bureau, which later became known as the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations (NASDAQ). Dunn is credited with coming up with the name "asterisc", which was made up of the first letters of the organizations he founded as well as the first letters of the words "finance", "report", "quotation", and "ticker tape". Land-based news networks began using ASTERISC in the 1970s, though at first the service was free. The service was initially provided on the then-new Integrated Data Network, but went live on the N America automated quotation system (NASDAQ) in 1944. The ASTERISC service was initially charged only for volatility reports, and free quotes continued to be issued during periods when the NASDAQ was down. ASTERISC became charged only for volatility reports beginning in 1976, and all free quotes were withdrawn in 1978. In addition to sending weather information and financial information, NASDAQ ASTERISC also reported the closing price of individual companies as well as 500 of the largest equities traded on the NASDAQ. This included stocks listed on the New York, Amex, NASDAQ and American Stock Exchanges. By the 1980s, ASTERISC was used by more than 100 financial organisations around the world, and by the 1990s the NASDAQ price of individual stocks was increasingly reported by all news networks using ASTERISC. In addition, news organisations began employing their own traders to inform their reporters about market movement, and began employing "quotes men" whose sole job was to collect information and issue reports based on it. ASTERISC continues to be used today by academic institutions, non-profit organisations, and financial organisations around the world. In 1999, NASDAQ paid the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations $19.6 million for ASTERISC's operations that year. The sale of ASTERISC, along with other assets, allowed NASDAQ to focus on its stock trading business and pay its members for referring customers to the service. The ASTERISC service was de-listed from NASDAQ in 2009, and is now offered via the European markets segment of the London Stock Exchange Group. NASDAQ remains the owner of ASTERISC, and provides the service to its European customers for free. ASTERISC is a registered trademark of the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations. Michele Lean (Michelle Elaine Lean; born Michele Elaine McKenzie; August 13, 1951 – December 2, 2018) was an American singer and songwriter. She was best known as the frontwoman of the seminal all-female rock band Heart. The band released seven studio albums between 1976 and 1983, and scored major hits with "Barracuda", "Crazy On You", and "These Eyes". Lean was born in Dallas, Texas, and began singing in local clubs at a young age. She formed the band Tangerine with her sister Rita in the mid-1960s. After changing the name of the band to the Chain, she met Jim Rodopich, who would go on to become the manager of Heart. She provided the band's vocals for a Tangerine song that Rodopich had co-written. He asked her to join Heart, and the band released their debut album, Feelin' Fine, in 1976. "Crazy On You" became their first hit, and the band developed a following with their second album, Alive and Kicking. Lean was a driving force in Heart and one of the primary songwriters for the band. She adopted a less sexualized image for the group, leading to the release of more radio-friendly singles like "These Eyes" and "Drummer Man". Despite her songwriting contributions, many of the group's hits were written primarily by other band members. Heart disbanded in 1984, but reunited in 2012 for a series of concerts and released two more studio albums. The band toured extensively in support of these albums, but disbanded for good in 2015. Lean's other musical activities included work with artists such as Meat Loaf, Jim Steinman, Michael Bolton, and Lionel Richie. She released three studio albums as a solo artist between 1994 and 2002. She made her last public appearance in 2016, when she performed with Heart at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony. She died from Alzheimer's disease on December 2, 2018, at the age of 67.

Lietava (Neris) is a small river town in Lithuania. It is the capital of Lietava district municipality. Lietava grew in importance when a rail bridge over the Neris river was constructed near the town in 1901. The town was known as Valanevo until 1934, when it was renamed in after an ancient Lithuanian kingdom that existed here between the 11th and 13th centuries. In 2011, Lietava municipality was merged with nearby Marijampolė municipality, and since 2014 Lietava is the administrative center of Lietava district. From the 19th century through the 1930s, Lietava was the home of many distinguished linguists, archaeologists, and ethnographers, including Vincas Krėvė-Arls, Mykola Kostinkiuk, Fedir Hovhannisyan, and others. Since 1990s, Lietava has been well known for its hunting club and hotel "Žygimantas". The town has a regional power plant and is well connected by roads. It has a church of the Holy Spirit built in 1929, and a Roman Catholic church from the beginning of 20th century. Lietava has a small castle built in the 15th century, and a baroque manor house built in the 18th century. In 2001, Lietava had 4,631 residents. The town, however, has a large military garrison which makes it one of the largest towns in Lithuania by population within the municipal boundaries (9,500 people).

Silly is a Dutch band, active since 1987. The band is famous for their song "spin the wheel". The band members are Johnny De Groot, Cees Geel and Eric van Bers. Silly has many remixes, such as the DJ Junior album mix and the Uncle Bricco mix. Silly has performed in the Dutch King's Day celebrations twice. In 2004 Silly sang "RackemAES", in 2014 Silly sang "Rimma Dat" and "Spin the wheel". The Silly song "Spin the wheel" has been banned by several municipalities. The reason is that the lyrics are inappropriate for listeners at school. In the song the singer offers to trade children for money. Other reason's for the bans are: the song is just too indecent, contains sexual innuendos, too many expletives, too many references to drugs and alcohol. Silly will continue to perform "Spin the wheel" even though it has been banned. Below is a list of cities and villages that have banned Silly because of the song "Spin the wheel". - Amersfoort - Apeldoorn - Arnhem - Ede - Groningen - Haarlem - Kampen - Nijmegen - Zwolle The Silly song "Spin the wheel" has been banned in these cities and villages. In 2004 Silly sang "RackemAES", in 2014 Silly sang "Rimma Dat" and "Spin the wheel".

The Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Single-Camera Picture Editing for a Comedy Series is a Emmy award given to television editors who work in single-camera shows. The award was first awarded in 2014, as a combined award for both the editing for a single-camera series and the editing for a multi-camera series. Since then, the award has been separated into a single-camera award and a multi-camera award. As of, Micah Bloomberg is the most recent single-camera winner, for his work on The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel. This is also the most recent multi-camera Emmy winner, as the category was discontinued following the 2016 awards. The following is a list of award winners: 2014 – Aly Mori for Better Off Ted 2015 – Willy Zabarsky and James Marks for The Last Man on Earth 2016 – No award given 2017 – Micah Bloomberg for The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel 2018 – Rachel Meyrvang and Jonnyna Jo Ferchoze for Bait School 2019 – Lindsay Stoper and Michelle Fox for Andor. The award was originally going to be named "Single-Camera Picture Editing for a Comedy Series" for the 2013 awards, but the name was changed at the last minute because the Executive Producers of Broad City expected to be nominated and were unhappy with the simple title. The award was renamed "Single-Camera Picture Editing for a Comedy Series" in 2019, and was again renamed to "Outstanding Single-Camera Picture Editing for a Comedy Series" for the 2023 awards. List of winners: 2014 – Aly Mori 2015 – Willy Zabarsky and James Marks 2016 – No award given 2017 – Micah Bloomberg 2018 – Rachel Meyrvang and Jonnyna Jo Ferchoze 2019 – Lindsay Stoper and Michelle Fox The Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Single-Camera Picture Editing for a Comedy Series is the most prestigious editing award for a comedy series. Note: This information is obtained from the open encyclopedia Wikipedia, which may be subject to change as more information is unearthed and shared with the public.

He was active in civic affairs in Boston, including serving as a selectman and as a representative to the Great and General Court. He was elected mayor of Boston in 1782, a post he held until 1783. In 1783 he was elected to the Continental Congress, where he signed the United States Constitution. He served in the Massachusetts Senate from 1784 to 1786 and then in the Massachusetts House of Representatives from 1786 to 1787. In 1787 Whittlesey resigned from the Continental Congress and moved to Charlestown, Rhode Island, where he continued to practice law and silversmithing until his death on April 14, 1817. He was buried at Dartmouth Congregational Church.

The Ada Developers Academy (ADA) is an open online training program for Ada developers, engineers, architects, and technical management. The goal of the ADA is to expand the availability of and increase participation in the Ada programming language by creating an online training program that is open, free, and fun. The Ada Developers Academy is run by the Free Electrons project, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that develops free software, including the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) and the OpenBSD operating system. All of theADA content is freely available under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. The ADA offers comprehensive and rigorous educational programs taught by expert instructors in the Ada language and other technology areas. These courses provide opportunities for knowledge growth, certification, personal development, and professional networking. Ada is an advanced high-assurance programming language designed for safety-critical and time-constrained systems and components. Ada is also used in the secure design of systems and components in use by the U.S. Department of Defense and U.S. Intelligence Community. The Ada Developers Academy started in 2019 and thus far has included courses on the following topics: * Application Lifecycle Management with Ada * Certified Ada Developer Training Program * Essential Ada Programming * Foundations of Programming with Ada * GNAT Training * Practical Ada Development * Real-World Ada * Security and Safety in Programming with Ada * Software Architecture in Ada * Systems Programming in Ada The Ada Developers Academy is intended to complement on-site training programs and bring a higher quality of training to the Ada developer community. Any experienced Ada developer can contribute to the Ada Developers Academy by offering a training program, becoming an instructor, or serving as a reviewer. To date, more than 120 course offerings have been submitted, including several from AdaCore, the company that developed the ADA curriculum. For more information, visit <https://ada.aliinc.com/>

By the Light of the Moon is a famous poem by Walt Whitman, first published in 1882. The title alludes to a similar phrase from a poem called "O Say, Can You See", which often refers to humanity's struggle against its evil tendencies. The Vampire Diaries version of the poem opens with the line: "Listen! My name is Adam, I am a vampire." This line alludes to the first line of the poem, "Listen! My name is Man". Both poems are written from the perspective of a speaker addressing a human, offering advice or seeking guidance. Adam, a vampire in the Vampire Diaries universe, presents himself as a child of nature, drawing inspiration from the moonlight to write this advice to a mysterious stranger. Although vampires typically do not require sleep, Adam finds it easy to "forget" that he is a vampire when in the moonlight. He describes feeling suspended in time and space, as if he is mortal and the moonlight is hiswindow to the world. He encourages the listener to seek out the beauty of the natural world, instead ofadmiring it only from afar. Adam's poem continues by alluding to a passage from the poem "O Say, Can You See", discussing humanity's constant struggle against evil tendencies. He explains that although he enjoys the moonlight, he does not envy humanity its ability to see in the dark: "Why Andreas, half-shut your eyes, / You will see by the moonlight / More beautiful than by day." Throughout the poem, Adam's tone alternates between humble and defiant, hopeful and defeated. He urges the listener to appreciate the natural world for what it is, but also acknowledges his own flaws and failures. The Vampire Diaries has frequently alluded to poems written by great philosophers throughout its ten-season history, and "By the Light of the Moon" is no exception. Although it is believed that the Vampire Diariespoem was written in 1994, creator Julie Plec has stated that she pulled lyrics from several sources for the poem, including Walt Whitman and the Romantic poet John Clare. Like Whitman, Adam takes a positive stance towards human nature, although he struggles with the realization that humanity cannot be trusted.

The Railway Club is a private social club located at 635 West 47th Street in the Upper West Side of Manhattan, New York City. It was founded in 1908 and is composed of current and former employees of the New York Central Railroad and the New York City Transit Authority. Members must be nominated by existing members and may include managers, conductors, engineers, train crew, and other employees of the New York Central Railroad and the New York City Transit Authority. The club maintains a library with over 50,000 volumes and a wine cellar with over 20,000 bottles of wine. The Railway Club is one of two private social clubs admitted to the Mayors's Committee of 100, a group of New York City's key private social leaders. Its current members include Bunny Mcleod, former president of Ireland and the first black person elected to the International Olympic Committee, John B. Fraser, former chairman and CEO of Standard Oil, and David Rockefeller, former CEO of Chase Manhattan Bank and current chairman of the private Rockefeller family foundation. The club is active in the community, raising funds for the Association of Jewish Retarded Children, and establishing a scholarship in memory of Gordon J. Lauchlan, who was the club's president in the 1950s and 1960s. The Railway Club boasts extensive and varied facilities, including a bowling alley, squash courts, exercise room, reading room, beauty salon and barber shop, dining room, billiards room, card room, library, wine cellar, gift shop, and overnight accommodation for visiting members. The club's three-story mansion at 635 West 47th Street was designed by firm partner Charles F. McKim and the building was completed in 1913.

Laventille is a district in the city of Kingston, Jamaica. The district is located in the east end of the city near the University of the West Indies. It is home to University College as well as several prominent schools including St. George's College, Haverfordwest School, and Queen's College. The district was built in the early part of the 20th century as part of a program to clear out the filth and overcrowding in other parts of the city and build houses in suburban settings. The name Laventille is a combination of the words "lavender" and "isle", referring to the purple flowers of the local lavender shrubs that can be found in the district. Laventille is a district in Kingston, Jamaica located east of the city center. It is home to several prominent schools and two universities, including St. George's College and Queen's College. The district was built as part of a government initiative to clear out the filth and overcrowding in Kingston by building houses in suburban settings. The name Laventille is a combination of the words "lavender" and "isle", referring to the purple flowers of the local lavender shrubs that can be found in the district. The district is located near the University of the West Indies and was built in the early part of the 20th century as part of a program to clear out the filth and overcrowding in Kingston by building houses in suburban settings. The district was built with a suburban layout, including winding streets, large front and back gardens, and many small personal backyards. Laventille is still a very prestigious address and is home to many prominent residents. Laventille is one of the most ethnically and culturally diverse districts in Kingston. It is home to many West Indian citizens, as well as people of many different national origins. Jamaica is a multi-ethnic country and Kingston has the most diverse population of any city in the English-speaking world. Many residents are originally from the Caribbean but Laventille is home to people of many different nationalities. The area is also very popular with students, who make up a large portion of the population. Laventille is close to some of Kingston's best known tourist destinations. Blue Lagoon, a popular water park, is right across the street from the Queen's Court Projects, one of Laventille's prominent landmarks. The area is also near two of Kingston's largest tourist hotels, the downtown Garden Inn and the Beacon Hotel. Overall, Laventille is a very safe area, although like many neighborhoods in Kingston, crime does exist. The district is home to some of the city's best football, basketball, and baseball players. The Laventille United soccer club is the most successful club in the district and has many notable alumni, including two-time FIFA World Cup winner David Beckam. Although Laventille has grown in recent years, the area has become increasingly popular with immigrants, particularly from the United Kingdom and Ireland. This has resulted in a decline in the area's original Caribbean culture, although Laventille is still home to many different nationalities and has a very diverse population. Despite its name, Laventille is not located on an island but is part of a large peninsula that extends into St. Catherine's Bay. The district is bordered by Richmond Road to the west, the University of West Indies to the north, St. Catherine's Bay to the east, and the Pareseste River to the south. Today, Laventille is one of the most popular neighborhoods in Kingston and is well known for its diversity, safety, and close proximity to several prominent tourist attractions.

Pacheco Creek is a stream in San Benito County, California. It is about 50 miles (80 km) long and flows into the San Francisco Bay near the city of Santa Rita. It was named for Juan Bautista Pacheco, an early Spanish explorer. The once-volcanic creek runs through the middle of a large sedimentary basin that was formed many millions of years ago when the bed of the North American continent was assembling out of the sea. The creek's valley was originally home to numerous indigenous peoples, including the Costanoan and Kashaya Pomo. They hunted, fished, and gathered plants and berries along its banks. The first European to see the creek was Father Juan Crespo, a Franciscan missionary, in 1669.
