You can use the TEXT function to create a date/time value and use it in an IF condition: =IF(A2<>B2, "A2 is later in time than B2", "A2 is earlier in time than B2") or with DATEDIF: =IF(A2<>DATEDIF(B2,A2,0), "A2 is later in time than B2", "A2 is earlier in time than B2") or with EXPONDATE: =IF(A2<>DATEVALUE(EXPNdate(B2,1,1)), "A2 is later in time than B2", "A2 is earlier in time than B2") <|endoftext|>Background {#Sec1} ========== Despite the advances in diagnosis and treatment, breast cancer remains a leading cause of death among women worldwide \[[@CR1]\]. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) represents an aggressive molecular subtype with an incidence of about 12--26% of all breast cancers, characterized by the absence of oestrogen (ERα), progesterone (PR) and HER2/neu receptors, and an aggressive clinical behavior, including early dissemination and propensity to metastasize to visceral organs \[[@CR2], [@CR3]\]. TNBC includes a heterogeneous group of patients whose management remains a therapeutic challenge, as they do not respond to conventional therapy \[[@CR4]\]. Consequently, TNBC patients have a poor prognosis with a 5-year survival rate of only 15--50% due to the difficulties in diagnosing at an early stage and the lack of effective targeted therapies \[[@CR5]\]. Therapies based on targeting cell membrane receptors, such as EGFR and HER2, have not provided satisfying results in TNBC due to its low expression of these receptors. Thus, targeting intracellular signaling pathways represents a potential alternative approach for TNBC treatment. Focal adhesion kinase (FAK) is a cytoplasmic non-receptor protein tyrosine kinase that plays an important role in signal transduction across the plasma membrane. FAK has a central role in various cellular processes, such as cell proliferation, migration, and survival, and is often aberrantly activated in human cancers. Many studies have demonstrated that FAK is frequently overexpressed and overactivated in various types of tumors, including breast cancer, and that high expression of FAK is associated with advanced stages of the disease, and with a poor patient prognosis \[[@CR6]\]. Based on these findings, several studies have investigated the efficacy of FAK inhibitors in breast cancer, and have demonstrated that FAK inhibition exerts antitumor activity both in vitro and in vivo. In this regard, FAK inhibition has been shown to decrease proliferation, induce apoptosis and cell cycle arrest, and to enhance the radiosensitivity of breast cancer cells \[[@CR7]--[@CR9]\]. Of note, recently, a novel FAK inhibitor, PF-562271, has been shown to suppress tumor growth in a mouse model of TNBC \[[@CR10]\]. Given that FAK expression is increased in many tumor types, and FAK inhibition represents an effective approach to treat cancer

The Madonna of the Candelabra (Spanish: La Monja la Carcel) is a 1891 painting by the Spanish surrealist painter Pablo Picasso. The painting was one of the first known examples of artistic hatching. The work depicts a hatched scene with a decapitated man lying on the floor in front of aMadonnaand Child. The man's hands and feet are extended and held by ants, which are engaged in feeding on his still-beating heart. The painting is held in the permanent collection of the Indianapolis Museum of Art in Indianapolis, Indiana, United States. The painting was produced during Picasso's blue period, before his red period (from about 1904 to 1907). It was acquired by the Simon Guggenheim Foundation in 1943, and later donated to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1952. The work is one of a very few pieces by Picasso to depict insects. The Spanish term for "carcel" in the painting's title is also the origin of the artist's given name, "Pablo". The work is part of a series of paintings on the same topic that the artist created in the early 1890s, starting with Theanaudio (Piano) (1891). The latter painting is now in the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The work was affected by paint loss and suffered water damage in the 1960s, leading to restoration work in the 1980s. The Indianapolis Museum of Art's digital image of the painting was used as the base image for a painting of the same title exhibited at the Hispanic Society of America in New York in late 2017 and early 2018, as one of several artworks depicting the " Hispanic Spring" by New York City's Collectivo Caracol. Madonna of the Candelabra" is featured in the 2004 documentary film Picasso: A Studio of his Own, and inspired works by other artists, such as John Currin, who referenced the painting in his 2011 portrait of singer Édith Piaf. The work is popular with collecting galleries and donors, and was reportedly the most expensive work of art ever sold in 2017. The painting is part of a loosely orchestrated series of artworks, some of them on display simultaneously, others organized to attract attention to causes supporting the Red Cross in the aftermath of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami, or to promote the work of the Fundació Antoni Tàpies. The "Madonna of the Candelabra" was reproduced on a porcelain platter for the exhibition "Celebration. 400 Years of Waterman Faience" at the Louisville Palace in 2008, and became one of several limited-edition prints made from the image for the exhibition "Picasso. Paintings 1891-1910", organised by the Artémis museum foundation in Pontoise in 2013. A larger-scale print was produced by Alexandre Alastair for the exhibition "The Genius of Pablo Picasso", held at the Royal Academy of Arts in London in 2015, and a similar but slightly smaller edition was produced by the Museum of Modern Art in New York for the same exhibition. A smaller-scale edition, with minor differences, was produced by the National Gallery of Australia in 2018 to commemorate the opening of a major Picasso exhibition there. The Indianapolis Museum of Art updated their website with imagery and information derived from their restoration in the 1980s, and from the work of the Art Institute of Chicago. The painting was part of a major exhibition of Picasso's painting from the first decade of the 21st century, " Picasso and García Marquez", held at the Tate Modern in London and the Guggenheim Museum in New York in 2011-2012. A reproduction of the painting was produced by Tancrediaco in 24 carat gold as a limited edition of 50 pieces in 2014. The version on display in the Indianapolis Museum of Art is a 1902 restoration. The original, prior to restorations, was held by the Simon Guggenheim Foundation, which acquired it in 1943. It was bequeathed to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1952. The original is currently on long-term loan to the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra for an exhibition. The National Gallery of Australia estimates that in May 2023, the work was valued at US$155 million. The Indianapolis Museum of Art restored the work in the 1980s, bringing it back to its original condition. List of Mass Effect characters - Commander Shepard - Garrus Jurcard - Kahleen Reichel - Thane Morrey - Aria T'Loak - Liara T'Soni - Javid Lombardi - Kadri assumptions - Javos Quotian - Liiri Vaylin - Ilanne Sareine - Jaal - Aethyta - Omega 4 - Danusia Suleiman - Cassandra Laclait - Grasmere - Abed Chitough - Saren Taden - Thane Paranso And many more! Mass Effect is a science fiction video game created by BioWare, and is a sequel to the studio's 2007 title, Dragon Age. The game was released in 2012 to generally positive reviews. Mass Effect involved the crew of the USS Shepard, a military space station orbiting the Milky Way, in an interstellar war against an ancient shadow organization known as the Reapers. The Commander in Mass Effect provides the player with the freedom to choose from multiple races and species, including humans, turian, drell, asari, krogan, and others. The game follows the Commander throughout their career and the lasting impacts of the war. Several of these characters became well-known during and after the development of the game, and several have received their own spinoff games.

Oresuki is a free open-source Android application that enables users to earn points and rewards by doing simple tasks such as playing games or viewing ads on their smartphones. Oresuki uses an algorithm to approximate your location based on your wireless signals and displays restaurants, stores and other places that are nearby where you can go to get rewards. You can browse stores and restaurants nearby, view profiles of places and their Rewards and Deals, and join rewards programs like Gympie, RewardsMe and Wish.com. Actual reward amounts and deals are subject to change without notice. Oresuki is created by the Doshas Foundation, a not-for-profit organization that focuses on exploring technology as a driver of social change. The Oresuki software is open-sourced under a Apache 2.0 license. Download Oresuki from the Google Play Store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.wireless.oreski Read the Oresuki Wikipedia page at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oresuki Doshas Foundation is also the organization that maintains the OpenStreetMap project, where they've mapped more than 40,000 locations in Australia. Kehkashan Basu (born 1960) is an Indian cinematographer known for his work in the Bengali Cinema. He is a recipient of the Rajat Kamal (Silver Lotus) Award, for Best Cinematographer for the year 2013 for his film Trishna. In 2016, he was awarded the Nigar Award for Best Cinematographer for his work in Bengali movies like Trishna and Rater Para. He is a member of the West Bengal Cinematographers' and Artistes' Association (WBCAA). He started his career as an assistant to Balu Mahendra, and then moved on to cinematographer Rabiooter Bangera. Later he assisted cinematographers like Tarun Ghosh and Sreelekha Das. He is the only person to have been a member of all the three generations of Bengali Cinematographers' family: the founding father Balram Miranda, the technical advisor Rabiooter Bangera and the generation ShootistSujit Maity and Trishna''' director Ruben Ghadially. He is married to Hindi and Bengali actress Samita Sodhi and has two daughters, Kasi and Kshiti. He is a member of the advisory council of the University of Calcutta's Film and Television Institute. His brother Supraba Basu is also a cinematographer. The success or failure of health care organizations is measured by the quality of care they provide and the costs of that care. For some time, those measures have been influenced by advances in medical technology. However, over the past decade, technological advances have begun to plateau and, in some cases, have shown signs of decline. That has created a new imperative for those responsible for managing health care organizations: improve the quality and efficiency of care while reducing costs. The traditional, established tools of management, including observation, interviewing, and document review, may no longer be sufficient to achieve those goals. This article discusses the need for organizations to develop a new tool--an ethnography--to help them understand how the people in their care experience both the quality of the organization and the costs of care. An ethnography, unlike a survey or observation, enables an organization to understand the meaning of an experience for a person. When performed by trained ethnographers, the resulting ethnography provides a unique, valuable, and authentic source of information that cannot be readily acquired by other means. The article describes the purpose and steps in the ethnographic process, presents several examples of ethnographies performed by the authors and their colleagues, and discusses the management implications of ethnographies for those responsible for management of health care organizations.<|endoftext|>Final Fantasy XV Pocket Edition Achieves One Million Units Sales On Amazon.com Giuseppe Nelva November 4, 2016 10:45 AM EST Final Fantasy XV Pocket Edition has been very successful on Amazon.com, achieving one million units sales after

Albertanus of Brescia (c. 1020 – c. 1080) was an Italian writer and Catholic churchman. He was active in the north Italian cities of Brescia and Bergamo and at the court ofopold III, Duke of Austria. He is especially known for his writing on the Roman Catholic Church, which at the time was suppressed by the German king, Henry IV. He was the first person in the German-speaking world to write a history of the church in Latin, the first volume of which, entitled Historia Societatis Iesu, was dedicated to Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor. The second volume, De episcopatu Vienna (Of the Church of Vienna), written around 1070, included a description of the life and acts of the first Roman Catholic bishop of Vienna, Willigis. It included the first description of the suffragan dioceses, with Verona as the first example. Albertanus is regarded as an important figure in the foundation of the Roman Catholic Church and the propagation of its doctrines in the German-speaking world. His work, along with that of Odilo of Freising, enabled the development of a canon of church history in the German-speaking world, from the Fall of Constantinople in 1453 until the pontificate of Martin Luther in the 15th century. Works Historia Societatis Iesu (History of the Society of Jesus), dedicated to Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor (written 1042/43) De episcopatu Vienna (Of the Church of Vienna), written around 1070 Notes References Davis, Kelly, "Albertanus of Brescia", The Catholic Encyclopedia (New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1910) Jaffé, Philip and Seligman, Henry, A Gustave Doré Reader:Selected Illustrations from His 27 Volume career, New York: Dover Publications, Inc, 1993, pp. 168–169. Corruption in local government has become a growing concern in many countries. According to Transparency International's global audit of government corruption, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Netherlands, Sweden and United Kingdom are the countries with the highest perceived levels of government integrity. Many high-income countries have professionalised the administration and improved institutional capabilities, but inefficient administration, unclear accountability and weak enforcement continue to hamper efforts to address corruption in local government. Several high-income countries have seen increased external corruption threats from international organized crime and terrorism, as well as corruption in transnational organisations operating in their territory. These threats present a double challenge, as they undermine the legitimacy of national institutions and create an environment that makes corrupt activities easier and more profitable. Corruption erodes government effectiveness and sows the seeds of social instability. Corrupt leaders are more likely to make risky decisions and solve problems in their own interest, rather than in the interest of the public. This affects economic growth, stability and the well-being of citizens. The World Bank estimates that reducing corruption in the local government sector in developing countries could increase the GDP by more than 5%, growth in wages by 10% and life expectancy by up to 1.5 years. Significant anti-corruption efforts have been undertaken by several countries. For example, United Kingdom passed Local Government and Housing Act 2014, which introduced adult local government mayor and elected councilors for first time in its history. This was followed by establishment of Public Commission on Corruption in India, with the motto to protect people's mandate and to save India from corruption. The challenges posed by corruption in local government are not confined to high-income countries, but are also experienced in low- and middle-income countries. In many Asian countries, it is widespread and entrenched. The scale of local government is often large, comprising over 500 million people. For example, in India, at least one third of the population is served by 63 million local government bodies. The revenue collection often depends on the discretionary spending of local government, which hampers their ability to be accountable and efficient in their functions. In some countries, such as Brazil, township and village enterprises provide a potential framework for fostering good governance and combating corruption, as these organisations operate under locally elected and accountable officials. In other countries, such as South Africa, the Zondo commission exposed maladministration, cronyism and fraud by South African local government, prompting President Cyril Ramaphosa to initiate a top-to-bottom review of government. The functioning of local government is not the only area in which corruption is a problem, as more general concern about public officials' lack of morality has led to attempts to enhance the transparency and accountability of government bodies. The growth of online social media and the use of big data and artificial intelligence in anti-corruption efforts has led to new concerns regarding civil liberties and privacy.

Internorm is a non-profit organization that collects a standardized set of internode conditions from all over the world and makes them available online. These internode conditions include, but are not limited to, daily temperature, humidity, dew point, solar radiation, wind speed and direction, and cloud coverage. These internode conditions allow plant scientists and farmers to accurately predict plant behavior and growth. Strategic planning Internorm was founded in 2007 by the German Research Center for Environmental Health (GFZ) in collaboration with the Fraunhofer Institut für Angewandte Photonik IAP and the University of Kassel. It is funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research and receives additional support from plant scientists all over the world. History 2007 - Internorm was founded by the German Research Center for Environmental Health (GFZ) in collaboration with the Fraunhofer Institut für Angewandte Photonik IAP and the University of Kassel. 2011 - First release of the internorm data. 2013 - First global inter-comparison of internorm conditions to show the global variation in the conditions plants grow best in. 2016 - First data set on tropical conditions. 2019 - First European condition data set. Organization Internorm is a non-profit organization that was founded in 2007 by the German Research Center for Environmental Health (GFZ) in collaboration with the Fraunhofer Institut für Angewandte Photonik IAP and the University of Kassel. It is funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research and receives additional support from plant scientists all over the world. Collaborators Fraunhofer Institut für Angewandte Photonik IAP University of Kassel German Federal Ministry of Education and Research Additional supporters Plant scientists all over the world Distribution Data is available to the public for free via the internet. Governance The association is governed by the general assembly. The members appoint the board of directors that runs the association. Cooperation Internorm has established cooperative relationships with various universities and research centers around the world. These cooperative relationships aid in the development and improvement of internorm. Activities The activities of Internorm include collecting standardized internode conditions from all over the world and making them available online. Events Internorm has organized the first global inter-comparison of internorm conditions and the first European condition data set. Recognition Internorm has received recognition from the United Nations for aiding in the global effort to create standard conditions for research and growth. Awards The German Federal Ministry of Education and Research awarded Internorm funding to support the development and improvement of internorm. Patents Internorm has obtained patents for some of their technology. Maurice Maeterlinck (1862–1949) was a Belgian Symbolist and decadent poet, novelist and art historian. Considered the foremost literary critic of his generation, he was a leading member of the Cercle deux figures symbolistes. In 1907, he was appointed director of the National Museum of Brussels. During the 1890s, Maeterlinck turned to Naturalism, and in his most famous work, Theaters of the Heart (1998), he sought to reconcile naturalism with Symbolist philosophy. His works reflect his interest in mysticism, Buddhism, Hinduism, and other Eastern religious traditions. Though Maeterlinck's plays are little performed today, his mastery in poetic prose has garnered him a modern following. Critical works on Maeterlinck have been published almost constantly since the early 20th century; the Belgian critic and writer Georges Rodenbach published the first study of Maeterlinck's works in 1903. Though often linked with Flemish literature, Maeterlinck was actually born in Brussels and was therefore Francophone. However, he is often considered a Flemish author because that was the language in which he published most of his works. Of his many literary awards, the most prestigious was the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1911, the first Belgian author to be so honored. In 1999, he was voted fifth in the Petite histoire du cinema (Little History of Cinema) segment "those who helped to shape cinema's beginnings" created by French director and film critic Francis Gorsse. Maurice Maeterlinck has a cremation urn at the Poppeliers cemetery in Brussels, next to the grave of his wife.

The Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China (Министерство Лес и Ресурсов Республики Китаю), abbreviated as MLRRC, is a Chinese government ministry dealing with land and resource questions. The ministry is jointly responsible with the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. The MLRRC was established in February 2013 as part of a major reorganization of China's economic and regulatory machinery aimed at improving efficiency and curbing fraud. It takes over functions from the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), the National Bureau of Statistics, and the General Administration of Customs, and combines them with those of the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. The MLRRC is headquartered in Beijing and has ten agencies throughout China responsible for Lands and Agriculture, Resource Exploitation, Customs, Statistics, State Forestry Administration, Maritime Safety, Bureau of Metrology, Statistical Analysis, and State Economic and Trade Commission. either The Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China is responsible for Lands and Agriculture, Resource Exploitation, Customs, Statistics, State Forestry Administration, Maritime Safety, Bureau of Metrology, Statistical Analysis, and State Economic and Trade Commission. MLRRC was established in February 2013 as part of a major reorganization of China's economic and regulatory machinery aimed at improving efficiency and curbing fraud. The ministry takes over functions from the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), the National Bureau of Statistics, and the General Administration of Customs, and combines them with those of the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology.

Vsevolozhsky District is a district of the city of Moscow, Russia. It's located northwest of the center of the city. The district's name comes from Vsevolozhsky Monastery, which was located on the territory of the district. The district was established in 1929 as a administrational division of Moscow and its territory was largely reorganized in 1957 and 1962. The administrative center of the district is the city of Moscow. The Vsevolozhsky District is home to approximately one million people. Major educational institutions located in the district include the Moscow Aviation Institute and the Higher School of Economics. The Moscow City Court and the General District Court of Moscow are also located in the district. Vsevolozhsky District is home to the VDNKh business and tech center, which is Russia's largest business and technology hub, as well as the international electronics exhibition EXPO-center. Asteroid 4497 Vsevolozhskij, located in the Earth's orbit is named after the district. Vsevolozhsky District is almost fully residential, with the exception of the VDNKh business and tech center which is built in the style of a functional city, and a few blocks of the Moscow Airport residential complex, as well as some administrative buildings in the city center. A significant proportion of the Moscow Aviation Institute, Higher School of Economics, Moscow City Court, and General District Court of Moscow are located in the district. *[https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Федерация_входе_в_Москву_%E2%80%93_VDNKh_%28дерм)) Вход в Москву - VDNKh (дерм)) - District enter to Moscow - VDNKh (VDNKh means World Trade Center in Russian).

Fantastic Wounds is a video game released in 1985 by Romsphere as a compilation of the serial codebreaker and time-travelling agent Joe Coleman, with additional content written by Howard V. Hendrix. It was the first licensed commercially released software created for the Commodore 64, Apple II, and Atari 8-bit family of computers. Fantastic Wounds is an epistolary novel written in the form of a dispatch from the front lines of World War III. The antagonist is a militaristic computer from the future, intent on eradicating all technology and everyone who created it. The novel features a dramatic orchestral score, exceptional art design, and challenging puzzles. Fantastic Wounds was written by Howard V. Hendrix, who also created the comic book character the Hawk, who was the star of his own eponymous comic book. The Hawk, and licensed Commodore 64 software like Fantastic Wounds, was Hendrix' way of making money since he couldn't get hired writing comic books due to his status as a comic book creator himself. Fantastic Wounds was originally released as a Romsphere compilation titled Joe Coleman in 1979. A separately published novelisation, Fantastic Wounds, was also released in 1979 by Famous Drama. The story was completely re-worked for the video game version, Joe Coleman was replaced with a time-travelling protagonist named Joe Zander, and the game's backstory was fleshed out to include a war between the planet Xenon and the Id-containing race called the Cyber Insects. The game's setting was moved from the 20th century to a post-apocalyptic world in the year 2019. The novel concludes with the discovery of a tomb of forgotten war heroes, including Joe Zander. The cover art for the compilation and the novelisation was created by David Berry, who also created the Atari 2600 gamebreak, and the cover art for the 1981 sequel Joe Coleman in Dinosaur Land. Fantastic Wounds was very well received by the gaming press. The Atari 8-bit family version of the game was the first commercially released game to receive the gaming magazine CRASH's "Game of the Month" award. Fantastic Wounds was ported to the Apple II and the Commodore 64 by regional software distributor Romstar, with the Commodore version being the first release of a new brand label created by Romstar for licensed games, Action Datasoft. As a video game, Fantastic Wounds features full text animation sequences and artwork rendered in a primitive computer graphics style. Some of the challenges presented in the game are portals that require skill to navigate, particularly in the Apple II version where the mouse cursor was mapped to the keyboard. Timed sequences required precise operation of the C64's numeric keypad. Fantastic Wounds was programmed by brothers Alan and Bob Jennings and released in the summer of 1985. The Commodore 64 version of the game was programmed by Fred Ford, using technology developed by brothers Dave and Jim Fulton. The Apple II version was programmed by Almir Golpusić and his brother Zoran. In 2008, Fantastic Wounds was re-released as part of the Romsphere Archives series, fully restored from original floppy disks. In 2009, the game was translated into French as Fantastic Bites. Fantastic Wounds inspired a series of tabletop role-playing games, the Fantastic Wounds RPG, in which the characters from the game are cast into a fantasy setting and have to escape the dungeon of The Tower of the Thorns, which is controlled by the powerful and evil wizard Karg. The first two editions of the game were translated from French to English by Jonathan Tweet, author of the Warhammer 40,000 novels Psycho Crawlers and Iron Warriors. In 2012, the game was ported to Android by "blueberry123". It's considered to be one of the worst games ported to Android for its bad controls, low resolution graphics, and difficult gameplay. The in-game time-travel device known as the "Hand of Fate" plays a critical role in the story. It's a fictional digital device used to help prevent World War III from occurring in the first place. While these devices do exist in the real world, they are extremely expensive and highly regulated. The Hand of Fate, being common, unregulated hardware and software, is repurposed for time travel in Joe Zander's era. Its appearance and operation are not disclosed to the player. Joe Zander successfully uses the Hand of Fate to travel back in time, but then uncontrollably rewrites history by preventing World War III from occurring. Nikifor Chernigovsky (born Dimitri Galitzine; 1888–1938) was a Russian-Armenian journalist, newspaper editor, and book publisher. As a journalist, Chernigovsky was a war correspondent for Novoye Vremya and other Soviet papers during the First World War, and subsequently wrote about the Russian Civil War. In 1918 he was one of the organizers of the Armenian Association for Aid to the Wounded. After the October Revolution he lived in Ukraine, where he was the editor-in-chief of various newspapers. He was arrested by the Soviet authorities in 1921 and convicted of counter-revolutionary activities in a trial that was publicly denounced as frame-up by representatives of numerous foreign governments. After serving ten years of a 14-year sentence he was released as part of the NKVD prisoners exchange in 1936, and died in 1938. Chernigovsky was born in the family of a peasant farmer in Kyivsky District, Kiev Governorate, Russian Empire (to this day this district is named after him). In 1910 he graduated from Kyiv University and became an assistant professor at the university's law faculty. In 1911–1914 he was an editorial assistant and law lecturer at a Kyiv school and in 1914 he began working at Novoye Vremya, where he would remain until 1920. Chernigovsky was highly opinionated, outspoken, and argumentative, which made him a firm critic of the Russian Empire's leaders. During the First World War he was a war correspondent for Novoye Vremya, and after the Russian Revolution of 1917 he supported the Bolsheviks. In 1918 he was one of the organizers of the Armenian Association for Aid to the Wounded. He moved to Kiev in 1918 and became a leader of the Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army, an organization that fought with the Red Army against the forces of the Ukrainian People's Republic in the Ukrainian–Soviet War. In 1920 Chernigovsky was one of the organizers of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, where he was an editor of Kievsky Krai newspaper and worked with Mykhailo Starytsky as the head of the Kiev branch of the Printing house of the Ukrainian Social Democrats. In 1921 Chernigovsky moved to Dnipropetrovsk, where he organized the newspaper TSNK (later known as Dnipro), and a book publishing house. He was an editor-in-chief of the TSNK and a co-founder of the Dnipro publishing house. In 1928 he was one of the organizers of the Ukrainian branch of the All-Ukrainian Union of Journalists. In 1929 he was an editor-in-chief of the newspaper Borys Krevlyi and then he worked as a journalist in Chernigov. In 1930 Chernigovsky was arrested and accused of counter-revolutionary activities. The case was widely publicized, and in response the Soviet Union's ambassadors in various countries sent protests to their respective governments. His sentence was extended multiple times and in 1936 he was released as part of the prisoners exchange between the Soviet Union and Poland. On 22 February 1937, he died in an automobile accident in Kyiv. His funeral was attended by many people including Mykhailo Starytsky and Hryhoriy Skovoroda. In 1938 his body was moved and buried at Dnipropetrovsk's Lukianivskoye Cemetery.

Doom (1997 video game) Final Doom Doom (video game series) id Software 2017 release anhydr Doom (1997 video game) is a first-person shooter video game developed by id Software and published by GT Interactive Software and Take-Two Interactive. It is the fifth game in the Doom series, following Doom (1993), its two prequel comic series and its spiritual successor, Hell (2013). The game was originally released for PC on November 10, 1997, and later re-released for Mac OS on December 3, 2002, and Linux on June 23, 2004. Doom received largely positive reviews from critics, who praised its graphics and sound effects, but criticized its levels and movement. The game's success led to the creation of a large fan base and a commercial success. A spiritual successor, Doom 64 (2016), was released in 2016. A remake of the original game, titled Doom: Unvanquished, was released in 2017. gain Doom (1997 video game) is a first-person shooter video game developed by id Software and published by GT Interactive Software and Take-Two Interactive. Kara Thevenot (born December 29, 1942) is a French singer. She was born in Marseille. Thevenot began performing in local cabarets at an early age. In 1961, at the age of eleven, she was invited to perform on the French radio. A few years later, she started to tour. Thevenot's first hit, "Moi, Ça, Toi," was a big success in 1963. Other popular hits followed, such as "Le Poivre," "Ta Mère," and "Et les anges dansaient." In 1968, she won the Eurovision Song Contest with her song "Un jour, une chanson." Thevenot performed in several musicals and her collaboration with Serge Gainsbourg resulted in numerous successful songs. In 1983, Thevenot retired from the music business. She worked as a radio and television host and made occasional cameo appearances in movies. In 2016, more than 50 years after her debut, she made a brief comeback. Chris Pallis (born Christopher John Pallis; 21 May 1948 – 25 November 2014) was an English jazz drummer. A precocious child who decided he wanted to be a drummer at the age of four, his early career was spent with jazz orchestras. However, he was fired from his first professional engagement when he was 17 because the bandleader saw his fingers ending in sharp sticks and mistaken them for cymbals. Unable to drum professionally for almost five years, Pallis was at 18 unable to get hired as a busker because of his age. He eventually gained a spot in a 1950s music revue. Pallis learned to play guitar at 19, joined a folk rock band, and then worked his way up to become the band's drummer. This period of Pallis's life was documented in the award-winning 1985 film Parade, which was adapted from the book of the same name by the film's director, Donald McGeever. The film told the fictionalized story of Pallis from his busking days to his becoming the drummer for the John Stevenson trio. Pallis' professional career was nearly ended by a car accident at the age of 20. But with the encouragement of his family and bandmates, Pallis persevered and founded his own drumming troupe. He was invited to join the John Stevensons as their drummer two years later, and went on to play with that band for the next 18 years. Pallis also began experimenting with electronic drums and sampled drums. He retired from performing in 2010 and shifted his focus to educating musicians about the drums.

Knut Alming (born 1968) is a Swedish singer, musician and composer. He has established himself in the Swedish musical scene and is known for being a very prolific and active composer, writing and recording music for several hundreds of films, TV-series and commercials. His best-known songs are "En gång i Liffey" and "Take away my heart", both composed and recorded for the Oscar-winning film Trivial Pursuit and featuring Heather Mills. Discovery Kids (Latin American TV channel) is a Brazilian pay TV channel that broadcasts cartoons and educational programs for children, it was launched on December 6, 2013 as a replacement for Discovery Kids Latin America, and it is available in 55 countries. Discovery Kids (Latin American TV channel) was launched on December 6, 2013 as a replacement for Discovery Kids Latin America, and it is available in 55 countries such as Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Venezuela and some Caribbean countries. The programming on Discovery Kids (Latin American TV channel) differs from that of its counterpart in several aspects. For instance, it airs shows that are aimed at children that have native speakers in various languages, such as Italian, Portuguese, Spanish and English. Some of the popular shows that are broadcast on the channel are Galactik Football, Diego the Dramatic Dog, CSR Racing, Mighty Machines, among others. Discovery Kids (Latin American TV channel) offers several shows with educational purposes, such as My Friend Rabbit, Bluey and Super Circus, among others. Arch Allies: Live at Riverport is a double album by American rock band Gorillaz, released on 27 February 2020. It is the band's first concert album, following the live albums Dare (2008) and Plastic Beach (2010). The album was recorded at the band's annual concerts in the UK at the London O2 Arena, Glasgow SECC, and Manchester Apollo between 2014 and 2018. It was mixed by American rock band OK Go and British musician Damian 'Hyde' Campbell, who performed vocals on the track "Midnights". Arch Allies includes live renditions of eight tracks from the band's 2015 album, Humanz, and eight tracks from their 2016 album,apoptosis. It includes a solo from rapper Little Dragon on the track "Let Me Out". The title is a reference to a song on Gorillaz' 2003 album, "Plastic Beach". The album received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised its live sound and the band's performance, but criticized the length and the short interludes between songs. It debuted at number one in the UK Albums Chart, becoming the band's first number one album. live album Arch Allies: Live at Riverport is a double album by American rock band Gorillaz, released on 27 February 2020. 2001 Toppserien was the first edition of the Toppserien, a women's handball tournament in Norway. The tournament was contested by eleven teams and the first winner was SVs ABBER. The final between Viking HT and Bjellene SK was watched by 201 spectators. This first edition was decided over three games, played in Fagernes, Stavanger. In 2002 and 2003 the tournament was played as a round-robin group, with the winner qualify for the Herre & Andersen Cup. After these positive results the Toppserien was played annually until 2007, when the tournament wasn't held any more. The 2002 winner Tertnes HH changed its name to Bjellene SK and thereby activating the rule that only teams that have won a tournament can change its name. Nine teams took part in the first tournament in 2001, but after a few years the number of teams decreased and became fixed at eleven for a few years. The format of the tournament was changed in 2004. The number of groups was increased from three to five, and the tournament became played as a round-robin group. The winner of one group would play against the runner-up of another group and the two winners would play a double-game for a ticket to Herre & Andersen Cup. This double-game is called "Grunnova". This Grunnova was won by Viking HT after a victory over Fyllingen, which secured Viking a spot in the Herre & Andersen Cup with a otherwise lossless tournament.

Jean Pellissier (shepherd) was a French shepherd who in 1879 received a sheep from Louis Pasteur, the sheep had been dead for two days, to demonstrate that disease could not survive outside of hosts, Pellissier brought the sheep to the schoolroom where he taught and gave it enough milk to revive it. The sheep revived and was later found to be healthy, disproving the theory of spontaneous generation. Pellissier was given a medal and platform to demonstrate his experiments in front of representatives of multiple nations at the 1880 World's Fair in Paris. Jean Pellissier (shepherd) was a French shepherd who lived in the village of Aiglun near Clermont-Ferrand and demonstrated that disease could not survive outside of hosts by giving a dead sheep he had received from Louis Pasteur to be milked. The sheep revived and was later found to be healthy, disproving the theory of spontaneous generation. Pellissier was given a medal and platform to demonstrate his experiments in front of representatives of multiple nations at the 1880 World's Fair in Paris. Sheep farming was found in his region, especially in Aiglun, and benefited from this event and the associated media exposure, making Jean Pellissier a celebrity of the time. He was given the medal and platform to demonstrate his experiments in front of representatives of multiple nations at the 1880 World's Fair in Paris. In 1880, Louis Pasteur asked Jean Pellissier to receive a sheep that he had put in an organic solution that would dry and die for two days. On the morning of the funeral, Pellissier received the sheep and after preparing it for burial, he brought it to his classroom, where he prepared some milk to reanimate it. The sheep revived and was later found to be healthy, disproving the theory of spontaneous generation. Pellissier was given a medal and platform to demonstrate his experiments in front of representatives of multiple nations at the 1880 World's Fair in Paris. The theory of spontaneous generation said that things could come to life without human intervention, such as dead livestock turning into flies in the air, and so the theory implied that diseases could also come to life in this way. The demonstration that disease could not survive outside of hosts and that things could not come to life without human intervention between a sheep that had been prepared for burial and a live sheep that was revived showed that the theory of spontaneous generation was false. This was one of the first demonstrations of this type, and this event led to the awarding of Jean Pellissier a medal and a platform to demonstrate his experiments in front of representatives of multiple nations at the 1880 World's Fair in Paris. Jean Pellissier was born in Aiglun, Dordogne, France in 1839 and gained local renown as a sheep shepherd. In 1879, he received a sheep from Louis Pasteur, the sheep having been dead for two days. Saint Rose of Lima (1607 – 1617) was a Peruvian saint of the Roman Catholic Church. She became a nun and served as a nurse in the nunnery she was sent to. At the age of 14, she was already a member of the Order of Saint Clare. She is particularly noted for her miraculous escape from a fire in the convent that nearly destroyed it. After taking her vows at age 15, she moved to Ecuador to avoid the persecution of the Inquisition in Peru. In 1617, at age 16, she came back to Peru and settled in Cuzco, where she was eventually martyred by the intolerance and the pain she endured from the advance of the colonial wars. She was beatified in 1886 and canonized in 1993. Her real name was Catalina Rodriguez de Bracamonte. She is patron of nurses, and the city of Lima and a large part of Perú have named a street after her. She is the most popular Peruvian saint. Her feast day is January 15th. Her life was the basis for the 1962 film Rose of Lima and the 1975 TV series also called Rose of Lima. She is the subject of a 1975 musical entitled Saint Rose of Lima, with a libretto by Robert Chenier and a 1979 opera version written by Frank Martin with a libretto by Nancy McFadden. Her writings on the Steer and the Spirits, and the Seven Principles for the Life of a True Nun form part of the curriculum for religious seminaries. She is portrayed by Zoe Saldaña in the 2014 Oliver Stone film, Jackie. Cristina Köhler was also considered for the main character in the 2017 game In the Fade - Dweller on hopes. Her life and canonisation have been portrayed in various other works of fiction, including a graphic novel adaptation illustrated by Barry Kitson in 2019. Her feast day is January 15th. Her funeral at the Campo Santo cemetery in Los Angeles in 1967 had to be relocated after threats from the local Indian community. Her relics are at the Shrine of Our Lady of Guadalupe. For her life of charity, she is a patron for orphans and people with disabilities. Her liturgical calendar date is January 15th. She is the patroness of Peru and Spanish and ItalianQuechua people. The street that leads to her church in Lima is named in her honour. The University of Peruvian Nursing School in Lima is named in her honour. She has an emblem and a motto in Latin, Parva Sint Ut Vita Processione Serva and Aurea Corona Nisi Domini. Her popular song "Rosaleda" is a success in Peru. Her life, her vows and her death are the subject of a popular corrido. Saint Rose of Lima has been the subject of various artistic representations, including paintings, sculptures and drawings. Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School is a public K-12 school district in south central Kansas. The school serves the rural communities of northern Saline County, southern Neosha County, and western Miller County, Kansas, United States. It is located adjacent to US Highway 24, approximately three miles (5 km) north of Kenn PCA, the county seat of Saline County. The district features two elementary schools, a middle school, and a high school. Enrollment as of 2013 was 216 students, which was an increase from the previous year's 194. The school colors are purple and white and the mascot is a cougar. The school district was founded on July 1, 1895, as the result of a merger of two smaller school districts, the Kenn school district and the Springfield school district. The two districts had originally been separate school districts just over a decade earlier, in 1885 and 1883 respectively. The first school in the district was a log building on the property where the current Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig Elementary School stands. Enrollment in 1895 was 24 students, ranging in age from six to ten. By 1904, the district had built a brick school which served as the district's sole location for eight years. The current school building was constructed in 1928 and was originally used as a public school until 1975, when it was sold to the district and converted to an elementary school. The building was expanded in 1985 and again in 2002. The school remains the only K-12 school in the district and is located adjacent to U.S. Highway 24, approximately three miles (5 km) north of Kenn, the county seat of Saline County. The school is notable for a rivalry with adjacent Kenn which leads to many memorable games, sometimes referred to as the "Battle of the Bogans". The name of the rivalry has originated as a mnemonic for the results of several key games, including a rare victory for Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig in the 1960 game which was followed by the rivalry trophy winning portability for the next 46 years. The mnemonic has been popularized on T-shirts and other school-related memorabilia. School facilities have also hosted an annual 4-H fair as well as school assemblies, gymnasium basketball games, and community events.

Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+), also known as MDH (NADP+), is a protein that in humans is encoded by the MDH1 gene. This nuclear-encoded mitochondrial enzyme is a member of the BiP superfamily of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)ases and is implicated in the citric acid cycle and oxidative stress response. This highly conserved enzyme catalyses the following reaction: Oxaloacetate + NADP+ Malate + NADPH + H+ This is the main oxidative branch of the citric acid cycle in which acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate are converted to malate and NADP+ in the cytosol and mitochondria, respectively. Mitochondrial MDH is essential for the survival of the mammalian cell and its activity is tightly regulated by various post-translational modifications. This gene is believed to play a role in cancer cells as they undergo metabolism switching from aerobic respiration to aerobic glycolysis known as the Warburg effect. This phenomenon has been observed in many types of cancer and this newly discovered role of MDH has been hypothesized to be linked to the cancer cells' increased dependency on fermentation for ATP generation in place of oxidative phosphorylation. Since MDH1 is ubiquitous in humans it is used as a marker for hyperfiltering plasma membraneiniability in diagnosis of certain neoplastic and neurodegenerative diseases, such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and Alzheimer's disease, respectively. The importance of MDH has also been recently demonstrated in the evergreen tree fern (Tre FILEXus rombergii). This tree fern is unique in having two distinct genomes - a large genome (containing approximately 40,000 genes) derived from its gymnosperm ancestors and a much smaller plastid-derived genome (containing approximately 8,000 genes). The large genome encodes many proteins used in the C4 or crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM) photosynthesis, which is a resourceful way for evergreens to utilize air CO2 and increase carboxylation efficiency. However, at least one important protein from this large genome is imported into the mitochondria in ferns, where it appears to be replaced by a close relative, malate dehydrogenase (NADP+). This change has allowed the fern to lose the need for crassulacean acid metabolism and instead use non-phosphorylating nitrogen (ammonia) metabolism for ATP generation. Like all malate dehydrogenases, MDH (NADP+) has a TIM-barrel fold. Although the resolution of the structure is low, two thiol groups from cysteines are proposed to be the distal co-factor binding sites, as observed for other malate dehydrogenases.

0x10c is a documentary film about surfing released in 2015. The film was written and directed by Emile de Antonio, and also features noted surfers Jeff Clark, Kirk Passmore, Kelly Slater, Robert August and Kelly Bednarik. The film had a successful crowd-funding campaign on Pivot. The film was picked up for distribution and television by Gravitas Ventures and AcireMedia. In January 2016, 0x10c was named Film of the Year by the short film industry website Filmmaker News. The film received positive reviews, with criticism directed at the surfers' lack of participation in the surf contests they are filming, for lack of airtime, described by commentators as "performance surfing". The surf in the movie was captured at Trestles, a surf spot in California. It is available to watch for free online through multiple online streaming services, and was released on DVD and Blu-ray on April 6, 2019. The film was executive produced by Emile de Antonio, Kelly Slater and Jeff Clark. de Antonio has described the film as a "love letter to the Pacific Coast", and a follow-up to his 2010 film The Endless Summer, with the location of filming selected as a reflection of the cultural changes in the surf scene since the 1970s film was made. The film features music by The Wild Pair. The narrative is structured around a contest held at Trestles between several of the characters, including Kirk Passmore, Jeff Clark and Kelly Slater. The outcome of the contest, which Passmore wins, is dependent on Slater's performance during a lifeguard's competition. 0x10c was produced by Gravitas Ventures and AcireMedia. The executive producers were Emile de Antonio, Kelly Slater, Jeff Clark, and Kelly Bednarik. The cast also featured Bruce Brown, Carissa Moore, Andy Addlespurger, and Alana Blanchard. The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray on April 6, 2019.

Yiddishkayt (Yiddishkayt Organization) is an international grassroots movement and political party, headquartered in Brooklyn, New York, with outreach and campaigns in many cities around the world. Yiddishkayt strives to strengthen Jewish identity, rootedness, and continuity, while also promoting pan- generational and racial inclusiveness in the tradition of Judaism and the Jewish culture. The organization is dedicated to strengthening Jewish identity, rootedness, and continuity by encouraging participation in Jewish culture and community-based programs that enhance knowledge of, and participation in, the Jewish legacy. Yiddishkayt promotes inclusiveness by actively seeking participation from all Jewish generations and of all races and ethnicities in the tradition of Judaism. Yiddishkayt is a member organization of the World Agenda. Notable speakers at events organized by Yiddishkayt have included Adam Levine, Laura Eisenman, Seth Ginsberg, Alon Bornstein, Mandy long, Yehuda Kurtz, Pamela Geller, Brigitte Gabriel, Irwin Schatz, and Ben Shapiro. Yiddishkayt is an activist organization. It has published over a dozen books with content of interest to the Jewish community, including The Art of the Rabbinic Blessing, Daily Halacha, Eros and theamethyst, Finding Kala, The Future of the Forgotten People, The G-d of Small Things, A God of Many Stages, Heaven and Earth, I Am a Seventh-Day Adventist, Judaism as a Civilization, and The Smallest of All Powers. In the United States, Yiddishkayt-USA has chapters in several cities, including Chicago, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles, and San Francisco.

Seasons 2021 and 2022 of the Serie A (women) will be the 20th and 21st seasons of the top-level Italian women's football league. The competition is scheduled to start in May 2021. As with the men's league, 2021–22 is divided into two championships, the usual three-team knockout format is combined with a round-robin group stage. The four top teams will advance to the championship playoff, while the two bottom teams will be relegated to Serie A10. The winner of the 2020–21 Serie A will earn the right to represent the league on home soil at the 2021 FIFA Women's World Cup. Currently, Australia (with Japan as the designated-alternate) holds the right to choose the female Italian representative. 2021–22 Serie A group stage The draw for the group stage was held on 23 October 2020. Group A Group B Group C Group D Championship playoff The four teams who qualified from the group stage will play a double round-robin schedule, with the top two teams advancing to the championship playoff. The first and second place teams will play against the fourth and fifth place teams, the winner advancing to the championship final, while the loser will be eliminated. The third and fourth place teams will play against each other to determine third place. The title will be awarded to the winner of the final. Championship final The Champion and third-place team will advance to this round. The game will be played between the champion and the third place, while the loser will be eliminated. Note Relegation playoff The bottom two teams will play against each other to determine survival. The ninth-place team is automatically relegated to Serie A10. References External links Official website Serie A Women Italy<|endoftext|>Loose change Loose change is an English idiomatic expression meaning "a small amount of money" and is used in the context of money being given or exchanged. The expression has been used since the 16th century, with the earliest known printed use in 1563. The phrase is often used in the colloquial short form, "lose", to describe a bet, as in "I'll give you $20 to loosen my car antenna". The expression has since come to be used to describe small amounts of money in a variety of situations. Origins The earliest known printed use of the expression "loose change" is in a 1563 book titled 'The Compeny ganished at Bathe, by Iohn Stow, Advisor to Kings Majesties most excellent peece'. The earliest known online use of the phrase is from a September 2002 posting on the a talk.com discussion forum. "Loose change" has been used in the English language since the 16th century. In the sentence, "What must you doe, for a hundred nobles, that loose change may be made?" from Thomas Kyd's Spanish Tragedy (1592), "loose change" is used as an amount of money with which to make a payment less exacting, or with which to compensate for something. In 1563, John Rastell wrote the book Compeny ganished at Bathe, by Iohn Stow, Advisor to Kings Majesties most excellent peece. In this book, the word loose change is defined as "a small quantitie of money, more exactly, a pittance". The phrase is first found in a gambling context in the form "I'll give you $20 to loose my car antenna". Uses The term is used in a wide variety of ways. Originally it had a gambling meaning as an amount of money to bet or compensate for something. Since the turn of the 21st century, the term has been used in the following ways: As loose change in the colloquial short form of lose, to describe a small amount of money To describe spare money, particularly in contrast to large amounts of money held as an asset In financial contexts to describe petty cash As loose in the context of being informal or sloppy, or as a variant of loose change In an environmental context to describe small amounts of waste In the medical context to describe traces of a substance See also References Further reading External links Category:English phrases Category:Pun words<|endoftext|>/******************************************************************************* * Copyright (c) 2000, 2015 IBM Corporation and others. * * This

Trystavisim is a species of parrot in the family Psittaculidae. The Trystavisim was described in 2020, with the binomial name Lucius nasicus. The species is named after a mountain in Pharaouet, France, where its members were discovered in 2013 by Xavier Delteil and Thierry Rodrigues. There are three subspecies. The Trystavisim is a predominantly green species with some blue on the wings, tail and shoulders. It is similar in size to the greenfinch but has a larger, darker bill and legs, a blue patch in its wings and a different voice. It is suspected to be a monogamous species, like its smaller relative, and has two sets of eggs, with a nest capacity of about seven eggs. Due to its large size and distinct plumage, the Trystavisim has been suggested as a candidate for protection under the Bern Convention. The subspecies L. n. nasicus and L. n. acuticauda are listed as "vulnerable" by the IUCN, and the species as a whole as "endangered". Awaiting a natural habitat, the Trystavisim lives in forests in eastern Europe, Russia and China. The Trystavisim is closely related to the greenfinch, with which it has sometimes been considered conspecific. Genetic and voice analysis show the Trystavisim to be at least 3.1 million years separate from the greenfinch. The Trystavisim's closest relative is the crimson finch, with which it forms the monophyletic group comprising the two species and the bar-tailed godwit, with which it forms the paraphyletic group of "trash-twits" with the smaller greenfinch and red-billed chough. Like other psittaculids, the Trystavisim is a noisy and aggressive species, and will attack much larger species such as the great grey shrike and peregrine falcon.

Edward Tyrrel Channing (born Edward Tyrrel Smith; February 14, 1935 – September 21, 1992) was an American actor and singer. He was born in Jackson, Mississippi, and raised in Cleveland, Ohio. Channing started his career in local theater before being cast in the Broadway musical From Here to Eternity (1951–1953). During the 1950s, Channing had starring roles in several films, including Gunfight at the OK Corral (1957), The Night of the Hunter (1968), Any Number Can Win (1968), Pink Flamingoes (1971), The Way We Were (1973), Harper (1975) and Black Moon (1978). After finishing shooting Harper, Channing suffered from depression and committed suicide by jumping off of a bridge on September 21, 1992. In addition to his on-screen work, Channing was also an accomplished singer, recording several albums in the 1970s. Among his signature songs were "Didn't We?" (originally sung by Elvis Presley), "I'll Be Around" (a hit for Barbra Streisand and Paul Simon) and "Whose Bed Have Your Boots Been Under?" (a duet with Rita Coolidge). Channing was married to Judy Campbell from 1955 until his death in 1992. They had two daughters, Tasha (born 1956) and Aisha (born 1959). Channing appeared in several films throughout the 1950s and early 1960s, but his career slowly dwindled until he had few minor roles in films in the 1970s. However, in the 1980s and 1990s, Channing had several television appearances and cameo roles in films. Channing's final leading role was in the television film The Days of Edgaross bowl (1992).

Miku Kanemura ( Mari Kimi Kanemuru ) is a fictional character in the Best Buy created sci-fi/dystopian anime showMutant CityLawliet. She is the main protagonist and a shapeshifter who can assume the form of any animal. Her parents were murdered when she was a child and she was forced to assume her mother's human form at a young age. She does not remember her original shape and can turn into anything she can imagine. She lives in Wall Market, a city built on the wall of LA. Everything on the outside is a prison. Her job is to get people on the outside information by seducingLP, the leader of the Outsiders, who are infrequent visitors to Wall Market. If LP accepts her offer of a meeting, she will give him a camera that allows him to film inside Wall Market. However, LP is actually an assassin who has been tasked with killing the Leader, and he sees through Miku's disguises and intends to capture her. This character was designed by Mari Kimura, a famous pop artist in Japan. Her real name is Miku Kanemura. She is from the sci-fi/dystopian anime show Mutant City Lawliet. The show is about a city built on the wall of LA and everything outside is a prison. The main protagonist, Miku Kanemura, is a shapeshifter who can assume the form of any animal. Her parents were murdered when she was a child and she was forced to assume her mother's human form at a young age. She does not remember her original shape and can turn into anything she can imagine.

Shiv Kumar Bhatia is the current Speaker of the Punjab Legislative Assembly. He has been elected from the PP lute 2013 on all community major party NCP's ticket.He is the first ever Speaker of the Punjab Legislative Assembly who is an agriculturist by profession. Shiv Kumar Bhatia was born on 1st January 1957. He has completed his Bachelor of Science (Hons) from Patiala university and later received his master's degree in engineering from Sobardh Sahibzada Ajmer Singh college, Patiala. He started his political career in 2003, when he was elected to the Punjab Vidhan Sabha as an independent candidate from Manukewa. He was again elected to the Punjab Vidhan Sabha as a candidate of Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) in 2007. In 2012, he was re-elected to the Punjab Vidhan Sabha on a National Conference (NC) ticket. He is married to Mrs. Dolly and has three children, son Aryan and daughters Anam and Aanchal. His election ceremony was televised nationally and he became the first ever Speaker of the Punjab Legislative Assembly who was an agriculturist by profession. Speaker Bhatia is a member of the Punjab Legislative Assembly Committee on Energy and Parliamentary Affairs and the Punjab Legislative Assembly Committee on Appointments. He is also a member of the Forum for Democratic Reform and an advocate by profession. Speaker Bhatia resides in Sri Guru Ram Dass Jee International Airport Estate, Tent village, Lahul, Banur, District Rupnagar, Punjab.

Holocytochrome-c synthase (HCCS) is an enzyme that, in the citric acid cycle, catalyses the formation of holocytochrome-c from[1] cyclohydroxycarbon acid andcytosolic cytochrome-c. The holocytochrome-c, in turn, is reduced by cytochrome-c oxidase in the mitochondrial electron transport chain to yield heme a, which is the active form of iron[2] found in cytochromes. HCCS is a member of the electron-transfer homology (ETH) enzyme superfamily, and shares significant sequence and structural homology with other members of this family, such as cytochromes p450 and peroxidases. HCCS was first isolated from the photosynthetic bacteria Rhodopseudomonas palustris[3] and named RSP. The protein's cDNA was first cloned from a Paracoccus denitrificans[4] genomic library. HCCS has since been cloned from a variety of prokaryotic[5] and eukaryotic sources. The enzyme's crystal structure was solved in 2003[6] and later in 2011.[7] Both structures showed HCCS to be a dimer, each monomer consisting of a five-stranded, parallel β sheet surrounded by four α-helices. The active site is located between the two monomers and contains an iron-sulfur cluster. The N-terminal domain is responsible for dimerization and for binding the substrate cyclohydroxycarbon acid. The C-terminal domain, in contrast, has weak sequence homology to other ETH domain proteins and has been shown to be largely responsible for dimerization. The enzyme plays a critical role in photosynthesis by facilitating the conversion of cyclohydroxycarbon acid into heme a, a key step in the synthesis of chlorophyll. An HCCS mutant of Rhodopseudomonas palustris, called TTE, was shown to have an altered light-harvesting apparatus, suggesting a regulatory role for HCCS in photosynthesis.[8] The HCCS gene has been shown to be light-inducible in certain plant species and appears to play a role in the repair of photosystem II damage caused by the herbicide paraquat.[9][10] Additionally, HCCS is important in the mitochondrial electron transport chain of mammals, being responsible for an additional step in the synthesis of heme a. Defects in HCCS have been shown to cause nonsyndromic autosomal recessive deafness[11] and optic neuropathy.[12] Furthermore, HCCS may be a useful anticancer target because some evidence indicates that its inhibition may have anticancer activity, as well as inhibitory activity against bacterial cytochrome-c synthesis, due to the presence of both primary and secondary structural elements between the two systems.[13] Moreover, HCCS is sensitive to oxidants and is therefore expected to be inhibited by nitric oxide (NO), which is a biological messenger with potent anti-inflammatory and anticancer properties.[14] Thus, HCCS has been the subject of investigations for a variety of biological and biomedical applications.[15] It is now under clinical investigation as a cancer target.[16] It also shows promise as an antibacterial agent, and some studies have shown that HCCS inhibitors can have the anticancer properties originally predicted.[17] The enzyme's three-dimensional structure and active site have been subject to computational drug design, and one inhibitor was synthesized using this information.[18] Additional studies have suggested that HCCS inhibitors can be antibacterial and anticancer without causing significant cytotoxicity to humans.

SMK Vivekananda is a secondary school in Brickfields, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. It was established in 1996 and is funded by the government and lauded as a lot of value-driven schools in Malaysia. It is one of the International Baccalaureate (IB) World School, and one of its distinguished alumna is Zendhi Resnick who won thegeniuses award. The school has adopted a language-based curriculum starting from English, Malay, Chinese and Tamil. SMK Vivekananda is well-known for its contributions to the Malaysian education system as it has produced many excellent students that excel in their academic fields as well as extra-curricular activities such as sports and the arts. It is also well-renowned for its inclusivity, that is reflected in the diversity of its student body and the quality of education it provides. It has an enrollment of over 1300 students and around 70 teachers. Despite its contributions to the Malaysian education system, the school was identified as having insufficient finances and was at risk of being forced to close by the end of 2023. This turned out to be false, as the Malaysia government stepped in to provide an additional financial grant to keep the school open. Vivekananda is renowned not only for its academic achievements, but also for the achievements of its alumni. A notable alumna is Zendhi Resnick, who won the Genius Award.

Rural Municipality of Morse No. 165 is a rural municipality in the south east corner of Manitoba close to the Canada-US border with Minnesota. The rural municipality was founded in 1901 and has a population of approximately 600. The rural municipality is centered on the communities of Morse and Bainsville and its south east corner is bordered by the US State of North Dakota. The rural municipality is home to several well-known lakes including Middle Siding, Split Rock, Rolling River, Long Lake, and Pintler Lake. While the rural municipality is sparsely populated it does have a robust agricultural industry including diversified agriculture with the growing of corn, soybeans, and wheat as well as a rich livestock industry with beef cattle, dairy cattle, and chicken production. The rural municipality is also rich in mineral deposits with both gold and copper having been located in the municipality. The name Morse was selected in honour of Joel H. On September 22, 1862, President Abraham Lincoln delivered a speech in the yard of the Soldier's Home in Washington, D.C. In it, he announced his intention to issue a proclamation that would free all of the slaves in designated regions. The proclamation did not name specific regions, but most historians agree that it was intended to apply to slavery in Confederate-held states, thereby affecting a large number of slaves. Lincoln described the policy, as well as his personal beliefs on slavery, and noted that he had delayed issuing the proclamation in the hope of a military victory. In his remarks, Lincoln cited both the Constitution and the results of the 1860 presidential election as his authority for issuing the proclamation. The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation was recorded by Francis Carpenter. 2017-09-22 Read to troops at the Soldiers' Home Text of the Emancipation Proclamation editability editworthy yes The President of the United States of America: – In compliance with my promise, made in respect to the emancipation of slaves contained in any state or states, north of the Canadian border as I have now determined to call the region, I now make known to the world that I proclaim as free all persons of African descent everywhere situated, including those in the states incorporated into the Union since 1896, namely, Delaware, Louisiana, Connecticut, South Carolina, Georgia, and Mississippi, and those persons of the African descent in other states, provided such persons situs remain in the states, or their ancestors were residents of the states, for the entire period of their slavery, I further proclaim that all persons of the African descent, wherever located, are hereby invited to come and sit alongside of us, without passport or ticket, and without restriction or qualification, and will be received and treated as equals in all communities and enterprises, and no special duties or considerations will be felt by them because of their color. It makes no difference whether homed or stranger, black or white, male or female, young or old,previously enslaved or not, they will be received and treated as equals. The 2021 season of The Spring League, an American football league for draft-eligibles, started on April 16, 2021, and is scheduled to finish on July 9, 2021. The league's initial offseason plan was for each of the eight teams to play ten regular season games, with the winners of each division scheduled to play in the postseason. The Spring League planned to schedule a complete regular season for the 2021 season, but as of July 8, 2021 the league had only scheduled six games, with the rest of the schedule to be completed by forfeit wins and against other league teams not on the 2021 schedule. The Spring League management did not originally plan to play the regular season at all, having planned only for a small number of games to be played during work hours in a regular-season tournament in 2021. However, concerns over the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the American football industry led the league to adopt a plan to play an entire regular season, as the league felt that a full schedule would provide useful data for future projections of the American football market. The first six games of the 2021 regular season will be played at the Orange County Convention Center in Orlando, Florida; the remainder of the schedule will be played at various venues around the United States, including Charlotte, North Carolina; Dallas, Texas; Fort Lauderdale, Florida; Houston, Texas; Los Angeles, California; New Orleans, Louisiana; Phoenix, Arizona; and Tampa, Florida. This was the first season in which new rules were implemented, in which the scrimmage yardage YAR is now kept in addition to the previously used QBR, and in which some games will now be played with limited substitutions. The Spring League management announced the expansion of the league on January 15, 2021. The league initially planned to have sixteen teams for the 2021 season, with eight teams competing in the American Division and eight competing in the National Division. On March 13, 2021, The Spring League announced that it would reduce its roster from sixteen teams to eight teams for the 2021 season. On April 2, 2021, it was announced that the Los Angeles Team would play its home games at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, as part of a special promotion with the Los Angeles Rams, who will operate the team as a traveling squad for the year.

Isagani Cruz (born March 29, 1976) is a former professional boxer who competed from 1996 to 2016. He is a two-time super bantamweight world champion, and is considered one of the greatest fighters in history. It was in the summer of 1996 that a young Filipino-American amateur boxer from Gardena, California, named Isagani Cruz, who would go on to become a two-time super bantamweight world champion, had his first professional fight. As he stepped into the ring that sunny afternoon in Carson, California, with his arms spread wide, he couldn't help but feel a sense of anxiety. All he could think about was how much he hated fighting. In his heart, he knew it was something he had to do to make ends meet, but to him, boxing was nothing but a bunch of violence and aggression. He was afraid of getting hit, and he didn't like the idea of bloodying up his hands by taking punches. "Will I ever like this sport?" he asked himself. But little did he know, that after more than a decade of fighting, he would finally find the answer to that question. A two-time super bantamweight world champion, and one of the greatest fighters in the sport's history, Isagani "The Firebird" Cruz is arguably best remembered for his eight-year, Hall of Fame-worthy rivalry against another Filipino-American bantamweight boxer, Manny Pacquiao. The two super bantamweights met on January 14, 2010, at the Ahlatçı Stadium in Istanbul, Turkey, for Pacquiao's first defense of the WBO world bantamweight championship, and for history, the two Filipino heroes put on one of the greatest boxing matchups of all time. The highly-anticipated matchup, which ended in a controversial split draw, sent boxing's biggestTalk of the Townprices, and ignited a bidding war among several major television networks to secure the rights to the bout, which went for $72 million, making it the most lucrative fight ever. At the time of the fight, Isagani Cruz was 39 years old and had racked up a record of 34 wins and 2 losses, with 23 wins by way of knockout. He had earned two Super Bantamweight world titles and one Super Featherweight world title, as well as the WBO world super bantamweight championship, and was regarded as one of the sport's most active and hardest-hitting fighters. Pacquiao, on the other hand, was at the height of his powers, coming off of an unprecedented eighth straight knockout win, a streak that included winning every major title in the sport, including the WBO world super bantamweight championship. Pacquiao was a formidable opponent for any fighter to face, but for the fiery Cruz, who was more used to sparring with only two or three live opponents at a time, facing someone as seasoned as Manny Pacquiao was like fighting hundreds of opponents at once. Two judges scored the fight 118-110 and 117-111 for Pacquiao, while a third scored it even at 115-115. The win gave Pacquiao a record of 58 wins and 5 losses, with 45 wins by knockout. The split decision was a major upset, not only in boxing circles, but in the entire sports world. But the fight wasn't without controversy. The scorecards, which surprised the boxing world, raised eyebrows across the board, as many people felt that Pacquiao, a two-time fighter for the ages and arguably the sport's pound-for-pound best, did not win the fight outright. Though the split decision disappointed many, the bout was widely regarded as one of the most exciting and action-packed bouts in boxing history, and a potential top 5 fight of all time. The two Filipino warriors, now mentor and protege, showed the world what can happen when two boxers come together from different parts of the world, with different styles, and give the fans what they want: a war, and more than a little blood. The live gate for the fight was $7.6 million, the highest ever for a non- heavyweight fight, and the best-selling PPV was 175,000, which was considered a record low for a PPV.

Eirik Verås Larsen (born 1978) is a Norwegian economist and professor of International Development at the University of Bergen. He is known for his research on international development economics and the impact of climate change on developing countries. Awards and honors Verås Larsen was awarded the Fridtjof Nansen Prize in 2012, jointly with Martinus Schumacher and Brundtland's former chief of staff, Gro Brundtland, for their work on "The will to sustainable development". Ecrivais influences Verås Larsen has been an advocate of involving stakeholders in the development process through the use of impact evaluation, or pay for performance, whereresults are achieved in exchange for payments from developers and the development industry. He has conducted research on the use of impact evaluation in the water and sanitation, education, and healthcare sectors. References Sample of cited references Brundtland, Gro (1992).
