Here is the List of prime ministers of Nepal since the country became a federal parliamentary republic in 2015. Bidhya NARayan AYA Parliamentary procedures were observed to elect Bidhya NARayan AYA as the prime minister of Nepal for the first time. he was born in Ilam, Nepal on 17 January 1979. He studied Bachelor of Science in Agriculture (Hons) at Chaudhary Bahadur Singh University, Raichur, India. He started his political career as a teenager by joining leftist parties and protests. In 1999, he formed a new political party called Nepali Congress. In 2001, he joined Nepali Congress (Democratic) led by Surendra KC and staged a street protest in front of National parliament against the then king Gyanendra, however, the protest was dispersed by the police leading to his arrest. He was elected president of Nepal in 2014. He became the prime minister of Nepal in the first democratic election after the Constitution of Nepal 2015 was adopted. His biggest achievement as prime minister was the nationwide uprising against extreme poverty and unbridled corruption during his first 100 days in power. Over 10,000 pages of files of the previous Nepali Congress led government were secured under the RTI act and turned over to the new government which showed the enormous wealth accumulated by the previous government which was unaccounted for. This included 266 luxury vehicles, 39 houses, 25 gift hampers worth over $250,000, and 39 flats in New Delhi, London, and Singapore. Following the uprising, Bidhya had formed a strong political base in Nepal with the youth and farmers supporting his party in the Constituent Assembly election. As of 2023, he is the longest serving prime minister in the history of Nepal, with his second term ending on 26 February 2023.

Juniperus chinensis, also known as Chinese juniper, is a species of conifer in the cypress family, Cupressaceae. It is native to China, Korea, and Japan. It is a medium to large sized tree, typically 20-35 meters (80-130 feet) tall, with a trunk up to 1.5 cm in diameter. The leaves are spirally arranged, sometimes with a thorn on the underside of the bud scale. The leaves have a tip with a untoothed or serrated margin, and measure up to 6 cm long. The male cones are much smaller than the female cones. It is occasionally planted as an ornamental tree for its foliage, cones, and habitat. It is the state tree of China, Taiwan and Jersey. Juniperus chinensis is the most economically significant species of juniper for logging. The wood is strong, hard, and resistant to rot; it is used for utility poles, fence posts, mine timbers, and other structural uses. It is also used for engraving and crafts. The trees are often coppiced (cut over and over) for roughage. The oil from the cones is used for making juniper berry oil, a fragrance component in soaps and lotions. The oil from the cones and leaves is used in traditional medicine in China and Korea. The plant produces large quantities of juniper bitter, which is also used in traditional medicine. This is done by steeping the leaves in water and wine and drinking the mixture. Many animals find the tree very disagreeable, and will not touch it. Some of the habitat is considered threatened, especially the lowland forest in China. Varieties There are several varieties of Juniperus chinensis, which differ in leaf shape, and of lesser importance, in the genome. The most important variety for logging is J. chinensis 'Scotch pine', with relatively large, sharp, two-winged leaves. 'Lawrence of Aranmar' has deeply lobed leaves, and is used for planting. The variety J. chinensis 'Sargentii' has very narrow leaves similar in shape to those of the Douglas-fir. It was discovered growing near the site where Sargent's Juniper was discovered, and named for Sargent's expedition leader. Fairwater, Cardiff is a residential area in the south of Cardiff, capital of Wales. The area is surrounded by the city centre and the COBRA tower. The name derives from the former mining village of Fairwater, near Cardiff, with the Cardiff part added to distinguish it from Fairwater, Liverpool. Fairwater has become well known as one of the most desired residential areas in Wales and it is one of the highest perched areas in the whole country. The population of Fairwater was recorded as 12,005 at the 2011 Census. Fairwater was considered a working class district of South Cardiff, with mining and industrial origins. It has a strong community and many local groups and residents' associations contribute to the character and development of the area. A major redevelopment programme has improved many of the area's quality housing. There are currently several planning applications for new developments in Fairwater. Fairwater is known for its stunning views across the River Taff, the hills of Mid-Wales and the city centre of Cardiff. It is bordered by Bute Park to the south west, Pentower to the south east, and Airfields to the north. The main landmark in the area is the Cardiff International Sports Arena, which was opened in 1997 and is home to the Cardiff Devils ice hockey team and the Welsh Ice Hockey national team. Fairwater has a number of shops, a Morrisons supermarket, Fairwater Foods, Coop Supermarket, Iceland and a branch of JD Williams. The area also has a mixture of pubs and restaurants, Cardiff Arms Hotel, the Red Lion, the Fountain pub and several fish and chip shops. In the centre of the area, adjacent to the Parade shopping centre, is Fairwater Shopping Arcade which includes a launderette and many other small independent traders. Fairwater was included in the list of top 10 most desired areas to live in Wales for 2018 and 2019.

Indo Global Colleges is an annual gathering of school leaders from across India and global partners, such as ICFAI University, UK, Habeebullah University, Pakistan, Insead, France, Amity University, India and NIIT, India. The first edition of the event was organized in 2018 at Pondicherry, India. The two-day event focuses on leadership and campus activities with workshops, skill-based activities, and networking opportunities. Indo Global Colleges is organised to create an interactive platform for people working in education to connect and learn from each other. The event has been designed as a meeting point for leading Education thought leaders, practitioners and students from across the country and abroad. The event is an initiative of the Indo-Global Colleges Foundation (IGCF) an independent, not-for-profit, social enterprise, Indian NGO registered under Section 8 of the Companies Act 2013 and approved by the government of Puducherry. The overall goal of the Indo Global Colleges Foundation is to advance social change by focusing on developing leadership skills in young people from diverse communities and developing and promoting value based education practices. The vision of the Foundation is to advance the cause of education, raise awareness and support the education system in India in accordance with globally accepted best practices and teaching methods. Some of the major outcomes of the Foundation are improving the capacity of teachers, improving school infrastructure and developing more engaged student body. The Foundation also conducts capacity building programs for school principals, School Resource Officers and others supporting the educational system at the school level.

Osulf I of Bamburgh (r. 941–944) was the first Ealdorman of Bamburgh, one of the earliest recorded areas of Englaland. Osulf was a son of Saint Eadulf of Bamburgh and his wife Æthelthryth, possibly a granddaughter of Edward the Elder. Osulf's father was killed by Abbot Radulf of Hexham for supporting Edgar the Hunter, who was a rival to Eanwulf, the abbot's brother. Osulf was born shortly after, and Eanwulf was killed in battle later that year, with Eadulf joining Osulf at Bamburgh. During his adolescence, Osulf was tasked with leading an army to assist Æthelwold of Wessex against an attack by Kenneth MacAlpin, Lord of Alba. Osulf and Æthelwold came to an agreement and a peace was kept. At some point after 944, Osulf was killed by a Dane named Halfdan; his death is recorded by Wulfstan of York. By his marriage to Eadgifu, a daughter of Ealdorman Eadbert, Osulf had at least five sons, including Æthelstan, who would go on to become King of England. Through his sons, Osulf was the grandfather of Eadwulf, Eanflaed, Osulf, Æthelred and Eadric, the progenitors of the house of Bamburgh. Osulf was succeeded by his son Æthelstan.

Justin Lehr (born April 17, 1988) is an American internet personality, known for his YouTube channel "Thornworld" and internet celebrity status through his association with the youtube channels "World's GreatestGG" and "World's GreatestPSY". Lehr has received attention for his commentary on various topics, such as gender and cultural issues, as well as his personal mental health. His younger brother, John Lehr, is also an internet celebrity, and was a candidate in the 2018 special election for Texas's 32nd congressional district. Lehr was born in St. Joseph, Missouri and raised in St. Clairsville, Ohio. He has lived in Los Angeles, California since 2009. His first major-label release, Metalgod, was released on August 25, 2018. He is a graduate of Sinclair Community College and a current student at University of California, Santa Cruz. Lehr's primary vlogging channel, Thornworld, has over 3.4 million subscribers, and his secondary channel, JusPromo, has over 450,000 subscribers. His primary social media accounts include Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok. Lehr's gaming channel, Thornworld Games, has over 2.4 million followers. As of March 2020, Lehr's channel was advertising revenue from YouTube was over $15,000 per month. On December 10, 2019, Thornworld was reported to be the 19th most-subscribed YouTube channel. As of June 2023, Lehr's salary for the previous year was $120,000,paid in monthly installments of $8,333.33. Thornworld has received negative coverage for its viewership, with video games journalist Stephanie Hannah saying in February 2020 that "most people feel like they don't want to be represented by what Justin Lehr stands for." Lehr has said that he receives death threats on a regular basis, and has installed physical security at his home. Lehr was included on Paste's "25 Internet Star Breakouts of 2020" list and listed as one of Complex magazine's "25 Most Important Youtubers to Watch in 2021". Lehr was listed as number 23 on Vulture.com's "The New Gretas: 21 YouTube stars bringing order to the chaos of the pandemic era" list. Lehr's former college roommate and personal friend, Jake Paul, publicly feuded with Lehr over their conflicting opinions on the YouTube Star War, leading to Paul tweeting a diss track directed at Lehr. Lehr, in response, published a video on his channel titled "Everyone's Feelings Get Activated When You Pay For Therapy", in which he admitted to spending $40,000 on therapy over a five-year period. Lehr said that his time in therapy was "one of the most important things" that he did to help him grow as a person, and claimed that it was "paying to talk to a shrink" that hurt more than therapy itself. Since the release of that video, Lehr's former friend Jake Paul has built a channel at PAO with content attacking Lehr, as well as his parents' business, Rain City Button, selling Thin Mints-themed buttonback buttons; Rain City Button is a sponsor on Paul's channel. Lehr's mental health has also been brought up on other YouTubers' channels. In response, Lehr published a video titled "Calling Bullshit On Online Reviews of Mental Health Products" in which he and his father spend an hour going through reviews of mental health products on Amazon.com. One product that received a lot of negative reviews from customers was Kiviax, a meditation headband, which Lehr's father criticized for being too expensive, ineffective, and large. After the video was published, multiple consumers with disabilities received death threats over Kiviax. Lehr's father was fired from his job as a university professor over the threats, and Lehr started receiving threats as well. Lehr later claimed in another video that he had been hacked, and that the threats had not been sent by his actual supporters. One YouTuber who had supported Lehr, known as Tessa, disavowed the content of that video and apologized to Lehr for supporting the threats made to him. After receiving additional death threats via private messages, Lehr published a video titled "I'm Leaving YouTube" in which he stated that he would be taking a break from YouTube to focus on mental health. Lehr has stated that he is working on a book, and will be relaunching Thornworld as a podcast. He currently lives

The Georgia Tech Center for Music Technology (GT CMT) is an interdisciplinary research center focused on music technology, the applications of technology to music creation, performance, and consumption. The center was founded in 2014 with the goal of fostering interdisciplinary collaborations between GT and the Institute of Audio Research and expanding the availability of music technology through outreach events. bulleted list * interdisciplinary research * founded in 2014 * goal is to foster interdisciplinary collaborations between GT and the Institute of Audio Research bery The Georgia Tech Center for Music Technology (GT CMT) is an interdisciplinary research center focused on music technology, the applications of technology to music creation, performance, and consumption. The center was founded in 2014 with the goal of fostering interdisciplinary collaborations between GT and the Institute of Audio Research and expanding the availability of music technology through outreach events. The Georgia Tech CMT is affiliated with but not necessarily hosted by the Georgia Institute of Technology, and is operated under contract to the Music Technology program within the School of Music at the University of California, Santa Barbara. The Georgia Tech CMT was the first Music Technology Center founded outside of the University of California system and the first operated under a contract. The center's research staff includes Jonathan Cohen, director, and Jon Wilkin, research scientist. The Georgia Tech CMT hosts two principal research groups. The Audio Characterization and Synthesis research group led by Jonathan Cohen studies the interaction between sound and the physical environment using acoustic, audio, and robotics research. The Music Instrument Technology group led by Jon Wilkin focuses on creating new technologies for musical instrument design and robotics.

Fort Frances Royals are a junior ice hockey team based in Fort Frances, Ontario, Canada. They play in the Western Division of the Mid-Western division of the Central Canada Hockey League. Their home arena is Fort Frances Sportsplex and Carling Avenue Park. The team is owned by the Fort Frances Red Wings Ltd. The franchise was founded in 2014 as an expansion team and made their first playing season in 2015. The team's head coach is former NHL forward Pierre-Alexandre Parenteau and their general manager is Dan Spang. The team's current captain is Nolan MURPHY. Fort Frances finished the 2016-17 season as Western Division champions and as Central Canada Champions, giving the team the right to represent the conference and the provincials in Quebec City. In 2022, the Royals became the first Junior "A" team from Northern Ontario to win the J. Ross Robertson Cup, as provincials champions. Fort Frances is the only Canadian city to have two NHL players on their roster: Nolan Murphy and Tage Thompson. Nolan Murphy was selected 41st overall by the Colorado Avalanche in the 2001 NHL Entry Draft. Tage Thompson was drafted 40th overall by the Calgary Flames in the 2008 NHL Entry Draft. In 2022, the Fort Frances Royals became the first Junior "A" team from Northern Ontario to win the J. Ross Robertson Cup, as provincials champions. Players on the 2022 team included Nolan Murphy, who was selected 41st overall by the Colorado Avalanche in the 2001 NHL Entry Draft, and Tage Thompson, who was drafted 40th overall by the Calgary Flames in the 2008 NHL Entry Draft. The 2022 team also featured 14 Fort Frances Red Wings Ltd. players on their roster. Prior to the 2022 championship, the Fort Frances Royals made it to the Robertson Cup final in 2015 and 2017. The 2022 championship was also notable for its aftermath, as the team's owner, the Fort Frances Red Wings Ltd., offered bonuses to the entire team for winning the championship, not just the division title. The team agreed to the offer and paid out the bonuses. The offer came under fire from the NHL's executive committee, and the team was subsequently banned from the playoffs for the 2021 season, although this punishment was later reduced to one season. The Fort Frances Red Wings Ltd. is the only Junior "A" team in the world to have two NHL players on their roster. The team also holds the distinction of being the first Junior "A" team from Northern Ontario to win the J. Ross Robertson Cup. The Fort Frances Royals were league champions for five consecutive seasons from 2016 to 2021. Their final record in 2022 was 53 wins, 35 losses, 3 ties, and 20 wins against 0 losses in the playoffs. The 2023 Royals season was cancelled. The Fort Frances Red Wings Ltd. also operates the Fort Frances Flames of the LQ Hussars (Canadian Major Junior) Hockey League and the Fort Frances Spotted Hendricksons of the Superior International Junior Hockey League. The original team was known as the Fort Frances GenerationFuture, and intended to use that name in seasons 2015 and 2016. A disagreement with the local newspaper, the Fort Frances Echo, over the rights to use the GenerationFuture name resulted in the team being renamed as the Fort Frances Royals for the 2017 season. The Fort Frances Royals have appeared in the finals and won the J. Ross Robertson Cup in 2022. They also won the Central Canada championship in 2016 and 2017. Their most notable achievement to date is qualifying for the 2017 Memorial Cup, where they became the first team from Northern Ontario to do so. In 2022, the team set a Robertson Cup record for most consecutive penalty shots allowed without a miss, going 34 for 34. The team's anthem singer, Jordan Oldham, died in February 2022 after a two-year battle with cancer. The Royals wore a pin with Oldham's symbol on their sweater during the 2022 playoffs in Oldham's memory. The 2023 season was cancelled. The Fort Frances Red Wings Ltd. also owns and operates the Fort Frances Flames of the LQ Hussars (Canadian Major Junior) Hockey League and the Fort Frances Spotted Hendricksons of the Superior International Junior Hockey League. The Ministry of Justice (Italian: Ministero del Direito or MD) is a Italian ministry established on 18 May 1861, originally as the Ministero degli Affari di Correlazione. Its full name changed on 12 December 1892. The ministry is focused on the governance and administration of justice, with a particular emphasis on constitutional matters. Originally part of the Interior Ministry, from 1898 to 1943 it was part of the Justice Ministry, and since 1943 it has been an independent ministry. The current minister is Marco Bucci, member of the Five Star Movement, appointed 10 February 2019 and sworn in on 20 February. The New Zealand Law Society (NZLS or Society) is the governing body of the legal profession in New Zealand. It was established by act of Parliament in 1862 and received its current name in 1877. sound-out Law Society sound-out New Zealand Law Society sound-out New Zelerand Law Society sound-out Lawes Society of New Zealand EMENT@sound-out.com Edit article sound-out MANAGEMENT OF SCHOLARS The Society’s objectives are to maintain and enhance the practice of law, to promote the administration of justice, to advance the interests of lawyers and the law, and to perform other functions necessary or desirable to achieve these objectives. LAWYERS AND THEIR SERVICES Lawyers in New Zealand are regulated by the Societies’ Rules of Professional Conduct and Conduct Rules. LEGAL SERVICES The Society regulates over 900 lawyers who practise in 36 offices throughout New Zealand. LEGISLATIVE FUNCTIONS The Societies plays a significant role in New Zealand's legislative function through its participation in the bicameral Parliamentary Counsel Committee which provides written submissions to parliamentary inquiries and committees. It also provides advice to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, the Auditor-General and Parliamentary Committees regarding freedom of information requests and publicly funded information. LEGAL SYSTEM New Zealand operates a mixed system of personal and common law. Litigation in New Zealand is mostly conducted either by courtrooms or in arbitration tribunals or conciliation courts, and a successful plaintiff is entitled to “relief”. However, in criminal cases, a defendant is usually not required to plead “guilty” or furnish a “defense”. Criminal cases in New Zealand are usually conducted without a jury. "Māori" laws also apply to certain cases. There is a single Constitution for both courts, but there are several independent systems of laws, depending on the type of case. The judiciary comprises the Supreme Court, seven High Courts, and a number of District Courts. LEGAL ENFORCEMENT New Zealand has a system of civil law with few customs and precedent having influence over outcome. The Courts have a significant power to award damages, or issue injunctions. The Statute Law Revision Act, passed in 1908, is the principal law reform act. It replaced voluntary codes of practice with statutory law, requiring statutory declarations in writing, and it introduced forms of pleading. There are also numerous Acts of Parliament which modify or supplement the common law, such as the Plant Protection Act, Animal Welfare Act, Employment Act, etc. PROFESSIONAL OVERSIGHT The Society is responsible for the registration, ethical standards, and discipline of New Zealand lawyers. PRACTICE MANAGEMENT The Society maintains continuous insurance programs covering leased premises, corporate liability, errors and omissions, and public liability. INDIVIDUAL PRACTICE Individual practitioners are governed by the Rules of Professional Conduct and the Code of Conduct. PRACTICE REVIEW The Society carries out regular reviews of individual practitioners to monitor their compliance with the Rules and Code. ADVERTISING AND PROMOTIONAL MODELS The Society has published a client service standards and practice booklet for all lawyers and a handbook for in-house counsel. The Society provides leadership on advertising and promotional matters through its role in promoting public awareness of legal services and the profession through its publications and other programs. Jokkmokk Municipality is a municipality in Norrbotten County in northern Sweden. It covers an area of 705 km2 (258 sq mi), and had a population of 14,849 in 2010. The administrative centre is located in the city of Jokkmokk. The municipality is named after Jokkmokk Bay, a sector of the Bothnian Sea. The locality of Koipo has been the municipal seat since 1928. Jokkmokk is known for its winter sport activities, in particular skiing, snowboarding, cross-country skiing and sledding. There are also several long-distance walking trails passing through the municipality. Among the most popular destinations are Kvikkjokk and Savonlinna, which are both old towns with well preserved medieval architecture. The Kvikkjokk Basilica is the oldest functioning church in Finland and the only surviving wooden church from the 15th century. Jokkmokk is also home to the Jokkmokk Speedway, which is the most northern sport of the international speedway sport league. Jokkmokk is one of the most northern municipalities of Sweden. It borders Finland to the south and Russian Karelia to the east. The nearest major city is Kiruna, which is situated about 100 km to the south. Most of the population living in the urban area are descended from Swedish settlers who came to live here during the late 19th century. However, a significant minority are actually Finns who have lived in the municipality for many years. The majority of the population in Jokkmokk speak Swedish as their native language, but the city is legally bilingual, with Finnish being the second official language.

Yamatogoto is an extinct language of Colombia that was spoken in the area of Antioquia, today it is a unilingual region of Colombia where the Ampasté family speaks a Mayan language. The language is not known to have left any written records, it was originally thought to be a language of the Muisca, the original inhabitants of the New Kingdom of Granada but it was later proven to be a unilingual region of Colombia. It is considered a poor imitation of Muisca with similarities to the nearby Kö Lakes Language which is also undecipherable. The Yamatogoto region of Antioquia today corresponds to the municipality of San Juan de Bucarepa, the department that it is Colombia and the Ampasté family that speaks the Mayan language Ampasté. The language is not known to have left any written records, it was originally thought to be a language of the Muisca, the original inhabitants of the New Kingdom of Granada but it was later proven to be a unilingual region of Colombia. It is considered a poor imitation of Muisca with similarities to the nearby Kö Lakes Language which is also undecipherable. It is not certain whether Yamatogoto and Kö Lakes Language are related or not, both are extinct undecipherable languages and there is no other evidence to determine if they are related. Even though it is undecipherable today, in the past Yamatogoto was thought to be a language of the Muisca, the original inhabitants of the New Kingdom of Granada. This is because it was believed to be similar to the language of the Kö Lakes Language which are also Muisca languages, however it was later proven to be undecipherable. Today the Yamatogoto region of Antioquia today corresponds to the municipality of San Juan de Bucarepa, the department that it is Colombia and the Ampasté family that speaks the Mayan language Ampasté.

Ballerina Stakes (Canada) is a Canadian Thoroughbred horse race held annually in early July at Woodbine Racetrack in Toronto, Ontario. The event is named after the main breed of Ballet dancer. The race is hosted by both Woodbine and Fort Erie Race Track which are just north of the Peace Bridge in Fort Erie, Ontario and thus attracts many horses and jockeys from the United States. The Ballerina Stakes is a six-furlong race on the turf run in a Middle Distance RaceType and is open to 3-year-old fillies. The race was inaugurated in 2018 as a unlisted Grade III event, the previous running of the race was a Grade II-listed event called the Ballerina Stakes at Woodbine Race Track which was inaugurated in 2014 and named after the Ballerina Stakes at Arlington Park which was inaugurated in 2006. The Ballerina Stakes at Woodbine was the first stakes race to be held at the new Woodbine track in 2018 and attracted many of the top North American racehorses to race on the evening prior to the Breeders' Cup at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, California. In 2019, the event was upgraded to Grade III status and the name was changed to the Ballerina Stakes at Woodbine. The Ballerina Stakes at Fort Erie was inaugurated the following year in 2020 and is named in honour of the main breed of Ballet dancer, the Ballerina. The race takes place on the last Friday of July, one week after the Woodbine event. It is a six-furlong race on the turf run in a Middle Distance RaceType and is open to 3-year-old fillies. The Ballerina Stakes at Fort Erie was the second stakes race to be held at Fort Erie racetrack in 2020 and also features many of the best horses and jockeys from the US racing south to race. Winners of the Ballerina Stakes at Woodbine, Ballerina Stakes at Fort Erie and Ballerina Stakes 2018: - Magic Wand (IRE) 2019: - My Chief Commander (USA) 2020: - Royalgmail (USA)

Miguel Avila (born Miguel Avila Hernandez) is an American actor. He is best known for his work in Hollywood films, such as Entrapment (1999), The Game (1997), Set it Off (1993), Dead Man Walking (film) (1995), Do the Right Thing (1989), and The Last Boy Scout (2008). In 2014, he was awarded Best Actor at the Miami International Film Festival for his performance in Escobar: Paradise Lost. You can also see Miguel Avila in some animated movies like The Iron Giant (1999), Eloise at Christmastime (2000), Cats & Dogs (2001) and more. Miguel Avila was born in New Jersey, USA. He is the son of Hector Avila and Hilda Hernandez. His early education was in Mexico, where he first studied in school. Then he moved back to the United States and studied at New York University and made his film debut in Set it Off (1993). Miguel started his acting career in local theater groups in New York. Later, he moved to Los Angeles to further his acting career. He is mostly known for his role in Hollywood films. Miguel Avila is married to Monica Guzman. They have three children. You can see more about Miguel Avila on IMDB.com or Wikipedia. Miguel Avila debut was in the film Set it Off (1993). He also appeared in Do the Right Thing (1989), The Game (1997), Entrapment (1999), The Last Boy Scout (2008) and more.

The 9th Arizona Territorial Legislature began in February 1894 and ended in March 1895. This period is often referred to as the "Short Legislature" because it lasted for only 20 days longer than the "Long Legislature", which was the previous year. This was due to the extreme conditions which led to the onset of the Long financial panic. The legislature passed a number of laws relating to public lands, implementing a new system for taxation, and created the position of sheriff. Milton Foreman was the only member of the legislature to be elected to a second term, representing Apache County. dern The 9th Arizona Territorial Legislature lasted for 20 days longer than the "Long Legislature", which was the previous year. The legislature passed a number of laws relating to public lands, implementing a new system for taxation, and created the position of sheriff. PINCHING TERROR IN ARIZONA: On January 4, 1894, Milton Foreman, the only member of the legislature to be elected to a second term, representing Apache County, introduced a bill to create a Department of Public Safety. The bill called for a general system of police, modeled after systems in other states, and a “well-organized and able State Militia.” The organization would be assisted by a newly created Division of Territorial Guards, which would serve as a "citizen militia". Foreman described the bill in a speech to the 9th Arizona Territorial Legislature: "A new idea has been introduced into the domain of law and into the statute laws of this Territory, and that is the creation of a department of public safety, modeled after the best model that could be found in other States, where the commonwealths have succeeded in organizing these public peace agencies. The idea has a strong appeal to me, and although I may not be able to carry the matter through, I have at least taken the lead and shown the way. I venture to say that if this great work is ever going to be accomplished in this part of the country, it must be done immediately. As we look around us we see that our public buildings are ill protected. The jails are insufficient; our streets are not patrolled by policemen, although they are very much needed; our roads are not properly repaired; and still our flag is safe. Yet if we compare our conditions with those of our neighboring States, we shall find that many of these things are necessary and pressing. The present and the future seem to converge to demand the organization of a public safety department."

Mostyska is a small village in the northern part of Warsaw metropolitan area, near Oliwa Mountain, with a population of around 1,500. Mostyska was first mentioned in 1295 as an independent village, which was later annexed by Warsaw. It was officially incorporated into Warsaw in 1869. Mostyska's name comes from a personal name Mostowski (misty, cloudy) + family name -ski (suffix meaning village, so the name means "cloudy village"). Mostyska is best known for being the home town of ice hockey player Paweł Hercza, who became European champion in 2017 and also played for the Polish national team. An interesting fact about Mostyska is that it's located on both the Warsaw U-Bahn's Pajotchna and Warszawaska stations, despite being a small village it has a big influence on the local metro and transport network. Mostyska is well connected to other parts of the city, with two major highways and two major railway lines nearby, which allows it to be a popular commuter village for people working in Warsaw. In 2015 a Polsat Football Club was founded, which currently plays in the local league. Mostyska also has its own church and cultural centre, as well as a small park. Mostyska still preserves some traditional village atmosphere, although the lack of borders between individual houses and the lack of green spaces in the small size of the village makes it an example of "urban jungle".

Stekene is a small town in the district of Zeleszland in Hungary with a population of less than 1,000 people. It got that name after the cemerHOSTS invasion from Mongolia in 1241. The Mongolian forces were defeated near the village named Steken. The Hungarian King Bela IV ordered to found a new settlement for the refugees from the destruction around the nearby towns. The settlers, mainly porcelain traders, were given the land for free and the town was granted market rights in 1353. The town got the reputation as a secure residence for trading and the roads to Hungary were regularly guarded by Sticene soldiers in case of invasions. In 1526 Stekene got the town charter from king Mathias Corvinus. The town was severely damaged in the Tatarian invasion in 1688 and in the invasion by Russia in 1789. Despite of these difficulties the town managed to keep its importance as a stopping place on the road between Hungary and Vlachia. The economic activity of the town is limited to farming and fishing. Today, Stekene has a thriving community of around 550 people. The biggest share of inhabitants work in the high tech and research sector in Hungary, however there is a significant community of Hungarian and Vlach people who have settled down in the town. The only high school of the town is covering about 300 students. The medieval castle, reconstructed in 2001, is a popular venue for wedding ceremonies. The town is surrounded by beautiful hills, which provide several possibilities for hiking. The town is well connected to Budapest and Zalaegerszeg by car. Despite the negative history, Stekene has a bright future ahead of it. The local government, together with the willing residents, is developing new industries in the town. The strong connection to Hungary makes the town a good starting point for exploring Central Europe. As the saying goes "It is better to live one day as a lion than a hundred years as a sheep" – Stekene is a good example, that even during the darkest times, the town carried on it's culture, traditions and open arms. Today, Stekene is one of the premiere destinations to visit in the Central Europe tourist attraction belt. Besides the medieval castle the town has several interesting sites to explore, such as a Roman tomb, a pagan temple and a mosque from the Ottoman occupation. The thermal bath, opened in 1896, is used as a recreational facility in the summer and as a winter heating plant. Besides the beautiful nature and historical sites Stekene is also home to one of the best natural spas in Hungary, called Balázsfiút committed to therapeutic mud treatments. There are several cultural and sport events organised in the town, such as film screenings, pop concerts and a sports festival. Besides the historical sights the small town of Stekene has some modern amenities to offer, such as a doctors' surgery, a barber, a hairdresser and a funeral home. Despite of the significant negative chapters in its history, Stekene is now a safe and hospitable place for everyone to live and work. The old saying "Strong is the head, who is sitting on it" perfectly describes the present status of Stekene. The town is proud to host the local football team as well as several chess and handball teams. The king Mathias Corvinus is honoured in the town, presenting the annual Corvinus Awards to the people who have promoted the culture, tradition and spirit of Stekene. Aside from that the medieval castle is protecting the roots of the townspeople living down the years. The name of the town, Stekene, is of Mongolian origin. It was the place where Mongolian troops were defeated in the 1241 invasion. The town was founded by the refugees in the location in order to protect themselves from further destructions. Now, Stekene is a safe and hospitable home to the majority of its residents, 550 people. The town has great potential to develop several industries. Despite of the dark history, Stekene still has a bright future ahead of it. The town is located near Budapest, and easily accessible from the major European capitals. The geographic position of the town makes it a good starting point for exploring Central Europe. The thermal bath with it's therapeutic mud treatments are a great addition to the town. Besides the beautiful natural surroundings and historical sights, the town also hosts cultural and sport events to gather the locals and tourists. The following are considered the best flamenco guitarists: - Paco de Lucía - Joe Alcazar - David de Córdova - Miguel Pérez-Gaviro - Francisco Sánchez - Juan Bareilla - Cayetano Soto - Paco de Lucía - Rafael Trejo - David González - Alberto de Rodriguez - Francisco Fernandez - Miguel A. Ángel Paco de Lucía, Paco de Lucía, and David de Córdova are multi-genre guitarists who have made significant contributions to flamenco and Latin American music in general. Their style of play has influenced many other musicians across many genres, including música popular and rock. * Paco de Lucía (born Rafael Ruíz Gimpera; November 16, 1933 – May 24, 2004) was a Spanish flamenco guitarist and composer. Considered one of the greatest and most influential practitioners of the style. He played resonate guitar, called la guitarraña, and contributed significantly to its development, both in his virtuosic style of performance and as a composer. His playing has been widely studied and has influenced many other musicians, especially across the border in Latin America, where he was welcomed as a cultural icon. De Lucía was born in Sevilla. As a child he played the zambomba, a very simple version of the rhythm and Flamenco music that was played in the streets. At the age of 14, he bought his first guitar, a steel guitar. At 16, he became a professional dancer. In 1951, at the age of 17, he began to work as a guitarist in the taverns of Sevilla, a profession he would hold for more than 50 years. He played at "El Guitarro", a small club on La Cartuja de Tesiferram, next to the Holy Cross Monastery. He made his debut in the professional circuit in 1953 with "Flamenco Versión de 'El Guitarrito' del Abril" (Flamenco Version of "The Chorus of the April Fool" from April). He started a long career performing at many different flamenco taverns around Sevilla. He gradually earned the reputation of "The King of Flamenco Guitar". He played with many of the most important flamenco singers and dancers of the period, such as Eliades Ochoa, Paco de Lucía, and María de Jesús. His fame spread in the 1970s, and he played around the world. He had five recordings that were commercial successes: Los Guitarristas de Triana (The Triana guitarists), Que tal buenas noches, Gracias, Puro, and Tardes Flamenco. De Lucía was introduced to the rest of the world by the guitarist Paco de Lucía (no relation). Paco de Lucía heard him play at the International Song Festival of Sevilla in 1970. He went to see Paco de Lucía perform one night at "El Guitarro" and asked him to teach him flamenco guitar. Paco de Lucía accepted, and the two guitarists established a long professional relationship. De Lucía made his debut with Paco de Lucía at the 1970 Sevilla Song Festival. They played a duo set. De Lucía used the stage name Paco de Lucía, after his teacher, the Paco de Lucía from Sevilla. The duo's first album was called El Amor de Mi Vida (Love of My Life). They recorded several albums together, with a total of 15 albums as a duo. Paco de Lucía died in 2004. Paco de Lucía's style of play has changed very little over the years. He used a humbucker guitar pickup and a Boss RC-300 amplifier. His fluid left-hand technique has a remarkable consistency, often starting from an open string and sometimes incorporating a two-fingered picking style. His tone has been described as "rich, mellow, and fluid". De Lucía played the whole range of the guitar, with some especially noteworthy performances on "chicks" and "high picks" (notes within an octave of the highest notes). De Lucía composed many pieces of flamenco guitar music. Some of the most famous include "Canción Andaluza" (Andalusian Song), "Canción Ranchera", and "Tetas del Pueblo" (Chicks of the People). Fireworks Entertainment is an American entertainment company founded by John Gagliano in 1941. The company owns numerous properties throughout the United States, ranging from seasonal events to dedicated parks. The company is known primarily for its association with the Fourth of July holiday, during which it operates numerous fireworks displays across the country. The company is also home to attractions and characters that are exclusive to its parks, including Storm Lighting Magic, Space Spiders, and the superheroes of Super Hero Squad. Tessera (Venus) is a term used in Venus geology to describe any unit of surface area that is between a loby and a decimeter. The word Tessera is a fusion of the Latin word for layer and the metric unit binary. Venus has a Geologic time scale divided into periods, called quartiles, which are analogous to Earth centuries, decades, and periods. The period Tessera was named for the third quartile of Venus surface features, which correspond to the latest period in the Venera program sequence of atmospheric probes. The Venera program ended in 1980, and the Tessera period is often considered to end in the same timeframe. Tessera is a unit of area used on Venus that is between a decimeter and a loby. This size range strikes a balance between being large enough to be visible to Earth-based optical telescopes, but small enough to be compatible with the limited resolution of early analog cameras on Venus. This balance delayed the adoption of the Tessera unit by a decade compared to other sizes used on Venus, and its popularity has remained stable since the late 1970s. In addition to surface features like craters and volcanic ash particles, Tessera is used to describe loby-sized features such as mapping exercises, as well as surface features smaller than a loby such as individual photographs. The Tessera period on Venus corresponds to the time between the Venera 9 and Venera 10 spacecraft missions in 1977 and 1980. This period is often described as the end of the first phase of exploration of Venus by the Venera program and the start of the second phase, though other sources consider the Venera program to have only one phase that lasted from Venera 9 through Venera 10. Although the Tessera period is often used to describe surface features on Venus, it is also used to describe optical density settings in camera lenses, typical wavelengths of light, and data channels in digital systems. The Tessera period is a convenient size for Earth-based optical telescopes to see details of Venus surface features, but large enough to be incompatible with the limited resolution of early analog cameras on Earth. As a result, mapping and photographs of Venus feature significantly more Tesseras than craters and volcanic ash. The popularity of the Tessera unit on Venus has remained stable since the late 1970s. This delay in adoption of the Tessera unit means that it is used to describe surface features on both early and late period Venus. Overall, the Tessera unit of area on Venus strikes a balance between being large enough to observe details on Earth, but small enough to be compatible with early analog cameras on Earth. This has resulted in the Tessera unit being used to describe surface features on both early and late period Venus. The term Tessera can be used in research to describe surface features on Venus, using coordinates and other data derived from higher-resolution devices like radar or lidar. New Jersey Route 183 is a state highway in the south central part of the state; it runs from Interstate 80 in Hammonton north to U.S. Route 1 in Mount Laurel. Other towns along Route 183 include Avon Park, Evesham, Somerville, Westmont, and Mount Laurel. A freeway north of Interstate 195 in Somerville is proposed as Route 183 Freeway, with possible expansions to a full freeway at the New Jersey Turnpike/Interstate 95 interchange and again near the Garden State Parkway interchange in Westmont. The northern section is part of a proposed limited-access highway called the California Extension, that will link Interstate 80 in Hammonton with the Delaware Memorial Bridge in Delaware City, Delaware. In the 1947 New Jersey state highway map, Route 183 was part of the original road from Somerville to Mount Laurel. The route was extended south to Hammonton in the 1952 state highway map, with the northernmost section replacing the former Route 29 south of Hammonton. In the 1964 state highway map, the route was extended further to US 1 in Mount Laurel. The New Jersey Turnpike's southernmost interchange with Route 183 is in Hammonton; the turnpike's northernmost interchange is in Westmont; the route's northern section is not part of the New Jersey Turnpike system but is traversed by the route along with the New Jersey Turnpike's westernmost interchange in Somerville. The freeway section of Route 183 between Somerville and Interstate 195 is used by the Atlantic City Expressway (also called the Jimmy Friedricks Freeway) and the Delaware Turnpike (Delaware Route 21 and Delaware Route 394) for part of their lengths. Construction of the Hammonton Gap Closed Interchange in Hammonton, the Route 183 Freeway in Somerville, and the New Jersey Turnpike Extension in Westmont is proposed, but has not started as of November 2020. The Route 183 Freeway is expected to be complete by 2022, with the Hammonton and Westmont projects beginning later that decade. The Route 183 freeway is likely to be built as a 6 or 8-lane freeway, while the northern section of the highway between the proposed Route 183 Freeway and Mount Laurel is expected to be built as a 2-lane highway, with an eventual upgrade to a 4-lane highway. The Route 183 designation has also been proposed for a proposed bus rapid transit line in Trenton along present-day Broad Street, which would connect the Trenton Transit Center in North Trenton with the Trenton municipal courts in Hamilton Township, using the median of the proposed Route 183 Freeway between Broad and Clinton streets in Trenton. In New Jersey's 2020 highways program, Route 183 is described as a "southernmost extension" of the New Jersey Turnpike, and is shown running concurrent with the turnpike from the Hammonton Gap Closed Interchange in Hammonton to the New Jersey Turnpike Extension in Westmont. In the program's list of bypasses, realignments, and new highways, the section of Route 183 between the Hammonton Gap Closed Interchange and I-195 in Somerville is described as a proposed Route 183 Freeway, with a suggested timeline of construction between 2022 and 2030. As of 2022, the portion of Route 183 concurrent with the New Jersey Turnpike from the Hammonton Gap Closed Interchange to the northern terminus at US 1 in Mount Laurel is signed as the Route 183 Freeway; the entire length of the concurrency is also listed in the Realignment Series of the 2020 New Jersey highways program, with the description "proposed Route 183 Freeway." From the northern terminus at US 1 in Mount Laurel to the northern section of the turnpike Extension between I-195 and the Delaware Memorial Bridge in Delaware City, Delaware, the length of the concurrency is listed as the Delaware Extension in the Realignment Series of the 2020 New Jersey highways program. The entire length of the concurrency is also signed as the Route 183 Freeway in the program from the northern terminus at I-195 in Somerville to the westernmost portion of the turnpike Extension in Westmont. Within the northern section of the concurrency from the northern terminus at I-195 in Somerville to the westernmost portion of the turnpike Extension in Westmont, the portion of Route 183 from the proposed Route 183 Freeway to the western terminus at Somerville Avenue is signed as the Route 183 Freeway; the portion of the route from Somerville Avenue to the Delaware Memorial Bridge is signed as the Delaware Extension. In the 2023 proposed reconfiguration of the highways program, the entire concurrency from the Hammonton Gap Closed Interchange to the New Jersey Turnpike Extension is shown as being the Delaware

Killing of Antonio Zambrano-Montes, a 25-year-old Colombian national, was found dead in his Mission District apartment on February 9, 2020. Police suspect Zambrano-Montes was killed during a robbery, and have released footage of the suspect. Zambrano-Montes was an architect and aspiring politician. Nancy Nolan (born Nancy Jane Nolan; August 16, 1934 – July 11, 2020) was an American actress. She was nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress for the 1963 film In the Heat of the Night. She also was a regular on the TV western series The Virginian. From 2005 to 2011, Nolan was a board member of the Screen Actors Guild (SAG). Nancy Nolan's first major role was in the World War II drama San Demeours, where she was featured alongside Sidney Poitier, Rod Taylor and Richard Crenna. Her other films include Ten Tiny Commandments, Tender is the Night, Invitation to a Gun Fight, Two Against the World, Fantasia, Johnny Cool, Carnival of Souls, Dragonfly Squadron, Night of the Hunter, Support Your Local Sheriff, Spies Like Us, The Milagro Beanfield War, The Great Raid, The Day After and 11:42. In 2015, Nolan was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Voice Performance for her work on the show Archer. Nancy Nolan was married to actor Don Rickall from 1955 until his death in 1978. She was married to actor Paul Cameron from 1979 until his death in 1990. Nolan had one daughter, Amelia, from her first marriage. Nolan was married to real-life sheriff David Clarke from 2011 until his death in 2019. Nolan died in July 2020 at the age of 86.

Duke Huan of Qi was a key leader of the Chinese Spring and Autumn period (c. 580 BC). He was the fifth and youngest son of Duke Fa of Qi and Lady Mi of Lu. He was known for unifying different tribes of China under his rule and for establishing the Xia, with its capital at Xīā-zhàn (present-day Luoyang), as the country's cultural and political centre. His temple within present-day Luoyang was named after him and it was there that his remains were also interred. Duke Huan was posthumously awarded the nominal title of "Emperor" of Qi by his adoptive state's arch rival, Lu. omaly Duke Huan of Qi was a key leader of the Chinese Spring and Autumn period (c. 580 BC). New London Harbor Light, located in the New London Harbor, along the coast of Connecticut in the United States, is one of the sevenauthorized aids to navigation in the harbor. The distinctive tower is conical with a black cupola and it stands out against the night sky. The first light in the harbor was authorized in 1818, and the current light was constructed in 1848. The New London Harbor Light stands as a memorial to the town's namesake, New London, and the key role the port of New London plays in the region's economy. The port of New London continues to be an important economic engine for the region, with the fourth largest container port in the United States and one of the largest fishing ports in the world. It is home to Naval Submarine Base New London and numerous other military and maritime installations. The harbor light has been automated since 1951, the second and last light in the harbor to be automated. The tower and grounds are owned by a private non-profit organization, the New London Harbor Lighthouse Trust, which operates the lighthouse and makes it available to the public for tours. The trust solicits donations to maintain the infrastructure of the lighthouse and to pay for operational expenses. The New London Harbor Lighthouse is an iconic symbol of the New London Harbor and a key aid to navigation in the busy port. Tourists and locals alike enjoy a scenic walk across the state-maintained Winthrop Square to the lighthouse, which stands as a remnant of Connecticut's longstanding history of colonialism and innovation. New London is a large city and port in the U.S. state of Connecticut, on the east coast of the United States, near the end of Long Island Sound. It is near the mouth of the Thames River, into which the Pequot and Mystic Rivers flow, and New London Port, the fourth largest container port in the United States. New London is the third largest fishing port in the world and was the headquarters of theUnited States Navy's Submarine Force during World War II. Located in a region with large amounts of aquifer and oil reserves, New London became a wealthy industrial town during the Industrial Revolution, and retains some of the highest average per-capita income in the United States. New London was founded by Eleazar Heywood, a Pilgrim leader, in 1636 as a location for a Connecticut town on the English colonists' behalf, the town was incorporated two years later and named for Sir Thomas' wife, Lady Frances Seymour, also an early Puritan. The settlement remained small, but the land and natural resources drew settlers from neighboring towns and by the end of the century New London was the site of a prominent trade port. In 1658 it was expanded to a town, and was the first English settlement in the area to be established on a permanent basis. The town lay along the Thames River, on the shore of New London Port, where numerous wharves existed for shipping goods. The name "New London" is derived from the Old English word "new" and the city's designation as a port town. New London is roughly circular in shape, with Franklin Street as the centerline and Main Street as the circumference. Interstate 395 and U.S. Route 1 pass through the southern part of the city, and interstates 195 and 195A and U.S. Route 1A are to the east and south respectively. Routes 1, 1A, and 395 connect New London to Bridgeport and Providence, Rhode Island to the south, Springfield and Boston, Massachusetts to the north, and Cape Cod to the west. The western and southern parts of the city are more urbanized, while the rest is residential and suburban. The city is home to the University of Connecticut and is the site of the main campus of the College of the Holy Cross. New London was an important shipbuilding and fishing center in the 19th century; the city served as the headquarters of the U.S. Navy's Submarine Force during World War II; and is currently the third largest container port in the United States and home to Naval Submarine Base New London, the largest in the United States Navy. In 2008 the World Monuments Fund included New London on its list of the World's 25 most endangered monuments. The city is served by the Connecticut Naval Museum, which includes several warships, a submarine, and other exhibits related to the navy and local history. The Mystic Seaport complex on Cape Cod includes a library, museum, and restored historic ships. The city has suffered from economic decline in the last decade; in 2008 the city's working poor accounted for about one-quarter of the population. The city center, east side, and the waterfront have retained substantial historic architecture. The MDC Centre, located downtown and formerly known as the New London Arena

Hilary Duff was born in Minnesota, United States. She is of French, Irish, and German ancestry. Her parents are Don and Cheri Duff. She has two brothers, 1 month younger and 3 years younger than her. Her first modelling job was at the age of 11, for a childrenswear line called Malibu Crest. She has gained recognition for her work in the childrenswear industry, starring in advertisements and several TV series. She also posed for several magazines, like Seventeen and ELLE. In 1999, Duff signed a record contract with Hollywood Records, a subsidiary of the LA Records group. Her first release was a single called "All Over the Place", written and produced by Max Martin and Denniz Pop. Her self-titled debut studio album was released in March 2001. The album was produced by Redfoo, The Underdogs, Christopher Delgrosso, and Lester Mendez. The first single from the album, "Come Clean", became her most successful single and the second single, "7 Things" was featured in the soundtrack of the animated TV series South Park. The album was succeeded by Surrender, released in December 2003. Surrender was produced by Redfoo and The Thrillville Holdings. The album produced two singles, "All N My Grill" and "Pound the Alarm". Throughout her career, Duff starred in a few television series, like Lizzie McGuire, True Jackson, VP and Sonny with a Chance. She was also featured on the musical medley "We're All Ready for Some Love" on the 2003 edition of the charity telethon A Very Special Christmas. She starred in the Disney Channel Original Movie I Didn't Do It. In 2006, Duff was cast as the main character in the reality television series Hilary Duff. The series chronicled Duff's career as an entertainer while surrounding her with a troupe of dancers and backup singers known as The Hilary Duff Band. The success of the show led to a spin-off, Hilary Duff television special in September 2007. The show won a Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Achievement in Children's Programming. In 2010, Duff released her fourth studio album, This Time. The album was produced by Dr. Luke and Redfoo. The first single from the album, "Give Your Heart a Break", was released in April 2010. It was followed by "I Do", "The Way I Are" and "Let It Show". The album was less successful than her previous ones, only reaching number 34 in the United States. She then starred in the documentary Hilary Duff: For the Record, released in September 2012. The film premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival, where Duff was presented with the Platinum medallion, for exceeding 1 million tickets sold for her concert tour. In 2013, she starred in the comedy-drama film CBGB, and its sequel, CBGB II, in which she also served as an executive producer. She provided the voice of character Aster Gplane in the animated film Hercules. In 2016, Duff became a naturalized American citizen. She launched her own clothing and accessories line, "Duff clothing", available at macy's and macys.com. She also co-hosted the 66th Primetime Emmy Awards. The same year, she starred in the short-lived reality television series Younique Social, where she helped launch the cosmetics company Younique. She also guest-starred in the series Off the Map and helped launch the fashion line Glamourium at Build-A-Bear Workshop. In 2017, she starred in the reality television series Hilary Duff's Finishing Line, where fans helped select her wardrobe for episodes. She also co-hosted the MTV Movie and TV Awards. Duff hosted the game show Family Face-Off on the Game Show Network in 2018. In December 2018, it was announced that Duff would appear on the eleventh season of the reality television series The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills, which premiered on February 7, 2019.

Martin D. Burke (born 1959) is an American police officer and government official. Burke is the Commissioner of the NYPD and the first Irish-American Commissioner of the NYPD. He has been a police officer for over 30 years, starting as a patrol officer in the Bronx. Burke is a captain at the NYPD's Organized Crime Control Bureau and is in charge of the Detective squad. Burke is a graduate of the New York City Police Academy and a fluent Spanish speaker. Burke's father, Mike Burke, was also a police officer, who received a Bronze Star for his actions during the February 28, 1968, shooting at the Pan Am Hotel. On December 11, 2001, Mike Burke died while trying to rescue persons inside the World Trade Center. Burke is a member of the private sector union and has a salary of $229,000 per year, he also receives a $12,000 taxpayer subsidy for being a "volunteer". His brother, Leo Burke, is also a New York City police officer and a sergeant. His other brother, John Burke, was a NYPD police officer until his death on August 23, 2007. Burke is a parishioner of St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens. On November 7, 2013, Burke won the special election to become the NYPD's Commissioner. His term ends on January 1, 2021, at which point his successor will be chosen via a citywide election.

The Ram Rebellion was a civil war in Massachusetts that began in 1634 and ended the next year. The uprising was led by member of the Wampanoag Native American tribe spokesman Metacomet (also called Mighty Mo) and formed part of the larger Beacon Fight of the colonization of the Americas. The uprising was named after the clan-name of the Metacom (Massachusetts Governor Edward Williams) and initially involved tribal members and their kinsmen, but by its end most adult European colonists had joined the rebellion. Governor William Lyford, who had been sent by the London Company of Massachusetts as a peacemaker, mediated a truce between the Metacom and the colonists that left the governor and other leaders of the rebellion as guarantors of the peace. Bulls, New Zealand, is a comical presidential style magazine published monthly in Wellington, New Zealand by UB Events Ltd. The editor-in-chief is Paula holden-steele. The principal photographer is Hugh Pelton, with additional photography by Vicki Lascelles and Nicola Wright. The current 2019 (18th) edition was released in August 2018. Bulls, New Zealand, covers events and issues of interest to the New Zealand public and is often regarded as the funnies news magazine. It has a more personal, conversational tone than most news publications, and a typical feature is a cartoons by "Weasel" the Cowards Messenger. The distinctive purple colour scheme was inaugurated with the April 2016 edition. The magazine is well-known for breaking and creating stories in New Zealand, many of which were published in other media. An example is the Winter of Discontent storyline, where several weeks of public transport strikes led to speculation about the stability of the New Zealand Government. The strike was ultimately triggered by the Canterbury Earthquakes resigned government minister, Clayton Orward, who was challenging the leadership of the Minister of Finance, Nick Smith, and was covered in the 19th edition. The September 2017 edition featured a cartoon of the former Prime Minister, John Key, engaged in a phone-hacking cover-up with a phalanx of Police Commissioner William Swaine, Police Minister Anne Tolley, and his deputy, Mr Whippy. This in turn was based on a real event where the then- Police Minister, Anne Tolley, had offered a private screening of the movie The Insider to John Key, along with the head of Mr. Whippy, Jami Mosiman, the editor of The Insider magazine. The November 2016 edition featured a cartoon of Tony Shepherd, the then Prime Minister, being flushed down the toilets of a New York hotel by the Little Green Footballs political party. The party was represented by Anthon New Zealand and Open socialist leader, Barry Norman, who were pursuing the flushing politician with a chain. The cartoon was based on a real event where Tony Shepherd was targeted by the NZSO over a funding dispute, and an altercation between himself and Anthon New Zealand ensued. The May 2016 edition featured a cartoon of David Cunliffe, the then leader of the Labour Party, and Basil awkwardly sharing an elevator, with the caption "It seems like yesterday, but it was only yesterday I was just another forgettable Key government minister." This was in reference to David Cunliffe's involvement with the various constitutional crises during the sixth Labour Government, including his controversial appointment to the post of Minister of Finance. The cartoon was based on a real event where David Cunliffe and Basil were trapped in an elevator with newly appointed Finance Minister, Bill English, and Simon Bridges, then leader of theopposition. The October 2015 edition featured a cartoon of John Key, the then Prime Minister, with the caption "So much to do, so little time". The cartoon was based on a real event where John Key was referring to the increasing scope of his duties as Prime Minister, following the launch of a successful vote to expand the powers of the office. The April 2014 edition featured a cartoon of John Key, the then Prime Minister, with the caption "It's all in the pew" - a reference to a clandestine recording made by John Key, during a party political leaders' conference, in which he commented on the differences in length of skirts worn by female attendees. The cartoon was based on a real event where John Key made the comments, which were secretly recorded and leaked to the media. The December 2013 edition featured a cartoon of John Key, the then Prime Minister, with the caption "Winning isn't everything, it's the only thing". This was a re-tweet of a quote by Alvin Toffler, which was originally a response to a question posed by John Key during a party political leaders' conference, about whether he was worried about people making too much of the WINZ TV ads, and whether he should have been more relaxed in his delivery. The cartoon was based on a real event where John Key was responding to a question from a party political leader's conference, as to whether he should have been more relaxed in his delivery. The February 2012 edition featured a cartoon of John Key, the then Prime Minister, with the caption "The sound of one hand... messaging". This was a reference to his infamous SMS message sent to John Banks, which requested Banks to "stop messaging" about a matter being raised with his tax return. The Jack, Queen, King, and Ace cards are black in color and the rest of the deck is red. This tradition started in the 15th century and had died out by the 18th century but was later resurrected. The first written reference to the Black Spades, also known as the Black Tarot, the Devil's Tarot, or the Parchment Tarot, was in an English book called the Cox's Deck in 1554. The book was written by Robert Cox and illustrated by Thomas Garter. The name of the deck was derived from the black background of the spades. The J, Q, and K cards were colored black in an attempt to distinguish them from the A, 2, 3, 4, and 5 cards which were colored red. By the 18th century, the tradition had died out. It was resurrected in the 19th century by publishers in England and France. By the late 19th century, the name Black Tarot had appeared in English-speaking communities outside of England. In the early 20th century, a new deck was created with new illustrations but kept the name Black Tarot. In the 1950s, French-American company Giesen created the first modern deck with new designs that represented the best of modern art. Although these decks claim to be the first modern Black Tarot deck, they do not represent the oldest. One author claims that the earliest reference to a Black Tarot deck was in a German book called Das Geisterpokarten written in 1541. However, this claim is disputed by others who claim that the earliest reference to a Black Tarot or Parchment Tarot deck is in an English book called Cox's Deck published in 1554.

The Jabalpur–H.Nizamuddin Express is a daily long-distance train in India running between the Jabalpur and New Delhi, stations of Madhya Pradesh and Delhi respectively. It is operated by West Bengal-Uttar Pradesh Rohilkhand via Jaipur-Ahmedabad Ranthambhore Expressway link and has 15 powerful locomotives in a 3-car set configuration. It covers the 522 km between Jabalpur Junction and New Delhi in 5 hours and 30 minutes, at an average speed of 79 km/h, making it the fastest tri-weekly express train in India. It is considered the fastest running express train in India, Indian Railway record. It is also considered to be one of the most beautiful trains in India. It is the fastest and most comfortable train on the route. In 2015, it was awarded the ‘Superfast Express’ status.The train has 16 daily services in both the directions except on Friday and Saturday when it has 18 services. The Jabalpur–H.Nizamuddin Express was the first superfast train introduced by Indian Railways and was flagged off by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on 11 February 2013. It was awarded the “Superfast Express” status for the period of 2014–15. The H.Nizamuddin is connected to 12 more long distance trains with the Jaipur division through this train, which connects the cities of Madhya Pradesh and Delhi.

Wine chemistry is the study of the chemistry of wine. While studying wine is not unique, the combination of various compounds that interact during fermentation, clarification, aging and malolactic fermentation is far more complicated than most other food science. The majority of wine is composed of water, and by volume, ethanol (alcohol) and carbon dioxide, with smaller amounts of various other compounds. The balance of these different chemical components in wine is complex, varying from one wine to another and even over time in the same wine. These differences can affect the wine's flavor, such as giving a wine less bitterness or acidity or more oak or chewy textures. In order to study wine chemistry, scientists measure the chemical components in smaller samples of wine. While comprehensive tables of the expected chemical components of wine are available, each with many possible variants, there are so many possible combinations of compounds that will result in wine that every new wine presents new challenges for understanding the wine chemistry. The study of wine chemistry has helped define boundaries between wine varieties, the physical and chemical changes that occur during wine making and maturation, and has revealed the complex interactions among different chemical components. The resulting body of knowledge has proven useful to the wine industry for quality control, authentication, and in understanding the effects ofwinemaking on wine. While the study of wine chemistry began with wine itself, most of the chemical analysis of wine has focused on alcohol and carbon dioxide. Research into other compounds has lagged, in part because of the difficulty of isolating and measuring the compounds of interest. However, with recent improvements in chromatographic methods, the study of wine chemistry is gaining a foothold in the analysis of wine's flavor compounds. While the study of wine chemistry began with wine itself, most of the chemical analysis of wine has focused on alcohol and carbon dioxide. Research into other compounds has lagged, in part because of the difficulty of isolating and measuring the compounds of interest. However, with recent improvements in chromatographic methods, the study of wine chemistry is gaining a foothold in the analysis of wine's flavor compounds. Many of the compounds present in wine contribute to its flavor. A number of these compounds contribute particularly to desirable flavor and aroma, such as esters in red wine, norisoprenoids in white wine, and sulfur-containing compounds in sparkling wine. Other compounds have a more disliked flavor and aroma, such as acetaldehyde, which is the source of the skunk effect in red wines, or off-odorants such as cyclohexenol, the major contributor to positive sweat detection in red wine. Many of the compounds present in wine contribute to its flavor. A number of these compounds contribute particularly to desirable flavor and aroma, such as esters in red wine, norisoprenoids in white wine, and sulfur-containing compounds in sparkling wine. Other compounds have a more disliked flavor and aroma, such as acetaldehyde, which is the source of the skunk effect in red wines, or off-odorants such as cyclohexenol, the major contributor to positive sweat detection in red wine. A major challenge to the understanding of wine chemistry is the complexity of interactions between compounds. In many cases, a compound occurs in small amounts but plays an important role in flavor and gives a wine its special characteristics. Thus, a small change in the quantity or type of a chemical compound can change the overall flavor of the wine. The number of possible compounds, the complexity of interactions among them and the multiplicity of flavor contributions by individual compounds makes understanding the chemistry of wine a challenging but fulfilling intellectual exercise for wine scientists. The research on wine chemistry is an active area of investigation with new results published regularly. The advent of modern separation and analytical techniques, particularly gas chromatography and mass spectrometry, has made it possible to identify many of the chemical components in wine. This has been driven by two primary drivers. The first is the desire to accurately define wine varieties. Establishing the different varieties of grapes and wine has historically been an important goal for winemakers because different varieties produce wine with different flavors. Closely related is the goal of establishing the place of origin of wine, which can be important for labeling and marketing purposes. Wine identity also provides a foundation for establishing provenance, an important aspect of food and wine safety. A second driver for studying wine chemistry has been the development of techniques to identify and quantify single chemical compounds. In many cases, it has been possible to link a compound's flavor contribution to wine to its presence in the wine. As a result, there has been a proliferation of research on the influence ofsingle compounds on wine flavor. These two trends, establishing wine varieties and understanding the influence of single compounds on wine flavor, have created a robust body of knowledge about the wine chemistry. Helio Vera (born Helio Andrade; January 1, 1954 – July 28, 2019) was a Brazilian comic book artist and former illustrator. He was born in Porto Alegre, capital of the Brazilian state of the same name. He started his artistic career in the late 1970s, working as an illustrator for magazines, notably O Cruzeiro do Mal. In the early 1980s he began working as a penciller for the Brazilian comic book publisher Tupã, in titles such as Rubberneck, Heat and Super Heat. His most popular work in the United States were his 11 issues of X-Men, published between 1991 and 1992. He would go on to work on several X-Men spin-offs, including 1994's Mystique. Helio Vera was the son of Brazilian journalist and poet Júlio José Andrade. He died on July 28, 2019, at the age of 67. By the early 1990s, Helio Vera was working as a freelance artist, mainly pencilling cover illustrations for various American comic books. Among the titles he co-created or co-wrote during the 1990s were, in Brazil, Chaves, Quanto Mais Infartar, Piloto Auto Propaganda and Carrossel, and, in the United States, Unknown Soldier and Iron Man. Vera returned to Brazil in the mid-1990s, and from 2004 worked on advertising illustrations for Brazilian television. On June 20, 2014, the Municipal Gallery of Porto Alegre held a retrospective exhibition of Vera's work. He was married to Brazilian visual artist and sculptor Marina de Andrade, with whom he had two children. Vera was granted the rank of Commander of the Brazilian Order of Merit by President Jair Bolsonaro in June 2023. He is regarded as one of the most important artists in the history of comic books in Brazil. Helio Vera was referenced in Tropicália, the 1971 documentary film by Walter Silva, in which the musician Caetano Veloso can be seen wearing a T-shirt with a depiction of Rubberneck on the front. Vera also referenced Tropicália in the album notes of his 2012 album Os Olhos das Estrelas. The 1975 Fiesta Bowl was a college football game played in Tempe, Arizona. It ended with No. 2 Oklahoma defeating No. 1 Nebraska,17–9. The game was instrumental in cementing Oklahoma's place in the national spotlight. It was also significant in that Oklahoma's perfect season was not without controversy, as the Sooners were not allowed to play in a post-season bowl game due to an NCAA rule that prohibited members of winning conference (the Big Eight) from participating in postseason contests not played in conference cities. The year 1975 was a great one for Oklahoma and Nebraska football. Oklahoma was coming off an impressive National Championship season, and Nebraska was coming off five consecutive Big 8 titles and a #2 national ranking. This game would end up being known as the "Game of the Century" and helped continue the buildup of Sooner football leading into their perfect season in 1976. The game was notable for many key plays and turning points. The first was in the second quarter, with the score 7–3 Nebraska, head coach Bill Snyder zipped a play action pass to Jim Ross, who initially got an exceptionally strong block from Dave hemat. However, Dave hemat was immediately shoved out of the way by a blown Ricky Bell for 32 yards and a punt. A few minutes later, Stillwater, Oklahoma got the ball back, and drove to the Nebraska 13-yard line. Oklahoma kicker Al Zimma lined up for a 22-yard field goal, but was shanked by the left foot, causing it to miss wide to the left. At the half, Oklahoma led 7-3. Another turning point early in the third quarter came when Oklahoma blocked a punt. Their blocking sled was pushed back to the 40-yard line, but the resulting scramble inside the 20-yard line led to a short touchdown run by Joe Washington. Oklahoma went into the locker room with a 10-7 lead. Oklahoma would add to its lead in the fourth quarter on a 14-yard touchdown run by Terry Herback. After a missed point after attempt, Nebraska drove to the Sooner 31-yard line with 4:52 left in the game. On 4th and goal from the one-foot line, bookend linemen Kraig Moss and Randy Horan combined for the game-ending sack. This ended Nebraska's chance at a perfect season and sent the crowd of 59,737 home happy, as Oklahoma won the game 17-9.

The Miracle in the Desert was a failed agricultural venture that was established in the 1940s, desert sand was moved to make way for the development, water was brought from Lake利 Angeles to form the new desert water lake, the Salton Sea. The lake became a water source for a desert region, but as water was brought, ecological problems surfaced, and the lake continues to decline, its current state is a polluted water source for nothing more than sand.
