The lake became a water source for a desert region, but as water was brought, ecological problems surfaced, and the lake continues to decline, its current state is a polluted water source for nothing more than sand. After its establishment, the development was called the Salton Sink. It was one of the few successful uses of cheap desert sand in modern times. The area gradually became known for its unusual ecology and associated folk mythology, and was featured in Alfred Hitchcock's movie The Mystery of the Valley of Death. The area has never attained self-sustainability, and the water brings many ecological problems such as algal blooms, seagrass die-off, and water supply deficits for local residents and farms. The level of the sea is falling, and has been described as a 'poisoned lake'. The climate change–related water evaporation is being amplified by additional water supply from local farmers and regional environmental problems such as Eucalyptus tree farming and urban runoff. The Salton Sea is regularly described as the worst ecological disaster in the history of California.

LaMond Tullis (born Frederic Lamond Tullis; January 1, 1916 – January 23, 2002) was an American historian, professor, and director of the Bureau of Jewish Statistics of the American Jewish Committee. Tullis specialized in the history of Medieval Spain and was a leading authority on the Kingdom of Jerusalem in the Middle Ages. He also wrote extensively on 20th-century Spanish history, including the history of the Jews in Spain. He was a professor at the University of Wisconsin–Madison for 32 years, beginning in 1953, and was also the director of the Bureau of Jewish Statistics of the American Jewish Committee from 1959 to 1973. He was appointed University of Wisconsin–Madison's Distinguished Service Professor in 1977 and served as the chair of the History Department from 1973 to 1976. He was a consultant at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum from 1983 to 1985. Tullis was born in St. Louis, Missouri and died in Washington, D.C. Tullis's published works include The Spanish Road: A History of Modern Spain (1966), co-authored with his wife, Rose Tullis; Jewish Subjects of the Crown of Aragon, 1294–1410 (1970); and The More Bloody Finch: Murder and Antisemitism in 19th Century fin de siècle fin de siècle Paris (1978). Tullis's books have been translated into several languages, including Spanish, Portuguese, and French.

He is survived by his wife and two children. A loving husband and father, Jason Willasey Callahan put his heart and soul into everything he did. He was a loving friend to all and a terrific brother to his siblings. He was an actor, a musician, a jokester, a jokester-next-door, a supporter of the LGBTQ community, a fighter for animal welfare, and a God-loving man of faith. For more information about Jason and the charities he supported, please visit jasoncallahan.org. Survivors include his wife, Elizabeth; his children, Evelyn and William Callahan; his mother, Bethany; his brother, Michael; and his sister, Leslie. The ordinary course of business is the daily activities that are regularly carried out by a business. These activities help a business to conduct its core operations. Some of the ordinary course of business of a business include financial and administrative activities, such as paying wages and administrative expenses. More specifically, it refers to the conduct of daily business that occurs between normal business hours. It can also refer to a procedure or set of procedures followed by a company or its agents or representatives that are not considered part of the regular course of activities defined in the company's operating agreement or bylaws. Many businesses conduct ordinary course of business outside of the control of a court or arbitrator, for example, a printing business may produce collateral material for a court case or a personal injury matter. When a dispute arises over ordinary course business activities, the dispute is typically settled outside of court and not as part of a lawsuit. The reason for this is that ordinary course of business disputes usually do not concern the dispute resolution terms of a contract. They are more typically resolved according to principles of good faith and fair dealing. This form of dispute resolution, as it is commonly referred to, is not binding and does not create legal liability, but it can have a negative economic impact on a business. Therefore, ordinary course of business activities should be decided by the parties to a contract and not by a neutral third party. The need for a neutral third party to adjudicate ordinary course of business disputes between parties to a contract has been accepted by the legal community and there are special procedures and governing law in place in many countries, which attempt to provide a fair and impartial process for resolving ordinary course of business disputes between contracting parties. For example, the U.S. concept of FDA regulatory compliance is similar in intent. Because ordinary course of business activities are not typically defined with the precision of contractual provisions, special procedures are needed to help resolve ordinary course of business disputes. The process for ordinary course of business resolution is less precise than the procedure for adjudicating contract disputes. The adjudicator in ordinary course of business disputes is not bound by rules of procedure, evidence, and legal precedent like a judge in a court proceeding is bound by rules of procedure and legal precedent. An ordinary course of business resolution procedure is intended to be flexible and to work within a reasonable timeframe. However, it often does not work perfectly. It is up to the contracting parties to determine if an ordinary course of business dispute can be resolved between the parties or if the dispute must be resolved in an alternative dispute resolution procedure or by a neutral adjudicator, usually a judge. Because of its imprecision ordinary course of business disputes are usually less costly than alternative dispute resolution procedures, but the process is often cumbersome and slow. Large organizations often have ordinary course of business procedures in place but they may also have a dedicated team of professionals who specialize in ordinary course of business resolution. Such teams may use a variety of strategies to help find a resolution of ordinary course of business disputes that works for all parties. Specialized methods for resolving ordinary course of business disputes can include comprehensive reviews of documents, many of which may be pre-contractual, negotiation and compromise. Regardless of the approach used, the process for ordinary course of business dispute resolution can often be time-consuming, cost-prohibitive and quite contentious, but it does allow the disputing parties to resolve their dispute without resorting to alternative dispute resolution procedures and without the threat of immediate legal action. Ordinary course of business resolution procedures can vary significantly between jurisdictions and organizations, so businesses should consult with legal or other specialized experts to learn how their ordinary course of business disputes are typically resolved. Large organizations may have dedicated teams for ordinary course of business dispute resolution because they may have large ordinary course of business bills, but smaller organizations can also use specialized teams to help avoid or resolve ordinary course of business disputes. Ordinary course of business dispute resolution can be a useful process to resolve disputes between parties without resorting to court or alternative dispute resolution procedures and without the threat of immediate legal action. There are procedural and evidentiary rules that do not apply in ordinary course of business dispute resolution, which means ordinary course of business dispute resolution procedures can be more flexible than alternative dispute resolution procedures or court trials. An example of a special rule that does not apply in ordinary course of business dispute resolution is the "Dead Man's Act" in common law jurisdictions, which means a witness who has personal knowledge of the matter in dispute cannot take an adverse position or make a statement that is contrary to the position he or she claimed to hold when the witness was examined during the course of the investigation. The Williams family lived in the house until 1919 when they moved to Washington DC. The house was then purchased by Dr. Wilton Daniel and his family. Belle C. Greene (1866-1928) was an American painter. She was a member of the National Academy of Design and the Royal Society of Portrait Painters in London. She was a professor at the Boston School of Fine Arts and a founder of the New England Society of Women Artists. Word count: 250 words In 1966, a portrait of Greene by Joy Harjo was the first work to be acquired by the Smithsonian American Art Museum's Women in the Whitney Collection. Autobiography of Belle C. Greene Life Greene was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts. She was the daughter of Elizabeth (née Hight) and Francis Greene. Her siblings were Francis, William, and George. She studied art at the Boston School of Fine Arts. She was a member of the National Academy of Design and the Royal Society of Portrait Painters in London. She was a professor at the Boston School of Fine Arts and a founder of the New England Society of Women Artists. Her work is in the Whitney Museum of American Art, the High Museum, and the Carnegie Museum. Wells City, New Jersey, where Greene was born and raised, is home to the Belle C. Greene Industrial Foundation, which operates the Belle C. Greene Museum to honor her legacy. The foundation was established in 1932 and is dedicated to preserving Greene's legacy and promoting appreciation of her life and work. South Gare lighthouse is a active lighthouse located in South Gare, New South Wales, Australia.The light is situated on a white concrete slab with the traditional iron fungi: pepper tree, and lantern window on the first floor and sweeping views over Port Stephens and The Rip along the Parramatta River. The light was first lit in 1864 and is operated by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The South Gare Light is one of eight man-made lights that line the southern coast of Port Stephens. The light is located on an easel right above the shipping channel, making it very difficult to see in rough seas. Visibility is frequently restricted by the combined height of the light and the smoke from passing ships. Despite this, the lighthouse remains an important navigational aid and is fully operational. The light was first lit in 1864 as part of a major expansion of maritime safety in NSW following the construction of a series of impressive lighthouses along the eastern seaboard. The Parramatta River was the first along the south coastline with the South Gare Lighthouse constructed by the British Government Siverworks Department. The lighthouse is administered by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, who replaced the light with a more modern structure in 1984. The lighthouse is located on South Gare Head, a promontory that juts out into the Tasman Sea. The area was originally used as a seasonal fishing camp by the Thorsborne family who later established the South Gare Hotel. The hotel burnt down in 1957 and the lighthouse was unoccupied until 1983 when the Land Conservation Council installed a caretaker and began negotiations with the Australian Maritime Safety Authority to purchase the lighthouse and land for conservation. The lighthouse was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register in 2008 and is also listed on the Australian Registry of Heritage Places. In 2011, the lighthouse and surrounding land was purchased by Parks Australia, with the intent of establishing a visitors centre and looking after the lighthouse and land for conservation. The current light is a seven-second rotation on and off band of green, red, red, green, red, red, white, red, off. The light characteristic and frequency is displayed in white on the first floor lantern window. In May 2017, the lighthouse was vandalised with a Cutlass Road storm causing significant damage to the roof and destroying part of the lantern. The culprits, who were unable to gain access, were never found. The administration of the lighthouse and surrounding land is now handled by Parks Australia from an on-site caretaker. The lighthouse is open to the public, with the cost of entry covering the lighthouse keepers's salary. Guided tours are available from March to September, with visitors able to explore the grounds and lighthouse and enjoy sweeping views over Port Stephens and The Rip. The lighthouse is a short walk from the car park of the South Gare Head Path, a walking track that leads from the cliffs at The Rocks Crossing to the lighthouse. The lighthouse is a popular vantage point for viewing the sweeping views along The Rocks Crossing that includes the Parramatta River, South Gare Shopping Village and Port Stephens. Leasburg is a town in Union County, North Carolina, United States. The town is located on U.S. Route 70, near the North Carolina–Tennessee state line. As of the 2010 census, Leasburg had a population of 3,803. Leasburg is the home of Leasburgnc.com, The Mast General Store, Leas-McDowell-Fry property, and the site of the first gold mining in western North Carolina. sitate Leasburg, North Carolina Leasburg is a town in Union County, North Carolina, United States. The town is located on U.S. Route 70, near the North Carolina–Tennessee state line. As of the 2010 census, Leasburg had a population of 3,803. Leasburg is the home of Leasburgnc.com, The Mast General Store, Leas-McDowell-Fry property, and the site of the first gold mining in western North Carolina. Leasburg was established in 1905 as a lumber and textile mill town. The population remained below 1,000 until 1920, when it increased to 1,002. It grew slowly until the late 1960s, when the discovery of gold and quartz veins led to a significant population increase. In the 1970s, Leasburg expanded and upgraded its infrastructure. Since the early 2000s, Leasburg has also seen significant commercial and residential growth. Leasburg is a small town with a long history, known originally as "Sparkletown" because of the local gold rush. It was the site of the first gold mining in western North Carolina and the location of the original "Mast General Store", which was built in 1875 by Joseph Mast. Today, the store is one of the oldest General Stores in the state, as well as the oldest building in Leasburg. Demographics As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 3,803 people living in Leasburg. The racial makeup of Leasburg was 65.4% White, 28.0% African American, 0.7% Native American, 0.4% Asian, 0.0% Pacific Islander, 1.7% from some other race and 1.1% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 5.4% of the population. As of the 2000 Census, there were 3,892 people, 1,308 households, and 1,031 families living in the town. The population density was 84.8 people per square mile (32.5/km²). There were 1,413 housing units at an average density of 30.7 per square mile (11.9/km²). The racial makeup of the town was 60.39% White, 36.32% African American, 0.12% Native American, 0.50% Asian, 0.03% Pacific Islander, 1.59% from other races, and 1.01% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 4.15% of the population. There were 1,308 households out of which 32.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 47.8% were married couples living together, 17.5% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.6% were non-families. 22.8% of all households were made up of individuals and 8.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.76 and the average family size was 3.27. In the town, the population was spread out with 27.7% under the age of 18, 9.1% from 18 to 24, 24.8% from 25 to 44, 25.3% from 45 to 64, and 11.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 87.3 males. The median income for a household in the town was $26,369, and the median income for a family was $30,469. Males had a median income of $26,566 versus $20,714 for females. The per capita income for the town was $11,958. About 15.8% of families and 22.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 31.4% of those under age 18 and 17.2% of those age 65 or over. USS Albemarle (1863) was a paddle wheel gunboat in the Union Navy during the American Civil War. The Albemarle, commanded by Master Commandant David Dixon Porter, was one of the first Union ships to launch full-scale naval combat operations against the Confederate States of America during the war, with operations along the Western Front against Port Royal, South Carolina; despite her success, the Albemarle was lightly armored and endured many casualties from Confederate artillery fire. The ship was awarded the Thanks of Congress for her actions during the war, and was eventually transferred to the Spanish Navy and renamed Reina Mercedes. The Albemarle was the only U.S. Navy vessel to see active combat in the war and was the only U.S. Navy ship to enter the harbor at bombardments of Fort Sumter. eder USS Albemarle (1863) was a gunboat in the Union Navy during the American Civil War. Charles Camsell (December 25, 1807 – January 27, 1867) was a Canadian businessman and politician. He represented Ontario South in the Legislative Assembly of Canada from 1854 to 1857 as a Liberal. Born in Guysborough, Nova Scotia, the son of Jonathan Camsell and Elizabeth Ann Wall, he was educated there. In 1829, he married Mary McGregor. Camsell came to Upper Canada in 1832, settling in London, Ontario. He became a merchant and manufacturer. In 1833, he founded the London Machine Works. He also helped found the Bank of Upper Canada and the Huron and Erie Canal. Camsell was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Ontario in 1854, serving until 1857. He was reelected in 1857 and 1863 but was defeated in 1866. Camsell served as a justice of the peace and on the town council. He died at London at the age of 65. Each day brings another report of a predator unchecked and unpunished. We read of a famous athlete, a promising politician, a beloved professor, a gifted student, all accused of assaulting children. And we ask: how could this happen? Yet the answer to that question is perhaps less complicated than we think. Child sexual abuse is a product of our own moral failure as a society. We collectively have not taught boys to be boys; we have not taught girls to be girls. We have not taught sex and violence the boundaries they should keep. As a result, bad things happen. To think more deeply about this moral failure, we must examine what is known about male sexuality. We know that boys’ brains develop differently from girls’ brains. The systems that manage empathy, affiliation, and compassion are underdeveloped. The parts of the brain responsible for moral reasoning, social awareness, and understanding of cause and effect are altogether undeveloped. We also know that our current social construct does not allow for this natural state. We tell them they can’t cry. We tell them they have to act tough. We ask them to do the impossible: be vulnerable and strong at the same time. In order to thrive, boys need to feel both empathy for others and the ability to exert control. But we deprive them of the emotional ability to understand and navigate emotional situations. As a result, boys feel frustrated and shut down. Lastly, we know that many boys are raised by parents who have not been adequately trained in how to parent boys. They use discipline like corporal punishment or humiliation, a natural deterrent to misbehavior in girls, as a means of control in boys. But at that age, the frontal lobe of the brain, where inhibitory control is developed, is not fully developed. When they misbehave, they don’t understand that the anger they are feeling is a sign of the frustration described above. And so, they lash out. When we put this all together, we can begin to understand why boys become sexual predators. The social constructs that reward emotional repression in boys lead to frustration and aggression. These traits, which are innate in many boys, lead them to find an outlet in sexual assault. In short, we have failed to raise boys, and this is what we have produced. The solution is not to punish or shame boys for what is a failure of our societal norms. We need to reform our social norms. We need to raise both boys and girls with clear standards of appropriate behavior, and we need to teach boys that emotional expression is an important aspect of who they are, not something to be hidden away. As a result of that change, we will see fewer assaults by boys on boys and more assaults on girls by boys. We will reduce the gender gap in assault rates. However, it will not end there. As long as we tell girls they can’t cry or express their fear, we will see boys assaulted for expressing their true selves. Boys will assault girls for two reasons: 1) girls have been taught their authentic expression is unacceptable, and 2) boys feel they have permission to do so, as long as they are “asserting themselves.” By changing the way we raise boys, we are indirectly attacking this second form of assault. But it will not end there. When we tell boys they cannot be who they are, we create boys who will assault boys in the same way they were assaulted by others. We have a much more complicated problem than we first realized. Fighting sexual assault is important. Kent is a county in South East England comprising the main urban areas of London, Canterbury, Rochester, Ashford and Ramsgate. The county of Kent is a popular destination for domestic and international visitors for its popular tourist attractions, such as the theatres of ancient Greek and Roman Dorchester-on-Thames and Canterbury, the birthplace of St Augustine, the minster at nearby Battle and the Dover Castle coastguard lookout. Save Dat Money Dat money, dat money, pivotal role in successful enterprise. Dat money was acquired by Dat Company, founded by talented team of Dat Brett, Dat Evan, Dat Cindy and Dat Ken. Dat Company used its proprietary DatMoney technology to provide DatFinancial management platform for customer data, needed to run dat business. DatMoney technology provides full visibility and transparency across all dat accounts, which help dat enterprises to manage financial resources and increase operating profits. Dat Company grew significantly over past few years, attracting valuable investors, including Google, Twitter and Naspers. Dat grew so huge that it hit landmark of 1B records, and its future looked extremely bright. Dat was enjoying its success to the fullest, when strange incident happened... Dat Company was using outdated Dat software, developed in-house, for critical system at dat center. Dat software was written in Obj-C language, which is notoriously difficult to port to new systems and technology. Dat Brett was tasked with finding a replacement for Obj-C, without proper consideration of its implications, and in much shorter amount of time. Dat Brett chose to use Swift, a new and easy to learn programming language developed by Apple. Problem was, Dat Brett failed to foresee that Apple would stop supporting Obj-C in next major OS release. Dat Brett tried his best to port Obj-C to Swift, but after 10 failed attempts Dat Brett resigned in despair. Dat financial data was at stake! Investors and employees were distraught, until they learnt of miraculous turnaround of Dat Evan. Dat Evan rebuilt Dat financial management platform entirely on Dat Security Framework, one of Dat's competitors products. Dat security framework supports legacy Obj-C based systems, allowing Dat Brett to finish porting in a timely manner. Dat Company continued to use Dat security framework to manage Dat financial data, and was happy to report Dat existing financial systems running since 2008, with no sign of interruption. Dat investors breathed a sigh of relief, and Dat company continued its winning streak to new highs, only now powered by Dat Security Framework. Dat Money was indeed dat money, saving Dat company from financial calamity.

Tupman is a small rural community in the California Central Valley. The area was founded in the late 19th century by Benjamin H. Tupman, who came from Connecticut to seek his fortune in the California Gold Rush. He is buried in the local cemetery, and the town is named in his honor. In the later half of the 20th century, Tupman was home to a Jiffy Lube car repair shop and a Canfield Hardware store, but these businesses have since closed. The main economic generator in Tupman is Agriculture, particularly farming and dairy production. The town is located about an hour east of the San Francisco Bay Area city of San Jose and about a half hour south of the city of Merced. As of the 2010 census, Tupman had a population of approximately 175. External links Tupman at Wikimapia Category accepted this answer. Robbie Williams popularized "Radio" in 1997. The song was written and produced by bands member Andrew Watt. The song is significant as it made Williams the first British solo male artist since the Beatles to have five singles from one album in the UK charts, and the first British male solo artist since the Beatles to have a number-one single in the US Billboard Hot 100. It also marked Williams' first collaboration with American rapper LL Cool J, and became the first single to exceed one billion views on YouTube. Williams described the inspiration for the song as follows: "I was looking out of the window of a jet coming back from Singapore and I saw this advert for Pirelli Tires. It said 'Where the ride takes you'. I thought this is a great theme for a song. It's about a guy taking his girl on a journey. It's like a road movie, the song kind of feels like you're taking her with you on a journey." Radio became Williams' second number-one single in the United Kingdom, and his sixth and final number-one single in the United States. It was certified platinum or gold in more than 20 countries. The song received positive reviews from music critics, who praised its "infectious chorus", "memorable verses" from LL Cool J and Williams' vocals. The song's music video, which features the pair performing the song atop a pink 1963 Jaguar E-Type, won numerous awards and remains one of Williams' most popular and iconic music videos.

The 2003 Maldives civil unrest was a political crisis that began on 28 September 2003 and lasted until 5 October 2003. President Mohamed Nasheed, who was re-elected in 2001, became the target of public anger after introducing emergency legislation. This legislation gave him vast discretionary powers, including the ability to detain people without charge and restrict publications. The Indian government reacted by downgrading its High Commission in Malé from a High Commission to a Consulate General. Protests, led by the Majlis-e-Amal (Movement) party, rapidly spread throughout the Maldives. After several days of demonstrations, thousands of Maldivians took to the streets, forcing Nasheed to resign. A transitional government of opposition leaders was appointed, and a presidential election was held in February 2004. effect Edith holds the view that the 2003 Maldives civil unrest was a trigger for the political unrest of 2012 - 2016. She states that: "The changing political dynamics in the Maldives had begun with the civil unrest of 2003. The multiple cycles of change began in 2012 when Abdulla Yameen was voted in as President of the Maldives. His first action was to execute an arrest warrant for his predecessor, Mohamed Nasheed, on charges of terrorism. Nasheed had previously been granted asylum in Mooré by the Indian government and was living in exile in New York. The next election, in 2015, was narrowly won by the People’s Alliance, a coalition of the main opposition parties. However, following another indictment for terrorism, this time of his predecessor, Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, the People’s Alliance boycotted the 2019 election, which was won by the Progressive Party of former president Nasheed. With Gayoom returned to power, protestors once again took to the streets calling for Gayoom’s resignation and a transition to democracy."

John Calvin's view of Scripture can be summarized in five points: 1. The Bible is the Word of God 2. It is the written word 3. It is God's word for our instruction 4. all of Scripture is to be taken literally 5. In some places, poetry or mystery was intended John Calvin's view of Scripture focuses on the spoken and written word of God as the inerrant and authoritative source of truth. Do not interpret my word but lay down both what is mine and what was mine, for you preached before my time what I now preach. You already have run well ahead of me, and have left me far behind. Isaiah 56:4 It is not beyond the reach of human capabilities to know the truth, it is a question of will. The Bible is God's instruction for our instruction. He does not want us to remain in ignorance, he wants all mankind to come to know him. Some places in the Bible are poetry or mystery meant to teach a spiritual truth. The miraculous birth, death, and resurrection of Jesus is taken literally. John Calvin (1409-1464) was a renaissance thinker who had a major impact on the theological development of the Protestant church. He stressed the sovereignty of God in all things. He also was an original Editor of the Geneva Bible. He wrote: "For my part, I desire that all possible precautions be taken to prevent any changes from being made in the text. For it is written: that you may believe that you understand my word which I have not spoken."

Christine Sixteen (also known as Christine Olshausen) (1598 – ca. 1680) was a German mystic known for predicting the year of 1666 as a time of great cataclysm. She is most often cited as predicting the flooding of the Rhine caused by the construction of the Bastei Bridge. However, she also made other predictions that did not come to pass, and some historians believe she was a fraud. End paragraph. The Division of Korea was a provisional division of the United Kingdom and France during the Cold War. It was created in 1948 after the separation of the previously unified Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea) and the Republic of Korea (South Korea). The division existed until 1953 when the two countries agreed to reunify and become one sovereign state. Nonetheless, similar arrangements continue to exist; for example, the two nations share customs and tax arrangements, and are still nominally at war. catalyzed by the partition of the Korean peninsula, the division of Korea was considered a crucial factor in Harry S. Truman's decision to approve the deployment of nuclear weapons in the region. This deployment was later cited as a key motivation for the development of the North Korea nuclear programme. The division of Korea resulted in a state of war between the two countries, as well as the separation of families and communities – many of the tens of thousands of Koreans living in Britain later returned to South Korea to contribute to the fight against the North during the Korean War. According to Patti Smith, "the division of Korea is one of the most unjust and unrecognized shameful episodes in the history of United States foreign relations". BEFORE 1948 – Korea was a colony of Japan, which ruled the country from 1910 until the Japan's surrender to the Allied powers at the end of World War II in 1945. Following the Soviet Union's intervention in the war on the side of the Soviet-backed North Korean Workers' Party, the country was divided at the 38th parallel into a U.S. zone (under American military supervision) and a Soviet zone. 1948 – The U.S. and Soviet Union established the United Nations Security Council Resolution 84, establishing the division of Korea, and simultaneously the two countries established the military alliance, the Korean Armistice Agreement. The two sides agreed to remain neutral until each reached "universal peace", and engaged in a state of war since 1948.

Annie Wersching is an American actress. She was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota and is of German and Irish descent. She is known for her lead roles in the TNT series Leverage and the NBC drama series Rise. Her film roles include Vanishing Grounds (2010), Spring Forward (2014), and Wondstuff (2016). Wersching made her Broadway debut in 2007 in Avenue Q. Her other theatre credits include The Diary of Evelyn Laurence, Eclipsed, and An Iliad. Wersching starred in the short-lived TNT series Trust me, I'm a doctor in 2014 and the Lifetime series Happy Valley in 2017. She also recurred on Grey's Anatomy as Ellis Lasky from 2019 to 2020. Wersching's television credits include Undressed, The Whale, Perpetual Bumble, and The Good Place. She was a series regular on the TNT drama series The Flight Attendant from 2016 to 2017. She is a founding member of the transgender advocacy organization FACT. Her voice work includesable in the animated film Home and Garden with Hannah Tate and Netflix's Black Summer. She won a Critics' Choice Award for Best Actress in a Movie/Miniseries for her performance in the true crime documentary Unbelievable. In 2020, she was named one of the Time 100, a list of the most influential people in the world. In June 2021, it was reported that Wersching was in final negotiations to join the main cast of Disney's Lady and the Tramp, the first live-action adaptation of the 1955 film of the same name. The film is set to be released in 2023. She was a contributing creator and co-writer for the Showtime comedy series Lady Dynamite. In 2020, she was one of the inaugural honorees at the Hollywood Decades festival, which celebrates LGBTQ+ people in film. She is a founding member of the transgender advocacy organization FACT. In February 2022, Wersching was nominated for a Critics' Choice Award for Best Actress in a Movie/Miniseries for her performance as Jo McGuire in Lifetime's The McGuireDoors. She was cast as the main character in the Amazon Prime Video adaptation of the graphic novel series The Twelve. Her other film projects include Lars and the Real Girl, My Days of Mercy, and Madly Never After. In June 2022, she was awarded the Imaginaire Award at the Imaginaire Awards in Paris. She is set to portray Tessa Thompson's character in The Silver Surfer, which is set to be released in 2023. She was nominated for a Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for her work on the NBC show Rise. She was again nominated for a Critics' Choice Award for Best Actress in a Movie/Miniseries for her performance as Vonda in Eclipsed. In July 2022, Wersching was revealed to be one of the four cover stars for the upcoming 25th anniversary issue of Vogue magazine. Wersching's debut CD, Undivided, was released on January 31, 2023. She voices Supergirl in the Justice League Dark animated film, which is set to be released in 2023. She was included on the Hollywood gender-nonconforming hall of fame in June 2022. She was awarded the Dolly Parton Use Your Voice Award at the 27th annual Dolly Parton Awards in April 2023. She was awarded the Inspiration in Action Award at the 2023 Variety Night of Recovery event in February 2023. She was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for her work on the NBC show Rise. She was awarded the Silver Sshield for her work in 2019 on the Showtime comedy series Lady Dynamite. In 2022, Wersching became a U.S. citizen. In December 2022, she became a naturalized British citizen. She was awarded the Hollywood gender-nonconforming hall of fame in February 2023. She was included on the New York Times list of the 100 Most Influential People Over 50 in 2022. Her net worth was estimated at $20 million

Jody Harris (born Jody Christine Egerton; 21 October 1940 – 5 January 2017) was an English singer, songwriter and record producer, whose career began in the early 1960s, and included four UK top 10 singles and five UK top 20 albums. She was part of the British Invasion group the Four Seasons. Born and raised in Birmingham, England, Harris was inspired to become a singer after seeing her first movie, John Gilbert's 1944 film noir Better Than Well, at the age of 11. After winning a talent contest at the Midland amateur music festival, she was signed to Decca Records. Her early recordings were covers of material by American artists such as Eddie Cochran and the Andrews Sisters. In early 1964, she was invited to join the Four Seasons, the original group whose lineup later included Bob Gaudio and Vini Poncia. The group's early hits, "And lo, Cudiwa!!", "BBmania", and the number 2 UK single "December, 1963 (Oh, What a Night)". were all written by Gaudio and Harris. In 1966, the band achieved their first number 1 with "1970". Harris sang lead on most of the Four Seasons' hits, with the exception of "Who's Sorry Now", which was sung by Bob Gaudio. In later years she described her role as a lead singer on the band's hits as "demeaning", and blamed it for her later alcohol abuse. By the time of their breakup in 1971, Harris had become addicted to amphetamines, barbiturates, and tranquilizers. Following her rehabilitation in 1976, she moved to West Germany and became a songwriter, producer and actor.

The Breit equation is an empirical formula, first published in 1936, for calculating the wavelength of an X-ray photon given the energy of the photon, the speed of light c, the electron rest mass m0, the reduced Planck constant h, and the helicity angle of the photon. The equation is: where is the helicity angle in units of radians, is the energy of the photon in electronvolts, and and are empirically determined constants for the element under investigation. The equation is named after its creator, Walter Rudolph Breit. While the original derivation of the equation is attributed to Breit, later work showed that the equation was already contained in a 1925 paper by Pieter Hendrik van der Linde. In quantum electrodynamics, the equation is used to predict the energy and wavelength of photons resulting from the electromagnetic interaction of electrons and other particles. The constants in the equation may have different values for different particles, but in that case they are considered to be average values. In general, the smaller the energy of the electron, the larger the value of, but for high-energy electrons is nearly equal to 2. The constant varies by approximately a factor of 4 depending on the particle, but for most particles it is close to 7. The constant is always close to π/2. The reduced Planck constant h is a fundamental constant of quantum mechanics related to the action of the Dirac gamma matrices. It is equivalent to 2.97 (±0.02)×10−15 J s, where the error is one standard deviation among different determinations. This empirical formula correctly describes the observed behaviour of photons in many situations. However, it is a first-order approximation only and does not include some higher-order effects such as the electron magnetic moment. These effects would require including second-order terms in. In nuclear and particle physics, the analogous equations for particles other than electrons are the C virial equation or Gamow–Teller relation, respectively, for the nuclear shell model and the Fermi-Watson theorem for Quantum Field Theory. This empirical formula is used in many fields of physics and other sciences. It is used for example in x-ray fluorescence analysis, in calculating the energy of gamma rays from nuclear decay, and in calculating the wavelength of light emitted by stars. The constant is significant for optical polarizers, which use the differential absorption of light of different polarizations to generate separation of light into its components. As the constant is not the same for all polarizations, the polarizers are designed to have a thickness which alters the polarization such that is roughly constant across the cross section of the polarizer. The constants and are related to the fine structure of the hydrogen atom. The constant is very important in Casimir physics, in particular the Casimir–Polder force, and also plays a significant role in QED in general. The constants and are of great significance in quantum chemistry, nuclear magnetic resonance and atomic physics, and also play a significant role in QED in general. The Breit equation is also used in biochemistry in the calculation of circular dichroism spectra. In statistics, the equation is used in the calculation of the moments of the normal distribution. The Breit equation is also useful in multiple proofs of the Handshu lemma in combinatorics, and is a special case of the generating function equation for the distribution of cycle lengths in a random permutation. In geometry, the equation is used to solve for the golden ratio. The equation can be used to estimate the magnetic field of a proton in molecular dynamics simulations. The equation can be used to estimate the refractive index of a material. In finance, the equation can be used to estimate the value of a options contract. In the music industry, the equation is used by iTunes and similar music distributors to estimate the bit rate of an audio recording in order to fit it into a given file format. Breit's constant also affects the periodicity of light emitted by the so-called blinking quantum dots. The equation is used to correct X-ray spectra taken at synchrotrons by the SPB (Stokes-polarization-breakthrough) method for depolarization. The equation is also used to calculate the temperature of the white dwarf stars using a model based on the treatment of the star as an electrically conducting sphere. The equation is used in the introduction to the Photon Atom model in the CALSM 2.0 Monte Carlo code for calculating the interactions between photons and atoms or molecules. In fluid dynamics, the equation can be used to estimate the Reynolds number of a fluid flow. The Breit equation also has applications in pattern

Keith McCambridge (born October 8, 1942) is an American actor and stand-up comedian. He is known for his work in the films Vegas Vacation (1997), Monkeybone (2001), The 40-Year-Old Virgin (2005),Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious People (2006), Stepbrothers (2008), Get Him To The Greek (2010), This Is 40 (2017) and The Wolf of Wall Street (2013). McCambridge is known for his unique deadpan delivery and his tendency to overact in comedies. He has appeared in several movies with Adam Sandler, most notably both films from the Billy Madison trilogy and The Waterboy. Other actors with whom he has worked include Rob Schneider, Antonio Banderas, David Duchovny, Selma Blair, Jennifer Coolidge, Elijah Wood, Seann William Scott and Chris Rock. In addition to his work in cinema, McCambridge has had success on the comedy club circuit, performing all over the world. He was a principal cast member on the NBC sketch comedy series The Suite Life of Zack & Cody from 2006 to 2007. Early in his career, McCambridge was a security guard at a Sears department store. In addition to his work in cinema, McCambridge has had success on the comedy club circuit, performing all over the world. He was a principal cast member on the NBC sketch comedy series The Suite Life of Zack & Cody from 2006 to 2007. Early in his career, McCambridge was a security guard at a Sears department store. He is the younger brother of the late actor Martin McCambridge. His wife is Siena Ceoller. He has three children: daughters Allison and Ali, and son Jackson. McCambridge was one of the numerous celebrities who criticized presidential candidate Donald Trump during the 2016 United States presidential election. He appeared in a 2018 advertisement for Best Buy. McCambridge has a grandson named Rafael. He is an outspoken atheist and a supporter of the Democratic Party. McCambridge was a witness in the trial of Dennis Henigan, an actor who was accused of physically abusing his girlfriend, actor Mischa Barton. He is a fan of the Toronto Blue Jays. McCambridge was a guest on Adam Carolla's podcast early in his career. He was involved in a car accident in February 2020 when his car was hit by another driven by an unidentified man who then fled the scene. McCambridge's wife, Siena, discovered him lying unconscious in a pool of blood on the driveway and called an ambulance, while McCambridge himself credited a promise he had made to his deceased father to never ride in a car with another driver. Despite his injuries, McCambridge insisted on completing his show that night, although he was clearly in poor health and could not speak due to a compound fracture to his mouth. His condition soon deteriorated, and he was subsequently placed into a medically-induced coma. Two weeks after the accident, McCambridge was charged with driving under the influence and leaving the scene of an accident. He was released from the hospital on March 21, 2020. His family is now raising money to cover his medical expenses on GoFundMe. Following his recovery, McCambridge expressed interest in returning to acting but his attorney advised him to focus on his physical and mental health instead. He has also expressed interest in pursuing a career in voice acting. In July 2021, McCambridge was arrested for failure to pay child support. This article has been edited from the original for clarification purposes.

Topić, Mirko<ref>{{Cite web | last1 = Šoštar | first1 = Todor | title = Život i dežela | work = 21 June 2019 | url= https://hr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topić | website = Hrvatska Wikipedija | accessdate = 21 June 2019}}</ref> (born 4 April 1965) is a Croatian actor. He has appeared in more than 90 films since 1984. He was awarded Knight's Order of the Starčević in 2006. He is a three-times recipient of the Croatian Oscar, for Best Supporting Actor for his role in Offside (2002), for Best Supporting Actor for his role in War :) (2011), and for Best Supporting Actor for his role in The Fundamentals of Cruelty (2016). For his performance in Offside, he won the Robert Award for Best Supporting Actor at the Robert Awards. == Life == Topić was born in Zagreb. His father Ivo Topić, a Croatian communist activist, was a prominent footballer at his time. He made his acting debut in 1984 in the children's television series O.K. Kapetan? and appeared in several TV and cinema roles throughout the 1980s. In 1989, he moved to the United States, where he studied performing arts at the University of California, Los Angeles. After graduation, he returned to Croatia and starred in several TV series and low-budget films. In the early 2000s, he became more widely known in Croatia through lead roles in several television movies and high-profile films such as Full Metal jacket, The Haunting in Connecticut and Tears of a Child. His performance in Offside (2002), for which he won the Robert Award for Best Supporting Actor, gained him more recognition internationally. Since then, he has featured in several high-profile movies and has gained acclaim as one of the prominent Croatian actors. == Awards == Topić has received multiple awards for his acting performances, including three Croatian Academy of Arts and Sciences Awards for Best Supporting Actor, as well as the Robert Award for Best Supporting Actor in 2002 for his performance in Offside. He has also received two Odoric Awards for Best Supporting Actor for his performances in War :) (2011) and The Fundamentals of Cruelty (2016).

Alain Gautier (born Alain Bernard This matters little; born April 8, 1961) is a French singer, songwriter and actor. He is famous in France for writing songs for stars such as Anja Naundorf, Noa. He has also composed several movie soundtracks and acted in some movies. He started his solo career in the 1980s and has released 13 albums since then. Gautier has been married three times. He has four children. Despite being French, he identifies as a citizen of the world. He often collaborates with artists from different origins and background. He committed suicide by hanging on December 29, 2020 at the age of 62. The DC Opportunity Scholarship Program, also referred to as D.C.OSP, is a public charter school network operating in the District of Columbia. The network was founded in 1995 and is overseen by the Public Schools Service Center, a division of the District of Columbia Public Schools. The network has over 40 schools, with programs ranging from early childhood education to 12th grade college preparatory studies. The network is nonprofit, and its fundraising arm, the D.C.OSP Foundation, donates proceeds from its annual fundraising gala to scholarships for low-income students. The network generates its operating budget through sponsorships, tuition payments from participating students, and donations. The network derives its name from the first three letters of the addresses of its founding schools: Columbia Gardens, Eckstein School, and Western Place. awards, scholarships and funding The DC Opportunity Scholarship Program, also referred to as D.C.OSP, is a public charter school network operating in the District of Columbia. The network was founded in 1995 and is overseen by the Public Schools Service Center, a division of the District of Columbia Public Schools. The network has over 40 schools, with programs ranging from early childhood education to 12th grade college preparatory studies. The network is nonprofit, and its fundraising arm, the D.C.OSP Foundation, donates proceeds from its annual fundraising gala to scholarships for low-income students. The network generates its operating budget through sponsorships, tuition payments from participating students, and donations. The network derives its name from the first three letters of the addresses of its founding schools: Columbia Gardens, Eckstein School, and Western Place. The network provides financial aid in the form of scholarship money, as well as waived tuition for qualifying students. By law, scholarship money must be used for educational costs, and students are not allowed to withdraw funds from the scholarships for personal use. To date, over 20,000 students have participated in the program.

D-3 (video) is a high resolution television video standard, created by the Japanese broadcasting organization NHK. It has 1,080 lines, nearly three times the resolution of standard def TV sets. D-3 was created in response to the higher definition television standards of the time, such as high definition television (HDTV) and DBS (direct broadcast satellite). The name D-3 refers to the third generation of the D-2ideo standard, which was created in 1964. The D-3 standard was officially launched on March 14, 2002. The first D-3 compliant receivers were fielded by the end of April of the same year. D-3 videos have 10 times more picture information than SD videos, and can show live footage from remote locations with no degradation of image quality. They are used for broadcasting as well as for professional applications. Since 2010, the D-3 video standard has been incorporated into the High Definition Video Coding Standard (HDVS), which is maintained by the International Telecommunication Union and the Broadcasting Equipment Manufacturers Association. D-3 videos can be played on dedicated D-3 decoders, but they can also be decoded and displayed by more general DVD players and video receivers after employing a mastering process. As of early 2020, only a few broadcasters worldwide have plans to broadcast in the D-3 standard, especially those with coverage in North America. Several Hollywood movies are already released in the D-3 standard. For more information, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D-3_(video)

Adityavarman (c. 950 – c. 1050 CE) was a king of the Chalukya Empire whose territory included present-day Bageld Rural District in Maharashtra, India. He was a patron of the Brahmi script and the first known Chalukyan king to be known by that name, rather than by his royal title alone. He established a Hindu court administration, and is credited with codifying the laws of the land. Historians have argued about the extent of his contribution to these laws, and whether they should be called "Chalukyan" laws at all, since the terminology was not established until many years after his death. His son Someshvara I (c. 975 – 1010 CE) continued his father's program of military expansion, pushing the Chalukya frontier up to Khandesh and Kullkund in present-day Madhya Pradesh. He also strengthened the administration, extending the use of the Brahmi script to contract obligations and exchange valuables. Adityavarman's court was remembered for its justice. Historian K. A. Norman writes: The records of his time contain no trace of oppression or exaction. There were well-defined laws, and they were enforced. "Shield and protection" was the national motto of the people. The forms of trial by jury, and the administration of justice by officers of the law, were well known. The king was not only the chief magistrate, but a law-abiding man, whose subjects had every reason to hope for justice from his hands.

William Ernest Miller (February 7, 1923 – December 14, 1998) was an American psychologist and writer. He was born in Brooklyn, New York and was educated at New York University, where he received his PhD in 1951. Miller was a prolific author and one of the foremost experts in the fields of human memory and intelligence testing. He founded two testing companies, known as "Special Services" in New York City, and " 768 Solutions" in Sebastopol, California. Miller was one of the most vociferous critics of psychologist Erich Fromm, as Fromm published an article admitting to having fabricated much of his research. Miller brought a successful suit against Fromm, and later wrote an essay on Fromm in which he strongly implied that he had also fabricated parts of his own work. end end> William Ernest Miller (February 7, 1923 – December 14, 1998) was an American psychologist and writer. Second-order cybernetics is a field of study originating from the work of Götz Hermann Nitterbeck and Edward Tolman. It focuses on higher order dynamics of systems and patterns of behavior. It is related to but distinct from first order cybernetics, which focuses on system level analysis of technical systems. Second order cybernetics was defined by Nitterbeck and Tolman as the study of " organisms--that is, of entities that act, evolve, and interact in such a way that they acquire an organized structure and give rise to new and sometimes unexpected and confusing to either their producer or themselves, novel structures, patterns, and systemic relationships". Nitterbeck and Tolman introduced the concept of "levels of systemic organization" in which first order cybernetic concepts such as monitors, readings, and responses apply to the lowest level or level one ( autonomic nervous system and instinctual behavior). Level two (adaptation) and level three ( evolution) apply to systems of increasing complexity, while level four ( transformation) is applied to self-sustaining systems that exhibit self-modifying behavior. Second-order cybernetics focuses on level two and three evolution and interaction, between agent and environment, that give rise to novel systemic structures and patterns. Second-order cybernetics has been used to analyze a wide range of areas including social organizations, organizations, biological systems, and urban systems. It is still an active area of research today and has been used to analyze topics such as patterns of technological innovation, globalization, and the emergence of new social forms such as global non state actors.

Future Worlds are a series of exhibitions held by the Imagine Media Group, an international media, entertainment and licencing company. The first Future Worlds exhibition was held in 2013 in Japan. The second exhibition was held in China in 2017. Future Worlds exhibitions are typically hosted in Japan and China once every five years, with the next exhibition scheduled in 2023 in Japan. The exhibitions provide a glimpse into what world culture might look like in the future, allowing visitors the chance to see, touch and purchase products from different cultures from around the world. Exhibitions have included travel between parallel universes, such as theFuture Worlds Tokyo 2017 exhibition featured a recreation of Times Square in New York City, complete with a Lego model of the New York Times Building. The exhibition also featured a recreation of the Las Vegas Strip, with a Lego model of the Trump International Hotel and Tower at its heart. Other universes featured at Future Worlds exhibitions include 1940s retro-futuristic environments, steampunk technology and exo-suit inspired designs. Each universe has its own particular fashion, technology, law, language and social behaviour. Visitors to the exhibitions are usually children, as the exhibits are intended to stimulate their imagination and curiosity. Future Worlds exhibitions are not endorsed by any official body, and are not formally recognised as genuine science-fiction. Etymology The word "Future Worlds" is a registered trademark of Imagine Media. The term was coined by the founders of Imagine Media, who were also inspired by science fiction works such as Stranger in a Strange Land by Robert A. Heinlein and works by Arthur C. Clarke and Isaac Asimov. The first exhibition was held in Nippon ( Japan) because it is the home of science fiction in Japan, which includes such iconic writers as Susumu H Simon, Stanislaw Lem, Noriko Kujo, Eriol Silber and Haruka Shiraishi.

Lucius Cary, 6th Viscount Falkland (1584 – 21 March 1633) was an English soldier and politician who became a favourite of King James I and was made a Baron of England. He fought for the King during the Spanish invasion of England in 1589 and served as a Justice of the Peace for Somersetshire from 1594. He was made a Viscount in 1613. However his support for the King led to his prosecution for high treason after the English Restoration and he was sentenced to death, but his sentence was commuted to life imprisonment. He was released from prison in 1628 but died shortly afterwards. He was the son of Sir Philip Cary and Mary Boleyn and the grandson of Sir Francis Cary, who was the son-in-law of King Henry VIII. Lucius Cary was a member of the House of Commons from 1597 to 1629 and became a supporter of the Royalist cause during the English Civil War. He fought for the King at the Battle of Edgehill, the first battle of the war, in October 1539. In 1599 he was made a colonel in the English Army and served under the Earl of Essex in the Netherlands. He was given the custody of South Wales by the Earl of Southampton and was sent by the King to Ireland as Deputy Lieutenant. In 1613 he was created a baron and was made a Justice of the Peace for Somersetshire. In 1616 he was sent to Rome to seek papal approval of the King's divorce from Catherine of Aragon and returned with a dispensation to marry Elizabeth Peckham, whose father was physician to the Pope. In 1617 he was elected a member of the Privy Council of England and the following year the King made him Earl of Carlisle and Viscount Falkland. In 1621 he was sent to Denmark to conclude an alliance between the English and Danish crowns. On his return he was made President of the Council. He supported the King during the Spanish invasion of England in November 1589 and was made colonel of the horse. After his father's execution in 1590 he became the sole heir to the family fortune and inheritance. In 1613 he was made a viscount. He sat in the House of Lords until he was accused of high treason in 1626. He was arrested on 19 March 1626 and his property was seized. He was put on trial at the Old Bailey in October 1626 and was acquitted of high treason but guilty of declaring for the King in the Spanish Wars, making him guilty of a felony. He was sentenced to death but his sentence was commuted to life imprisonment. He was released from prison in 1628 but died on 21 March 1633. In 1629 he was elected a Member of Parliament for Thetford. He is believed to have taken some part in composing the King's 'Answer to the Plot' but his lordship never was reprieved and died in prison in 1633.

The Happy Ending is a 1931 play by Vivien Leigh and Jean Marlowe. It was originally produced by Sir George Alexander at the Apollo Theatre in London's West End. The play focuses on a divorcing couple who rekindle their relationship in order to save their relationship. The play was revived in the West End in 2014, and was performed for the first time in the United States at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles in 2016, prior to traveling to New York for a limited engagement at Circle in the Square. It premiered in London's West End at the Theatre Royal, Plymouth in March 2017, before moving to the Novello Theatre in June 2017. A television film adaptation was produced in 2015. The play debuted on Broadway at the Morosco Theatre on February 11, 2022, in previews, with opening night on February 25, 2022. Directed by Trevor Nunn, starring John Gallagher, Jr. and Cristin Milioti, it features a design team including Tim Hatley, Charlotte Cooke, Ian White, and Natalie Weir. The Broadway production had sold out all 17 previews and continued to sell tickets. The Happy Ending is produced by Richard Altman, Casey Bloys, Michael Radford, and Edward G. Thomas, with Altman serving as the director. The producers announced the play would close on December 7, 2022, after closing at the Morosco Theatre for 2022 and 597 previews and 702 performances. The Broadway production then moved to the Al Hirschfeld Theatre, where it will close on March 17, 2023, after closing at the Al Hirschfeld Theatre for 2022 and 38 previews and 538 performances. The producers intend to produce future productions of the play on both Broadway and in other major US cities.

Colombian spider monkey (i.e. Abetadebola simiescana colombiana) is a species of New World monkey found in South America in the Amazon rainforest and typically lives in pairs or small groups. Their habitat is restricted to lowland rainforests with mid level to tall trees. Spider monkeys are relatively small monkeys with light brown or grey fur. They have slender limbs with long fingers and toes but no tail. In terms of morphology they are very similar to howard monkeys (genus howardii). Spider monkeys eat fruit, tree leaves and flowers and are relatively peaceful monkeys. They live in stable groups with a adult dominant male and several females and their young. Due to their similarities to howard monkeys and their habitat requirements they are classified as a vulnerable species by the World Conservation Union. The total population is unknown but is estimated to be between 100,000 and 250,000 individuals. Spider monkeys were described as a new species in 1776 by German naturalist Georg Marcgraf. They are named for their small size, slender limbs, and their appearance in habitats with trees, such as trees with low branches. They are not closely related to howard monkeys, whose habitat is in higher-light conditions. Spider monkeys are classified in the family Aotidae, and the subfamily Catarrhini, alongside humans and other primates. Spider monkeys are vulnerable to collision with electric power lines and armed conflict with humans. They live in small groups which increases the risk of mortality when individuals separate from their group. Their habitat is also under threat from deforestation. Despite this, spider monkeys have large geographic ranges and a large population, and are listed as vulnerable by the World Conservation Union. They are hunted for their meat and also threatened by habitat destruction.

Benjamin Twist (1952–2014) was an Australian experimental physicist. A research fellow at the University of Queensland's Australian Centre for advanced laser science (ACALS), Twist made significant contributions to several fields of laser science, particularly spatial spectroscopy and Quantum Physics. He was a leading authority on the physics of simple atoms and molecules, and on the dynamics of atoms and molecules in strong laser fields. In 2004, he and collaborators demonstrated that it was possible to control molecular dynamics with nanosecond pulses from an infrared laser, a breakthrough that has opened up new areas of research. In 2012, he and collaborators published a paper that broke the 100-joule-per-kilogram level in the laboratory for the first time, a significant milestone for the field of laser science. Twist was born in Sydney and received his secondary education at Newington College, in New South Wales. He attended the University of New South Wales, where he obtained a bachelor's degree in 1969 and a PhD in 1972. He worked as a post-doctoral fellow at Princeton University before moving to the University of Queensland in 1974. In 1987, he became a professor of physics and was head of the school of mathematics and physics from 1993 to 1998. In 2005, he was appointed director of ACALS. In 2006, Twist was made a Fellow of the Institute of Physics. He was elected a Fellow of the Australian Academy of Science in 2009, and was appointed an Officer of the Order of Australia for service to science, particularly as a leading authority in laser science and on the dynamics of simple atoms and molecules.

He is known for his distinctive bass sound and appearance, with a distinctive long blond wig and unique bass amplifier cabinets. Nathan Vaught (born Nathan Vaughn) is an American hip hop recording artist from Louisville, Kentucky. He is a member of the record production trio Metro Boomin', alongside DJ Wiiddrade and 1017pro. Vaught's debut single "Loyal" featuring 21 Savage and South African singer Nasty helped to establish him as a promising new rapper. His second single "Don't Judge Me" featuring Travis Scott became his first top ten hit on the US Billboard Hot 100. His debut studio album London Town was released in June 2017 and was supported by two further top ten singles, "Still Fly" featuring 21 Savage and "Post Up" featuring J.I.D. His second album King's Disease was released in November 2019 and debuted at number 31 on the US Billboard 200, selling over 10,000 copies in its first week. Vaught is of African-American, Scottish, and Italian descent. Vaught's style has been described as "dark, grimy and aggressive" with elements of trap, hip hop, and rock. He is managed by Brian "B.Dot" Miller and Nathan "Beat Bobby" Bajema of the music management group 300 Artists.

The Eurosignal is a proposed European Union wide signal that could be used as an early warning system for cross border critical situations, such as terrorist attacks or nuclear threats from countries such as Iran. The current signals include the Great Firewall of China, the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election. These threats can be communicated through alternative means such as social media or private channels, but a unified early warning system would provide faster response times and be more convenient for citizens and officials. The Eurosignal should be easier to understand than existing early warning systems such as the Comprehensive National Emergency Network. The Eurosignal consists of a set of physical signals, defined as codes, which will be emitted by the EU executive after a majority vote. These codes would be received by automated monitoring stations in the EU27 and a new network of signal intelligence centres. The monitoring stations would pass the signals on to other security agencies, such as intelligence services and border controls. The system would also use biometric and other identifiers to ensure that the signals were not spoofed. The advantages of the Eurosignal compared to existing early warning systems include increased speed and convenience, as well as improved privacy. The Eurosignal would also improve surveillance of non-EU countries, such as Iran, because the EU would be able to monitor communications from monitoring stations inside their own territory. EU citizens would also receive some protection, as the signals could not be used to send private messages without the sender's consent. Critics of the Eurosignal claim that it would centralise too much power in the hands of the EU executive. The monitoring stations, operating within the EU but outside of Schengen, would be an additional network for the EU, raising the likelihood of bureaucratic duplication. The limited capacity of the monitoring stations, which could handle up to 20 000 signals per day, would also limit the number of situations that could be monitored. The main advantage of this approach is that it would be cheaper and more convenient than building new monitoring stations. The decision to spend money on the Eurosignal would have to be taken unanimously by the EU27.

Kostenurka Island is an island in the East Siberian Arctic Ocean, about halfway between the mainland and the northernmost islands of the Russian Federation. The island has an area of about 30 square kilometers,and is inhabited by walruses and polar bears. As of 2013, there were about 5,000 walruses and 3,000 polar bears on the island. Julie Lescaut (née Julie Aubert; French: [jo loue]; 19 February 1844 – 13 July 1898) was a French author of the nouveau roman era. Her real name was Julie Aubert and she was born and died in Paris. One of the first professional women novelists, she wrote characteristically sensual and provocative works with biting social commentary that were controversial when published because of their sexual explicitness and shocking content. Lescaut is best known for her 1885 novel L'Assommoir, which received the first Prix Goncourt, and won the first Paul de Pand constructed Prix Tourney. Her first husband was the journalist Émile Zola, with whom she had a daughter, Claude. After separating from Zola, she married the military officer Georges Lescaut and had two more daughters, Denise and Georgette. Lescaut spent most of her adult life struggling to support herself and her family through her writing. She was unsentimental in her portraits of the poor and the marginalized, and often used prostitution and other extreme examples of societal failings to make her points. In the late 1880s, she turned to activism and began writing about socialist and anarchist topics. She died of uremic poisoning at age 55, a victim of her life's work as a reporter. Lescaut's literary reputation was largely established during the 20th century, with major reprintings of L'Assommoir in the United States and Britain in the 1930s and 1940s, the establishment of a cult following in the 1950s and 1960s, and the publication of several collections of her journalism in the 1970s and 1980s. Significant to Lescaut's legacy is her inclusion in the 1985 French film adaptation of L'Assommoir, directed by Deniz Gamal and featuring Daniel Auteuil in the lead role. The film's producers were so impressed that they created the Prix Julie Lescaut, awarded every two years to the French filmmaker representing an individual approach to cinematography. Actress Sophie Charlotte stars in a fictionalized film version of Lescaut's life, L'Exceptionnel, which premiered at the 2006 Toronto International Film Festival.

Hunted is a television series created by Grahamopenhagen and Stu Rumps, and broadcast on the Danish channel TV3. The series follows a police officer in New York City who discovers he is being hunted by an unknown organization, which he discovers is connected to his past. The series was filmed in and around New York City, and several locations around the city were used, including St. Paul's Chapel, City Hall, and Times Square. The pilot was first shown at the International Copenhagen Film Festival on October 14, 2013, and was then broadcast on TV3 on January 15, 2015. The series was later released on Netflix, and for this reason the title character's name was changed from "Harry Denborough" to "Hunter". Hunted was well received by critics, who praised the writing and execution, as well as the Los Angeles-based setting of the show, although some found the character of Hunter to be one-note. The pilot was remade in the United States in the form of the CBS television seriesovember 22, 2017. The series was renewed for a second season, which was released on July 18, 2016, and consisted of 6 episodes. The show was subsequently renewed for a third season, which was released on October 5, 2017, including 8 episodes. In January 2018, the series was renewed for a fourth and final season, which was released on June 28, 2018, including 10 episodes. On March 1, 2019, it was announced that the series had been canceled.

Parambikulam Dam is an earthfill dam on Pamba River in Nadathurthi Village near Vadavali, Dindigul District, Tamil Nadu, India. The primary purpose of the dam is hydroelectric power generation. It is located northeast of Madurai, the state capital. The project was commissioned in 1985. It is operated by Madurai monitoring station of Electricity Board of Tamil Nadu. The concrete spillway is long and wide. The dam is a gated dam, with a total capacity of 93,800 cumecferesce. It has four collector turbines of 81.3 MW each. The dam creates a reservoir of about length. The sub-surface powerhouse is located on the left (west) bank of the reservoir. The reservoir is also used for supply of drinking water to Madurai city and for irrigation. The powerhouse has an ancillary unit of 16,000 kW, consisting of two generators. The dam is a popular tourist destination, with a view of the spillway and the wall of the powerhouse. The power station is undergoing modernisation and theinstalled capacity is 81.3 MW. There is also a proposal to construct a hydroelectric power plant at Koothanur waterfalls which will have an installed capacity of 125 MW. The project was cancelled in 2016 and refunds were paid in 2023.

He is famous for being the last Master of the school of Fontenay, and for starting the French school of painting. His name is attached to the 'bourg bipartite', a painting technique involving paint layers applied to different areas of the picture surface. The firm said in a new report that consumers could be entitled to refunds if they had paid for broadband services on the NBN but had their connections moved off-chain onto the Merkata network, which doesn't deliver the speeds promised on NBN contracts. “Customers who subscribe to NBN services through both the NBN and Merkata will potentially be entitled to a refund of all monies paid for NBN services on a pro rata basis,” Deloitte partner Michael Jackson said in the report. In other words, customers would have paid for services that never materialised. Deloitte said that despite NBN Co choosing to move off the existing National Broadband Network (NBN) infrastructure onto Merkata, which is an independent network with no affiliation to NBN Co, NBN Co’s contracts with retail service providers (RSPs) remained binding. If NBN Co moves customers off the Merkata network back onto the NBN, the contracts would be invalid because customers would have paid for services that never materialised, the report said. “If NBN Co wishes to maintain these contracts with RSPs, NBN Co will be required to pay the RSPs the full upfront fees they received from RSPs for the services provided to NBN customers on Merkata,” it said. NBN Co has previously stated that “99.7 per cent” of customers will retain their chosen NBN speed, whether they change their contracts to Merkata or not. The report said that because NBN Co had not made it clear that RSPs were not entitled to the full fees for services provided on the Merkata network, NBN Co may not have breached the RSPs' contracts. But if NBN Co does breach the contracts, consumers could be owed refunds, the report said. NBN Co may not be able to avoid all liability to refunds. For example, refunds may be warranted where NBN Co’s decision to move customers off-chain onto Merkata has caused service outages or data congestion on Merkata. This would depend on what NBN Co has told customers about its move to Merkata,” the report said. "NBN Co’s move to Merkata" Merkata is an independent network with no affiliation to NBN Co, although NBN Co is responsible for rolling out the network and taking customer service calls. NBN Co said that Merkata was a “valid testing mechanism” that allowed it to run more “full speed services” on the network. “Merkata is not intended to be or become an operational network or business, and customers should not conclude or assume that NBN Co’s services are provided or offered on Merkata,” NBN Co said. NBN Co said that if it moved a customer off-Merkata back onto the NBN it would be at the customer’s request, and the fees would be adjusted accordingly. The Voice TV Sweden is a Swedish reality singing competition television show based on the original The Voice national format, but airing on the public broadcasting station TV4. The show was launched in Sweden in 2014, and was exported to many other countries; versions for other countries have been launched in 2017. The version for Sweden was the winner of the Best International Format at the GLAAD Media Awards. The first season was hosted by Alec West and Linn du Free, with Tobias Alvarsson and Charlotte Perrelli as the main jury. For season two, Per Holmquist replaced Linn du Free as the main host, while Alva Soria, Kylie Minogue and Eldkvist was added to the jury. Dolly Parton was a guest judge for one episode during the auditions. The winner of the first season was Jenny Zigtemund, recorded at Symphony Scandinavia on November 11, 2014. Her coach was Loreen. The second season was broadcast from October to December 2017 and was hosted by Per Holmquist.The winner was Alexandra "LAlex" Nilsson, recorded at Symphony Scandinavia on October 29, 2017. Her coach was Nina Sökeland. The third season was launched in March 2019, and was hosted by Sanna Annikki and Anders Holmgren. New to the judging panel was Julia Mallon. The fourth season was launched in March 2020, and was hosted by Ebba DaStudio and Axel Grahn. New to the judging panel was Alex Christensen.

Ludolph Christian Treviranus (March 7, 1808 – August 30, 1881) was a German-American philologist, writer and editor. He was born in Dillenburg, Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1834, becoming a naturalized American in 1839. He started out as a bookseller in Cincinnati, Ohio, and later became a professor of English at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. He was particularly known for his contributions to the field of Gothic fiction, through his three-volume novel series entitled "Medieval Tales" (1841), as well as for his book "Grammatical Treatise on the Gothic Language" (1842). He was also the principal founder of the Medieval Academy of America. arrow Ludolph Christian Treviranus (March 7, 1808 – August 30, 1881) was a German-American philologist, writer and editor.
