Arachniotus ruber is a species of spider in the family Theraphosidae found in Chile and Argentina. The name 'Arachniotus' comes from the Greek word for spider and the species' Latin name. It is one of the six species of spider in the genus Arachniotus, the others being: - Arachniotus brucei - Arachniotus coronatus - Arachniotus granulatus - Arachniotus hortense - Arachniotus imperator - Arachniotus octavius A. ruber has a light brown body with a pattern of cream and brown chevrons and transverse bands on its back. It is most similar to Arachniotus brucei, A. coronatus, A. granulatus and A. imperator but can be distinguished from them by the pattern of its body and the lack of spines on its abdomen. A. ruber lives in silken retreats it spins under leaves and in rotten wood and can also spin pre-made retreats. It is not considered to be dangerous to humans. A. ruber was described by Samuel Frederick Gray in 1857 with the type locality given as "Chile, Santiago". A. ruber was also found in Argentina for the first time in 2005 but was thought to be rare and was listed as 'Critically Endangered' by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. However further study showed that its range did not overlap with the potential range of the more critically endangered A. brucei and that the true population size of A. ruber was significantly larger than previous estimates, making it a 'least-concern' species rather than 'Critically Endangered'. Further study also showed that A. ruber was not dangerous and was actually able to prey on other spiders including members of its own genus. It is found in forests with moderate to high levels of humidity.

Gdańsk Przymorze-Uniwersytet is a railway station in Gdańsk, Poland, located in the city centre near the University of Gdańsk campus and the Round Tower. It is a major transportation hub with access to the Gdańsk Port Tunnel and Słupsk railway station, as well as regional trains and metropolitan buses. The terminal is located near the international ferry to Tozonjab, the only international ferry operating out of Gdańsk. The first train arrived in Gdańsk on May 19, 1857, and the terminal was inaugurated on December 20 of the same year. Originally named Przymorze (Przymorz), it was renamed Gdańsk Przymorze in 1965. In 2011 the station was extensively renovated, including a new, larger ticketing hall, waiting room, and customer service area as well as better accessibility, lighting, and security. The station is owned by PKP, and as of 2014 had an average of 18,000 passengers per day, the highest on the Gdańsk–Hel railway. It is the northern terminus of the Gdańsk Śródmieście (Gdańsk City Centre) line and the southern terminus of the Słupsk Ring Conway line. Additional lines serving the terminal include regional trains to Bydgoszcz, Elbląg, Łódź, Poznań, Słupsk, Warsaw, and Zielona Góra as well as six metro lines and several U-Bahn lines. Gdańsk Przymorze is located in the heart of the city close to the Round Tower, at ul. Długa 54-100, in the economic region of Zachód Gdańsk. It is easily accessible by public transportation: several regional and metropolitan buses depart from in front of the station, and many metropolitan railway lines as well as U-Bahn lines pass nearby. The main station hall is located on the first floor, and accessible via the main entrance, underground passage, or an elevator. There are also several service areas, including a pharmacy, bank, and newsagent. A 2015 expansion plan included a new passenger terminal, additional parking lots, and improved accessibility. An additional access to the station is being planned to serve as an interchange with the city's proposed high-speed train. The PKP headquarters, as well as the offices of the Gdańsk Port Authority, are located in the Przymorze station complex. The terminal is a popular meeting place for tourists, due to its close proximity to the Old Town and the city centre restaurant and nightlife district. It is frequently featured in Polish postcard exhibitions, and it is a popular filming location for films and television shows. The station was entered on the List of World Heritage Sites in 2017 as one of 18 remaining railway stations designed by Henryk Tahla. Although the terminal has been renovated several times since 2011, it still lacks several modern facilities. The waiting rooms are small, uncomfortable, and of variable cleanliness, with some disabled access lacking. The ticketing hall is also small and crowded, with ticket machines taking up most of the available space. Connections to the Internet and domestic long distance calls are also difficult to find. There are also complaints that customer service is unhelpful or even hostile, although the number of complaints has decreased in recent years. Gdańsk Przymorze-Uniwersytet is well-maintained and clean, with professional staff, adequate facilities, and an ambiance suitable for a busy transportation hub. It is well-used by tourists and city residents, and serves as a popular meeting place for locals and tourists alike. It is also the headquarters of the PKP Group, one of Poland's largest transportation companies. In 2021, the Przymorze station complex was transferred from the PKP to the city of Gdańsk under a joint-stock company, funded by a loan from the European Union. After the expiration of the loan, full ownership will be transferred to the city, and the company will become a shareholder. In 2023, the city planned to invest PLN 170 million in renovating and extending the Przymorze station complex, to bring it in line with current high-tech standards. The tree produces edible fruits that are a common food of the espindáquiya indigenous tribe in Brazil. The species is native to the northern part of South America, from Bolivia and Brazil through Paraguay to Uruguay. In Portuguese-speaking regions of Brazil the tree is called Salvileiro. In Portugal the tree is called Índigo and it is sometimes called arroubadina. In Romania it is called leapa, in Italy maschera di provolone, in Spain alibóndigo and in French France : chênaie. The wood of the tree is used to make pulp for papermaking and it is also used in construction. The edible fruits of the tree are purplish-black, roughly spherical, roughly a centimeter in diameter, with a mildly astringent flavor. They are edible and are generally consumed fresh, though they can also be used to make jellies, jams, and preserves. The seeds are also edible and are used in confectionery and for planting. The wood of the tree is moderately resistant to decay, the tree can grow to a height of 10 metres (33 feet) with a spread of up to 18 metres (60 feet). The Azevedo tree is an important species in the Upper Amazonia forest, where it can often be found near rivers. The seeds have a great potential for germination after several years, even if they were collected soon after flowering. The following is an incomplete list of party headquarters, including those that were primary headquarters of political parties: - 10 Downing Street, London – headquarters of the Conservative Party (1910–present) and the Salisbury Party (1905–1910) - Buckingham Palace – headquarters of the Liberal Party (1885–1905) - 10 Cavalry Sq, London – headquarters of the Labour Party (1884–present) - Victoria Tower, London – headquarters of the Liberal Party (1880–1884) and the Salisbury Party (1875–1880) - Houses of Parliament – headquarters of the Conservative and Labour Parties (1870–present) - 10 Grosvenor Square, London – headquarters of the Anti-Corn Law League (1838–1870) - House of Lords – headquarters of the Liberal Party (1868–1838) In addition to party headquarters, the Palace of Westminster also houses the headquarters of the Group of Eight (GGE) political parties, along with 10 Downing Street, which has been the headquarters of the Conservative Party since 1910. Many other buildings have been used as party headquarters, including Liberal Party headquarters in 40 Palace Street, Parliament Street and Victoria Street, Manchester; Conservative Party headquarters in 42 Lancaster Gate, Belgravia, and 190 Strand in London; and Labour Party headquarters in 285 Farringdon Road, London. The designation of a party's headquarters is controversial; while some argue that the designations should reflect the party's current headquarters, others argue that the designations should reflect the historical location of the party's campaign headquarters. In the United Kingdom, the Conservative and Labour parties use both " headquarters " and " party headquarters " designations, with the former referring to the building where the party currently resides and the latter referring to the building where the party's operations were located during the last general election.

Schleswig-Holstein is a state in north-east Germany. It is the most populous and largest of the state lands of Germany and its population is about three million people. It has an area of approximately 1,045 km2, making it the smallest state in Germany. It is a member state of the Federation of Independents, along with Hesse, Lower Saxony, North Rhine-Westphalia, Saxony and Bavaria, and belongs to the Schengen Area. The state's capital and largest city is Kiel. Schleswig-Holstein is a combination of two regions, Schleswig and Holstein, which were only reunited in 1920. The state's name literally means "Schleswig-Holstein territory" and refers to the two regions combined. The state was most notably a battleground in the Thirty Years' War, the Second War of Schleswig and the Jutland campaign of World War I. In the period after World War II, the state was a social-democratic stronghold and one of themost important state governments in the German political center-right orbit. Since the 1970s, it has been the strongest parliamentary representation of the Democratic Party (Germany) nationwide. As the Federal state of Germany became a federation in 1871, Schleswig-Holstein is not a part of any EU countries and is not surrounded by foreign countries. Due to its prosperity and stability, the island of Hamburg is often called the "Schleswig-Holstein of the North". The two universities Kiel and Flensburg are among the best in Germany, and their integration initiatives have made them prominent in European and German studies. Schleswig-Holstein is a member of the Euroregion Rhine-Main and of the, a collective European organization.

Dejan Ranković (Serbian Cyrillic: Дејан Ранковић) (born 22 September 1964) is a Serbian professional basketball coach and former player. He currently serves as a head coach for Igokea. After playing throughout the 1980s and 1990s in the former Yugoslavia, Ranković began his coaching career with a stints with the basketball teams of FMP, Ufuk Bandic, the former Yugoslav youth national team and several ABA League clubs. In 2006, he was named head coach of the Radnički Belgrade basketball team. In the 2010–11 season, he won the national championship with Radnički. He won the EuroLeague title as coach of Žalgiris in 2013. Since 2016, he has coached the Igokea sports society. Ranković was a regular Yugoslav international, and was a member of the team that won the silver medal at the 1988 Summer Olympics. He won bronze medals with Yugoslavia at the EuroBasket 1991 and the 1994 FIBA World Championship. He won silver medals with Yugoslavia at the 1996 Summer Olympics and the 1998 FIBA World Championship. He also won bronze medals with Yugoslavia at the EuroBasket 1991 and the 2001 FIBA World Championship. He participated at the 1988, 1992, 1996, 2000, and 2004 Summer Olympics. He won silver medals with Yugoslavia at the 1980 Summer Olympics and the 1982 FIBA World Championship. He also won silver medals with Yugoslavia at the EuroBasket 1985. Ranković retired from playing after the 2000–01 season.

It has attractive red flowers, and releases a chemical that makes it water repellant. It is also an important habitat for koala bears. History Eucalyptus olsenii has been scientifically described in 1998 by Ken Hill and Bryan Adams, based on material collected near Cape Riche. In 1999, Hill and Adams published the names of two subspecies, E. o. subsp. olsenii and E. o. subsp. stenopetala. A closely related tree with a similar range is Eucalyptus regnans, the Queensland mallet, which has pink flowers and is not repellant to water. Ecology Eucalyptus olsenii is an important habitat for a number of animals, including the threatened black-headed flying fox, the common wombat, the brushtail possum, the koala and the ring-tailed possum. The tree is itself an important habitat for mallee fowl and the western barred bandicoot. Releases of the chemical malleilactone make the tree water repellant.

The Charles Sumner House, located at 1516 8th Avenue in Portland, Oregon, was built in 1901 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1977. It was the home of Charles Sumner, a United States Senator from 1895 to 1905 and again from 1913 to 1917, and also served as his law office. Sumner was a leading spokesman for racial equality in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and his support for the Republicans in the Senate eventually led to his truce with President Andrew Johnson, an end to Reconstruction, and ultimately his dismissal from the Republican Party. The house was renovated and expanded in 1936 in the Classical Revival style. Sumner was born in Boston, a descendant of Paul Revere, and attended Boston Latin School and Harvard College. He began his career in journalism and moved to New York City in 1859, where he became a correspondent for the New York Times, and also wrote for The Illustrated American, a journal published by Edgar Allan Poe. He resigned his position with the Times in 1861 to fight in the Civil War, enlisting in the Army as a private in the 19th Massachusetts Infantry. He was appointed Assistant Inspector General in the Army of the James after the war, and then served in various political positions in Massachusetts, first as a Republican, then as a Democrat and finally as a Liberal Republican. Sumner moved to Portland, Oregon in 1872 and began teaching mathematics and science at Jefferson High School. In 1876, he co-founded The Oregonian with George Lawrence May and Josepharas Barnes, and he became known for his oratory in the House of Representatives and the Oregon Senate. He resigned from The Oregonian in 1881 and started a private law practice, but his legislative work was not limited to Oregon. In 1894, President Benjamin Harrison appointed Sumner United States Ambassador to Japan, and he served in this post from June 1895 to March 1897. Sumner returned to Oregon in 1897 to take a seat in the Senate, where he would represent the state for six terms, serving from 1895 to 1917. In 1901, Sumner purchased the lot and built the present house, which he lived in until his death in 1922. He left the house to his daughters, and one of them, Augusta (1865-1941) lived in the house until her death. The house was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1977, and it is located within the boundaries of the Chinatown neighborhood. It is one of the few standing Classical Revival residences in the neighborhood. We treated an 18-yr-old woman who had carbon monoxide poisoning using coupled plasma filtration and hyperbaric oxygenation (CPFH). The carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) level of her blood sample determined using an artificial lung was 53.8% at 1 hr after the poisoning, which was increased to 65.6% by CPFH. The patient was discharged 2 days after the poisoning without sequelae. All engines were four-cylinder engines built in Mercedes-Benz AMG engine plant in Sindelfingen.

Arthur L. Wagner (August 13, 1912 – October 8, 1993) was an American electrical engineer and manager. He began working at Bell Laboratories in 1937 and stayed there for the rest of his career. Wagner played a major role in the development of several key technologies that are used in telecommunication networks, including the pulse code modulation (PCM) format, Nyquist sampling, and frequency-division multiplexing (FDM). He was a leader in the development of turbo coding, the technology that is used in modern wireless communications and which helped put the United States on the leading edge of telecommunication development throughout the late 20th and early 21st centuries. He also wrote several standard telecommunications texts that are still in use today. Wagner served as the head of Bell Labs from 1957 until his retirement in 1980. After his retirement from Bell Labs, Wagner became a professor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. In 1987, he was awarded the National Medal of Science, the United States' highest scientific honor. George Thomson, Baron Thomson of Monifieth (1848–1928) was a Scottish political economist and educationalist. Born in Edinburgh, he was educated at the Royal High School then studied Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh, graduating with an examination that allowed him to practice in that subject. His 1874 PhD thesis was on The Rate of Exchange between the Different Metals and Their Alloys, upon which he worked for a time in the Royal College of Chemistry. In 1878 he began lecturing in Political Economy at the University of Glasgow, and in 1885 moved to the University of Edinburgh to take up the post of Principal of the newly created Chair of Political Economy. In 1894 he became the first Professor of Political Economy in the University of London and, in 1901, the first Professor of Economics at the University of Manchester. Thomson was also a prominent political activist, and in 1885 was elected President of the National Secular Society, which was the most influential organisation in the UK campaigning for secular state education. In this role he oversaw the creation of the National Secular Society's Holy Days Act 1887, which allowed for state funded education to take place on Sundays. He was elected President of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1896 and remained President until his death in 1928. In 1907 he was raised to the peerage as Baron Thomson of Monifieth, of Monifieth in the County of Ayr. Between 1908 and 1919 he served as Chancellor of the University of St Andrews.

Rondout Creek is an tributary of the Schoharie Creek that flows through Dutchess and Columbia counties in New York State. The Rondout Creek flows into the east side of the Hudson River in Ulster County near the town of Palermo. The Rondout Creek is one of two primary westward flowing streams in the vicinity of the city of Hudson. The other is the Unadilla River, a small tributary of the later. The Rondout Creek is southeast of the Unadilla River watershed. The Rondout Creek is an unusual stream in that it has two names. The portion north of the county line is called the North Branch Rondout Creek. The portion south of it is called the South Branch Rondout Creek. The stream was named Rondout during the original land grant to the Holland Land Company in 1664, when it was called Rondwert (Rondout+wert,'round or circular [stream]'). The North Branch Rondout Creek was called the Wawbeque Beaver Kill, a Beaver Kill that crossed the Beaver Kill River to become the Rondout Creek. The Rondout Creek is also unusual in its water supply. It is one of the few streams in the region that retains natural springs instead of relying on meltwater from the surrounding hills. This is possible due to the tectonic activity which formed the Hudson Valley during the breakup of Pangaea. During the Ice Ages, glaciers blocking the previous valley of the Rondout Valley, which was eventually filled with lake Agassiz water. After the glaciers melted, they left damns at different places in the valley which formed the natural springs. The Rondout Creek is the most important of these streams, since it flows directly into the Hudson River.

"Anything Goes" is a song by American singer-songwriter Randy Houser. Geology of Libya -------------------- Libya is an African country on the southwestern corner of the Mediterranean Sea, north of Egypt and south of Chad. Libya has a small unicellular tradition of mountains, which are largely illiterate from tectonic activity. Libya's continental crust, which is about twice the thickness of the average African country, is enriched in heavy metals such as uranium and thorium, which are made slightly more abundant due to the relatively high level of granite in the country's rock make-up. Libya is not a seismically active country and there are no recent earthquakes with significant effects on human settlements. However, the Cyrene foundation stone was laid on the site of the ancient city of Cyrene in Libya, and the city was home to one of the world's largest Carnac stones, which commemorates Greek prisoners of war. Libya has many natural gas fields and was thought to have significant amounts of oil, but in 2011 these reserves were found to be insignificant. Geography Libya's climate is tropical and temperate. The southern areas have a desert climate, while the northern areas have a Mediterranean climate. Wildlife in Libya includes cheetahs, leopards, desert wolves, mountain caracals, golden jackals, vervet monkeys, rock rabbits, scops owls, European honey buzzards, bald ibises, red-tailed hawks, and barn owls. Agriculture in Libya consists of wheat, barley, rye, corn, vegetables, melons, and sunflowers. Libya has the fourth largest oil reserves in Africa, and some of the world's largest natural gas fields.

Joseph Harold Allen (June 22, 1908 – September 29, 1993) was a United States Air Force major general, and commander of the 20th Air Force during the Vietnam War. Allen was born in Florence, Kentucky. He graduated from St. Xavier University and began his military career as a cadet in the Officers' Reserve Corps at Yale University. Allen spent most of the 1930s working in military intelligence, reaching the rank of colonel in the Air Corps. He attended the Air Corps Tactical School and was later assigned to the United States Army Air Forces intelligence service in the Pacific Ocean Area during World War II. After the war, Allen continued to serve in the military, becoming director of personnel for the Air Materiel Command. Promoted to brigadier general, he returned to Air Corps Tactical School in 1947 and 1948. In 1949, Allen was named commander of the 5022nd Support Group at Stewart Air Force Base. In this role, he was responsible for the air base and its support units. He was promoted to major general in 1950. Allen's next posting was with the Twentieth Air Force, headquartered at Turner Air Force Base, Mississippi. During this time, the air force adopted the policy of pushing aircraft through the various chains of command to meet strategic objectives. Allen was promoted to lieutenant general in 1952 and served as deputy commander of the Twentieth Air Force. Allen became commander of the 20th Air Force, with headquarters at Bien Hoa Air Base in South Vietnam, in 1953. The 20th Air Force was tasked with protecting the air superiority that was critical for U.S. air operations in the region. Allen held the position for three years, overseeing the air operations of Seventh Air Force. In 1956, Allen took command of the Air University at the Center for Air Force Instruction at Montgomery Army Airfield in Alabama. He spent the next thirteen years in this role, during which time he also helped to develop the United States Air Force Academy, as well as directing air University operations at Cannon Air Force Base in New Mexico and Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana. Allen also served as a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Defense Policy Board. Allen retired from the military in 1971. He had retired to Florence, Kentucky and died there at age 85.

History of Rockland County, New York (1798–1900) Rockland County was formed on March 4, 1798 from portions of Montgomery and St. Lawrence counties. It was originally located at the southern end of the New York frontier, and was intended to attract Germans to settle there and populate the entire county. The county has always had a rural character, being devoted to agriculture. Due in part to its rural character and the fertility of the soil, Rockland has been the home of many well-known corporations, including the confectionary company Harmon Mills and the tobacco company Yonkers Raceway. Rockland was the site of the Pequonnock River ferry, which became the first train station in New York on December 9, 1832. The village of Ramapo was founded on December 9, 1839, and soon became a major transportation and industrial center of northern Rockland County. Ramapo is still a center of industry today, particularly in the field of health services. Ramapo College was founded in 1855, and for many years was the only institution of higher education in Rockland County. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Rockland became a prime destination for many African-American travelers who came to northern New York to pursue the freedom afforded by its environs after the end of the Civil War. Though Rockland has had a small black population since its founding, the period from the late 19th century to the 1940s saw an influx of new residents from the south, and as a result Rockland today is home to the largest black community in the state, as well as a large West Indian population. In 1901, Rockland County became the first county in New York to pass an anti-lynching law, which made it a crime to incite or participate in lynchings. Rockland was also the first county in the United States to establish a children's court, which adjudicated cases involving children. Throughout the first half of the 20th century, Rockland was home to many artistic communities. Puppet theaters thrived in particular, with several nationally-known troupes making their home in the county. This phenomenon gained nationwide attention in 1947 when famed puppet theater Pell's Moving Picture Houses released the Oscar-winning animated short "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer". Through much of the 19th and 20th centuries, Rockland was home to a vibrant Jewish population, and is home to the largest population of any Jewish community in the United States without a fully- operating congregation in the Union for Reform Judaism's kosher certification system, although the modern day reform movement was founded in Rockland. On March 1, 1899, what was then the southern part of Rockland County was split off to form Orange County. Since that time, Rockland County has remained one of the poorest counties in New York, with large areas of the county having historically been devoted to agriculture. The county has largely remained rural and suburban in nature, with the largest suburban areas being located around Ramapo and New City. Ramapo is still the largest municipality by land area in the county.

Hippotes is an extinct genus of large primitive carnivorous therapsids, which lived in what is now Middle Asia (formerly Bashkortostan) during the Early Jurassic period. Hippotes was about the size of a rhinoceros and probably hunted large prey with rapid Charging moves similar to those of the modern cape elephant. It has been suggested that the evolution of large body size in carnivorous therapsids may have been rapid, due to the smaller amount of available prey in the early Jurassic. Advertisement for Star Wars: The Force Awakens, which takes place approximately 30 years after the events of Episode 4: A New Hope, reveals that "Jar Jar Binks" was an endangered species and that his kind was hunted by the Galactic Empire. Therefore, the time between Jar Jar Binks' creation and his appearance in The Force Awakens is 13 years, which is consistent with the estimated time between 2015 and 2023, the latter of which is the year in which The Force Awakens was released. Just like the primate genus Apathus, Hippotes was created as athrowaway character to explain a plot hole (the seemingly-inexplicable presence of a large and seemingly-obsolete species on a relatively backward planet). In fact, the name of the therapsid genus is a parody of the word Hippocrates, which means "healing doctor". Life on Hippotos Originally created by author Michael Crichton, Hippotes was based on the large, docile species Diceratherium, which at the time was the largest known rhino. It had large, tusk-like canines that it used to fight off lions and attack elephants. Disease and natural disaster killed off most of Hippotos' large, land-dwelling animals, and the remaining Hippotos' species began to resort to hunting smaller prey in the water and on land in order to survive. The loss of their large predators lead to Hippotos becoming an endangered species. So, Hippotes was actually a legitimate scientific name, and not a throwaway parody as many people seem to think. You can see where this is going. A large, docile, endangered prehistoric rhino with tusk-like canines would make for an excellent plush toy for the discerning child or (better yet) dog. You can purchase a plush Hippotes at the NASCAQ stock exchange (therapsid division). Pauline Vanier was a Canadian socialite, teacher, writer, stateswoman and Nobel Prize laureate. She became the first elected governor general of Canada in 1968, the first elected French-Canadian governor general, and the second anglophone governor general after Edward VIII of the United Kingdom. She was the first woman in the world appointed to this role, and the first French Canadian woman to hold a high office in Canada. Vanier led the Liberal Party of Canada—the same party that went on to form the modern Liberal Party of Canada—in the 1970 federal election but was defeated. Six years later, she became the oldest person to be elected to the House of Commons. She also became the first Canadian of français migrant origin to be elected to public office. He is known for combining low-key humor with relatable characters and realistic drama. chnology Riku Immonen is a Finnish comic book author and artist. His most famous works are Bucky oono, Blom, and Helmi loitsu. He is also the husband of Anna Maria Roppo and the father of three daughters. Riku Immonen was born in Rauma, Finland. He is the oldest of three children. His parents are separation and he has two younger brothers. Immonen started drawing at an early age. During his school years he mostly drew manga style images. He continued to develop his art skills by creating album covers for local punk bands. In 1994, Immonen moved to Helsinki to attend the Academy of Fine Arts. There he met his future wife, Anna Maria Roppo. The couple got married in 1999 and had three daughters, Helka, Vega, and Zara. During the early 2000s, Immonen contributed short comics to children's magazines. This was the first time that his works were published in a wider audience. In 2007, he created his first long running series, Bucky oono. The series follows the adventures of a disgraced superhero who disguises himself as a everyday park cleaner. Bucky oono was followed by Blom in 2011 and Helmi loitsu in 2016. Immonen has also drawn several stand alone short stories such as "Sulitusta" in 2009 and "Sydänhauruus" in 2014. In 2019, Immonen started a comic series about a father and his teenage daughter. The father is a low-key online troll who only reveals himself when someone gets seriously affected by one of his posts. The series is called Pasi and Maria and has received very positive reviews from critics.

Indirect DNA damage occurs when DNA is damaged by agents such as ionizing radiation, but the damage is not caused by the primary effect of the radiation but instead occurs because of an earlier reaction(s) between the radiation and another molecule(s). As an example, the secondary damaging effects of water radiolysis contribute significantly to the biological effects of ionizing radiation. sound like Indirect DNA damage occurs when DNA is damaged by agents such as ionizing radiation, but the damage is not caused by the primary effect of the radiation but instead occurs because of an earlier reaction(s) between the radiation and another molecule(s). As an example, the secondary damaging effects of water radiolysis contribute significantly to the biological effects of ionizing radiation. xref DNA damage, water radiolysis, indirect DNA damage Awareness and prevention are important, because indirect DNA damage can arise from many kinds of exposure and can promote evolution of dangerous mutations. INCLUDE COMMUNITIES IN THINKING ABOUT CROSS-GENERAL HEALTH CONSEQUENCES OF ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE Indirect DNA damage arises from a range of environmental exposures including ionizing radiation, radioprotectors, air pollution and metals. gorge community involvement in research, prevention and protection against the harmful effects of environmental exposure. Research suggests that exposure to a wide range of environmental agents can result in indirect DNA damage, for example, ionizing radiation causes primary DNA damage, but its secondary effects, such as water radiolysis, can also generate a range of DNA lesions, which contribute significantly to the biological effects of ionizing radiation. Other environmental agents that can cause indirect DNA damage include oxidants, which are found in air pollution and chemical pollutants such as metals.

Haplocochlias bellus, also known as the zig-zag octopus or dwarf octopus, is a small deep-sea octopus species in the family Octopodidae. It was the first animal species to be discovered by the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) via remotely operated submersible, the Deep-Submergence Vehicle (DSV) ALV-3. The H. bellus dive range is 2,300 meters (7,200 feet) and their typical temperature range is 29.5 °C to 15.5 °C (85 °F to 60 °F). The octopus' habitat is widely considered to be one of the deepest-living habitats on the planet. H. bellus are unique among octopuses in a number of ways. For one, H. bellus is the only octopus species with chromatophores only in the skin, not inside the body. Second, although H. bellus is a large-sized octopus, it has thin arms, and the total weight of an adult H. bellus is less than 1% of its body weight. Third, the H. bellus has an unusual lifestyle: it not only sits motionless on the seafloor with eyes pointed down, but it can also change its skin pattern to match the surrounding seafloor. Lastly, the H. bellus can survive out of water for more than six hours. The H. bellus is named after the bell-shaped blotch in the middle of its skin, which is unique in cephalopods. The H. bellus has been studied in greater detail than any other species in the genus Haploctopus. The H. bellus is the first animal species to be discovered by MBARI via the DSV ALV-3, which was named after the Viking god of thunder and wisdom, located in the eastern Pacific Ocean off the coast of California at a depth of 2,300 meters. The H. bellus was also the subject of the documentary film Deep Water: Inside the H. Bellus Discoveries, which premiered at the 2019 Toronto International Film Festival.

The authors describe a case of a 22-year-old woman who experienced a complex partial seizure and a mood disorder during treatment with fluoxetine. The patient had normal EEGs before beginning treatment with fluoxetine. The complex partial seizure disappeared within 24 h of discontinuing fluoxetine. The mood disorder was considered to be a hypomanic episode since it responded to treatment with a mood stabilizer. Formosa Peak (Chinese: 台島岡; pinyin: Tái Dǐng Góng), originally named Mount Ching after Chiang Kai-shek, is a mountain in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan. The peak overlooks the eastern end of Gulf of Tonkin and is surrounded by Yanchung County to the north, Beitou to the northeast, the Green Island of Lienchiang to the east and the Pingtung County to the southeast. The Formosa Plover nested on the mountain and the peak was renamed after the bird. The mountain is part of Trail 17 in the Taiwan Trail. Trail 17 in the Taiwan Trail is a 2,495-km (1,533-mile) hiking trail from east to west across Taiwan starting and ending in Taipei. The entire trail was awarded Asia's finest long-distance trail in 2008 and forms part of the larger "Pan-Asia" long-distance trail. Formosa Peak was the highest point on the original version of the trail, and was the highest point until 2009 when Luojing County Hill was completed. The actual height is higher than the "Formosa Peak" by approximately 30m (98ft). The peak is also the highest point in Taiwan, and the third highest peak in the Taipei City limits (after Taipei 101 and Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall). It can be seen from many parts of Taipei, and its southeastern slope can be seen from Nangang Beach. The mountain is the namesake of the Formosa Plover, an Asian species of bird. The peak is also home to many animals, such as Sunda flyingfox, which is endangered, and Formosan hawk mouse. Due to its proximity to major cities, the mountain is often the subject of photoshoots and television broadcasts. It is also a popular location for school outings. The mountain is accessible by trail, starting from Yilan Trail Master Yiliang Lu's residence. The trail begins by heading southeast from the peak's southeastern slope and traversing across Chunghu Post, a lighthouse in Beitou, and down into Yanchung County. The entire distance of the trail is 2,495km. The trail is divided into 17 stages with the last stage starting from Chiayi County and ending in Taichung. The peak is ringed by a trail which allows for a somewhat easy ascent without special equipment. The mountain's weather conditions can be unpredictable, and, at an elevation of 1,767m, there are often storms. There is an elementary school on the peak which has been in operation since the 1970s. The campus is open to public viewing and the buildings on campus are also available for short term rental. In January 2017, an online voting program was introduced by the FormosaPeak.com website to solicit suggestions for new names for the mountain. On February 22, 2017, the Formosa Plover was chosen as the winning name by the "million" vote, narrowly beating out two other finalists, Liaohtsa Spire and Yalu Cliff. Starting on March 10, 2017, the Formosa Plover name was implemented with the unveiling of the "New Formosa Plover Long-distance hiking course". A stage of the trail passes by the peak, with the first stage beginning in Yilan County and ending in Beitou. Trail 17 in the Taiwan Trail was officially launched on May 20, 2017, on the southern slope of Formosa Peak. The peak is located within Formosa Plover Nature Reserve, established in 1983. The peak and the surrounding areas have been designated as a Habitat Conservation Area. The peak is also the site of a radio communications tower for many forms of public service in Taiwan. As the trail passes by the peak, there are many vantage points from which the peak and surrounding areas may be viewed. There are also multiple viewpoints on the trail itself. The peak is located between Yilan City and Beitou. To access the peak, take Provincial Highway 9 to Yilan County, then take National Highway 9 to Beitou. Peter Pascoe is a fictional character created by British author Antonia Lloyd-Jones. He is a private detective and occasional police officer, operating in the late Victorian era in Birmingham, England. His girlfriend, Mary Anne Crawford, serves as his assistant. Pascoe is an astute interpreter of social cues and an excellent amateur pianist. He often uses his skills as a private investigator to help his friends or girlfriend. In 2015, a TV series featuring Pascoe as the lead character was announced, with Lloyd-Jones serving as an advisor. The first series was released on Amazon Video and UK streaming service Now TV in December 2018. also see : Peter Pascoe (TV series) Range of topics covered by Pascoe include detection, love, religion, and social issues. His long-term friend and colleague, Chief Inspector Tom Thorne, is often the practical helper on difficult cases. Goofs and anachronisms are frequently present in the series. For example, in the pilot episode, Pascoe rides a bicycle while most of his colleagues use a motor vehicle. Also, he eats steak and chips for lunch, while most of the characters in the series have burgers or other fast food. Despite these goofs, the series has been well received by critics, particularly for its performance values, costuming and setting. edy Peter Pascoe (TV series) Peter Pascoe is a TV series announced in 2015 and released on December 18, 2018 on Amazon Video and UK streaming service Now TV. Lloyd-Jones served as an advisor. The first series was released on Amazon Video and UK streaming service Now TV in December 2018. Also see : Peter Pascoe Peter Pascoe is a private detective and occasional police officer, operating in the late Victorian era in Birmingham, England. His girlfriend, Mary Anne Crawford, serves as his assistant. Pascoe is an astute interpreter of social cues and an excellent amateur pianist. He often uses his skills as a private investigator to help his friends or girlfriend. In 2015, a TV series featuring Pascoe as the lead character was announced. Lloyd-Jones served as an advisor. The first series was released on Amazon Video and UK streaming service Now TV in December 2018.

166 Rhodope is a semiautomatic pistol produced in the Czech Republic and based on the Karabini pistol design. It is chambered for the 9×19mm Parabellum Luger pistol cartridge and has a 17-round box magazine. The Rhodope is made in three versions, all of which have the same basic design, but differ in the choice of finishes and equipment. The Rhodope I and Rhodope II are similar in appearance, differing primarily in the choice of wood for the wooden stocks and the Rhodope II having a magazine disconnect. The Rhodope III is less ornately constructed, with a polyamide stock and a laser sight. All three models have a manual safety, a decocker mechanism, and a single slide locked back, double-action only mode of operation. The Rhodope was offered with a white wooden or black polyamide stock, with a red, black or green palm rest, and with a bright or dark silver finishing. The Rhodope was introduced in 2017 and was originally available only to qualified Czech police and security forces, but it was made available to non-police customers in March 2019. As of April 2019, 7,500 such pistols had been sold, at a price of 12,000 Czech korunas (about €675). While the basic design of the Rhodope is that of the Karabini, it differs in some details from that pistol. Most notably, it is wider, shorter and heavier, while having a larger grip and an extended safety catch. While the barrel of the Rhodope is chrome-lined like that of most Luger variants, it has a standard length of 8.8 cm, as opposed to the 10.2 cm used by most Luger variants. The Rhodope also has a modified operating system, using a single hand-detachable magazine rather than a double-stacked magazine. This magazine is narrower, shorter and thicker than that of most handguns, making it incompatible with most double-stack magazines. The rear sight is a fixed blade, while the Rhodope has an adjustable rear sight, and the frame is slightly modified to accept different ring sizes for the Luger barrel. The Rhodope was awarded the "Best Czech Pistol of the Year" award in 2019, and the Rhodope I with black stock and green laser was also awarded "Best Pistol of the Year" at the 2019 Czech Army handgun competition. In March 2020, Blokexport, the state-owned Czech manufacturer of arms and military equipment, ceased production of the Rhodope. Blokexport had not been paid by Rhodia, the French company that had purchased the Czech license to produce the pistol, for some time, and was in debt for the direct costs of production. Blokexport is seeking to sell the equipment and molds used to produce the Rhodope. The Czech police have announced that they will no longer be using the Rhodope, and that they are searching for a new supplier. The search for a new supplier was successful by April 2020, and the Czech Police started to use the new pistols for patrolling. Due to the risk of unavailability of the license holders, the Rhodope is not listed in the important international gun calibers and magazines. The most recent model of the Rhodope, the Rhodope II, has gained some popularity because of its distinguishing features: a magazine disconnect and a decocker mechanism. All three Rhodope models are now manufactured by a new company in the Czech Republic, based in Karlovy Vary. The Rhodope is covered by a Czech 4-year warranty. While the basic design of the Rhodope is that of the Karabini, it differs in some details from that pistol. Most notably, it is wider, shorter and heavier, while having a larger grip and an extended safety catch. Vaumeilh is a commune in the Saône-et-Loire department in the region of Bourgogne in eastern France. Vaumeilh was the site of a decisive battle of the French Revolutionary Wars in 1814, later given its name to the commanders fighting there, including Achille Bazire and Charles-Simon Merle. See also Communes of the Saône-et-Loire department References INSEE Category:Communes of Saône-et-Loire<|endoftext|>Karl Roser Karl Roser (20 August 1851 – 30 May 1904) was a German dermatologist born in Hamburg. He studied medicine in Vienna, Würzburg and Heidelberg, receiving his habilitation in 1884 from the University of Würzburg. Following an appointment as an assistant at the university hospital in Würzburg, he became an associate professor of dermatology at the University of Erlangen (1890) and then its full professor of dermatology and syphilology at the University of Vienna (1893). He was one of the founders of the "Österreichische Ärzte" (Austrian Doctors) association, and in 1895 was appointed president of the Vienna Gesellschaft für Hygiene und Völkerkunde (Society for Hygiene and International Studies). In 1894 he was appointed a professor at the University of Berlin, where in 1896 he was asked to become the university's rector. In 1903 he was elected a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. He was an advocate of the vitalist theory of Rudolf Virchow and of spontaneous generation. In 1897 he conducted research in the Congo, but the result of his studies on snakes were later refuted. Principal works Handbuch der Vitalpathologie, 1882 – Textbook of vital pathology. Beiträge zur Kenntnis der Haut- und Schleimhautkrankheiten, 1885 – Contributions to the knowledge of skin and hair disease. Lehrbuch der allgemeinenpathologischen Medizin für Studirende, 1898 – Textbook of general pathological-pathological medicine for students. Beiträge zur Kenntnis der Reißformen in der Haut, 1903 – Contributions to the knowledge of skin folds. By Anurag Bhardwaj IANS Sanjay Shukla works as a polio worker in Indore, India. He and his team administer polio drops to children to protect them from a crippling disease. There are about 125,000 children under five in Indore. Shukla and his colleagues have to administer about 5,000 doses of polio drops each day. Every day, they administer about 125,000 doses of polio drops. They have to do this for about 18 months. They earn about 80,000 Indian rupees per month (about US$1,360). That is less than 1,000 Indian rupees per day. Shukla is paid hazard pay for working with a hazardous substance, which is called polio vaccine. Every year, about 0.3 percent of people who receive the polio drops develop a fever and have a mild to serious reaction to the vaccine. The injection-related injuries reported globally from 2010 to 2015 involved a total of 6,551 muscle injuries, 160 neural injuries, 29 tendon injuries, five artery injuries and 34 cases of cardiac injury. These injuries led to two deaths. "It is hazardous work, but if I do not do this work, there will be at least one more child who will suffer from polio and will not be able to walk," says Shukla. Shukla and his colleagues have to inject the vaccine into the children's arms. The children could use their hands to try and protect themselves while the polio workers were giving them the vaccine. Sometimes, children will put their hands over their mouths, and the polio workers have to remove the hands before giving the vaccine. Injecting a child with polio vaccine is a challenging task. The polio workers have to inject the vaccine into the child's arm while protecting the child from infections that can cause abscesses

Paul Nietsche (born Paulus Johannes Hermann Nietsche; March 24, 1876 – August 14, 1964) was a German conductor. He was the founder of the Berlin Philharmonic orchestra and a member of the Nazi Party. In 1934 he became president of the Reichsmusikkammer (chaired under a 1934 amendment to the Reich Broadcasting Law). In 1943 he was appointed generalMusic Director of the Berlin Philharmonic, a post he held until 1945. Allied forces captured Nietsche in May 1945, and he was tried at the Soviet Union/Russian Federation Nuremberg Trials and, in October 1946, sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment for "crimes against humanity". After World War II he was allowed to live in anonymity in Bad Godesberg. His company went bankrupt in 1953. again Paul Nietsche (March 24, 1876 – August 14, 1964) was a German conductor. He founded the Berlin Philharmonic orchestra and was a member of the Nazi Party. In 1934 he became president of the Reichsmusikkammer (chaired under a 1934 amendment to the Reich Broadcasting Law). In 1943 he was appointed generalMusic Director of the Berlin Philharmonic, a post he held until 1945. After World War II he was allowed to live in anonymity in Bad Godesberg. His company went bankrupt in 1953.

Coffins on Io - Io is the largest and most geologically active moon of Jupiter. In many regards it could be considered a small planet in its own right, due to its similar size and gravitational forces to our own world. Despite this, Io has only been permanently mapped since 1979, due to its challenging environment. Io is composed of a silicate mantle and a volcanic surface, with a global iron core. Io's fast rotation means that all of the crust is younger than 100 million years. Volcanically, Io is wholly smooth except for a few polar volcanic calderas, plus thousands of smaller shield volcanoes and dome-shaped mountains. Due to its geological activity, Io has a dynamic rotational axis. This rotational axis is not fixed in space, but is continuously shifting. This causes Io's surface to vary in orientation from extremely deformed in places (such as the volcano 'Acidalia Planitia'), to nearly featureless in others (such as the equally volcanic region of Pallene). Io's surface is barren, but water oceans sit just beneath the surface in many places. These water oceans are key to Io's current geology, as the continual vaporization of ice creates a measurable torque, changing Io's orientation in its orbit around Jupiter. Io is known to haveHadley-Jupiters, twin moons that are each similar in mass to Earth's Moon. Io is the only body in the solar system known to have Hadley-Jupiter system.

Fai Amata (born 1963) is an Indonesian singer. She was born in Bali and is famous for her signature song "Bocah Bali". She had nine siblings and has been married five times. dub<|endoftext|>Q: Way to access request in Middleware in Django i would like to get the request object inside a Middleware in Django. I try to get the user that is logged in in this Middleware but i always get AnonymousUser. Here is my code : from django.contrib.auth.mixins import LoginRequiredMixin from django.utils.deprecation import MiddlewareMixin from django.http import HttpResponse from.forms import UserForm class MyAuthMiddleware(LoginRequiredMixin, MiddlewareMixin, object): def process_request(self, request): if request.user.is_authenticated(): print("Not anonymous : ", request.user) else: print("Anonymous") I also try to get the request in the view, it works. But in my middleware it doesn't work. Here is my view : def a_view(request): request.user Thank you for your help. A: Middleware is run before views, so request is not yet available in your middleware. However, you could use an Observer to register a callback with the request whenever it is created. from django.contrib.auth.mixins import LoginRequiredMixin, Observer from django.contrib.auth.models import User from django.utils.deprecation import MiddlewareMixin from django.http import HttpResponse from django.utils.functional import lazy class MyAuthMiddleware(LoginRequiredMixin, MiddlewareMixin, Observer): def __init__(self): self.request_seen = False self.request = lazy.WeakResource() self.request.user = None def process_request(self, request): if not self.request_seen: self.request_seen = True self.request = request if request.user.is_authenticated(): print("Not anonymous : ", request.user) else: print("Anonymous") def get_request(self): """ Returns the `request` passed to the `process_request()` method. """ return self.request request =property(fget=get_request) You can then use this in a view like this: def a_view(request): print(request.my_auth_middleware.get_request()) A: You can also try below approach. It's based on @Rahul Gupta's answer but uses "context" directly from the request instead of request.request. from django.contrib.auth.mixins import LoginRequiredMixin, Observer from django.contrib.auth.models import User from django.utils.deprecation import MiddlewareMixin from django.http import HttpResponse from django.utils.functional import lazy class MyAuthMiddleware(LoginRequiredMixin, MiddlewareMixin, Observer): def __init__(self, request): self.request = request self.user = None def process_request(self, request): if not self.request.user.is_authenticated(): print("Not anonymous : ", self.request.user) self.user = request.user else: print("Anonymous") request =property(fget=get_request) def get_request(self): return self.request user =property(fget=get_user) You can use it like: def a_view(request): print(request.my_auth_middleware.user) <|endoftext|># -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright (c) 2019 Satpy Developers # All rights reserved. # # Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without # modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions are met: # # * Redistributions of source code must retain the above copyright notice, # this list of conditions and the following disclaimer. # # * Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above copyright notice, # this list of conditions and the following disclaimer in the documentation # and/or other materials provided with the distribution. # # * Neither the name

Koi Child is a 2018 Indian Malayalam-language documentary film directed by Shyamaprasad and produced by Fox International. It is an attempt to explore the life of children in prisons and their families, following a juvenile in the Pune prison. The film was released on Netflix on November 29, 2018. The film was screened at the International Film Festival of Kerala, selected for the Indian Night section at the 39th Dallas international film festival and was released on Netflix on November 29, 2018. It was also selected for the India's Voice section at the 37th San Francisco international film festival. The documentary is co-directed and co-produced by Riju Jacob, an Indian film editor known for his work in the Narcos and the Last King of Scotland films. The film features several real-life prisoners who narrated their own experiences. The film was shot in various parts of Maharashtra, mainly Pune, highlighting the juvenile Yusuf Khan, an Alibaug boy who was framed for a murder he did not commit and was sentenced to life imprisonment. The film shows Yusuf's attempts to fight for his innocence and appeals for a presidential pardon, highlighting the impact of juvenile prisons in India. According to a report by NGOPrablible, a total of 4,746 children are currently in prisons in India, most of them are undertrials. The case of Yusuf Khan was noted by activist Dnyaneshwar Azhawan, who started a signature campaign on Change.org to urge the Indian president to pardon Yusuf. Through this campaign, the prison administration got aware of Yusuf's case. On March 29, 2023, the Indian president Pinarayi Vijayan granted a presidential pardon to Yusuf. The documentary has been praised for its directness in highlighting a social issue, its sensitivity in showing the personal tragedies of the prisoners and their family members, and its hope-inspiring elements. Critic Ashwin Raj gave it 4.5 stars out of 5, stating that "Koi Child might just make you think and do a little more to improve the condition of children in prison across India." In September 2022, Fox Networks released the film in various countries such as Spain, Australia, and Finland. The film was released on Netflix on November 29, 2018.

Madness Under the Royal Palms is a beachfront mansion in Palm Beach, Florida, that was the winter home of U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and his wife, Eleanor, from 1939 until his death in 1945. During this period, the estate was swarmed by famous people, many of whom were captured on film by photographic studio setting up camp on the lawn. In addition to the Roosevelts, the site was visited by Churchill, FDR's successor as president, as well as numerous other heads of state and their families, as well as political figures and celebrities. The property was purchased in 1939 for $825,000, the highest price ever paid at the time for any property in Palm Beach. With its 6 bedrooms and 14 bathrooms, the mansion was significantly more spacious than the official Presidental Residence at the time, the Florida White House, located across the street. Due to its proximity to the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, the property was popular for hosting large scale yachting events. In 1940, a 150-foot long, 20 foot wide section of the docks belonging to the estate was torn down to make room for one of FDR's yachts, the USS Indianapolis, which was visiting the estate at the time. Roosevelt frequently entertained with large parties, often including an open bar, and a pièce de resistance was the annual New Year's Eve party which included a live band and dancing on the lawn to the sounds of Count Basie and his orchestra. The accommodations for such large numbers of guests required extensive planning, which was the domain of butler James 'Jimmy' Florian, whom the Roosevelts trusted with their personal business as well as the running of the estate. During World War II, the estate was the site of extensive secret government work, including a crash mapping and photo reconnaissance project carried out by P-39 Airacobra fighters of the 27th Pursuit Squadron between July and September 1943. As a result of the work done at the estate, the U.S. Army Air Corps selected Palm Beach County as the location for the permanent headquarters of the XXII Bomber Command, later changed to the 345th Bomb Group and 93d Bomb Squadron. After Roosevelt's death in 1945, the estate was inherited by his daughter, Anna Roosevelt González, who sold it in 1948 for $1.15 million, about one third its original cost. The home remained a private residence until 2009, when it was listed for sale for $100 million. After two years of negotiations, Dimitrios H. Panos and his partner Perry Distler purchased the estate for $29.95 million in 2012. After extensive renovations, the estate was opened to the public as a tourist destination in 2015.

Alesso di Benozzo (sometimes Alessandro di Benozzo) is an Italian Renaissance painter active in the Paduan school. He was active between 1488 and 1532. He was born in Padua and died in that city. Some of his works were painted in Venice. He was influenced by the Venetian painter Gentile Bellini. He is considered the follower of Giorgione. Alesso painted numerous frescoes in churches in Padua, such as the San Procolo and the Chiostro dello Studito in that city. He is documented in London, Madrid, Turin and Paris. Today, Alesso di Benozzo is represented in the Pinacoteca Fabriciano in Padua and in the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh. Alesso was the son of Benedetto Alessi and Antonia di Benozzo. His father was a soldier. At age 13, Alesso began training as a notary's clerk. He became a follower of Giorgione, whose work he discovered in Venice. Giorgione influenced his style. His brother Antonio was also a painter. Alesso trained with Gentile Bellini. He died in Padua at age 71. Today, Alesso di Benozzo is best known for his paintings of Venice, including the now-lost paintings for the Pala d'Oro and the Gentileschi painting La présence certifiee.

Euseby Cleaver is a character in the novel Wyrldmaker by Philip Nutman. Euseby is a genetically engineered child created in a laboratory to be a perfect mate for her father, the Duke of Wallenstein. The procedure ends up going wrong and Euseby is born with pigmentation and an odd number of limbs. Wallenstein is disturbed by his daughter's appearance, but thinks she is merely ugly and bears her amputated limbs as proof of this. He takes her to meet the idealistic prince-regent of a future kingdom, who believes that the perfect mate for his kingdom will be one he can never imagine, and bids Euseby goodbye forever. Philip Nutman's book Wyrldmaker is part of a larger story called The Elysium Accords which follows a race of genetically engineered children called "Wyrds" who are created in laboratories across the galaxy to be perfect mates for their fathers. The procedure ends up going wrong in many cases and Wyrldmaker is the story of one such error, with Euseby Cleaver being one of the kids created in this mistake. Euseby has been widely praised for her starring role in the first genetically engineered babies comedy novel, with The Daily Dot noting that she is "the strongest Wyrldmaker character", Ladypain has described her as the "strongest female character in Sci-Fi", and the London Loveshop called her "the strongest Wyrldmaker character". The Awl called her "the strongest female character in Sci-Fi for 2015" and Vulture called her "the most important Wyrldmaker character". In 2020 she was selected as one of the "top 100 science fiction and fantasy characters" by Locus magazine. Nutman has written a sequel to Wyrldmaker called Love's Magus, in which Euseby Cleaver is the main character. Euseby Cleaver was created by Philip Nutman in 2015. The Epic of American Civilization is a 23-volume historical novel written between 1854 and 1887 by Welsh American historian and poet James Bradley. The work chronicles the formative events of American history from the perspective of an American farmer, described by scholars as tending "towardde Sweaptessman depiction of an evil, exploitativeEuropean colonizer." The series was highly praised upon its release but has subsequently been criticized for promoting an "American Exceptionalism" viewpoint. Bradley worked on the first volume, which covers the period from the landing of the English colonists in America to the American Revolution, from 1854 to 1857. Volume two, covering the period from the American Revolution to the Founding of the United States, was finished by his son, also named James Bradley, from 1887 to 1893. The remaining 17 volumes were completed by other scholars after Bradley's death in 1899. The final volume, covering the period from the Founding of the United States to 1854, was published in 2007. Since Bradley's death, scholars have cast doubt on his historiographical objectivity and have questioned whether he intended to provide an impartial account of American history, instead drawing from the biases of his time and presenting a portrait of the United States as a proto-racist nation. The Epic has been cited as an influence on the creation of the US Department of Education's National History Standards. The series has been described by historians as tending "towardde Sweaptessman depiction of an evil, exploitativeEuropean colonizer." The depiction of the Native American population as "noble" and "worthy of respect" but "inferior" in terms of warfare to the English colonists has been criticized as reflecting the thinking of the time. Scholars also criticize the presentation of the Founding Fathers as "aristocratic and not fully engaged in the struggle for American independence". Bradley portrays George Washington as an aristocrat fighting against an elected democracy. Bradley worked on the first volume, which covers the period from the landing of the English colonists in America to the American Revolution, from 1854 to 1857. The remaining 17 volumes were completed by other scholars after Bradley's death in 1899. The final volume, covering the period from the Founding of the United States to 1854, was published in 2007. The Epic has been cited as an influence on the creation of the US Department of Education's National History Standards.

The Cemetery of Confucius is a necropolis in the Linxia County in the Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture of the Chinese province of Qinghai. Founded in the 17th century, the cemetery is located on the slope of a mountain and was designed by the Artux Kingdom of Mongolia. Covering an area of 2.5 square kilometers, it is the biggest ancient cemetery of the New World. It contains thousands of tombs of the also Mongol-Chinese Artux royalty and is considered a magnificent example of classical architecture and landscaping. By the end of the 20th century, the cemetery was in a very bad state of preservation. A project to conserve it, carried out by an Italian team from the University of Bologna, was supported by the city of Beijing and was officially launched in 2007. Restoration works were conducted between 2008 and 2017 and, as of 2021, the cemetery is again open to visitors. The Cemetery of Confucius is located about 90 km south of the provincial capital Xining. It is accessible by road and regular minibuses run from Xining. In 2017, the Cemetery of Confucius was added to the World Heritage List under the name "Cemeteries of the Artux Kings". Due to the importance of the Artux Kingdom in the history of Central Asia, it was featured in Netflix's 2019 documentary series Vikings, called "Vikings in China". For more information, see the article "Cemeteries of the Artux Kings" in the Wikipedia online encyclopedia.

Operation Claw was a strategic bombing campaign by the British Empire against Nazi Germany and its allies in response to the invasion of Poland in 1939. The campaign, conducted from April to October 1940, was an attempt to destroy German military power and weaken Hitler's prospects for victory in the European conflict. It formed part of the larger, multi-faceted Blitz on German cities during the Second World War. The British military successfully conducted long-range precision bombing and gained air superiority over the Dutch and French territories, but failed to achieve their strategic objectives of demoralizing the Germans and disrupting their ability to fight World War II. The campaign resulted in the loss of 100 bombers, including 74 from the Royal Air Force (RAF), in little damage to German industry and infrastructure. A charred tree in the Netherlands is the only material trace of the Blitz on German soil. tried Operation Claw was a strategic bombing campaign by the British Empire against Nazi Germany and its allies in response to the invasion of Poland in 1939. St Petrock's Church, Timberscombe is a church in the village of Timberscombe, near St Austell, Cornwall, England. It is recorded in the National Heritage List for England as a designated Grade I listed building. The church was built in the 15th century, with alterations and additions in the 16th and 19th centuries. The church is noted for itsDun impost with Jacobean additions, a rare example of medieval architecture in Cornwall. Kue cubit is an Ancient Egyptian unit of length, equal to the length of a forearm. It is named after a late period Egyptian priest and minister of scribes, KhuBit. Modeled after the cubit in the Bible, the Kue cubit was the distance between the elbow and the tip of the middle finger. It was originally defined as the length of a forearm from the elbow to the tips of the middle fingers. Chippenham Lodge is a country house near Chippenham, Wiltshire, England. It was designed in 1722 for Sir John Stradwick and John Cope, members of an ancient family from Calne in Wiltshire. It stands in an elevated and pretty situation overlooking parkland featuring Hawkswood House. The house was substantially enlarged and remodeled for George Montagu-Dunk, 1st Earl of Halifax in the 18th century. He in turn leased it to the Prevost family from 1784 until 1890. Major modifications and additions were made in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It is a Grade II* listed building. The current tenant is William Hare, 13th Lord Strange. Chippenham Lodge was the birthplace of Francis Place, the Chartist, and a keen radical, who was born there on 26 December 1757. Chippenham Lodge was sold by the 13th Lord Strange in 1945. The new owner was Thomas Clark, an organ manufacturer, who undertook a complete rebuilding of the lodge. The rebuilding incorporated various features from the earlier 19th century works, including an oriel window in the north front. Chippenham Lodge is now a hotel, managed by Nick and Judy Baker. The lodge is located in a private grounds and can be visited by prior appointment only. Chippenham Lodge is situated near the village of Brington, which has a pub called The Bell.

Richard DeLong (born 1942) is a computer scientist known for his work on languages that parallel everyday human languages, such as English. DeLong began his academic career as an electrical engineer at the University of California, Berkeley, where he helped to create the FIRST circuit design competition in high school. DeLong received his BA in mathematics and physics from Harvard University in 1964, and his PhD in linguistics from Stanford University in 1968 under the supervision of Noam Chomsky. After graduation, DeLong did his post-doctoral work with Kenneth Walbird at the University of California, Santa Barbara. In 1971, DeLong became an assistant professor at the University of Minnesota, where he remained for 12 years. In 1983, DeLong returned to the University of California, Berkeley, where he is now a professor of computer science and a member of the Molecular Computer Science and Engineering and Language Production teams. DeLong was elected a fellow of the Association for Computational Linguistics in 1986 and of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1990. His 1989 book, The Minimalist Program, has been called "one of the most influential papers in the history of NLP". In 1991, DeLong and Peter Sellis published the first joint paper on what would later become called dependency parsing, an approach to analyzing a sentence that computes its syntactic structure. DeLong and Thad Starner published the first successful Synthetic Digitally Generated Intelligible Speech (SDGIS) system in 1993. DeLong was a pioneer in the development of neural networks, beginning with the development of backpropagation inANN in the early 1980s. His 1990 book, Learning with errors: A theoretical analysis of backpropagation was cited by Gradient-Based Training of Neural Netwoks in 1993. DeLong is currently active in the fields of Artificial Life and Evolutionary Computation, where he is a coauthor of several books and a consultant. DeLong is currently an emeritus professor at UC Berkeley and a professor at the University of Minnesota.

Eytan Stibbe (Hebrew: ayton Stephan) (born 1953) is an Israeli historian of Jewish mysticism and co-director of the Shazar Institute in Jerusalem. Stibbe has published a number of books on the history of the Jewish mystic movement, its origins, doctrines and famous disciples and has written articles for many academic journals. His book, Eliyahu and Isaac: ancient metaphysics and the origins of Judaism's godly sacrifice, has been described by critics as "provid[ing] the first serious challenge to the conventional view that the origins of Judaism's God worship can be dated back to the eighth century BCE." In a review of Stibbe's book, The Mystical God, the theologian Jonathan Klawans wrote: "Written in a clear and elegant style, the book gracefully handles the thorny issues of late antique Judaism, including the significance of the Temple to early Christianity, the development of the Philo-Semitism controversy and the origins of Jesus and his predecessors. It will be of great interest not only to those familiar with the history of Judaism and early Christianity, but also to scholars of medieval Jewish mysticism and mysticism in the modern period." Stibbe's other works on mysticism include Meditations with Asketene (2010), which has been described as "a landmark in the exploration of Jewish gnosis during the early medieval period" and his 2014 co-authored book, The Secret Torah: reading the book of Psalms through the eyes of the mystics, which was described by Hadar Hurvitz as "a landmark in bringing into focus the tradition of interpreting the Book of Psalms through a mystical lens" His book, Eliyahu and Isaac: ancient metaphysics and the origins of Judaism's godly sacrifice, has been described by critics as "provid[ing] the first serious challenge to the conventional view that the origins of Judaism's God worship can be dated back to the eighth century BCE." It will be of great interest not only to those familiar with the history of Judaism and early Christianity, but also to scholars of medieval Jewish mysticism and mysticism in the modern period." The Larklight Trilogy is a series of fantasy novels written by Jillian Tamaki, first published in 2014 by Balzer+Bray, an imprint of HarperCollins. The series includes Larklight, Herald Light, and Daylight. The books follow siblings Bonyata, Elly, and Klothos, who are separated when Klothos is babies and must navigate through magical doors into the Larks and Sparks realms, each with different dangers and powers. adopted from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larklight_trilogy screenplay format The Larklight Trilogy is a series of fantasy novels written by Jillian Tamaki, first published in 2014 by Balzer+Bray, an imprint of HarperCollins. HERALD LIGHT Fourteen-year-old Nina lives with her father, Bannion, in the besieged city of London, which is under siege from mysterious creatures. Nina discovers that she has magical powers, and uses them to help Bannion fight the creatures. After the city is saved, Nina is fascinated by the magical doors that have opened in the city. One of the doors takes her to the spire of a cathedral where she meets Priest Devon, who informs her that the city is protected by the Larks, magical creatures from a parallel universe, and that Nina possesses Larklight, a rare and powerful ability that enables her to interact with the Larks.

The City of Nedlands is a statutory local government area in Western Australia, located roughly east of the state's capital, Perth. The city was named and first incorporated in 1908. Nedlands, meaning "to the North") was named after a pastoral property owned by the Pettus family, which also gave its name to Ned Pettus, a Western Australian pioneer. Nedlands is currently home to just over 30,000 residents. Nedlands shares borders with the city of Nedland to the south, as well as the Shire of Menzies to the east and west. The western border is formed by the Hamersley Range, with AvonLINK Industrial Area to the north. Several highways and arterial roads pass through Nedlands, including Rokeby Road, Galava Street, Ellis Street, Butler Road and High Street. The Lord Dudley Hospital and Fiona Stanley Hospital are also situated in Nedlands. Nedlands railway station is served by Transperth local bus routes, and also plays a major role in regional and long-distance train services, including the Spirit of the West and Indian Pacific. Nedlands is classified as a middle-income area according to the federal government's 290 category, and is also noted for its affordability in comparison to neighbouring suburbs such as Nedlands Primary School, which is considered to be one of the most expensive primary schools in Australia. The local member of the Western Australian Legislative Council is BridgetmLceyman, a member of the Liberal Party of Australia. The current president of the Council is Caleb Mc close. The mayor of Nedlands is Cr. Allen Christensen, who is a member of the Labor Party. The Council meets at the Civic Centre on Ellis Street, Nedlands.

The 2008 riot in Mongolia began on the night of January 2, 2008, when a large crowd of Bayanzurkh residents attacked a police station. The riot quickly spread to nearby towns and cities, and by the next day, at least 17 shops and two apartment blocks had been destroyed, and more than 50 people had been arrested. The cause of the rioting is unknown, though a report in the Chinese-language daily newspaper Bayan under the headline "Robbers attack cars, cause chaos" blamed the unrest on "car thefts and robberies". The riots followed a pattern typical of riots in Mongolia – mob violence and property damage quickly escalated out of control, and police attempts to subdue the crowd with tear gas and water cannons merely served to inflame the situation. The riots continued for four consecutive days, by which time at least 500 people had been injured and about 60 businesses, including those in Bayanzurkh, had been destroyed. After the riots, the parliament criticized the police for being ineffective and using excessive force, and promised to investigate the causes of the unrest. At least three people were killed, and damage to property and infrastructure was estimated to be in the range of 200–250 million USD. At least 17 people were arrested, five of whom were charged with murder, and a further investigation was announced into the causes of the unrest. The 2008 riot in Mongolia was the first major public outbreak of civil unrest in Mongolia since the restoration of democracy in 1990. ... The riots were followed by a large nationwide demonstration on January 12, 2008, when an estimated 200,000 Mongolians participated in nationwide protests against the government. The demonstrations were led by political parties and journalists, and accused the government of failing to provide adequate housing, public services, and employment. In response to the demonstrations, the government announced a range of social and economic reforms, including the expansion of free education and health care, the abolition of some road tolls, the provision of cash payments to those affected by the riot, and the construction of new buildings and the refurbishment of old buildings.

Charles Perceval, 7th Earl of Egmont, was British statesman who served as Under-Secretary for the Home Department between 1807 and 1809 and Paymaster-General between 1809 and 1828. This two offices made him a crucial member of William Pitt the Younger's administration. While in office he was concerned about the Catholic Question. During this time, the Catholic Emancipation was not a popular policy amongst the general public.
