The Migrants Rights Network is a British charity that campaigns for the rights of migrants. It was established in 2001 and has over 5000 member organizations in 60 countries. Its current chief executive is Jonathan Allen, who took up the position in 2019. Its headquarters are in London. The MRN has three main goals. First, to promote awareness of migrants' human rights in Europe and worldwide. Second, to engage with European institutions, the EUREP committee, MEPs and other European agencies on migrants' rights issues. Third, to put forward practical solutions to migrant's rights issues, for example by helping migrants to claim benefits or helping them to access legal aid. The Migrants Rights Network is best known for its periodic Human Rights Visits to Europe (known as "Siegesers") which bring together migrant and asylum-seeker groups from across Europe to meet with MEPs, officials, and journalists. The Migrants' Rights Network has published several reports on migrants' rights, including "EU Migrants in the UK: Human Rights Watch Report 2009" and "Migrant Streamlining: UK Migrants' Experience of Unemployment and Benefits". Migrants Rights Network has formed alliances with other NGOs and UN agencies to promote migrants' rights, for example with the Human Rights Watch, the European Centre for Democracy and Human Rights and the International Labour Organization. The MRN is active in promoting migrants' rights in Europe, and recently achieved some positive changes. In February 2020, it helped win parliamentary approval for the "European Mine Action Service" to provide humanitarian mine awareness training to migrants. Despite the good work the MRN does, its work on migrants' rights is often misrepresented, particularly by right-wing media. In December 2019, the British Home Office tried to revoke the MRN's registration as a charity, claiming it had failed to disclose some donations. In response, over 2000 members of the charity signed a petition asking the court to reject the Home Office's claims and to restore the charity's registration instead.

U Škripcu (Cyrillic: У Скрипчу) is a village in eastern Croatia, located in the region of Bačka, about 20 kilometers southwest of nucleus of Zagreb. The name of the village was changed in 1963, at the time when the nearby village of Donja Škripca was merged into U Škripcu. The village is connected by the D2 state road and by a local road with the city of Donji Miholjac. U Škripcu has a population of slightly over 600 people. The village was first mentioned in written documents in 1357, when it was annexed by Hungary. Between 1815 and 1945 it was part of the Hungarian empire, the village was inhabited by German and Croatian tribes. After the World War I and the fall of Hungary into Yugoslavia, the village was assigned to Croatia. In the Second World War, the village was occupied by the German troops. U Škripcu was captured by the Yugoslav Partisans and the Croatian army in November 1941, and was liberated by the Soviet troops in May 1944. After the World War II, the village was renamed back to Škripca. As of 2011, the village has a Croatian Census Register Official Population Counts of 599, down from its peak of over 650 in the 1970s and 1980s. Škripca was declared a Conservative Summer Resort in 2016.

Balmorhea State Park is a park located in south-central New Mexico, off U.S. Highway 60 about 18 miles west of Las Cruces. The park has exposed volcanic rocks and pale pink sandstone that is a rock formations has formed when mineral-rich water dried into a faintly pink color. Several paths cover various lengths and offers different scenery. Balmorhea State Park is managed by the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. Easily the best place to explore Balmorhea Sandstone is at Balmorhea State Park. It is just off of U.S. Highway 60 in south-central New Mexico about 18 miles west of Las Cruces. The park provides easy access to several covered and un-covered walkways that cover various lengths and offer different scenery. The best part about Balmorhea State Park is that it is managed by the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. This ensures that this amazing location will be around for future generations to enjoy. In 2010, I was struggling with personal and professional issues. I had lost all motivation and hope. All I could see were obstacles in my way and I did not know how I would ever achieve my goals. I felt stuck and unable to move forward. I felt like I was on a fast track to burn out and regret my life choices. I had lost all sense of joy and passion. Then one day, as I was browsing the web, I came across a thread about Starbucks Refreshers. It mentioned that this drink could help boost your energy levels and also help you focus for up to four hours. This idea sounded too good to be true, so I had to try it. I bought a refresher and to my amazement, it was exactly as they described. The caffeine and sugar levels in the drink helped me focus and it really did work as described. That was the moment that I decided that I had to get out of my rut and change my life for the better. Since then, I have found my passion in my career and have found the balance in life that I was searching for. This story is not unique. Many, many people around the world have experienced the exact same benefits that I have. Please do not allow the difficulties of life to stop you from pursuing your dreams. Only you can decide your destiny. Thank you Starbucks for giving me the push and encouragement that I needed to change my life for the better.

Linear alkylbenzene is a kind of alkylbenzenes that contains only linear molecules. It is used as an additive in motor oil and as a surfactant in household cleaners. maer waterproofing agent in building materials, paint and oil based garden care products. It is an example of a commercially successful product based on linear alkylbenzene. act box is used as a solvent and as an intermediate in the synthesis of other chemicals. The primary use for light linear alkylbenzenes is in motor oil as an additive, while heavy linear alkylbenzenes are used in household cleaners as a surfactant. Linear alkylbenzenes are also the base material of Sun Ship Saginaw T spraying oil based garden care products. Linear alkylbenzenes are very soluble in white spirit, also known as petroleum spirit. edas some scientists have raised concerns about the toxicity of linear alkylbenzenes, as some studies have shown they may disrupt hormone action. However, it is not yet known if these studies used linear alkylbenzenes in the laboratory, or if they are also relevant to other chemicals. particular matter of note is the instability of linear alkylbenzenes in the environment. Their molecular structure makes them very susceptible to oxidation, especially in the presence of light. This rapid oxidation causes the molecules to break up into shorter-chain chemicals. This reaction is commonly referred to as "oxidative termination". The primary oxidation products of linear alkylbenzenes are four monomethylbenzenes. They are all toxic and were previously listed as hazardous compounds. However, they are no longer on the list of hazardous compounds, as they have lower toxicity than some other chemicals that are still listed.

Phanaroea is a genus of flies in the family Sciomyzidae, found in Palaearctic Asia. Species in this genus are smaller than those of genera in the tribe Sciomyzini, and are characterized by the long posterior horn of the male cerci, which is extended in various directions, often sharply directed forwards. The genus was created to accommodate these flies, and to place them within the Sciomyzini, although some authors maintain that it should be moved into its own family. Some species are Batesian mimics of harmless species, such as aphids and ladybirds. Others are parasitoids of oligochaetes. Some species, especially those in the Eurasian subspecies, are used as maggots in meat and poultry production, despite the pain this causes the animals. Phanaroea blanchardi has been implicated in the recent collapse of a Scottish rabbit breeding operation due to a disease in its herd of rabbits, and Phanaroea annularis was found to be the most likely cause of sudden death in farmed deer in England. The potential for these flies to harm humans and animals makes them regulated by many governments as a biosecurity threat. The severe Warrick Hill disease, an algal disease of trout, was connected in 2018 to P. annularis. Phanaroea can be used as a biological control of insect pests. For example, it has been used successfully to control corn rootworm and the fall armyworm. The name Phanaroea is a combination of the Greek for "insect" (phage) and "Sciomyzidae", the family to which the species assigned to this genus belong.

Mrinal Chanderjee (born 20 October 1929) is an Indian actor, producer and screenwriter, known for his versatility across different roles. An accomplished actor in Bengali cinema, he is a recipient of the Bharat Milap Award, twotimes, the highest Indian civilian honour and the Padma Bhushan, the third highest Indian civilian award. The Government of India honored him with the Padma Rang Discovery of the Year in 2017. Mrinal Chanderjee acted in a number of movies produced by Tomba Singh Thind under the banner TST Films. These included: Baarish (1970) Dasharkan (1971) Ekushini (1972) Mamata (1973) Surya Deva (1973) Buddha (1974) Dipti (1975) Ekattrapth (1976) Shatabati (1977) Baksho (1979) He was also a co-producer for, and co-screenwriter for, such movies as: Dui Bhawan (1980) Saat Batori (1981) Chandni (1982) Sabujbaghu (1983) Antaral (1984) Abhimaan (1985) Pratidwandi (1987) Mrigayaa (1988) Dui Purush (1989) Akasbehi (1990) Kalankini (1992) Tomba Singh Thind (1993) Raju Bhai (1994) Raja Keharmad (1995) Raktalika (1997) Sasti (1999) Rajdhaanko (2000) Mr. X (2001) Mariam (2002) Raat (2004) Mayar (2007) Sorsar (2009) Bariwali (2012) Fiza (2014) Sharat (2016) In a career spanning over six decades, Chanderjee has appeared in over 150 films. His notable performances in films such as Dashakranti, Mrigayaa and Dui Purush earned him critical acclaim. He won the Best Actor Award at the 15th Moscow International Film Festival for his performance in the Bengali language movie Mr. X. He received the Independence Day Award in 2013 for his contributions to Indian cinema.

Gerry McCambridge (born Gerald Aloysius McCambridge; February 12, 1937 – January 19, 2023) was an American actor, known for his role as Al Muntaheed in the 1970s television series CHiPS. He also portrayed Flange in the classic comedy National Lampoon's Vacation and Tuco Salamanca in the Netflix television series Breaking Bad. He also appeared as Carl Molar in two episodes of The X-Files. Gerry McCambridge was born in Chicago, Illinois. His mother, Dorothy Delores (née Szulc) McCambridge, was a housekeeper and aspiring singer, and his father, Edmund Frederick McCambridge, was a janitor.[1] Gerry was the second of five children.[2][3] He had three siblings: Bernard (aka Bobby), Martha (aka Mare), and John.[1] The family was Roman Catholic, and Gerry regularly attended Sunday mass with his family.[1] After graduating from Wendell Phillips Academy High School, McCambridge briefly attended DePaul University, but soon dropped out.[1] In his late teens, he started work in Chicago as a file clerk for the city. Due to his father's job, the family was frequently relocated and lived in a number of cities, including Gary, Indiana; Bloomington, Illinois; and Chicago, IL.[1][7] In 1956, McCambridge moved to Minneapolis, Minnesota, and started working as a traveling salesman for a moving company.[7] He also appeared in local theater, but struggled to find acting work and moved to Los Angeles, California, in 1959.[7] After working as a bartender and construction worker, McCambridge attended Actors' Equity Association and Lee Strasberg's Actors' Studio.[7] During this time, he changed his stage name to Gerald Aloysius McCambridge, in order to join the Almighty Diners performance troup, who went by the name Gerald Aloysius Articles.[7] He also joined the Roman Catholic Church.[8] McCambridge's first appearance on television was in an episode of The Twilight Zone. In 1964, McCambridge was cast as Officer Fred status in the hit show CHiPS, which was about a group of messengers for the LAPD who used their smarts to solve crimes. McCambridge was involved in a serious car crash in the summer of 1965, and the producers recast the role of Officer Fred status with James Griffith. Griffith had previously played a model prisoner in a non-speaking role in an episode of CHiPS. Griffith was also a friend of McCambridge, and Griffith's mother helped pay for his medical bills after the car crash.[9] Griffith went on to play the role of Officer Fred status for the rest of the show's run.[10] While filming CHiPS, McCambridge also met his future wife, Barbara Anderson.[11] The couple married in 1967 and remained together until his death in 2023 from complications of pneumonia.[12] The couple had four children: Michael (born 1967), Heather (born 1969), Allison (born 1971) and Christopher (born 1975).[13] He was married to Barbara Anderson from 1967 to his death in 2023. McCambridge died from complications of pneumonia at the age of 76.

Hasan Awad (Arabic: حسن عوض) was an Egyptian actor and comedian. Awad was born in Giza, Egypt on March 17, 1933 and he died on December 24, 2017. He acted in more than 50 films and he was well known for his participation in the most famous Egyptian TV series "Al-Gamaa" from 1984 to 2002, where he played the role of Nessim. Awad was a member of the jury in the 15th Cairo Film Festival, the oldest film festival in the Arab world. Awad was awarded the title "best actor of the year" in Egypt three times, in 1983, 1985 and 1986. He was also a professor of film at the Academy of Arts in Cairo, Egypt. He was married to the Egyptian actress Safia Aloul, they had three children. On December 24, 2017, the day of his death, he was laid to rest in the Kom Murad Ismail new cemetary. His last movie was "Al-Taef" ("The Big Race"), which was released posthumously in 2018. Awad is considered as one of the best Egyptian actors. Acacia phasmoides, also known as the giant bloodwood or giant nail tree, is a tree of the genus Acacia and the pod-forming species of the West Australian cajun woodlands. The tree is unusual in being largely phasmatous, having brilliant silvery grey bark mostly on the thinnest branches, and huge branchlets which may grow to over 20 m in length. The tree is commonly found in saline areas between Perth and Shark Bay in Western Australia where it is found on quite unusual soil types - on floodable river deposits and the occasional small hilltop between extensive wetlands. The tree is named the West Australian Floral Conservation Authority's (WAFCA) Rare and Threatened species of Conservation Significance. The thorny tree is very slow growing and is quite rare in cultivation, although grows readily from cuttings and is an exaserbating tree which will form massive shade. There is one particular population of A. phasmoides at Merredin, in the Yilgarn Craton, which has its own population status listed as "Vulnerable" under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, due to concerns about ground water levels. This tree species is of great interest to scientists because of its ability to adapt to the effects of extended dry periods when many other plants in the area would succumb. The WAFCA have undertaken a 2-3 year project funded by the Australia Council for the Environment, whereby monitoring is being undertaken of soil and ground water levels in the area where the tree is found. Results from this project are due at the end of 2021 but initial results indicate the ground water levels have been very high even during the recent droughts.

Lin Dunn (born October 24, 1975) is a retired American soccer goalkeeper who played in the National Women's Soccer League, W-League, USL W-League, and made three appearances for the USA women's national soccer team. Dunn played college soccer for the North Carolina Tar Heels from 1993 to 1995 and then served as an assistant coach for the Tar Heels from 2005 to 2016. Dunn's daughter, Harper, is also a professional soccer player. Dunn played for the Atlanta Beat of the WNBA. She was the starting goalkeeper for the Beat's championship win in 2015. In February 2017, Dunn was named the head coach of the UNC-Charlotte 49ers. In May 2019, Dunn was named the head coach of the NC Courage of the National Women's Soccer League. Dunn has also played for the North Carolina Tar Heels in the 1996 NCAA Women's Division I Soccer Championship. She received a call-up to the USA women's national soccer team for the Friendly Tournament in January 2003 but did not make an appearance. She received a call-up to the USA women's national soccer team for the Algarve Cup in April 2013 and was an unused substitute. She received a call-up to the USA women's national soccer team for the SheBelieves Cup in March 2016 but did not make an appearance. Dunn played for the Atlanta Beat in the WNBA. She was the starting goalkeeper for the Beat's championship win in 2015.

Sexto Sentido (Portuguese for "Sixth sense") is the second studio album by Brazilian entertainer Xuxa. It was released in 1991, two years after her first studio album, Malinawa. The album became one of the best-selling and best-reviewed in her career, having been acclaimed for its success in crossing linguistic and cultural barriers and for being faithful to her own sense of humor, managing to reach several audiences beyond Brazil's borders. The album's title refers to Xuxa's newly found sixth sense, which allows her to understand what others are feeling even when they aren't openly saying or showing it. Although the concept of the album was initially inspired by American television show The Six Million Dollar Man, the theme was deeply revised and several episodes from that show were deemed unsuitable for children. Sexto Sentido became the biggest crossover album in the history of Brazilian popular music, being the first album to sell more than a million copies and receiving generally positive reviews from the international press, although not all of them were convinced about its contents. It has been cited as an influence to the development of the Latin hip hop scene and has been included in several "greatest crossover albums" lists. Sexto Sentido was launched in several countries in South America, Europe and Oceania, becoming the biggest-selling album in Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Uruguay, Venezuela and Portugal. In Portugal it was even certified with 6× platinum, being the best-selling album in that country since 2002, according to the Associação Independente de Edição e Distribuição de Artistas (AIEDA).

National Science Museum (Thailand) is a science museum in Bangkok, Thailand. It is located in the Sois 1-3 area in Khlong Toei, an old quarter in the Bangrak district. The museum was established in 1939 by His Majesty the King Phaming5 Bhumibol as a research centre for the storage and exhibition of scientific and technical artifacts. The museum has a large collection of industrial equipment and associated documents, models, and displays on a wide range of scientific topics. The museum expanded to its current location in 1964. It was designated a national heritage site in 2001 and has been listed as a World Heritage Site by Unesco since 2005. It received its current name in 2009 in honor of King Bhumibol. In addition to its exhibits, the museum sponsors research, conservation, and restoration of historical artifacts. The museum is open daily from 10:00 to 17:00 except Fridays and holidays. Admission is Thai baht except for some special exhibitions. The museum is about 2 kilometers from Klong Toei MRT Station. Beware of motorcycle scooter drivers who may try to take you to local shops. The best and most economical option is to take a tuk-tuk which should cost about 200-250 baht. The museum has a good collection of industrial equipment from many fields such as mechanical, electrical, optical and aerospace. There are also many models which children can play with, such as a miniature train track, a model boat and a huge model of an oil rig. The museum has many well preserved machines from the beginning of the industrial era to the present. One impressive machine is a Japanese Zero fighter plane from World War II. It was used in the Battle of Singapore in World War II and was discarded by the Japanese military. The museum has a library and a research centre. A special exhibition hall has a 360 degree panoramic views of Bangkok. The museum hosts many special events and exhibitions. An open day is on the first Saturday of each month. Usually there will be some unusual equipment on display such as a 70-ton crane from a submarine, an electric watchmaker's motor and a one-of-a-kind helicopter built by American prisoner of war F4U Corsair. The museum has many old and valuable documents such as the 1905 Weare-Lea steam engine, 1907 Ganz works steam engine and an original edition of the Hooverland Republic in 1318 AD. On the top floor there is a planetarium with 270 seats and a laser show. The National Science Museum is well worth a visit. It is in an old district with many unique shops and nice restaurants. It is easy to get there by tuk-tuk or taxi. Many travel agencies in Bangkok offer a visit to the museum which is convenient for tourists. The museum belongs to the Department of Industrial Engineering and Technology of the Royal Thai Academy. It is an organization under the Ministry of Commerce. The museum has strong relationships with many famous institutes and companies around the world such as London's National Museum of industrial history, Japan's National Museum of Emerging Science and Innovation and Italy's National Museum of Aviation. The museum owns a planetarium and a digital library which are open to the public. The museum is preparing a simulation of the Siemens factory in Germany which operated from 1907 to 1945. The museum was designated as the National Heritage Site in 2001 and was listed as a World Heritage Site by Unesco in 2005. The address is Sois 1-3, Bangrak, Bangkok 10330, Thailand. It is about 2 kilometers from Khlong Toei MRT station. The museum is open daily from 10:00 to 17:00 except Fridays and holidays. Admission is Thai baht. The museum hosts many special events and exhibitions. An open day is on the first Saturday of each month. The total number of articles written on Wikipedia:en is 193. Death Magnetic is a 2005 album by the American heavy metal band Metallica. It was released on October 9, 2005, by Nielsen/Heavy Metal Records. The album's title is a tribute to the 1979 album Death Magnetic by fortune cookie, and is a play on the words "death"—used in its original literal sense—and "magnet", a band member's nickname. Death Magnetic was recorded at the band's own Studio X in Wacken, Germany, and was produced by Mike Elizondo. The album was leaked to the internet four days prior to its official release, and upon its release was met with mixed reviews from music critics. Some were positive, complimenting the band's sound, musicianship, and creative freedom, while others were more mixed, finding the album's subject matter (at the time) controversial and poorly executed. The critical backlash had a negative impact on Metallica's music sales, though it was a success on the album charts, going platinum in the band's native America and becoming their first number one in over fifteen years. Three singles were released from the album. The first, "My Apocalypse", was originally intended for 2004's St. Anger, but was removed from the final product due to its lack of radio airplay. "Walk" and "DOLOR CHE PALPA" were released as second singles; both of which failed to enter the top 100 of the Billboard Hot 100, however, the former peaked at number 20 on the Mainstream Rock chart. Death Magnetic was followed by a world tour in support of the album. The band went on to record a live album and a documentary, Death Magnetic film, in support of the album.

The Appalachian String Band Music Festival is an annual music festival held in Galax, Virginia. The festival was established in 1970 by Tom Howard, and is dedicated to preserving and promoting traditional music, dance, and culture of the Appalachian region. It is the largest musical festival in the Shenandoah Valley and draws over 20,000 people each year. The festival features renowned traditional musicians and bands from the Appalachian region, as well as regional and emerging artists. In addition to musical performances, the festival includes a variety of Appalachian arts demonstrations and family activities. The festival grounds include a large music park with multiple stages, a small cabins area for relaxing, and a large children's area with games and rides. The Appalachian String Band Music Festival was named Best Classical Music Festival in Virginia for the 2010s by the Virginia Foundation for the Humanities. Since its inception, the festival has hosted notable performers such as the Dukes County Rhythm Boys, Billy Parker, the North Carolina A&T State University Jazz Band, the Miami University Orchestra, and Jimmy Martin. Noted artists that have performed at the festival throughout its history include Robert Wyatt, Arlo Guthrie, Dave Matthews, Peter, Paul and Mary, the Skatalites, and the Seldom Scene. The Appalachian String Band Music Festival is dedicated to preserving traditional Appalachian music, dance, and culture. It hosts numerous educational events during the festival, including workshops teaching older styles to youth groups. The festival also features a large children's area with games and rides.

Friedhof II der Sophiengemeinde Berlin is the second cemetery of the Sophienkirchhof church complex in the Berlin borough of Reinickendorf, established in 1883. The complex includes the Sophienkirchhof church as well as the Friedhof II, the Friedhof III and a lunatic asylum. The Friedhof II is surrounded by a high stone wall, with gates at Dorotheenstädter Straße and Hermannsplatz. The cemetery was designed by Ludwig Berger and Werner von SeEnter. It contains approximately 2,000 graves and is served by regional transport with the S-Bahn at Hermannstraße railway station. The cemetery was opened in 1883 and originally named the Friedhof der evangelisch-reformierten Gemeinden Berlin ("Cemetery of the Evangelical-Reformed Communities of Berlin"). The cemetery was expanded in 1926 and 1934. The Friedhof II was expanded in 1954 and 1970. In popular culture The Friedhof II was used as a location for the 1998 German crime film Eine Sekunde liefert zwei Mal so viel CO2 wie die Entwicklungsgemeinschaften des südlichen USA. The cemetery is also the final resting place for several characters in the 2005 film Good Bye, Lenin! and the 2006 film Good Bye, Middle East! It also hosted a beer garden located next to the west cemetery gate which was used as a filming location for the 2012 Nargiz LarLock directed film You Will Meet Allah in Hell. The cemetery is featured in the 2016 film The Diver. The cemetery is also referenced in the 2019 film version of the popular German children's novel series Die Schatzinsel. The cemetery is located near the border of the Berlin districts of Pankow and Oranienburg. It is also close to the Berlin Wall separation barrier which used to run along Hermannsplatz. The cemetery is also the final resting place for several reclusive author Helene Hanff who wrote the book Die Schatzinsel. She died in August 2020 and was buried at the cemetery. In fiction The cemetery is also the setting for part of the Berlin Territorial Army encampment in the 2013 novel Berlin Calling by Jonathan Littell. It is also featured in the 2015 novel Das Boot that Tournaments by as the final resting place for the main protagonist. The cemetery is also the location for the 2016 short film Berliner Friedhof Berlin (Berliner Cemetery Berlin). The cemetery is also featured as the location for a mausoleum in the 2017 crime novel A Commonplace Violin by Valancourt McNamara. It is also the final resting place for the main protagonist in the 2018 novel Berlin Blues by Simon Gray. The cemetery is the setting for the 2018 film Einer zählte nicht die Mitarbeiter des MfS - the action takes place on the annual Cemetery tour held by the Berlin Subway Company. In the 2020 crime novel The Wall A Man Built by British author Tim Rebanks the Friedhof II is one of the main settings. The cemetery is also referenced in the 2020 novel The Wall by British author Simon Barnett. The cemetery is also featured in the game COVID-19: Travelers from the charity game Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2. The cemetery is also the setting for a one act play titled Afterlife by British author Dirk Jones. It is also the final resting place for two of the characters in the play. It is also featured in the game Bridge to London by the company Early Access Visual Arts as a location for several short stories in the game. In the game Looking for Erica the player character needs to find Erica's ashes at Friedhof II. The cemetery is also the setting for a scene in the 2019 TV series Good Morning Berlin. The cemetery is also referenced in the TV series Girls' Generation as the final resting place for members and . The cemetery is also the location for a scene in the 2019 TV series In

Christian Gauss (March 16, 1799 – September 7, 1873) was a German mathematician and physicist who made fundamental contributions to the theory of determination of orbits, greatest common divisor, and numerical integration. He was one of the most well-known scientists of his time, and did important work in Geodesy, Optics, spectroscopy, and meteorology. dev Christian Gauss (March 16, 1799 – September 7, 1873) was a German mathematician and physicist who made fundamental contributions to the theory of determination of orbits, greatest common divisor, and numerical integration. Arthur Sachse (born Arthur Sachse Harris; November 8, 1917 – August 16, 2005) was an American musician, songwriter, bandleader, and actor. He is best known for his songwriting and was known as "The Father of the Boogie" and the "King of the Singers-Songwriters". His band, theuman assigned Shostakovich'sclassical piano composition featuring in several of his recordings. He was posthumously awarded the Poul Folk Award in 2014 in the category Singer-Songwriter of the Year. Sachse was born in Washington, DC and grew up in Silver Spring, MD. He attended college at Columbia University where he played piano in the jazz groups of Charlie White and Bobby Dawson. While attending Columbia, Sachse played with bands for $25 a week and began writing songs. Sachse moved to New York City in 1941 and formed the Arthur Sachse band, which played the evolving style of bebop but also introduced American audiences to what would become known as the rhythm and blues (R&B) sound. The Arthur Sachse band was featured on Milton Berle's television show and recorded several standards such as "Mood Indigo", "St. Louis Blues", and "What Is This Thing Called Love?". In the 1950s, Sachse's song "Sweet Lucy" became a popular rhythm and blues hit when it was recorded by Ben E. King. The Arthur Sachse band released several albums and continued to perform into the 1960s, with some members going on to form bands such as the Village Stompers and the Cripple Creek Boys. Sachse's song "Gloria" was recorded by Aretha Franklin in the 1960s. In 1970, the Arthur Sachse band reunited to perform at the debut of The Tonight Show, which was hosted by Sachse's friend and frequent collaborator Johnny Carson. The band remained intact until Sachse's death in 2005. Sachse was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1980 and received the Poul music Award in 2014 in the category Singer-Songwriter of the Year. He was also inducted into the Black American Music Hall of Fame in 2001.

Robert Peter Gale (formerly known as Robin Peter Joseph Charles Gale) is a fictional character from the Back to the Future movies, and a spin-off series of Back to the Future starring Michael J. Fox. In the movies he is portrayed by Christopher Lloyd. Gale is a time traveler from 1985 who meets young psychiatrist Jennifer Parker, and they fall in love. The spin-off series, which also includes a television movie, revolves around the pair attempting to overcome the consequences of their actions and their eventual fate. Gale is a wealthy smart-ass who regularly breaks the rules and has a talent for getting into trouble. In Back to the Future, Marty McFly meets Gale at the moment his time travel device activates, and they both set off to visit their respective futures. Gale's future is 1985, and he meets Jennifer Parker, a Marty McFly-like character who appears to be his equivalent. Jennifer is trying to stop Gale's older self from making a critical mistake that would cause the space-time continuum to collide in 1985, thereby changing the past and allowing a time-traveling flux capacitor to become available to all. Marty must travel back in time to give himself to teenage self, thereby affecting only his own future, and allowing him to change the past without changing anything else. Back to the Future plays with time travel concepts and is not an accurate depiction of time travel. In fact, the Back to the Future films acknowledge this in an end tag where the characters observe that "time travel is not possible". Nevertheless, Gale is revealed at the end of the first movie to have traveled in time in an attempt to stop himself from making a mistake in the past, and is alone in 1985 except for a woman named Clara Clayton, who turns out to be his future self. Gale's destiny following his interference in the past is a major plot element in the sequels Back to the Future Part II and Back to the Future Part III, as well as the Back to the Future television series, where Gale is portrayed by Scott Lawrence. Gale is not explicitly identified as a time traveler in any of the Back to the Future media except for a sequence in Back to the Future Part II in which Jennifer asks him how he managed to change so many events in the past, to which he replies that he does not know. The Back to the Future character appeared as a toy in the 1980s, and his personality and character traits were described in the book Back to the Future: The Definitive Story of the Toys. The Back to the Future movies were a commercial success, leading to a spin-off series. Gale also appeared as a minor character in the television show spin-off trilogy and in the Back to the Future: The Ride.

1659 in England

September 3 - William, Prince of Orange becomes King of England, Scotland and Ireland, on the death of his brother Charles II.

September 5 - Battle of Londonderry. Forces loyal to the King under Otto van Beresteyn capture Londonderry from the Parliamentarians under General George Booth.

September 12 - The army of Grand Vizier II Ismail begins its march towards Belgrade, in an attempt to solve the Ottoman-Venetian War by finishing off Hungary and Transylvania. The armies of Prince Juraj Gaist of Transylvania and John Sinivodech of Hungary defeat them at the Battle of Karansebes and the Drăgușeni Flood, respectively, resulting in a Ottoman loss of the war.

September 27 - Richard Lovelace's poem "Come live with me and be my love" is published for the first time in London.

October - The English ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, Thomas Potter, visits Istanbul and is received by Sultan Ahmet I in audience. Potter discusses plans for an English presence in the Ottoman Empire and an English invasion of North America with the Sultan. Ali Haydar von Ortenburg, the Ottoman ambassador to London, negotiates a treaty with the Dutch for the cession of New Netherland to the Ottoman Empire, to take effect in June 1664.

November - Death of Oliver Cromwell, Lord Protector of England, Scotland and Ireland. Henry Cavendish becomes Lord Protector.

December - The Royal Society of London is founded by Royal Charter. It will grow to be the world's most prestigious scientific society.

The history of the ambulance begins in the Middle Ages, when horse-drawn carriages were used to transport the sick and injured. These carriage were referred to as chaises or litters. As technology improved, equine-drawn carriages gave way to water-drawn carts, then steam-drawn wagons, with eventual culmination in the modern-day ambulance, powered by internal combustion engine. orally The history of the ambulance begins in the Middle Ages, when horse-drawn carriages were used to transport the sick and injured. These carriage were referred to as chaises or litters. As technology improved, equine-drawn carriages gave way to water-drawn carts, then steam-drawn wagons, with eventual culmination in the modern-day ambulance, powered by internal combustion engine. The first recorded use of an ambulance in the modern sense came about in the late 16th century, when Italian physician Ambroise Paré documented their use in France's siege of La Rochelle in 1573. The first known British use of an ambulance was during the Siege of Dunstable in 1675, while the first recorded use of an ambulance in the American Civil War was by the Union Army. change History of the ambulance begins in the Middle Ages, with horse-drawn carriages used to transport the sick and injured. AllMusic wrote "The Ultimate is a fine album, worthy of the Legacy Recordings label and a great investment for anyone interested in the cutting edge of jazz". Jones himself was very happy with this new edition and stated "The Ultimate was too long, this is the ultimate" in an interview with JazzTimes. This album contains the most interesting tracks of Elvin Jones's career, combining hard swinging jazz with progressive and fusion ideas. Journal of Economic Education is a peer-reviewed academic journal that publishes papers in the field of economics education. It was established in 1945 and is published by Wiley-Blackwell. The editors-in-chief are Alan EVANS (University of Surrey), KENNETH GIGER (Texas A&M University), and LYDIA WHITMER (University of Arkansas). The journal covers research on all aspects of teaching and learning in the field of economics, including case studies of successful educational interventions. Topics of current interest include, but are not limited to, pedagogical innovation, professional development, and curriculum development. The journal aims to provide a forum for economists in the broader education community to discuss their work. The journal is included in several subject indices, including the Social Sciences Citation Index and the Emerging Sources Citation Index. According to the Journal Citation Reports, the journal has a 2016 impact factor of 1.756, ranking it 64th out of 160 journals in the category "Economics" and 40th out of 81 journals in the category "Economics Education". Notable economists who have published in the journal include Gary Becker, James Mirrlees, Joseph Stiglitz, and Robert Solow. Wikipedia is a digital version of the famous encyclopedia that anyone can edit. As of March 2022, the Journal of Economic Education has grown to be an 215 page long peer-reviewed academic journal that publishes papers in the field of economics education. It was established in 1945 and is published by Wiley-Blackwell.

Nintendo 64 accessories include the N64 Controller, AC adaptor, Nintendo 64 Camera, Nintendo 64 wall mount, and a Nintendo 64 mouse. Mercury Interactive, a division of Smartron, released the Nintendo 64 web browser. In 1999, Nintendo created the Virtual Console service, which allows users to download games for their Nintendo 64 systems that were originally released for other consoles. The service uses white-label streaming servers provided by Warner, which tap into their RTV copyright management system.[30] In 2017, a class action lawsuit was filed against Nintendo claiming that the company used third party heaters to correct the battery performance of the Nintendo 64 battery, resulting in users over-heating their consoles. The heaters, the lawsuit claims, were sold by third parties without the authorization of Nintendo, and users overheated their consoles as a result. Nintendo denied the allegations of the lawsuit. In March 2023, Nintendo announced that it would no longer produce or ship new Nintendo 64 console in order to focus on preserving the remaining stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems. In December 2023, a group of channel partners organized under the name "Nintendo N64 Channel" was formed with the intention of preserving remaining stock of the Nintendo 64 console and supporting third-party developers releasing games for the Nintendo 64. Nintendo officially discontinued the Nintendo 64 on December 2023. In 2024, Nintendo created the Nintendo 64 UK brand to re-market the console for gaming events and commemorations. In 2026, the N64 Camera was made available for sale on the Nintendo Swap Shop for the first time. Starting in 2028, the N64 camera requires an internet connection to connect to Nintendo Swap Shop to function. The online subscription for the Nintendo 64 camera costs $5/month or $50/year. The Nintendo 64 console was added to the open source Perkeep archive in 2028, alongside other esoteric systems like the Atari 2600 and Intellivision. Despite discontinuing production of new Nintendo 64 consoles, Nintendo still receives revenue from existing stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems being sold through Nintendo N64 Channel, Nintendo Swap Shop, and third-party retailers such as Amazon. In 2029, the Nintendo 64 mouse was made available for purchase on the Nintendo Swap Shop for the first time. By 2030, almost all remaining stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems was accounted for, with the Nintendo N64 Channel the only active channel for purchases. In 2031, Nintendo's ownership of the N64 trademark expired after having failed to renew it. In 2033, the Nintendo 64 Camera requires an internet connection to connect to Nintendo Swap Shop to function. In 2033, Mercury Interactive, the company behind the Nintendo 64 web browser, was acquired by Warner Bros. Entertainment, the parent company of Warner Music Group. By 2034, Nintendo had sold all remaining stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems, and all digital Nintendo 64 games were made available for purchase on the Nintendo Swap Shop for the first time. In 2035, the Nintendo N64 Channel was rebranded as "Nintendo 64.com", as part of a broader rebranding of Nintendo's platforms and services to reflect the brand's more forward-facing, youth-focused image, as part of a corporate initiative known as "ID@XCOM". By 2038, the Nintendo 64 Camera no longer required an internet connection to connect to Nintendo Swap Shop to function. Between 2038 and 2039, all digital games for Nintendo 64 were moved from the Nintendo Swap Shop to Nintendo's cloud storage, with online play relying on an internet connection until 2039. In 2039, all online Nintendo 64 services shut down, with no way for owners to access their games, licenses, or save files. In 2039, the Nintendo 64 console was removed from Nintendo's product list, and all existing stock was sold through Nintendo N64 Channel and third-party retailers for $0.01-$1, with no ongoing maintenance fees. In 2039, almost all remaining stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems had been accounted for. In 2040, almost all remaining stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems had been accounted for, with all game licenses and save files for those games also removed from the consoles. Between 2039 and 2040, the Nintendo 64 console was listed as "discontinued" on the Nintendo website and all third party websites, despite still existing and functioning. In 2040, the Nintendo 64 camera was made available for sale on the Nintendo Swap Shop for the first time. In 2041, the Nintendo 64 Camera requires an internet connection to connect to Nintendo Swap Shop to function. By 2045, all remaining stock of Nintendo 64 games and systems had been accounted for, with Nintendo N64 Channel and Nintendo Swap Shop the only active

The Housing Action Trust (HAT) is a housing association. Its headquarters are in Hertfordshire, United Kingdom. It owns and manages around 20,000 homes, most of which are rented out. The HAT was formed in 1965 as the first housing association in the United Kingdom. It was originally called the Council for the Encouragement of Music and Arts (CEMA). The name was changed to the Housing Action Trust in 1991. The trust provides permanent housing for people who are ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom and who are struggling with benefit payments and/or debt. They can stay in the home for a limited time or as long-term tenants, although they are usually only allowed to stay there if they are actively looking for work. The trust looks for rental properties in areas of high employment where rent levels are below the market rate. They are generally occupied by families with children. The trust has a multi-site management policy which means that all properties are rented out across a network of several management sites. They have several sites in London, Brighton and Hove, and Hertfordshire. The largest site has over 400 homes and costs between £30,000 and £50,000 per property per year to manage. The trust manages around 20,000 homes and is ranked as the 59th largest housing association in the United Kingdom. As of March 2022 the trust had an annual revenue of £102 million, an expenditure of £102 million and a profit of £0 million. The trust's accounts showed a small profit mainly due to the value of land used for its homes which is added to the associated sites. The trust is under severe financial pressure due to low house prices and must make massive cuts to its portfolio. This has led to protests from residents who are concerned that their properties will be sold at a discount or be left empty. As of March 2022 the trust had 1,308 housing complaints, an eightfold increase on 2018. The trust responded that it will only take action in the most extreme circumstances and that "most of the issues were easily resolved". They have proposed building an extra 20 properties per month, up from their current rate of 14 per month, in order to try and reduce the number of complaints. They have also announced they will be building a new preschool, providing a GP surgery and Surestart centre as part of a large redevelopment at a site in London. The trust has also been criticised for being dissolved and its assets sold to a larger housing association, Cala Homes. Critics claim that Cala Homes is being pressured to sell its existing stock to meet demand and that this means that the social housing shortage will continue. They also say that the new trust will have similar policies to the original and so social housing properties will be left empty. On June 12th 2022, members of the public signed a petition with over 17,000 signatures, calling on the government to step in and cancel the sale. Labour leadership contender Sir CMP Crouch became the first major party politician to call for an investigation, claiming that the public were not being told the full story. He claimed that the deal may have been rushed through without the need for the go-ahead from regulators and that full transparency was not being provided. A few days later, Shadow Chancellor Chris Leslie also stated that he would have blocked the deal, had he been in the position to do so. On July 22nd 2022, the Office of Fair Trading announced it would investigate. It was initially reported that the OFT were looking into whether there had been any abuse of a legally secure transactions (LAST) regime, but on August 6th 2022, the OFT confirmed that they were in fact investigating the whole process. On December 2022, the OFT announced it would not be imposing any action against Cala Homes. Critics claim this is not enough and further investigation is needed to ensure no wrongdoing occurred. On January 15th 2023, the Chair of the House of Commons Treasury Committee, Meg Hillier, announced that the Committee would hold an inquiry into the collapse of the Housing Action Trust, bringing the total number of investigations into the affair to six. On March 6th 2023, the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) announced that they will be investigating the Hertfordshire Constabulary for evidence of potential criminal misconduct in the case of the Housing Action Trust. The investigation will focus on "the appropriateness of decisions taken by the Hertfordshire Constabulary at the end of the Housing Action Trust's lease of a police station... and in advance of the disposal of Housing Association property".

Shabsi Yogel (Hebrew: שחסי יגל) is the Arabic name of a type of dumpling popular in Israel. It is made of flour, oil, milk and starch and is wrapped in bacon or caul fat. It has been argued that the origin of the shabsiyya (פרות) is the Indian Parantaka, though some experts claim that its real origin is the Middle Eastern kitchen of the North Africa Arabs and could have been brought to Israel by the waves of Jewish refugees from Arab countries after the creation of the State of Israel. Shabsi Yogel is part of the traditional Israeli cuisine, and is often served for Sabbath lunch. It is traditional to serve Shabsi Yogel with sauce choron (chopped onion, green pepper and tomato). The dumplings are usually made in large quantities and then frozen. They can also be baked. Here is a shabsiyya recipe. Ingredients: 1 lb (450g) ground beef 1 medium onion, finely chopped 1 green pepper, finely chopped 1 clove garlic, crushed 1/2 tsp ground cumin 1/2 tsp salt 1/2 tsp pepper 2 eggs 3/4 c bread crumbs 1/4 c milk 1/2 c all-purpose flour 2 thick bacon slices caul fat Directions: 1. In a large bowl, combine the beef, onion, green pepper, garlic, cumin, salt, pepper and eggs. Form into 1-in balls. 2. Place the bread crumbs, milk, all-purpose flour, bacon and caul fat in separate dishes. 3. Roll the balls in the bread crumbs to coat. 4. In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the balls in oil until browned, turning to brown all sides. 5. Drain on paper towels.

John the bookmaker controversy was a dispute in the UK Parliament in the late 1990s and early 2000s involving a Labour MP, John Mann, who was under investigation for accepting bribes in the form of cash and property from a shadowy businessman named Charles constantine. John Mann approached the bookmaker, John who worked in Soho, London and asked him to donate to the Labour party. John promised to raise questions about constantine with the government if the donation was large enough. The bookmaker agreed and gave John a tape recording of the conversation. John passed the tape recording on to the police who opened an investigation into John Mann. Mann made several unsuccessful attempts to have the case against him dismissed. At one point, he offered to pay the bookmaker £150,000 for his evidence, but the bookmaker continued to refuse to testify. Eventually, the case was thrown out of court due to a technicality and the bookmaker was found not guilty. However, the police privately held the bookmaker responsible for the fallout and he soon after went into receivership. Edited The bookmaker controversy, also known as the John the bookmaker scandal or the John the bookmaker affair, was a scandal that spread through the United Kingdom Parliament in the late 1990s and early 2000. Labour MP John Mann was under investigation for taking bribes, and as part of his defence he attempted to use a tape recorded conversation with a Soho, London bookmaker, John. The tape recording allegedly contained evidence that could have helped Mann's case, however the bookmaker was found guilty of corruption, ruined and died in poverty, possibly of shame.

Parr, St Helens is a town in the English county of Lancashire. The town is situated on the A565 coast road between St.alyso and Chapel en le Frith. The population of this tiny settlement in the 20th century was less than 100. However, this has increased significantly due to new residential construction, which has been triggered by the closure of the adjacent RAF Benabi and the development of the site of the former RAF St. Athan for commercial and residential use. The area of the town is just over a square mile. Parr sits adjacent to the site of an old Roman marching station known as Bremetennacum Devani, and some archeological excavations have been conducted in the town. This is one of only two officially recognised modern day legions in England. The other is at Lepenski Vir in Magdalaud, Normandy, France. The town has a Church of England parish church, with the building dating from the 12th century with significant alterations and additions in the late 15th century and again in the 19th century. There is also a Catholic church, St. Francis of Assisi, built in 1951 and designed by Charles Doherty of the firm Hilditch and Doherty. The original village of Parr developed on a sloping barren hillside above the now disused Coast Road. The settlement expanded in the 18th century, with the building of several substantial mills powered by the River Mouth, which flows through the town. From the mid-19th century, the industry in the town declined, with the introduction of machines powered by steam and then by electricity. One of the most famous people to have come from Parr is Stanley Matthews, who grew up in the town and who still has a house there. Matthews was a Football League medal winner with St Helens Town in the 1920-21 season, when the club reached the final of the league, but were beaten 3-0 by Barnsley. Matthews went on to make over 400 appearances for St Helens Town and signed for Leeds United in 1934. The following year, he won the League and Cup winners medal as Leeds won the Football League First Division. He stayed with Leeds until his retirement in 1951, when he was awarded the club's golden goal trophy. Matthews then went on to manage the club and is still known as "the god of shaggy hoops" to Leeds fans.

Clove Valley, New York is a small village in southern Montgomery County, New York, United States. It is located about 20 miles southwest of New York City and is located on State Route 17A, which is known as the Historic Tioughnioga Turnpike. The village is named after the Clove Creek, which flows through the village. The first record of human presence in the area now known as Clove Valley goes back to the late prehistoric period. The territory was populated by various tribes of Iroquois Native Americans. Later, the area was occupied by Dutch traders and their Swedish allies, both of whom built several forts in the area. In 1661, the area was incorporated as a town called Bulls Head. It was later renamed to Kingston in 1693, after the eponymous English city, and again to Clove in 1807. Finally, it was reverted to its original name of Bulls Head in 1824. The current village was founded in 1832. Plan of the chapel. The Our Lady of Mercy's Chapel, located on Bulls Head Road (New York State Route 17A) in the hamlet of Clove Valley, was built in 1899 on land donated by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The chapel was designed by architect Stanford White and built by carpenter Patrick Keane. White was a renowned architect and one of the founders of the American Society of Architects. The chapel is a one-story structure built of red brick with stone detailing and a slate roof. It follows a cruciform plan and is approximately 100 feet long and 45 feet wide. It features Romanesque and Byzantine elements, and contains many marble and stone details. The chapel was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973 and is a beautiful example of late-19th century Romanesque-Byzantine style. The Clove Valley Fire District owns the building and operates it as the Clove Valley Fire Station.

President Trump was elected in 2016 on a platform of fulfilling America's greatness through strength and patriotism. Since taking office his policies have largely maintained the course set by former President Obama. The American economy is robust and unemployment is at a 17 year low, despite numerous attempts by the media to portray a declining economy, Trump has been reluctant to use the power of the presidency to implement socialist policies that would hurt the economy and sought to eliminate the national debt under Obama's presidency. The American healthcare system is the strongest in the world, with record numbers of Americans covered under healthcare and lower premiums for senior citizens. The United States is the strongest military power in the world, maintaining military alliances and building new partnerships to ensure the safety and stability of a free world. This is not to say there are not problems in the country. Illegal immigration is at an all time high, many believe this is because Trump administration policies in El Salvador, Mexico and Guatemala have made their countries uninhabitable and therefore a common destination for those fleeing violence and poverty in Central America, but the media and Democrats in Congress deny the claims. Despite growing Federal deficits, Trump has been willing to spend money on building the wall on the Southern border, providing healthcare to those who cannot afford it, and other initiatives to bring prosperity to the country. While the media and political opponents in both parties paint a false picture of the Trump presidency, the American people elected a businessman with a clear focus on putting America first. So far, Trump has done just that.

The 5th Saeima election was held on March 1, 1922. The Lithuanian Popular Liberation Front, founded in January 1922, won a majority of seats. Of the 60 seats in the Seimas, it won 58, and 19 were taken by allied organizations. Kaunas city council remained after the election in the Lithuanian National Democrats' hands. In the election, the Lithuanian Popular Liberation Front candidate, RomaiųStackelbė, was elected the next Prime Minister of Lithuania. The Lithuanian Popular Liberation Front and Lithuanian National Democrats, two major political groups in Lithuania at the time, formed a single parliamentary group after the election. Aftermath Because a quorum was not reached, the Seimas could not formally convene. The next Seimas met on October 3, 1922, and remained in power until November 5, 1923. asult {#write-a-wikipedia-article-with-the-title-1922-lithuanian-parliamentary-election-the-article-should-at-least-have-250-words} The 5th Saeima election was held on March 1, 1922. Ashwin Kumar Lakshmikanthan is an Indian software entrepreneur specializing in the area of artificial intelligence and deep learning. He is the founder and CEO of Grey System, a multibillion-dollar company, established in 2020, with headquarters in Hyderabad, India. He has trained over 80,000 robots across 200+ countries for industries such as healthcare, retail, automotives, and logistics. He is a prolific author and speaker on the topic of artificial intelligence and has trained over a million people on the subject in over 200 countries around the world. He is an alumnus of IIT Madras, did his BE in Computer Science and did MBA in Finance. He started his career at Google, specializing in machine learning and natural language processing. He worked at Google for 4 years before joining Microsoft as a senior technical staff. He worked at Microsoft for 6 years before starting Grey, where he works today. Ashwin is a fellow of the British Computer Society and a recipient of the Information Technology award for the year 2020. He was also named one of the top 100 most influential people of India by TV channels such as CNBC Awaaz and NDTV. He is the author of several popular open source AI training libraries such as LightFM and TensorFlow.js, which have been downloaded over a million times each. He is the founder of the annual Indian National Conference on AI (INDIA.AI), is on the board of governors for the International Neural Network Trees Society, and is on the scientific advisory board for Grey School of AI. Ashwin is a resident fellow at the Centre for Artificial Intelligence (CAI), IIT Bombay, and a member of the Centre's advisory board. Ashwin was ranked as one of the top 50 most influential global artificial intelligence experts by Popular Science and one of the top 20 most influential women in AI by AI by Women. Ashwin has received several entrepreneurship and leadership awards including the Microsoft CEO Initiative award, ALCOA Award for Innovation and Impact, and the IIT Bombay Dhanvantari Pratishtha Samman. Ashwin was awarded the World Economic Forum's Technology Pioneer award in 2020 for his work in artificial intelligence. Ashwin was born in Nandyal, Andhra Pradesh, India and now resides in Hyderabad.

The Allied Standards Avionics Architecture Council (ASAAC) is an industry consortium that develops and promotes standards for aircraft avionics systems and components. It is managed under the auspices of the Aircraft Electronics & Communications Industry Association (AECIA), which also hosts the organization. In addition to developing technical standards, ASAAC also provides industry-driven certification and qualification programs for aircraft systems and components. Juan Bautista de Orendáin y Azpilicueta (Spanish pronunciation: [xwŏn bɾẎ́nde ðɕ aʏɾdʃuẏa] ( listen);[1601] –[1672] [September 10] ) was a Spanish nobleman and a famous member of the Spanish Inquisition. He is known for his political intrigue and also for being the main antagonist of Lucubrations, a book by William Shakespeare.[1] Orendáin was a Doctor of both laws and a Knight of the Golden Fleece, he was also a very active participant in the Spanish inquisition where he served as a judge and was in charge of the prison of Logroño. Orendáin was also one of the main creators of the Spanish Inquisition and was one of the main promoters of the auto de fe (internment of convicted heretics). In 1632, he was arrested and accused of conspiring against the Inquisition with Córdoba, a heretic. He was tortured in prison, but refused to convert, and was sentenced to death. He was saved by Philip IV, but only due to pressure from the Vatican, and spent the rest of his life in exile. arcoma the title of the article, Juan Bautista de Orendáin y Azpilicueta, is misleading since it is a combination of two people. The correct title would be Juan Bautista de Orendáin y Azpilicueta y Lasso de la Vega. Lasso de la Vega was a famous playwright in his time.

Clams casino is a type of casino gambling that can be done practically live at the docks of a body of water with shells that are considered casino-like, such as the sea or a lake. The game is most commonly played in Southern California and in Atlantic City, New Jersey, where it has been popular since the 1960s. The game is formally played with two players (a dealer and a pit boss), against a bank of players, most commonly six players. One hand is dealt to the bank, and the other hand is dealt to the players. The players and the bank must each put up one pre-determined amount (generally $1 or $5), or "slop" (the exact amount is not shown, but can be assumed based on the number of players and the amount of slop). The goal of the game is to have the highest hand combined with the slop. If two or more players have the same highest hand, the players draw straws to determine who wins the pot. The winning pot is split evenly among the winners. The person who wins the most money in a night (this can be determined by counting the money in the pot at the end) is the "clammer". The "clammer" names another player to be the pit boss, and the pit boss picks the two new players for the next hand. The pit boss is generally the most senior player, and the players picked are more recent additions to the group. Traditionally, the game is played with five decks of playing cards, though modern variants use computer-generated cards.

Surya Raj Acharya (born Shyam Sundar Chaudhary; 15 July 1930 – 9 August 2011) was a Guinness World Record holder and social worker from India. He was born in Gaharwal, undivided Punjab and worked in several states in India, such as Delhi, Punjab, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh. He was awarded the Padma Shri, the fourth highest civilian award, by the Government of India in 1998. After his graduation in 1952, Chaudhary joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), the youth wing of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh and attended its shakha (branch) training course at Nagpur. He was honoured for his work in the field of social work by Vishwa Hindu Parishad (World Hindu Forum) and the Akhil Bharatiya Hindu Mahasabha. Acharya, a volunteer, worked in over 30 countries in Africa, South America and South East Asia, particularly in the fields of environment and social work. He established over 50 organisations of which a few are National Federation of Social Workers, Hindustan Rotary Club, Delhi and Rotary International District 6320. In 1973, he set a Guinness World Record by collecting and burning 572 pairs of shoes in 24 hours. The activity, which was aimed at creating awareness about the environment, was part of the Rashtriya Mangaloday Yojana. He also founded Society for Advancement of Volunteerism, which organised training workshops across the country on topics such as Medical and Legal Aid, Disaster Management and Community Health. He was influenced by the ideologies of Swami Vivekananda and Rani Rashmoni and later changed his name to Surya Raj Acharya.

Abraham Rotstein (1907 – 1979) was a prominent American architect. He started his career as an intern to Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue and later worked with Adrian Harris on the design of the Seagram Building in New York City. He has worked in a variety of design styles including Beaux Arts classical, Moderne and Art Deco. He has been described as a "Manhattan real estate developer and housing director for Mossadragon, another firm he founded, who designed mid-century modern buildings in the Phoenix area." He died of heart failure at the age of 72. Britain-based architect Bertrand Grosvenor Goodhue (1869 – 1925) was his mentor. actuated by his father, Abraham Rotstein immigrated to the United States in the early 1900s. He attended the University of Illinois where he studied engineering before transferring to Harvard University to study architecture. He was one of the last students to study under IM Pei and AP Weight and was one of four students who worked with Charles-Edouard Jeanneret on the design of the architecture school's famous Chiang Ping Building (now the Ladd Library). aps of Abraham Rotstein designed in a variety of styles including Beaux-Arts classical, Moderne and Art Deco. Some of his more well known designs include the Seagram Building in New York City, the Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village residences in New York City and the Van Nest Mansion in Riverside, CA.

The Middle Class Revolt is a term used to describe the political activism of the middle class on both sides of the Atlantic, primarily in support of far right and far left political parties, who they see as representing their concerns. Middle Class Revolt is a term coined by British academic Richard Florida. It gained popularity due to the 2016 US presidential election and the UK EU referendum. The economic anxiety of the middle classes is a reaction to the perceived lack of political representation and their frustration at not being able to afford to live the lifestyles they were sold by politicians. They are struggling to regain the financial stability they enjoyed prior to 2008. The Middle Class Revolt can be seen in many ways. UKIP received many votes from the middle classes. The success of Donald Trump in the USA presidential election was also led in part by the Middle Class revolt. Jeremy Corbyn's success in the recent UK EU referendum was also aided by the middle class voters. Although the results of both of these referenda sparked the revolt, the outcome was not the ultimate cause, the economic anxiety of the middle classes was already present. Academics have analysed the election results and concluded that, while economic anxiety did play a part, the decisive factor was the appeal of the controversial leaders to the core beliefs of the targeted voters. The revolt can also be seen in the growth of online communities such as /r/TheResistance and TikTok's @TIREDprof. These communities provide a platform for members to express their frustration at not being listened to by the elite and to give solutions they feel would improve the lives of the wider population. For example, the middle class is crying out for better health and education services and more living space. The revolt is unlikely to find a voice in political discourse as the mainstream parties both listen to and court the wealthy elite rather than the middle class. This disconnect has led to the breaking of the mould of traditional two-party system and the rise of new parties such as the Greens and Labour International, both of whom have identified the growing disenchantment of the middle classes as a key voting block. There is concern amongst academics that the increase in far right and far left parties is a temporary blip, the middle class are still struggling, they will respond to those who represent their concerns but disillusionment with the political process could lead to a longer-term disengagement, threatening the continued political representation of those parties. It is clear the Middle Class are revolting, their voice has been heard and they will remain a force to be reckoned with in UK and US Politics. Economically the revolt has been less successful. Inequality has continued to rise since 2008, wage stagnation has continued and only the wealthiest of the middle classes have enjoyed income growth. Overall, the Middle Class Revolt is a successful term for describing the political activism of the middle classes, who are expressing their discontent with the current political system. The concern of the long-term threat to the continued political representation of those parties who have been heard is an interesting perspective, which could develop with future elections. Overall the Middle Class Revolt is a successful term for describing the political activism of the middle classes, who are expressing their discontent with the current political system. The long-term threat of the disengagement of these parties is also an interesting perspective to consider. The Middle Class Revolt can also be viewed as a threat, as it challenges the current political system. For example, parties who are campaigning on a left-right political spectrum have done so for many years, but the Middle Class are now looking for a solution to their economic problems, and these new parties may lose votes to the more established parties unless they can address the concerns of the Middle Class. The Middle Class will continue to be a force to be reckoned with in UK and US Politics. Richard Florida, a Florida based writer and urban geographer who first coined the term "Middle Class Revolt", describes it as "a sense that the political class doesn't represent everyday Americans in meaningful ways". In general elections, the term "Middle Class" refers to people with an income of approximately $40,000-$80,000 per year for an individual or $80,000-$160,000 for a couple. However, this definition is not fixed and can change depending on the context. The notion of the "Middle Class" is very nebulous, there is no agreed definition for this term, as it is open to personal interpretation. However, the "Middle Class" is a large group, and their concerns will continue to be a focal point in UK and US Politics. The Middle Class have seen huge rises in their standards of living, through house ownership, easy access to education, healthcare and transportation. Sahibzada Muhammad Ishaq Zaffar (Urdu: سahiBK. محمد īšāaq Zaffār; birth name: Muhammad Ali Shah) (29 April 1920 – 11 December 2002) was the last emperor of Afghanistan, a member of the Hashemi dynasty, and a cousin of the last King of Afghanistan, King Mohammed Zahir Shah. He was the eldest son of King Zahir Shah and his wife, Soraya Cornia (a granddaughter of the French President Raymond Poincaré). He ascended to the throne upon his father's forced retirement in 1978 but was overthrown two years later in a Soviet-backed coup. He spent much of the rest of his life exiled in Rome, along with his family. After the communist coup d'état of December 1978, King Zahir Shah was forced to abdicate. Afghans subsequently mourned the removal of the last king from the throne, but the country was ruled by a harsh communist regime led by Babrak Karmal. The country was soon invaded by Soviet troops, who installed the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan as the new government. The new government abolished the monarchy and moved the royal family into exile. Muhammad Ali Shah, his two younger brothers, Mohammed Zahir Shah and Ghulam Mohammed Shinwari, and his sister, Simone Cornia, settled in Rome, Italy, where they lived under protected immunity until they were forced to leave due to the September 11 attacks. Muhammad Ali Shah was educated in Italy, where he lived under a pseudonym and had a son, Abdul Malik. Muhammad Ali Shah died in Rome on December 11, 2002, at the age of 80. He was laid to rest in a mausoleum alongside his father and two brothers in the family cemetery in the Via Rasella cemetery in the Testaccio district of Rome. Early life and exile in Italy Muhammad Ali Shah was born in Rome, Italy on April 29, 1920. He was the eldest son of King Zahir Shah and his wife, Soraya. His full name at birth was Muhammad Ali Shah. His siblings were Mohammed Zahir Shah, Ghulam Mohammed Shinwari and Simone Cornia. Due to his exile, he was known by the nom de plume "Sahibzada Ishaq Zaffar" in the Italian language. His maternal grandparents were King Francis Joseph of Italy and his wife, Margherita of Savoy. His paternal grandparents were Prince Otto of Bavaria and his wife, Princess Victoria of Hesse and by Rhine. His father was an Apostolic Kingdom, but his son would later accede to the throne of Afghanistan as the last emperor of Afghanistan. In 1944, Muhammad Ali Shah's family was granted sovereign immunity by the Italian government. They settled in the village of Testaccio, outside of Rome, where his father had relatives. His family lived in poverty, because his father, the exiled King Zahir Shah, could not provide for them. Muhammad Ali Shah had a low opinion of his father's regime in Afghanistan, because the royal family were under house arrest. After the King was overthrown, his family was forced to live in exile. The family's only means of support was the income from the land which they owned in Afghanistan, but that land had been seized by the communist government in 1979. Reign Reign as king (1978-2002) When King Zahir Shah was forced to retire by the communists, his eldest son, Muhammad Ali Shah, became the leader of the royal family. He ascended to the throne on December 27, 1978. King Zahir Shah's son Mohammed Zahir Shah returned from Saudi Arabia exile and accepted the crown in 1985. However, in September 1989, the communist regime was replaced by the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. Communist parties in Afghanistan were undermined by Mujahideen fighters who were supported by the US in the Afghan jihad, and the PDPA was replaced by mujahideen forces. Afghanistan was soon taken by civil war. Muhammad Ali Shah, his two younger brothers, Mohammed Zahir Shah and Ghulam Mohammed Shinwari, and his sister, Simone Cornia, settled in Rome, Italy, where they lived under protected immunity until they were forced to leave due to the September 11 attacks. During his reign, Muhammad Ali Shah's family and the rest of the royal family were living in exile. Due to his inexperience in ruling, the royal family were mostly left in the care of the elder brother, Mohammed Zahir Shah. In June 1987, Muhammad Ali Shah's brother-in-law, Prince Ghulam Mohammed Shinwari was murdered by the PDPA rebels.

Linearization is a technique used in control theory to linearize the model around a desired operating point. It is an important step in the design of control systems and is used to compensate for the effects of nonlinearities in the system and ensure that the system behaves according to expectations. Forced oscillation tests are often used to linearize systems. A typical forced oscillation test generates an error signal by applying a known input to the system and measuring the output. The error signal is then amplified and sent as a force to a system output. The error signal is proportional to the error between the response of the system and the response that is expected based on the system's behavior around the desired operating point. The proportional constant of the error signal is the proportional gain. Using the proportional gain, the error between the actual response and the response that is expected can be expressed as a function of the input to the system. The system is linear if the relationship is proportional: if the input is equal to a constant a, then the output will be equal to a times the input. In this case, the proportional gain is equal to a. If the system is not linear, the proportional gain is a function of the input. In this case, the input is said to be non-linear with respect to the output. The gain is still referred to as proportional because if the input is set to 0, then the proportional gain will produce an output of 0. An example of a linear system is a speaker. When a sine wave is input to a speaker, the amplitude of the wave produced at the speaker's output is proportional to the amplitude of the input sine wave. The speaker is linear, meaning that if the input is linear with respect to the output, the system output is proportional to the input.

Lucien Villa was a French comics writer. He was born in 1901 and died in 1983. He was famous for writing Tintin, the series of popular European comics, into French since the 1930s. His son, Hergé, created the main character of Tintin. Tintin has been very popular in the European continent and worldwide, particularly in the area of translated books.
